CL empirical fits using inverse power law are also offered. One regular PP type lost capacitance through self-healing, with the film exhibiting clearings’ pockmarks; the films of the other two types did not have the same pattern. The HT film was partially fused; the film of the other regular PP type that lost more than 10% of capacitance was largely indistinguishable from a fresh film, except for receding metallization edges. The edge recession, as evidenced by microphotography, caused by electrochemical corrosion, is responsible for CL.

title: A MQTT-Based Infrastructure to Support COIL Activities Through Real Remote Labs
authors: Hélio Sousa Mendonça, José Carlos Alves
abstract: This demo shows an infrastructure that allows for easy implementation of real remote labs. In this infrastructure, several nodes are remotely interconnected by publishing/subscribing MQTT messages. There are physical nodes ca-pable of connecting to real circuits and/or sensors/actuators, and virtual nodes that implement simulated versions of circuits that interact remotely with signals from other nodes. The latencies that occur are low enough for groups of students located in different physical locations to benefit from a near realtime experience in interacting with the circuits thus implemented.

title: Client Side Experimenting with uDAQ28/LT
authors: Katarína Žáková, Jakub Lengvarský, Jakub Matišák
abstract: This paper presents an approach to experimental work in control engineering designed for easily portable and small-sized laboratory devices. The Web Serial API allows web applications to directly communicate with serial devices via the browser, expanding possibilities for hardware interaction. Leveraging this technology, we have developed an application for controlling the presented system.

title: Real-Time Resilient Traffic Prediction for LEO Access Networks via Adjacent Satellite Collaboration
authors: Quan Chen, Lizeng Gong, Lei Yang, Yi Wang, Kanglian Zhao, Wen Yao
abstract: Emerging Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite networks, represented by Starlink, have developed a rapidly growing user base and increasing network traffic. Accurate and reliable satellite traffic prediction is essential for optimizing network performance and resource management. However, the high-speed motion of satellites and the uneven geographic distribution of users pose significant challenges to satellite network traffic prediction. Yet, empowered by Artificial Intelligence (AI) and inter-satellite links (ISLs), new opportunities arise. This article proposes a Real-time Resilient Traffic Prediction (RRTP) framework via adjacent satellite collaboration. Unlike existing methods that rely solely on historical data and delayed ground updates, by exchanging real-time traffic data, the onboard collaborative prediction learns the spatiotemporal traffic correlations among adjacent satellites, updates the parameters of the neural network models, and timely corrects the predicted traffic volume. The base model can be pre-trained on the ground and uploaded to satellites to save computations. Since RRTP requires neither global nor continuous long-term data exchange, RRTP enhances resilience to abrupt traffic changes and unexpected events, such as link/satellite failures. The overhead, cost, and applicability of RRTP are further discussed and validated through comparative simulations of a series of mega-constellation case studies.

title: Manifold Subspace Projection-Based MIG Detectors in Sample-Starved Clutter
authors: Jiayi Chen, Xiaoqiang Hua, Yongqiang Cheng, Hao Wu, Hongqiang Wang, Kang Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a class of manifold subspace projection (MSP)-based matrix information geometry (MIG) detectors to deal with the challenge of detecting targets in samplestarved clutter. In accordance with common practice, the sample data can be modeled using Hermitian positive-definite (HPD) matrices, while the clutter covariance matrix is estimated as the geometric mean of the secondary HPD matrices. We define a projection that maps the HPD matrices to a submanifold with reduced clutter, aiming to increase the degree of separation of targets and clutter. Three MSP-MIG detectors corresponding to different geometric measures are proposed. Experimental results confirm the advantage of the MSP-MIG detectors compared with the conventional detectors as well as their counterparts without using MSP in sample-starved clutter.

title: HLIF: A History-Aware Model Boosting Neuronal Heterogeneity in SNNs
authors: Fan Luo, Yanfeng Lu, Zeyu Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) offer biological plausibility and energy efficiency, but conventional Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) neurons with shared parameters limit adaptability and diversity. We propose a history-aware LIF (HLIF) model that adaptively adjusts firing thresholds based on spiking history, enhancing intra-layer heterogeneity. This adaptable threshold modulation is a general mechanism that can be integrated with various trainable neuron models. Experiments show that HLIF achieves 95.17 % on CIFAR-10, 77.70 % on CIFAR100, and 68.20 % top-1 accuracy on ImageNet, demonstrating competitive results within state-of-the-art SNN frameworks.

title: A Distributed Brute-Force Attack and Misleading Countermeasure for Securing ModbusTCP Implementations in PLCs
authors: Mohammd Abdul Jawad, Mohammad Z. Masoud, Álvaro Álesanco, José García
abstract: this paper demonstrates a brute-force attack on password based ModbusTCP implementations in PLCs and HMIs using a swarm of 20 microcontrollers. To counter this attack, a misleading LADDER-based algorithm that misleads attackers with false register values and randomized passwords is proposed. To evaluate the attack and the proposed protocol, two attack scenarios and two password lengths have been leveraged on a PLC in a LAN environment. Results show that the misleading protocol causes each attacker to receive different passwords and data, disrupting brute-force attempts while enabling attacker identification. When tested with one thread and 20 Arduino kits, each kit found a different password and received different data when reading PLC registers. This approach not only prevents unauthorized access but also allows administrators to track attackers' IP addresses, highlighting the effectiveness of deception-based defenses in industrial security.

title: Boosting Brain Tumor Classification with Attention-Enhanced Xception Architecture
authors: Soumyarashmi Panigrahi, Dibya Ranjan Das Adhikary, Binod Kumar Pattanayak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Our study investigates the impact of attention mechanisms on the performance of pre-trained Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) in classifying brain Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) images. Attention mechanisms are designed to dynamically emphasize relevant input data regions, enhancing feature extraction and boosting model performance. We explore the efficacy of integrating attention mechanisms into established pre-trained CNN architectures, specifically Xception and VGG19, using the publicly available "Br35H: Brain Tumor Detection 2020" dataset. Our comprehensive evaluation employs a range of metrics, including accuracy, Jaccard index, precision, recall, specificity, F1-Score, and F2-Score. The results highlight the significance of attention mechanisms in improving the analysis of medical images, particularly in brain tumor classification using MRI scans. Our study provides valuable insights for developing more accurate and efficient deep learning-based diagnostic tools by elucidating the influence of attention mechanism selection on pre-trained model performance.

title: Leveraging Blockchain for Secure Mobile Payment Systems: A Privacy Centric Approach
authors: Vinayak Musale, Poonam Bhosale, Sumegh Tharewal, Madhuri Rao, Ojas Ninawe, Amruta Amune
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Mobile payment systems have transformed financial transactions with unprecedented ease and accessibility. But the explosion in their numbers has been met with increasing security threats and issues of privacy. This paper puts forward a new blockchain-based paradigm for mobile payment systems that prioritizes privacy but retains high-security standards. This design leverages the essential capabilities of blockchain technology like decentralization, immutability, and cryptographic protection. It incorporates advanced privacy-protecting techniques such as zero-knowledge proofs and homomorphic encryption. The system design intended here is to mitigate common vulnerabilities present in centralized systems, reduce the risk of data breaches, and provide users with more control over their financial data. By comparative analysis and simulations, we show that our privacy-oriented blockchain solution strongly improves transaction security, minimizes fraud, and maintains user anonymity without sacrificing system performance or compliance with regulations. This work is a contribution to the ongoing work on developing more secure and privacy-aware financial technologies in a rapidly digitalizing economy.

authors: Kristina Höök, Jonas Löwgren, Anna Ståhl

title: Is Deciphering Cell Types in Complex Tissues the Next Frontier for Protein Language Models?
authors: Haohuai He, Zhi-An Huang, Jibin Wu, Kay Chen Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Spatial proteomics allows for the analysis of protein expression within tissue contexts. While cellular expression and spatial location are commonly utilized, the properties of protein markers can offer additional valuable information. Therefore, we propose a deep learning framework that utilizes embeddings from the ESM2 protein language model to incorporate prior biological knowledge of protein markers. Our framework integrates these marker priors with single-cell expression and spatial information through a cross-attention mechanism to generate informative cell representations. We demonstrate that this integration significantly improves cell type annotation performance across multiple spatial proteomics datasets, highlighting the value of leveraging PLM-derived marker knowledge.

title: Meta Learning Technique for Few-Shot Image Recognition
authors: Abhishek Kumar, Ravi Kumar Burman, Jyoti Kumari, Anurag Sinha, Binod Kumar, Shrikant Upadhyay
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Few-shot learning (FSL) enables models to perform well with limited labeled data, overcoming traditional ML limitations. This paper compares key meta-learning methods-MAML, Prototypical Networks, Matching Networks, Siamese Networks, and Relation Networks-each tackling FSL through either optimization-based or metric-based approaches. Evaluation metrics include Accuracy, Precision, Recall, and F1-Score on the CIFAR-FS dataset. Relation Network outperforms others in generalization and adaptability with minimal data. MAML adapts quickly but lacks computational efficiency. The study provides insights into the strengths, weaknesses, and ideal use cases of each method, offering direction for future performance enhancements in real-world applications.

title: Time-Domain Modeling and Power Decoupling of the Cross-Coupled Active Power Flow in a Multi Active Bridge (MAB) Converter
authors: Ayooluwa Ajiboye, Chanaka Singhabahu, Benjamin Shani, Hassan Habib Chaudhry, Alireza Khaligh
abstract: The principal component within the multi active bridge (MAB) topology is the high-frequency magnetic link (HFML) interconnecting multiple ports, thereby facilitating multidirectional power flow. However, a byproduct of this unifying AC magnetic link is the cross-coupled power flow induced by the inter-port phase shifts, subsequently preventing independent port-wise operation. Therefore, this work presents a time-domain analytical framework for the accurate estimation of the cross-coupled active power flow by applying a superposition-based approach to the MAB port-equivalent models. These port-equivalent models are derived from the full-order <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$n \times n$</tex-math></inline-formula> inductance matrix (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {L}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-matrix) extracted from an asymmetric integrated-leakage HFML via a single-port impedance measurement scheme. Furthermore, a control-integrated power decoupling (IPD) feedforward compensator is developed to suppress undesirable propagative voltage fluctuations during transient power flows, thereby ensuring port-wise decoupling of the converter. Steady-state experiments conducted on a 3.2 kW SiC-based four-port MAB prototype are used to validate the accuracy of the proposed time-domain model with respect to the terminal active powers. Whereas transient experiments with output-voltage step-changes are used to verify the improved decoupling performance of the proposed full-order <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {L}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-matrix IPD scheme, in comparison with an uncompensated PI (Proportional-Integral) controller, and the existing <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$Y$</tex-math></inline-formula>-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\Delta$</tex-math></inline-formula> (star-delta) decoupling method.

title: Secure Sum-Rate Optimization in RIS-Assisted RSMA HAP Systems With Untrusted Users
authors: Zain Ali, Saud Althunibat, Mazen Omar Hasna, Khalid Qaraqe
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) leveraging high-altitude platforms (HAPs) are pivotal for bridging coverage gaps in remote regions and ensuring service continuity when terrestrial infrastructure fails (e.g., during disasters) or becomes congested (e.g., mass events). While integrating rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) and reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) enhances spectral efficiency, securing transmissions against unknown eavesdroppers with imperfect channel state information (CSI) remains a critical challenge. We propose a secure multi-user, multi-cluster RIS-assisted RSMA system for HAPs, jointly optimizing precoding, RIS beamforming, and cluster time allocation to maximize sum-rate under secrecy rate constraints. The non-convex problem is transformed into a tractable semidefinite program (SDP) via successive convex approximation, auxiliary variable bounding, and a rank-1 penalty method. Simulations demonstrate significant performance gains over benchmarks, robustness to practical RIS phase quantization, and scalability across varying numbers of users per cluster, validating the framework's efficacy.

title: Manufacturer-Oriented Risk Assessment of Imaging Systems with Multi-Criteria Decision Making and Machine Learning
authors: Kholoud E. Nassar, Ahmed M. Salaheldin, Manal Abdel Wahed, Neven Saleh
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: This study presents a hybrid Multi-Criteria Decision Making (MCDM) and Machine Learning (ML) framework designed to support operational decisions related to the upgrade or replacement of medical imaging systems. Focusing on Computed Tomography (CT) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) units installed across healthcare facilities in Egypt, the research offers a novel contribution by analyzing equipment lifecycle management from the manufacturer's perspective, rather than that of the healthcare provider. A real-world dataset from Siemens Healthineers was used, incorporating six performance indicators such as system age, utilization rate, and downtime. Two sets of weights were applied-objective CRiteria Importance Through Intercriteria Correlation (CRITIC) and expert-based (Service Marketing Head)-within the Evaluation based on Distance from Average Solution (EDAS) method to generate replacement prioritization rankings. Furthermore, four supervised ML algorithms were trained to classify systems into three lifecycle stages. This hybrid approach demonstrated a classification accuracy of up to 96.5 % in identifying these classes. Results highlight the value of integrating domain expertise and data-driven techniques for supporting lifecycle planning, installed base retention, and service strategy development in the medical imaging industry.

title: Transformer-Based Fusion of Time-Domain and Time-Frequency Features for Robust Radar Jamming Recognition
authors: Yaobo Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The escalating sophistication of electronic warfare technologies underscores the critical and challenging need for accurate radar jamming recognition in highly dynamic electromagnetic environments, which is pivotal for precise target tracking. While contemporary deep learning-based jamming recognition methods predominantly leverage time-frequency (TF) maps derived from Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) as primary features, this transformation inherently discards crucial fast transient information from the original time-domain signals. To address this limitation, we propose a novel time-frequency multi-representation jamming recognition algorithm. This algorithm synergistically integrates fine-grained time-domain features with the signal energy distribution from TF representations, thereby substantially enhancing recognition accuracy within intricate deceptive jamming scenarios. Furthermore, to capture global contextual dependencies often missed by local operations, a Transformer-based prediction framework is employed. This leverages its intrinsic self-attention mechanism, enhancing the model’s ability to discern complex patterns and thereby bolstering overall recognition robustness. Comprehensive experimental evaluations across diverse simulated complex deceptive jamming environments demonstrate that the proposed algorithm consistently achieves a recognition accuracy surpassing 99%, unequivocally validating its superior performance and practical efficacy.

title: Penetration Testing of a Merchant Payment Platform; Systemic Vulnerabilities and Compliance-Centric Mitigation
authors: Ahmad H. Al-Omari
abstract: Merchant Payment Platform (MPPs) are vital systems in today’s financial world, handling payments, transactions, and customer support all in one place. However, their complexity, especially when serving multiple businesses on the same platform makes them a magnet for cyberattacks. In this study, we rigorously tested an MPP and uncovered eleven exploitable weaknesses, including critical flaws like price manipulation, unauthorized access to sensitive data, and tampered transactions. Using a mix of automated tools (like Nessus and Burp Suite) and hands-on hacking techniques, we identified these issues while aligning our work with top security standards such as the OWASP Top 10 2023 and PCI DSS v4.0. Our findings highlight how vulnerabilities in one part of the system can cascade into others, emphasize the importance of compliance with regulations like General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS), and offer practical fixes, such as tightening access controls, validating data server-side, and embedding security into development processes to help businesses safeguard these critical platforms against evolving threats

title: Sentiment Analysis of Hazardous Events and Disasters
authors: Pranav Daga, Siddhesh Dumre, Madhuri Rao, Kulamala Vinod Kumar, Sumegh Tharewal, Dhanajay Bhagat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This research addresses the critical need to understand the emotional and psychological impact of hazardous events and disasters by applying sentiment analysis to social media and textual data, specifically focusing on Twitter. Traditional disaster assessment often lacks insight into public sentiment, a vital factor for effective response and recovery. This paper explores the application of natural language processing (NLP) techniques to analyze public discourse on Twitter before, during, and after major disasters. The primary objective is to develop a robust sentiment analysis framework capable of accurately assessing and interpreting public sentiment using advanced NLP methods tailored for the characteristics of Twitter. This includes addressing challenges such as the real-time analysis requirements of Twitter’s rapid, short-form posting style, the noisy and ambiguous nature of tweet data, and the need to capture evolving public reactions as events unfold. By identifying sentiment trends and patterns on Twitter, this research aims to provide timely and actionable insights for disaster management agencies, policymakers, and humanitarian organizations to enhance disaster preparedness, response strategies, and communication efforts. This approach seeks to leverage the immediate feedback provided by Twitter to complement traditional disaster assessment methods, incorporating the crucial dimension of public emotional well-being during crises. The work presented here provides and interesting rationale that combines public sentiment with machine learning techniques for effectively handling disaster response.

title: Securing Smart Supply Chains with Adaptive AI Agents: A Virtual Simulation Framework
authors: Haidar Jabbar, Samir Al-Janabi
abstract: The increasing complexity of modern supply chains necessitates advanced, adaptive cybersecurity solutions. This paper proposes a multi-layered defense framework leveraging Artificial Intelligence (AI) agents, combining Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) for sensory anomaly detection, Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) for network-level threat identification, and Reinforcement Learning (RL) for autonomous threat mitigation. A collaborative agent architecture is introduced to enhance detection accuracy, threat correlation, and adaptive response effectiveness across distributed supply chain systems. The framework is evaluated using a Python-based NS-3 simulation with synthetic traffic, achieving 94% detection accuracy while maintaining low false positive rates. While synthetic data validates the initial design, future work will extend evaluation to real-world cloud environments and address explainability challenges. This integrated approach offers a scalable and resilient model for securing smart supply chains against evolving cyber threats.

title: A Comprehensive Exploration of Machine Learning Models for Banknote Authentication
authors: Amiya Ranjan Panda, Janbhi Tripathy, Priti Mohan Pattanayak, Manoj Kumar Mishra, Mahendra Kumar Gourisaria, Junali Jasmine Jena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Banknotes are legally issued instruments that represent monetary value and are sanctioned by governmental authorities. However, their high value and widespread use have made them a frequent target for counterfeiting. Due to the striking similarity between genuine and counterfeit notes, accurately distinguishing between the two poses a considerable challenge. This study aims to evaluate the performance of various machine learning models using the Banknote Authentication dataset, with the objective of identifying the most effective model for classifying banknotes as genuine or counterfeit. The models employed include Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machine, Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbor, XGBoost Classifier, and Naive Bayes. Model robustness was validated using a Train-Test split methodology, with accuracy serving as the primary evaluation metric. Among the models tested, the XGBoost Classifier demonstrated the highest accuracy of 99.7273%, followed by K-Nearest Neighbor, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, Logistic Regression, and Naive Bayes. The findings of this research provide valuable insights that may inform the development of more accurate and reliable predictive systems for banknote authentication.

title: Detecting GAN-Generated Fake Images Using Deep Learning and Feature Analysis
authors: Sudip Sao, Mohit Ranjan Panda, Tanmay Singh, Subham Singh, Sohalia Sana, Shrestha Saha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The dissemination of extremely realistic deep-fake images created by Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) is a serious threat to the integrity of digital information in a number of critical fields. The forged images, normally indistinguishable from real ones for the human eye, compromise security systems, media credibility, and the reliability of digital proof for forensics. To address the increasing demand for effective detection, this work presents a new approach that synergistically combines deep learning strategies with advanced feature analysis. The proposed approach is particularly designed for detecting the subtle artifacts and statistical anomalies inherent in the generation process of the GANs. The proposed approach is anticipated to obtain state of-the-art detection performance and improved generalizability across a large number of GAN architectures compared with the current detection strategies. The outcome of this work will be of great significance for the ongoing endeavors toward limiting the detrimental impact of fake images on security, media integrity, and the reliability of digital proof.

title: Generalization Error Analysis for Attack-Free and Byzantine-Resilient Decentralized Learning with Data Heterogeneity_supp1-3657395.pdf
authors: Qing Ling
abstract: Decentralized learning, which facilitates joint model training across geographically scattered agents, has gained significant attention in the field of signal and information processing in recent years. While the optimization errors of decentralized learning algorithms have been extensively studied, their generalization errors remain relatively under-explored. As the generalization error reflects the scalability of a trained model on unseen data and are crucial in determining the performance of a trained model in real-world applications, understanding the generalization error of decentralized learning is of paramount importance. In this paper, we present fine-grained generalization error analysis for both attack-free and Byzantine-resilient decentralized learning with heterogeneous data as well as under mild assumptions, in contrast to prior studies that consider homogeneous data and/or rely on a stringent bounded stochastic gradient assumption. Our results shed light on the impact of data heterogeneity, model initialization and stochastic gradient noise – factors that have not been closely investigated before – on the generalization error of decentralized learning. We also reveal that Byzantine attacks performed by malicious agents largely affect the generalization error, and their negative impact is inherently linked to the data heterogeneity while remaining independent on the sample size. Numerical experiments on both strongly convex and non-convex tasks are conducted to validate our theoretical findings.

title: Exploiting CRUSAP: An Adversarial Security Evaluation of a Lightweight RFID Protocol
authors: Aiman Malik, Amna Amjid, Madiha Khalid
abstract: Ultra-lightweight authentication protocols are essential for resource-constrained environments such as RFID systems, where conventional cryptographic methods are impractical. The Cloud-based RFID Ultra-Lightweight Secure Authentication Protocol (CRUSAP) employs Bitwise Crossover rearrangement and Rotation-based primitives to achieve secure communication. This paper presents a comprehensive cryptanalytic evaluation, demonstrating that CRUSAP's reversible operations and deterministic design render it vulnerable to practical attacks. Full Disclosure, Desynchronization, and Time-Memory Trade-Off (TMTO) attacks compromise session secrecy and entity authenticity. Experimental analysis shows that 8-bit temporary identifiers (TIDS) are fully recoverable, while 96-bit TIDS can be partially recovered (60%) due to statistical leakage via a Full Disclosure attack. Time-Memory Trade-Off (TMTO) and Desynchronization attacks further allow the extraction of session keys and nonces. Although attacks on larger key sizes may demand significant computational resources, including GPUs and extensive memory, the protocol remains fundamentally vulnerable due to inherent structural weaknesses. Even with dynamic key updates, CRUSAP lacks adequate entropy isolation and structural robustness, highlighting the need for irreversible primitives, protocol redesign, or stronger lightweight authentication schemes.

title:
A 0.018-mm

                    0.05-2 GHz Balun-LNA With Post-Linearization and Balanced Loads Achieving 33.5-dBm OIP3 and 3.7-dB NF
authors: Sinyoung Kim, Donggu Lee, Sukju Yun, Kuduck Kwon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
abstract: In this article, a 0.05–2 GHz broadband balun-low-noise amplifier (LNA) achieving high linearity and balanced output loading using a post-linearization current-bleeding (CBLD) technique is presented. The proposed architecture is based on a conventional common-gate (CG) and common-source (CS) balun-LNA topology, in which the CBLD path simultaneously provides symmetric loads and performs post-distortion (PD) linearization without any auxiliary stage or additional current consumption. This dual-function implementation enables significant third-order linearity improvement over a wide frequency range while maintaining low noise and stable input matching. Fabricated in a 28-nm CMOS process, the proposed balun-LNA achieves a noise figure of 3.7–4.1 dB, a maximum voltage gain of 20 dB, and an input return loss (S₁₁) better than −10 dB across a 3-dB bandwidth of 2 GHz. The measured IIP3 ranges from 9.8 dBm to 13.5 dBm, corresponding to a peak OIP3 of 33.5 dBm. The LNA consumes 10.2 mA from a 1.2-V supply and occupies an active area of only 0.018 mm².

title: E-mode P-GaN/AlGaN/GaN HEMT with Diode-Engineered Gate Configuration for Extended Gate Voltage Swing
authors: Jun-Hyeok Yim, Myeongsu Chae, Hyungtak Kim, Ho-Young Cha
abstract: A novel enhancement-mode (E-mode) p-GaN/AlGaN/GaN high-electron-mobility transistor (HEMT) featuring a diode-engineered gate configuration was developed to extend the gate voltage swing range. In the proposed design, a small diode is monolithically integrated in series to the p-GaN gate, introducing an additional forward voltage drop to the threshold voltage of the HEMT. This approach significantly increases both the threshold voltage and the maximum allowable gate voltage swing compared to conventional p-GaN gate HEMTs, which typically exhibit low threshold voltages and limited gate swing ranges. The device employs a standard heterostructure, and the compact size of the embedded diode ensures that the increase in chip area is negligible.

title: A Two-Board Design for Interconnected Intelligence in Tiny IoT
authors: Nil Llisterri Giménez, Felix Freitag, Leandro Navarro, Mennan Selimi
abstract: Machine learning is nowadays used in tiny micro-controller boards, sometimes called TinyML. At the same time, LoRa Internet of Things (IoT) communication technology can now provide LoRa mesh network topologies that interconnect remote IoT devices. Both tendencies, however, have not converged yet to combine the potential of both. In this paper, we argue for a solution consisting of a two-board design as an architecture for interconnected ML-enabled IoT nodes in a LoRa mesh network. A prototype of the architecture using the TTGO LoRa32 board as a network device and the Arduino Portenta H7 as an application device is implemented as a case study to show the feasibility. We analyze a federated learning protocol design to illustrate how distributed applications can interact within the proposed two-board node architecture. We position the architecture with regard to several performance aspects and observe that the design delivers a separation of concerns by one board hosting the ML-application and the other providing an advanced network service to the application.

title: Treating the Filter Weights as Learnable Functions: An Efficient Nonlinear Filtering Framework and Its Adaptive Algorithms
authors: Mingjing Cui, Dongyuan Lin, Lei Li, Yunfei Zheng, Shiyuan Wang
abstract: Adaptive filters, constrained by a linear filtering framework, often struggle with nonlinear modeling in complex processes. Kernel adaptive filters (KAFs) offer a promising solution by mapping input signals into diverse feature spaces. However, their computational efficiency and filtering accuracy may still not meet the demands of practical applications. To this end, based on Kolmogorov-Arnold (KA) representation theorem, this paper proposes a novel nonlinear filtering framework by treating filter weights as learnable functions. Specifically, the learnable functions are represented as a linear combination of multiple Gaussian basis functions with different centers. To determine the coefficients that define these learnable functions, the weight-learning-based least mean square (WL-LMS) and weight-learning-based recursive least squares (WL-RLS) algorithms are further proposed based on minimum mean square error (MMSE). In addition, to ensure convergence and assess the steady-state and transient performance of proposed algorithms, a thorough theoretical analysis of the convergence conditions and excess mean square error (EMSE) is provided. Finally, linear-in-parameters system identifications validate the correctness of theoretical analysis, while chaotic time-series prediction and nonlinear system identifications demonstrate the superiorities of the proposed WL-LMS and WL-RLS algorithms.

title: Effects of sequential dual-target TMS on the dynamic characteristics of brain networks as revealed by fNIRS
authors: Lingling Chen, Yanglong Wang, Congcong Huo, Guangjian Shao, Xingshuo Dong, DongSheng Xu, Zengyong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) modulates cortical excitability to promote neuroplasticity, but single-target TMS has limited effects on multi-region synergy. Sequential dual-target TMS may enhance brain network reorganization through temporal stimulation, though its mechanisms remain unclear. This study investigates the immediate effects of single- and dual-target TMS on brain functional networks in stroke patients using functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) and dynamic functional connectivity (dFNC) analysis. Fifteen subacute stroke patients and fifteen healthy controls underwent three interventions: single-target SMA-rTMS, single-target LDLPFC-rTMS, and sequential dual-target stimulation (Dual-rTMS). fNIRS data were analyzed via dFNC to identify connectivity states (weak, moderate, strong) and evaluate time fraction, state transitions, global efficiency, and total signal power. Results revealed three dFNC states: State 1 (weak connectivity, 44.24%), State 2 (moderate, 39.44%), and State 3 (strong, 16.32%). Single-target TMS (especially SMA-rTMS) increased time fraction in State 1, indicating low-connectivity induction, while Dual-rTMS further prolonged State 1 and reduced inefficient transitions (e.g., State 1→2: p < 0.005). Stroke patients showed impaired transitions from State 2→3 (p = 0.024) versus controls. Time fraction in State 3 correlated positively with motor function scores (FMA-LE: r = 0.52, p = 0.045; BBS: r = 0.52, p = 0.047), while State 1 correlated negatively (FMA-LE: r = -0.52, p = 0.045). Sequential dual-target TMS optimizes network dynamics by sustaining low-energy states and suppressing maladaptive transitions, outperforming single-target approaches. dFNC temporal patterns may serve as biomarkers for post-stroke motor function, supporting sequential dual-target TMS as a promising rehabilitation tool.

title: A Blockchain Based Decentralized Identifiers for Entity Authentication in Electronic Health Records
authors: Gunjan Kumar Chouhan, Shubhangi Singh, Aanya Jaduvansy, Priya Rai, Adyasha Rath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Electronic Health Records (EHRs) are essential in contemporary healthcare as they facilitate the storage and sharing of personal patient data. Traditional cloud-based EHR systems, though, are afflicted with centralized control, privacy threats, restricted interoperability, and susceptibility to data breaches. To alleviate these challenges, this paper suggests a blockchain-based, patient-centered EHR management system that uses Ethereum smart contracts, Decentralized Identifiers (DIDs), and InterPlanetary File System (IPFS) for safe, distributed, and effective handling of health data.The system put forward puts patients at the forefront of EHR access and control, allowing them to grant or withdraw permissions to healthcare providers, insurers, or researchers using fine-grained, attribute-based policies executed through smart contracts. DIDs remove the need for third-party identity providers, providing secure and verifiable user authentication directly on the blockchain. IPFS, on the other hand, provides cost-effective, tamper-proof off-chain storage of medical records, with metadata and access logs stored on-chain to minimize gas usage.Extensive testing on the Ethereum Goerli testnet proves that the system provides greater security, lower storage costs, efficient access control, and better interoperability than conventional models. This method not only solves existing shortcomings in EHR systems but also opens the door to scalable, transparent, and patient-enabled healthcare data management.

title: A Blockchain-Based IoT Framework for Smart Homes: Enhancing Energy Prediction and Security with LSTM and Equilibrium Optimization
authors: Priyanka Pramod Pawar, Deepak Kumar, Santosh Reddy Addula, Qasim Naveed Cheema, Anwar Ul Haq, Mohan Kumar Meesala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This research aims to develop a secure smart home system capable of forecasting energy consumption and user profiles through deep learning techniques and an edge computing strategy utilizing blockchain technology. The proposed system monitors Internet of Things (IoT) devices, such as refrigerators, dishwashers, smart microwaves, and furnaces, leveraging blockchain for enhanced security and transparency. The study highlights the effectiveness of Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural networks—a specialized deep learning approach for time series prediction—in achieving favorable forecasting outcomes. The findings indicate that the optimal window size significantly affects model uncertainty estimates and prediction performance. By employing the Equilibrium Optimization (EO) algorithm for hyperparameter tuning, the study enhances the efficiency of the LSTM model. Overall, the results demonstrate that the LSTM model is effective in accurately predicting the energy requirements of smart homes.

title: A Target Detection Method of Pulse Group Frequency Agile Radar
authors: Yichen Shan, Baoqing Xu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The signals are not correlated in frequency agile radar between different pulse groups, and the signal-to-noise ratio fluctuates seriously, which brings great difficulty for target detection. In view of this, a target detection method of pulse group frequency agile radar is proposed. Firstly, the optimal number of pusle groups and pulse number inside each pulse group are determined by accumulated loss curve of fast-fluctuating signal. Secondly, the matched MTD filters are designed according to the change of the clutter spectrum width of different pulse groups, then pulse compression and MTD are performed for each group. Finally, accumulating the data of the same velocity channel in each pulse group through the mapping relationship between doppler domin and velocity domin, then perform the CFAR detection. Simulation experiments shows that the proposed method has good detection performance and clutter suppression performance, and it has a certain superiority.

title: Research on Obstacle Avoidance Maneuver Decision-Making Technology Based on Safety Reinforcement Learning
authors: Shi Qiu, Zhiyuan Gu, Ziwei Zheng, Shouzhao Sheng
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: This research tackles the critical challenge of maneuver decision-making for obstacle avoidance in high-speed helicopter nap-of-the-earth (NOE) flight by proposing a safetyenhanced Reinforcement Learning (RL) approach. To address the significant limitation of conventional SAC-Lagrangian algorithms, which often impose insufficient penalties for safety constraint violations, we introduce a novel Lyapunov-Barrier Soft Actor-Critic (LB-SAC) algorithm. This method synergistically integrates Lyapunov stability theory with control barrier functions, creating a dual-layer safety assurance mechanism that explicitly enforces stability constraints and hard safety boundaries during policy optimization. Extensive experimental results in complex mountainous terrains demonstrate the superiority of the LB-SAC-based decisionmaking model, showing a remarkable reduction in constraint violation rates to just <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 \%}$</tex> of baseline algorithms and a 32% improvement in mission completion efficiency. Our approach significantly outperforms existing deep RL methods, establishing a new paradigm for autonomous flight decisionmaking that harmonizes stringent safety guarantees with high operational performance in high-risk environments.

title: Multi-Modal Semantic Segmentation Based on Spike Encoding and Early Fusion with Events and Images
authors: Zhuxi Li, Qiugang Zhan, Ran Tao, Peiming Kan, Zhiguang Qin, Guisong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Event and frame-based cameras provide complementary sensing modalities for semantic segmentation: event streams capture fine-grained temporal dynamics, while frame-based images offer dense spatial and semantic information. Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs), inspired by biological neural computation, are inherently suited to modeling the temporal characteristics of event data. Therefore, we propose a hybrid ANN-SNN segmentation framework that leverages a Spiking Dynamics Encoding (SDE) module for temporal encoding of event streams and Artificial Neural Network (ANNs) for extracting spatial and semantic features from images. The SDE employs Leaky Integrate-and-Fire (LIF) neurons to transform asynchronous event streams into spatiotemporal confidence maps, enabling adaptive capture of motion-sensitive cues. Besides, to effectively integrate heterogeneous features from both modalities, we design an Early Cross-Modal Fusion (ECMF) module that concatenates and fuses low-level features from both branches through a shared convolutional layer at the initial processing stage. Experimental results on the DSEC and DDD17 datasets validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework in enhancing temporal modeling and cross-modal feature integration for multimodal semantic segmentation.

title: A Smart Clinical Application for Early Diagnosis of Progressive Diseases Using Machine Learning
authors: Rabab Hamed M. Aly, Asmaa M. Mohamed, Yasmin S. Mortada, Gehad T. Mohamed, Sara S.Abd Elfadil, Hoda M. Amin, Rasha Y. Youssef, Nagwa G. Goher
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: The early diagnosis of progressive diseases such as liver disease, chronic kidney failure, colon cancer, and Wilson's disease is crucial for the reduction of the humanity rate and therapy management. In this paper, robust models based on a machine learning approach provide very high accuracy measures for kidney disease, liver disease, colon cancer, and Wilson's disease with machine learning techniques. Based on these results, we created a clinical assistant app with AI that significantly improves early detection with three key characteristics. The primary feature involves the real-time analysis of patient data, including symptoms, laboratory findings, and imaging, to accurately identify high-risk individuals for liver and kidney diseases with over 96% certainty. The second feature is monitoring disease progression markers, such as predicting kidney function decline with 96.33% accuracy using AdaBoost to allow for treatment before symptoms appear. Furthermore, the third feature is AI-driven decision support systems that speed up diagnosis, especially for tricky cases such as colon cancer and Wilson's disease. By integrating these models into clinical pipelines, the application fills crucial gaps in early detection, such as the asymptomatic progression of colon cancer or the genetic intricacies of Wilson's disease, enabling doctors to treat patients sooner, based on personal circumstances, and ultimately leading to improved patient survival rates while lowering healthcare costs.

title: Secrecy Performance Analysis of AmBC-assisted MEC System with Backscatter Device Selection
authors: Ahmed N. Elbattrawy, Mohamed G. Abd El Ghafour, Ahmed H. Abd El-Malek, Sherif I. Rabia, Waheed K. Zahra
abstract: This work investigates the secrecy performance of an ambient backscatter communication (AmBC)-aided mobile edge computing network. A computationally-constrained user offloads its tasks to a computational access point in the presence of a passive eavesdropper. A selection scheme is proposed to select an AmBC user to offload its task, while inducing jamming signals on the eavesdropper. Closed-form expressions are derived for the system success probability (SSP) and the asymptotic SSP over Nakagami- m fading for the interference-limited regime. Numerical results investigate the impact of key parameters on the SSP and show that the proposed selection scheme achieves better performance than the Round-Robin and random selection schemes.

title: Large-Scale Planar Array Near-Field Calibration Based on Plane Wave Spectrum Maclaurin Expansion
authors: Yuanhua Tang, Zhengpeng Wang, Wei Fan, Xiaoming Chen, Steven Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper introduces a novel near-field calibration method for large-scale planar arrays. A novel signal model is developed by representing the plane wave spectrum (PWS) corresponding to the measured signals as a Maclaurin series expansion. By performing the Fourier transform of each polynomial term in this expansion, the measured signals can be expressed as a linear combination of the derivatives of the free-space scalar Green’s function. The initial excitations and Maclaurin coefficients are jointly estimated through iterative minimization of an evaluation function, which is defined by measuring the difference between the measured signals and the virtual signals computed using the proposed signal model. An alternating optimization strategy is employed to ensure fast and efficient convergence of the minimization process. A 6 × 9 planar array composed of rectangular open-ended open waveguides was calibrated at a measurement distance of 0.5 m using the proposed method, achieving a calibration error range of ±0.58 dB and ±4.9°. The calibration was conducted using probe measurements over approximately one-quarter of the AUT aperture, with a 3 × 3 uniformly spaced rectangular sampling grid within this scanning region. The obtained results validate the effectiveness of the proposed calibration method.

title: Robustness of Question Answering Systems in the Biomedical Domain: a study of the BioASQ dataset
authors: Andrew Reeves, Hang Dong
abstract: Robustness is a critical consideration when integrating artificial intelligence (AI) systems into decision-making processes. This concern is particularly relevant for generative AI systems, which are designed to consistently produce convincing outputs but can be prone to hallucinations, risking overconfidence in their outputs. This paper investigates the performance of fine-tuning and retrieval augmented generation (RAG) under external data quality perturbations, including typographical errors and factual inaccuracies. Results from experiments using the BioASQ Task 12b question answering dataset and PubMed articles showed nuanced trade-offs, with either RAG or fine-tuning performing better for different scenarios. Furthermore, an analysis of LLMs’ self-reported confidence scores indicated a tendency toward overconfidence, particularly in the presence of inconsistent or erroneous context data. A novel mitigation strategy, leveraging an LLM for data quality error correction was evaluated, but the results demonstrated limited effectiveness, highlighting the need for more advanced correction techniques.

title: Event-Triggered Model-Free Adaptive Predictive Control for Networked Wind-Power Microgrids Subject to Aperiodic DoS Attacks
authors: Rui Hou, Li Jia, Xuhui Bu, Jianfang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Escalating cybersecurity risks in communication networks pose severe challenges to the stability and reliability of microgrid control systems. This paper investigates the load frequency control problem of nonlinear networked wind-power microgrids under denial-of-service (DoS) attacks and event-triggered communication. A data-driven prediction framework is first established to construct a control-oriented dynamic linearization data model for the underlying nonlinear system. Sub-sequently, a novel event-triggered model-free adaptive predictive control (ET-MFAPC) algorithm with time-varying parameters is proposed, which integrates multi-step adaptive prediction and receding-horizon optimization. The proposed algorithm features several key innovations: 1) An output-related auxiliary variable is designed to circumvent unavailable pseudo-partial derivatives (PPDs) and their sign constraints. 2) An adaptive predictive compensation module is developed to mitigate the impacts of DoS attacks by reconstructing hijacked data packets. 3) An attack-aware online optimization mechanism is formulated to adaptively tune controller gains for improved system performance. Furthermore, a comprehensive security analysis is conducted based on a model-independent data energy function, and explicit boundary conditions are derived for tolerable attack frequency and duration. Finally, the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method are validated through simulation studies.

title: Networkless Collision Avoidance for Multiple Vehicles Using Joint Spatial–Temporal Chance-Constrained Optimization_supp1-3651393.mp4
authors: Dengyu Xiao
abstract: Generating high-quality, collision-free trajectories in real time for multiagent systems is challenging due to uncertainties arising from robot localization, network disturbances, and sensor errors. Existing approaches typically address this problem either deterministically, relying on reliable and consistent communication networks, or through approximations that often lead to overly conservative trajectories. In this article, we propose a method for generating trajectories by accounting for collision probabilities involving uncertain neighboring agents and obstacles, which is designed for multiple ground vehicles operating in a communication-free environment with limited detection ranges and Gaussian noise. A receding horizon framework is developed and formulated as a joint spatial–temporal chance-constrained optimization problem using nonlinear model predictive control (JSTC-MPC). To ensure the reliability and computational efficiency of the trajectories, an analytical and tighter approximation of joint spatial–temporal collision probabilities is introduced, effectively handling constraints from neighboring vehicles and obstacles at different JSTC-MPC stages. Furthermore, we propose a real-time replanning strategy that leverages chance-constrained, time-aware Voronoi spaces to address safety concerns in the presence of infeasible solutions. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through simulations and real-world experiments.

title: QoE-Aware Quantization in Buffer-Based Adaptive Bitrate Control with PD Controller for MPEG-DASH
authors: Eiki Asada Ryogo Kubo
abstract: Adaptive video streaming using Moving Picture Expert Group dynamic adaptive streaming over a Hypertext Transfer Protocol (MPEG-DASH) has become widely used on the internet recently. Various adaptive bitrate (ABR) algorithms have been proposed for video streaming. Buffer-based control-theoretic approaches for ABR control switch video bitrates in response to changing network conditions. However, the bitrate variations caused by frequent throughput variations can degrade the quality of experience (QoE). This study proposes a quantization scheme for buffer-based ABR control using a proportional-derivative controller for MPEG-DASH. The proposed scheme selects a quantized bitrate based on the output of the ABR controller, buffer level, its change, and throughput variation. In the quantization scheme, two kinds of algorithms are installed to detect throughput variation: Detection using one previous segment (PS1) and detection using three previous segments (PS3). The PS1 and PS3 algorithms are based on the variation in estimated throughput for a segment and three segments, respectively. Simulations confirm that the proposed scheme detects throughput variations earlier and more accurately than the conventional method and improves QoE.

title: Augmented Reality as a Transformative Tool in Engineering Education: Analysing its Impact on Learning and Engagement
authors: Babatunde Azeez Agboluaje, James Uhomoibhi
abstract: Augmented reality (AR) technology is being recognized as a valuable tool in the educational landscape, particularly in engineering. Despite the predominance of two-dimensional media in educational contexts, AR technology offers a unique opportunity to enhance the learning experience by integrating physical and virtual environments. This study explores the transformative potential of Augmented Reality (AR) as an innovative tool in engineering education through a systematic review of 85 peer-reviewed studies investigating AR's role within educational frameworks, specifically emphasising engineering education. Analysis was made to identify key themes, existing barriers, and gaps in current research and propose future directions for integrating AR into engineering curricula. This study highlights the significance of promoting AR as a transformative educational tool to enhance future educational results and quality. The findings suggest that augmented reality has the potential to revolutionize education by increasing accessibility and engagement for people from a variety of backgrounds.

title: SFI: A Practical and Efficient Backdoor Attack Framework against Split Learning
authors: Fangchao Yu, Bo Zeng, Kai Zhao, Zhi Pang, Lina Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Split learning is a computing resource-friendly distributed learning framework that protects client training data by splitting the model between the client and server. Previous work has proved that split learning faces a severe risk of privacy leakage, as a malicious server can recover the client's private data by hijacking the training process. In this paper, we explore the vulnerability of split learning to server-side backdoor attacks, where our goal is to compromise the model's integrity. Since the server-side attacker cannot access the training data and client model in split learning, the traditional poisoning-based backdoor attack methods are no longer applicable. Therefore, constructing backdoor attacks in split learning poses significant challenges. Our strategy involves the attacker establishing a shadow model on the server side that can encode backdoor samples and guide the client model in learning from this model during the training process, thereby enabling the client to acquire the same capability. Based on these insights, we propose a backdoor attack framework named SFI. Our attack framework minimizes assumptions about the attacker's background knowledge and ensures that the attack remains imperceptible to the client. We implement SFI on various benchmark datasets, and extensive experimental results demonstrate its effectiveness and generality.

title: Medical Data Security in Blockchain: A telemedicine data sharing scheme based on custom OPE and 4D-YG hyperchaotic
authors: Zhenlong Man, Chang Gao, Ze Yu, Xiangfu Meng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Aiming at the problems of sensitive data leakage and unauthorised direct access faced during the storage and transmission of shared medical data, this paper proposes a new medical data security sharing scheme based on blockchain. Firstly, to ensure the security and randomness of the keys in the scheme, a new 4D-YG hyperchaotic key generator is designed. Secondly, self-expanding fractal Sierpinski triangle permutating operation is performed on medical images to achieve image decentring effect. Utilize a custom Order-Preserving Encryption (OPE) algorithm to diffuse it, ensuring consistency in pixel order before and after encryption. Subsequently, mix-bit triple normalized diffusion is performed on the images that have completed preliminary diffusion to enhance the resistance of privacy data within the image to attacks. Finally, the decryption permission for encrypted shared medical data is restricted through smart contracts in the blockchain. While achieving secure transmission of medical data, it enables hospitals to perform medical image segmentation and organ recognition diagnostics on shared data in an encrypted state, which is more in line with practical needs. According to performance test data, the proposed encryption algorithm can effectively resist differential attacks and frequency attacks, and the Number of Pixels Change Rate (NPCR) test results can reach the ideal value of 99.6094%.

title: A Finite State Automaton for the Tsetlin Machine Using High-Capacity Resettable D Flip-Flop Cells
authors: Zeyu Han, Nobuyuki Yoshikawa, Yuki Yamanashi
abstract: Single Flux Quantum (SFQ) circuits provide ultrafast operation and low power consumption, making them attractive candidates for machine learning accelerators. The Tsetlin Machine (TM) is a low-complexity and highly interpretable architecture, organized as a voting system of propositional clauses. In the TM, an ensemble of finite-state automata (FSAs), called Tsetlin automata, independently decides whether to include or exclude specific literals. The chosen literals are assembled into propositional clauses that collectively form the voting system, while each FSA updates its state based on rewards or penalties determined by the prediction outcome. However, existing FSA designs for TM based on SFQ circuits still suffer from either a narrow margin or excessive circuit area. To achieve compact and stable state transitions using SFQ circuits, we designed High-Capacity Resettable D Flip-Flop (HC-RDFF) cells by cascading storage loops. The proposed FSA was implemented using two HC-RDFFs to store the include and exclude states, respectively. The FSA with 16 states requires only 395 Josephson junctions with a static power of approximately 128 μW, exhibiting a bias margin of −21% to +25% at low speed and a maximum operating frequency of 20 GHz in simulation. We fabricated the HC-RDFF and the FSA using a 10 kA/cm² Nb four-layer superconducting process and verified their correct operation through low-speed measurements. The number of FSA states can be increased simply by extending the cascaded storage loops in the HC-RDFFs. We expect the proposed FSA to be suitable for constructing stable TM systems based on SFQ circuits with reduced hardware costs.

title: A Set-Membership Filter for Group Target Tracking Using Bounded Bearing-Only Measurements
authors: Jingling Li, Xianbin Gao, Ping Wei, Huaguo Zhang, Lin Gao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, a set-membership based group target tracking algorithm is proposed for bearing-only measurement scenarios. In set-membership filtering, the initial state, process noise, and measurement noise are usually considered bounded (modeled as compact sets), which allows us to achieve target tracking by propagating the sets containing the target state. Simulation results show the effectiveness of the proposed method, even when the shape of the group target has a tendency to spread.

title: Enhancing Process Mining on Sparse Event Logs: A Simulation-Driven Academic Case Study
authors: Towfeeq Fairooz, Aleeha Iftikhar, Zeeshan Tariq, Sally McClean, Ian McChesney
abstract: Many business processes involve complex, partly automated workflows, with limited timestamp data in the process event log. Sparse event logs limit the opportunity for process analysis and optimization. This paper describes the use of Discrete Event Simulation (DES) to model such processes and to augment sparse event logs with richer, synthetic data, enabling the application of process mining techniques for process enhancement. The approach is illustrated by application to an administrative process in an academic institution, namely an assessment extension request process. The study combines data-driven and knowledge-based approaches to understanding and modeling the existing process. Preliminary data analysis is used to obtain high-level process insights. The paper shows how this lays the foundation for the use of domain knowledge to construct and verify a discrete event simulation model. By integrating process mining with simulation, research can provide actionable insights to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the current assessment extension request process. Observations are made on how this approach can be applied to other business processes with sparse event logs.

title: Evolutionary Nanorobotic Design Based on Bioinformation Feedback
authors: Weiqi Liu, Jiawei Zou, Shaolong Shi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: We study a novel design technology for nanorobots, aiming to address the issue of self-driven nanorobotic design based on evolutionary computation. By using evolutionary algorithms, candidate solutions for nanorobots with specific functions are automatically designed with a computer, where the biological gradient field (BGF) induced by tumor lesions provides auxiliary knowledge for the design of the morphology, function, and adaptive behavior of nanorobots in complex biological environments. Traditional robot design methods separate the design of robotic structure and control system, leading to limitations in adaptability and scalability. To tackle this problem, we adopt a ‘de novo design’ research paradigm, discovering and optimizing efficient robot structures and behaviors by simulating the process of natural selection, and uses BGF to dynamically guide the evolutionary process by embedding environmental feedback into genetic coding as auxiliary information. Furthermore, to enhance the generalizability of BGF, we employ a multi-physics field model for simulation modeling. Computer simulation experimental results validate the effectiveness and scalability of the proposed method for nanorobotic design.

title: A Survey of Domain-specific Fine-tuned Large Language Models
authors: Paria Sarzaeim, Akramul Azim, Gary Bauer, Masoud Makrehchi
abstract: The advancement of large language models (LLMs), such as GPT-3, BERT, and Llama, has introduced a new era in natural language processing (NLP) as they have demonstrated exceptional capabilities across diverse tasks. Fine-tuning these LLMs with domain-specific data has become a popular practice, particularly in domains like education, law, medicine, and software development. This process not only empowers LLMs with domain knowledge but also enhances their capabilities by addressing issues such as reliability and reducing the chance of hallucination. This survey examines a range of domain-specific fine-tuned models by highlighting their unique characteristics, enhancements in performance, and the challenges they address, including the demand for extensive computational resources. Furthermore, we explore the fine-tuning methodologies, including instruction tuning used in the development of these models, and ultimately, inform future research on the existing gaps and how to enhance the effective application of LLMs across diverse domains.

title: Quantification of Major Depressive Disorder via Spectrogram-Based Analysis of Electroencephalography Signals
authors: Maryam Khan Afridi, Aamir Arsalan, Nargis Bibi
abstract: This paper investigates the application of spectrogram-based analysis of electroencephalography (EEG) signals for the quantification of Major Depressive Disorder (MDD), employing a transfer learning approach with pretrained deep neural networks. The study involved creating spectrograms from EEG data collected from 61 subjects, including 32 diagnosed with MDD and 29 healthy controls. These spectrograms were used as inputs to fine-tune pre-trained models (VGG16, VGG19, and ResNet50) to classify MDD patients and healthy controls. The experimental results reveal that the ResNet50 architecture outperformed other deep learning models by achieving a classification accuracy of 98.54% by utilizing the EEG data from only the 3 parietal region electrodes. The findings of the study underscore the potential of EEG-based approaches in the effective diagnosis and quantification of MDD.

title: Technology-Enhanced Dual-Task Testing for Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias: A Review of Trends, Tools, and Emerging Directions
authors: Mahmoud Seifallahi, Sohini Lahiri, James E. Galvin, Behnaz Ghoraani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are growing global health challenges, projected to affect over 82 million people by 2030. Early diagnosis is essential, offering the potential to extend life expectancy by over 50% and reduce healthcare costs by up to $150,000 per patient. Dual-task (DT) testing—evaluating motor performance under cognitive load—has emerged as a promising, non-invasive method for early ADRD detection. This review provides a comprehensive synthesis of DT-based ADRD assessments from January 2010 to October 2025, integrating insights from engineering and clinical neuroscience. We explore a broad range of DT paradigms (e.g., gait, balance, upperlimb function), sensing technologies (e.g., wearable sensors, electronic walkways, infrared/depth cameras, video, tablets, and brain imaging tools like fMRI and fNIRS), and analytic approaches, from traditional statistics to deep learning. Emerging tools, including eye-tracking and AI-based video pose estimation, are also discussed. We critically examine methodological trends, highlight key findings, and identify current limitations. Emphasizing the need for equitable, scalable, and clinically viable DT systems, this review highlights the role of modern sensor and AI technologies in enhancing early ADRD detection. It serves as a key resource for engineers, data scientists, and clinicians developing technology-driven tools for early detection and monitoring of neurodegenerative diseases.

title: A Graph Neural Network-Based Method for Dynamic Path Scheduling in AGV Systems
authors: Hongchao Ma, Yurun Feng, Huichao Shi
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: With the increasing application of Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs) in intelligent manufacturing, an increasing number of smart workshops rely on AGV systems for material handling and distribution. However, traditional AGV scheduling methods, often based on fixed rules or heuristic algorithms, struggle to adapt effectively to real-world scenarios involving multiple tasks and dynamically complex environments. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an improved AGV material distribution algorithm based on Graph Neural Networks (GNN). The proposed approach models the workshop environment as a graph structure and utilizes Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) to deeply extract features from nodes and paths, enabling task node probability prediction and route smoothness scoring. Based on this, a multi-AGV collision-free path planning and conflict avoidance mechanism is designed, taking into account both static priorities and dynamic operational states. This allows for reasonable task sequencing and assignment, ensuring real-time path planning and efficient execution during multi-vehicle collaboration. Simulation experiments under various dynamic multi-task scenarios demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms traditional approaches in task completion efficiency, providing a practical and scalable solution for intelligent workshop scheduling.

title: An Immersive Virtual Reality Platform for First Aid and Emergency Training
authors: Marcello A. Carrozzino, Matteo Caponi, Simone Pisani, Bruno Papaleo, Alda Mazzei, Rudy Foddis, Massimo Bergamasco
abstract: Virtual reality (VR) technologies have emerged as valuable tools for medical and emergency training, providing safe, immersive, and repeatable environments where complex procedures can be practiced effectively. This article presents an immersive VR system designed to train workplace first-aid responders, with a particular focus on cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR). The platform integrates a physical CPR manikin with virtual patient overlays through mixed-reality calibration, incorporates realistic emergency scenarios with environmental hazards, and enables synchronous multiuser interaction between trainees and instructors. To assess its potential, we provide a detailed description of the system's architecture and functionalities, introducing the results of an extensive user study employing validated questionnaires on usability, performance, and user experience. The proposed framework contributes to the advancement of VR-based medical education, highlighting its benefits, current limitations, and future research opportunities.

title: Measurement of 5G-NR Signal in V2I Environment in 5 GHz Band by Software-defined Radio System
authors: Hiroshi Harada, Masaki Shimomura, Shota Mori, Norichika Ohmi
abstract: A measurement system using software-defined radio technology to acquire the transmission characteristics of Fifth Generation New Radio (5 G -NR) signals was developed for vehicle-to-everything (V2X) environments. Using this system, the radio wave propagation characteristics and the block error rate characteristics of 5 G -NR signals in a vehicle-to-infrastructure (V2I) environment at a real intersection with two lanes on each side were measured in the $\mathbf{5 ~ G H z}$ band. The results show that the 5 GHz frequency band has strong directionality; however, when the transmitter was placed at a height of approximately 13 m and the receiver was mounted on a vehicle with a height of 1.5 m, using a horizontal plane omnidirectional antenna and a vertical plane antenna with a half-power beamwidth of 9° and a transmit power of approximately 15 dBm, it was possible to maintain a communication range of roughly $40-60 \mathrm{~m}$ around the intersection, even when the vehicle was moving within the intersection environment.

title: AI-Driven Exterior Damage Assessment for Shared Vehicle Systems: A Benchmarking Study of Segmentation and Detection Models
authors: Cátia Loureiro, Sandra Dixe, Hugo Baptista, Cristiana Neto, Tiago Aston, Duarte Fernandes
abstract: Shared vehicle systems, which rely heavily on user-to-user condition verification, require robust automated damage assessment for vehicle safety. This paper addresses that need by providing a comprehensive benchmark of deep learning models for automated vehicle exterior damage identification, focusing on two critical tasks: vehicle region segmentation and damage detection. For segmentation, the following models were evaluated: YOLOv8, RTMDet, Mask-RCNN, Mask2Former, Mask-DINO, and QueryInst, assessing precision, recall, mAP, and inference time. The findings revealed that transformer-based models, Mask2Former (84.8% mAP50) and Mask-DINO (88.6% mAP50), achieved notable segmentation performance. However, YOLOv8 (up to 88.9% mAP50) demonstrated the best balance between performance metrics and speed. For damage detection, models from the YOLO family, RTMDet, RT-DETR, DINO, and YOLO-NAS were benchmarked. Performance in this more challenging task was notably lower, with RT-DETR (L) achieving the highest mAP50. These results highlight the challenges affecting model per-formance, including class imbalances and variability in damage representation. Thus, this study provides important insights into the limitations and potential of current deep learning models when applied to a publicly available dataset, supporting the development of next-generation solutions for vehicle damage assessment.

title: Frame-Correlation Exploitation for Secure Audio Watermarking: A Parallel Multi-Watermarking Framework with Enhanced Robustness
authors: Qiutong Li, Zheng Xing, Qingyang Xu, Xiaochen Yuan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To further balance the robustness and imperceptibility of audio watermarking technology and protect the global market information security, this paper proposes an inter-frame correlation-based multiple parallel audio watermarking scheme (ICMP). Adjacent Frame Extraction Process (AFEP) is proposed to select the adjacent frame. Then, Discrete Cosine Transform (DCT) is applied to each embedding frame and its adjacent frame to extract their corresponding frequency domain coefficients. To improve robustness, midfrequency DCT coefficients are selected to embed multiwatermarks. For enhancing embedding capacity, randomly generated vectors are transformed into orthogonal unit vectors using Gram-Schmidt orthogonalization. By projecting each interframe difference coefficient onto orthogonal vectors, multiwatermarks are embedded in parallel by adjusting the projections into a predefined range. Experimental results show that, compared to existing schemes, the proposed scheme generally offers superior imperceptibility and robustness.

title: A Median Enhancement Attention Network for Highway Traffic Hazy Image Enhancement
authors: Xiaoyong Li, Fuchun Zhu, Haofang You, Ye Wang, Yang Chen, Wenjie Zhang, Xinyi Xu, Zheng Liang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Foggy highway images often suffer from issues like color cast, low contrast, and blurry details, primarily caused by light scattering and absorption in the atmosphere. These problems bring significant obstacles to traffic vision tasks. To solve these limitations in foggy image enhancement, we propose a median enhancement attention network based on supervised learning, named MEANet. Specifically, first, we process the image with different convolution kernels to obtain multiscale features, and then fuse these features to acquire more abundant information. Subsequently, we design a median attention module to balance color and improve details, incorporating pixel attention and channel attention. To enhance feature extraction, we introduce median pooling within the median attention module. Finally, qualitative and quantitative evaluations demonstrate that our method outperforms other methods in both dehazing for highway scenes and underwater image enhancement.

title: A user-friendly Google Earth Engine Web Application for vegetation trait mapping and time series analysis from Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-3 imagery
authors: Emma De Clerck, Jochem Verrelst
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: A Google Earth Engine (GEE) web application is introduced for automated mapping of a suite of quantitative vegetation traits (e.g., LAI, fAPAR, GPP, chlorophyll/nitrogen/water content) from Sentinel-2 and Sentinel-3 imagery, covering both surface reflectance and top-of-atmosphere radiance. The system operationalizes validated Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) models based on radiative transfer simulations within a fully cloud-based workflow, enabling on-demand generation of vegetation trait maps at 20–300 m resolution without requiring coding expertise. Key innovations include: (1) dynamic model loading for 30 GPR models enabling estimation of 11 vegetation traits, (2) automated masking/compositing for trait mapping, and (3) Savitzky-Golay smoothing for noise-reduced temporal analysis. The application demonstrates the potential of GEE to bridge advanced machine-learning-based retrieval methods and practical, operational Earth observation use.

title: The Need for Up- & Re-Skilling of Staff of Universities of Applied Sciences in Ethiopia
authors: Ephrem Tekle, Margareth Gfrerer
abstract: Universities of Applied Sciences (UAS) are new to Ethiopia. On the Ethiopian Ministry of Education's initiative fifteen universities were transformed to U ASs. Neither the academic staff nor the administrative staff of these universities are prepared to fit into the requirements of an UAS. Therefore, up-skilling and re-skilling have become an important issue. Together with European partners the Ethiopian UASs are trying to learn what it means to be staff (academic or administrative) of an UAS. The research question works on “How to qualify lecturers for the future - the unknown?” It is of special interest, whether the ongoing up-skilling and re-skilling projects have a certain focus on the future as described by A. Toffler. This research checks in a first step A. Toffler's vision on ‘Education in the Future Tense’ against the two ongoing Erasmus+ capacity building higher education projects in order to find out whether the ongoing projects meet the requirements as set out in the book ‘Future Shock’ published in 1970. The literature review presents a brief summary of the book's chapter on education. Followed by an insight of the two projects and the clarification of the important terms of uncertainty-future-futureness. The discussion brings light on what has been or has not been considered in the ongoing projects.
