A comparison of Bloom's Taxonomy with the Ahvenainen's futureness approach will demonstrate how academic staff could/should be trained to gain interest in playing with uncertainty for the sake of preparing students for the unknown future.

title: Templse: Cloud Integrated Health Monitoring System
authors: Arnab Abhijit Chaudhuri, Anadi Chakraborty, Avinash More, Vipul Gohil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper presents Templse (Temperature and Pulse Rate), a unified IoT-based health monitoring system that combines a contactless infrared thermometer and a pulse rate monitor in a single compact device. Built around an ESP32 microcontroller with onboard Wi-Fi connectivity and powered by a rechargeable lithium-ion battery pack for portability, the system enables real-time vital sign acquisition and cloud integration. A GY-906 MLX90614ESF IR sensor measures body temperature without contact, while a SEN-11574 PPG sensor captures heart rate. To ensure reliable pulse detection in noisy conditions, the device firmware incorporates adaptive filtering and thresholding algorithms. Measured temperature and heart rate are displayed locally on an OLED display and simultaneously uploaded via Wi-Fi to the cloud services (Blynk and ThingSpeak) for remote monitoring. The device demonstrates temperature accuracy within ±0.3°C and heart rate accuracy within a few BPM compared to reference devices.

title: Evaluating the Performance of Three IHS-based Pansharpening Techniques
authors: Ouahab Adelwhab, Hautia Cherifa
abstract: Pansharpening, the process of fusing low-resolution multispectral (MS) images with high-resolution panchromatic (Pan) images, is crucial in enhancing the spatial and spectral quality of satellite imagery. This study evaluates three variations of the Intensity-Hue-Saturation (IHS) pansharpening technique: traditional IHS, Fast IHS with Spectral Adjustment (FIHS), and FIHS with Spectral Adjustment (FIHS-SA). Using satellite images from IKONOS, PLEIADES, QuickBird, and WorldView, we employ evaluation metrics including the Spatial Correlation Coefficient (SCC), Correlation Coefficient (CC), and Quality Noise Ratio (QNR) to assess the performance of each method. The results indicate that while traditional IHS provides acceptable spatial enhancement, it suffers from notable spectral distortions. In contrast, both FIHS and FIHS-SA demonstrate improved spectral fidelity, with FIHS-SA exhibiting superior performance across all tested images. This research underscores the significance of selecting appropriate pansharpening techniques to achieve optimal outcomes in various remote sensing applications, emphasizing the balance between spatial enhancement and spectral integrity.

title: Evaluating Administrative Accountability for Artificial Intelligence Application Errors in Jordan: Legal and Ethical Implications
authors: Mohmmad Husien Almajali, Ala’ A. Masarweh, Ihab Fahmi Rayyan
abstract: The world is progressively adopting Artificial Intelligence (AI) across all sectors to improve productivity, decision-making, and service provision. In Jordan, AI is being investigated in many fields, such as healthcare, education, financial services, and government activities. However, the tendency to rapidly embrace AI technologies presents unique challenges, one of the most serious being failures within the system and the legal accountability of individuals and organizations operationally responsible for the systems within which the mistakes are made. The article intends to identify legal responsibility in case a person or administrative organization is to be blamed for AI application inaccuracies in Jordan, focusing intensely on the social and legal consequences. The analysis emphasizes the country's existing legal documents, the ethical aspects of the application of AI technology, and the comprehensive plan for administrative responsibility. The analysis of the components makes it possible to understand better how Jordan can cope with the problems of AI governance and bear the consequences of malfunctioning AI systems and ethical misconduct at the hands of powerful AI.

title: A Portable Femtoampere-Sensitive Readout System for a High-Pressure Argon Ionization Chamber
authors: R. Bıyık, T. Yalçın, O. Alaçayır
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and validation of a portable femtoampere-sensitive electronic readout system for a high-pressure argon-filled ionization chamber (IC) radiation detector. The system integrates a custom-built ionization tube with a low-noise analog front-end, precision digital processing, and a power-efficient embedded platform. At its core is a transimpedance amplifier (TIA) based on an electrometergrade op-amp (ADA4530-1), enabling accurate conversion of ionization currents in the femtoampere range. A dual-path amplification architecture ensures dynamic range adaptability across low and high dose rate conditions. The digital subsystem— featuring a 16-bit Sigma-Delta ADC-equipped STM32 microcontroller—handles real-time digitization, temperature compensation, and self-adjustment offset via integrated DACs. The device was calibrated and tested at the Secondary Standard Dosimetry Laboratory (SSDL) of the Turkish Nuclear Energy Research Institute (TENMAK), covering a wide radiation range from 3 μSv/h to 60 mSv/h using multiple <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">137</sup>Cs sources. The system demonstrated excellent linearity (R² > 0.998), with a minimum detectable dose rate of approximately 2 μSv/h, and maintained a total measurement error below 10%. These results affirm the device’s suitability for portable, high-precision radiation monitoring in field and safety applications. The novelty of this work lies in the integration of a high-pressure argon ionization chamber with a dual-path femtoampere readout front-end and a fully self-adjusting digital control unit, enabling portable, low-dose-rate detection below 3 μSv/h.

title: RDKD-SAR: An RT-DETR knowledge distillation framework for SAR object detection
authors: Jialei Ni, Yinghua Wang, Hongwei Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Transformer-based object detectors have demonstrated substantial potential across a wide range of computer vision tasks, including object detection in Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images. However, these models are often plagued by high computational costs, rendering them impractical for realtime applications. To tackle this issue, knowledge distillation (KD) has been introduced to transfer knowledge from a large teacher model to a smaller student model. In this paper, we propose a novel knowledge distillation framework for RT-DETR, a state-of-the-art object detector, and also tailored for SAR images. Our method involves layer-by-layer distillation between RT-DETR networks of varying parameter sizes and introduces two aspects of improvements: Adaptive Queries Alignment and Teacher Scoring Mechanism. The former is used to guide distillation matching more quickly, while the latter improves distillation performance without introducing additional parameters. We evaluated our approach on the OGSOD-1.0 SAR dataset using RT-DETR with ResNet-18, ResNet-50, and ResNet-101 as the backbones. The corresponding parameter sizes are $20.1 \mathrm{M}, 42.7 \mathrm{M}$, and 76.8 M, respectively. The results show that after distilling RT-DETR with ResNet-101 to that with ResNet-18 as the backbone, the student model achieves 1.8 mAP improvement compared to the original student model, with only 26.1% of the teacher model’s parameters. This distillation method reduces computational costs and parameter sizes while enhancing detection performance.

title: Structurally Consistent Multi-Stage Learning for Abdominal and Cardiac Organ Segmentation
authors: Shanshan Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Accurate segmentation in medical images remains a challenging task due to the intricate anatomical structures, ambiguous boundaries, and limited labeled data typically available in clinical scenarios. U-shaped encoder-decoder architectures, such as U-Net and its variants, have become the de facto standard in medical image segmentation owing to their ability to fuse multi-scale features through skip connections. However, conventional training strategies often rely solely on supervision at the final output layer, leaving rich intermediate representations underutilized and lacking explicit consistency constraints across different decoding stages. In this paper, we propose Structurally Consistent Multi-Stage Learning (SCMSL), a simple yet effective training framework designed to improve segmentation quality by enhancing supervision and structural coherence across multiple decoder stages. SCMSL incorporates two key components: (1) multi-stage supervision, which introduces segmentation losses at various decoder stages to guide hierarchical feature refinement throughout the network; and (2) a novel Gram Matrix Loss that measures the similarity between the structural representations of outputs from different stages. By capturing second-order feature correlations, this loss encourages the network to produce consistent and anatomically plausible predictions across scales. Our method is model-agnostic and introduces no additional inference-time complexity, making it easy to plug into existing segmentation architectures. We validate SCMSL on two widely used benchmarks-Synapse multi-organ CT dataset and ACDC cardiac MRI dataset. Experimental results show that SCMSL significantly improves segmentation accuracy and boundary smoothness over strong baselines, confirming the effectiveness and generalizability of our approach.

title: Traffic-Aware RAW Slot Allocation Scheme for Heterogeneous IoT Networks
authors: Mahesh Miriyala, V.P. Harigovindan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: IEEE 802.11ah is a promising technology that supports Internet of Things (IoT) applications by offering extended coverage, improved energy efficiency, and enhanced scalability. In this paper, we propose a novel Traffic-Aware Adaptive Restricted Access Window (TARA-RAW) slot allocation scheme tailored for IEEE 802.11ah networks. The proposed method employs fuzzy logic to intelligently classify devices into groups based on dynamic transmission parameters such as data volume, transmission frequency, and latency requirements. Each group is then allocated an adaptable number of RAW slots, which are dynamically adjusted according to real-time traffic patterns and network load. To validate the effectiveness of TARA, we develop both an analytical model and a simulation framework to evaluate key performance metrics including throughput and energy consumption. Results demonstrate that the TARA scheme outperforms traditional uniform grouping approaches, achieving higher throughput and lower energy expenditure, thereby making it highly suitable for large-scale and diverse IoT deployments.

title: A Scalable Multiple Extended Targets Tracking Based on the Non-Homogeneous Poisson Process and PHD Filter*
authors: Weilong Qiu, Yuansheng Li, Ling Cui, Yixing Du
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a scalable Bayesian framework for tracking multiple extended targets based on a nonhomogeneous Poisson process (NHPP) and the Probability Hypothesis Density (PHD) filter. In the context of extended target tracking, the measurement-to-target association is unknown and evolves over time. To dynamically capture this evolution, an association-based NHPP (AbNHPP) Bayesian tracking framework integrating the target’s association variables and its Poisson measurement rate is derived. To more flexibly model the target’s Poisson measurement rate and ensure the closed-form solution for the PHD filter, this paper adopts the following models: the target’s measurement rate is modeled as a Generalized Inverse Gaussian (GIG) distribution, the target’s kinematic state is modeled as a Gaussian distribution, and the target’s extension is modeled as an inverse-Wishart (IW) distribution. Specifically, the GIG distribution for measurement rate of extended targets is modeled as Time Independent Poisson Rate (TIPR). Simulation results validate the superiority and scalability of the proposed algorithm.

title: U2Sign: Urdu-Driven Pakistani Sign Language Sequence Production
authors: Usman, Rohail Zulfiqar, Neelma Naz, Jameel Malik
abstract: Sign language production systems are inherently complex and require the integration of linguistic, visual, and computational components, which makes standardization and cross-method comparison challenging. This work presents U2Sign, an open source framework for the automatic production of Pakistani Sign Language (PSL) from inputs of the Urdu natural language, addressing the communication needs of the Pakistani speech-impaired community. The system processes both spoken and written Urdu through a pipeline that includes Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR), followed by Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques such as normalization, lemmatization, part-of-speech tagging, and rule-based word reordering to generate a sequence of glosses. These glosses are mapped to a custom-built PSL lexi-con, and missing entries are handled through fallback strategies. The gloss-to-pose module utilizes skeletal pose sequences extracted from annotated videos using MediaPipe, with gloss-aligned pose frames stitched together using temporal smoothing to generate coherent PSL animations. The final output is rendered as video through a web-based interface built with React.js and Flask, which supports real-time interaction. U2Sign is reproducible, extensible, and culturally relevant and holds significant promise for applications in education, healthcare, and public accessibility within Pakistan.

title: DNSODN: A Detail-Enhanced and Normalized Distance-IoU Aware Network for Small Object Detection
authors: Kehong Li, Yifan Wang, Xuefeng Chen, Liang Feng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Small object detection remains a critical challenge in computer vision due to limited semantic information, indistinct visual features, and susceptibility to environmental interference, particularly in construction-site scenarios. Existing models often overlook shallow features and effective label assignment, limiting detection accuracy. To address these limitations, a framework named Detail-enhanced and NWD-IoU-driven Small Object Detection Network (DNSODN) is proposed. The framework integrates a Detail-enhanced Feature Pyramid Network (DEFPN), which refines shallow feature representation through attention-based enhancement, and a Normalized Weighted Distance Intersection over Union (NWD-IoU) metric, which supports robust and discriminative label assignment. Experiments on the SODA and SODA-D datasets indicate that DNSODN consistently improves detection performance across different object scales, highlighting its effectiveness in small object detection under challenging environments.

title: Adaptive Gamma Correction with Explicitly Nonlinear Balancing
authors: Fengzhen Gao, Zhicheng Lin, Xinchuan Qiu, Wenqi Deng, Bin Huang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper introduces an adaptive non-linear weighted Gamma correction method designed for explicit controllability and adjustable image enhancement according to quality demands. While existing non-learning approaches offer efficiency, they lack flexibility. Conversely, deep learning methods, despite their adaptivity, suffer from ambiguous control and high model complexity. To address these limitations, our proposed method combines global Gamma correction with the Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF) of the grayscale histogram, dynamically balancing global and local image information. The non-linear weighting scheme effectively enhances dark details while suppressing overexposure, mitigating common artifacts such as over-enhancement. Its explicit formulation facilitates integration into Image Signal Processor (ISP) systems and offers differentiability, enabling parameter optimization through various search strategies for diverse image processing tasks. Experimental results demonstrate the method’s capability for high-quality enhancement across a range of visual quality requirements.

title: Dynamic Modeling and Control Strategy of Mechatronics Servo System
authors: Jian Ma
abstract: A high fidelity dynamic model is constructed to address the nonlinearity, parameter uncertainty, and external disturbances in mechatronic servo systems. A self disturbance rejection control strategy combining proportional integral derivative and extended state observer is proposed. The dynamic model comprehensively considers the electrical characteristics of the motor, shaft stiffness, and rotational inertia parameters, as well as key nonlinear factors such as dead zone saturation, friction, and gear backlash. The self disturbance rejection control strategy of the servo system achieves high-precision and robust adaptive control of the servo system by real-time estimation and compensation of the total system disturbance. The simulation findings denote that when the output shaft stiffness increases from 50% to 200%, the first-order resonant frequency of the system increases from 562rad/s to 1687rad/s, with a peak amplitude of 12.61dB. At a tooth gap of 0.05, the proposed control strategy reduces the tracking error to 0.039°, which is better than the traditional control strategy of 0.051°. Under external wind speed interference, the proposed control strategy exhibits superior disturbance resistance and robustness, with pitch angle control accuracy maintained above 42.88° at different wind speeds, significantly better than traditional control methods. The findings denote that the established model can accurately characterize the dynamic characteristics of the system, and the designed control strategy greatly enhances the tracking accuracy and anti-interference ability of the system, providing theoretical support and solutions for the design and control of high-performance servo systems.

title: From Diesel to Electric: Exploring Fleet Increment Curves for Zero-Emission Bus Transition
authors: Yiyang Peng, Zhuowei Wang, Anthony Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Bus electrification is a key trend in the global evolution of public transportation systems. However, replacing diesel buses (DBs) with Battery electric buses (BEBs) is a long-term process, where the limited driving range and prolonged charging times might necessitate a larger BEB fleet to maintain trip services compared to the replaced DB fleet. To quantify this fleet expansion across variable replacement decisions, we introduce the fleet increment curve (FIC), a novel conceptual idea that guides BEB procurement decisions during the transition to the zero-emission bus (ZEB) system. First, the FIC is derived from solving a series of mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) (namely MILP-FIC model) by varying the replaced DB fleet as inputs, where each MILP is developed by means of linearization techniques, while formulating the mixed-fleet operation under limited charging accessibility. To solve the MILP-FIC, Lagrangian relaxation (LR) is applied to relax charging accessibility constraints, decomposing the problem into route-specific subproblems. Subsequently, representing FIC by-products as piecewise linear functions enables extended models developed for addressing long-term fleet replacement scheduling and charging resource allocation. A general fleet replacement scheduling is presented, which accommodates multiple BEB types (varying battery capacities and charging power) by deriving type-specific fleet procurement curves. We use real-world bus route data from Hong Kong to explore the FIC, revealing how route characteristics—such as trip frequency, trip duration, and energy consumption—interact with charging site characteristics (e.g., siting and sizing) to shape the FIC. The curves typically follow a non-decreasing trend, while an S-shaped trend occurs across certain routes. Additionally, the results demonstrate the effective incorporation of FIC into the planning for ZEB transition, providing valuable insights for bus operators.

title: Complex Sawi Integral Transform and Some Applications
authors: Waseem Al Mashaelh, Alaa Al-Zboon, Rania Saadeh, Alaa Al-Wadi, Ahmad Qazza, Iqbal H. Jebril
abstract: This thesis presents a new complex integral transform, related to Sawi in transform. The definition of the new transform is presented, and we prove the main properties and theorems related to it. The new transform is discussed for convergence analysis, and it is applied to some differential operators and applications. The applicability and efficiency are tested of the new approach in solving some ordinary differential equations, and some applications in physics and engineering are presented, that are solved by the new complex integral Sawi transform.

title: Eyes on the Road: Unleashing the Power of Autonomous Vehicles with Cameras
authors: Aarav Kannan J, R. Rajalakshmi, M Gowtham, R Geetheshwar, S R Srividhya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This manuscript presents the design and implementation of a voice-controlled robotic vehicle (VCRV) leveraging Smart Control Automation Structure (SCAS) for efficient and accessible navigation. The system enables real-time vehicle control through multiple interaction modes—including voice commands via an Android smartphone, gesture-based control using the gyroscope sensor, and manual input through a custom mobile interface. The core architecture integrates an Arduino UNO microcontroller, HC-05 Bluetooth module, L293D motor driver IC, ultrasonic and PIR sensors, along with a real-time video surveillance module for enhanced situational awareness. The VCRV system was tested in various indoor environments and demonstrated an average response time of 1.2 seconds for voice commands with a 94% command recognition accuracy. The obstacle avoidance module, powered by ultrasonic sensing, achieved a 96% success rate in detecting and responding to barriers within a 20 cm range. Gesture control via the smartphone gyroscope exhibited a 92% accuracy in directional navigation. Additionally, the system’s modular design ensured easy integration of additional features, including a mobile-based live video stream and sensor-driven safety protocols. The results highlight the system's reliability, responsiveness, and adaptability, making it suitable for use in assistive mobility, remote surveillance, and educational robotics. Its low-cost, scalable, and user-friendly design paves the way for further research and enhancements toward autonomous and intelligent robotic platforms.

title: A Data Science-Driven Face Recognition Attendance System Integrated with a Voice Assistant
authors: S Supriya, M Sreekrishna, G S Gopika, Kundu Madhu, Kattajaya Durga Prasad
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Accurate and efficient attendance tracking is a critical component of institutional management in educational and organizational environments. Traditional methods such as manual roll calls and biometric systems like fingerprint recognition often suffer from inefficiencies, hygiene concerns, and susceptibility to manipulation. This manuscript proposes a robust, contactless attendance management system based on real-time face recognition, enhanced with voice assistant integration and powered by advanced machine learning techniques. The system leverages convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for facial feature extraction, the Viola-Jones algorithm for face detection, and support vector machines (SVMs) for classification. Additionally, it integrates real-time 3D face tracking and customizable face modeling to enhance recognition accuracy under varying conditions. Attendance data is updated instantly through an IoT-enabled database, ensuring scalability and remote access. Voice assistant capabilities further improve user interaction, offering voice-driven commands and status feedback. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s high accuracy, speed, and reliability, making it a viable solution for modern attendance tracking. This work lays the foundation for intelligent, secure, and user-friendly attendance systems suitable for smart classrooms and automated institutional workflows.

title: On Compensation Function Observer-Based Active Disturbance Rejection Control for MIMO Uncertain Systems and Its Application to 2-DOF Helicopter System
authors: Kaiwen Liu, Sen Chen, Zhi-Liang Zhao, Wenchao Xue
abstract: This article investigates the control problem for multiple-input multiple-output systems with nonlinear uncertainties. By introducing a prediction-correction mechanism, a new compensation function observer (CFO) is constructed to enhance the estimation accuracy of the total disturbance. Subsequently, the CFO-based active disturbance rejection control (CADRC) is designed to mitigate the total disturbances and attain the desired control performance. Based on an inductive decoupling-based Lyapunov method, this article rigorously establishes the closed-loop stability of the CADRC under a broad class of nonlinear state-dependent uncertainties. Moreover, a comparative frequency-domain analysis quantitatively reveals the superior disturbance estimation and rejection capabilities of the CADRC. Finally, the proposed CADRC is implemented on a Quanser two-degree-of-freedom helicopter system subject to additional digital uncertainties, and the experimental results demonstrate its clear superiority over the conventional ADRC.

title: Beamforming-Enabled Blind Navigation With Application to 5G and DTV Signals of Opportunity
authors: Shaghayegh Shahcheraghi, Zaher M. Kassas
abstract: A beamforming-enabled blind navigation (BBN) receiver is developed. Unlike conventional opportunistic receivers, the BBN requires no prior knowledge of the reference signal structure. Moreover, unlike Doppler subspace-based blind receivers, which fail when there is not sufficient Doppler separation between sources, the BBN overcomes this limitation via beam forming, enabling effective spatial separation even when Doppler frequencies are closely spaced. The BBN operates in three stages: detection, acquisition, and tracking. In the detection stage, two sequential matched subspace-based detectors are developed to identify sources in the spatial domain and estimate their angles of-arrival (AOAs). A closed-form expression for the detection probability of the proposed detector is derived. Following AOA acquisition, beamforming is applied to mitigate multipath and interference from co-channel transmitters, ensuring that the estimated beacon corresponds solely to the desired source. Tracking loops are designed to refine and maintain AOAs, Doppler, and beacon estimates. Experimental results with real 5G signals on a ground vehicle show that the BBN receiver can detect two co-channel base stations (gNBs), one of which was otherwise undetectable with state-of-the-art blind receiver. Navigation observables extracted from the 5G gNBs via the BBN were used to estimate the vehicle's 408 m trajectory, achieving a position root mean squared error (RMSE) of 7.1 m, which is significantly lower than the 32.3 m achieved with state-of the-art blind receiver and the 11.7 m with the conventional opportunistic 5G navigation receiver. Experimental results are also presented using real digital television (DTV) signals collected on a ground vehicle in a multipath environment, marking the first demonstration of blind tracking with DTV signals and highlighting the signal-structure-agnostic nature of the proposed BBN receiver.

title: Cloud Services Cyberattacks: Most Infectious Viruses and Method of Infections
authors: Khaled M. Musa, Mohammad Abdallah
abstract: Cyberattacks make cloud services and computer systems vulnerable to increasing risk to losing data, information, or loss of control of cloud services or computer systems. All cyberattacks can be caused through several types of viruses, worms, trojan horses, or cyberattacks. There are different methods of infections or separate ways that we get attacked. In this research we will look into the most recent infections of virus attacks with their percentage of information through a virus list gathered from a leading virus protection company Kaspersky lab. The research will look into the recent caused infections method to be to implement the most effective security mechanism to protect our data, information and system or cloud services.

title: Optimized Machine Learning Classifiers for Automatic Modulation Recognition of Digital Signals
authors: Pukkela Pragati, Komala Mallikarjunaiah, Mallikarjunaswamy Srikantaswamy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Presently, Automatic Modulation Recognition (AMR) recognizes the signal types in communication systems for effective demodulation and decoding. Due to the growth of signal complexity in digitally modulated schemes like M-ary Frequency Shift Keying (MFSK), M-ary Phase Shift Keying (MPSK), and M-ary Quadrature Amplitude Modulation (MQAM), more tenacious models need to be fit into a classification process. Classically, Maximum Likelihood (ML), Wavelet Transform (WT), and Higher-Order Statistical (HOS) features have traditionally been employed to make estimations toward AMR. However, these approaches usually suffer from some serious drawbacks, such as high computational complexity, poor adaptability to noise, and degraded performance in dynamic wireless environments. In this context, an enhanced machine learning-based automatic modulation recognition (EML-AMR) model is proposed, empowered by advanced feature extraction and deep learning-based classifiers. Our work proposes a hybrid convolutional neural network and long short-term memory (CNN-LSTM) network that improves modulation recognition by efficiently learning time-frequency characteristics. It remarkably improves the accuracy, speeds up the process, and it is robust against noise. Experimental analysis demonstrates that the EML-AMR model is far better than traditional methods by improving the classification accuracy by 0.17%, reducing the computational complexity by 0.22%, and improving the real-time signal detection efficiency by 0.15%. Such advances make the proposed model highly suitable for practical applications in spectrum monitoring, military communications, and intelligent signal processing.

title: Machine learning-driven prediction of optimal design parameters for ripple carry adder
authors: Samriddh Kumar Singh, Shobhit Mittra, Neha Singh, Shilpi Birla
abstract: Adder circuits are fundamental building blocks in digital electronics and computing systems with applications in basic arithmetic operations to complex computational tasks. Their performance is often limited by propagation delay, area, and power trade-offs. This paper focuses on exploring a machine learning (ML) driven multi-target regression approach for optimizing key design parameters of adders, specifically a ripple carry adder (RCA). Using artificial intelligence (AI) methodologies for automated very large scale integration (VLSI) design optimization will contribute to saving design time for energy efficient sustainable innovations to widen the horizons of computing and communication technologies in the observable future. A dataset containing 8000 datapoints for delay and power consumption of RCA design with different transistor sizes and supply voltages is generated using simulation program with integrated circuit emphasis (SPICE) circuit simulation at 32nm technology node. Multi-target based regression is then used to predict optimal device dimensions and supply voltage, for delay and power constraints. Experimental results demonstrate R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.984, root mean square error (RMSE) of 20.96 and a mean square error (MAE) of 11.37 between the predicted and actual design parameters. This approach provides efficient parameter exploration for optimized and efficient design and operation of digital and analog circuits with different features.

title: Wideband Chebyshev-Distributed Quasi-TTD 3×4 Beamforming Network for Low-Sidelobe and Frequency-Invariant Beam Pointing
authors: Shuo Li, Hongmei Liu, Yao Meng, Zhongbao Wang, Shaojun Fang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A wideband 3×4 beamforming network (BFN) is presented, integrating a 3×4 Blass-like matrix with Chebyshev amplitude distribution for low sidelobe levels (SLLs) and a 4×4 phase-compensation network to ensure frequency-invariant beam pointing. Phase shifters with adjustable phase-slope are introduced to flatten the phase response of the Blass-like matrix, and further to realize quasi–true-time-delay characteristics for the overall BFN. A prototype operating at 5.8 GHz was fabricated and measured, showing an output amplitude ratio of 0.332:1:1:0.332, an amplitude imbalance of 1.5 dB, and a linear phase error of 10° over a 31% bandwidth. The BFN enables a multi-beam antenna array to achieve low SLLs of -15 dB and stable beam pointing from 4.9 GHz to 6.7 GHz, validating its effectiveness for wideband multi-beam applications.

title: Research on feature extraction and analysis of machine tool vibration signal based on wavelet transform
authors: Kun Yang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The vibration signal of machine tool contains abundant information of equipment running state, and its accurate feature extraction and analysis are of great significance to ensure machining accuracy and prevent faults. In this paper, a signal feature extraction method based on wavelet transform and FFT is proposed. Taking high-precision CNC machine tools as the research object, the vibration signals of machine tool spindle box and tool holder in Y and Z directions under certain working parameters are analyzed. Through the wavelet decomposition of the vibration signal in the Y and Z, the approximate coefficients and detail coefficients of different scales are obtained. The analysis results show that the low frequency part of the spectrum in the $\mathbf{Y}$ direction of the spindle box is mainly distributed in the $319 \mathrm{~Hz}-725 \mathrm{~Hz}$. There is large amplitude in the 1450 Hz. The frequency part of the Z direction of the spindle box is mainly distributed at $224 \mathrm{~Hz}, 435 \mathrm{~Hz}-725 \mathrm{~Hz}$. When the frequency is 2901 Hz, the maximum amplitude is 0.016. The vibration is mainly caused by the excitation of the cutting force.

title: Is 1+1 Greater Than 2? The Synergistic Effect of Blockchain and Artificial Intelligence on Consumer Perceptual and Experiential Needs
authors: Yanji Duan, Qingyun Zhu, Joseph Sarkis
abstract: This study investigates whether combining blockchain and artificial intelligence (AI) enhances consumer value and creates synergies in reverse logistics operations in a retail setting. Using a behavioral experiment with 250 participants on a simulated e‑commerce platform featuring blockchain only, AI only, or their combination while searching for returned product‑logistics information. Two dimensions of consumer outputs were assessed: perceptual outcomes—attitude toward the firm and repurchase intention—and experiential outcomes—task completion time and accuracy. Results indicate a clear perceptual complementarity. Integrating blockchain's verifiable transparency with AI‑driven personalization significantly strengthened consumer sustainability perceptions and willingness to repurchase relative to single‑technology conditions. Differently, experiential effects diverged. Combining both technologies increased task completion time, and did not significantly improve accuracy, revealing performance substitutability rather than synergy. These findings refine complementarity theory by demonstrating that a technology bundle can simultaneously yield positive perceptual spillovers and negative experiential trade‑offs. Retailers are therefore advised to adopt the blockchain–AI pairing when strategic objectives center on trust and brand perceptions but to simplify the interface when operational speed is important. Robustness checks were completed to further establish rigor in the results. Our study also provides actionable insights for managers, emphasizing the prioritization of technology adoption, the importance of bundling blockchain with AI, and the differentiation between perceptual and experiential synergies to maximize consumer value in retail operations.

title: Road Vehicle Detection and Tracking using DeepLearning with YoloV6 and DeepSort
authors: Thandu Asha Latha, Niteesha Sharma, S Vijay Kumar, Karka Sainihar, G Sai Chandana, Kasam Ajay
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The cities face significant problems with vehicles running into each other while many drivers struggle with both traffic congestion and road safety issues which demand effective systems for vehicle tracking. This system implements YOLOv6 as its real-time object detection component while utilizing Deep SORT for tracking observed vehicles. The system deploys Tkinter for building its user interface that enables interface features for system control Video-driven training enables the model to identify and follow cars and trucks which results in live traffic observation. YOLOv6 stands as an advanced deep learning detection model which detects vehicles with precision and Deep SORT operates through deep learning techniques to maintain tracking of vehicles across multiple frames. The application runs deep learning computations through TensorFlow while performing video handling duties through OpenCV. The tracking mechanism utilizes active tracking to register the movement routes of surveillance vehicles for graphic presentation. The system delivers crucial benefits to both traffic surveillance operations and automated traffic management systems and intelligent transportation solutions. Visually unobstructed GUI implementation based on Tkinter lets users operate between model loading and video uploading functions while viewing detection and tracking results. Real-time processing becomes possible due to GPU acceleration features in this implementation design. The proposed system proves its worth as a monitoring instrument for tracking road traffic patterns and detecting vehicle movements to support traffic enforcement and accident detection and congestion evaluation functions. The precise and effective operation of YOLOv6-Deep SORT creates a dependable system for performing real-time vehicle tracking and detection in the field.

title: A Reinforcement Learning - Based Method for Evaluating Track Quality in Radar Systems
authors: Yicheng Yao, Zhigang Wang, Qinglin Zheng, Huaxing Kuang, Shikun Li, Feng Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In radar track initiation and tracking, clutter causes massive false tracks, as the system misidentifies clutter signals as targets. Excessive false tracks degrade system accuracy and reliability, making accurate clutter identification critical. Traditional evaluation methods relying on numerical calculations or threshold settings fail in cluttered complex scenarios with poor environmental adaptability. To address this, this paper proposes a reinforcement learning - based track quality evaluation method, comprising a radar video - input evaluation model and reinforcement learning. The model takes multi - cycle radar video, uses CNN to extract spatiotemporal features, and outputs track quality variations. Reinforcement learning trains the model to adaptively adjust each track’s quality, solving the difficulty in accurately dividing true track quality values. Experiments show the model effectively evaluates track quality and suppresses false tracks during initiation and tracking.

title: Enhanced Track-Before-Detection for OTH Radar with Range Walk Migration Correction
authors: Nanlin Huang, Haoqi Wu, Hongzhi Guo, Zhihang Wang, Zishu He
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper investigates the detection and tracking performance of the weak airborne target in over-the-horizon (OTH) radar during extended coherent integration time (CIT), especially the critical challenge of range walk migration (RWM) in performance. To address the significant performance degradation caused by RWM, two novel track-before-detection (TBD) methods are proposed that synergistically combine coherent and noncoherent integration approaches. Firstly, the prior kinematic constraints (KC) is utilized to divide echo data into virtual frames containing coherent pulses, and then RWM correction is performed based on the maximum one-range-cell movement constraint through range-domain pulse circular shifting (CS). For scenarios where precise range cell migration is unknown, the segmented Keystone transform (SK) is proposed to correct the RWM. Both methods perform moving targets detection (MTD) processing within frame to achieve coherent integration and incorporate dynamic programming-TBD (DP-TBD) across frames for robust noncoherent integration. Simulation results show that both methods can effectively enhance the target detection and tracking capability, which is better than the conventional competitors.

title: Interpretable and Efficient PDE Solving Via Multitask Symbolic Regression
authors: Yipeng Huang, Dejun Xu, Zexin Lin, Yunpeng Gong, Hao Lan, Wei Guo, Min Jiang, Zhenzhong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Partial Differential Equations (PDEs) are fundamental mathematical tools for describing natural phenomena in scientific computing and engineering modeling, with wide applications in fields such as fluid dynamics, heat transfer, and electromagnetism. However, existing PDE solvers often lack interpretability and are restricted to solving individual equations separately, making them inefficient for real-world applications that require simultaneous solutions of multiple structurally similar PDEs. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a multitask symbolic regression approach that leverages the underlying similarity in the solution spaces of structurally identical but parametrically different PDEs. The proposed method not only ensures interpretability but also accelerates the simultaneous solution of multiple PDEs by leveraging latent similarities among them. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the method not only achieves better accuracy than baselines on representative PDE benchmarks but also offers substantial improvements in computational efficiency.

title: Adaptive Cyber-Attack Detection and Mitigation in Atm Networks Using Network Motif Discovery, Machine Learning, Smote, and Hybrid Whitelisting-Blacklisting Strategies
authors: Ivy Payne Nkrumah, Robert A. Sowah, Percy Okae
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: As cyber threats continue to evolve in sophistication and scale, the need for robust and adaptive security mechanisms becomes increasingly critical, particularly for critical infrastructures such as ATM networks. This research explores innovative methodologies for detecting and mitigating cyber-attacks through the use of network motif discovery and machine learning (ML) techniques. The study focuses on applying graph-based algorithms to identify recurrent subgraph patterns (motifs) in network traffic, enabling the detection of novel attack behaviors. To address the challenge of class imbalance in network traffic data, the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) is employed to generate synthetic samples for underrepresented attack classes, thereby improving classifier performance. Additionally, a novel hybrid approach that combines whitelisting and blacklisting strategies is proposed for effective attack mitigation. The proposed methodology is evaluated using real-world network traffic data, with performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and ROC AUC to assess the system's effectiveness. The results reveal that the model achieves a perfect accuracy of 1.00, with precision, recall, and F1-scores of 1.00 for both normal and attack traffic. The confusion matrix confirms zero false positives and false negatives, while the hybrid whitelisting/blacklisting strategy enhances the system's robustness in real-time attack detection and mitigation. This research contributes to the field of cybersecurity by providing a scalable and adaptive solution for real-time attack detection in dynamic network environments, offering substantial potential for securing critical infrastructure systems such as ATMs.

title: Degradations of Gamma-Irradiated SiC MOSFETS under Repetitive Short-Circuit Stress
authors: Haoshu Tan, Haochen Wang, Lin Zhang, Pei Li, Hong Tao, Juntao Li, Bing Huang, Peng Dong
abstract: SiC MOSFETs are expected to be exposed to irradiation when applied in harsh environments such as space. Therefore, it is important to understand the ionization radiation effects on the short-circuit (SC) reliability of SiC MOSFETs. In this work, the degradation modes and degradation mechanisms in the atomic scale of Gamma-irradiated SiC MOSFETS under repetitive short-circuit stress are investigated. Compared to single-stress scenarios, the synergistic effect of irradiation and short-circuit stress significantly accelerates the negative shift of threshold voltage of irradiated devices and thus results in the degradations of switching performances. The cyclic SC stress results in the dominate hole trapping in the oxide over the annealing of active oxide defects from the self-heating. The Electro-thermal simulations and Hybrid-functional density functional theory (DFT) calculations are performed and demonstrate that the hole injection into the oxide and the subsequent hole trapping by electrically active oxygen vacancies (VO) are main cause for the enhanced formation of positively charged oxide-trap after irradiation and SC stress, where the irradiation and repetitive SC stress promote the structural transformation of VO and hole trapping of VO by overcoming the thermal barrier, respectively.

title: Hydrotwin: Capturing the Heartbeat of the Ocean
authors: Tiago Gomes, Alberto Santos, Joachim Vanneste, Astrid van Toor, Carolina Ramos, Daniele Aromatario, Rita Carriço, Erica Cruz, Guilherme Vaz
abstract: The underwater sounds cape provides valuable information about the marine environment. By listening to natural and anthropogenic sounds one can learn about the presence of certain species, ecosystem changes and the impact of human-related activities. Listening to the ocean is a cost-intensive task in terms of equipment, logistics and human resources. The status quo is still based on recording equipment that is deployed for several months, with data recovery only at the end. If the equipment remains functional and is successfully retrieved, operators are faced with large volumes of audio data, typically analysed on a few research goals. Much of this analysis still relies on manual review. To reduce the effort and uncertainties associated with such activities and providing a more holistic approach to this topic, the Hydrotwin technology has been developed. Powered with Artificial Intelligence-based software and optimised for real-time performance, Hydrotwin Intelligence can completely automate the analysis of acoustic data. Analysis results are stored in the cloud and presented to stakeholders in a data-rich dashboard. While hardware-agnostic, Hydrotwin also offers its own acoustic recorders that are powered by Hydrotwin Intelligence, HT-S and HT-C. This technology enables continuous and autonomous detection and geolocation of biological and anthropogenic sound sources. Integrated with acoustic virtual models, produced with RAINDROP, Hydrotwin offers a holistic Digital Twin of the Ocean that can be used for the monitoring and management of offshore assets and operations.

title: Flight Courses Automatic Recognition Algorithm of Space Target Based on Trajectory Data
authors: Xuehai Tang, Haiguang Li, Hui Wang, Xianbo Zhang, Zhi Qi, Ying Sun
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: In response to the demand for automated realtime data processing systems in flight tests of space targets and satellite launch missions, the third-order B-spline least squares curve fitting algorithm was used to achieve outlier replacement and random error separation of trajectory measurement data; By analyzing the motion characteristics of different flight courses of space targets, and calculating the acceleration and velocity inclination angle of targets in real time based on target trajectory measurement data, automatic recognition of different flight courses such as powered flight phase, free flight phase, gliding (cruising) flight phase, and reentry flight phase of targets has been achieved; Furthermore, based on the two body motion model, the elliptical orbit parameters of the target were calculated, realizing satellites and reentry targets recognition. The above algorithms can be applied to automated real-time data processing systems.

title: Memristive Dynamical Spiking Neural Networks with Spatiotemporal Heterogeneity
authors: Xinming Shi, Peng Zhou, Connlaoth McTaggart, Xin Yao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: We propose a fully memristive spiking neural network (MSNN) that incorporates spatiotemporal heterogeneity to improve temporal representation and fault tolerance. In our proposed work, each neuron possesses a distinct time constant (spatial heterogeneity) that evolves over time in response to input stimuli (temporal heterogeneity), enabling diverse, adaptive, and temporally rich responses. Both synaptic and neuronal behaviors are modeled using SPICE-level analog memristors, and the network is trained end-to-end using backpropagation through time (BPTT) in a differentiable framework. This approach eliminates the need for digital interfacing circuits such as ADCs or explicit comparators, supporting compact and efficient hardware deployment. Evaluations on the MNIST and DVS128 Gesture datasets show competitive accuracy and significantly improved robustness to hardware faults, such as stuck-at errors in RRAM cells. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of spatiotemporally heterogeneous MSNNs for scalable, reliable neuromorphic computing.

title: MDCPP: A Meta-Learning Dual-Path Framework for Causal and Uncertainty-Aware Radar Effectiveness Indicator Selection
authors: Jingxian Yang, Yibin Rui
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: We propose the Meta-Dual-Path Causal Probabilistic Processor (MDCPP), a meta-learning framework for dynamic and interpretable radar effectiveness indicator selection. Unlike conventional static evaluation methods, MDCPP adopts a dual-path architecture to separately model task-related and environment-induced factors, enabling fine-grained disentanglement of performance drivers. The framework incorporates an adaptive Bayesian MAML optimizer with orthogonality, entropy, and causal regularization to promote generalization and interpretability. Monte Carlo sampling is used to derive posterior estimates and confidence intervals for indicator weights, allowing uncertainty-aware decision-making. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that MDCPP consistently outperforms classical approaches in adaptability, robustness, and accuracy, making it well-suited for evaluation in dynamic and uncertain operational environments.

title: Easy-Flowgorithm: A Web-Based Tool Towards STEM Problem Solving Skills Development
authors: Ricardo Vardasca, Luís Beirante, Marco Tereso, Domingos Martinho, António Pratas, Fernando Bento
abstract: The development of problem-solving skills within Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) disciplines is essential and can be a differentiating factor in the future success within the professional roles associated with them. The use of tools such as flowcharts and pseudocode allow design of solutions to complex problems step by step and provide students with a dual approach for that. It is aim of this research to design implement and assess a web-based tool allowing flowchart and pseudocode design of problem solution providing correspondence between those tools. The web application developed is simple, intuitive, accessible and easy to use. It can be an important asset for students at their initial stage of STEM disciplines aiding them to develop important skills that would be useful in their learning process development and future professional path.

title: Topology and Electromagnetic Force Analysis of Dual-Stator Bidirectional Modulation Machines
authors: Yutong Zheng, Yiduan Chen, Siyang Zhang
abstract: This article presents a systematic classification of topologies for dual-stator field modulation machines (DS-FMMs), based on rotor types—namely permanent magnet, iron pole, and consequent-pole—and modulation methods, distinguishing between unidirectional and bidirectional approaches. Two variants of dual stator hybrid multi-excitation machines (DS HMEM-I and DS HMEM-II) are utilized as case studies to illustrate and summarize the various topologies and operating principles associated with bidirectionally modulated machines. Subsequently, an analysis is conducted on the magnetic field modulation effects and air-gap harmonic components of DS-HMEM-I and DS-HMEM-II, comparing their electromagnetic performance against other DS-FMMs. Finally, a radial electromagnetic force analysis is performed on the superior DS-HMEM-I, highlighting the effects of field-modulation harmonics. The findings indicate that DS-HMEM-I exhibit high torque capability and efficiency; furthermore, the interaction among multiple harmonics generates a complex radial electromagnetic force wave characterized by significant amplitude

title: A Physics-Regularized Neural Surrogate Framework for Printed Memristors
authors: Sorin Liviu Jurj
abstract: Printed memristors offer a pathway to low-cost, flexible neuromorphic hardware, but their variability and filamentary switching pose challenges for fast, accurate device modeling. We introduce a Physics-Regularized Neural Surrogate (PRNS) for printed memristors, combining data-driven learning with physics-based regularization terms (masked Ohmic/Space-Charge Limited Current (SCLC) constraints and Ordinary Differential Equation (ODE) consistency). While classical Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) enforce governing equations through differentiable Partial Differential Equation (PDE)/ODE residuals, here physical relations act as regularization rather than hard constraints. The model embeds Ohmic conduction, SCLC, and interfacial transport equations into network training while explicitly handling device-to-device variability via parameter perturbation and noise injection. We validate the approach on a literature-calibrated synthetic dataset representative of flexographically printed Ag/PMMA:PVA/ITO devices, achieving relative Root Mean Square Error (RRMSE) of 0.0633 versus 0.2730 for the Voltage-ThrEshold Adaptive Memristor (VTEAM) model (4.31× improvement). Cross-validation yields RRMSE 0.115 ± 0.062, with stability under 10% added noise. Extended validation across digitized I-V curves from three printed memristor technologies (inkjet-printed IGZO, aerosol-jet MoS₂, paper-based MoS₂/graphene) demonstrates competitive or superior accuracy versus VTEAM, Yakopcic, Stanford-PKU, and MMS models. Supplementary experiments (15 tests) confirm comprehensive reliability modeling including temperature-dependent retention (activation energy Eₐ = 0.379 eV), endurance degradation (660-cycle lifetime), and electro-thermal coupling effects. Circuit integration via one-transistor-one-resistor (1T1R) memory cell simulation shows 29% lower write energy (94.2 pJ vs. 133.6 pJ) with gradual analog switching. The formulation supports SPICE-compatible lookup table (LUT)/behavioral export; all code and datasets are released openly for reproducibility.

title: Bayesian Attention-Based Stacked Autoencoder for Quality Prediction in Industrial Processes
authors: Yuhang Xia, Zhengyangfan Fang, Yi Huang, Jingsheng Qing, Lingjian Ye, Lang Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a Bayesian attention-based stacked autoencoder (BASAE) soft sensor for industrial processes. The BASAE model dynamically evaluates the predictive contribution of each hidden layer and adaptively allocates attention weights through an online Bayesian soft attention mechanism (BSAM), significantly enhancing prediction accuracy. Unlike traditional stacked autoencoders (SAE), the BASAE more effectively extracts hierarchical features that are highly relevant to critical quality variables. To validate its superiority, the proposed method is applied to an industrial debutanizer column, where it demonstrates outstanding performance in predicting key quality indicators, showcasing both improved robustness and interpretability in complex industrial environments.

title: Unsupervised LPI Signals Detection Under Clutter Background Based on Autoencoding Vision Transformer
authors: Sheng Mao, Xia Wu, Xiangyu Fan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Recent years have witnessed increasing complexity of electromagnetic environments, and the low probability of intercept (LPI) radar signals are challenging to be detected. Performance of traditional analytic methods are often limited due to the influence of parametric mismatch, and supervised deep learning methods require a large amount of labeled data, which is also compromised under practical circumstances. To solve these problems, this paper proposes an unsupervised detection method based on the framework of autoencoding Vision Transformer (AE-ViT). The signals from target background are used for training, aiming at the reconstruction; in the detection stage, the LPI signals can be detected for high reconstruction error. Simulation results show that the proposed AE-ViT method outperforms the traditional methods.

title: Spin Estimation and 3D Geometry Reconstruction using Multi-perspective Space-borne Sub-THz Interferometric Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar
authors: Bangjie Zhang, Marina S. Gashinova, Marco Martorella
abstract: Sub-terahertz (sub-THz) radar enables high-resolution and highly detailed imaging of space objects, offering substantial advantages for space domain awareness (SDA). Accurate estimation of spin motion and three-dimensional (3D) geometry of non-cooperative space targets is essential for SDA tasks such as target characterization, autonomous rendezvous and proximity operation (RPO), and debris removal. Interferometric ISAR (InISAR), which generates 3D images in the form of point clouds, can also resolve the effective rotation vector—defined as the component of the total rotation vector perpendicular to the line of sight (LOS). This component is critical for 2D image scaling and for enhancing understanding of the imaging projection plane (IPP). However, the component along the LOS remains unknown, which limits the ability to fully exploit multi-perspective ISAR imaging to characterize targets. In this paper, a novel spin estimation framework is proposed based on multi-perspective InISAR, which leverages viewing angle diversity during on-orbit observation to resolve the total rotation vector of space targets. The proposed method performs InISAR imaging and the estimation of the effective rotation vector for each perspective, followed by the combination of effective rotation vectors to determine the total rotation vector as a unified least-squares solution. The framework requires no prior 3D model and achieves robust spin estimation. Both simulation experiments using sub-THz radar parameters and laboratory validation using W-band radar are carried out to verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating its potential for future SDA and on-orbit servicing applications.

title: A Symbiotic 5G-IoT Demonstration Platform with Network Slicing and Hardware Simulation Capability
authors: Tracey Kah-Mein Lee, Zhi-Ao Cheng, Nan Jia, Hoe-Heng Tan, Yong-Thiang Ng, Chee-Wai Chan, David Hee, Saeid Sanei
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The world has eagerly embraced 5G technology, which makes significant strides in mobile communications. However, the full benefits of $\mathbf{5 G}$ hardware, particularly in massive sensor communications and very low latency applications, have not yet been fully realized. Also the current costs of new 5 G hardware are quite high, requiring users to optimally configure their systems. To help users navigate these challenges we propose SymbIoTic5G, a novel hardware-based $\mathbf{5 G}$ industrial experimentation testbed. Our novelty stems from using commercially available 5 G infrastructure as far as possible, using programmable network switches to emulate unavailable $\mathbf{5 G}$ features. It enables realistic, scalable testing without the cost of full physical deployments. Our main contributions include i) AIdriven communication resource allocation tested on two strategies to optimize quality of service, and ii) scalable sensor simulation framework that realistically preserves physical and statistical sensor properties. In combining AI, sensor emulation, and real-world 5G, SymbIoTic5G bridges the gap between theory and deployment, offering a cost-effective platform for next-generation industrial network research.

title: Cross-border E-commerce Product Listing Compliance Identification by Integrating Large Language Models and Hybrid Retrieval Technology
authors: Shuang Wu, Xing-Rong Fan, Run Zeng, Lin Zhang, Jinshan Ran, Bo Liu
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Big Data and Internet of Things
abstract: None

title: Enhancing Shared Vehicle Management with AI: A Study on Interior Damage Detection Models
authors: Sandra Dixe, Cátia Loureiro, Beatriz Miranda, Diana Ferreira, Tiago Aston, Duarte Fernandes, Hugo Peixoto
abstract: Sustainable urban mobility, promoted by shared vehicles, has gained attention as a solution to reduce carbon emissions and facilitate transportation in cities. However, man-aging these vehicles presents challenges, such as internal damage caused by vandalism or improper use. This study evaluates the effectiveness of different Artificial Intelligence (AI) approaches for automatic interior damage detection in shared vehicles, considering their specific characteristics, such as compact and urban-oriented designs. The research also investigates whether the public dataset used, consisting of images of vehicle interiors with and without damage, is suitable for this scenario, given that shared vehicles may differ from conventional cars. Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) approaches, such as YOLOv5, YOLOv7, YOLOv8, YOLOv10 and RTMDet, as well as transformer-based models like RT-DETR and Dino, and hybrid approaches incorporating attention mechanisms, such as YOLO-NAS, were analyzed. The key question is whether damage detection in shared vehicles can generalize to highly variable images in this dataset. The diversity of vehicle interiors, including differences in materials, lighting conditions, and structural configurations, presents a significant challenge for AI. Ensuring accurate damage detection despite this variability is crucial for practical applications. Therefore, it is essential to assess not only model accuracy but also their ability to generalize to new vehicle configurations not represented in the dataset. Furthermore, this study provides insights into the necessary next steps for developing a robust and effective damage detection service, contributing to better management and maintenance of shared vehicle fleets.

title: ISAC Waveform Design via QPSK Watermarking in Wavelet Domain
authors: Yihao Cai, Jing Yang, Liangting Zhan, Xianxiang Yu, Guolong Cui
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technology has attracted significant attention in recent years. This paper proposes a novel dual-function radar-communication (DFRC) waveform design method that embeds communication watermark information in radar waveforms by exploiting discrete wavelet transform (DWT) and quadrature phase shift keying (QPSK) modulation. The proposed method utilizes DWT to perform multiscale decomposition of radar waveforms, embeds QPSK-modulated communication watermarks into highfrequency wavelet coefficients, and thereby achieves covert information modulation while preserving radar detection performance. Simulation results demonstrate that compared to discrete Fourier transform (DFT)-based watermarking methods, the proposed method achieves a lower bit error rate (BER). Furthermore, the detection results of the watermarked waveform remain nearly comparable to the original signal, ensuring robustness and practicality of the proposed scheme in DFRC applications.

title: Broad Learning System with Robust Adaptive Kernel
authors: Xin Lu, Haiquan Zhao, Jinhui Hu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: For the performance degradation problem of broad learning system (BLS) in non-Gaussian noise environment, the variant of BLS based on M-estimator shows good robust performance. However, in most cases, the determination of the optimal loss function is often very time-consuming due to the lack of prior knowledge of the sample data. Therefore, this paper constructs a variant of BLS based on adaptive robust kernel (ARBLS) to improve the generalization performance of the model in non-Gaussian noise environment. Adaptive robust kernel function is a general loss function that includes many common Mestimator paradigms. By alternately optimizing model weights and adaptive robust kernel parameters, AR-BLS realizes the adaptive adjustment of model robustness under different outlier noise distributions without human intervention. Simulation experiments on multiple public datasets and actual application scenarios verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Federated Learning with Robust Local Training for Noisy MRI-Based Mental Disorder Diagnosis
authors: Yao Hu, Rui Liu, Jibin Wu, Zhi-An Huang, Kay Chen Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: While deep learning-based computer-aided diagnosis (DL-CAD) model can identify mental disorders from neuroimages, its need for vast, private data creates a roadblock. Federated Learning (FL) solves the data access problem by enabling privacy-preserving collaboration, but it introduces a critical vulnerability that noisy labels from local clients can corrupt the global model. We develop a noise-resilient FL framework with robust local training, dubbed NRFL, to explicitly tackle noisy labels in FL for MRI-based mental disorder diagnosis. Within NRFL, a divide-and-conquer noisy label compensation approach is developed on the client side to mitigate the negative effects of noisy labels by combining the global knowledge. Subsequently, we utilize the FedAVG to aggregate the uploaded local model parameters on the server side. Empirical evaluations demonstrate that NRFL attains competitive results on the ABIDE-I and the ADHD-200 datasets under <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 \%}$</tex> noise.

title: Low Energy, Real Time Passive Acoustic Detection of Dolphin Clicks and Whistles
authors: Jeff Neasham, Richard Burnett, Gavin Lowes, Ben Sherlock, Per Berggren, Sarah Dickson
abstract: This paper describes the development of software algorithms and hardware for real time passive acoustic detection of dolphin clicks and whistles, with strong emphasis on low power implementation to allow long term deployment with a small alkaline battery pack. The objective is to produce an affordable and practical technology for live reporting of dolphin presence, via underwater acoustic communication or terrestrial/satellite radio link, to support mitigation of impact of offshore construction and fishing activity, as well as data for marine science. Highly computationally efficient algorithms were developed and validated by offline processing of acoustic recordings from the UK waters, annotated by expert bioacousticians. Accuracy of 98.3% and 99.7% was achieved for click and whistle detection respectively, with zero false positives. These algorithms have been successfully ported onto a proven ARM Cortex M4 based embedded processor platform, with a mean power consumption of only 12 mW, and tested by playback of the above recorded data. This has proven the feasibility of this approach and a full prototype system is being prepared for deployment in the sea trials at the time of writing.

title: Factorized VRFT: Proposal and Experimental Verification
authors: Ryuto Miyoshi, Yusuke Fujimoto, Takeshi Nishida
abstract: This paper discusses the data-driven model matching problem with a one-shot preliminary experiment. Although many methods, such as Virtual Reference Feedback Tuning (VRFT), have been proposed as a solution for this problem, they are nonconvex in general, i.e., convex only under the assumption on the structure of the feedback controller. This paper introduces a new method, named Factorized-VRFT (F-VRFT), as a solution for the above problem, where the cost function is convex for any linear controller. In particular, the cost function of F-VRFT is quadratic; thus, the optimal parameter is available explicitly. Furthermore, by leveraging this property, we show that the method can be easily extended to adaptive model matching. The effectiveness of this method is demonstrated through experiments with a practical motor

title: CoreEditor: Correspondence-constrained Diffusion for Consistent 3D Editing
authors: Zhe Zhu, Honghua Chen, Peng Li, Mingqiang Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Text-driven 3D editing is an emerging task that focuses on modifying scenes based on text prompts. Current methods often adapt pre-trained 2D image editors to multi-view observations, using specific strategies to combine information across views. However, these approaches still struggle with ensuring consistency across views, as they lack precise control over the sharing of information, resulting in edits with insufficient visual changes and blurry details. In this paper, we propose CoreEditor, a novel framework for consistent text-to-3D editing. At the core of our approach is a novel correspondence-constrained attention mechanism, which enforces structured interactions between corresponding pixels that are expected to remain visually consistent during the diffusion denoising process. Unlike conventional wisdom that relies solely on scene geometry, we enhance the correspondence by incorporating semantic similarity derived from the diffusion denoising process. This combined support from both geometry and semantics ensures a robust multi-view editing process. Additionally, we introduce a selective editing pipeline that enables users to choose their preferred edits from multiple candidates, creating a more flexible and user-centered 3D editing process. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of CoreEditor, showing its ability to generate high-quality 3D edits, significantly outperforming existing methods.

title: Machine Learning in Gas Sensing: A Paradigm Shift for Enhanced Detection and Selectivity – A Review
authors: Neeraj Dhariwal, Sakshi Bisht, Preety Yadav, Taro Ueda, Takeo Hyodo, Vinod Kumar
abstract: The incorporation of Machine Learning (ML) with gas sensing has brought a revolution in the field by greatly improving the sensing performance, detection accuracy and selectivity. Traditional gas sensors are typically limited by issues that include cross-sensitivity, drift, and environmental fluctuations, which affect their performance. This review investigates how these limitations have been countered using data and advanced algorithmic features in ML. The use of ML in gas sensing mainly involves important steps such as feature extraction and selection, as well as a variety of superior models like Support Vector Machine (SVM), Artificial Neural Network (ANN), and Random Forest (RF). These methodologies enable proper categorization of the types of gases involved, as well as qualitative regression for concentration estimation. The E-nose systems, which integrate gas sensors arrays with machine learning algorithms, are particularly noteworthy due to their ability to mimic the human olfactory system. This combination enables the detection and classification of complex gas mixtures with high accuracy, enhanced selectivity, and robustness against environmental variations—capabilities that conventional single-sensor systems often lack. These applications are most well-known in the fields of food quality inspection, disease detection, and environmental monitoring. Despite recent progress, there are gaps regarding systematic insights about mathematical algorithms, optimization of the gas sensors, and real-world applications of ML in the field of gas sensing. This study reveals that, by overcoming the current problems and proposing future research directions, this work greatly promotes the role of ML in improving the gas sensing technologies to build highly selective, sensitive, and robust sensing systems for various complicated, realistic applications.

title: Advancing Toward Deployable Sapphire Fiber Sensors: A Review of Emerging Sensing Techniques and Innovative Optical Cladding Strategies
authors: S. Narasimman, Koustav Dey, Chen Zhu, Rex E. Gerald, Jie Huang
abstract: Single-crystal sapphire optical fibers have emerged as promising candidates for sensing in extreme environments where conventional silica fibers fail, owing to their exceptional thermal stability, high mechanical strength, and broad optical transparency up to ∼2040 °C. Recent progress has extended sapphire fiber sensing into diverse domains, including temperature, pressure, strain, and chemical detection, yet significant challenges remain, particularly the highly multimode nature of these fibers and the absence of a robust cladding suitable for harsh conditions. This review provides a comprehensive overview of recent advances in sapphire fiber–based sensing technologies, with a primary focus on interferometric configurations and sapphire fiber Bragg grating–based sensors, while also briefly discussing emerging approaches such as distributed Raman and evanescent-field–based sensing. Special emphasis is placed on innovative optical cladding strategies, including spinel and ceramic coatings, ion implantation, nanoporous structures, and advanced oxide systems, which are evaluated in terms of thermal stability, refractive index compatibility, and fabrication scalability. Key challenges such as strain sensing at ultra-high temperatures, long-term stability, and reliable integration are critically examined. The review concludes by outlining future research directions focused on developing durable cladding systems, refining fabrication methods, and integrating hybrid sensing modalities to enable deployable sapphire fiber sensors for aerospace, energy, and industrial applications in extreme environments. The objective is to consolidate current knowledge and guide ongoing efforts to realize deployable sapphire fiber sensors for harsh environments.

title: Development of a Novel Laboratory-Scale Testbed for Measuring the Iron Loss in a DAB Converter
authors: Yu-Chen Su, Keiji Wada
abstract: This paper attempts to develop a new laboratory-scale testbed for measuring the iron loss within a dual-active-bridge (DAB) converter, particularly when using the transformer with a non-unity turns ratio. The regenerative construction is utilized to estimate the transformer under test, which is back-to-back connected to another transformer with the same turns ratio, enabling the usage of identical power converters on both sides. Accordingly, the proposed testbed uses two H-bridge converters fed by a common 50 V DC source and operated at a switching frequency of 20 kHz to feed two back-to-back connected transformers with a turns ratio of 1:7.8. With the help of power regeneration, the DC source needs only to cover the power loss rather than the power rating, thus reducing the burden of experimental equipment. However, the preliminary test results reveal two key issues that influence the measurement. To identify the root causes, theoretical discussions are conducted, and potential solutions are proposed in response to these two problems. The simulated waveforms are also provided and performed well in accordance with the experimental waveforms, and the iron loss measurement results are finally summarized to highlight that the developed system performs comparably to the actual DAB converter system. The proposed testbed is thus expected to be of practical value for transformer manufacturers to preliminarily measure the total iron loss of a DAB converter.

title: Federated Meta Learning for Cross-Domain Personalization with Partial Model Initialization
authors: Ayshika Kapoor, Dheeraj Kumar
publish: 2025 International Joint Conference on Neural Networks (IJCNN)
abstract: With the rapid deployment of edge devices, there has been growing concern over the privacy preservation of clients’ private data. Federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising solution that enables edge devices for collaborative model training without compromising data privacy, as the local datasets of clients are not shared directly. However, previous works have shown that the performance of conventional FL approaches significantly deteriorates when the data distributions across clients are heterogeneous or non-IID. Integrating personalization into FL addresses these challenges by adapting the global model to local data distributions, but existing personalized FL (PFL) frameworks often fail to generalize when clients’ datasets have cross-domain features. One approach to mitigate this challenge is partial model initialization, where to update clients’ local model only a subset of model parameters are initialized from the global model while retaining local parameters.
