However, obtaining effective generalization across distinct data distributions remains a challenge. In such instances, meta-learning is preferred as it provides the adaptation of a global model across distinct data distributions and tasks by employing only a small number of data samples. In this paper, we propose MetaPartialFL, a novel framework that integrates meta-learning with partial model initialization to address cross-domain personalization and heterogeneity in FL. The approach partitions model parameters into shared global and client-specific local components, enabling effective generalization across clients while maintaining adaptability to each client’s datasets. Extensive evaluations on cross-domain benchmark datasets, such as Office-Home, Office-31, PACS, and DomainNet, demonstrate that MetaPartialFL outperforms state-of-the-art methods, making it a robust and efficient solution for cross-domain FL applications.

title: Community Detection Based on Multi-Information Fusion of Motifs and Attributes
authors: Shuo Li, Chunlei Han, Hongbin Cao, Xinyue Luo, Xiangyi Teng, Jing Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Community detection in attributed networks is crucial for uncovering densely connected subgraphs, enabling a wide range of real-world applications such as recommendation systems and anomaly detection. While existing methods have successfully utilized network topology and node attributes for community detection, they often overlook two key challenges: (1) the importance of higher-order structures such as motifs, and (2) the limited discriminability between topological and attribute information. To address these limitations, we propose MIMA (Community detection based on Multi-Information Fusion of Motifs and Attributes), a novel community detection method that integrates multi-information sources. MIMA first constructs three distinct layers—the original topology layer, motif topology layer, and attribute layer—to capture low-order topology, higherorder topology, and node attribute information, respectively. These layers are then encoded using a graph variational autoencoder to generate more expressive node representations. Finally, the Hilbert-Schmidt Independence Criterion (HSIC) is introduced as a regularization constraint to enhance the independence between topological and attribute representations, thereby improving the robustness and accuracy of community detection. Extensive experimental results demonstrate the superiority of MIMA over state-of-the-art methods in attributed network community detection tasks.

title: Machine Learning Guided Prognostic Modeling in Multiple Sclerosis: A Data-Driven Framework
authors: Shrey Jha, Malladi Nanda Gopal, G Ramya, R Lavanya, S Viveka, K Deepa, Soubraylu Sivakumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: In this study, Mexican mestizo patients who were first diagnosed with clinically isolated syndrome (CIS) at the National Institute of Neurology and Neurosurgery (NINN) between 2006 and 2010 have their MS progression predicted using machine learning models. A diverse set of features-including clinical, demographic, neurophysiological, and MRIs data. The Multiple Sclerosis (MS) progression in patients was predicted using a range of machine learning models trained on clinical datasets. Five classifiers-CatBoost, Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Gradient Boosting-were evaluated using metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score. Among these, CatBoost emerged as the top-performing model, achieving 90% accuracy, 89% precision, 90 % recall, and an 89 % F1 score, reflecting strong generalization and balanced classification. Random Forest and Gradient Boosting also performed competitively, while SVM and Logistic Regression showed comparatively lower effectiveness. Confusion matrix analysis further confirmed CatBoost's superior predictive reliability with minimal misclassification. These results demonstrate the suitability of ensemble-based models-particularly CatBoost-for robust and clinically relevant MS progression detection.

title: A Mobile Robots Path Planning Algorithm Based on Evolutionary Decomposition Strategy
authors: Shiyao Feng, Fangqing Gu, Hailong Wang, Lei Chen, Zhihui Liang, Hao-Tian Wu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: This paper presents an efficient path-planning method for mobile robots in large-scale or complex search spaces utilizing an evolutionary decomposition strategy. The core innovation lies in decomposing the complex path-planning problem into manageable sub-problems through a redesigned evaluation function that optimizes key node selection. By implementing this divide-and-conquer approach with parallel processing capabilities, the method significantly enhances computational efficiency. The proposed approach integrates evolutionary mechanisms from genetic algorithms to further improve performance. Specifically, the method incorporates systematic redesigns of the coding scheme, the fitness function, the initial population generation strategy, and genetic operators, including selection, crossover, and mutation. Through iterative evolutionary updates, the population progressively converges toward globally optimal path solutions. Experimental validation demonstrates that the algorithm achieves substantial improvements in both optimization quality and computational efficiency, particularly when addressing largescale or complex path-planning tasks. The method exhibits strong adaptability across various scenarios and is highly practical for real-world applications, effectively balancing the optimality of the solution with computational performance.

title: DBFNM: Dual-Branch Fusion Network with Mamba Decoder for Indoor Depth Completion
authors: Yujie Diao, Zhisheng Wang, Jiayu Fan, Yuhua Cong, Quan Ouyang, Xin Tang, Rufei Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Accurate depth maps are essential for indoor navigation and modeling by robots, but raw depth maps often have missing areas due to sensor limitations, environmental factors, and distance constraints. Existing methods that fuse RGB images with depth maps usually cannot utilize spatial structural information and exhibit poor accuracy at object edges. To bridge this gap, a dual-branch fusion network with Mamba decoder, called DBFNM, is proposed for depth completion in this work. It consists of two complementary branches: one branch utilizes semantic and texture information from RGB images as visual guidance, while the other extracts spatial geometric structures from normal maps as structural guidance. In particular, a geometric gated encoder is utilized to fully leverage spatial information. In the dual-branch decoding stage, a dual-branch feature interaction alignment module is designed, which is composed of three components, including dual-branch edge feature alignment, dual-branch interaction, and global alignment. Then, the decoded dual-branch features are processed by a dual-modal fusion network based on a spatial propagation network to obtain dense depth map predictions. Extensive experimental results on the NYU-Depth V2 and SUN RGB-D datasets demonstrate that DBF achieves superior depth completion performance compared to existing methods in indoor scenes, particularly in handling large-scale missing depth regions and preserving edge details.

title: NexusSplats: An Efficient Approach for Robust Novel View Synthesis from Unstructured Image Collections
authors: Yuzhou Tang, Dejun Xu, Yongjie Hou, Yunpeng Gong, Zhenzhong Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Photorealistic 3D reconstruction of unstructured real-world scenes remains challenging due to complex illumination variations and transient occlusions. Existing methods based on Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) and 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) struggle with inefficient light decoupling and structureagnostic occlusion handling. To address these limitations, we propose NexusSplats, an approach tailored for efficient and high-fidelity 3D scene reconstruction under complex lighting and occlusion conditions. In particular, NexusSplats leverages a hierarchical light decoupling strategy that performs centralized appearance learning, efficiently and effectively decoupling varying lighting conditions. Furthermore, a structure-aware occlusion handling mechanism is developed, establishing a nexus between 3D and 2D structures for fine-grained occlusion handling. Experimental results demonstrate that NexusSplats achieves state-of-the-art rendering quality and reduces the number of total parameters by 65.4%, leading to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.7 \times$</tex> faster reconstruction.

title: Two-Step Weighted Least Squares Positioning Algorithm Based on AUV Navigation Velocity in Complex Underwater Acoustic Environments
authors: Jingxu Zhao, Feng Zhou, Zhaofeng Liu, Chi Cao, Xin Su
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper focuses on mobile positioning for autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) in complex underwater environments. The positioning algorithm based on time of arrival (TOA) assumes that the underwater acoustic communication between AUV and underwater sensors is real-time and reliable. The distance between the AUV and underwater sensors can be obtained through the time delay of acoustic signal transmission. However, the uncertain and complex nature of the underwater environment can cause underwater sensors to fail to receive acoustic signals from the AUV reliably. This leads to an insufficient effective observation data in the positioning solution process, causing underdetermined problems in the solution equation, and thus making it impossible to solve the AUV’s position information stably in real time. To overcome this problem, we frist established a positioning model considering the navigation velocity of the AUV. Based on this Model, we then proposed a two-step weighted least squares algorithm combined with a fast horizontal distance model for the deep sea (TWLS-HD-V). Furthermore, we derived the Cram´er-Rao Lower Bound (CRLB) of the proposed model and compared it with that of the basic model. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm was tested on both numerical simulations and deep-sea data. In conclusion, this algorithm effectively overcomes two key challenges in complex underwater environments: sound line bending and insufficient time delay information. As a result, it improves AUV positioning accuracy and ensures reliable positioning trajectories.

title: A Hybrid Approach for Blockchain DDoS Attack Detection: Stacked ELM Model with Lion Swarm Optimizer for Feature Selection
authors: Yogesh Ramaswamy, Zabiha Khan, Leeladhar Gudala, Santosh Reddy Addula, Praveen Veeramachaneni, Deepa Dawadi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: With the rapid adoption of blockchain knowledge across various domains, ensuring its security and availability against cyber threats has become a critical challenge. One prominent threats to blockchain networks is Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks, which can overwhelm network nodes, degrade system performance, and disrupt transactional processes. Traditional DDoS detection methods often suffer from high computational complexity, inefficient feature selection, and delayed response times, making them less suitable for real-time blockchain applications. To address these challenges, this study proposes a novel DDoS attack detection framework based on a Stacked Extreme Learning Machine (ELM) model with Lion Swarm Optimizer (LSO)-based feature selection. The LSO algorithm efficiently selects the most relevant features from network traffic data, reducing dimensionality and enhancing detection accuracy. By leveraging its swarm intelligence-based optimization capabilities, LSO improves the feature selection process, ensuring that the most significant attributes are retained while redundant or irrelevant ones are eliminated. This enhances computational efficiency and allows the model to process real-time traffic data with minimal latency. The Stacked ELM model, known for its fast-training speed and generalization ability, is employed as the classification mechanism to distinguish between normal and malicious traffic. By stacking multiple ELM layers, the model achieves deeper feature extraction, leading to improved classification performance. The combination of LSO-based feature selection and Stacked ELM ensures high accuracy, reduced false positive rates, and efficient detection of complex DDoS attack patterns targeting blockchain networks. Extensive experiments are conducted on benchmark datasets to evaluate the proposed framework’s performance in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The results demonstrate that the planned approach significantly outperforms traditional machine learning representations in detecting DDoS attacks with high efficiency and low computational overhead. The study concludes that integrating advanced feature selection techniques with deep learning-based classifiers provides a promising direction for securing blockchain networks against evolving cyber threats.

title: Machine Learning and Deep Learning approaches for Sentiment Analysis of Amazon
authors: Tanvir Auti, Zafar Dakhani, Hrushikesh Kulkarni, Prasad Pawar, Usha A. Jogalekar, Renuka Agrawal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The vast amount of data that is available online keeps growing exponentially as web technology advances. This proliferation encompasses both newly created data and already- existing material. The internet has developed into a central location for a number of activities, including opinion sharing, idea sharing, and online education. Amazon reviews have become one of these platforms' most useful sources for sentiment research. A multitude of unstructured and varied viewpoints, some neutral and some favourable and bad, are hosted on these sites. Based on the comparative study , we investigate in our survey both lexicon-based and machine- learning approaches to sentiment analysis for Amazon evaluations. We also investigate more general issues and uses of sentiment analysis on Amazon.com. By utilizing findings, our work clarifies these features and advances knowledge of opinion mining in the context of e-commerce platforms.

title: Co-Optimization of Resource Allocation and Operation in Large-Scale Energy Systems: Part I—Parallel-Distributed Theory
authors: Yuxiong Huang, Bingkai Huang, Gengfeng Li, Zicheng Dai, Zhaohong Bie
abstract: Integrated resource allocation across heterogeneous operators is imperative to achieve globally optimal planning in large-scale energy systems, yet faces fundamental barriers of computational intractability and stringent privacy protection requirements prohibiting sensitive data sharing. This paper develops a parallel-distributed framework resolving these dual challenges in large-scale planning-operation problems. Particularly, this complex problem is decomposed into two aspects: capacity optimization and location optimization. For the former, an enhanced equivalent projection (EP) technique handling mixed-integer optimization is employed, which compresses operator data into non-reconstructable proxies, reducing variables and ensuring privacy-essential security. For the latter, the location optimization leverages a tree-parallel Monte Carlo tree search (MCTS) algorithm that breaks commercial solvers’ resource utilization bottlenecks through asynchronous distributed computing, enabling previously intractable large-scale planning solutions. These innovations unify within a parallel-distributed framework where hierarchical planning center and operators coordination enables simultaneous privacy preservation through encrypted EP exchanges and computational acceleration via parallel MCTS processing. An illustrative example is presented at the end of this paper. In Part II, we deploy this methodology across integrated electricity-gas-heat systems and transmission-distribution networks, and verify its effectiveness in large-scale system planning.

title: Privacy-Preserving IoT Analytics using Federated Learning and Decentralized AI at the Edge
authors: T.B Sivakumar, S. Lavanya, Y.M. Mahaboob John, Nageswaran M K, S. Kaliappan, G. Manikandan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Advanced analytics solutions that address the privacy, latency, and efficiency issues present in traditional centralized systems are imperative due to the swift growth of IoT devices. Because their aggregate sensitive data and require longer data transfer times, existing approaches that rely on centralized data processing are set by serious privacy risks, high latency, and scalability issues. To get around these constraints, the article proposes a novel system that makes use of decentralized artificial intelligence at the edge and federated learning. Federated learning preserves privacy by sending only model updates, not raw data, whereas decentralized AI lowers latency by executing local real-time analytics. The proposed system showed significant improvements in data privacy as shown by a drop in data breaches from 15 to 4 and a drop-in data exposure rate to less than 10%. Latency reductions of up to 48% were achieved. The system's reliability in practical applications was further demonstrated by the improvement in computational efficiency that came with decreases in CPU, memory, and energy usage.

title: The Impact of Instance Reduction on Classification Process in Intrusion Detection
authors: Safaa Y. Al-Adwan, Salwani Abdullah, Mohammed AlWeshah, Wandeep Kaur
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) play a critical role in safeguarding computer networks and systems from security threats. However, the increasing volume of network traffic poses significant challenges in terms of computational efficiency and model performance. To address these challenges, this research investigates the impact of feature selection and instance reduction techniques on the performance of IDS. We employed a combination of feature selection methods (Boruta, XGBoost, ensemble methods, and genetic algorithms) and instance reduction techniques (cosine similarity-based filtering) to preprocess the UNSW-NB15 and NSL-KKD’99 datasets. The performance of various classification models, evaluated using accuracy and AUC metrics, was assessed on the original and reduced datasets. The results demonstrated that instance reduction significantly reduced the datasets size by approximately 48.8% and 51.63% less than the original datasets without compromising model performance. Feature selection further enhanced the accuracy and efficiency of the models. The combined application of these techniques offers a promising approach to improve the performance and scalability of IDS. This research contributes to the field of cybersecurity by providing insights into effective data preprocessing strategies for intrusion detection systems. Future research may explore the application of these techniques to other datasets and the development of more advanced feature selection and instance reduction methods.

title: Dynamic Demand Forecasting with ARIMA for Energy-Efficient Paging in 5G Networks
authors: Sushanta Meher, Bharat Jyoti Ranjan Sahu, Shatarupa Dash
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The evolution of 5G wireless networks demands energy-efficient communication systems while ensuring Quality of Service (QoS). Traditional paging mechanisms in static modes lead to suboptimal energy usage under dynamic traffic conditions. This research proposes a Dynamic Demand Forecasting Framework with ARIMA to predict user activity patterns and optimize real-time paging strategies. By leveraging ARIMA for accurate traffic demand prediction, the framework dynamically adjusts paging intervals, minimizes unnecessary signaling, and reduces energy consumption without compromising QoS. The proposed model integrates ARIMA’s time-series forecasting capabilities to adaptively respond to fluctuations in network traffic, enabling intelligent and energy-efficient paging. The framework is validated using traffic datasets and evaluated against existing static paging strategies. Results demonstrate significant energy savings and enhanced network performance, particularly in dynamic and high-density user environments. This work paves the way for intelligent, adaptive paging systems that align with the sustainability goals of 5G and beyond.

title: Collaborative VR Simulation for Familiarization and Training of Astronauts to Mars and Moon Missions
authors: Mariano Guida, Bogdan Sikorski, Paolo Leoncini
abstract: Virtual Reality, as an interface technology devised to immerse and interact in a virtual, synthetic reconstruction of an operational environment, has now reached the maturity to place astronauts in a simulated environment that closely resembles a planet to be explored, such as the Moon or Mars. Within the framework of a space exploration technology program, an immersive multiuser VR simulator has been developed by the VR team at the Italian Aerospace Research Center (CIRA). It leverages the latest VR tech to allow astronauts to familiarize themselves with other planets' environment and to start carrying out training activities. The main aim of this work is to raise stakeholder awareness about possibilities of a collaborative, haptics-assisted VR environment to take in charge more and more parts of an astronaut's skill preparation.

title: High-Accuracy Transformer-Based Procedure for Frequency Hopping Sequence Prediction
authors: Fuqiang Cao, Jie Zhong, Lin Xin
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Frequency-hopping communication is widely employed in modern secure communication systems due to its robust anti-jamming capabilities. Chaotic sequences, recognized for favorable statistical characteristics, are frequently utilized to generate frequency-hopping patterns. Phase space reconstruction of chaotic frequency hopping sequences effectively removes redundant information and preserves only the essential predictive components, thus enabling a clearer characterization of the sequence’s intrinsic dynamics. Leveraging these reconstructed sequences, the Transformer network captures crucial temporal dependencies while filtering out noise, resulting in significantly improved prediction accuracy. Therefore, in this paper, we propose a Transformer-based approach for frequency hopping sequence prediction. By forecasting three representative sequences, our proposed model attains minimal errors in evaluation metrics, and its prediction error distribution exhibits a tighter concentration near zero. This approach demonstrates superior accuracy and stability compared to conventional time series prediction methods, effectively validating its practical value in frequency hopping sequence prediction.

title: Analyzing the Operational Gaps in SAFUA: Simulation-Based Evaluation of Secure Automotive Firmware Update Protocols
authors: Hudaila Menal, Maria Imdad
abstract: The Secure Automotive Firmware Upgrade Approach (SAFUA) proposed a hierarchical authentication framework for in-vehicle systems, implementing the Unified Diagnostic Services (UDS) protocol to ensure secure firmware distribution (ECUs) via wireless transmission. However, despite claiming strong cryptographic potential in predicted lab conditions, SAFUA ignored the dynamic nature of real-world vehicular networks, such as latency, packet loss, and concurrent firmware delivery, which pose significant threats to both performance and safety. To explore these neglected dynamics, this research paper conducts a theoretical investigation using CAN-FD based firmware modeling under dynamic network and cryptographic workload conditions. This analysis demonstrates that SAFUA, although secure by design and structurally, turns operationally unreliable and risk prone under dynamic conditions, which reduces its effectiveness in time sensitive applications such as autonomous driving and safety critical ECU updates. Hence, this research recommends the implementation of adaptive key rotation mechanisms and cryptographic load-aware scheduling to improve SAFUA's system stability and address latency related flaws. Our research exposed substantial weaknesses: authentication failed in 23% of sessions under 10% packet loss, 17% of sessions exposed unencrypted retransmissions at risk to man-in-the-middle attacks, and latency surged by 81% during concurrent ECU updates, collectively compromising firmware integrity and delivery timing. Future work will focus on extending this evaluation using simulation tools like NS-3 and examining how SAFUA can integrate with standardized remote update ecosystems such as Uptane for end-to- end integrity assurance.

title: Design of Flexural Disk Hydrophone and Array Based on Textured Piezoelectric Ceramic
authors: Chunting Gu, Xinran Xu, Guangya Xie, Jiarong Wang, Xu Yang, Zhenyu Zheng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of large volume and low sensitivity of traditional piezoelectric ceramic hydrophones, a flexural disk hydrophone is designed using a new piezoelectric material - textured piezoelectric ceramic. A finite element model was established to simulate and calculate the receiving performance of the flexural disk hydrophone and the array, and the influence of material and size parameters on the receiving performance of the flexural disk hydrophone was analyzed. The calculation results show that, compared with the piezoelectric ceramic PZT-5H flexural disk hydrophone, the sensitivity of the textured piezoelectric ceramic flexural disk hydrophone has increased by more than 5dB.

title: Sensing-centric Secure Energy-efficient Beamforming Design for Integrated Sensing and Communication Systems
authors: Shuaijie Zhang, Yongbo Zhao, Derui Tang, Xiaoping Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The energy efficiency (EE) and security of integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems are of significant importance in practical applications, but relatively few current design schemes have considered both simultaneously. In this paper, we propose a secure and energy-efficient beamforming design for sensing-centric ISAC systems. Our objective is to maximize the EE of the sensing-centric system subject to constraints on the maximum permissible Cramér-Rao Bound (CRB) for extended target estimation, the minimum required signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) for legitimate users (LUs), the minimum outage probability for a potential passive eavesdropper (PE), and the maximum transmit power. To solve this non-convex fractional optimization problem, successive convex approximation (SCA) and semidefinite relaxation (SDR) techniques are employed after equivalent transformations. Simulation results demonstrate that, compared to conventional energy-efficient beamforming algorithms, the proposed beamforming algorithm achieves a higher secrecy rate, significantly enhances physical layer security (PLS), and exhibits applicability in more complex environments.

title: When Voice Meets Touch: Conflict Analysis in Mobile Applications
authors: Suwan Li, Lei Bu, Shangqing Liu, Guangdong Bai, Fuman Xie, Kai Chen, Chang Yue
abstract: The recent advancement of the automatic speech recognition (ASR) contributes to the voice user interface (VUI), which is broadly embedded into mobile apps. The VUI implemented on modern mobile operating systems like Android naturally involves multiple threads, and brings new race issues and challenges in defining and identifying them. Specifically, when the GUI and VUI (GV) actions both access to the same resource simultanously, the data race named GV-race may occur. GV-race can lead to wrong behavior and even crashes. However, to the best of our knowledge, this problem has not been adequately studied. In this paper, we present the first study of GV-race on Android apps. However, the involvement of the VUI complicates the concurrency model, affects the temporal relationship and brings state space explosion in global analysis. To tackle these challenges, we firstly define primitives and their happen-before rules to abstract GV interaction patterns. Using these primitives, we are able to characterize and formally define GV-race. We then develop Roma (GV-race detector on mobile apps) to detect both app-level and system-level GV-race automatically. Through static program analysis, Roma extracts GV related call graphs for each pair of conflicting GV actions to reduce the state space, and generates a universal GV interaction graph using our pre-defined primitives. It encodes happen-before constraints to formally specify the freeness of GV-race, so that the detection of GV-race can be reduced to constraint solving with SMT solvers. We apply Roma to analyze 266 apps. Roma finds 52 apps with app-level GV-race and 56 apps with system-level GV-race. We confirm that 101 apps are true positives.

title: The Signal Condition Unit for Electrostatic Monitoring in the Gas Path of Aeroengines
authors: Yidi Bai, Zhenhua Wen, Jiaxing Zhang, Weibo Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the characteristics of weak output signals and susceptibility to noise interference in aero-engine gas path electrostatic sensors, this paper designs an aero-engine gas path electrostatic monitoring signal conditioning unit. This paper presents a signal conditioning circuit for electrostatic signals, implemented using the high-input-impedance FET operational amplifier OPA828 and the low-noise instrumentation amplifier AD8421. This paper introduces the DSP28335 chip and achieves hardware-level integration of algorithms, such as time-domain AL feature extraction and FFT spectral analysis, by leveraging the DSP’s hardware multiplier with prioritized scheduling and parallel computing pipeline architecture. Experiments demonstrate that the designed signal conditioning unit effectively amplifies electrostatic signals while suppressing noise. By implementing hardware-integrated noise reduction and feature extraction algorithms, this unit transmits feature-extracted signals instead of raw data, achieving an $80 \%$ reduction in data transmission volume. This work provides a critical technological enabler for the lightweight and high-reliability airborne deployment of electrostatic monitoring technology.

title: Bearing Estimation for Acoustic Vector Array Near the Baffle Based on Sparse Reconstruction
authors: Hongyue Chen, Qing Wang, Xinyu Gu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper investigates high-resolution bearing estimation methods for vector linear arrays near the composite acoustic baffle. A sparse approximate minimum variance method tailored for vector arrays under planar baffle conditions is proposed. This approach incorporates baffle-adapted array steering vectors that account for acoustic vector field interactions with planar baffles, extending the sparse approximate minimum variance method to acoustic vector array signal processing in the baffled environments. The results demonstrate that incorporating baffle scattering effects into the methodic framework significantly enhances the bearing estimation performance, and sparse approximate minimum variance method adapted for vector array near the planar baffle maintains high estimation accuracy and resolution capabilities at low signal-to-noise ratios.

title: On the Applicability of Low-Cost Air Quality Sensors for Early Stage Forest Fire Detection
authors: Lidia Abad, Sofía Aparicio, Raimundo Alfonso, Mercedes Guijarro, Javier Madrigal, Ana Carmen de la Cruz, Juan Luis Gómez-González, Eisharc Jaquet, Esther Hontañón
abstract: This work explores the feasibility of air quality sensors to detect wildfires at early stages, when the fire is not yet spreading uncontrollably. To this aim, a variety of low-cost commercial sensors widely used for the measurement of pollutant gases (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf>, CO, O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>), carbon dioxide (CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and particulate matter (PM) in the air have been chosen and integrated into autonomous and wireless multisensor electronic modules. The modules have been deployed in the field and forest fuel burns have been carried out to evaluate the response of the sensors to the onset of fire. The results provide insights into the optimal design of cost-effective and energy-efficient sensor nodes for their use in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) for the early detection of forest fires.

title: Study on Levitation Force Characteristics of Superconducting Magnetic Levitation Bearings: Experimental and Simulation Analysis
authors: Danyang Wang, Guomin Zhang
abstract: Superconducting magnetic bearings (SMB) have many advantages, including self-stabilizing operation, reduced energy consumption, and extended service life, which make them highly suitable for applications in flywheel energy storage systems. This study studies the levitation performance of YBCO superconducting bulk materials, and measuring their levitation force using a specialized testing device. Based on a mathematical model of levitation force, finite element simulations were conducted to analyze the variation patterns of the levitation force under different cooling methods. Using the H-formulation and finite element method (FEM), a three-dimensional simulation model of the superconducting magnetic bearing was established to simulate the levitation characteristics under different permanent magnet stator arrangements (Halbach array and opposed-pole array). Simulation results show that the opposed-pole array SMB exhibits higher axial levitation force compared to the Halbach array under the investigated operating conditions. The experimental and theoretical findings presented here offer insights for the subsequent design and optimization of superconducting magnetic levitation bearings in flywheel energy storage systems.

title: BKD-BSNN: Blurred Knowledge Distillation-Enhanced Binarized Spiking Neural Network for Efficient Neuromorphic Vision
authors: Jianming Zhu, Ping He, Zhiyuan Hu, Rong Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) are naturally adapted to asynchronous sparse event stream data generated by neuromorphic visual sensors by exchanging and processing information through asynchronous spikes between spiking neurons. However, SNNs still face the challenges of high memory usage and high computational overhead during practical deployment. Binarized neural networks (BNNs) can drastically reduce computational overhead and storage requirements by limiting the weights and activations to binary values. Based on this, we propose a blurred knowledge distillation-enhanced binarized spiking neural network (BKD-BSNN) for neuromorphic visual data. We construct a lightweight spiking neural network architecture and binarize its weights. In order to compensate for the loss of network accuracy caused by binarized weights, we adopt a distillation mechanism that combines logits-based knowledge distillation and blurred knowledge distillation, utilizing the full-precision spiking neural network as a teacher model for guidance. Compared with the traditional full-precision SNNs, the weights of the whole network are changed from 32 bits to discrete binary, which reduces the memory footprint to 3.125% of the full-precision SNNs and eliminates the multiplicative calculation of the weights. The experimental results show that the accuracy reaches 69.6% and 99.48% on CIFAR10-DVS and N-MNIST datasets respectively, and 98.48% on DVSGesture which even exceeds that of the full-precision SNNs, which fully proves that our proposed method can maintain high recognition accuracy while improving computational efficiency.

title: Application of 1D Convolutional Neural Network for State Estimation of Highly Maneuvering Underwater Target
authors: Wasiq Ali, Babar Sattar Khan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Efficient state analysis of rapidly maneuvering underwater vehicles is a challenging research area, especially in noisy and complex aquatic conditions. This study explores the capability of one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1D CNN) to analyze key motion features of a highly dynamic underwater target. The proposed 1D CNN computation model examines time-series data collected by two underwater observers, focusing on predicting the target’s trajectory, location, and velocity in the $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$ axes, together with its rotational parameter. The computational framework recognizes the convoluted connections within the time-series information to accurately estimate the target’s state parameters. The mean squared error is used as a performance metric for evaluating the effectiveness of 1D CNN by comparing the estimated features with the actual features of the target. Simulation outcomes signify that the proposed 1D CNN approach can effectively estimate the state variables of a highly maneuvering underwater target. Subsequently, neural framework also displays its ability to predict the target’s constantly changing actions in complex underwater acoustic environment.

title: Design and Optimization of a Hybrid ALU Using CMOS, Pass Transistor Logic, and Transmission Gate Logic for Low-Power Applications
authors: Adithya Kusumanchi, Mani Shankar, K. Venkata Rao Challa, N. Subhashini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This work presents the design and development of a hybrid Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) that combines the strengths of multiple logic families to achieve enhanced performance parameters. ALUs are fundamental components in modern digital systems, and there is an increasing demand for designs that deliver high-speed operation, low power consumption, and optimized silicon area. The proposed hybrid ALU methodology incorporates advanced design techniques such as low-power full adders and subtractors, along with Pass Transistor Logic (PTL)-based multiplexers, to effectively address these critical requirements. A detailed comparative analysis demonstrates that the proposed hybrid ALU outperforms conventional Pass Transistor Logic (PTL), Transmission Gate (TG), and traditional CMOS logic designs with respect to average power consumption, propagation delay, and area utilization. The hybrid ALU implementation achieved the lowest power consumption of only 32.16 µW while maintaining an optimal balance between processing speed and compact area. The design and performance evaluation were conducted using Cadence design tools targeting an industry-standard 180 nm CMOS technology node, confirming the approach's feasibility and superior efficiency.

title: Research on Waveform Design Against Interrupted Sampling Repeater Jamming and Priori Information Representation Model
authors: Tong Yu, Zhiyong Song
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Interrupted sampling repeater jamming (ISRJ) is a novel active jamming technique that poses a severe threat to radar detection, as the jammed signals form false targets after pulse compression. To address this issue, this paper proposes an antijamming method based on orthogonal waveform design, which suppresses false targets by using the orthogonal characteristics between the jammer sampling signal and the unsampled signal. Considering that priori information directly impacts waveform design performance, a BP neural network model is constructed to establish a nonlinear mapping relationship between priori jamming information and detection probability. Simulation results show that the proposed model exhibits small prediction errors across multiple priori information scenarios, providing data support for the minimum prior information threshold required for target detection.

title:
A 136.6-dB-DR 174.3-dB-FoM
                    <sub>S</sub>
                    Versatile Current-to-Digital Converter With a Truncated-Noise-Shaped Baseline-Servo-Loop
authors: Taeryoung Seol, Sehwan Lee, Geunha Kim, Samhwan Kim, Yeonjae Shin, Jeongyoon Wie, Seungyeob Baik, Hongki Kang, Minyoung Song, Jong-Hyeok Yoon, Junghyup Lee
abstract: This article presents a high-resolution, wide dynamic-range (DR) current-to-digital converter (IDC) capable of directly digitizing a broad range of bio-current signals. To achieve high resolution, the IDC uses a second-order continuous-time delta–sigma modulator (CT-DSM) architecture with a low-noise current-recycling operational amplifier (op-amp) and a highly linear pseudo-differential voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO)-based quantizer. The IDC achieves a signal-to-noise-and-distortion ratio (SNDR) of 96.3 dB and a spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of 109.2 dB over a 4-kHz bandwidth while consuming <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$64.1~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>W, corresponding to a Schreier figure-of-merit (FoM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">S</sub>) of 174.3 dB. To extend the DR of the CT-DSM with minimal power and area overhead, a digital-intensive truncated-noise-shaped baseline-servo-loop (TNS-BSL) scheme is proposed. Fabricated in a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.18~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>m CMOS process, the proposed IDC achieves a DR of 136.6 dB, corresponding to a maximum input range of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$200~{\mu }$</tex-math> </inline-formula>A.

title: Electromagnetic Haptic Feedback System for Teleoperated Robotic Puncture Tasks
authors: Shiwei Zhao, Xutian Deng, Wenjie Xu, Peng Tang, Hongping Deng, Jianhui Zhao
abstract: In minimally invasive procedures involving puncture techniques, as robotic-assisted surgical systems continue to evolve, haptic feedback technology has emerged as a critical enabler for enhancing the operator's perceptual capabilities, improving puncture accuracy and reducing the risk of tissue damage. The traditional mechanical haptic feedback may suffer from friction, which affects the haptic interaction experience. In this paper, a magnetic haptic feedback device based on electromagnetic coils is designed, which can dynamically adjust the magnetic field according to the changes in puncture force, thus achieving high-fidelity reproduction of the puncture force. Furthermore, a magnetic haptic feedback algorithm based on three sequential stages—calibration, training, and feedback—is proposed. In the calibration stage, the system obtains the nonlinear mapping between the coil duty cycle and the magnetic force. In the training stage, a residual-connected multilayer perceptron model learns the mapping from force to duty cycle. In the feedback stage, coil currents are dynamically computed according to the target feedback force and current pose, enabling high-precision force reconstruction and real-time magnetic field control. This paper proposes and implements a magnetic haptic feedback system tailored for teleperated robotic puncture tasks, integrating three-dimensional virtual simulation, vision-based servo control for puncture functionality, and a magnetic feedback mechanism based on electromagnetic coils. The system consists of a surgeon-side and a patient-side. The surgeon-side constructs a three-dimensional simulation environment to specify the target puncture point, remotely control the puncture process, and receive real-time force feedback; the patient-side uses a six-degree-of-freedom robotic arm to perform the puncture operation and collects puncture force data during the process, which is then feedback to the surgeon-side. Through phantom experiments and user evaluations, the superior performance of this system in terms of force feedback fidelity and operational immersion has been validated.

title: Using Language Models to Detect and Reduce Gender Bias in University Forum Messages
authors: Gianina Salomó-López, Cristóbal Alcázar, Roberto Barceló, Camilo Carvajal Reyes, Darinka Radovic, Felipe Tobar
abstract: Gender bias refers to systematic and unequal treatment based on an individual’s gender <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref1" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]</xref>, or the preference or prejudice toward one gender over another <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref2" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[2]</xref>. Gender biases can be led by humans or autonomous systems, and although their occurrence in decision making is usually unintentional, they have profound consequences on societal interactions. These biases are particularly detrimental in educational settings, where they can reinforce stereotypes, influence student performance and engagement, and perpetuate systemic inequalities. In this regard, a source of concern is artificial intelligence (AI) systems and machine learning (ML) models that use natural language processing (NLP) techniques as they convey challenges and opportunities. Although using gender-biased datasets on model training has known harmful consequences <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref3" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[3]</xref>, AI/ML’s unparalleled ability for text processing makes them an attractive resource for detecting and mitigating gender bias from natural language. Our focus is to address gender bias in educational contexts using AI, a crucial step to fostering inclusive learning environments and promoting equitable opportunities for all learners.

title: MSHCDI-Net: A Multiscale Hybrid Cross-Domain Interaction Network for Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Peitao Li, Bin Chen, Chaobing Zheng, Shiqian Wu, Meng Jia
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Low-light image enhancement aims to improve visibility and image quality under challenging illumination conditions by enhancing brightness, contrast, and detail. Deep learning-based methods, particularly Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), have shown notable success. However, their limited receptive fields often restrict recovery performance by focusing on local features. In contrast, transformer architectures offer the advantage of capturing global contextual information. By leveraging the self-similarity of image patches, local degradation can be effectively addressed through fusion. To this end, we propose MSHCDI-Net, a hybrid network composed of CNN and Transformer branches. In MSHCDI-Net, Transformer branches take feature map patches as input and utilize the Transformer mechanism to propagate global context among patches. Extensive experiments conducted on public low-light datasets demonstrate that MSHCDI-Net consistently outperforms existing state-of-the-art algorithms, achieving superior visual quality in the reconstructed images.

title: Shape Matching Based on Dynamic Contour Modeling Using PointFlow
authors: Hanlin Dong, Fang Yang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a shape matching algorithm called PFFM. It is based on PointFlow dynamic contour modeling and Fast Marching. PFFM aims to address the problem that traditional shape matching methods lack robustness under geometric transformations (such as rotation and scaling), local occlusion, and noise disturbances. PFFM innovatively combines two key components. On one hand, it uses the composite vector field-driven edge-tracking mechanism of the PointFlow model. On the other hand, it integrates the integral invariants of the Fast Marching algorithm. This combination helps construct a closed contour matching framework that possesses both geometric invariance and anti-interference capability. Specifically, we first construct a composite vector field. This field consists of a gradient-driven field and an edge-tracking field. We also introduce an adaptive stopping mechanism. These steps significantly reduce noise sensitivity and interference from local deformations. Meanwhile, we design a geometrically invariant energy function based on integral invariants. This function is combined with the optimized correspondence derived from dynamic programming. Together, they ensure the geometric invariance of the shapedistance metric. Experimental results demonstrate the advantages of the PFFM algorithm. In both single-target and multi-target matching tasks, it significantly outperforms classical methods such as SIFT, RIFT, and HAPCG in terms of the average RMSE index. Moreover, PFFM exhibits superior robustness in mixed interference scenarios. Overall, this algorithm provides an effective solution for high-precision shape matching in complex scenes.

title: A Generalizable Attention-Based Data Collection Scheme for Multi-AUV Underwater Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Baining An, Jiani Guo, Shanshan Song, Guangjie Han, Jun Liu, Junhong Cui
abstract: Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) provide a new prospect for data collection in underwater wireless sensor networks (UWSNs). For dynamic underwater environments, researchers typically apply deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to design multi-AUV collection schemes for UWSNs. However, these methods suffer from the following issues. 1) Overloaded observations. The importance of various observations for an AUV varies over time. Considering all observations equally complicates decision-making for subsequent actions. 2) Dynamic scale of AUVs and sensors. Once the number of AUVs or sensors is changed, traditional static neural networks require retraining, lacking scalability across diverse scenarios. To solve the above issues, we propose a Generalizable Attention-based Data collection scheme (GAMD) for Multi-AUV UWSNs, while enhancing AUVs’ collection efficiency. GAMD incorporates the attention mechanism with multi-agent DRL framework, which enables AUVs to prioritize observations more critical for action decisions. Moreover, we propose an adaptive information processing approach, enabling the AUV policy model to seamlessly adapt to various scenarios without retraining. Additionally, we develop a training paradigm with incremental complexity across different scale scenarios to simplify training process and accelerate convergence. Simulation results demonstrate that GAMD alleviates the training cost compared to the state-of-the-art methods, and simultaneously optimizes collection energy efficiency, collection time, and trajectory distance.

title: Joint Movable-Antenna Position and Sensor Angle Optimization for Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: Zhihui Shang, Guojie Hu, Qingqing Wu, Kui Xu
abstract: In uplink communications of sensor networks, by utilizing the movable-antenna (MA) array, the access point (AP) can flexibly reconfigure the wireless channel between itself and each sensor to improve the system performance. However, relying solely on the MA technology still cannot achieve overly desirable performance, especially in two extreme scenarios: i) The total antenna span at the AP is relatively small, for which the channel reconfiguration ability is weak; ii) The angle of arrivals (AoAs) to the AP at some sensors are close, for which the correlation between any two of these uplink channels remains strong, no matter how the MA array is deployed. Motivated by these considerations, in this correspondence we propose to simultaneously utilize the MA technology and adjustability of AoAs to sufficiently reconfigure channel conditions. Specifically, we aim to maximize the sum rate by jointly optimizing antenna positions and the receive beamforming at the AP, and concurrently the AoA to the AP at each sensor (which can be adjusted in a certain range by optimizing the deployment of each sensor beforehand). The formulated problem is highly non-convex. To tackle it, we derive the optimal minimum mean-square error (MMSE) receive beamforming given fixed antenna positions and all AoAs, based on which we further adopt the alternating optimization to iteratively handle another two types of variables. We also present the special case of two sensors to reveal insightful conclusions. Finally, we perform simulations to show the potential advantages of our proposed scheme compared to the current MA technology.

title: Beyond One-Size-Fits-All: Comparing and Selecting Regression Metrics for Robust Model Assessment
authors: Yousef M. Jaradat, Mohammad A. Alia, Mohammad Z. Masoud, Ahmad A. Manasrah, Ismael A. Jannoud, Omar Alheyasat
abstract: In this study, we present a comprehensive overview of common regression metrics, including Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE), Coefficient of Determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>), and Adjusted R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Each metric serves a unique purpose, from emphasizing large deviations (MSE/RMSE) to quantifying average errors (MAE), relative disparities (MAPE), and explained variance (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and Adjusted R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>). We illustrate the practical significance of these metrics through a case study where three distinct regression models (Linear Regression, Random Forest, and Gradient Boosting) are evaluated. Our findings show that different metrics can yield varying, and sometimes contradictory, assessments of model performance. This demonstrates the importance of choosing metrics that align with domain requirements and error sensitivities. By combining multiple metrics and leveraging both linear and ensemble methods, practitioners can achieve a richer, more accurate understanding of a model’s strengths and limitations, thereby supporting more informed decision-making in real-world regression tasks.

title: STAV360: A Dataset for Subjective Tile-based Assessment of 360° Videos
authors: Moatasim Mahmoud, Stamatia Rizou, Andreas S. Panayides, Pavlos I. Lazaridis, George K. Karagiannidis, Nikolaos V. Kantartzis, Zaharias D. Zaharis
abstract: Tile-based 360° video streaming has recently emerged as a promising strategy for efficient and flexible 360° video transmission. However, spatial variations in the delivered scene quality, caused by combining different quality levels, can influence the users’ perceptual experience. While several models and datasets have been developed for 360° video quality assessment (360° VQA), none of the available studies consider the spatial quality variation that arises in multi-quality tiled 360° video streaming. To bridge this gap, conducting subjective evaluation experiments for tiled omnidirectional videos is essential for developing reliable tiled 360° VQA models and optimized streaming algorithms. This paper introduces the STAV360 dataset, a dataset for subjective tile-based assessment of 360° videos. The STAV360 dataset consists of six 360° video sequences, each tiled and encoded using twelve different patterns, along with subjective ratings and tracking data of 27 participants. STAV360 reveals interesting patterns in subjective tiled 360° VQA, paving the way for new research opportunities in tile-based 360° video streaming and objective 360° VQA metric models. The STAV360 dataset is publicly available at https://github.com/SLG-European-Projects/STAV360.

title: Improved retinal image classification utilizing fundus pictures with ResNet50 and CLAHE-Grad-CAM
authors: Khirod Kumar Ghadai, Subrat Kumar Nayak, Biswa Ranjan Senapati, Debahuti Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The eye is a very important element because it lets us see our surroundings. Numerous progressive ocular disorders can result in irreparable visual impairment, demanding accurate identification for timely intervention. This study presents an improved deep learning methodology that exceeds conventional techniques in assessing the health state of retinal pictures. In order to label retinal images as normal or abnormal, the suggested system was built utilizing the open-source retinal fundus multi-disease image dataset (RFMiD). By combining the Gradient-weighted class activation mapping (Grad-CAM) method with contrast limited adaptive histogram equalization (CLAHE), we have been able to improve the images and see which parts of the retina the model finds most interesting. The enhanced model's accuracy, precision, recall and F1 score were 98.11%, 98.00%, 98.20%, and 97.97%, respectively. The developed system was found to be capable of clinical decision support and to offer encouraging predictions in the classification of retinal pictures. This conclusion was reached based on the experimental results that were collected from the study, providing a novel means of preventing retinal illness by detecting the abnormality's presence or absence.

title: FreqDGT: Frequency-Adaptive Dynamic Graph Networks with Transformer for Cross-Subject EEG Emotion Recognition
authors: Yueyang Li, Shengyu Gong, Weiming Zeng, Nizhuan Wang, Wai Ting Siok
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) serves as a reliable and objective signal for emotion recognition in affective braincomputer interfaces, offering unique advantages through its high temporal resolution and ability to capture authentic emotional states that cannot be consciously controlled. However, crosssubject generalization remains a fundamental challenge due to individual variability, cognitive traits, and emotional responses. We propose FreqDGT, a frequency-adaptive dynamic graph transformer that systematically addresses these limitations through an integrated framework. FreqDGT introduces frequency-adaptive processing (FAP) to dynamically weight emotion-relevant frequency bands based on neuroscientific evidence, employs adaptive dynamic graph learning (ADGL) to learn input-specific brain connectivity patterns, and implements multi-scale temporal disentanglement network (MTDN) that combines hierarchical temporal transformers with adversarial feature disentanglement to capture both temporal dynamics and ensure cross-subject robustness. Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that FreqDGT significantly improves cross-subject emotion recognition accuracy, confirming the effectiveness of integrating frequencyadaptive, spatial-dynamic, and temporal-hierarchical modeling while ensuring robustness to individual differences. The code is available at https://github.com/NZWANG/FreqDGT.

title: Model Predictive Control for Integrated Pressurized Water Reactor Based on Proxy Model
authors: Yunze Xue, Ke Su, Ming Cheng, Bowen Zhang, Yizhuo Li, Honglin Pan
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: The Integrated Pressurized Water Reactor (IPWR) is a strongly coupled and fast-feedback system, and its control performance needs to be ensured in severe transient processes and fault conditions. Model predictive control (MPC) is an important means to achieve this, but it suffers from the problem of difficult dynamic tracking of the system operating behavior. To address this issue, a model-based predictive control method for IPWR based on a proxy model and an improved particle swarm optimization(PSO) algorithm is proposed in this paper. The IPWR proxy model, which takes into account the model deviation caused by faults and performance degradation, is constructed using multi-layer perceptron. The optimal control output is searched for using the PSO algorithm. It is demonstrated by simulation results that the proposed predictive control method can overcome the severe disturbances introduced by faults and ensure the safe and smooth operation of the IPWR.

title: Design and Analysis of Lifted Weight Storage Gravitational Power Generation System
authors: Yash Goswami, Abhinav Bhatnagar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper explores the innovative concept of power generation using gravitational systems, providing a comprehensive theoretical framework and mathematical implementation. The proposed system leverages gravitational potential energy to generate electricity, showcasing a scalable design suitable for powering small household items. At its core, the system comprises a load suspended at a height, descending under the influence of gravity. This motion is transmitted through a gear train and pulley mechanism to drive a dynamo, converting mechanical energy into electrical energy. They mathematically modelled the system and its mechanical and electrical interactions to allow for the possibility of making accurate predictions of its output in terms of energy. Design elements-that is, an optimal pulley, gear, and dynamo, were integrated such that there was an efficient flow of energy while minimal loss occurred. By bridging theoretical principles with practical applications, this study aims to establish a sustainable energy solution that aligns with modern energy demands. The insights, including mathematical derivation of total electric power generation, presented in this paper serve as a novel foundation for future advancements in gravitational energy systems, paving the way for innovative approaches to decentralized and renewable power generation.

title: RMNet: Dual-Dimensional Difference Recalibration-Guided CNN-VMamba Synergistic Network for Remote Sensing Image Change Captioning
authors: Xintong Cao, Wenqian Dong, Jiahui Qu, Yunsong Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Global surface changes are increasingly monitored using multi-temporal remote sensing technologies. As an emerging technology, change captioning can organically integrate the location information of changed regions with the semantic analysis of regional attributes to generate natural language descriptions of changes, providing critical support for the intuitive interpretation of remote sensing monitoring results. However, existing methods have two key limitations: first, single-stream CNNs fail to extract spatiotemporal information sufficiently which leads to the easy omission of subtle changes, while single-stream Transformers suffer from relatively high parameter counts; second, using pixel-level difference information directly causes the model to focus on pseudo-changes induced by illumination or noise, reducing the accuracy of real change characterization and subsequent description. To address these issues, this paper proposes RMNet which is a dual-dimensional difference recalibration-guided CNN-VMamba synergistic network, with two core innovations: 1) a dual-stream architecture adopted that combines the strong local feature extraction capability of CNNs with the powerful global context modeling ability of VMamba, further enhanced by a channel-wise spatial window attention mechanism; 2) a dual-dimensional difference recalibration mechanism that optimizes features by highlighting core changes and suppressing pseudo-changes through dimension-specific enhancement strategies. Extensive experiments on the LEVIR-CC dataset demonstrate significant performance improvements across all evaluation metrics, validating the effectiveness of RMNet in overcoming current limitations in remote sensing change captioning tasks. The code is available at https://github.com/Jiahuiqu/RMNet.

title: Analysis of JunctionLess MosFET: A Comprehensive Review on Design, Performance, and Future Prospects
authors: Siga Karthik, Vishal Narula, Rekha Chaudhary
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The continuous shrinking of semiconducting devices has imposed rigorous demands on conventional MOSFET technology like short-channel effects (SCEs), increased leakage currents, and process variability. Junction less MOSFETs (JL-MOSFETs) came as a different solution to avoid these limitations by eliminating the p-n junctions and introducing a uniformly doped channel to facilitate fabrication and increase device reliability. Of the various JL-MOSFETs, double-gate (DG) structure has demonstrated enhanced electrostatic control, reduced leakage, and better scalability, which makes it extremely competent for sub-10 nm nodes. Here is a review article on DG-JL MOSFETs describing their structural advantages, functioning principles, and key performance indicators like threshold voltage control, subthreshold slope, and ON/OFF current ratio. In addition, advances in semiconductor materials like high-mobility III- V compound and 2D materials like MoS<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and graphene have also improved the functionality and efficiency of DG-JL MOSFETs. The article further elaborates on modelling methodologies like drift-diffusion models, quantum mechanical simulations, and AI optimization techniques, which enable accurate characterization and design improvement. Though their promise, however, is within grasp, DG-JL MOSFETs are also plagued by challenges in the doping control, thermal management, and accuracy of fabrication, which call for further effort in strain engineering, nanowire architectures, and hybrid JL- TFET designs. This study highlights the significance of DG-JL MOSFETs in enabling next-generation low-power, high-performance electronic devices while outlining the future research directions for their further development.

title: FSRNN: ANN-SNN Conversion of Full Spike-Driven RNNs for Energy-Efficient Digital Predistortion
authors: Long Chen, Han Ji, Xiaotian Song, Yanan Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Wideband radio frequency power amplifiers (PAs) are essential in modern wireless systems (e.g., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 G} / \mathbf{6 G}$</tex>), but their nonlinearities cause signal distortion, requiring digital predistortion (DPD) for correction. Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) have shown strong performance in DPD, yet their high computational cost and energy consumption limit their use in energy-constrained scenarios. Spiking neural networks (SNNs) offer a low-power alternative due to their event-driven nature, but building high-performance spiking RNNs remains challenging, as the complex structures and nonlinear operations in ANNbased RNNs are incompatible with the linear dynamics of spiking neurons. To address this, we propose an innovative ANN-SNN conversion strategy for a Full Spike-Driven Recurrent Neural Network, termed FSRNN. Specifically, FSRNN introduces a novel group approximation strategy to approximate nonlinear functions and a Spiking Multiplication to correct errors in multiplication between two non-stationary vectors. Moreover, a full spike-driven RNN architecture is designed to ensure a complete spiking conversion without performance loss. Our experiments on the DPA- 200 MHz benchmark demonstrate that the proposed FSRNN achieves an ACPR of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 4 6. 9 4 ~ d B c}$</tex> and an EVM of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{- 4 3. 2 8 ~ d B}$</tex> while reducing energy consumption by 82.51 %.

title: A Research on Visual-Servo-Based Palletization Task for Manipulators
authors: Yang Li, Fudong Wang, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: This paper presents a precision optimization method for intelligent robotic arms manipulating small structured objects, using a Kinova Gen3 Lite arm in a ROSbased simulation. The system integrates visual perception, task planning, path planning, and closed-loop control, with a RealSense D435 depth camera mounted as an “eye-in-hand” system for Tetris block identification. Task planning employs a cost function and the Hungarian algorithm for palletizing optimization. Path planning combines MoveIt! for global planning with IBVS (Image-Based Visual Servo) and 2.5DVS (2.5D Visual Servo) for local planning and multi-feature pixelerror control. Gazebo simulations show the superior performance of the 2.5 DVS method, achieving sub-pixel accuracy (0.5 px minimum) compared to conventional IBVS (1.5 px minimum). The integrated planning-control approach significantly improves motion quality and energy efficiency.

title: Beacon: Post-Training Quantization with Integrated Grid Selection
authors: Shihao Zhang, Rayan Saab
abstract: Quantization is a widely used compression technique for reducing the memory and computation costs of large pre-trained models. A key challenge in per-channel post-training quantization (PTQ) is selecting appropriate scaling factors to replace weight values with values from a scaled integer grid. Existing methods typically fix the scale at the outset via heuristic tuning or grid search. We propose Beacon, a simple and effective algorithm that eliminates the need for such manual tuning. Beacon performs per-channel PTQ directly using an unscaled grid and automatically determines the optimal scaling factors by exploiting the geometry of quantizing a channel. It does not rely on back-propagation or large calibration sets. Despite its simplicity and tuning-free nature, Beacon achieves competitive performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, making it a practical solution for efficient model deployment.

title: Power-Line Physical-Layer Key Generation Study Based on Low Complexity 3-Wire 4-Port Modeling
authors: Werner Henkel, Tai Him Yim, Aditya Ojha, Sumit Giri, Ehsan Olyaei Torshizi
abstract: We first present a simplified full ABCD or Smatrix model for a 3-wire powerline grid connection to support our simulations of physical-layer security to finally be able to obtain statically significant results. Typical in-house power-line cables consist of three wires labeled L (Line), N (Neutral), and PE (Protective Earth). $4 \times 4$ ABCD or S-parameter matrices are derived from the well-known $2 \times 2$ ABCD matrix known for 2-conductor transmission lines including a FEXT (Far-End CrossTalk) model for 8 of the 16 ABCD matrix elements. For a point-to-point ABCD matrix, bridge taps with loads over L and N are represented by their corresponding $\Delta$ circuit and its ABCD matrix to finally allow for simple matrix multiplication of the cascade of such line and bridge taps elements between two end points. As a first application that promises secret key generation we study transfer functions when introducing randomly changing reactive loads at the legitimate terminals. We observe that the phase response at a certain frequency is very suitable to be mapped to key elements. The resulting key distribution is close to uniform and the key disagreement rates for legitimate and eavesdropping channels are almost ideal, i.e., close to zero for the first and close to 0.5 for the latter.

title: EM-Optimized Parameter Learning Framework for Interpretable Modeling of Therapeutic Activity and Adverse Side Effects in Personalized Hypertension Treatment
authors: Mashael Al-luhaybi
abstract: Accurate prediction of pharmacological activity and associated therapeutic side effects is essential for advancing personalized medicine, particularly in hypertension therapy where patients’ responses vary depending on their health profiles and comorbidities. However, existing machine learning approaches face challenges in minimizing uncertainty specifically when targeting exploiting explainable models for ethical and personalized hypertension treatments. Moreover, pharmacological-hypertension datasets often contain missing and heterogeneous data due to incomplete side-effect reports which consequently reduce likelihood estimation and posterior calibration of the learned models. To address these challenges, a novel uncertainty-aware probabilistic learning framework based on Bayesian Networks (BNs) optimized via the Expectation–Maximization (EM) algorithm is proposed to reduce uncertainties through higher likelihood estimation for hypertension medications. This implementation extends previous EM-based probabilistic models by integrating uncertainty evaluation using influence strength and sensitivity analysis to enhance interpretability and reliability. The BN–EM framework learns dependencies between drug-related attributes such as drug classes, pregnancy categories, and brand names to predict side effects and activity levels. Three probabilistic experiments were conducted to assess the proposed parameter learning approach. The BN–EM model outperformed Tree-Augmented Naïve Bayes (TAN) and Naïve Bayes (NB), achieving the highest micro-averaged accuracy of 97.03%, compared to 95.48% and 89.55%, respectively. These findings highlight the potential of EM-optimized probabilistic modeling to support transparent and clinically interpretable personalized hypertension therapy.

title: 2025 27th International Multitopic Conference (INMIC)
authors: N/A

title: NeuroAttn-WGAN: Attention-Driven EEG Signal Denoising Using Wasserstein Generative Adversarial Networks
authors: Samarup Bhattacharya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG) signals are an integral component of brain-computer interfaces (BCI), as they provide a noninvasive, direct measure of the electrical activity in the brain. However, artifacts in the EEG signal degrade the usefulness of the signal in BCI applications. Common artifacts in EEG signals include ocular artifacts (caused by eye movements) and myogenic artifacts (caused by muscle contractions). Such artifacts are particularly hard to remove because their frequency range overlaps with the frequency range of the EEG signals. Thus, for this task a model is proposed, based on Wasserstein GAN with Gradient Penalty(WGAN-GP) featuring an encoder-decoder architecture for the Generator along with self-attention and cross-attention to capture temporal dependencies while the Critic(Discriminator) ensures realistic output through adversarial feedback. This novel architecture is found to perform better than benchmark deep learning algorithms proposed in [1].

title: Machine Learning-Enhanced Quantum Identity Authentication over Noisy Quantum Networks
authors: Mohamed Shaban, Muhammad Ismail
abstract: The quantum Internet promises to revolutionize computing, communications, sensing, and security by leveraging quantum entanglement. In this context, quantum repeaters play a crucial role by performing entanglement swapping to extend entanglement across distant nodes. However, malicious repeaters can retain entangled pairs, enabling man-in-the-middle attacks that compromise security. Quantum Identity Authentication (QIA) protocols aim to mitigate this threat by verifying the legitimacy of communicating parties. However, existing QIA protocols rely on unrealistic assumptions, such as noise-free environments or static noise profiles, that do not reflect the nature of real-world quantum networks. Such noise can cause benign sessions to be flagged as attacks or allow attacks to go undetected. To address these limitations, we propose a machine learning-enhanced QIA framework designed for noisy quantum environments. The protocol performs random authentications during communication sessions using parameters derived from a shared secret key. These parameters determine the preparation and measurement of authentication qubits, known only to legitimate users. A trained machine learning model analyzes physical-layer information (e.g., entanglement fidelity, routing path) and protocol-level data (e.g., basis selection, encoding bit, and measurement outcomes) to detect malicious behavior under fluctuating noise conditions. We evaluate several attack detection models and identify XGBoost as the most effective, achieving 97.18% accuracy and an F1-score of 0.96. The proposed XGBoost-enhanced QIA protocol detects attacks within the first authentication round, achieving a 100% detection and a 1.7% false alarm rate. This reflects a 16.1% improvement in detection rate and a 92.5% reduction in false alarms compared to the entanglement-based QIA benchmark.

title: To Mask, or Not to Mask, Alice and Bob&#x02019;s Dating Dilemma_supp1-3634842.pdf
authors: Zhanshan Sam Ma
abstract: Face masking in current COVID-19 pandemic seems to be a deceivingly simple decision-making problem due to its multifaceted nature. Questions arising from masking span biomedicine, epidemiology, physics, and human behaviors. While science has shown masks work generally, human behaviors (particularly under influences of politics) complicate the problem significantly given science generally assumes rationality but our minds are not always rational and/or honest. Minding minds, a legitimate concern, can also make masking legitimately confusing. To disentangle the potential confusions, particularly, the ramifications of irrationality and dishonesty, here we resort to evolutionary game theory. Specifically, we formulate and analyze the masking problem with a fictitious pair of young lovers, Alice and Bob, as a Sir Philip Sydney (SPS) evolutionary game, inspired by the handicap principle in evolutionary biology and cryptography figures in computer science. With the proposed Alice and Bob’s dating dilemma (ABD) as an asymmetric four-by-four strategic-form game, 16 strategic interactions were identified, and six of which may reach equilibriums with different characteristics such as separating, pooling, and polymorphic hybrid, being Nash, evolutionarily stable or neutrally stable.
