The six equilibrium types seem to mirror the diverse behaviors of mask believers, skeptics, converted, universal masking, voluntarily masking, coexisted and/or divided world of believers and skeptics. We suggest that the apparently simple ABD game is sufficiently general not only for studying masking policies for populations (via replicator dynamics), but also for investigating other complex decision-making problems with COVID-19 pandemic including lockdown versus reopening, herd immunity versus quarantines, and aggressive tracing versus privacy protection.

title: Deep Learning Based Channel Estimation for MIMOOTFS Systems
authors: Yixin Chang, Tao Zhou, Liu Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Confronting the fundamental limitation of subcarrier orthogonality degradation caused by Doppler shifts in high-mobility multiple-input multiple-output orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (MIMO-OFDM) systems, this paper investigates channel estimation in the delay-Doppler (DD) domain for multiple-input multiple-output orthogonal time frequency space (MIMO-OTFS) modulation systems characterized by quasi-static sparse channels. To overcome the high-complexity constraints, we propose a novel channel estimation network that synergizes the strengths of a residual network with squeeze-and-excitation (SE-ResNet) and a Transformer. This network deeply exploits channel correlation information from both spatial and temporal dimensions, collaboratively enhancing the representation learning of spatial and temporal features for more accurate channel state information (CSI) estimation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves approximately 17 dB performance gain over traditional algorithms and significantly outperforms existing single deep learning (DL) models in estimation accuracy, effectively addressing the inherent limitations of unimodal architectures by joint spatial and temporal modeling. We also compare the normalized mean square error (NMSE) performance under varying velocities, spatial correlation coefficients and MIMO antenna configurations. This work not only validates the effectiveness of the spatial-temporal cooperative mechanism for enhancing channel estimation accuracy but also provides a low complexity scheme of channel estimation for high-mobility communication systems.

title: Joint Resolution Limit of Direction of Departure and Direction of Arrival for MIMO Radar
authors: Huiran Cheng, Dazhuan Xu, Yushan Xie
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Resolution is one of the important indicators for radar parameter estimation. Although most of the current research on resolution is focused on single parameter estimation, there have also been some achievements in the research on the resolution of multiparameter joint estimation. However, the problem of the joint resolution limit (JRL) for the direction of departure (DOD) and direction of arrival (DOA) for bistatic Multiple-input Multiple-output (MIMO) radar has not been studied. The study derived the JRL of DOD and DOA for bistatic MIMO radar by combining Shannon’s information theory achievements. Based on the general signal model, we can obtain a explicit formula for scattering information (SI) under two targets condition, reflection its influence factor. We define the DOD interval and DOA interval corresponding to the orthogonal component of SI is 1 bit as the JRL. Meanwhile, the paper also provides closed-form expressions and approximate representations of the DOD resolution limit (DOD-RL) and DOA resolution limit (DOA-RL) by using parameter degradation analysis method. The results indicate that the resolution limit is inversely correlated with the number of radar transmitter and receiver units, the element spacing, the transmit signal frequency, and the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). These resolution limits are universal, that is, they are independent of specific algorithm. Finally, MATLAB was used to simulate the research fundings, verifying their accuracy and effectiveness.

title: Demonstration of a Digital Product Passport System for Second-Hand Electronic Devices
authors: Pedro Vilchez, Javier Cano, Cayo Puigdefabregas, Felix Freitag, Leandro Navarro
abstract: The foundation for the Digital Product Passport (DPP) was presented in the recent European Ecodesign for Sustainable Products Regulation (ESPR) in July 2024. DPP systems will provide ICT support to increase the circular economy of products significantly. With the DPP, a significant step forward will be taken by providing comprehensive, trusted, and publicly accessible product information for items or batches regarding digital records. Currently, the DPP building is undergoing a standardization process. Nevertheless, commercial players are preparing DPP systems but mainly with a proprietary implementation, making it difficult for researchers to experiment. In this demo paper, we will show an open-source implementation of a DPP system for managing the lifecycle of second-hand electronic devices such as computers. Our system is oriented towards the use cases of economic actors such as repairers, refurbishers, and the customers of these devices. Our system integrates a blockchain-based registry for the actors to trust the data and operations. The implementation of the demo DPP system is publicly available and can be deployed as a set of microservices.

title: Addressing Class Imbalance in Arabic Medical Questions using Ensembles and SMOTE
authors: Bushra Al-Smadi, Bassam H. Hammo, Hossam Faris
abstract: The rise of telemedicine platforms like Altibbi has transformed healthcare access, enabling patients to consult specialists remotely. One vital component of these platforms is medical question classification, which ensures that patient inquiries are efficiently directed to the appropriate specialists. However, these datasets often suffer from class imbalance, leading to biased model performance. This study explores the use of AraBERTv0.2-Twitter embeddings combined with ensemble learning techniques, Bagging and Boosting applied to various classifiers, including Logistic Regression (LR), Random Forests (RF), Decision Trees (DT), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN). We evaluate their performance on a dataset of Arabic medical questions from Altibbi under four experimental conditions: (1) Bagging without Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE), (2) Bagging with SMOTE, (3) Adaptive Boosting (AdaBoost) without SMOTE, and (4) AdaBoost with SMOTE. This allows us to analyze the impact of synthetic oversampling on classification performance and identify the most effective approach for addressing data imbalance. Experimental results show that Bagging with LR, without SMOTE, achieves the highest Macro F1-score (0.8468) and G-Mean (0.9077). AdaBoost with LR benefits significantly from oversampling, reaching a G-Mean of (0.8921) with SMOTE. Additionally, RF improves G-Mean from (0.8831) to (0.8893) when combined with Bagging and SMOTE. These findings highlight the vital role of ensemble methods in enhancing classification fairness and accuracy. By integrating such strategies, telemedicine platforms can significantly improve the automated classification of medical questions, ensuring patients receive timely and accurate responses from the right specialists.

title: Evaluating the Economic Impact of On-Grid and Off-Grid Solar PV Systems in Homes
authors: Ahmad Manasrah, Nezar Qudah, Yousef Jaradat, Mohammad Masoud, Mohammad Jaradat
abstract: Renewable energy systems have become very popular in many applications in the past two decades. The most common of which is solar photovoltaic systems, especially in residential applications. Typically, those systems are applied in a relatively small capacity scale to accommodate the power needs of a household. However, usually such systems do not have power storage options like batteries due to excessive initial and running costs and maintenance for hybrid off-grid systems. In this study, an economic comparison is established between two systems for a residential building in Amman, Jordan. The first one is a grid-connected solar photovoltaic system that does not have a battery system. The second one is a hybrid off-grid system that carries a battery pack. Results of the comparison shows that even though the hybrid off-grid system has much higher initial and running costs, the two systems have roughly similar return on investment (ROI) at 13% and payback period of five years. However, results also showed that the hybrid off-grid system has a close-to-zero levelized cost of energy (LCOE) whilst the on-grid system has $0.09/kWh LCOE as opposed to utility tariffs at $0.21/kWh.

title: Energy-Assisted Compliant Switching of Dual-Mode Morphing Wing With Metamorphic Mechanism_supp2-3651986.mp4
authors: Bing Li
abstract: The concept of morphing wings is often incorporated in the design of highly adaptive aircraft. However, the design of dual-mode morphing wing and the research of mode switching method remain insufficiently developed. This article presents a novel dual-mode morphing wing based on the characteristics of multiple modes of metamorphic mechanism. Through the combination of basic 4R mechanisms, we designed a class of line symmetry Bricard mechanisms. A novel self-coupling joint is developed to enable compliant switching between different modes without new actuator. Based on the energy change during movement, we propose an energy-assisted method to realize the mode switching. Ultimately, we constructed a prototype aircraft with two modes: variable anhedral angle for enhanced maneuverability and variable sweep angle for better aerodynamic efficiency. The mode switching experiment shows that the motion state of the joint changes compliantly during the mode switching. The experiments show that the morphing wing can change the anhedral angle (7°–12°) and sweep angle (15°–30°), and can change the mode with the help of flight conditions. The aircraft can fly successfully in both modes, which shows the superiority of the design method. The findings of this study hold significant potential for the design of morphing wings in highly adaptive aircraft.

title: Cyber Security Threat Modeling of IoT Security Design Patterns
authors: Ashish Kumar Dwivedi, Nikunja Bihari Kar, Anubhav Shivhare
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The role of threat modeling and attack simulation has become more prominent for information technology as well as operational technology due to the increasing number of cyber attacks on existing entities. Different constituents of IoT (like devices, services, users, etc.) are playing a crucial role in providing data to operational technologies such as industrial control systems, remote terminal units, transportation, healthcare, water treatment usages, etc. The constituents of IoT technology require in-depth analysis and design elements to model the possible threats beforehand and work upon the domain-specific vulnerabilities. In this study, a threat modeling framework is proposed to analyze the pattern-based solution for an IoT use case i.e., IoT security patterns. The pattern-based solutions are often specified by using UML Language, that is not a fully formal language. The semi-formal approach requires a thorough analysis. The presented threat modeling framework can identify hidden insecure issues and provides rigorous analysis, which are not found in security pattern notation. The proposed framework is based on a metamodling approach. A specific use case of IoT in the domain of health care is considered to analyze the efficacy of the proposed framework.

title: AI-Optimized Training Recommendations with Biometric Data for HR and Finance Excellence
authors: M. Karthik, M. R. Prakash, Zufarova Gulmira, Logith B, B. Vanaja, G. Manikandan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The amalgamation of artificial intelligence (AI) and biometric data is revolutionizing training suggestions in the fields of HR and Finance. This study presents an AI-optimized training system that uses deep learning and reinforcement learning algorithms to evaluate biometric data from wearable devices. The data includes heart rate, stress levels, activity levels, and sleep patterns. The technology generates customized training programs and adapts them in real-time depending on immediate feedback. The training dataset comprises heart rate measurements (70 ± 10 bpm), stress level readings (5 ± 2 GSR units), activity level data (5000 ± 2000 steps), and sleep duration records (7 ± 1 hours). The model attained the model achieved an accuracy rate of 92%, a precision rate of 91%, a recall rate of 89%, and an F1-score of 90%, surpassing the expected performance of earlier systems. In addition, it enhanced employee engagement and performance by 15% and decreased training time by 20%. These findings emphasize the system's efficacy in improving training outcomes and its potential influence on HR and Finance. Subsequent efforts will prioritize enlarging the dataset, using sophisticated AI methods, and resolving ethical considerations related to biometric data.

title: Cloud-Integrated Fake News Detection in European Portuguese: A Multilingual XGBoost Model Optimized for Accuracy
authors: Naresh Jetty, Prashanth V, Sanat Pattanaik, Diganta Sengupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Education, security, and progress in today's digital society are all greatly aided by information that accurately portrays the world. Nevertheless, there is a major cause for alarm over fake news in that respect. Efforts to combat false news have been ongoing, but the threat is ever-evolving, making it a complex and dynamic problem. So, to identify online false content, our method use an improved XGBoost algorithm. An enhanced jellyfish algorithm that enhances classification accuracy optimally selects the XGBoost weight. Users' devices can be integrated with the models through browser extensions and smartphone applications. The classification representations are accessible through web services and run on a server in cloud. While these models are effective at detecting false news in both English and European Portuguese, the latter is where the emphasis is, due to the dearth of work in this area. In addition to creating the first publicly available dataset for detecting false news in European Portuguese via online scraping, the models outperformed prior work despite training with a substantially larger quantity of data from a broader range of sources.

title:
Intelligent Fuzzy-Pid
                    <sup>Æ</sup>
                    control Scheme for ELD-LFC of Hydro-Thermal based three area Power System
authors: Khusboo Parvin, Srikanta Mohapatra, Subhra Debdas, Pabitra Kumar Tripathy, Humaid Abdullah Fadhil ALHinai, Amit Kumar Sahoo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This study covers research on load frequency control (LFC) of a three region thermal-hydro power system based on multiple electrical stations in relation to the Economic load dispatch (ELD). The LFC and ELD actions are accomplished on the same platform with a 1% step load perturbation using a noble fuzzy adaptive exponent PID (Fuzzy-Pid<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Æ</sup>) controller. Since the fuzzy membership function and adaptive exponent operate in accordance with systems demand, the controller benefits the three areas efficiently. Furthermore, this controller smoothly handles the severe power system uncertainty due to its fuzzy rule-based adaptive exponent derivative methodology. The results enable the fuzzy adaptive exponent controller to offer superior control performances when compared to the conventional fuzzy PID controller and PID controller. A new Dung Beetle Optimization (DBO) has been used in this study to schedule the gains of the proposed fuzzy - PID<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Æ</sup> controller. Appropriate gain scheduling is necessary because the controller's performance is mostly reliant on the choice of parameters. The optimal property of the expected DBO has also been examined by comparing with the simulated results of the conventional PSO and GA algorithm. Eventually, it is discovered that using a DBO guided fuzzy-PID<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Æ</sup> controller substantially improves LFC and ELD in a typical electrical multi-grid power system scenario.

title: Load Balancing in Wireless Communication Network using LSTM and Water Filling Algorithm
authors: Archana Sarangi, Shubhendu Kumar Sarangi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: For managing an efficient as well as automatic network, we need accuracy in cellular traffic load prediction. The characterization as well as channelization of the demands of the resources for network at diverse scales of time, allowing for dissimilar users’ actions at changed locations and time; via basic conventional techniques of prediction is challenging task in technical domain. In this paper we propose to use Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Water Filling Algorithm to achieve the accurate load prediction of a base-station and to distribute the power of the predicted load for load balancing using the SRJaffry Network_Traffic_Prediction Dataset. Firstly, the periodic data is extracted on hourly basis and is fed to LSTM network. The predicted data (with accuracy) is then used for power distribution using Water Filling Algorithm. On comparison it is found that the LSTM-Water-Filling Algorithm provides a better performance in comparison to the standard schemes, particularly for a comparatively time of long duration along with burst prediction of traffic.

title: Distribution of Renyi Entropy from Nakagami Distribution Sample
authors: Rama Rasheed, Azeza A L Abdallah, Andaleeb M. Abu Kamel
abstract: This paper rigorously computes the precise quantiles associated with the Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) method for Renyi entropy applied to the Nakagami distribution. Additionally, it approximates the quantiles of the asymptotic distribution of this statistic. Furthermore, the thesis introduces an enhanced version of this statistical measure. Remarkably, even in cases involving small sample sizes, the proposed method provides a formula for determining quantiles based on the chi-square distribution. This approach yields an exact distribution of statistics and reveals key characteristics of the MLE Renyi entropy applied to the Nakagami distribution.

title: Kinetostatic Modeling and Position-Orientation Control of Bellow-Shaped Soft Continuum Robots_supp1-3650845.pdf
authors: Guoying Gu
abstract: Bellow-shaped soft continuum robots with parallel mechanisms feature an excellent balance between structural stiffness and contact compliance, making them highly promising in various applications. However, their complex structures and nonlinear elastic characteristics pose significant challenges in modeling and control. In this work, we propose a kinetostatic model and a corresponding position-orientation controller for bellow-shaped soft continuum robots. First, bellow-shaped soft actuators are simplified into hyperelastic cylinder soft actuators with mechanical equivalence. In addition, the overall deformation is decoupled into elongation and bending components to enhance computational efficiency. Based on these two simplifying strategies, the kinetostatic model is developed with absolute nodal coordinate formulation theory. Then, forward and inverse kinetostatic mappings are defined, and the numerical solution algorithm is presented. Finally, the developed model is experimentally validated through configuration simulation and feedforward trajectory tracking. Experimental results demonstrate that the developed model achieves low prediction errors, with configuration simulation errors of 3.43%. Furthermore, with the model-based feedforward controller, a two-segment soft continuum robot can accurately follow desired trajectories with specified bending angles, achieving average position and angle errors of 4.14 mm and 1.58<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{\circ }$</tex-math></inline-formula>, respectively.

title: Contactless Control: A Real-Time Gesture Recognition Framework for Everyday Computing
authors: Priyanka More, Saniya Samant, Shlesha Patil, Shubhangi Topale, Vrushali Samant
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: With the advent of touchless interaction, gesture recognition has become a strong means of augmenting human-computer interaction, allowing more natural and accessible control interfaces. Contactless Control is a real-time gesture recognition system proposed in this paper to execute common computing tasks through hand gestures. A dataset was developed using MediaPipe and OpenCV, recording 21 hand landmark coordinates (x, y, z) for eight different gestures. These gestures were subsequently mapped to system-level commands like browser tab navigation (Next/Previous), opening applications such as Google Chrome, screen capture, and desktop opening. The system employs a Random Forest classifier trained on the dataset gathered in CSV format, which performs well in separating gesture classes in real-time. The framework proposed is implemented using a Flask-based application to facilitate seamless integration with current desktop environments. The light and scalable design enables real-time inference with little computational overhead, making it ideal for personal computers, smart kiosks, and assistive technologies. This work shows the potential of vision-based gesture recognition to transform human-computer interaction by providing contactless, efficient, and user-friendly control systems

title: A Lightweight Attention Convolutional Network for End-to-End Monaural Speech Separation
authors: En Ye, Erhua Zhang, Chunxia Hou
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Existing single-channel speech separation methods often rely on complex deep neural network architectures, such as convolutional neural network and recurrent neural network. These approaches suffer from high model complexity and poor real-time performance, especially in resource-constrained scenarios. To address this issue, this paper proposes a lightweight attention convolutional network (LAC-Net), centered around a Lightweight Multi-Branch Attention Block (LMBA Block). This module integrates Ghost Module, Channel Split and Channel Shuffle operations, as well as an improved Convolutional Block Attention Module. It significantly reduces model parameters and computational cost while effectively enhancing speech feature modeling and separation performance. Extensive experiments were conducted on WSJ0-2mix, Libri2Mix, and the selfconstructed Chinese datasets NJUST603-2Mix and NJUST6033Mix. The results demonstrate that LAC-Net consistently outperforms several classical baseline models in terms of SDRi and SI-SNRi. While maintaining a compact model size, LACNet exhibits stable performance in multi-speaker scenarios and achieves favorable results in real-time evaluations, highlighting its strong generalization ability.

title: Research on Alzheimer’s Disease Progression Prediction Algorithms Incorporating Temporal Dependencies
authors: Peng Tang, Yong Liu, ZuQiang Su, Feng Hu, Jin Dai
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder primarily affecting the elderly, characterized by gradually worsening memory loss, cognitive impairment, and behavioral changes, ultimately leading to the loss of ability to perform daily activities. As global populations age, AD has emerged as a significant challenge in public health. While there is currently no cure, early diagnosis and intervention can substantially improve patients’ quality of life. This study focuses on the temporal cumulative effects during the progression of AD from Cognitively Normal (CN) to Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI), and then to AD. We propose a predictive model for the progression of Alzheimer’s disease that takes into account the temporal cumulative effects, which can effectively capture the role of time accumulation in the development process of the disease. Our model was trained using longitudinal data from Alzheimer’s patients to predict disease progression at three future time points. Extensive experiments have shown that the proposed algorithm achieves optimal performance in terms of precision and recall. Over three time periods, the average prediction precision for CN, MCI, and AD is 0.805, 0.812, and 0.812, respectively, while the average recall rate is 0.862, 0.801, and 0.816, respectively.

title: MSHFF-Net: An Explainable Multi-Scale Hierarchical Feature Fusion CNN for Breast Cancer Diagnosis from Histopathological Images
authors: Muhammad Hassaan Ashraf, Musharif Ahmed, Muhammad Nabeel Mehmood, Muhammad Esham Qureshi, Hamed Alghamdi
abstract: Breast cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer-related deaths among women. Therefore, accurate multi-class grading of histopathological images is crucial for early screening and effective treatment of breast cancer. Given the large amount of intra-class variation and inter-class similarity, traditional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) frequently struggle in multi-class grading. To mitigate these challenges, we present MSHFF-Net, an Explainable Multi-Scale Hierarchical Feature Fusion architecture that combines adaptive multi-scale blocks with a feature-fusion stem to simultaneously capture tissue-level patterns and fine-grained cellular structures. The model processes input images of size <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$320 \times 320$</tex>, preserving spatial resolution to enable detailed feature extraction. MSHFF-Net is trained on the publicly available BRACS benchmark dataset using Leaky ReLU activation and sparse categorical cross-entropy loss function. It achieves an overall accuracy of 73.94%, outperforming several state-of-theart CNN backbones. These results demonstrate the effectiveness of hierarchical multi-scale feature fusion in enhancing automated breast cancer diagnosis from histopathological images. Furthermore, to ensure interpretability, the Explainable AI (XAI) method Gradient-Weighted Class Activation Mapping (Grad-CAM) is employed to visualize the decision-making process of MSHFF-Net, providing greater transparency and clinical trustworthiness.

title: Design A Low-Power Differential Active Inductor VCO for Aerospace Applications
authors: Nikhat Anjum, Vimal Kumar Singh Yadav, Vijay Nath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper presents a novel differential voltage-controlled oscillator (VCO) utilising a gyrator-C-based active inductor in CMOS technology, targeting aerospace applications. In the proposed design, bulky spiral inductors are replaced by a symmetric transistor network (M<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>-M<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</inf>) that emulates inductive characteristics, while cross-coupled transistors (M<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">11</inf>-M<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</inf>) create strong negative resistance to maintain stable oscillations. Key innovations include a dual-control voltage system (Vc<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</inf>/Vc<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) that permits accurate course and fine frequency adjustment. The simulation effects reveal a wide tuning range of 71.11%, overlaying frequencies from 2.03 to 4.27 GHz. phase noise measured -87.41 dBc/Hz at a 1 MHz offset and -111.1 dBc/Hz at a 10 MHz offset. The design famous a slight power consumption ranging from 5.72 to 7.09 mW and achieves a FoM<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">T</inf> of-166.35 dBc/Hz.

title: An Improved Truncated Statistic CFAR Algorithm Based on Interquartile Range
authors: Zihang Cheng, Peng Li, Renhong Xie, Jiangren Su, Weihao Pan, Huaxiang Fu, Zhongjun Jiang, Junhua Gao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper presents an improved Constant False Alarm Rate (CFAR) detection algorithm, termed LQTS-CFAR, which integrates Interquartile Range (IQR) and Local Outlier Factor (LOF) to enhance the robustness of the traditional TSCFAR algorithm. By leveraging IQR to construct adaptive truncation thresholds and using LOF to filter out strong interference, the proposed method improves the accuracy of background clutter power estimation through maximum likelihood estimation. Simulation results show that LQTS-CFAR outperforms conventional CFAR algorithms in homogeneous, multi-target, and clutter-edge environments. It effectively mitigates the target-masking effect in weak clutter regions and exhibits superior performance in terms of detection probability and false alarm control. The proposed approach significantly enhances environmental adaptability while maintaining acceptable CFAR loss, making it suitable for practical radar signal processing applications.

title: SlidingGLCMK-NN Classifier for Stream Learning.
authors: Suja A Alex, Vania Vieira Estrela, Gabriel Caumo Vaz, Yuzo Iano, Gabriel Gomes de Oliveira, Angela Maria Alves
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Big Data and Internet of Things
abstract: None

title: DEW-Net: A W-Shaped Dual-Encoder Network with Attention Fusion Mechanisms for Pathological H&E Image Segmentation
authors: Fuhan Meng, Xixiang Deng, Yingbo Qu, Chentao Li, Qiang Ma, Yusong Mao, Xinwei Zhang, Pan Huang, Hu Chen, Qiushi Wang, Peng Feng
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Segmenting programmed cell death-ligand 1 (PD-L1) expression regions in lung squamous cell carcinoma from pathological H&E images represents a challenging pixel-level prediction task, attributed to the morphological heterogeneity and size discrepancies of expression areas. Although hybrid architectures of CNN and Transformer can extract local features and capture long-range dependencies, they inadequately address information interaction and redundant information elimination during the fusion process, adversely impacting PD-L1 segmentation accuracy. To address this, we propose a W-shaped dual-encoder network (DEW-Net) with novel attention fusion mechanisms. First, a CNN encoder and a Swin Transformer encoder are connected in parallel to extract multi-layer local and global features from pathological images, respectively. Second, a Cross-Attention Fusion (CAF) module is proposed to strengthen information interaction and semantic feature fusion. Additionally, a Channel Attention (CA) is introduced in skip connections to enhance the channel-wise information of shallow features, while a Bilateral-voting Position Attention (BPA) module is further proposed to eliminate positional noise in same-scale shallow features and reinforce position-wise information. We conducted extensive experiments on four datasets. On the PD-L1 segmentation dataset, DEW-Net achieved superior performance, with DSC and IoU reaching 79.93% and 71.27%, respectively. These results demonstrate its strong performance and generalization capability compared to other state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods.

title: Multi-Horizon Short-Term Stock Trend Prediction using a hybrid CGTA model
authors: Ibanga Kpereobong Friday, Sarada Prasanna Pati, Debahuti Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Stock market trend prediction aims to predict the up/down movement of price change that helps market participants determine the optimal time to open and close their buy/sell positions to maximize profit. Prior studies have typically aimed to predict solely the 1-day up or down price movement, while others have extended to predict other short-term movements, such as 3-days, 7-days, and up to 30 days ahead. This type of prediction across different time frames enables traders to maximize their longer-term market view to strategize their trading positions. In lieu of this, we propose a multi-horizon stock trend prediction approach that predicts buy/sell positions for multiple time frames (1 day, 3 days, 7 days, and 10 days ahead) in a single output. This work proposes a CGTA model that combines layers from a convolutional neural network (CNN), gated recurrent unit (GRU), time distributed layer, and multi-head attention. This model architecture ensures that both class imbalance and long-term dependency in the data are efficiently handled so as to improve classification accuracy. The proposed CTGA model achieves an average accuracy of 82.16% across the different indices taken for the study, outperforming existing benchmark models in terms of classification accuracy and financial evaluations.

title: Solving Fuzzy Graph Coloring Problem Using A Hybrid Slime Mould Algorithm
authors: Siba Prasada Tripathy, Alok Kumar Jena
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The Graph Coloring Problem (GCP) is a traditional NP-hard problem that is conceptually related to the map coloring problem, which was studied extensively in the 20th century. GCP has been researched extensively over time, and many versions have been created. Although much advance has been made, it is still a subject of research, regularly motivating new strategies for the solution. The primary objective of the Graph Coloring Problem (GCP) is to assign colors to the vertices of a graph in a way that ensures no two connected vertices share the same color. In this study, we explore a variant of GCP in which the chromatic number is predefined, and we propose an innovative solution utilizing the Slime Mould Algorithm (SMA) to address this constraint-driven coloring challenge. The vertex colours are assigned dynamically according to fitness evaluation to strike a balance between exploration and exploitation based on algorithms inspired by the adaptive and oscillatory foraging behaviours of slime moulds. We further embed a fuzzy logic-based mechanism in the coloring process to adapt the coloring problem to the real world with uncertainty. We evaluate our method on the DIMACS benchmark dataset. Synthetics results show that the SMA-based approach yields the best results compared to others. This problem and different solutions have applications in several areas, e.g. scheduling systems, frequency assignment in mobile networks, coloring maps, testing of circuits, and register assignment in compilers.

title: Harnessing Quantum Gradient Machine Learning to Decode Subtelomeric Methylation in Telomere Maintenance Pathways
authors: Don Roosan, Rubayat Khan, Saif Nirzhor, Avik Mahata, Hasiba Khan
abstract: The overarching objective of this study is to determine whether subtelomeric DNA methylation states directly govern the choice of telomere length maintenance mechanisms in cancer cells that depend on either alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) or telomerase (TERT). Prior evidence suggests that ALT+ cells frequently exhibit hypomethylated subtelomeric regions, facilitating homologous recombination, whereas TERT+ cells maintain higher levels of subtelomeric methylation that support telomerase-based elongation. By integrating BioNano DLS optical mapping data, quantum-derived probabilities for coverage and position, and transcriptomic profiling of ATRX, DAXX, and TERT, this study aims to clarify how methylation-mediated chromatin accessibility affects telomere biology in cancer.

title: Semi-Supervised Learning Based GPR Data Interpreting Method for Subsurface Defect Detection in Heterogeneous Media
authors: Zekun Qin, Yao Chen, Hongfeng Ji, Bo Yan, Kaiwen Liu, Haokai Qi, Shuhua Gao, Zhengfang Wang, Jing Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Ground-penetrating radar (GPR) has become a critical tool for non-destructive subsurface defect detection in concrete structures. However, achieving robust and accurate recognition under limited labeled data remains a significant challenge, particularly in heterogeneous media. In this study, we propose a semi-supervised learning framework specifically designed for GPR-based defect detection under heterogeneous subsurface conditions. To address the domain gap, we construct diverse and representative synthetic datasets via stochastic simulations and further validate the framework on real measurement data. Furthermore, a novel data augmentation technique ScanDrop is developed to simulate signal occlusion and structural perturbations, thereby improving model robustness. We also introduce an orthogonal feature selection and similarity ranking mechanism to extract salient features across datasets and enhance model generalization. Experimental results on both synthetic and real-world data demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, showing consistent improvements over baseline and ablation models, and indicating its potential for more complex GPR-based applications in heterogeneous environments.

title: DSM Accuracy Enhancement via Satellite Stereo Imagery Super-Resolution: Multiscale Attention and Coordinate Mapping Optimization
authors: Jiang Ye, Zijun Shao, Jiayun Gou, Yingjia Huang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Contemporary stereo optical satellite imagery imposes inherent limitations on the resolution and elevation accuracy achievable in digital surface model (DSM) extraction. To mitigate these constraints, we introduce a novel stereo image pair super-resolution (SPSR) methodology. Existing super-resolution (SR) research primarily focuses on single images and fails to address the geometric model degradation in stereo pairs postprocessing. Furthermore, a rigorous comparison is absent between direct SR application on DSM versus DSM extraction from SR-enhanced stereo imagery. Our solution employs a dual aggregation transformer with multiscale attention (DATMAT) network, which effectively resolves challenges in multiscale information aggregation and computational redundancy for remote sensing imagery. Crucially, by establishing a geometric position mapping model between super-resolved and source imagery, we rectify the loss of geolocational fidelity post-SR. Extensive experiments on WV2, SV1, GF7, and ZY3 datasets demonstrate that DATMAT significantly outperforms representative and recent deep learning methods (e.g., HAT, DAT, and EDSR). Quantitatively, DATMAT improves PSNR by 1.60%–19.08% and SSIM by 0.73%–8.03% over peer models. In terms of DSM vertical accuracy, although the performance gap among deep learning methods is inherently narrow, DATMAT achieves the lowest elevation RMSE across all tested platforms, reaching an optimal 2.46 m on WV2 and 3.78 m on GF7. Compared to the strongest competing Transformer-based models, DATMAT further reduces the elevation RMSE and MAE, while consistently maintaining the highest concentration of low-magnitude errors. These results indicate that DATMAT provides superior geometric model recovery and cross-scene robustness, establishing a high-precision, low-cost framework for satellite-based DSM production, promoting the practical utility of submeter resolution geospatial mapping.

title: Investigations of Beam Characteristics in High-Power Millimeter-Wave Transmission Line for ECRH System
authors: Guoyao Fan, Mei Huang, Donghui Xia, Cheng Chen, Feng Zhang, Wanxin Zheng, Xixuan Chen, Jieqiong Wang, He Wang
abstract: The millimeter-wave beam characteristics in the oversized circular corrugated waveguides transmission lines (TLs), approximately 40 m, for electron cyclotron resonance heating (ECRH) system on HL-3 tokamak were studied. The irradiance moments were calculated and the phase retrieval, also mode analysis was finished according to the wave amplitude profiles obtained by taking temperature using an infrared (IR) camera on paper target placed in front of the waveguide outlet. As results, the wave beam is radiated from the waveguide aperture with about 0.44° and less than 0.05° tilt angles in x- and y-directions, and expanses faster than LP01 mode, and the phase profile is inclined along the x-axis and flat along the $y$ -axis. The proportion of LP01 mode is about 94%, and it is about 4.6% for the LP11(even) mode. All results agree well with the assumed theoretical calculations that 95% LP01 mode and 5% ${}_{\mathrm { }}$ LP11(even) mode with relative phase $- 0.75\pi $ in the waveguide, verifying their reliability. These results suggest that the wave beam coupling efficiency between waveguides and the initial coupling efficiency at matching output unit are important, and they are good enough for the experimental system.

title: Comparative Study of Object Detection Models for Automotive In-Vehicle Environments
authors: Diana Ferreira, Cristiana Neto, Ana Santos, Carlos Ferreira, Duarte Fernandes, José Machado
abstract: The rapid progression of autonomous driving and advanced driver-assistance systems has emphasized the need for robust and efficient object detection within vehicle environments. This paper conducts a comparative analysis of state-of-the-art object detection models for in-vehicle environments using public datasets, guided by the CRISP-DM (Cross-Industry Standard Process for Data Mining) methodology. The study includes several YOLO models (YOLOv5, YOLOv7, YOLOv8, and YOLOvl0), a transformer-based model (RT-DETR), and a CNN-based model incorporating self-attention mechanisms (YOLO-NAS). The evaluation relies on key metrics such as mean Average Precision (mAP) and inference time to determine each model's effectiveness. The experimental results indicate that while our approach to vehicle interior objects detection for forgotten items shows promise, the overall performance fell short of expectations. The YOLOv7 x variant achieved a recall of 0.632 and an mAP50 of 0.351, offering better precision than YOLOv5 in some cases. However, its 10.3-millisecond GPU inference time underscores the challenge of balancing accuracy and computational efficiency. The findings emphasize the impact of dataset quality and class balance in achieving robust and reliable object detection, highlighting the need for tailored datasets to enhance model reliability in real-world automotive applications. This research contributes to the broader vision of green and smart cities by advancing technologies that improve vehicle safety and support sustainable urban mobility systems.

title: The Extreme Two-Wave Model: A Channel Model for Severe Fading Conditions
authors: Maryam Olyaee, Juan P. Peña-Martín, Juan M. Romero-Jerez
abstract: Harsh propagation conditions due to severe multipath fading can be found in several wireless communications environments, where the channel characteristics significantly deviate from the predictions made by traditional fading models. In this work we introduce the Extreme Two-Wave (ETW) fading model, which is specifically tailored to model severe fading scenarios, simultaneously encompassing the Two-Ray and the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\kappa$</tex-math></inline-formula>-<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mu$</tex-math></inline-formula> Extreme fading models, which have been previously proposed for these situations. The ETW model is a limiting case of the recently introduced Multi-cluster Two-Ray (MTW) fading model and finds applications in wireless scenarios where the received waves may add deconstructively and there is a non-negligible probability of null signal reception. The probability density function, the cumulative distribution function and the generalized moment generating function are obtained for the proposed model, as well as the outage capacity probability, the average channel capacity, the outage probability under interference, the bit error rate and the probability of secure communications in the presence of an eavesdropper. Moreover, an effective algorithm is introduced to generate random ETW fading white power samples. It is also shown that the proposed model offers a very good fit to empirical data measurements in environments experiencing severe fading conditions.

title: A Deep Learning-Based Automated System for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation and Defibrillation
authors: Abdel Rahman Shaaban, Mostafa El-Hussien Ibrahem, Mostafa S. El-Mohandes, Neven Saleh, Ahmed S. El-Hossiny
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Cardiac arrest is one of the leading causes of death globally, with out-of-hospital cases often classified as severe. Therefore, a rapid and accurate response is crucial to improving survival rates. This study presents the design and implementation of a low-cost, portable, automated cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) device integrated with an intelligent defibrillation system. It is composed of three main components: ECG acquisition using the AD8232 module, a mechanical compression mechanism driven by a slider-crank setup, and a defibrillator unit capable of delivering high-voltage shocks. A convolutional neural network (CNN) was employed to classify ECG signals into shockable and non-shockable rhythms. A dataset composed of three separate sets was utilized for training and testing, achieving an accuracy of 98.5%. Evaluations showed that the CPR device effectively controlled compression depth using LED indicators, accurately detected rhythms, and reliably delivered energy through test capacitor configurations. The device offers a compact, affordable, and efficient solution for improving out-of-hospital cardiac arrest response.

title: Assessing Privacy Risks in Differential Privacy Models for Communication-Centric Learning
authors: Milon Biswas, Yifan Guo, Weixian Liao, Wei Yu
abstract: The rise of communication-centric machine learning (federated learning, edge-cloud inference, and learning as a service APIs) has heightened concerns about data leakage and privacy under adversarial access. While Differential Privacy (DP) offers formal privacy guarantees, real-world deployments in networked systems often experience empirical leakage that could exceed theoretical bounds. This paper presents an empirical framework for evaluating privacy leakage in DP-trained learning models deployed in communication-intensive environments. In particular, this study study Membership Inference Attacks (MIA), quantify empirical loss via Privacy Loss Random Variables (PLRV), and track privacy degradation using Rényi Differential Privacy (RDP). To enhance privacy risk auditing, further proposed a Fuzzy Inference System (FIS) that integrates theoretical guarantees, leakage metrics, model utility, and query patterns into an interpretable Fuzzy Risk Score (FRS). Our experiments on MIMIC-III and Adult datasets reveal substantial discrepancies between formal and empirical privacy loss in practical deployment scenarios. This study bridges privacy theory with communication-aware security, providing actionable insights for secure learning across distributed systems, including nextgeneration networking, the Internet of Things, and federated Artificial Intelligence (AI) architectures.

title: Health-Aware Multi-Agent Dispatching Framework Using Disjoint Set Structures for Intelligent Crowd Management
authors: Akram Y. Sarhan
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Our research introduces a health-aware dispatching framework for large-scale crowd events, focusing on safety and privacy. It combines (i) Disjoint Set Union (DSU) for efficient group management, (ii) Multi-Agent Systems (MAS) for decentralized coordination, and (iii) Ciphertext-Policy Attribute-Based Encryption (CP-ABE) for secure attribute protection. The DSU allows quick group updates, while the MAS policy forms temporary health-based subgroups and seamlessly reintegrates them. The framework balances throughput and safety with a biobjective dispatch policy, minimizing risks and delays. A JADE simulation with 1,001 agents demonstrates scalability, showing stable monitoring and efficient DSU operations, effectively managing vulnerable subgroups without disrupting flow.

title: Optimized Control for ISOP LLC-DAB Converter to Achieve Full-Power-Range Zero-Voltage Switching and Fast Dynamic Response
authors: Qunfang Wu, Wanxiang Liu, Wenlong Chen, Bo Hu, Qin Wang, Dezhi Li
abstract: In recent years, the input-series-output-parallel (ISOP) LLC-DAB converter has been applied to DC microgrids and energy routers. However, the existing control methods still have some limitations, such as a limited range of soft switching, large current stress, and slow dynamic response speed, which restrict the efficiency and dynamic performance of the converter. This paper optimizes the Triple-Phase-Shift (TPS) modulation scheme to achieve full-range soft-switching operation across varying input voltages, while simultaneously optimizing current stress characteristics and improving the converter's efficiency. Meanwhile, a more concise closed-loop control strategy is developed. Then, a direct power control (DPC) strategy based on inductor current stress optimization is presented. This strategy calculates the phase-shift ratio parameters according to the converter's required power transmission. The calculation ensures the transmitted power quickly matches the load power. The approach improves the converter's dynamic performance during input voltage and load variations. The improvement is achieved while maintaining optimized current stress conditions. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed control strategy is verified by experimental results of a 2.5kW prototype.

title: Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithms in Designing Redundant Water Distribution Systems
authors: Matteo Nicolini
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Water supply and distribution systems are critical infrastructures whose design heavily influences the operating conditions during unexpected demands. Rapid urbanization, increasing leakage and ageing infrastructures are the main factors responsible for poor performance under different scenarios. Water distribution networks have to be designed with the aim of reliability, but also with the need of containing costs. In these last decades, several Evolutionary Algorithms have been proposed for solving such problems, obtaining successful results. The paper aims at comparing the performance of two multi-objective genetic algorithms in solving a relatively simple optimization problem, for which the complete Pareto front has been calculated. The tests have been performed on the problem of designing the pipes of a two-loop water distribution network where the first objective is the minimization of the cost and the second objective is the maximization of the redundancy, expressed as the average pressure surplus above a minimum required value. The performance indices considered keep into account both the exploration and the exploitation capabilities of the algorithms.

title: A Comparative Evaluation of Search and Metaheuristic Algorithms for the N-Queens Problem: Scalability, Efficiency, and Success Rates
authors: Eslam Mahmoud Mohamed Mahmoud Aly, Muhammad Maaz Hamid, Muhammad Imad, Raja Hashim Ali
abstract: The N-Queens problem is a well-known test in artificial intelligence and optimization, it involves the arranging N queens on NxN chessboard so that no two queens attack each other. This study offer a replicable comparison of four distinct algorithmic approaches: Depth-First Search (DFS), Simulated Annealing (SA), Hill Climbing (HC), Genetic Algorithm (GA). Each algorithm was implemented with the same unified experimental setup and tested across increasing board sizes (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=10,30$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50,100,200$</tex>) using the same identical initial states to maintain a fair comparison. the evaluation focused on a critical performance indicators such as execution time, number of moves, memory consumption, and success rate. The results show that while DFS performs reliably on smaller boards, it becomes impractical as N increases. HC with random restarts and SA both performed effectively on larger board sizes, SA demonstrating better time efficiency but needing more moves. Although GA achieved low memory consumption and fast iterations, it struggled to find valid solutions beyond <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$N=30$</tex>, even with increased number of generations. this work delivers a reproducible benchmarking framework that supports fair algorithmic evaluation and highlights the trade-offs between efficiency and scalability across different optimization methods. the insights gained from this study can inform future research in constraint satisfaction and hybrid metaheuristic strategies.

title: Precoding Strategies for Network Coexistence and Interference Mitigation on Licensed Spectrum
authors: Sezanildo S. Paula Filho, Juno V. Saraiva, Roberto P. Antonioli, Igor M. Guerreiro, Yuri C. B. Silva, Walter C. Freitas, Behrooz Makki
abstract: The increasing demand for wireless services has led to dense deployments of access points (AP) in licensed spectrum, intensifying challenges related to coexistence - the simultaneous operation of multiple networks in the same frequency band and interference. This article investigates precoding strategies and heuristic methods to improve coexistence between a primary and a secondary network operating in the same licensed band. A heuristic AP shutdown strategy is proposed for the secondary network, where the APs causing the highest interference - estimated based on available metrics - are selectively deactivated. This approach dynamically reduces interference to the primary network while preserving the secondary network’s performance. Different precoding strategies are analyzed, and the simulation results indicate that the methods based on mimimum mean square error achieve good performance in terms of spectral efficiency. Overall, the proposed combination of AP management and efficient precoding offers a promising solution for spectrum sharing in dense network environments.

title: Dynamic Adjustment for Different Loss Functions in Multi-Label Classification
authors: Hongtao Peng, Haiyan Wu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: To address the class imbalance problem in multilabel classification, we propose a novel dynamic adjustment method that automatically tunes key hyperparameters within the loss function during training. This method dynamically adjusts hyperparameters based on the model's performance, eliminating the need for manual hyperparameter tuning, ensuring that the model can more effectively adapt to the dataset's distribution, thereby improving its ability to recognize samples from different classes, especially in cases of imbalanced class distributions. Experimental results show that the dynamic adjustment method outperforms baseline loss functions, with robust performance across datasets like MS COCO14 (image dataset) and PubMed (text dataset). It effectively improves recall for minority classes and maintains overall model stability, particularly for long-tailed distributions. This approach can be integrated with various models based on neural networks and has a broad application potential for other tasks, making it a valuable tool for enhancing model performance.

title: A Hybrid Self-Healing Framework Using Network Motif Discovery and Machine Learning With Blockchain Integration for Proactive Cyber-Attack Detection in Financial Networks
authors: Ivy Payne Nkrumah, Margaret A Richardson, Robert A. Sowah, Percy Okae, Isaac Aboagye, Kenneth Broni, Godfrey Mills
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: In the evolving landscape of cyber threats targeting Automated Teller Machine (ATM) networks, anomaly detection systems must move beyond reactive alerts toward proactive, interpretable, and adaptive defense mechanisms. This study presents a hybrid anomaly detection and mitigation framework that integrates network motif-based traffic analysis, machine learning, blockchain-based forensic logging, and a conceptual self-healing mechanism. Motif patterns were extracted from the CICIDS2017 Friday dataset using NetworkX to reveal latent structural behaviors in network flows. Initially, a One-Class Support Vector Machine (OC-SVM) was applied but yielded suboptimal results due to class imbalance, achieving only 29.6% precision, 59.4% recall, 39.5% F1-score, and 90.92% accuracy. Consequently, the study transitioned to a supervised SVM model. Without SMOTE, this model achieved 96.34% accuracy, 82.01% precision, 48.66% F1-score, and 35.00% recall. To improve minority class detection, SMOTE was introduced, leading to increased recall (81.20%) but reduced precision (27.45%), demonstrating the inherent trade-offs of resampling. Confirmed anomalies were logged immutably on a private Ethereum blockchain via Solidity smart contracts, deployed using Remix IDE, ensuring forensic traceability and tamper-proof records. The framework, called Efficient Self-Healing Secure Framework for Enhanced Cyber-resilience in ATM Networks (Eshsfec-A), includes a semi-automated whitelist-based response mechanism to support healing processes. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) validated the feature separability, and the system flagged over 300 attack vectors in real time. This work demonstrates a viable path toward future self-resilient cybersecurity solutions for financial infrastructures.

title: From Informed Independent Vector Extraction to Hybrid Architectures for Target Source Extraction
authors: Zbyněk Koldovský, Jiří Málek, Martin Vrátný, Tereza Vrbová, Jaroslav Čmejla, Stephen O'Regan
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Signal Processing
abstract: This article revises informed independent vector extraction (iIVE) as a framework for connecting model-based blind source extraction (BSE) with deep learning. We introduce the contrast function for iIVE, which is derived by extending IVE with beamforming-based constraints, enabling an interpretable use of reference signals. We also show that structured mixing models implementing physical knowledge can be integrated, which is demonstrated by two far-field models. With the contrast functions, rapidly converging second-order algorithms are developed, whose performance is first verified through simulations. In the experimental part, we refine iIVE by training models containing unrolled iterations of the developed algorithm. The resulting structures achieve performance comparable to state-of-the-art networks while requiring two orders of magnitude fewer trainable parameters and exhibiting strong generalization to unseen conditions.

title: Ring artifact reduction in photon counting CT using redundant sampling and autocalibration
authors: Scott S. Hsieh, James Day, Xinchen Deng, Magdalena Bazalova-Carter
abstract: Ring artifacts in CT are caused by uncalibrated variations in detector pixels and are especially prevalent with emerging photon counting detectors (PCDs). Control of ring artifacts is conventionally accomplished by improving either hardware manufacturing or software correction algorithms. An alternative solution is detector autocalibration, in which two redundant samples of each line integral are acquired and used to dynamically calibrate the PCD. Autocalibration was first proposed by Hounsfield in 1977 and was demonstrated on the EMI Topaz prototype scanner in 1980, but details surrounding this implementation are sparse. We investigate a form of autocalibration that requires just two redundant acquisitions, which could be acquired using flying focal spot on a clinical scanner but is demonstrated here with a detector shift. We formulated autocalibration as an optimization problem to determine the relative gain factor of each pixel and tested it on scans of a chicken thigh specimen, resolution phantom, and a cylindrical phantom. Ring artifacts were significantly reduced. Some residual artifacts remained but could not be discriminated from the intrinsic temporal instability of our PCD modules. Autocalibration could facilitate the adoption of widespread photon counting CT by reducing ring artifacts, thermal management requirements, or stability requirements that are present today. Demonstration of autocalibration on a rotating gantry with flying focal spot remains future work.

title: An Advanced Algorithm for Constructing Elevation Change Time Series with Satellite Altimetry Observations
authors: Xiao Li, Shengkai Zhang, Lexian Yuan, Luke D. Trusel, Haotian Cui, Feng Xiao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Establishing long-term time series of elevation changes using satellite altimetry data enables comprehensive monitoring of the Earth's surface over extended periods. In polar regions, long-term elevation monitoring of ice sheets and ice shelves is crucial to determine their mass balance. This paper introduces the indirect adjustment method (IAM), a novel algorithm for establishing elevation change time series. Through theoretical comparisons and practical calculations of the Ross Ice Shelf (RIS) and Filchner–Ronne Ice Shelf (FRIS) using CryoSat-2 altimetric data, we conducted a comparative analysis of the IAM with previous methods for constructing elevation change time series. A particular advantage of the IAM is its ability to integrate data from a larger number of altimetric cycles, thereby maximizing data utilization. The elevation values in the time series constructed using the IAM have a lower standard deviation, reducing uncertainty caused by data errors and improving the accuracy of determining long-term elevation changes, with an average reduction of about 30% in the annual trend standard error relative to the Fixed Full-Matrix Method (FFM). Notably, even in the case of partial missing data, IAM yields significantly more effective cycles in the resulting elevation change time series compared to other methods. In 5 × 5 km grids of the RIS and FRIS, the time series constructed using the IAM algorithm show more effective cycles, increasing the average number of effective cycles by approximately 34% relative to FFM, improving the spatiotemporal resolution and continuity of the time series. This enhancement allows for more detailed and precise elevation change estimates over time.

title: GangaFlow: A Multi-Model Deep Learning Framework for Real-Time River Pollution Detection and Analysis Using Drone Imagery
authors: Avantika Ramprasad Patil, Nishit Bohra M, Omkar Hanumant Thorve, Nilkanth Deshpande, Shrikrishna Kolhar, Shilpa Gite, Biswajeet Pradhan, Sashikala Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Pollution of the waterways is a serious environmental issue affecting ecosystems, public health, and sustainable development. This paper presents the GangaFlow - a real-time multimodal deep learning system designed for pollution analysis in the Ganga River using drone imagery. The system integrates YOLOv8 for object detection, U-Net for semantic segmentation, and AlexNet for image classification. The pre-processing steps included the conversion of the RGB colormap to HSV and data augmentation to enhance the models’ performances. The evaluation on the annotated drone image dataset resulted in significant improvements in accuracy, with an IoU of 0.5 for YOLOv8 at least and a 20% increment in IoU when compared to individual models. A 15% increase in F1-scores was signified, which is an indication of the robust detection and classification of pollutants. The scalable AI-driven GangaFlow is expected to make efficient large-scale monitoring of river pollution possible, furnishing policy-informative insights for regulators of the environment. GangaFlow has pioneered a novel real-time river pollution monitoring framework based on AI and has genuine practice relevance to large environmental management purposes.

title: Social Media, Polarization, and the Erosion of Informed Voting: The Impact of Echo Chambers on Democracy
authors: Sayan Pan, Sangita Dutta, Saikat Samanta, Shubham Paul, Saikat Ghosh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The spread of misinformation on social media is significantly filled by users who share or comment on erroneous or controversial posts. Echo chambers—environments where individuals engage mainly with like-minded peers—amplify these dynamics. Due to homophily (the tendency to connect with similar others) and biased information diffusion, these spaces reinforce users’ beliefs. This research explores how language use mediates conversations about misinformation by analyzing linguistic markers such as in-group cues, readability, and discourse connectives across different topics and communities. Findings indicate that discussions within echo chambers show a higher use of group identity signals and readability, making misinformation more persuasive and easily processed.

title: DOA Estimation Based on Spatially Distributed Polarization Sensitive Array
authors: Ping Ni, Muran Guo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Polarization-sensitive arrays can sense the polarization parameters of incident signals, and demonstrates strong suitability and the robustness to function effectively in complex electromagnetic environments. However, in practical applications, traditional polarization-sensitive arrays face challenges such as inflexible positioning and low angular measurement accuracy. This paper proposes a direction of arrival (DOA) estimation structure based on a distributed polarizationsensitive array, which innovatively employs multiple non-coherent sub-arrays that can be flexibly positioned in different spatial locations according to actual application requirements. Through composite rotation transformations, a spatial diversity structure is formed, and by distributing two array elements to constitute a distributed architecture, the virtual array aperture is effectively expanded, thereby enhancing angle measurement performance. When applied to the classical Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) algorithm, the distributed polarization-sensitive array not only enables DOA estimation of the azimuth and elevation of incident signals but also significantly improves angular measurement performance and resolution capability.

title: Automated 3D Modeling of Objects using LiDAR
authors: Vijay Singh Sisodiya, Sunil Kumar, Amitangshu Pal
abstract: Automated 3D modeling has several potential applications ranging from industrial quality control to archaeological artifact analysis and rapid prototyping. This paper presents the development and implementation of a LiDAR-based system for 3D modeling of various objects. We create a versatile and efficient scanning setup using a 2D LiDAR sensor - by leveraging the advantages of LiDAR technology, we achieve precise distance measurements and create high-resolution 3D models. Through experimentation, we show that our proposed solution produces high-fidelity 3D models for a wide variety of object types, shapes and sizes, which can be used to estimate their precise volume and surface areas. For all the objects tested in our experiments, the volume and area estimation error remains below 10%, whereas for most of the objects, the error remains below 2-3%.
