title: A Novel Gridless DOD and DOA Estimation Method for Incomplete Data
authors: Sizhe Gao, Yunyu Wei, Jingjing Wang, Pengcheng Guo, Ziming Yin, Kuo Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an efficient direction of departure and direction of arrival estimation method for bistatic MIMO radar with faulty arrays. A third-order tensor model is built, and the measurement three-dimensional structure can be better utilized than the traditional matrix model. Subsequently, the atomic norm minimization technique is used to further improve the angle estimation performance. Furthermore, we found in the research process that when the faulty arrays still maintain the symmetry property, the measurement tensor can be converted to the real-valued domain by the forward-backward averaging technique and the unitary transform technique. The new algorithm we proposed exploits the multidimensional structure of the signal without estimating the signal subspace. Comparing with traditional matrix completion methods, it has better performance in terms of robustness and resolving correlated targets. And the algorithm proposed in this paper does not require angle pairing. Simulation results verify the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

title: QuickScale: a Quick Scaling Scheme for Erasure-Coded Deduplicated Storage Systems
authors: Chunxue Zuo, Lanlan Cui, Fang Wang, Jun Liu
abstract: Modern deduplication-based storage systems employ erasure coding to post-deduplicate data to ensure reliability. In the erasure-coded deduplicated storage systems, existing coding schemes mainly perform erasure coding over a single object (intra-object coding) to address the problems of degraded read performance and storage inefficiency. However, due to intra-object coding, traditional storage scaling schemes need to reorganize and relocate all stored data between the client and storage nodes to support storage scaling, which inevitably incurs substantial data transfer overhead, thereby degrading system scalability. In this paper, we propose a fast scaling scheme called QuickScale for erasure-coded deduplicated storage systems. QuickScale first implements the intra-object coding in a realistic distributed storage environment and verifies that this coding scheme can significantly alleviate the degraded read performance by 35%-67% and save storage space by 24% 30%. Motivated by these results, QuickScale uses a node-to-node scaling approach that avoids repeatedly transferring all stored data between the client and storage nodes during scaling, thereby improving the scalability. Experimental evaluations using six real-world datasets demonstrate that QuickScale achieves better scaling performance (in terms of scaling time during scaling) over the state-of-the-art scaling schemes by up to 63.5%-76.4%.

title: Practical Solutions to Volt-var Optimization under Uncertainty via Blackbox Optimization
authors: Feng Li, Ilhan Kocar, Antoine Lesage-Landry
abstract: In this work, we propose an optimal reactive power dispatch (ORPD) stochastic program for volt-var optimization (VVO) of power distribution networks. The formulation considers not only control settings of conventional VVO devices, e.g., voltage regulators, capacitor banks, and on-load tap changers, but also optimal settings for volt-var droop curves of distributed energy resources (DERs), compliant with the IEEE 1547-2018 standard. Instead of including the power flow equations in the optimization problem which makes it nonlinear and nonconvex, a power flow solver is utilized and the problem is solved by blackbox optimization (BBO). The feasibility of the derived solution is improved by using unbalanced power flow simulations. The solution is effective under various demand and DER generation scenarios such that device settings are not frequently changed, making it practical for in-field implementations. Through numerical simulations on IEEE test feeders, we illustrate the performance of the solutions of our proposed approach on both in-sample and out-of-sample scenarios. We show that our approach outperforms a benchmark reinforcement learning method, and is also scalable to large-scale distribution networks.

title: End-to-End Seam Tracking with Flow Matching-Based Diffusion Policy
authors: Zhaoqi Chu, Xiangrong Liu, Xuhui Que, Bo Yu, Juan Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: To address the challenges of initial pose definition, online tracking, and task planning in multi-target, multi-seam robotic welding scenarios, this paper proposes an end-to-end multimodal seam tracking framework that integrates RGB cameras and line-structured light sensors. The method combines global scene perception with high-precision local sampling, enabling joint task and trajectory planning under a behavior cloning paradigm. Built upon the Diffusion Policy framework, the proposed policy model replaces the traditional Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM) with Flow Matching, significantly improving training and inference efficiency. To enhance data diversity for imitation learning, a domain-randomized demonstration sampling environment is constructed. The collected demonstrations are transferred into the PyBullet simulation environment using a sim-to-sim pipeline for policy training. Experimental results on multi-object, multi-trajectory simulation tasks demonstrate that the proposed method enables autonomous initial pose guidance, robust seam tracking, and seamless trajectory switching without human intervention.

title: Doppler Fold Clutter Suppression Based on MixedNorm Sparse Recovery for Inter-pulse non-uniformly spaced Radar
authors: Xiaojian Xu, Liang Zhang, Dehua Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a single Coherent Processing Interval (CPI) ambiguity resolution scheme for Pulsed Doppler (PD) radar using Inter-pulse non-uniformly spaced waveforms, which improves efficiency compared to traditional multiple CPI methods. For airborne radar with platform motion induced clutter Doppler-broadened, we propose a sparse recovery method for fold clutter suppression. Mixednorm constraints were applied to restrict clutter energy, preventing spectral leakage caused by over-sparsification. To improve the computational efficiency of the proposed method, the solution process using the Alternating Direction Method of Multipliers (ADMM) is derived. Simulation results within a PD airborne radar context validate the effectiveness of the proposed methodologies.

title: Verified Validator, Delegation, and Reward Processes in PoS System
authors: Raeesa Mukhtar, Nazir Ahmad Zafar, Hamra Afzaal
abstract: The Proof of Stake(PoS) consensus procedure has become a largely embraced option to the energy-demanding Proof of Work (PoW) contract, guaranteeing the integrity, reliability, and decentralization in the latest Blockchain programme. In a PoS system, staking procedures, validator and delegation functions, reward distribution processes, and governance control operations must be implemented accurately to maintain the system's security. This paper represents the formal verification and validation of Stake Manager key features, as verification of validators and delegators, setting staking tokens, reward evaluation and distribution, and authentication of the owner. This formal model is evolved using the Communicating Sequential Processes (CSP#), and this model is verified concerning critical safety and liveness properties defined in Linear Temporal Logic formula (LTL). The Process Analysis Toolkit (PAT) model checker is used to check these properties, containing accurate reward distribution and exclusion of deadlocks. This verification mechanism ensures that all processes work properly in all feasible execution states. The results ensure the reliability and security of the Stake Manager Contract and emphasize the efficacy of formal verification in securing the PoS blockchain structure.

title: Securing 5G Critical Interfaces: A Zero Trust Approach for Next-Generation Network Resilience
authors: Sibaram Prasad Panda
abstract: The dynamic and virtualized nature of 5G networks introduces unprecedented challenges in securing critical interfaces such as N1, N2, N3, and Service-Based Interfaces (SBIs). These interfaces are essential for interconnecting 5G components like the NG-RAN, 5GC, and external entities but are increasingly targeted by sophisticated cyberattacks. This paper explores a novel application of Zero Trust Architecture (ZTA) to strengthen the security of these critical interfaces. By analyzing vulnerabilities across traditional, centralized, and virtualized RAN implementations, the study identifies key threats and highlights the gaps in existing security frameworks. It further proposes an adaptive ZTA framework tailored for 5G environments, emphasizing continuous verification, granular access control, and cross-layer security. The findings offer actionable insights into integrating ZTA principles within 5G networks, paving the way for a unified, scalable, and resilient security paradigm.

title: Enhanced Lung Disease Detection Model Using PSO-Based Feature Selection and Ensemble Learning Approach
authors: Soumya Snigdha Mohapatra, Sourav Parija, Debendra Muduli, Santosh Kumar Sharma, Rakesh Ranjan Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of lung diseases necessitates the implementation of prompt and accurate diagnostic measures to enhance patient outcomes. This research proposes an innovative approach to address the challenges associated with the analysis of complex, high-dimensional clinical data. This study employs particle swarm optimization (PSO) used for feature selection to identify the most significant traits, alongside Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to reduce the complexity of the data. Subsequent to the enhancement of these features, they are categorised into distinct groups utilizing various algorithms, including Logistic Regression, KNearest Neighbours (KNN), and a range of ensemble methods. The model exhibiting the highest accuracy achieved a score of 96.08%, underscoring the significance of advanced feature reduction techniques and the design of robust classifiers in the analysis of medical data. This finding highlights their potential application in real-world healthcare diagnostics.

title: Follow the Forest Trail: Distillation by Gradient Boosting Models to Enhance Symbolic Regression Performance
authors: Assaf Shmuel, Teddy Lazebnik, Oren Glickman
abstract: In recent years, Machine Learning (ML) models have been introduced across diverse scientific fields, due to their strong predictive performance. However, in many applications the demand for interpretable models often surpasses the need for mere accuracy. Symbolic Regression (SR) offers a solution with its concise and explainable formulas, yet it typically falls short in accuracy when compared to other ML models such as Random Forests. This paper proposes a novel two-step ensemble approach, inspired by the student-teacher model in knowledge distillation. Initially, a Gradient Boosting Model (GBM) is trained to harness its high accuracy; this model acts as the ‘teacher.’ Subsequently, an SR ’student’ model is trained on the output of the gradient boosting model, effectively distilling the knowledge into a form that combines interpretability with enhanced performance. We perform an extensive evaluation of this method across three different SR models and 10 regression datasets. Our findings show that the proposed method exhibits a consistent improvement of 3.3-6.7% in accuracy compared to standard SR models. Furthermore, this process serves as an explainability framework that helps to uncover and interpret the decisions of complex ML models.

title: Ultralow-Profile Folded Transmitarray with Low RCS by Combining Two Asymmetric Reflections and Integrated Absorption-Scattering
authors: Zhengjie Wang, He-Xiu Xu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: In this letter, we propose a strategy of engineering an ultralow-profile folded transmitarray (FTA) with low radar cross section (RCS). The architecture integrates a frequency selective rasorber (FSR), a transmissive-reflective metasurface (TRM), a focusing polarization-conversion metasurface (FPCM), and a feed horn. Two operation modes are engineered to simultaneously achieve high-gain radiation and low observability. For radiation, spherical waves from the feed are transformed by the TRM and FPCM into a high-gain beam. Therein, two asymmetric reflections are employed achieving an ultralow profile of 1/7 the focal length. For invisibility, out-of-band and in-band RCS reduction are achieved by FSR absorption and TRM scattering, respectively. For verification, a proof-of-concept prototype is numerically and experimentally characterized, indicating a measured peak gain of 24.6 dBi with a corresponding aperture efficiency of 26% at 14.1 GHz. In addition, a relative bandwidth of 10 dB RCS reduction is reached as 95.5% and 87.1% for co- and cross-polarized incident waves, respectively. Such a highly integrated stealth meta-FTA exhibits strong potential for stealth communication systems.

title: Inducing Implicit Focus Through Structured Irrelevance for Robust Neural PDE Solvers
authors: Yunpeng Gong, Qingyuan Zeng, Chenchen Liu, Jian Guan, Jiajing Lin, Chuangliang Zhang, Yongjie Hou, Yipeng Huang, Zhenzhong Wang, Xiaobo Li, Xiaodan Feng, Min Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Neural solvers for partial differential equations (PDEs) have shown remarkable potential across scientific computing and physics-informed learning. However, their performance often hinges on fragile feature dependencies, leading to poor generalization and vulnerability to input noise or domain shifts. In this work, we propose a simple yet effective trainingtime perturbation scheme that improves generalization by injecting structured, semantically irrelevant signals into the input space. Specifically, we randomly replace small, localized regions of the input with constant values, thereby compelling the model to focus on predictive patterns that remain stable under partial information loss. We formally analyze the learning dynamics and show that such perturbations induce an implicit feature selection mechanism, which we term Perturbation-Induced Implicit Focus (PIIF). This mechanism arises as the model progressively suppresses unstable or co-dependent input dimensions and prioritizes those that consistently yield informative gradients across masked configurations. Applied to neural PDE solvers, our method improves both cross-domain generalization and robustness to partial corruption, without requiring architectural changes or auxiliary supervision. The results suggest that structured irrelevance serves as an effective inductive bias, guiding neural solvers to discover physically meaningful and resilient representations.

title: Active Transfer Learning Strategy for Spiking Neural Networks
authors: Yupeng Liu, Guowei Peng, Cheng Zeng, Qirong Yang, Xiurui Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: In recent years, Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) have attracted considerable attention due to their low power consumption and high robustness. However, SNN models are inherently difficult to train and require a large amount of labeled data to achieve satisfactory performance. To reduce the reliance on large labeled datasets, active learning and transfer learning methods have been introduced in the field of Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). However, their application to SNNs remains in the early stages of exploration. In this paper, we propose ATSNN, an active transfer learning method for SNNs, which effectively addresses both domain adaptation and the scarcity of labeled samples during model training. First, we design a joint domain adaptation loss function to enhance transfer learning within the SNN architecture. Second, an active learning strategy is employed to provide higher-quality labeled data for the target domain, further improving transfer learning performance. Extensive experiments on multiple datasets demonstrate that ATSNN improves SNN performance in the target domain while requiring fewer labeled samples.

title: Early Wildfire Detection with Metal Oxide Gas Sensors: A Smart Approach for Real-Time Monitoring
authors: Cristina Brugera, Félix Meléndez, Ángel López Luna, Patricia Arroyo, Victor González, José Ignacio Suárez, José Luis Herrero, José Manuel Perea, Jesús Lozano
abstract: Detection of forest fires is a crucial challenge for environmental protection and infrastructure safety. In recent years, the increasing impact of fires, aggravated by climate change, has highlighted the need for more efficient early detection systems. Traditional methods, such as thermal sensors and smoke detectors, have limitations in large or inaccessible areas. In this context, electronic systems have emerged as an innovative alternative for air quality monitoring and fire detection, using gas sensors to identify characteristic combustion compounds. This work presents the development of a compact system specifically designed for fire detection in controlled conditions and in the open field. The proposed system integrates multiple gas sensors, allowing real-time data acquisition and storage. In addition, future lines of research are discussed, including the development of advanced data filtering and analysis algorithms to minimise external interference and improve detection accuracy.

title: An Adaptive Real-Time Data Comparison Method
authors: Jingdong Zhang, Haiguang Li, Yulin Zhang, Ping Wang, Fujun Zhang, Danfeng Fu, Nannan Miao, Baonian Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: In the domain of real-time data processing, challenges such as network hopping—where communication nodes switch frequently—frame loss caused by link congestion or interference, and data duplication from redundant transmissions often disrupt the stability of real-time data comparisons, leading to inconsistent or unreliable results. To address these issues, this study proposes a dual-constraint calculation method that limits both the time range and the number of comparison points. Specifically, it dynamically adjusts the time window to focus on relevant data segments and selects key comparison nodes to balance density and efficiency, ensuring neither excessive computational load nor critical data omission. The algorithm integrates real-time time alignment, employing timestamp synchronization and interpolation techniques to calibrate misaligned or delayed data onto a unified timeline, aligning disparate data streams accurately despite network delays. It further incorporates outlier-resistant calculations through robust statistical approaches, effectively identifying and mitigating anomalies caused by frame loss or interference, such as extreme value deviations. When applied to data comparison software, experimental results demonstrate that the new algorithm significantly reduces the adverse impacts of network instability and data outliers. This enhancement ensures reliable data analysis and supports informed decision-making in dynamic network environments.

title: Real Remote Laboratory for Cooperative and Online Learning of Digital Systems
authors: Hélio Sousa Mendonça, José Carlos Alves
abstract: As digital design methodologies and tools are evolving to higher abstraction levels, teaching the low-level concepts of digital electronic system design is becoming increasingly challenging. The raise of the design abstraction level and, more recently, the ability of AI -assisted automated design is pushing the interest of students away from the lower-level details of the digital world. Nevertheless, digital electronic systems are (still) made of transistors, gates and flip-flops, and people do need to keep this basic knowledge to be able to build efficient circuits, understand them and develop the essential electronic design automation tools. For learning these subjects, hands-on experimentation, and learning by doing, is proven to be an effective tool, and when students finally see and feel the results of their designs, motivation raises rapidly. This paper presents the technical aspects of a platform created in the DECEL project to support an FPGA-based remote laboratory based on a commercial single-board computer that can be located somewhere in the Internet. This computer runs a Linux operating system and is based on an AMD/XILINX device that integrates in the same chip an ARM Cortex A9 CPU and a region of FPGA programmable logic. The user develops a digital circuit using standard hardware-description languages (Verilog or VHDL) and runs the implementation tools for the target FPGA using a very simple web interface running in a remote server.

title: A Wideband Small-Footprint Platform-Insensitive Monopolar Patch Based on Slot-Assisted High-Order Mode Tailoring
authors: Jiawang Li, Fan Wu, Wen-Jun Lv, Kin-Fai Tong
abstract: A wideband, compact monopolar patch antenna with an inherent filtering response is presented in this paper. By employing a slot-assisted mode-tailoring technique, the field distributions of several higher-order modes at the patch center are engineered to produce a stable monopolar radiation pattern with enhanced bandwidth. The closed-form analysis indicates that increasing the current intensity at the central region can transform the conventional TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">22</sub> mode into one that exhibits a monopolar pattern. This concept is realized by incorporating four slanted slots at the corners of the patch, which constrain the surface current toward the patch center. Besides, these slots also excite an additional slot mode, which serves as a second resonance. At higher frequencies, the slots continue to confine the current distribution of the original TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">33</sub> mode to a small central region and thereby forming a quasi-TM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">01</sub> monopolar radiation. By combining the three engineered resonances, the proposed single-layer patch achieves a significantly improved bandwidth. (The simulated and measured impedance bandwidths (S11 < -10 dB) are 26.9% and 27.1% respectively). More importantly, the proposed antenna preserves a stable radiation pattern even when the ground-plane size changes. This robustness arises from the slot-assisted mode-tailoring scheme, which strongly confines the current distribution to the central region of the patch. The small-footprint prototype realizes peak gains of 6.92 dBi in simulation and 6.42 dBi in measurement. To ensure the application of the proposed antenna on a vehicle, a large-scale simulation has been performed to verify the wide impedance bandwidth, realized gain and consistent radiation patterns when the antenna is positioned on the roof of a car. While good in-band results are obtained. Radiation nulls are observed near the band edges, resulting from the mutual cancellation of radiated fields. With its broad bandwidth, stable monopolar radiation, and built-in filtering (stopband gain not exceeding 0 dBi), the proposed antenna offers an attractive solution for modern wireless platforms demanding compact form factors and robust interference immunity.

title: Virtual Imaging-Guided Harmonization of Chest X-rays Using a Generative Adversarial Neural Network
authors: Mojtaba Zarei, Ehsan Abadi, Liesbeth Vancoillie, Ehsan Samei
abstract: Objective: To reduce variability in chest radiography (CXR) from acquisition and post-processing, and assess whether harmonization improves image quality and down-stream diagnostic performance. Methods: A generative adversarial network (GAN) was trained exclusively on virtual images produced by a Virtual Imaging Trial (VIT). The model maps non-harmonized CXRs to noise-free, unprocessed references using a dual U-Net with contrastive loss. Evaluation spanned virtual, physical-phantom, and clinical data using generic (GIQMs) and chest-specific (CIQMs) metrics. A phantom benchmark compared the method with ComBat harmonization and a conventional denoising algorithm. Clinical generalization was tested on VinDr-CXRs, examining feature compactness via Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection (UMAP). We also assessed NIH-CXRs, quantifying diagnostic accuracy with bootstrap uncertainty. Results: Compared with non-harmonized images, harmonized CXRs yielded approximately 89% lower NRMSE, 50% higher PSNR, and 86% higher SSIM. On phantom data, CIQM variability fell from 0.255 to 0.026 and was reduced more consistently than with ComBat or denoising. Clinical analyses on VinDr-CXRs showed tighter UMAP clusters for harmonized features, indicating suppression of acquisition-related variability. On NIH-CXRs, training and testing a classifier in the harmonized domain improved diagnostic accuracy over the non-harmonized domain and lowered cross-domain sensitivity; pleural and cardiac categories showed consistent gains, while texture-dependent labels exhibited task-dependent effects. Conclusion: VIT-guided training enables a GAN to harmonize CXRs toward a raw reference, improving quantification variability and harmonizing image representations across systems. Significance: The proposed virtual-to-clinical strategy is scalable and generalizable, offering a practical path to standardized CXR appearance and reliable downstream detection across institutions.

title: Towards Testing the Accessibility of Dynamic Visual Changes in Android Mobile GUI with Multi-Modal LLMs

title: Revolutionizing Exams: Competency-Oriented E-Exams with Digital Laboratories
authors: Lukas Wojarski, Joana Eichhorn, Alexa Nebel, Julia Mergner, Tobias R. Ortelt, Luis Rodriguez-Gil
abstract: This demo shows the integration of digital laboratories into engineering education, specifically through the “DigiMatLabExam” project at TU Dortmund University. Recognizing the critical need to bridge theory and practice, the project aims to enhance student engagement and competence in a lecture on the fundamentals of materials technology by incorporating virtual experiments and real-world applications into both coursework and assessments. The digital laboratory simulates key materials testing methods and allows for a detailed microstructure analysis, fostering a deeper understanding of material properties for more than 350 enrolled students. Initial evaluations indicate that this innovative approach improves student motivation and confidence, while effectively linking theoretical concepts to practical skills. This approach not only prepares students for professional challenges but also aligns educational practices with industry demands, paving the way for future enhancements in STEM education through competency-oriented assessments.

title: Hybridizing Expressive Rendering: Stroke-Based Rendering With Classic and Neural Methods
authors: Kapil Dev
abstract: Nonphotorealistic rendering (NPR) has long been used to create artistic visualizations that prioritize style over realism, enabling the depiction of a wide range of aesthetic effects, from hand-drawn sketches to painterly renderings. While classical NPR methods, such as edge detection, toon shading, and geometric abstraction, have been well established in both research and practice, with a particular focus on stroke-based rendering, the recent rise of deep learning represents a paradigm shift. We analyze the similarities and differences between classical and neural network-based NPR techniques, focusing on stroke-based rendering, highlighting their strengths and limitations. We discuss tradeoffs in quality and artistic control between these paradigms and propose a framework where these approaches can be combined for new possibilities in expressive rendering.

title: The Role of Virtual and Remote Learning Factories in Ambidextrous Manufacturing Innovation Management: A Vision for the Future
authors: Caroline Colsman, Chiara Nezzi, Jan-Philipp Rammo, Erwin Rauch
abstract: In the face of increasing volatility and technological disruption, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must balance incremental improvements and radical innovations, a challenge known as ambidextrous Manufacturing Innovation Management (MIM). Learning and Innovation Factories (LIFs) play a crucial role in supporting this innovation process. However, traditional LIFs often require significant physical infrastructure and resources, which many SMEs lack. The MIM4SME project aims to develop, implement, and validate a virtual and remote LIF -integrated MIM framework that enables SMEs to efficiently balance incremental improvements and radical innovations. This paper outlines the state of the art, theoretical foundations, and procedural steps necessary for developing this framework.

title: ECG-Based Seizure Prediction Using Progressive Feature Fusion Mamba
authors: Kai Shu, Le Wu, Chongjin Yu, Aiping Liu, Ruobing Qian, Xun Chen
abstract: Seizure prediction is of paramount clinical importance for optimizing interventions and improving patient quality of life. Recent advancements in ECG-based seizure prediction have garnered attention due to their potential for portability and ease of data collection. However, existing methods primarily focus either on heart rate variability (HRV) to capture ECG trends or on convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for local feature extraction, but often fail to effectively combine both global and local information, limiting the prediction performance. To address this challenge, we propose the Progressive Feature Fusion Mamba (PFFMamba) network for ECG-based seizure prediction. PFFMamba enhances prediction accuracy in two key ways. First, it utilizes Mamba’s selective scanning mechanism to focus on important historical data while discarding irrelevant information, enabling the model to effectively capture subtle local variations and the long-term dependencies among them. Second, we introduce a progressive feature fusion structure to overcome Mamba’s limitation in combining parallel features and align with the hierarchical nature of features at different stages. This structure integrates frequency channels in the shallow layers, feature channels in the intermediate layers, and HRV representations in the deep layers, ensuring robust feature interaction throughout the network. By combining these strategies, PFFMamba extracts features that embody both long-term dependencies and multi-perspective representations. We evaluate our approach through seizure prediction experiments and demonstrate that PFFMamba achieves a sensitivity of 96.7%, a false prediction rate of 0.548/h, an AUC of 0.775 on the USTC Epileptic ECG database and a sensitivity of 95.9%, a false prediction rate of 0.641/h, an AUC of 0.724 on the Siena database, surpassing current state-of-the-art methods.

title: A Deep Learning-Driven Approach to Predict Traffic Accident Severity
authors: Rahul Kumar, Sanskriti Verma, Saumya Nigam, Oshin Rathor, Saloni Verma
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Traffic accidents are a major public safety issue, causing widespread harm and economic losses due to factors like human error, adverse weather, and vehicle malfunctions. Unintentional collisions between cars or between cars and pedestrians are known as traffic accidents, and they frequently cause serious injuries, fatalities, and substantial property damage. Usually, bad weather, inadequate road infrastructure, distracted or intoxicated driving, and driver error are the causes of these events. Drivers must follow safety precautions to reduce these dangers, such as following traffic laws, keeping their cars in good condition, wearing seat belts and helmets, and avoiding distractions while operating a motor vehicle. Predicting traffic accidents accurately is essential for putting preventative safety measures into place, lessening the demand on emergency services, and eventually saving lives. In order to predict the severity of traffic accidents, we provide a deep learning-driven method in this study that blends Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) with conventional machine learning models, such as Random Forest (RF), Logistic Regression (LR), and XGBoost. High-level spatial features are extracted from raw traffic data using CNNs and then fed into machine learning classifiers to provide precise predictions. According to our experimental findings, the CNN + XGBoost model outperformed CNN + RF (93%) and CNN + LR (92%), achieving an accuracy of 95%. This integrated strategy demonstrates how deep learning and machine learning may be combined to improve prediction performance and offer insightful information for managing traffic safety.

title: Dialogue Injection Attack: Jailbreaking LLMs through Context Manipulation
authors: Wenlong Meng, Fan Zhang, Wendao Yao, Zhenyuan Guo, Yuwei Li, Chengkun Wei, Wenzhi Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated significant utility in a wide range of applications; however, their deployment is plagued by security vulnerabilities, notably jailbreak attacks. These attacks manipulate LLMs to generate harmful or unethical content by crafting adversarial prompts. While much of the current research on jailbreak attacks has focused on single-turn interactions, it has largely overlooked the impact of historical dialogues on model behavior. Although recent studies have explored multi-turn jailbreak attacks, they generally assume that the attacker can only manipulate the user prompt. In contrast, we highlight that an attacker can also control the model’s previous outputs. To this end, we introduce DIA, a new paradigm that leverages fabricated dialogue history to enhance jailbreak effectiveness. DIA operates in a black-box setting, requiring only access to the chat API or knowledge of the LLM’s chat template. We propose two methods for constructing adversarial historical dialogues: one adapts gray-box prefilling attacks, and the other exploits deferred responses. Our experiments demonstrate that DIA achieves state-of-the-art attack success rates on recent LLMs, including Llama-3.1 and GPT-4o. Additionally, we show that DIA can bypass 6 different defense mechanisms, highlighting its robustness.

title: Post-Processing Geometry Enhancement for G-PCC Compressed LiDAR via Cylindrical Densification_supp1-3653212.pdf
authors: Wei Gao
abstract: The geometry-based point cloud compression algorithm achieves efficient compression and transmission for LiDAR point clouds with high sparsity. However, the low-bitrate mode results in severe geometry compression artifacts, which involve both point reduction and coordinate offset. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to directly enhance the geometry quality for compressed LiDAR point cloud (CLGE) in a post-processing manner. Our proposed method consists of two branches: cylindrical densification and adaptive refinement. The former adopts a multi-scale sparse convolution framework to effectively extract spatial features in the cylindrical coordinate system and generate dense candidate points quickly. Large asymmetric sparse convolution kernels are also designed to capture the shapes of different regions and objects. The latter branch refines the candidate points through several MLP layers, which takes the neighborhood features between the candidate points and the input points into account. Finally, the designed ring-based farthest point resampling serves as an effective alternative for achieving the target number while maintaining the geometry distribution. Extensive experiments conducted on several datasets verify the effectiveness of our approach under different compression artifact levels. Furthermore, our method is easily extended to upsampling and is robust to noise. In addition to the geometry signal quality improvement, the point cloud enhanced by our proposed method alleviates the performance degradation in object detection task due to compression distortion.

title: Development and Validation of a Task-Technology Fit Questionnaire to Evaluate Telemedicine Applications from Physicians’ Perspective
authors: Ni Luh Saddhwi Saraswati Adnyani, Rajesri Govindaraju, Khoirul Muslim, Titah Yudhistira
abstract: Telemedicine has the potential to enhance both the accessibility and quality of healthcare services. Patients can access telemedicine through various modes, one of which is via applications. Evaluating the task–technology fit (TTF) of telemedicine applications is essential to ensure that they effectively meet user needs and, in particular, support physicians’ tasks in delivering remote healthcare services. However, no instrument has been specifically developed to assess the TTF of telemedicine applications from the physician’s perspective. This study, therefore, aimed to develop and validate a questionnaire-based instrument for evaluating the TTF of telemedicine applications from the physician’s perspective. A mixed-methods approach was employed, consisting of two phases. In the first phase, the instrument was developed through a literature review, interviews, and expert feedback. In the second phase, the instrument was validated through assessments of content validity, face validity, construct validity (convergent and discriminant), reliability (internal consistency), and predictive validity. Content and face validity were assessed by six experts and ten physicians, respectively. Construct validity, reliability, and predictive validity were evaluated using data from 185 physicians and analyzed with Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modelling (PLS-SEM). The final TTF instrument, named Telemedicine Application Task–Technology Fit Questionnaire (TATTFQ), comprises 36 items across nine dimensions. The findings indicate that the developed TTF instrument has adequate relevance, reliability, and validity, making it suitable for evaluating the TTF of telemedicine applications from the physicians’ perspective. This instrument has strong potential for widespread use in evaluation and development programs aimed at optimizing telemedicine applications.

title: An Approach for Modeling, Simulation, and Parameter Estimation of Half-Cell Bifacial PV Modules
authors: Gustavo H. P. Santos, Samuel Silva, Givaldo Reis, André R. Mocelin, Roberto Zilles, Henry P. Viveros, Elmer P. T. Cari
abstract: Bifacial modules have gained prominence due to their ability to capture additional energy from rear-side irradiance. However, models and parameter estimation methods for bifacial modules remain limited largely due to varying interpretations of rear irradiance effects. An approach to address that issue is the standardization of models in line with the IEC TS 60904-1-2 standard. This study proposes a bifacial module model based on that standard featuring two current sources, each representing front and rear irradiances, and introduces bifaciality coefficient as a new parameter to be estimated. A conventional half-cell bifacial photovoltaic module with 655 W was tested in a solar simulator, and the resulting data were used for simulations and parameter estimation of the proposed model by a mean–variance mapping optimization algorithm. According to the results, the model can effectively estimate the parameters and represent the bifacial photovoltaic module comprehensively due to its low error rates and a strong fit to <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I$</tex-math></inline-formula>–<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V$</tex-math></inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$P$</tex-math></inline-formula>–<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V$</tex-math></inline-formula> curves. Furthermore, a sensitivity analysis revealed the incorporation of the new parameter does not affect the identifiability of the model.

title: A Survey on AI-Generated Text Detection: Methods, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Ahmed Ismail, Cherry A. Ezzat, Abeer M. El-Korany
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Recent advancements in large language models (LLMs) have unlocked unprecedented capabilities in generating human-like text and introducing new challenges and opportunities, especially when distinguishing between AIgenerated text (AIGT) and human-authored content. Existing solutions, including watermarking, statistical analysis, stylistic detection, and machine learning-based approaches are promising for detecting AIGT. Still, When it comes to combating text obfuscation techniques such as adversarial attacks and other strategies intended to mislead text origin, these methods often encounter significant obstacles. This survey focuses on the effectiveness of current detection methods in the presence of attacks such as paraphrasing. We investigate the limitations of existing detectors, their robustness against adversarial strategies and the changing field of detection methods. We also explore the role of datasets in developing robust detectors and the challenges they face in simulating real-world scenarios. From recent research work, we aim to provide insights to improve detection methods on post-attack text, identify gaps in the current state-of-the-art, and offer actionable recommendations for future work. Our study highlights the need to advance detection solutions to ensure trust and responsibility in AI-generated text systems.

title: Adaptive BM3D Denoising via Joint Wavelet Packet and SVD Noise Estimation
authors: Wenli Zhang, Kefan Chen, Kaicheng Wang, Yirui Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Aiming to address the issue of poor performance due to unknown and variable noise intensity in denoising, an improved block-matching three-dimensional cooperative filtering (BM3D) denoising algorithm for images was proposed. First, wavelet packet decomposition and singular value decomposition (SVD) are combined to estimate the noise variance independently of the high-frequency subband coefficients and tail singular values of the image, respectively. Second, the average of these two values is calculated as the final estimate of the noise level. Lastly, this precise estimation is input as a core priori information into the BM3D framework. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the proposed algorithm has significantly outperforms traditional methods in terms of denoising performance, detail preservation ability, noise suppression effect, and objective evaluation indexes.

title: Research on Performance Improvement of Reconnaissance Signal Time-frequency Analysis Based on Improved Combined Deep Network
authors: Nie Jing, Jiang Longwei, Wang Dayong, Song Chengcheng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Addressing the two issues in time-frequency analysis methods, namely the contradiction between timefrequency resolution, and the significant deterioration of method performance as the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) decreases, this paper proposes a signal recognition method based on an improved combined deep network. The time-frequency analysis graph of the signal is treated as an image for processing. Firstly, a convolutional neural network (CNN) is utilized to determine the SNR of the mixed signal. Then, an Auto-Encoder (AE) is improved by adding an encoding layer to enhance its ability to extract signal features. Subsequently, network parameters corresponding to different SNR conditions are obtained through training. Finally, based on different SNRs, the corresponding network parameters are loaded to achieve the recognition and de-noising of noisy signals. Through simulation experiments and algorithm comparisons, it can be concluded that the method proposed in this paper has significant advantages in signal recognition and parameter acquisition.

title: Meta-Learning-Enhanced GNN Approach for Signal Compression in Uplink Cell-Free MIMO Networks
authors: Junyu Xie, Jing Guo, Siqiang Wang, Hanxiao Yu, Zhong Zheng, Zesong Fei
abstract: In this work, we investigate the uplink signal compression problem for fronthaul-constrained cell-free (CF) multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) networks. Considering the dynamic nature of wireless communications, e.g., the varying number of accessing users and the changing rate requirements, we propose a scalable and adaptive approach by integrating graph neural network (GNN) with meta-learning. In particular, the problem of maximizing the achievable uplink sum rate is formulated by optimizing the beamforming matrix of each access point (AP), while accounting for the requirement of user rate. To tackle this non-convex optimization problem, we develop a joint-Reptile-enhanced GNN approach. Therein, the uplink CF-MIMO network is modeled as a heterogeneous graph with cooperative node features, and the joint-Reptile approach is employed to obtain adaptive and generalizable meta-parameters, enabling rapid adaptation to dynamic CF-MIMO networks. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach exhibits better adaptability compared to conventional initialization benchmarks. Moreover, it can achieve higher sum rate performance across various signal dimensions, while maintaining scalability.

title: Experimental Validation of Large-Scale Distributed MIMO With Real-Time Adaptive Modulation
authors: Muralimohan P, Spandan Bisoyi, Pavan Reddy M, Harish Kumar D, Kiran Kuchi
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and experimental validation of a distributed multiple-input multiple-output (dMIMO) testbed. The testbed comprises 24 spatially distributed transmission point (TP) units, each with 2 antenna ports, centrally coordinated by a baseband unit (BBU). Orthogonal pilot signals are transmitted from all TP units, enabling each user equipment (UE) to perform downlink channel estimation and provide explicit channel state information (CSI) feedback to the BBU. The centralized unit then aggregates these channel vectors into a full CSI matrix and computes a zero-forcing precoder which is applied to both demodulation reference signals and user data. An adaptive modulation algorithm is employed that selects the modulation order for each UE in every subframe based on a pre-defined performance metric, allowing the system to adapt to varying channel conditions. Using this architecture, our testbed spatially multiplexes 17 single-antenna UEs in real time and achieves an average per-user spectral efficiency of 2.94 bits/s/Hz/UE, significantly outperforming existing implementations. All the findings are supported by extensive real-world experimental evaluations conducted using the testbed.

title: A Comparative Study of Machine Learning Algorithms for Credit Card Fraud Detection
authors: Mohammad Aburass, Rehab Aburass, Marwa Hamza
abstract: This paper explores the relationship between machine learning (ML) algorithms-based fraud detection techniques and the accuracy of identifying fraudulent credit card transactions. Credit cards serve as a main role-player in the digital era to meet different financial needs, creating a crucial demand for efficient fraud detection techniques to protect both consumers and financial institutions. These companies require consistent fraud detection systems to ensure consumers can safely use their credit cards to purchase goods, rent properties, or make loan payments. The study aims to separate fraudulent transactions from genuine ones by employing machine learning techniques including Random Forest, Decision Trees, Adaptive Boosting, and Gradient Boosting to evaluate credit card transaction data. To improve fraud detection accuracy, the prediction models assess accuracy, precision, recall, and F1 score. Using European credit card data, this paper evaluates several machine-learning techniques to identify the most successful approach in accurately detecting fraudulent transactions.

title: KL Divergence Regularization for Stabilizing Output Distributions in Online SNN Learning
authors: Lei Liu, Kainan Wang, Aili Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) show significant promise for neuromorphic hardware due to their utilization of spatiotemporal information and pulse transmission between layers. Despite their potential, training SNNs with Backpropagation Through Time (BPTT) incurs substantial memory overhead owing to temporal dependencies. Recent studies have explored online learning algorithms for SNN training, which update network weights using temporally local information and thus circumvent the high memory demands of BPTT. However, during inference, the discrepancy in output spike distributions across different time steps compromises the reliability of the final average spike rate when calculating instantaneous loss. To address this, we introduce a divergence term (Kullback-Leibler Divergence) into the instantaneous loss function, minimizing inter-time-step output distribution variations. Experiments on both static and neuromorphic datasets demonstrate that the proposed loss function achieves competitive performance.

title: Infrared-guided Adaptive Low-light Image Enhancement for Multi-modal Anti-UAV Detection
authors: Li Ng Yan, Jian Yang, Zhong Wang, Chuanxiang Li, Xueyan Dong
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Low-light conditions severely degrade visible (RGB) image in anti-UAV applications, limiting robust detection at night. We propose an infrared-guided adaptive gamma correction framework that enhances RGB images by leveraging an IR visibility prior to regulate target luminance, and preserve structure. Building on local adaptive gamma correction, our method integrates variance gating, spatial smoothing, and a highlight-protection mechanism that progressively attenuates enhancement in bright regions. To improve generalization, we further use the correction as probabilistic data augmentation so detectors learn invariance to enhancement. Evaluated on the multi-modal dataset from the “Multi-modal Low Slow Small Target Detection Competition,” the approach improves performance on two architectures, yielding higher recall and notable gains. Our submission ranked first on the official leaderboard, indicating strong real-world applicability. The results show that IR-guided, artifact-aware enhancement coupled with augmentation is an effective recipe for reliable anti-UAV detection under challenging conditions.

title: CSMF-YOLO for Remote Sensing Target Detection
authors: Muyuan Fan, Ziheng Xia, Jinhua Wei, Yingxia Wang, Bingxiu Yang, Wenjun Huo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The YOLO series exhibits unique advantages in remote sensing image target recognition tasks due to its end-to-end efficient inference mode and real-time detection capabilities. However, it still struggles to fully address the inherent challenges of remote sensing target detection. For instance, the traditional Spatial Pyramid Pooling (SPP) module lacks explicit feature enhancement, resulting in the loss of small target information. Additionally, attention mechanisms inadequately model the long-range dependencies between targets and complex backgrounds in remote sensing scenes.To tackle these issues, this paper proposes a You Only Look Once network based on Channel and Spatial Multi-scale Fusion (CSMF-YOLO), which integrates the SPPF_Fusion and Spatial - Channel Collaborative Attention(SCCA) modules. Experimental results on the DOTA remote sensing dataset demonstrate that this method improves the mean average precision (mAP) by $4.8 \%-7.8 \%$ compared to the original YOLOv8, with particularly significant performance improvements in small target detection and complex background scenarios. The innovations of this paper lie in constructing a hierarchical processing framework of “feature enhancement -multi-scale fusion - attention optimization.” It is the first to combine multi-scale pooling with explicit feature enhancement to handle the scale variations of remote sensing targets. By using adaptive branch attention, it resolves the problem of weight allocation in small target feature fusion. Moreover, it enhances the global contextual understanding ability through the collaborative modeling of spatial and channel attention, providing a superior technical solution for small target detection in remote sensing images.

title: A Phase-Based and Student-Centric Requirements Classification Framework for Software Engineering Education in the Metaverse
authors: Yousra Odeh, Rana Yousef
abstract: The metaverse is shifting traditional education of software engineering into a new era making it more interactive and practical for students and empowered with technologies. This research introduces a Phase-Based and Student-Centric Requirements Classification Framework tailored for Software Engineering Education in the Metaverse. The framework categorizes requirements into distinct phases—Pre-Navigation, Active Learning, and Post-Navigation. Also, the framework aims to personalize the software engineering student education experience in the metaverse. The framework is validated by software engineering academic professionals. It contributes to bridging the gap between the current traditional learning and the metaverse to increase the potentiality of benefiting software engineering students in their education and learning process. This study is a foundation and scalable to align in the future with the emerging education paradigm in the metaverse.

title: Modified Open-Loop Phase Estimation of SOGI-FLL for Frequency Coupling Suppression and Synchronization Stability Enhancement of VSC Systems
authors: Ruoxue Yu, Xianfu Lin, Yiyi Zhang, Jingrong Yu, He Wen
abstract: The second-order-generalized-integrator-based frequency-locked loop (SOGI-FLL) has widely used in synchronizing voltage source converter (VSC) systems. However, it causes frequency coupling (FC) and stability issues. This article proposes a modified open-loop phase estimation scheme to address these challenges. The root cause of the FLL-induced adverse effects is first examined, revealing that, despite the symmetrical structure of the SOGI-FLL, it introduces asymmetrical dq-frame coupling terms into the VSC control. This results in significant sequence impedance coupling and negative resistance behaviors. To this end, a nonlinear synchronization phase compensation factor is designed to balance the uncovered asymmetrical coupling terms, thereby minimizing the FC. Additionally, to address the negative resistance issue, an impedance phase compensation function with two degrees of freedom is further proposed to regulate the impedance phase and effectively narrow the frequency range of negative resistance. Last, experiments are conducted to confirm the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Open-Set Drone Recognition from RF Signals Using DenseNet-OpenMax
authors: Yichen Tang, Yanhua Jin, Huidong Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The development of the low-altitude economy has led to the widespread application of drones, which poses challenges for drone supervision and regulation. This paper proposes a combined DenseNet-OpenMax method to achieve the identification of authorized and unauthorized drones. This architecture uses DenseNet as a feature extractor and incorporates center loss for supervised training to build a model capable of distinguishing known classes and identifying unknown ones. Subsequently, this model is introduced into the OpenMax algorithm for training and evaluation. In this paper, signals from 14 classes of drones are used as the dataset for experiments. The results show that the average accuracy in the closed-set recognition phase reached over 98%, while the average accuracy in open-set recognition reached over 96%. This demonstrates that the proposed architecture offers a practical and effective solution for unauthorized drone identification.

title: A Comparative Assessment of Evolutionary Algorithms for Design of Optimal FIR Filters
authors: Gauri Shanker Gupta, Deep Shekhar Acharya, Pankaj Mishra, Vishal H. Shah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Evolutionary Algorithms (EA) have found large scale applications in all fields of science and engineering. As per the literature, recently, EAs have been extensively used to design optimal digital FIR filters, for various applications. The design task is to evaluate the best filter coefficients so as to satisfy the desired criteria and constraints, if any. To design a digital FIR filter using EA, the design task is formulated as a cost function (error function), which is optimized (minimized) to solve for the coefficients of the digital FIR filter. This paper presents a comparison among the design of digital FIR filters, such as low-pass, high-pass, band-pass and band-stop, using different EAs. The EAs considered in this work are Genetic Algorithm (GA), Particle Swarm optimization (PSO), Simulated Annealing (SA), Artificial Bee Colony (ABC), Ant Colony Optimzation (ACO), Teaching-Learning Based Optimization (TLBO), Cuckoo Search Optimization (CSO), Jaya Algorithm (JA), Bat Algorithm (BA), Fire Fly Algorithm (FF) and Cat Swarm Optimization Algorithm (CSA). The afore-mentioned algorithms have been implemented to the filter desing problem and their performance has been compared on the basis of the effectiveness with which they are able to search the optimal coefficients of the digital FIR filter so as to satisfy the desired specifications. After identifying the best algortihm among the different algorithms, considered in this work, the optimal filter has been applied to edge detection.

title: A Study on Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System Classification Based on YOLOv8
authors: Jia Zhang, Dalin Huang, Qiuxian Peng, Maoyuan Dai, Xin Gao, Fei Du
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Accurate Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) classification of breast ultrasound images is vital for the early diagnosis and effective treatment of breast diseases. This paper explores the feasibility of using the YOLOv8 algorithm to implement lesion feature recognition and automated BI-RADS classification for breast ultrasound images. We provide a systematic overview of the YOLOv8 model architecture, data processing workflow, and training methodology. The model was trained and validated on a dataset of 4,279 breast ultrasound images. We employed multiple metrics to comprehensively evaluate the model’s performance. The experimental results demonstrate that YOLOv8 can effectively identify breast imaging features and complete BI-RADS classification, offering an efficient and reliable technical solution for the intelligent recognition and classification of breast lesions.

title: A Novel Deep Learning Approach for Enhanced Ischemic Brain Stroke Detection from CT Images Using Deep Feature Extraction and Optimized Feature Selection
authors: Ahmad Abumihsan, Majdi Owda, Amani Yousef Owda, Fathi Gasir, Mobarak Abumohsen, Lampros Stergioulas
abstract: Ischemic brain stroke is the most prevalent type of stroke caused by the occlusion of blood vessels via thrombi or blockages and is the second most common cause of mortality globally, after ischemic heart disease. To improve patient outcomes, ischemic stroke must be diagnosed timely and precise. This paper introduces a novel approach toward ischemic stroke detection from computed tomography (CT) images by integrating deep learning and optimization techniques for feature extraction and selection. The VGG16 model is utilized to extract high-dimensional spatially rich features that efficaciously capture the intricate texture and spatial patterns within the CT scans. To optimize these features, a genetic algorithm (GA) is leveraged to select the most discriminative subset and reduce redundancy. The new method was developed and evaluated on a unique, first-hand dataset gathered from a specialized private hospital in Palestine. The findings show that the suggested combined technique VGG16-GA highly enhances the performance of all classifiers. Notably, the VGG16-GA-XGB model attained superior outcomes, with an accuracy of 98.89%, precision of 98.85%, recall of 98.93%, and an F1-score of 98.92%.

title: Sentiment Analysis for Early Detection of Booking Cancellations Using Machine Learning
authors: Abhishek Kumar, Upendra Prasad, Rajesh kumar Tiwari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Hotel booking cancellations disrupt occupancy rates and revenue planning in the hospitality industry. Traditional models often rely solely on structured booking data, ignoring valuable insights from unstructured customer reviews. This study introduces a hybrid machine learning framework that integrates booking data with sentiment analysis derived from hotel reviews using a fine-tuned BERT model. Sentiment scores were combined with structured features to train Logistic Regression, Random Forest, and XGBoost classifiers. Random Forest achieved the highest performance (F1-score: 0.8440). SHAP explainability highlighted key features like lead_time, adr, and Sentiment_Score. The framework enhances prediction accuracy and supports real-time deployment in hotel CRM systems for proactive cancellation mitigation.

title: Light-Load Efficiency Improvement of Single-Stage Microinverter with Online Iterative Trajectory Optimization Strategy
authors: Ruinan Xue, Panbao Wang, Wenbo Hao, Wei Wang, Dianguo Xu
abstract: Due to the inherent intermittency of solar energy, photovoltaic (PV) microinverters (MIs) often operate under prolonged light-load conditions. To improve energy utilization, this paper proposes a novel online iterative trajectory optimization (OITO) strategy for the single-stage series resonant dual-active-bridge (DAB) MI to enhance the light-load efficiency. Through the zero-voltage switching (ZVS) condition analysis, the all-switch ZVS constraint is constructed. On this basis, a ZVS-constrained real-time iteration algorithm is developed to optimize inductor RMS current, with particular emphasis on minimizing the RMS current under light loads. By analyzing the constraint priorities and iteratively solving boundary equations with switching-frequency limits, the optimal trajectory of degrees of freedom (DOFs) is derived. Compared with conventional DAB MIs, the proposed strategy achieves a wider ZVS range while producing reduced inductor RMS current, which improves the light-load efficiency of the MIs. Accordingly, a GaN-based MI prototype is built, and the proposed strategy is validated, achieving a peak efficiency of 97.21%.

title: Low-cost Optimal Vertex Path Planning Algorithm Based on Obstacle Attraction
authors: Zhi Liao, Ronggang Yang, Gao Ma, Chengji Lu, Caiping Wang, Yiwu Wu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Sampling-based Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT) / RRT* algorithms are widely used to solve motion planning problems and have been improved and developed over the decades. However, most of the algorithmic improvements result in only near-optimal paths for their generation. To overcome this problem, this paper proposes improved algorithms, Optimized Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (O-RRT*), which can truly optimize the paths to the optimum in finite time. First, ORRT * applies the attraction effect to obstacles to form partial optimal vertices. Then, the path is optimized by creating a new parent node through the combination of dichotomy and attractive potential field. Next, the goal-bias strategy expansion is used to reach the goal area quickly when no obstacle between vertexes and the goal. All tree node expansion processes are affected by the attractive potential field. In the comparison experimental results with the state-of-the-art algorithms Quick-Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (Q-RRT*) and Flexible Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (F-RRT*), it can be concluded that O-RRT* not only outperforms the other algorithms in terms of initial solution and convergence, but also truly succeeds in converging to the optimal path in finite time.

title: ScaleMix: Enhancing fNIRS Classification with Scaling and Mixup Augmentation for Data-Driven BCI Applications
