title: Hybrid Crime Data-driven Route Optimization System for Safer Urban Navigation
authors: Sukruthi Sanampudi, Chandra Prabha, Sampann Raheja, Sudeepa Roy, Raghavendra G Ambekar
abstract: As cities expand and daily commutes become more unpredictable, concerns over personal safety during travel are rising. Traditional navigation systems often focus on saving time, neglecting the safety aspect of travel. This study addresses this gap by proposing a solution that incorporates crime data into pathfinding algorithms to recommend safer routes for commuters. To achieve this, we turn to data-driven techniques that allow us to understand and map urban risk more effectively. We leverage K-Means clustering to group crime points and identify crime hotspots. Additionally, our approach introduces a new metric: the Danger Index, which quantifies the risk of each cluster based on crime count and severity. These values are integrated into the cost function of the pathfinding algorithm. Through a comparative analysis of A*, Graph Neural Networks (GNN), and Dijkstra’s algorithm, we found A* to be the best fit as it effectively balances safety, distance, computational efficiency, and memory usage. Specifically, A* reduced danger exposure by around 25-30% compared to its alternatives, making it a practical choice for real-time, safety-focused navigation.

title: State Baseline Modeling and Fault Detection for Aero-Engines With Unknown Performance Degradation Based on Deep Neural Networks
authors: Zhen-Lei Ma, Xiao-Jian Li
abstract: This paper is concerned with the data-driven state baseline modeling and fault detection problem for aero-engines. Long-term operations can result in performance degradation of aero-engines, which naturally causes the state baseline being varied at different stages of performance degradation and further increases false alarm and missed detection rate of fault detection. To tackle this problem, a deep neural network is first designed to learn the state evolution behavior and generate state baseline. Moreover, a multi-step reciprocal prediction method is developed to characterize the state prediction error and enhance the accuracy of state baseline modeling. Then a fault detector is designed by means of the state baseline to perform fault detection. Furthermore, a variable period state baseline update mechanism combining fuzzy logic system and periodic update is proposed to match the performance degradation so as to ensure the accuracy of fault detector and reduce false alarm. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed state baseline modeling and fault detection method is verified through an aero-engine example. Numerical results show that the proposed method reduces the prediction error by an average of 42.8% compared with other advanced methods, while achieving a fault detection accuracy of 98.0% without performance degradation and 96.0% with 2% performance degradation.

title: Trustworthy Dataset Proof: Certifying the Authentic Use of Dataset in Training Models for Enhanced Trust
authors: Zekun Sun, Liwei Liu, Zhe Li, Tianyu Wang, Zhihao Sui, Na Ruan, Conghui He, Dahua Lin, Jianhua Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: In the realm of deep learning, the veracity and integrity of the training data are pivotal for constructing reliable and transparent models. This study introduces the concept of Trustworthy Dataset Proof (TDP), which tackles the significant challenge of verifying the authenticity of training data as declared by trainers. Existing dataset provenance methods, which primarily aim at ownership verification rather than trust enhancement, often face challenges with usability and integrity. For instance, excessive operational demands and the inability to effectively verify dataset authenticity hinder their practical application. To address these shortcomings, we propose a novel technique termed Data Probe, which diverges from traditional watermarking by utilizing subtle variations in model output distributions to confirm the presence of a specific and small subset of training data. This model-agnostic approach improves usability by minimizing the intervention during the training process and ensures dataset integrity via a mechanism that only permits probe detection when the entire claimed dataset is utilized in training. Our study conducts extensive evaluations to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed data-probe-based TDP framework, marking a significant step toward achieving transparency and trustworthiness in the use of training data in deep learning.

title: Estimation of Mutual Inductance Caused by Misalignment of JT-60SA TF Coil
authors: Suzuka Yoshida, Miyu Kazuno, Kazuya Nakamura, Tomoaki Takao, Shogo Sonoda, Haruyuki Murakami, Kazuya Hamada
abstract: The JT-60 Super Advanced (JT-60SA) was built as part of a project aimed at the early realization of fusion energy. The JT-60SA is used to support and complement work for ITER and to develop young fusion scientists and engineers. The superconducting coil system of the JT-60SA includes the toroidal field (TF) coils, equilibrium field (EF) coils, and central solenoid (CS) modules. Each TF coil is monitored by the quench detection voltage (QDV) system, which compares voltages at adjacent TF coils using a bridge circuit. The EF coils do not produce a voltage in the TF coils because, ideally, the TF coils are orthogonal to the EF coils. However, when the EF coils are energized, the QDV in the TF coils sometimes exceeds the threshold, falsely detecting quenches, which leads to the discharge of a TF current. It is believed that a magnetic flux from the EF coils passing through the TF coils may occur due to coil misalignment during installation and inadequate clearance design. As a result, an induced voltage could be generated in the TF coils. To understand how other coils influence the TF QDV system and to ensure the stable operation of the JT-60SA, it is crucial to investigate the cause of the induced voltage in the TF coils. In this study, a coil misalignment model was developed using finite element analysis software. This model was used to calculate the mutual inductance between the TF and EF coils. Furthermore, a circuit simulation model of the TF QDV system was created to quantitatively analyze the induced voltage caused by the misalignment of superconducting coils.

title: Gender Disparities and Work Stress: A Case Study of Women of Pakistan's Software Industry
authors: Sadia Khalid, Uzair Rasheed, Wasi Haider Butt
abstract: Pakistan, despite being the first country to adopt the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), continues to lag in areas related to mental health, work environment, and gender equality. While the country is a prominent global provider of software services, the industry remains largely excluded from initiatives addressing these three goals. This study explores how women in Pakistan's software industry are treated in comparison to their male counterparts, and how this affects their mental health. It specifically examines three key stress factors (stressors) and six types of stress responses (strains). The study captures the frequency of experiences related to each stressor and strain from 337 Pakistani software professionals. Survey results and analysis reveal that women in the software sector experience significantly higher levels of stress than men, with burnout being the most prominent outcome. As working women play a vital role in both the global and Pakistani economies, it is crucial to understand and address their unique challenges in order to enhance their mental well-being and overall productivity.

title: Consistency-Regularized GAN for Few-Shot SAR Target Recognition
authors: Yikui Zhai, Shikuang Liu, Wenlve Zhou, Hongsheng Zhang, Zhiheng Zhou, Xiaolin Tian, C. L. Philip Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Few-shot recognition in synthetic aperture radar (SAR) imagery remains a critical bottleneck for real-world applications due to extreme data scarcity. A promising strategy involves synthesizing a large dataset with a generative adversarial network (GAN), pre-training a model via self-supervised learning (SSL), and then fine-tuning on the few labeled samples. However, this approach faces a fundamental paradox: conventional GANs themselves require abundant data for stable training, contradicting the premise of few-shot learning. To resolve this, we propose the consistency-regularized generative adversarial network (Cr-GAN), a novel framework designed to synthesize diverse, high-fidelity samples even when trained under these severe data limitations. Cr-GAN introduces a dual-branch discriminator that decouples adversarial training from representation learning. This architecture enables a channel-wise feature interpolation strategy to create novel latent features, complemented by a dual-domain cycle consistency mechanism that ensures semantic integrity. Our Cr-GAN framework is adaptable to various GAN architectures, and its synthesized data effectively boosts multiple SSL algorithms. Extensive experiments on the MSTAR and SRSDD datasets validate our approach, with Cr-GAN achieving a highly competitive accuracy of 71.21% and 51.64%, respectively, in the 8-shot setting, significantly outperforming leading baselines, while requiring only ~5% of the parameters of state-of-the-art diffusion models. Code is available at: https://github.com/yikuizhai/Cr-GAN.

title: Image-Based Iterative Active Error Compensation for Polygon Mirror-Based Scanning Systems
authors: Bo Cong, Han Woong Yoo, Georg Schitter
abstract: This article deals with the correction of cross-scan errors in polygon mirror (PM)-based laser scanning systems by active error compensation (AEC) using a fast-steering mirror (FSM). However, AEC is susceptible to sensor noncollocation errors since the FSM is typically controlled via an internal angular sensor. This sensor error can be evaluated by position measurements of the scanning laser, but these measurements are not always feasible due to the inherent duty cycle of PM-based scanning systems. Image-based iterative AEC (II-AEC) is proposed to use partial measurements to address the sensor noncollocation error, thereby improving the precision of PM-based scanning systems. II-AEC consists of a cascade structure where the inner loop employs iterative learning control for the FSM using the internal sensor, and the outer loop iterates the inner loop reference based on the laser positions measured by a complementary metal–oxide–semiconductor (CMOS) sensor. II-AEC has been implemented and evaluated on a PM-based stereolithography apparatus, resulting in a 40-fold printing precision improvement compared to the uncompensated apparatus.

title: LLM-Enhanced Multi-Objective Fair Influence Maximization
authors: Huanqi Wang, Li Wang, Feng Chang, Jian Zhu, Wenjing Hong, Zexuan Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Influence maximization has been extensively studied in the context of social networks. In recent years, increasing attention has been paid to ensuring fairness in the diffusion process, aiming to prevent underrepresentation or systematic disadvantage of certain groups. However, existing approaches typically rely on hand-crafted heuristics or meta-heuristics, which often require substantial expert knowledge and computational resources. Meanwhile, Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive capabilities in reasoning, optimization, and knowledge generalization across various domains. Despite their success, there is still a lack of research leveraging LLMs to guide influence maximization, particularly under fairness constraints. In this paper, we propose a novel framework that integrates an LLM-informed surrogate model into a multi-objective evolutionary algorithm for Fair Influence Maximization (FIM). This approach jointly optimizes influence and group fairness while reducing computational burden with an LLM-assisted evolution process and a Kriging-based surrogate. Experimental studies on real-world datasets show the competitiveness of the proposed method in achieving a balanced trade-off between influence propagation and fairness.

title: Few-shot Tiny object detection framework via super-resolution network embedding
authors: Siyao Huang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: For the Case of few shot Condition, a tiny object detection framework based on super-resolution reconstruction network and attention mechanism is proposed in this paper, which can effectively improve the detection performance of tiny objects. Firstly, attention mechanism is introduced into the feature extraction network, so that more tiny object feature information can be obtained during feature extraction, background information can be suppressed, and detection efficiency of ROI with possible tiny objects can be improved.The obtained ROIs are reconstructed by using super resolution network based on GAN to enlarge the image and enhance the details of tiny objects, which is beneficial to the detection of tiny objects. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed framework outperforms the SOTA ones.

title: Ground Moving Target Detection of Distributed MIMO Radar based on Hybrid Coherent Accumulation
authors: Youngjun Cheng, Qi Zhao, Jiale Wang, Fei Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a hybrid coherent integrationbased joint detection method for moving target detection in distributed multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) wide band phased array systems under complex terrain backgrounds. The method achieves long-time coherent integration within channels through generalized Radon-Fourier transform (GRFT), effectively addressing the energy dispersion problem caused by range cell migration of high-speed targets. Meanwhile, it employs time-delay compensated non-coherent integration techniques to eliminate phase mismatch between multiple channels, significantly enhancing the detection capability for weak targets. Simulations demonstrate that the hybrid coherent energy integration and joint optimization techniques can effectively improve the ground moving target detection performance of distributed MIMO wide band radar systems.

title: A Cloud-Based Platform for Wildfire Risk Monitoring Using Wireless Sensor Networks
authors: João Cardoso, Leonardo Sousa, Pedro Salgueiro, Filipe Araújo, José Saias, Luís Rato, Vitor Nogueira, Teresa Gonçalves, Catarina Silva
abstract: Forest fires pose a growing threat to ecosystems and human settlements, reinforcing the need for effective monitoring and early detection systems. The SenForFire project introduces a cloud-integrated platform designed to collect, process, store, and visualize real-time environmental data from a network of low-cost wireless sensors deployed in fire-prone areas. Currently, the system focuses on continuous data acquisition and real-time visualization, establishing a foundation for future predictive ca-pabilities in wildfire prevention. This paper presents the system's requirements, architecture, data flow, and visualization tools, aiming to contribute to research and development in wildfire risk assessment.

title: A Novel Framework for Swarm Behavior Recognition Integrating Multi-Modal Data and a VGG16 Network
authors: Yuxuan Huang, Yihang Tao, Guoshun Tang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper introduces an efficient approach for identifying the behavior of swarm targets. The core of the method comprises a real-time recognition system, which applies time-frequency analysis to radar echo signals and utilizes an end-to-end neural network architecture capable of processing multi-dimensional parameters for behavior classification. By employing this time-frequency processing, parameters such as range, Doppler frequency, and angle of the swarm targets are estimated, facilitating the creation of a comprehensive multidimensional dataset. The neural network design, adapted from the VGG16 framework, incorporates multiple input branches to handle distinct feature types. Simulation outcomes demonstrate that multi-parameter learning-which integrates range, Doppler, and angle information-effectively addresses the limitations associated with the low information content of single-dimensional feature recognition techniques. The proposed system achieves higher accuracy in swarm behavior recognition compared to methods relying on individual dimensions.

title: Detection of Alzheimer's Disease Using EfficientNet Family
authors: Thatikonda Radhika, Sridhar Chintala
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: AD is among the leading causes of dementia that is predisposed to progressive brain atrophy with implications on memory and cognition. Early and proper diagnosis is paramount in effective management and treatment. In this, we propose a deep learning model using the Efficient Net family of convolution neural networks (Efficient Net B0, B1, B2, and B3) for the four-class classification of AD MRI images as very mild, mild, non-moderate, and moderate. Our model utilizes advanced image pre-processing and data augmentation to enhance the model's robustness. We validated the models on the OASIS MRI dataset and achieved a maximum classification accuracy of 99.93% using Efficient Net B1, outperforming other variants and state-of-the-art benchmarks. Performance metrics are extremely effectiveness of the model in identifying AD stages. The approach facilitates early diagnosis and improved clinical decision-making for Alzheimer's disease. Index Terms: Alzheimer's disease, Deep learning, Early diagnosis, Detection of MRI images

title: Epileptic Seizure Prediction and Detection Based on Limited-Channel EEG Signals
authors: Yuxiao Zhang, Peng Zhang, Zhigang Yin
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Epilepsy is a chronic neurological disease characterized by abnormal neuronal discharges in the brain. Traditional EEG-based seizure prediction methods rely on high-density electrode configurations, which limit their applicability due to complexity and poor wearability. This study aims to develop an epileptic seizure prediction and detection system based on limited EEG channels that enhances usability while maintaining effective performance. The proposed method implements a three-class classification for seizure prediction, seizure detection and normal state identification. It incorporates three key components: (1) an adaptive overlapping EEG data segmentation module using sliding windows to mitigate class imbalance, (2) a dual-branch neural network model that separately extracts and fuses time domain and frequency-domain features, (3) a patient-specific adaptation mechanism to optimize system performance. The entire system operates using only four EEG channels located at the forehead and behind the ears to maintain wearability. Finally, it achieves an average sensitivity of 86.2% for seizure prediction and 98.3% for seizure detection, with a false prediction rate of $0.1 / \mathrm{h}$ at the event level on the CHB-MIT dataset. In conclusion, the proposed system can effectively offer a practical solution for home-based epilepsy monitoring and mobile healthcare.

title: Edge-Deployable Transformer-Augmented Hybrid Wavelet Network for Early Detection of Subclinical Cardiac Arrhythmias in Wearable Devices
authors: Odeh Adeyi Victor, Zhang Xiaoling, Izis Kanjarawy, Adekambi Kowiyou Akambi, Tembo Zalerape Dumisani, Almathani Mohammed Adnan, Ssemwogerere Rajab, Kuyikabasi Uko
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Subclinical cardiac arrhythmias, such as asymptomatic atrial fibrillation (AFib), are precursors to catastrophic cardiovascular events but remain undetectable by current wearable technologies due to their reliance on thresholdbased algorithms. This paper introduces NeuroWave, a novel edge-deployable framework that fuses multi-resolution wavelet analysis with a Transformer-CNN hybrid architecture to identify subtle arrhythmic patterns in real-time. NeuroWave leverages discrete wavelet transform (DWT) to decompose ECG signals into time-frequency sub-bands, isolating transient anomalies (e.g., microvolt-level P-wave variability), while a lightweight Transformer with sparse attention mechanisms captures longrange dependencies between arrhythmic events. Trained on the MIT-BIH Arrhythmia Database and externally validated using ambulatory ECG data from the CEBS Database, NeuroWave achieves 94% accuracy on subclinical cases, outperforming commercial wearables (Apple Watch, Fitbit) by 18% in sensitivity. By bridging wavelet-based signal processing with state-of-the-art deep learning, this work pioneers a new paradigm for intercepting silent cardiovascular diseases, aligning with global precision cardiology initiatives.

title: How to Exploit Target Location Distribution for MIMO Radar: PCRB or PWML?
authors: Lingyun Xu, Bowen Wang, Ziyang Cheng, Bin Liao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper studies waveform design for multiple input multiple output radar by exploiting prior target location distribution. Specifically, the angle of target is random and unknown, while its prior information can be leveraged for radar waveform design. To utilize this, we first derive a posterior Cramér-Rao bound (PCRB) as a theoretical lower bound for direction-ofarrival estimation error, and then formulate a PCRB-oriented waveform optimization problem under transmit power and peak-to-average-power ratio constraints. To simplify exploitation, we further propose a novel beampattern metric, probability weighted mainlobe level (PWML), and formulate a PWML-oriented waveform design problem that maximizes the lowest PWML. Efficient algorithms are proposed for these formulated waveform design problems. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed waveform optimization algorithms. It also yields practical guidelines for selecting appropriate waveform design strategies based on the characteristics of prior information: the PCRBoriented design is more effective under low prior uncertainty, while the PWML-oriented design performs better with high prior uncertainty.

title: Enhancing Mass Mailing with Post-Quantum Cryptography: Implementation of Crystal Kyber and Crystal Dilithium
authors: P. N. Kokare, Deepali Vora, Ganesh Deshmukh, Abhishek Shelar, Pratik Choudhari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Mass Mailing operates as a secure automated solution for template creation followed by delivery systems which functions for quantum-age security challenges. Mass Mailing combines the key encapsulation functions of CRYSTAL-Kyber and the digital signature capabilities of CRYSTALDilithium to establish end-to-end encryption together with digital signatures for protecting digital communication integrity and authenticity. The secure templates in Mass Mailing maintain quantum-resistant security through NISTstandardized lattice-based cryptographic schemes that protect against interception and unauthorized access and forgery attempts. Mass Mailing eliminates traditional mass mailing system vulnerabilities because it implements tamperproof security measures and quantum-resistant features. The research examines the system deployment of Mass Mailing alongside its security benefits and scaling features as a vital solution for modern digital communication after quantum development.

title: TransSE: A Transfer Learning-Based Predictive Model for Distinguishing Super Enhancers and Typical Enhancers_supp2-3657361.tif
authors: Junxiang Gao
abstract: Super-enhancers (SEs), comprising clusters of transcriptional regulatory elements, play essential roles in gene expression regulation and cell fate determination. Current computational methods for identifying SEs from genomic sequences face challenges in prediction accuracy and cross-species generalizability. This study introduces TransSE, a deep learning framework combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks with cross-species transfer learning for SE prediction. TransSE employs a two-phase strategy: pre-training on combined human and mouse data to learn conserved regulatory features, followed by species-specific fine-tuning to capture organism-specific patterns. Evaluation on human and mouse datasets demonstrates that TransSE achieves superior accuracy compared to existing methods including SENet, DeepSE, and transformer-based models (DNABERT, Enformer), with AUC values of 0.828 (human) and 0.832 (mouse). Ablation studies confirm that convolutional blocks are essential for feature extraction, while transfer learning and recurrent layers provide meaningful performance improvements. Feature analysis reveals that TransSE distinguishes SEs from typical enhancers based on learned sequence representations, achieving 10.4-fold improvement in clustering metrics. The model demonstrates effective cross-species prediction capability, maintaining AUC <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.79 when trained on one species and evaluated on another. Conservation pattern analysis shows that TransSE integrates both evolutionarily conserved and species-specific regulatory features, enabling robust performance across organisms with limited training data. A user-friendly web interface (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">http://transse.shenlabahmu.com</uri>) provides automated SE prediction, motif analysis, and variant impact assessment. Case studies using experimentally validated SEs demonstrate the tool's utility for investigating regulatory elements and prioritizing functional variants in disease-associated genomic regions. TransSE advances the investigation of gene regulatory mechanisms and facilitates identification of disease-associated variation in enhancer regions.

title: Fed-ensemble: Enhancing Federated Learning with Ensemble Models for an Explainable Thyroid Cancer Recurrence Prediction
authors: Hasibul Hasan Sabuj, Dan Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: The prediction of thyroid cancer recurrence is a critical task in clinical decision-making, yet traditional machine learning models face significant challenges, particularly around data privacy, model generalization with huge datasets, and interpretability. In healthcare, patient data is sensitive and sharing it across institutions for model training raises privacy concerns. This research addresses these issues by utilizing federated learning (FL), a decentralized machine learning approach that allows institutions to collaboratively train a model while ensuring patient data remains private. FL enables local model training at each institution, with only model updates shared across participants, safeguarding sensitive data. Alongside federated learning, the study incorporates Explainable AI (XAI) techniques to enhance the transparency of predictions, enabling clinicians to interpret and trust the model’s decision-making process. By combining multiple machine learning models in an ensemble approach, the research improves the prediction accuracy and robustness of thyroid cancer recurrence, even with limited data. The method is evaluated using a cohort dataset of thyroid cancer patients, with synthetic data augmentation addressing data scarcity. The results demonstrate that the approach outperforms traditional models while addressing critical challenges of data privacy and model interpretability. This proposed model outperforms previous methods, significantly higher than the best result on same dataset from prior work. Additionally, our model shows superior performance even when trained on larger datasets, confirming its generalizability and robustness.

title: CAA: Toward Camouflaged and Transferable Adversarial Examples_supp1-3657036.pdf
authors: Qin Liu
abstract: Transferable adversarial examples (AEs) are visually indistinguishable from benign images, but can successfully mislead unknown deep neural networks. However, existing AEs normally vary considerably from benign images in the feature space, making them hard to pass label checking and adversarial detection. Therefore, how to make AEs camouflaged, disguising as benign images during detection is still an open problem. In this paper, we propose a novel camouflaged adversarial attack (CAA), which produces camouflaged adversarial examples (CAEs) for the first time. Our main idea is to make CAEs’ adversarial properties keep “dormant” state until the target model inadvertently triggers the “activated” state. To this end, we craft attack and camouflage perturbations, so that CAEs are visually and feature/label-wise indistinguishable from benign images at first, but will implicitly turn into AEs once being triggered. Specifically, we exploit two common preprocessing operations, image scaling and JPEG compression, as the trigger, and propose a two-stage optimization strategy. As the preprocessing details of target models are unknown, the first stage trains a well-designed generative adversarial network under varying scaling/compression parameters to enhance the robustness of attack perturbations. The second stage uses feature (dis)similarities and contrastive distances to improve the transferability of camouflage perturbations. Extensive experiments on ImageNet dataset validate the effectiveness of CAA. Especially for robust models, the average fooling rate after preprocessing could reach 96.3% outperforming the state-of-the-art adversarial attack by 13.5%.

title: Towards Smart Agriculture: Efficient Plant Disease Diagnosis with InceptionV3 and Grad-CAM
authors: Liana Mikhailova, Syed Ghazi Abbas, Raja Hashim Ali, Talha Ali Khan, Shan Faiz
abstract: Plants are very necessary and important for humans and their lives. Therefore, it is very necessary to identify and understand the plant's disease in order to cure it. Due to the growing problems in agriculture, timely and accurate detection of diseases has gained popularity in recent times. Most existing models for plant disease classification generally focus solely on maximizing accuracy. However, they neglect or do not consider efficiency on low-resource devices. Additionally, they often fail to reliably handle rare disease classes or field-acquired images. Therefore, this study aims to develop an efficient, accurate, and interpretable deep learning model capable of overcoming these limitations in practical deployment scenarios. In this work, InceptionV3, a lightweight convolutional neural network, was fine-tuned using transfer learning on the comprehensive “New Plant Diseases Dataset” comprising over 87,000 labeled images of healthy and diseased plants. The reliability of the model was improved by expanding the data for a specific class. It was therefore evaluated based on real-world scenarios, such as images with noise, motion blur, and challenging lighting conditions. The results of the experiments show that Inception V3 is accurate and comparable to deeper networks such as Inception-ResNet-V2. Despite this, it also significantly reduces computational complexity and inference time. Our visualization using Grad-CAM gives us consistent results and, moreover, highlights areas that show disease damage. This improves interpretability. Our model creates an affordable and effective plant disease detection system that is highly suitable for use in agricultural settings and does not require a lot of resources.

title: Data-Driven Cyberattack Detection Based on Deep Learning for Power Cyber–Physical Systems
authors: Song Liu, Yun Wang
publish: IEEE Canadian Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering
abstract: The cyberthreats faced by power cyber–physical systems (CPSs) have become increasingly serious. However, existing cyberattack detectors still cannot resist them effectively due to the data imbalance, the high false alarm rate (FAR), and highly covert cyberattacks. To address the issues, this article proposes a novel data-driven cyberattack detector based on deep learning for power CPSs. The proposed detector is equipped with two Wasserstein generative adversarial networks (WGANs), which overcome the data imbalance issue in existing detectors by synthesizing adequate abnormal samples involving cyberattacks. Moreover, a novel substation-level detector with a modified light gradient boosting machine (LightGBM) and a maximal information coefficient (MIC) unit is introduced into the proposed detector. It captures differences between abnormal sampled values caused by cyberattacks and natural faults, thus reducing the FAR. Furthermore, a novel overall-level detector based on an improved graph convolutional neural network (IGCNN) is built for the proposed detector. It performs spatial–temporal topology mining on complete power CPS graphs to fully extract more comprehensive attack-related features than existing detectors, thus realizing exhaustive detection sensitive enough to highly covert cyberattacks. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed detector are verified by experimental research on actual power data from China.

title: Optimized Triple-Junction Insulation Facilitating Low-Delay and Controllable Electrohydraulic Discharge Toward Underwater Acoustics
authors: Menglei Wang, Nianhan Xu, Jiaqi Yan, Yuliang Ma, Jinhao Wu, Chaoran Zhang, Jie Bai, Yanan Wang, Ruoyu Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: Underwater pulsed discharges are pivotal for research fields like acoustic wave generation and material processing, where improving energy efficiency and achieving precise parametric control are critical objectives. However, the performance of electrohydraulic discharge load faces challenges including large breakdown delay and jitter, complex multi-physical coupling, etc. Here, an underwater surface load utilizes carbon-foil triple-junction (TJ) points to trigger kV-level discharges and pressure waves. The optimized load offers key advantages: largely-reduced electric breakdown delay and phenomenal reproducibility in repetitive operation. This study systematically investigates the effects of current density, load length, and stored energy on discharge characteristics, acoustic performance, and bubble pulsation. Results show that increasing foil length from 5 mm to 20 mm (at 2 J) elevates the voltage peak from 0.93 kV to 1.37 kV and improves energy deposition efficiency from 1.47 J to 1.85 J. Furthermore, the acoustic performance is highly controllable: peak pressure rises with stored energy, reaching up to 43.1 kPa (corresponding to a sound pressure level of approximately 212.7 dB re 1 μPa @ 20 cm), while the discharge pressure waveform before material failure is closer to a strong shock wave. Additionally, four distinct bubble regimes are identified in varied tests: merged double bubbles, non-merging double bubbles, triple bubbles, and multi-bubbles. These findings may deepen the understanding of underwater discharge physics and demonstrate its advantages in related applications.

title: Towards Robust SEA Detection: Leveraging Model Diversity and Randomization Against Adversarial Attacks
authors: Insaf Kraidia, Samir Brahim Belhaouari
abstract: Deep Learning-based Social Engineering Attack (SEA) detectors have shown promising results in identifying malicious content. However, these models remain vulnerable to adversarial attacks, where carefully crafted inputs can significantly impact their performance. This paper presents a novel defense mechanism that leverages model diversity and randomization to counter black-box adversarial attacks. Unlike traditional approaches that rely on a single model with fixed parameters, our method automatically utilizes multiple base model variants during inference, each trained on different data distributions with distinct settings. We use a random selection method from these variants for the final predictions, adding an element of unpredictability that increases the difficulty for attackers in creating successful adversarial examples. Our experimental results across various transformer-based architectures demonstrate that our approach maintains robust performance while effectively defending against 12 different types of black-box attacks targeting words, sentences, and characters. The proposed method achieves an average performance improvement of 2-3% over existing defense mechanisms on clean data and a significant 17% improvement in resistance to adversarial settings. It outperforms existing approaches by 13-44% in accuracy under adversarial attacks, all without substantially increasing computational complexity or compromising clean data performance. This work enhances the reliability and trustworthiness of SEA detection systems while addressing practical challenges in deploying robust defense mechanisms.

title: Enhancing IoT Network Security: Machine Learning-Based Intrusion Detection Using Vortex Search Optimization and SMOTE for Improved Classification
authors: Chandrakanth Reddy Borra, Ramya Vani Rayala, Zabiha Khan, Srinivas Cheekati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Internet security, and more particularly the prevention of harmful traffic on the increasingly popular Internet of Things (IoT) devices, has recently attracted a lot of attention. Such threats are hard to spot, which is why a sophisticated intrusion detection system (IDS) is required. As a smart IDS, machine learning (ML) shows promise in many domains, including the IoT. Features extraction models, however, should be used to extract data from the IoT environment so that ML models can use it. These models are crucial for the detection rate and accuracy. A number of network intrusion detection methods based on machine learning have been developed to successfully thwart these attacks on IoT networks. These methods typically employ feature extraction or feature selection techniques to reduce the dimensionality of input data before feeding it into machine learning models. This study employs a normalization pre-process on the IEEE Dataport input data and a synthetic minority oversampling technique (SMOTE) approach to select imbalanced data instances. Next, the Vortex Search Optimization Algorithm (VSA) is used to increase the classification accuracy by optimally selecting various features that have been extracted. The last step is for the input samples to be classified using a Fine-tuned based Support Vector Machine (FT-SVM). In order to determine how well the model works, it is compared to a standard data set. The experimental findings demonstrated the superior characteristics of the given model on the utilized dataset.

title: Leveraging Feature Selection and Explainable AI for Effective Autism Screening
authors: Qusai Y. Shambour, Mohd Khaled Shambour, Yousef Alraba’nah, Mosleh M. Abualhaj
abstract: The early detection of autism spectrum disorder (ASD) in toddlers is essential for facilitating timely interventions, yet conventional diagnostic approaches often result in significant delays. To address this challenge, this study proposes an intelligent machine learning (ML) framework designed to improve the efficiency of ASD screening for toddlers aged 12 to 36 months. The framework integrates several key techniques: Gaussian Noise Up-Sampling (GNUS) to mitigate class imbalance, MaxAbsScaler for feature scaling, and Extra Trees (ET) for feature selection, ensuring that classification models receive optimized input data. Six distinct ML algorithms— Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGB), Random Forest (RF), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Naïve Bayes (NB), Quadratic Discriminant Analysis (QDA), and Support Vector Machine (SVM)—were evaluated on a cross-cultural ASD toddlers dataset. The results reveal exceptional classification performance, with XGB and SVM achieving perfect 100% scores in accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-measure when utilizing features selected by the ET algorithm. To enhance interpretability and transparency, eXplainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) was incorporated through Shapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), providing insights into the decision-making processes of the top-performing models. By combining robust predictive modeling with explainability, this study contributes to advancing early detection tools for ASD, ultimately fostering better developmental outcomes for affected children.

title: Towards Using Ontology-Based Systems for Explainable Medical Diagnosis in Nutrition Domain
authors: Duha Al-Darras, Bashar Al-Shboul, Nadim Obeid
abstract: Ontologies offer a powerful means of structuring medical knowledge for AI-driven diagnosis. This paper investigates the conceptual design of a framework that integrates ontologies and logical reasoning to automate the diagnosis of nutrition-related medical conditions. There is a significant gap in the literature on direct diagnosis using ontologies and logical reasoning for such conditions. By proposing a theoretical framework, this work aims to enhance diagnostic accuracy, efficiency, and reliability while providing explainable diagnoses. It is important to note that this study is part of an ongoing Ph.D. thesis and that the implementation of the proposed framework is planned in future work. This approach has the potential to improve patient outcomes and reduce healthcare costs significantly.

title: Mitigating Structural Fragmentation in Sonar Deconvolution: A Directional Total Variation Approach With FISTA Acceleration
authors: Pengcheng Pan, Xuesong Liu, Fei Wang, Fan Zhou, Rongxin Jiang, Yaowu Chen
abstract: Underwater 3-D imaging systems face critical challenges in achieving high-resolution reconstructions owing to physical aperture limitations and computational complexity. Conventional beamforming methods suffer from wide mainlobes and elevated sidelobes, whereas existing deconvolution approaches, though effective in super-resolution recovery of discrete point targets, tend to oversegment contiguous scattering bodies into sparse point clusters under operational conditions, leading to structural fragmentation and compromised target detectability. This study proposes a deconvolution framework for underwater targets through a hybrid regularization combining total variation and L1-norm constraints. The comprehensive validation demonstrates superior performance in continuous structural reconstruction, with experimental results showing an improvement in the structural similarity index compared to other deconvolution methods. Field tests conducted in marine environments further validate the framework’s ability to suppress sidelobe artefacts while maintaining contour integrity, thus establishing its potential for high-precision underwater detection and mapping applications.

title: Sensitive Band Selection Method for Hyperspectral Images of Pine Wilt Disease Infected Trees Based on Adaptive Subspace Partitioning
authors: Huixiang Liu, Ruirui Zhang, Meixiang Chen, Weijia Wang, Hao Shi, Chunjiang Zhao
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Pine wilt disease (PWD), referred known as “pine cancer,” is incurable and highly contagious, with a high mortality rate, posing a serious threat to global pine resources. Early detection, localization, and clearance of infected trees remain the only effective control strategies. However, the subtle physiological alterations occurring in early-stage infected trees are scarcely discernible in visible-light imagery, rendering detection through conventional computer vision techniques extremely challenging. This study demonstrates the feasibility of hyperspectral remote sensing for the early detection of PWD-infected trees. Targeting the weak pathological spectral responses characteristic of early infection, we develop a novel adaptive subspace partitioning (ASP) mechanism that adaptively identifies pathology-sensitive spectral bands while reducing hyperspectral data redundancy. This approach enables the refined extraction of subtle but diagnostically significant spectral cues, providing a new methodological framework for early detection of PWD-infected trees. Furthermore, to enhance spectral feature learning, a spectral reconstruction network integrating a multi-attention mechanism with a CNN–ViT architecture is introduced, enabling joint mining of spatial–spectral contextual information and precise modeling of infected-tree spectral properties. By combining the spectral reconstruction network with the ASP mechanism, the PwdBSNet model for hyperspectral band selection of PWD-infected trees is constructed. Experimental results demonstrate that, PwdBSNet consistently outperforms mainstream band selection methods including GPCBS and FNGBS. Compared with baseline models, PwdBSNet achieves improvements of 8.35% in OA, 9.91% in AA, and 0.11 in Kappa, offering a novel and effective approach for hyperspectral band selection in PWD detection.

title: Cooperative Multi-AUV System for Underwater Data Collection and Path Optimization
authors: Xuerui Zhang, Zengli Liu, Xuanzhi Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The growing demands for marine resource exploitation and environmental monitoring have exposed critical challenges in Underwater Wireless Sensor Networks (UWSNs), including imbalanced energy consumption, limited data timeliness, and insufficient adaptability to large-scale deployments. Existing AUV-assisted solutions remain constrained by periodic return requirements for storage offloading, failing to meet real-time demands, while conventional path-planning algorithms are prone to local optima. To address these issues, this paper proposes a multi-Autonomous Underwater Vehicle (AUV) cooperative data collection system specifically designed for the shoal-and-reef environment of the South China Sea. A hybrid hierarchical communication architecture integrating acoustic, optical fiber, and blue-green laser links is developed, enabling peripheral AUVs to collect sectorial data and relay it in real-time to a central AUV. This is complemented by a mobile AUV that facilitates near-realtime cross-medium transmission. Furthermore, to resolve the complexity of AUV path planning within this framework, we introduce an information entropy-enhanced Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) algorithm. This approach incorporates a dynamic parameter adaptation mechanism and multi-agent cooperative optimization strategy, significantly accelerating convergence speed and enhancing robustness. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the proposed algorithm outperforms existing methods in path optimization, energy efficiency, and delay control, achieving an average path length reduction of $15.7 \%$ and reducing total node energy consumption by $42.3 \%$. These improvements effectively extend network lifetime and enhance resource utilization balance, validating the system’s efficacy for long-term, large-scale underwater data acquisition missions.

title: Joint Active-Passive Beamforming and Panel Selection for Hybrid IRS Systems in Multi-User Scenario
authors: Mahima Chaudhary, Shravan Kumar Bandari
abstract: The hybrid intelligent reflecting surface (H-IRS) maintains a balance between power efficiency and performance gains. While deploying multiple H-IRS panels enhances connectivity in challenging fading environments, activating all panels simultaneously increases system complexity and power demands. To address this, we propose a selection combining scheme that dynamically selects the optimal H-IRS panel, ensuring reliable communication under varying channel conditions. The key challenge of selecting the best H-IRS is tackled by choosing the channel link with the maximum sum-rate achieved by the users. To achieve this, we jointly optimize the base station (BS) beamforming vector and H-IRS phase shifts under dual power constraints (BS transmit power and active H-IRS element power). We solve this problem semi-optimally using a combination of fractional programming (FP), majorization-minimization (MM), and alternating optimization (AO) techniques. The performance analysis is done using sum-rate and bit error rate (BER) parameters, and it is observed that BER performance improved when the number of H-IRS panels increased from 1 to 5. Also, an improvement in the sum-rate and spectral efficiency (SE) of 17% and $15 \mathrm{bps} / \mathrm{Hz}$ is observed.

title: A Two-Channel Spline Interpolation Approach for Active Impulsive Noise control
authors: Menghan Yang, Pengwei Wen, Xinxin Xu, Wen Jing Wang, Botao Jin, Linru Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Traditional active noise control (ANC) algorithms are primarily focused on linear systems, which limits their effectiveness in practical scenarios where the channels often have nonlinear characteristics. To address this limitation, this paper presents a novel two-channel robust spline-filtered-x least mean square algorithm. The proposed algorithm integrates a logarithmic framework with a spline interpolation strategy to design a cost function. This approach improves the algorithm’s robustness and ability to accurately identify non-linear system. Simulation results confirm the algorithm’s effectiveness in various noisy environments.

title: Kidney-Stone-Ultrasound Object Detection Using YOLOv8
authors: N Charan Sai, V Harshith Reddy, Lubin Balasubramanian, B Sowmiya, P Akilandeswari, Mehdi Samieiyeganeh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The prevalence of kidney-related diseases, including kidney stones, is growing because of lifestyle patterns and lack of hydration, and that is why early diagnosing is required to successfully treat any kidney disorder. In the case of kidney stones, ultrasound imaging is commonly deployed to diagnosis kidney stones, and manual interpretation can result in inaccuracies and time wastage. This study will involve designing a real-time deep learning algorithm to detect kidney stones to help the radiologists to make faster and accurate diagnosis. The recommended method identifies kidney stones in ultrasound images with the help of the advanced object identification algorithm YOLOv8. The program gives hope in detecting anomalies once trained on a specific set of annotated ultrasound images. The results of the system are bounding boxes, class predictions (stone vs. normal), and confidence scores that can assist medical professionals visually and quantitatively. Evaluation measures such as mAP, precision and recall are used to validate the performance of a model. This is the next step to the application of AI in automating healthcare diagnostic tools.

title: TherMOS: A Robust Low-Resolution 2D Spatial Thermal Model Order Reduction Approach
authors: Marcel Königseder, Pascal A. Schirmer, Peter Schreivogel, Kaichen Zhang, Yubo Song, Huai Wang, Marcelo Lobo Heldwein
abstract: With the rapid shift toward the electrification of society, the reliability and lifespan prediction of power electronic components have become increasingly crucial. Thermal simulations serve as a fundamental tool to analyze the thermal behavior of these systems; however, real-time applications require a significant reduction in computational complexity. This study presents an improved Proper Orthogonal Decomposition method using Galerkin projection, offering enhanced numerical robustness and adaptability to arbitrary, time-dependent boundary conditions. The method is validated on an integrated metal substrate circuit board, demonstrating high accuracy with temperature prediction errors below 1 K during both steady-state and transient operations when compared to FE solutions and a maximum error of 2.1 K when compared to steady-state measurements. This work, which is publicly available on GitHub, contributes both academically and technically toward efficient, reliable thermal management in power electronics.

title: Lightweight Image Dehazing Algorithm Based on Enhanced AOD-Net

title: Implementation of CBF Algorithm Deployment and Accelerated Computing Design Based on GPU
authors: Deyu He, Xin Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In response to the bottleneck of large-scale matrix real-time computation in traditional beamforming (CBF) on CPU platforms, this paper adopts GPU CUDA architecture acceleration: by optimizing one-dimensional/two-dimensional thread blocks and shared memory, integrating cuBLAS library to improve computing power; Combining multi stream asynchronous transmission to reduce transmission latency. This solution breaks through CPU limitations, significantly improves computing efficiency, and meets the real-time processing needs of big data.

title: Stochastic Kriging-assisted Controlled Random Search for Simulation Optimization and Its Application to Critical Dimension Measurement_supp1-3657700.pdf
authors: Chuljin Park
abstract: We consider an optimization problem with continuous variables, where the objective function must be evaluated via simulation. Our interests specifically focus on the situation where limited simulation observations (e.g., one or two) at each solution vector can be obtained, even though each observation includes random noise. To solve the problem, one may employ existing surrogate-assisted algorithms that typically update their surrogate models whenever a new observation is obtained. However, this updating process can face challenges such as out-of-memory issues, high computational costs, or imbalanced data due to excessive exploitation. In this study, we introduce a new algorithm called Stochastic Kriging-assisted Controlled Random Search (SKCRS). At each iteration, it employs a controlled random search to sample multiple vectors and uses a stochastic kriging model to select the most promising candidate solution vector from those sampled vectors. If the model fails to provide useful information to identify a suitable solution vector, the algorithm defaults to functioning as the original controlled random search without using the model. We tested our algorithm and compared it with existing algorithms using numerical functions and a case study in semiconductor manufacturing. The results demonstrate that our algorithm empirically outperforms existing algorithms regarding computational efficiency and estimation accuracy.

title: Multiwindow Hierarchical Range-Spread Target Detection in High-Resolution Maritime Radars
authors: Yu-Fan Xue, Shu-Wen Xu, Xiao-Jun Zhang, Si-Yuan Chang, Peng-Lang Shui
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, a multiwindow hierarchical rangespread target detection method is proposed to address target detection in complex oceanic scenes. The adaptive range-spread generalized likelihood ratio test linear threshold detectors (GLRTLTDs) with multiple range integration windows are employed cooperatively to address the detection of different radial sizes targets, which significantly reduces the mismatch loss of range windows. The detection results from wider windows are used as prior scene information to obtain pure clutter reference cells and reduce the interference from other targets. The hierarchical exploitation of the scene greatly improves detection performance of small targets around moderate or large targets. Moreover, the measured data with the test small target and simulated rangespread targets validates the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: CBCT Image Corpus for Tooth Implantation & Automatic Medical Report Generation
authors: Rajwinder Kaur, Punit Soni, Lokesh Pawar, Gurpreet Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The work in this paper focuses on the implementation of a system for automatic medical report generation and preparation of the corpus. This corpus contained CBCT images for tooth implantation. The main emphasis has been given to the information related to the heights of different regions. These heights reflect the distance from crest to sinus floor, crest to IAN canal, crest to nasal floor, crest to Mental foramen, crest to incisive canal etc. The corpus further contains the information about the existence of lingual concavity, mental foramen etc. The collective information about these quantitative parameters concluded the overall idea according to Lekholm & Zarb or Misch classification. The algorithm considered for comparison with the proposed ensemble model are Naive Bayes, SVM, Adaboost, Gaussian Process, Decision Tree, Random Forest and Kstar. The overall accuracy efficiency extracted out of the complete comparative analysis is 97.89% by using proposed optimized ensemble model.

title: DNN-Aided Over-The-Horizon Emitter Localization
authors: Jin Zhang, Wei Xia, Congcong Zhou, Yongzheng Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: We investigate the problem of over-the-horizon (OTH) localization of the emitted signal propagated through the ionosphere. We consider that the ionosphere is described by the quasi-parabolic (QP), which can effectively describe the signal propagation through the ionosphere. We develop a deep neural network(DNN)-aided OTH position determination algorithm that integrates the conventional Kalman filter (KF) and emerging neural networks. The OTH position determination network (OPDNet) of the proposed algorithm could dynamically tackle ionospheric parameter uncertainties in the absence of prior statistics. Simulation results demonstrates superior localization performance under both stationary and potentially time-variable ionospheric conditions.

title: The Role of Pleiotropy in Body-Brain Evolution of Simulated Robotic Agents
authors: Ninel Dogaru, Michel El Saliby, Eric Medvet
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Body-brain optimization of embodied agents is known to be a difficult task, as the two components may interact in non-trivial ways. This holds particularly in the case of modular robots, as bodies can be as complex as brains. When optimizing the agents through evolutionary computation (EC), this difficulty impacts on the design of the genetic representation which has to allow for mutually compatible body and brains. While the common approach is to “split” the representation in two distinct parts, one for the body, one for the brain, previous studies and biology suggest that pleiotropy may be beneficial. In brief, pleiotropic representations are those where one gene can affect more than one trait, possibly belonging to different components (body vs. brain). In this work, we experimentally study the effects of pleiotropy in genetic representations for body-brain evolvable robotic agents. We design a generic representation allowing for pleiotropy and instantiate it for two cases of different complexity: navigation of simulated differential-drive robots and locomotion of voxel-based soft robots (VSRs). Our results suggest that there is little interplay between evolutionary pressure, i.e., fitness, and pleiotropy. Pleiotropy tends to settle to some “natural” level mostly dictated by the representation.

title: Neuron Segment Connectivity Prediction with Multimodal Features for Connectomics
authors: Qihua Chen, Xuejin Chen, Chenxuan Wang, Zhiwei Xiong, Feng Wu
abstract: Reconstructing neurons from large electron microscopy (EM) datasets for connectomic analysis presents a significant challenge, particularly in segmenting neurons of complex morphologies. Previous deep learning-based neuron segmentation methods often rely on pixel-level image context and produce extensive oversegmented fragments. Detecting these split errors and merging the split neuron segments are non-trivial for various neurons in a large-scale EM data volume. In this work, we exploit multimodal features in the full workflow of automatic neuron proofreading. We propose a novel connection point detection network that utilizes both global 3D morphological features and high-resolution local image context to extract candidate segment pairs from massive adjacent segments. To effectively fuse the 3D morphological feature and the dense image features from very different scales, we design a proposal-based image feature sampling to improve the efficiency of multimodal cross-attentions. Integrating the connection point detection network with our connectivity prediction network which also utilizes multimodal features, we make a fully automatic neuron segment merging pipeline, closely imitating human proofreading. Comprehensive experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed modules and demonstrate the robustness of the entire pipeline in large-scale neuron reconstruction. The code and data are available at https://github.com/Levishery/ Neuron-Segment-Connection-Prediction.
