title: Formal Verification of the Health Code System for Quarantine Management
authors: Iram Tariq Bhatti, Shahid Ali Khan, Adnan Rashid, Aimal Tariq Rextin
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic, emerging in late 2019 in Wuhan, China, prompted the rapid deployment of digital containment tools worldwide. China's Quarantine Management System (QMS) integrated health QR codes, contact tracing and facial recognition to assess infection risk and enforce quarantine measures. Given the potential reuse of such systems in future health crises, ensuring their correctness, reliability and fairness is crucial, especially when they govern mobility and access to essential services. Conventional testing often fails to detect subtle errors in these complex, data-driven applications. This work applies formal verification, using probabilistic model checking, to model QMS functionality and analyze its behavior under diverse infection rates and user behaviors. We verify properties such as deadlock freedom, reachability, fairness, and reliability with the PRISM model checker. Results highlight the value of formal methods in building trustworthy digital health technologies and guiding improvements in both system design and public policy.

title: Horizontal Array Aperture Extension Method for Wavenumber Estimation
authors: Jiarui Yin, Ran Cao, Dewen Li, Longxiang Guo, Jingwei Yin
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the requirement for a large array aperture in estimating horizontal wavenumbers of normal mode using a horizontal line array, an aperture extension method that effectively improves wavenumber estimation accuracy is proposed. Using the Toeplitz structure of the range-averaged covariance matrix generated by the relative motion between the source and the array, this paper innovatively introduces a covariance matrix fitting-based aperture extension method into the wavenumber estimation problem. This method effectively doubles the number of array element and then increases the aperture. Numerical simulations conducted in a typical shallow water waveguide environment demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances the resolution capability and estimation accuracy of normal mode horizontal wavenumbers. The estimation performance improves with increasing distance of relative motion between array and source, demonstrates superior performance compared to the nonextended method across different signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs).

title: Enhancing Speech Emotion Recognition Through Multimodal Fusion of Acoustic and Textual Features
authors: Mishal Saeed, Sabeen Masood, Syed Saqib Raza Rizvi
abstract: Human speech emotion recognition has emerged as a crucial technology in domains such as AI-driven applications, healthcare, and human-computer interaction. Speech signal emotion detection improves user experience and makes systems more adaptive. Most speech emotion recognition systems rely solely on acoustic features, ignoring linguistic context. This work bridges this gap by integrating natural language processing techniques with speech signal analysis. This study presents a hybrid speech emotion recognition approach that synergistically blends acoustic features (MFCCs, pitch, and spectral features) with contextual NLP embeddings using an optimized deep learning architecture. It employs both machine learning and deep learning models to predict emotions like happiness, sadness, anger, and fear from vocal expressions. The system detects important speech features like pitch, tone, energy, and amplitude using ML-based classifiers. Furthermore, NLP methods like sentiment analysis and word embeddings are used to increase classification accuracy by incorporating contextual knowledge. According to preliminary results, deep learning models perform better than conventional machine learning techniques, providing increased accuracy and an emphasis on lowering background noise. The proposed hybrid model reduces bias in emotion classification (e.g., anger vs. sadness) by combining vocal and textual cues.

title: Subbottom Profiling based on the High-resolution Raypath Separation using Beam-Time-Delay Domain Deconvolution
authors: He Wang, Hongnan Chen, Ting Zhang, Xinyu Gu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In general, sea subbottom parameters can be rapidly estimated using the $\tau-p$ relation of sediment-bottom reflected (sBR) arrivals derived from the bearing time records (BTR). However, when the sediment layers are thin, it becomes challenging to distinguish sBR arrivals from arrivals travelling only through the water, particularly when using a bandwidth-limited source. The inaccurate estimation in such scenarios consequently degrades the subbottom profiling performance. To address this issue, we propose applying a two-dimensional deconvolution technique to enhance the sediment raypath separation in the beam-time-delay domain. This method improves the resolution of BTR by deconvolving the known response patterns of conventional beamforming and matched filtering. As a result, the accuracy of the $\tau-p$ relation is improved, giving rise to more reliable estimates of both the number of sediment layers and their corresponding thicknesses. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is validated using both the simulated and realsea experimental data, where the resulting subbottom profiling manifests itself as promising priors to further improve the matched-field geoacoustic inversion.

title: Facial Emotion Recognition for University Students using CNN: Transforming Learning Environment
authors: Adyasha Swain, Suprava Ranjan Laha, Sasmita Sahoo, Ankit Dalei, Vaibhav Srivastav, Debasish Swapnesh Kumar Nayak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The well-being and academic performance of university students are significantly influenced by their emotional experiences within learning environments. This research presents a novel application of Facial Emotion Recognition (FER) using web cameras and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to enhance classroom and laboratory settings. The system is designed to monitor students’ emotional states in real time, enabling educators to adapt learning environments for improved engagement and well-being. Initially, an image dataset was collected through web cameras placed in classrooms, capturing students' facial expressions during lectures and activities. The dataset was preprocessed to account for variations in lighting, facial orientations, and occlusions. A CNN-based model was developed and trained to classify emotions such as happiness, sadness, anger, and neutrality. Hyperparameter tuning and data augmentation techniques were employed to optimize model performance. The model was evaluated using metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score to ensure its effectiveness across diverse conditions. Additionally, the system was optimized to handle real-time emotion detection in varying classroom environments. This real-time FER system allows continuous monitoring of students' emotional states, providing actionable insights for educators to create more supportive and adaptive learning environments. The results demonstrate the potential of FER technologies to transform educational environments by fostering a deeper understanding of student emotions and promoting well-being. This research offers a foundation for the integration of AI-driven tools in modern education to enhance learning experiences.

title: Knowledge, Attitude, and Practice Toward AI Use Among Health Profession Students in a Malaysian Public University
authors: Anis Faeza binti Faisal, Hussam Mizher, Syahrir Zaini, Qasem Abdallah, Mohammad Abdallah
abstract: Introduction: Artificial intelligence (AI) has evolved rapidly into an effective tool in educational and healthcare settings. The purpose of this research is to assess the knowledge, awareness, and attitudes of healthcare students regarding AI and its use in medical education. Methods: A web-based survey was distributed through email and WhatsApp to 247 health students at the International Islamic University Malaysia (IIUM). Demographics, Knowledge, Attitude, and Practice (KAP) questionnaire answers, and perceived healthcare education barriers for AI adoption were collected. Associations between variables were analyzed. Results: Of the respondents, 66 (26.7%) were male, and 181 (73.3%) were female. The majority demonstrated a high level of knowledge (72.5%), a strong positive attitude (96.8%), and frequent AI-related practices (80.6%). Most students recognized that AI requires extensive labeled data for learning, and over half emphasized the importance of understanding AI's ethical implications. The most common AI-related activity was exam preparation. Despite their overall positive attitude, many students do not actively engage with AI tools, indicating potential barriers such as limited access or training. Conclusion: This study highlights a generally positive perception of AI among healthcare students at IIUM Kuantan Campus. However, the gap between positive attitudes and practical engagement suggests a need for improved AI training and accessibility in medical education.

title: Optimizing Multimodal Feature Alignment for Enhanced Text-to-Video Retrieval Performance
authors: Nasim Matar, Feras Alnaimat, Ahmad al-Qerem, Shadi Nashwan, Issam Jebreen
abstract: Multimodal AI integrates text, images, video, and audio to create models with a more comprehensive understanding of real-world interactions. A fundamental challenge in multimodal learning is ensuring proper feature alignment between modalities, which significantly impacts retrieval accuracy and generative quality. In this paper, we focus on optimizing multimodal feature alignment for improved text-to-video retrieval performance. We propose an efficient contrastive learning approach to align text, video, and audio embeddings, leveraging pretrained models (e.g., CLIP, Flamingo) with lightweight finetuning techniques (LoRA, frozen encoders). Experimental evaluations demonstrate a 32% improvement in Recall@5, highlighting the importance of structured feature alignment. Our findings provide a computationally feasible strategy for advancing multimodal retrieval models. Furthermore, we address bias mitigation as an essential component of robust multimodal AI, illustrating how dataset reweighting and targeted correction techniques can foster more balanced generative outputs.

title: The Synergy of Cognitive Cities and Open Data in Advancing Sustainable Urban Mobility: A Case Study of Pamplona, Spain
authors: Anas Al-Rahamneh, José Javier Astrain
abstract: This study examines the synergistic relationship between cognitive cities and open data frameworks in advancing sustainable urban mobility, using Pamplona, Spain as a case study. The research investigates how Information and Communication Technologies (ICT) and Open Data (OD) enhance transparency and reduce carbon emissions in urban transportation systems. By integrating publicly accessible datasets into sustainable transport infrastructure, the study demonstrates improvements in route optimization and strategic planning. The paper introduces the Pamplona CityApp, a digital tool that promotes environmentally conscious mobility through personalized route planning and carbon footprint monitoring. The findings highlight how technology-driven, citizen-centric approaches can create responsive urban ecosystems that balance technological innovation with broader societal goals of sustainability and improved quality of life.

title: Fractional Bernoulli Equation with Ujlayan-Dixit operator
authors: Amer Dababneh, Hamzah O. Al-Khawaldeh, Iqbal H. Jebril, Iqbal M. Batiha, Shaher Momani
abstract: This study explores the solution of the fractional Bernoulli equation using the Ughlaian and Dixit (UD) approach, which is also applicable to its classical counterpart. The focus is on transforming the fractional Bernoulli equation—modeled in its classical form—from a nonlinear to a linear equation. A detailed mathematical procedure is provided, along with an illustrative example to demonstrate the method.

title: Call for Articles: IEEE Pervasive Computing
authors: N/A

title: AI in Employee Performance Management: Process Mining for Enhancing Productivity and Growth
authors: Maqsood Mahmud, Ghayur Ahmad, Zahra Afridi
abstract: This study examines the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and process mining in employee performance management at Prince Muhammad Bin Fahad University. A survey of 44 staff members assessed AI familiarity, productivity impact, and ethical concerns. Results showed 68% of postgraduate respondents and 75% of participants under age 35 highly accepted AI tools. Correlation and sentiment analyses, supported by predictive modeling, identified key factors influencing AI adoption. Strong associations were observed between AI learning tools and career alignment (r = 0.88), and between fairness and work quality (r = 0.82). Younger participants expressed optimism, while 61% of older respondents raised concerns about data privacy and bias. These findings underscore the importance of transparent, ethical, and user-centric AI systems. The research demonstrates that AI, integrated with process mining, offers strategic value for data-driven decision-making in human resource management.

title: Compact Wideband Parasitic Patch Antenna with AMC Surface for Stable High-Gain Performance
authors: Shengzhe Li, Yu Yun, Zhe Wu, Wenlong Yang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: A wideband and high-gain design by integrating artificial magnetic conductor (AMC) cells with parasitic patches is proposed in this letter. The antenna has an overall size of 0.86×0.86×0.077λ₀³ (λ₀ is the free-space wavelength at the center frequency) and is fabricated on two F4B-TMS220 substrates with a dielectric constant of 2.2. Parasitic patches are introduced around the main radiator to excite multiple resonant modes and achieve impedance bandwidth enhancement. Meanwhile, the AMC layer provides an in-phase reflection response within the operating band, which improves the radiation condition, increases the effective permittivity, and shifts the resonance toward lower frequencies. Simulation results indicate that the proposed antenna achieves a 33% impedance bandwidth (4.9–6.83 GHz), a peak gain of 8.3 dBi, and a 35% 1-dB gain bandwidth (4.6–6.65 GHz), while maintaining a total efficiency higher than 92% across the operating band. Furthermore, the fabricated prototype exhibits good agreement with simulations, validating the effectiveness and application potential of the proposed design in broadband and high-gain antenna systems.

title: A Deep-Supervised Knowledge Distillation Method for Industrial Anomaly Detection
authors: Yulei He, Lei Sun, Yao Li, Gushuai Liu, Junming Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Visual anomaly detection plays a critical role in industrial quality inspection. Traditional knowledge distillation approaches often employ similar or even identical architectures for student-teacher models, limiting their ability to represent anomalies in diverse ways. Effectively transferring knowledge between teacher and student networks remains a significant challenge. To address these issues, we propose a novel knowledge distillation framework based on deep supervision for industrial surface anomaly detection. Specifically, we leverage the rich semantic information from the highest feature layer of the teacher network to guide the learning process at multiple levels within the student network. To facilitate this hierarchical knowledge transfer, we design multiple projection modules to bridge the feature spaces between the teacher and students. Furthermore, we integrate CBAM attention modules into the teacher-student architecture to enhance feature extraction and mitigate limitations posed by structural similarity. The proposed distillation approach is structurally simple yet demonstrates strong performance. We evaluate our method on two benchmark datasets, MVTec AD and BeanTech AD. Experimental results show that our model achieves impressive average AUROC scores of 98.69% and 94.58%, respectively, surpassing state-of-the-art methods.

title: Comparative Study of Different Gate Dielectrics on AlGaN/GaN MOSHEMTs
authors: Ankita Chandola, Peyush Pande, Priyanka Nautiyal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This study presents a comparative analysis of various gate dielectric materials used in AlGaN/GaN Metal Oxide Semiconductor High Electron Mobility Transistors (MOSHEMTs). The materials used as dielectrics, such as Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>, Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> and Hfo<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, have different dielectric constants. To ascertain the enhancement in the device's performance, the properties of the device specifically, the drain current, threshold voltage, and transconductance were examined. The results of the simulation show that among the evaluated dielectrics, Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> exhibits the highest drain current and also the maximum negative threshold voltage shift. Higher transconductance is obtained for HfO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>. Consequently, the findings suggest that with different materials as dielectrics, there is a significant improvement in the performance of HEMTs based on GaN that have a dielectric layer on the gate (MOSHEMT) as opposed to those that don't (Schottky HEMT).

title: Evaluating the Impact of Emerging Contaminants on Membrane Performance in Ultrapure-Water Production for Semiconductor Manufacturing: A PRISMA-Directed Meta-Analysis_supp1-3657662.docx
authors: Hafiz Usama Tanveer
abstract: Ultrapure water (UPW) is indispensable in semiconductor manufacturing, where it serves as the foundational input for wafer cleaning, chemical dilution, and rinsing steps. As device geometries shrink below 5 nm, even parts-per-trillion (ppt) levels of contaminants can compromise yield, reliability, and compliance with industry standards such as SEMI F63 and ASTM D5127. Emerging contaminants (ECs) including per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), pharmaceuticals and personal care products (PPCPs), chemical mechanical planarization (CMP) organics, and micro/nanoplastics pose new challenges for membrane-based UPW treatment systems, especially under evolving regulations like the EPA PFAS Rule (2024). This PRISMA-guided meta-analysis evaluates 31 peer-reviewed studies (2002–2025) to quantify how reverse osmosis (RO), nanofiltration (NF), and ultrafiltration (UF) membranes perform under EC exposure. RO consistently achieved >99% rejection for long-chain PFAS and PPCPs but showed lower efficacy (93.8–99.2%) for short-chain compounds. NF demonstrated variable rejection (86–98%) depending on compound characteristics but offered energy savings in suitable contexts. UF was effective for microplastics but suffered significant flux decline (15–45%) with CMP-related organics. These findings offer critical, data-driven insights for semiconductor facilities seeking to maintain compliance, reduce operating costs, and optimize yield amid stricter water quality demands.

title: Collaborative Spatio-Temporal Anchors and Key Feature Enhancement for UAV Tracking
authors: Qiuyu Jin, Yuqi Han, Linbo Tang, Wenzheng Wang, Haotian Sun, Yanhua Wang
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Target tracking in unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) platforms faces significant challenges due to high maneuverability-induced appearance variations, including abrupt scale changes, viewpoint shifts, and non-rigid deformations. Existing trackers suffer from two critical limitations: (1) fixed-interval sampling strategies fail to capture nonlinear state transitions, and (2) error accumulation in dynamic reference updating degrades long-term robustness. To address these issues, we propose a novel dynamic spatio-temporal perception framework with error suppression. Our approach introduces two core innovations: First, the Spatio-Temporal Anchors Module employs the Wasserstein-1 distance to quantify feature distribution evolution, enabling geodesic-equidistant sampling of representative reference frames that uniformly cover target transition trajectories. This distribution-aware mechanism adaptively balances update density during stable phases and critical transitions. Second, the Key Feature Enhancement Module conducts attention-driven fusion of candidate regions and historical references, dynamically propagating spatially salient features—identified through attention response analysis—via a cascaded architecture to mitigate error accumulation. Extensive evaluations on UAV123, UAVTrack112L, DTB70, and LaSOT benchmarks demonstrate state-of-the-art performance, with notable improvements in occlusion scenarios and deformation resistance, confirming its practical viability for aerial observation systems.

title: A Robust Position Sensor Offset Correction Method Based on Harmonic Current Injection for SPMSM
authors: Peng Zeng, Yao Sun, Hanbing Dan, Feng Zhou, Mei Su, Patrick Wheeler, Marco Rivera
abstract: The performance of the surface-mounted permanent magnet synchronous motor (SPMSM) drive system under the rotor field orientation (RFO) control scheme may significantly deteriorate in the presence of position sensor offset (PSO). To address this problem, first, the effects of the SPMSM drive system under PSO are investigated. Furthermore, a robust online PSO correction method based on d-axis harmonic current injection is proposed. Compared with existing schemes, the proposed scheme is independent of motor parameters so that exhibits high robustness to parametric uncertainties. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by experiments.

title: Automatic Detection of Onset and Offset of Respiratory Electromyographic Activity in severe COPD Patients on Non-Invasive Mechanical Ventilation_supp1-3657639.pptx
authors: ABEL TORRES
abstract: Objective: Accurate detection of inspiratory onset and offset in the diaphragm electromyographic signal (EMGdi) is clinically relevant to assess patient-ventilator interaction in COPD patients undergoing non-invasive ventilation (NIV). Manual annotations are time-consuming and subject to inter-observer variability, highlighting the need for reliable automatic methods. Method: We developed a fully automatic algorithm to detect EMGdi activity cycles and their onset/offset timing in overnight NIV recordings. Four ECG suppression approaches were combined with root mean square (RMS) and fixed sample entropy (fSE) envelopes, and a novel bias correction strategy based on inspiratory-to-basal signal-to-noise ratio (I2BSNR) was introduced. Performance was compared with double-blind annotations from two independent experts. Results: In a cohort of 10 severe COPD patients (9212 annotated cycles), the best configuration (adaptive filtering with fSE exponential envelope) achieved F1=0.96, with onset bias -28 ms (SD 270 ms) and offset bias +120 ms (SD 292 ms). We show that fSE-based envelopes consistently outperform RMS in onset/offset detection, and that I2BSNR-based correction reduces systematic bias to within accepted clinical timing windows. Conclusions: The proposed method provides accurate and robust onset/offset detection of EMGdi during NIV in COPD patients. This enables reliable quantification patient-ventilator asynchronies such as ineffective efforts and delayed cycling, offering direct clinical value for optimizing nightly ventilator settings in severe COPD.

title: A Novel and Accurate Recurrence Plot–Based Characterization of Speech Dynamics in Hyperfunctional Dysphonia, Laryngitis, and Vocal Fold Polyp
authors: Anisha G Krishnan, G Jyothish Lal, E. A. Gopalakrishnan
abstract: The accurate and interpretable detection of pathological voice conditions remains a critical challenge in clinical speech analysis. Existing acoustic and deep learning–based approaches are majorly based on spectral or temporal representations that provide limited insight into the underlying physiological behavior of the vocal folds. This work introduces a novel and accurate Recurrence Plot (RP) –based framework that models sustained vowel phonations as nonlinear dynamical systems. This enables direct characterization of vocal fold oscillatory patterns through Recurrence Plots and Recurrence Quantification Analysis (RQA). The proposed method facilitates robust multiclass classification of three common voice disorders such as hyperfunctional dysphonia, laryngitis, and vocal fold polyp. Using the publicly available Saarbrücken Voice Database (SVD), the proposed method achieves a mean classification accuracy of 90.2% and shows superior disease-specific performance. Compared to a state-of-the-art CNN-based temporal feature method, the proposed work showed a relative improvement of 32% for laryngitis and a 32.4% improvement for Vocal Fold polyp, while the performance for hyperfunctional Dysphonia remains comparable. These improvements indicate that modeling speech as a nonlinear dynamical process provides richer and more discriminative representations than traditional linear methods. Thus, by integrating physiological interpretability and strong diagnostic performance, this study presents a clinically meaningful and explainable solution for pathological voice assessment

title: High-Frequency Injection Method for Position Sensorless Drive of IPMSM with a Single DC-Link Current Sensor
authors: Da-Hye Park, Wook-Jin Lee
abstract: This paper proposes a new high-frequency injection method for saliency-based position sensorless drives of interior permanent magnet synchronous machines, utilizing a single dc-link current sensor. Due to the minimum duration time required for accurate current measurement, there exists an immeasurable region during which current cannot be measured. In addition, the simultaneous reconstruction of three-phase currents is not possible, and unaligned sampling points introduce reconstruction errors that degrade rotor position estimation accuracy. To address these limitations, a new pulse-width modulation (PWM) technique is proposed to enhance rotor position estimation accuracy, and an alternating dq-axis injection method is adopted to avoid current immeasurable regions. The proposed approach requires no additional compensation based on motor parameters and enables high-frequency injection close to the inverter switching frequency. The effectiveness of the proposed HF injection sensorless drive is validated through experimental results under both acceleration and load conditions, demonstrating that a single current sensor achieves performance similar to that obtained with three-phase current sensors.

title: Energy-Assisted Compliant Switching of Dual-Mode Morphing Wing With Metamorphic Mechanism_supp4-3651986.mp4
authors: Bing Li
abstract: The concept of morphing wings is often incorporated in the design of highly adaptive aircraft. However, the design of dual-mode morphing wing and the research of mode switching method remain insufficiently developed. This article presents a novel dual-mode morphing wing based on the characteristics of multiple modes of metamorphic mechanism. Through the combination of basic 4R mechanisms, we designed a class of line symmetry Bricard mechanisms. A novel self-coupling joint is developed to enable compliant switching between different modes without new actuator. Based on the energy change during movement, we propose an energy-assisted method to realize the mode switching. Ultimately, we constructed a prototype aircraft with two modes: variable anhedral angle for enhanced maneuverability and variable sweep angle for better aerodynamic efficiency. The mode switching experiment shows that the motion state of the joint changes compliantly during the mode switching. The experiments show that the morphing wing can change the anhedral angle (7°–12°) and sweep angle (15°–30°), and can change the mode with the help of flight conditions. The aircraft can fly successfully in both modes, which shows the superiority of the design method. The findings of this study hold significant potential for the design of morphing wings in highly adaptive aircraft.

title: S²TA-Fuse: Semantic-Superpixel Tokenized Attention for Spatial Spectral Fusion
authors: Jiawei Jiang, Wei Li, Jieyuan Pei, Junwei Zhu, Honghui Xu, Yuchao Feng, Jianwei Zheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Superpixel paradigms have long been regarded as a well-established approach of mitigating spatial redundancy in hyperspectral images, yet their reliance on non-differentiable and irreversible segmentation renders them unsuitable for end-to-end spatial–spectral fusion (SSF). To tackle this limitation, this study introduces S²TA-Fuse, a transformer-based solver named Semantic-Superpixel Tokenized Attention for Fusion, which preserves the efficiency of superpixels while removing the need for explicit segmentation. The central design lies in a semantic attention mechanism that adaptively organizes pixels into deformable and content-aware semantic groups. Pixels sharing similar latent states are softly aggregated and encoded as compact tokens, upon which attention is computed to capture intricate long-range dependencies. This formulation endows the model with an inherent ability to accommodate scale variations while maintaining linear computational complexity with respect to the number of pixels. On top of the semantic backbone, two complementary components are devised. The Local Spectral Pyramid enhances the representation of multi-scale spectral cues in the spatial domain, whereas FreqNet supplements global information by modeling frequency-dependent variations through amplitude and phase decomposition. Comprehensive experiments on widely used benchmarks for spatial–spectral fusion demonstrate that S²TA-Fuse consistently surpasses the state of the art both in quantitative accuracy and visual fidelity.

title: Design of an Integrated OFDM Waveform Based on Combined Zadoff-Chu Sequence Precoding and Pulse Shaping Techniques
authors: Lingyi Hu, Renhong Xie, Ruixin Yang, Liwen He, Zihang Cheng, Peng Li, Zhonghai Yang, Hao Pan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of OFDM integrated signal communication information degrading the ambiguity function performance and elevated peak-to-average power ratio(PAPR) impairing the overall performance of the system, this paper proposes an OFDM integrated waveform design method based on the combination of Zadoff-Chu (ZC) sequence precoding and pulse shaping technique. The ZC sequence optimization enhances the inter-symbol correlation of OFDM integrated signals, thereby improving their communication modulation characteristics. Concurrently, the implementation of an advanced Nyquist pulse shaping technique achieves effective spectral shaping, resulting in significant PAPR suppression. Simulation results demonstrate that the synergistic combination of ZC sequence precoding and pulse shaping techniques effectively enhances the radar detection capability of OFDM waveforms. This joint approach achieves dual-functional performance improvement while suppressing the PAPR, significantly optimizing the system’s integrated performance.

title: Feedback-Enhanced GM-CPHD-MHT Fusion for Bearing-Only Underwater Multi-Target Tracking Under Unknown Cluttered Scenario
authors: Xiong Qiang, Pengfei Shao, Qiming Ma, Chenxi Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the performance degradation of conventional Multiple Hypothesis Tracking (MHT) algorithms in high-clutter environments and the poor performance coupled with the lack of trajectory generation capability of the Gaussian Mixture Cardinalized Probability Hypothesis Density (GMCPHD) filter based on random finite sets under unknown clutter scenarios, this paper proposes a feedback-enhanced GM-CPHDMHT fusion algorithm (FE-GM-CPHD-MHT). This algorithm achieves complementary advantages through a bidirectional closed-loop architecture. The forward channel utilizes the target state estimates output by GM-CPHD as enhanced measurements input into the MHT module, optimizing trajectory generation. The feedback channel leverages high-confidence trajectories generated by MHT to inversely estimate clutter density, dynamically updating the clutter parameters within the GM-CPHD model. Extensive 200-run Monte Carlo experiments conducted under unknown clutter intensity demonstrate that, compared to traditional methods, the proposed algorithm exhibits significant advantages in tracking error reduction and can accurately estimate clutter density.

title: Fuzzy knowledge Perception with Fault Tolerance and Brain-inspired Reasoning for Diagnosis of Ultrasound images
authors: Qinghua Huang, Sifan Gao, Guanghui Li, Wei Wang
abstract: Fault tolerance to interference and interpretability are crucial for computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems. In clinical practice, deep learning models are often not accepted by doctors and patients due to their lack of diagnostic reasoning capabilities. Moreover, ultrasound imaging data contain significant noise and artifacts, making deep models vulnerable to interference, which frequently leads to misclassification. To address this issue, this study leverages fuzzy logic to achieve fault-tolerant perception of image content and employs a fuzzy trustworthy brain-inspired reasoning framework for diagnostic decision-making. In the fast-thinking module, we innovatively introduce the fuzzification of deep classification probabilities and construct a fault-tolerant perception set based on medical feature classification information. In the slow-thinking module, we establish a tensor decomposition-based knowledge graph, where medical feature information and membership degrees from the fault-tolerant perception set are jointly embedded to form a trustworthy factor matrix. The reasoning space reconstructed under this matrix guides the reasoning process from medical features toward the correct diagnostic outcome. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed model, we conducted diagnostic experiments on thyroid nodules and breast tumors, achieving AUC scores of 0.9549 and 0.9751, respectively. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach exhibits outstanding diagnostic performance on real-world ultrasound data.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Reward-Guided Attention for Autonomous Driving
authors: Yueyong Chen, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Autonomous vehicle control using reinforcement learning is a complex task, especially in dynamic and changing traffic environments, where accurately identifying critical scenarios and making safe and effective decisions remain major challenges. Existing methods are deficient in key feature extraction and policy interpretability, which limits their performance capability in high-risk scenarios. In this paper, we propose an attention mechanism based on reward perception, which utilizes reward feedback information to guide the model to focus on key regions in the image that are highly relevant to the decision-making outcome, thus improving the model's attentional selectivity and strategy robustness. Based on this mechanism, an end-to-end visual reinforcement learning automatic driving control framework is constructed, where the system takes vehicle front-view images as inputs, fuses basic visual features with key reward features, and generates state vectors to be inputted into the reinforcement learning agent to make action decisions. Meanwhile, a reward function fusing traffic rules and passing efficiency is designed to regulate vehicle behavior. The experiments are carried out on the CARLA simulation platform, and a complex scenario containing key traffic elements such as pedestrians, obstacle vehicles, downhill turns and tunnels is constructed. The results show that the method in this paper outperforms traditional reinforcement learning methods in terms of learning efficiency, strategy stability, and attention visualization and interpretation effects, demonstrating the effectiveness and application prospects of reward-driven mechanisms in improving the safety and interpretability of autonomous driving systems.

title: JQA: Joint Design of Hardware-Friendly Quantization and Efficient Accelerator for Spiking Neural Networks
authors: Hanwen Liu, Kexin Shi, Wenyu Chen, Malu Zhang, Yang Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Brain-inspired Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) have attracted significant attention for their potential to enable energy-efficient computing on neuromorphic hardware. However, the current SNN community focuses primarily on performance improvement by developing large-scale models on CPU or GPU platforms, which limits the applicability of SNNs in resourcelimited edge devices. In this paper, we propose JQA, a softwarehardware co-design framework for efficiently deploying highperformance SNNs on resource-constrained platforms. On the software side, we introduce a hardware-friendly quantization strategy, which enables SNNs to perform the entire inference process using integer arithmetic and bit-shifting. On the hardware side, we develop an efficient SNN accelerator that adopts a row stationary (RS) dataflow while incorporating tiling and parallelism schemes specifically designed for SNNs. JQA is designed at the register-transfer level (RTL) and implemented on the Xilinx Zynq XC7Z035 FPGA board with limited resources. Extensive experiments demonstrate that JQA outperforms existing works in terms of accuracy, throughput, and energy efficiency. These state-of-the-art results suggest that JQA offers promising potential for real-world SNN applications in resource-constrained scenarios.

title: SEEND: A Spike-Based End-to-End Framework for Energy-Efficient Speaker Diarization
authors: Kexin Shi, Hanwen Liu, Jibin Wu, Wenyu Chen, Malu Zhang, Yang Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: End-to-end models based on Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) have demonstrated remarkable progress in speaker diarization, becoming the dominant approach for speaker diarization. However, their high energy consumption, arising from intensive matrix multiplications, hinders deployment on portable or low-power devices. Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs), inspired by the event-driven communication mechanisms of the human brain, offer a promising energy-saving alternative for ANNs, yet remain largely unexplored in speaker diarization. In this work, we present SEEND, the first spike-based end-to-end speaker diarization framework, which establishes an energy-efficient computation paradigm for this task. Specifically, we propose a lightweight Spike Time-Frequency Decoupled Extractor (S-TFDE) for effective time-frequency feature extraction and fusion with low computational cost. Building upon S-TFDE, SEEND stacks multi-stage S-Former blocks to capture both fine-grained local speaker patterns and long-range frame dependencies, refining speaker spike embeddings. Furthermore, inspired by information entropy, we introduce a Spike Embedding Enhancement (SEE) method, which improves the expressiveness of spike speaker representations, thereby boosting diarization performance. Extensive experiments on LibriSpeech-based simulated datasets demonstrate that SEEND achieves a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times$</tex> reduction in energy consumption while maintaining excellent diarization performance, setting a new benchmark for spike-based speaker diarization.

title: Enhancing Obesity Prediction with Explainable AI: A DeepHealthNet-Based Comparative Study
authors: Sridhar Chintala, Siri Chandana Kota, Payal Bhardwaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Obesity is becoming a global issue as daily habits shift toward less movement and more unhealthy eating as life becomes more convenient. People are unknowingly developing habits that increase the risk of obesity. The purpose of this study is to predict obesity categories using Machine Learning (ML) and Deep Learning (DL) models on actual data. We tested a few different models including K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Logistic Regression, Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Long-Shortterm Memory (LSTM), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and our custom architecture DeepHealthNet. Among these models, the proposed DeepHealthNet achieved the highest accuracy (97.00%) above Logistic Regression (95.60%), followed by MLP (95.00%) by a lower difference. Further examinations of the DeepHealthNet model showed differences in predicting obesity rates based on gender in Men (94.29%) and Women (92.71%).

title: Persymmetric adaptive detection in multipath and Gaussian environment
authors: Hongzhi Guo, Haoqi Wu, Lei Yuan, Zhihang Wang, Zishu He, Ziyang Cheng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper addresses the adaptive detection problem of radar in multipath and Gaussian noise, as both homogeneous environment (HE) and partially HE (PHE) are considered. Besides, the persymmetric property of the noise covariance matrix is utilized to convert the detection problem. Two detectors with a tunable parameter are derived based on the generalized likelihood ratio test (GLRT) in HE and PHE, respectively. The simulation experiments show the derived detectors are constant false alarm rate (CFAR) tests, and the proposed detectors are superior to the existing detectors, especially in the case of limited training data.

title: Next-Generation AI Framework for Advanced Deepfake Detection and Prevention Systems
authors: Bharath Singh Jebaraj, Akhil K V, Gautam Pradeep, R Kalai Arasan, Chitranjan Kumar Patel, Vivekrabinson K
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Deepfake are generated by artificial intelligence, which manipulates or alters the real image with the fake one. In general, smart computer programs are used to identify false videos and images, known as deepfakes. It uses tools such as TensorFlow and EfficientNetV2 to identify small errors that indicate something has been faked. The MTCNN method assists the program in detecting the faces in the media, and OpenCV and MoviePy in analyzing significant segments of videos. Gradio allow people to try a program and get results immediately. Their tests demonstrate that using all of these tools in tandem performs well to verify the authenticity of videos and images and helps to prevent misinformation spreaders online.

title: MYA-EWS: A Real-Time Anomalous Event Warning Framework Fusing Target Detection and Semantic Reasoning
authors: Wei Jia, Shanchuan Yu, Xiaogang Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The real-time detection and early warning of abnormal events such as fighting, congestion, and unattended objects are very important in public space scenes with dense human flow (such as railway station waiting hall). Traditional visual inspection methods have the defects of insufficient high-level semantic understanding ability, and multimodal large language models (MLLM) have the advantages of deep understanding, but they are difficult to meet the real-time requirements. Aiming at the problems of high false alarm rate of complex scenes and insufficient understanding of abnormal events in the monitoring of public areas in large scenes, this paper proposes an abnormal event early warning framework, MYAEWS, which integrates YOLO11 target detection and Qwen2.5VL7B. Firstly, the framework uses YOLO11 to perform real-time target detection and rule filtering on the monitoring video stream, and then transmits the key frames and detection results to Qwen2.5VL-7B. The customized Prompt is used to understand multi-modal graphics and text and judge abnormal data, realize the semantic understanding and early warning of abnormal events, and generate video summary and abnormal event work order. Experimental results show that the proposed framework achieves an abnormal event detection accuracy of 89.3% on the data set of the self-built railway station waiting hall, and the false alarm rate is lower than that of the traditional method, which verifies the effectiveness of the multi-modal fusion architecture in complex scenes.

title: GAN-Aided Knowledge-Data-Driven MPC for Crystal Diameter Regulation
authors: Yin Wan, Chun-Jie Han, Ding Liu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Addressing the significant challenges posed by nonlinearity, time-varying dynamics, and modeling errors in crystal diameter regulation during Czochralski (CZ) silicon single crystal growth, this paper proposes a Knowledge-Data Fusion Model Predictive Control (KDD-MPC) method incorporating Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-based knowledge transfer. The method introduces a GAN module in the offline phase. Through adversarial training on key process variables such as crystal diameter and crystal lift rate, the GAN extracts deep structural knowledge, which is then migrated to a Radial Basis Function (RBF) neural network, significantly enhancing the generalization capability of the prediction model. Building upon this, an MPC control framework incorporating knowledge transfer is constructed, forming a data-driven control strategy guided by structural knowledge. During online operation, the proposed method continuously refines and updates model parameters based on real-time error feedback, achieving high-precision and robust online control. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms traditional approaches in crystal diameter tracking performance, exhibiting superior dynamic response capability and stability. This provides a novel solution for modeling and controlling nonlinear complex industrial processes.

title: AI-powered Inclusive Learning: Use Cases at Deusto
authors: Olga Dziabenko, Diego Lopez-de-Ipina, Javier Garcia-Zubia, Unai Hernandez Jayo, Maja Pusnik, Bostjan Sumak, Sergio Duarte Correia, Tuncer Can, Darja Ivanusa Kline
abstract: This paper explores the transformative role of AI-driven technology in engineering higher education, on the example of the Faculty of Engineering, the University of Deusto, enhancing inclusivity through personalized, accessible, and ethical learning experiences. The study evaluates AI's benefits and challenges through questionnaire and institutional pilot programs, introducing the need for AI literacy training, transparent policies, and human monitoring to mitigate ethical concerns, algorithmic bias, and unequal access. A responsible and collaborative approach among educators, policymakers, and technologists is essential to ensure equal and unbiased AI integration. Future research should focus on AI's long-term impact, the development of AI literacy programs, and innovative strategies for inclusive education.

title: Lightweight Vein Recognition for Secure IoT Edge Devices: A Channel-wise Attention Approach for Big Data Biometrics
authors: Yuming Fu, Jing Chen, Haiyang Li, Qun Song, Feng Xi, Huafeng Qin, Shuqiang Yang

title: Demo of an Early Warning System for Remote Sensing of Wildfires
authors: Marta Oliveira, Luís Malarmey, Pedro Casau, Paulo Pedreiras, Sandra Millán Arias, Cristina Montesinos Barrios, João Barraca, Pedro Fonseca
abstract: In this demo, we will showcase an IoT-based warning system for fire monitoring and early warning system. The system integrates wireless environmental sensors to monitor temperature, humidity, wind speed and other biophysical indices in real-time. The system uses open-source technologies including Apache Kafka, Mosquitto, Logstash, Elasticsearch, Kibana, N8N and Elastalert. This system processes, stores, and visualizes incoming data, allowing for real-time monitoring and predictive analysis as alerting system. During the demonstration, participants will observe live sensor data visualization and automated alerting mechanisms that indicate potential fire risks. This system provides a proactive approach to wildfire monitoring, supporting early detection and efficient response strategies.
