title: Optimizing IoT Energy Consumption and Security: A Quantum-Based Data Aggregation Mechanism
authors: Achyut Yaragal, Kirankumar Bendigeri
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: With the proliferation of interconnected sensor devices, the Internet of Things (IoT) is rapidly becoming one of the most significant global technological developments. The transition from a human-centric to a "Things" network is taking place without a hitch, allowing everyday items to establish wireless connections with one another. There is a correlation between the IoT routing protocol's power consumption and the longevity of the network. Also, because small sensors are typically difficult to recharge after deployment, the enormous amount of data generated by the IoT will lead to transmission collisions, security problems, and energy loss as a result of increased data redundancy. In order to conserve energy, data aggregation typically puts some nodes into sleep mode while others remain active, reducing data redundancy at each node. As a result, employing the fuzzy matrix to cluster nodes with very comparable data is crucial. After that, a fuzzy similarity matrix is used to cluster the data that has been received from the member nodes at the Cluster Head (CH). After clustering, the following step is to select a subset of nodes from each group to serve as redundant nodes. Data duplication, network congestion, and transmission expenses are all mitigated by implementing the sleep scheduling technique. In order to reduce power consumption, to offer a blockchain-protected Energy-Efficient Data Aggregation Mechanism (EEDAM) that aggregates data at the cluster level. Quantum based Draf Mongoose Optimization Algorithm (QDMOA) is used to pick the fuzzy logic parameter allocation in the best possible way. When blockchain technology is linked into cloud servers, it verifies the edge computing, allowing for the provision of secure, on-demand services to the IoT with little latency. To concluded by simulating the proposed mechanism's operation and comparing its results to those of more traditional energy-saving techniques. Extending the wireless sensor network (WSN), reducing data amounts, and ensuring suitable IoT security are all achieved by the proposed structural design, according to the simulation results.

title: Delay-Multiply-And-Sum Beamforming for Real-Time In-Air Acoustic Imaging
authors: Wouter Jansen, Walter Daems, Jan Steckel
abstract: In-air acoustic imaging systems demand beamforming techniques that offer high dynamic range and spatial resolution while remaining robust, yet conventional Delay-and-Sum (DAS) beamforming suffers from high sidelobes and low contrast. Conversely, advanced adaptive methods are typically too computationally expensive for real-time field operation. To overcome this trade-off, we propose a higher-order non-linear beamforming method using the Delay-Multiply-and-Sum (DMAS) technique with Coherence Factor weighting, specifically adapted for in-air microphone arrays. By leveraging Newton-Girard binomial expansion, we reduce the complexity of n-th order DMAS to O(N), enabling GPU-accelerated, real-time performance on embedded platforms, with the implementation also made available as open-source. Through validation against simulated and real-world data, we demonstrate that the proposed 5th-order DMAS with CF achieves a dynamic range improvement of nearly 40 dB over DAS, alongside significantly higher image SNR and artifact suppression. We demonstrate real-time viability on various GPU platforms, establishing this approach as a practical, high-performance solution for 3D in-air sonar and industrial acoustic imaging.

title: Secure Lightweight Authentication with Anonymous Data Access for UnattendedWireless Sensor Networks
authors: B D Deebak, Gregory Epiphaniou, Carsten Maple
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Unattended wireless sensor networks (U-WSNs) are deployed in various scenarios, including disaster relief, environmental monitoring, and medical applications. These differ from traditional WSNs because they do not have a permanent, stationary sink to collect and analyze data. However, given the potentially sensitive information, secure data transmission with privacy preservation is a major concern. This paper proposes a provably secure lightweight authentication with anonymous data access (PSLA-ADA). Appropriate key agreement protocols were extensively researched to examine the key properties of cryptographic protocols. Moreover, the proposed PSLA-ADA framework employs three-factor authentication with an anonymous data access strategy to ensure perfect forward secrecy, providing a significant degree of efficient security. Formal and informal analyses show that the proposed PSLA-ADA secures data privacy, integrity, and confidentiality. Using a practical testbed, the proposed PSLA-ADA shows better performance in terms of transmission efficiency (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\approx 91.63\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>) and overhead ratio (at a reduced cost of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\approx 17.67\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>) compared to other representative approaches.

title: PEPpip: A Vision-Inspired Explainable Deep Learning Framework for Sequence-Based Protein-Protein Interaction Prediction and Interaction Map Estimation
authors: Shubhrangshu Ghosh, Pralay Mitra
abstract: Predicting protein–protein interaction (PPI) patterns from primary sequences constitutes a complex pattern recognition task that demands advanced and explainable deep learning frameworks, as PPIs underpin critical cellular and pathological mechanisms.We propose PEPpip, a deep learning framework for binary sequence-based PPI prediction that also derives interaction maps via explainable-AI (XAI) methods. PEPpip encodes sequence pairs into 3D image-like feature maps using three pre-trained protein language models(PLMs). To learn PPI patterns, it applies two vision-based classifiers—ResNet and Vision Transformer( ViT)—whose predictions are fused through a novel Post-hoc Inference Combiner(PIC) leveraging their complementary strengths. In addition, PEPpip uniquely generates PPI maps by combining XAI-based interaction maps from integrated gradients and ViT attention, further refined through a modular noise-cleaning pipeline. We introduce a novel residue-residue interaction-aware, class-discriminative attention map(RiaCdAm) mechanism that embeds biological priors into ViT attention, improving interpretability and contact relevance. PEPpip achieves state-of-the-art AUPR (Area Under Precision-Recall curve) scores across species—91.1%(Mouse), 89.1%(Fly), 87.7%(Worm), 68.1%(Yeast), and 71.9%(E.coli)—outperforming existing methods by 2–3%. It also performs strongly on Human-PPI tasks. While its sequence-driven, XAI-based PPI map approach is not directly comparable to structure-based learners, PEPpip surpasses competing sequence-based classifiers in interaction map estimation, exceeding the next-best method by over 5% in top-L/10 and top-L/5 categories (L: shorter protein-length in the pair). PEPpip provides a unified and interpretable framework for binary PPI prediction with coarse-grained interaction map estimation, offering a practical first-pass screening tool for large-scale interactome analysis and paving the way for future XAI-integrated models.

title: Deep Learning-Based Cascade Failure Prediction for Transmission Lines at Risk in an IoT-based Power Grid Monitoring Framework
authors: Jen-Cheng Wang, Yun-Chung Yu, Mu-Hwa Lee, Ming-Jhou Lin, Chien-Hsing Lee, Li-Cheng Wu, Joe-Air Jiang
abstract: Under an internet of thing (IoT)-based framework, a power grid monitoring system can collect real-time transmission line data, which can then be used to predict the cascading failure risks within the grid. This study proposed a two-stage cascade failure prediction (CFP) model that integrated deep learning techniques with supervised classification algorithms to identify transmission lines susceptible to cascading failures, thereby preventing large-scale power system collapses. In the first-stage, the CFP model utilizes historical transmission line data to predict lines at risk in the next time step. In the second-stage, it assesses whether the predicted at-risk lines could trigger system instability or power outages. Three deep learning-based algorithms were employed in the first-stage, whereas three binary classification algorithms were utilized in the second-stage. The proposed CFP model was evaluated using an IEEE 39-bus system, where 2,000 cascading failure events were simulated through a real-time digital simulator (RTDS). Experimental results demonstrate that the two-stage CFP model, particularly when combining a deep neural network with a binary classifier, can accurately identify potential risk lines in the test grid with an accuracy ranging from 97.5% to 98.3%. Moreover, the CFP model exhibits strong robustness against noisy and erroneous data. These predictive results provide valuable insights for power companies in formulating preventive safety strategies against cascading failures.

title: Three-Dimensional Fusion Imaging for Space Targets with Space-Based Distributed Radars
authors: Xiaozhi Zhuang, Shuai Shao, Jiaqi Wei
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The rapid advancement of aerospace technology and proliferation of low earth orbit (LEO) satellite density enable space-based distributed radars. However, existing 3D radar imaging algorithms, such as interferometric inverse synthetic aperture radar (InISAR) and back projection (BP), face a trade-off between resolution and computational efficiency. The former suffers from angular glint effects causing scattering point displacement or loss, while the latter incurs an impractical complexity, hindering real-time processing. To address the above challenges, we propose a computationally efficient and glint-resilient 3-D fusion imaging framework for space-based distributed radars. The method first employs InISAR pre-localization to coarsely locate scattering centers. Then, through point-wise 3-D BP, angular-glint artifacts are identified. Subsequently, real scattering points are recovered within height domains constrained by an oriented bounding box (OBB). This method markedly reduces computational load while preserving high-resolution and effectively suppressing angular-glint distortions under sparse target observation scenarios.

title: Toward Enhancing Outdoor Mobility Assistive Technologies for People with Vision Impairment: Experts' Perspective
authors: Abeer Malkawi, Azrina Kamaruddin
abstract: Outdoor mobility can be a severe challenge for people with vision impairment (PVI). Significant researchers have proposed assistive technologies (ATs) to enhance PVIs' mobility activity. However, rarely are there ATs that have been reliably adopted in the daily life of PVI. This is partly due to a lack of AT developers to consider three essential user factors: PVIs' outdoor behavior, challenges, and requirements for AT. Accordingly, this study aims to identify these three factors from experts' perspectives. We have chosen this path since many previous studies focused on PVIs' perspectives while ignoring expert opinions. We further argue that experts possess comprehensive knowledge about PVI needs, as their main task is improving their quality of life. We conducted semi-structured interviews with six experts. Our findings highlight the PVIs' behaviors to correlate with safe outdoor mobility. In addition, the requirements and challenges may illuminate some uncovered aspects of possible AT improvements. One interesting finding is the significance of the complementary between the white cane and AT, which overcomes cane limitations. Based on this outcome, we encourage the developers to propose ATs that complement the white cane and do not substitute it for successful and safe outdoor mobility for PVI.

title: ChatGPT Vs. DeepSeek: A Comparative Analysis of AI Models for Enhancing Virtual Reality Experiences
authors: Jaber Khalid Mohammad, Salah Mousa, Al Rifaee Mustafa, AlQbailat Naji, Issa Bassem, AbuElzeet Ashour
abstract: With rapid advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) and virtual reality (VR), integrating AI-driven models into VR environments has gained significant attention. This paper presents a comparative analysis of two state-of-the-art AI models, ChatGPT and DeepSeek, to enhance VR experiences. The study examines their architectures, learning efficiency, expressive power, and interaction capabilities, focusing on their ability to generate immersive, intelligent, and adaptive VR environments. Through a comprehensive evaluation, key similarities and differences between the models are highlighted, particularly in natural language processing, virtual asset generation, and real-time user interaction. Experimental findings suggest that while ChatGPT excels in conversational AI and contextual text generation, DeepSeek performs better in visual rendering, object manipulation, and dynamic content adaptation. The research concludes with insights into the future of AI in VR applications, discussing ethical considerations, algorithmic bias, and potential improvements for next-generation AI-driven virtual experiences.

title: Evaluation of AES Encryption Using Diverse S-Box Design Approaches
authors: V. Sarada, Trisha Modi, Sahil Singh, Sahil Hinge
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: AES is a prominent symmetric encryption technology that assures data security through multiple transformation cycles. An important part of the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) framework, the replacement layer uses an 8 × 8 S-Box to make it non-linear and make it more resistant to cryptographic analysis methods because S-Boxes on FPGA platforms have a much greater implementation cost compared to other components, optimizing them for efficient resource utilization is essential. In order to minimize hardware resource utilization, this research looks at different ways to construct S-Boxes for AES encryption, with a specific focus on an 8 × 8 S-Box that uses an alternate irreducible polynomial. Even in resource-constrained settings, the proposed approach maintains the same degree of cryptographic security while increasing gate efficiency. Vivado 2020.2 was designed with the AES architecture in mind, with an emphasis on measuring performance according to silicon area, encryption speed, and power economy. Real-Time encryption and minimal latency operations are essential for safeguarding information in embedded systems, industrial automation, and the Internet of Things (IoT). Our approach guarantees a superior encryption solution for these scenarios.

title: Application of Neural Tuning Machine Based PI Controller for Dynamic Performance Improvement of GSC Voltage and Power Flow in DFIG Systems
authors: Bhabasis Mohapatra, Ritesh Dash, Binod Kumar Sahu, Manoj Kumar Debnath
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This paper presents an in-depth analysis of a Neural Tuning Machine (NTM)-based PI controller for optimizing the dynamic performance of a Doubly Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) grid-connected system. The research addresses the limitations of traditional PI controllers, such as high torque ripple and current distortion, by introducing the NTM-PI controller. The proposed control strategy is designed to improve voltage stability at the Grid-Side Converter (GSC) and enhance reactive power management in the DFIG system. Through a series of MATLAB simulations, the study compares the performance of the NTM-PI controller with conventional PI controllers under varying operational conditions. The results indicate that the NTM-PI controller offers superior voltage stability, smoother power flow control, and faster convergence during optimization processes. The paper also explores the tuning mechanisms of the NTM-PI controller using cost function and fitness value analyses to demonstrate its adaptability in real-time applications by using a MATLAB-model. This research highlights the potential of NTM-PI controllers to improve the integration of renewable energy sources, such as wind power, into modern grid systems, ensuring better efficiency and stability under dynamic load conditions. The findings provide a foundation for future developments in control strategies for renewable energy grid integration.

title: Urban Traffic Forecasting, Urban Data Platforms and Urban Foundations Models
authors: Axel Schaffland, Julius Schoning
abstract: In the context of urban environments, accurate traffic forecasting is of significant importance to a multitude of stakeholders. This study aims to demonstrate the potential of sensors installed within the traffic network to facilitate precise forecasting. The work addresses various aspects, including sensor types, sensor positioning, data and tool pipelines, and the utilization of graph neural networks (GNN) for traffic forecasting. Additionally, it offers a perspective on applying these networks in urban foundation models (UFM) for forecasting purposes. This work illustrates the required sensors, tasks, and methods for traffic forecasting based on the city of Osnabrück in Germany as a case study.

title: Design and Research of a Voice-Controlled Autonomous Training System Based on Knowledge Graph
authors: Xiaojing Xu, Hua Deng, Xiangjie Kong, Peng Wen, Xiang Liu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: The evolution of training paradigms from task-oriented to capability-oriented necessitates more autonomous and intelligent simulation training systems. Traditional systems often lack adaptability and real-time, personalized guidance, limiting training efficiency. To address this gap, this paper explores human-machine interaction technologies for autonomous training control. We propose a novel voice-controlled autonomous training system architecture leveraging knowledge graph (KG) technology. This system is designed to provide contextualized knowledge support and operational guidance by modeling domain knowledge and procedures. A functional prototype for a manual docking and rendezvous scenario was developed to validate the feasibility of the proposed approach. Preliminary results indicate the system's potential to enhance training autonomy, flexibility, and effectiveness, laying a foundation for intelligent training systems.

title: Influence of Moisture on Fault Diagnosis for Rotor Poles of Large Synchronous Machines Using Frequency Response Analysis
authors: José Manuel Guerrero, José E. Ruiz-Sarrió, Kumar Mahtani, Juan de la Morena-Marigorta, Carlos A. Platero
abstract: Frequency Response Analysis (FRA) is a well-established technique for the condition monitoring of power transformers. The use of FRA for rotating electrical machines is nowadays a prominent research area. In previous works, the use of FRA for synchronous machine field winding diagnostics has been studied, but some key factors remain uncertain in this application. The moisture content is one of the uncertainty factors that could be envisaged as potentially influential. Therefore, the influence of moisture content on the FRA response of poles of synchronous machines is addressed in this paper. For this purpose, numerous experimental tests have been carried out on an extracted pole of a 40-MVA hydro-generator, with different moisture contents, considering healthy state, ground faults, and interturn faults. The main contribution of this work is to prove that, in contrast to what occurs in ordinary insulation testing, the moisture content does not have a significant influence on the FRA response of the pole, discarding this method for moisture diagnostics. However, this fact makes FRA very interesting for in-situ inspection, as it is independent of the moisture content. This way, it is not required to dry the machine before testing.

title: Resource Scheduling in ORCA for Next-generation Mobile Networks: A Survey and Future Outlook
authors: Sandra Arnaout, Arifur Rahman, Munjure Mowla, Adam Flizikowski, S³awomir Hausman, Piotr Korbel, Zoran Vujicic
abstract: The immense growth of mobile and IoT traffic is pushing the surging data demand beyond the traditional mobile network architectures towards a new domain of architectures, i.e., converged optical and radio networks (ORCA). The architecture can significantly enhance overall networks performance in terms of capacity, latency, dynamic range, reliability, and energy efficiency. Although resource scheduling in ORCA brings unprecedented advantages, which is the key to the success of next-generation (NG) mobile networks, it has also pose some challenges. In this paper, we conduct a state-of-the-art research survey of resource scheduling strategies in ORCA, such as topology-aware dynamic resource allocation, traffic load variation and management in resource allocation, optical layer virtualization, scalability, and energy efficiency aspects. In addition, the techno-economic aspects of the converged network architecture and associated resource scheduling procedure is also summarized. Moreover, we highlight the significance of resource scheduling in real-world scenarios, along with the most relevant open research challenges. Furthermore, we offer insights into the future outlooks of resource scheduling mechanisms and propose a conceptual framework.

title: Strategies for Crop Planting Optimization Under Multiple Factors
authors: Jinting Lan, Weijun Zheng, Yushi Wu, Hai-Lin Liu, Lei Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Against the backdrop of limited agricultural resources and fluctuating market demand, optimizing crop planting strategies is of paramount importance for enhancing the economic benefits of mountainous rural areas. Most existing research focuses on static planning or single risk factor analysis, which finds it difficult to comprehensively address market uncertainties and the complex interactive effects among crops. To this end, this paper proposes an integrated decision-making framework that combines constrained optimization, stochastic programming, and dynamic programming. In particular, a profit maximization model is established using the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\epsilon$</tex>-constraint method, and a Monte Carlo simulation is introduced to quantify the impacts of random variables such as prices and yields. Moreover, the Pearson correlation coefficient is employed to characterize the substitution and complementary relationships among crops. Experimental results show that the proposed model increases profit by 14%, reaching 79.34 million yuan, surpasses uncertainty-only models by nearly 10 million yuan, and keeps revenue volatility within 18%, confirming its effectiveness in complex agriculture.

title: Adaptive Graph Structure Learning-Enhanced Cascade Forests for Robust Tabular Data Classification
authors: Zhaobin Qiu, Dazi Li
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Traditional ensemble learning approaches often struggle to effectively model complex interdependencies among features, limiting their capacity to capture underlying data patterns. While Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) excel at modeling relational structures, their reliance on predefined graph topologies poses a significant challenge for tabular data, where meaningful feature interactions are typically latent and not known a priori. To address these limitations, we propose the Adaptive Graph Structure Learning Cascade Forest (AGCF), a novel algorithm that integrates graph structure learning within an ensemble learning framework. A core contribution is a feature graph structure learning module. This module dynamically infers implicit feature relationships by optimizing an adjacency matrix through gradient-based learning, thereby generating enriched feature representations adapted to the specific dataset. Furthermore, AGCF employs a feature importance-guided graph updating mechanism, establishing a bidirectional feedback loop between the forest ensemble models and the evolving graph structure. This interaction enables the forest models to inform the graph learning based on feature importance, while the learned graph structure, in turn, provides relational context to enhance the forest's representations and predictions. Extensive experiments on diverse industrial and medical datasets demonstrate that AGCF achieves superior classification performance compared to a range of baseline methods.

title: An Improved Gain, Radiation Efficiency Enhanced and Low-SAR Antenna for IoMT Long-Range Monitoring
authors: Yangkun Song, Yu Luo, Chang Li, Ningning Yan, Kaixue Ma
abstract: A low Specific Absorption Rate (SAR) antenna with enhanced radiation efficiency and improved gain is proposed for further improvement of long-range biological monitoring systems within IoMT platforms. A unidirectional uniform current distribution form with high radiation efficiency and low SAR values was first theoretically calculated and proved, which is the current distribution with a ratio coefficient N. Subsequently, we achieved the desired current distribution by ingeniously utilizing the higher-order mode currents of the meandering dipole. The simulation current distribution in each section of this third-order mode dipole agrees with the theoretical calculations. The antenna operation frequency covers the ISM 2.45 GHz band (2.4-2.48 GHz), and the antenna has a peak SAR of 155.5 and 59.2 W/kg for 1-g and 10-g of tissue, respectively. The measured radiation efficiency is more than 2.4% in the band, the peak efficiency is more than 3%, the gain is more than -10.27 dBi in the band, and the peak gain is -8.53 dBi. In addition, based on the communication link budget analysis, it can be confirmed that the proposed antenna can establish a reliable communication link up to distances of 15 m (78 Mb/s) and 20 m (10 Mb/s) at 2.45 GHz, for transferring high data rate information.

title: High-Speed Channel Modeling and Signal Integrity Optimization Based on DNN and NSGA-II
authors: Qiwen Zhang, Weicheng Xie
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the time-consuming challenges with traditional electromagnetic simulations in circuits and the limited diversity of design parameter combinations resulting from singleobjective eye diagram optimization, we proposed a rapid multiobjective optimization algorithm for circuit design parameters. This algorithm integrates a Deep Neural Network (DNN) with the Non-dominated Sorting Genetic Algorithm II (NSGA-II) to generate Pareto front solutions within the circuit design parameter space. By mapping the circuit geometric design parameters to eye height and width, the DNN is trained by a multi-conductor transmission line model with PCB fabrication process, utilized to evaluate the fitness of individuals in the NSGA-II algorithm. The experimental results indicate that the MSE predicted by the DNN is $10^{-3}$, with an average single prediction time of 12 ms, which is only 0.0687% of the time required by the electromagnetic solver. The Pareto front comprises 6 groups of non-dominated solutions, surpassing the single group of solutions typically found in single-objective optimization.

title: Monitoring Abnormal Operating Conditions in Czochralski Silicon Single Crystal Growth Based on Slow Feature Analysis and Stacked Denoising Autoencoders
authors: Jun-Chao Ren, Zi-Xing Huang, Ding Liu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Monocrystalline silicon fabricated via the Czochralski (CZ) technique serves as the predominant material for integrated circuit production. Nevertheless, the inherent complexity and pronounced nonlinearity of the CZ process render it vulnerable to instabilities, including thermal field oscillations, mechanical perturbations, and system degradation, often manifesting as critical abnormalities like crystalline diameter drift. Such deviations can disrupt the stability of the solid-liquid interface, impair the structural integrity of the ingot, and ultimately diminish manufacturing yield. To mitigate these issues, this work introduces a novel hybrid monitoring framework that synergistically combines Slow Feature Analysis (SFA) with Stacked Denoising Autoencoders (SDAE). The objective is to facilitate proactive fault identification via an intelligent system, thus circumventing the latency and subjectivity inherent in manual oversight. Within this framework, SFA is initially applied to isolate the most gradually evolving features from temporal sensor data, effectively capturing the foundational trends governing crystal growth. Subsequently, these slow features are processed and refined through a multi-layer SDAE architecture, which bolsters representational robustness and discriminative capacity via nonlinear mapping and noise suppression. Leveraging this enhanced feature set, a dual-indicator detection scheme—integrating the Squared Prediction Error (SPE) and Hotelling's <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$T^{2}$</tex> statistic—is established to reliably discern anomalous process states. Experimental results validate the efficacy of the proposed approach, confirming superior detection accuracy and operational stability, which underscores its suitability for real-world industrial deployment. Consequently, this research contributes a substantive theoretical foundation and a practical methodology toward intelligent supervision and enhanced control of Czochralski silicon crystal growth.

title: Unveiling the Nexus: Exploring the Interplay Between Low Computer Literacy and Cybercrime in Jharkhand
authors: Sumit Sachin, Ravi Kumar Burman, Abhishek Kumar, Manorama Patnaik, Suresh Pratap, Goutam Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper explores a connection between low computer literacy and cybercrime victimization in Jharkhand, which is one of the socio-economically deprived states in India. We estimated the probability of susceptibility to cybercrime as a binary outcome of logistic regression analysis based on the data that was collected by performing structured surveys conducted in 24 districts. Findings indicated that 46.2% of participants were victims, and the low level of digital skills is closely associated with a low awareness of online dangers. The predictive model achieved an accuracy of 55.5%, highlighting the need for more advanced modelling approaches. The generated results also make a great case as to why swift policy intervention is necessary in the digital area of marginalized groups resided in Jharkhand, to limit the danger of cybercrimes.

title: Use of Machine Learning Algorithms to assessment of Drinking Water Quality in Environment
authors: Sarojini Naik, Apurva Kandelkar, Richa Agnihotri, Sanju Purohit, Vikram Deokate, Vishal Borate
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Water is essential to human living; hence, maintaining its purity is vital to health. This work seeks to find the best algorithm for the statistically imputed dataset and the most accurate drinking water prediction algorithm. The dataset are use to estimate water potability using eight algorithms analyzing nine features. Our study uses hyperparameter tweaking and features engineering to increase the accuracy of numerous machine-learning models that predict drinkable water. PCA, ICA, and TSVD output are engineer to forecast water potability in diverse characteristics. Grid search is essential for optimizing and tweaking nine classification models’ hyperparameters. RF, Xgboost, LR, GNB, and Ada-Boost models are used to forecast water categorization. KNN, DT, SVR, and MLP models predict water portability. PCA, ICA, and TSVD have been use to indicate water potability. This study employed 9 characteristics and 3276 occurrences. Four metrics were calculated to evaluate categorization methods: accuracy, recall, precision, and score. This study explains predictions using Explain Like I’m Five (ELI5) and Shapash, two prominent Explainable AI (XAI) tools. The dataset was split into 80% training and 20% testing, with SMOTE, SMOTeTomek, and Near Miss approaches used for training balance. The XGB model had the highest accuracy (99.80%) in forecasting water potability, whereas the RF model had a higher accuracy is 99.40%.

title: Evaluating Deep Learning Architectures for Multi-Class Classification of Medical X-Ray Images
authors: Nora Elreshidy, Osama Gamal, Anwer Hosny, Mohamed Deshish, Mohamed Elarabie, Abdelnasser Elnasharty, Ebrahim Elsharawy, Mohamed Deshish, Mohamed Elarabie, Abdelnasser Elnasharty, Ebrahim Elsharawy
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: The demand for healthcare continues to promote the importance of intelligent systems that could effectively assist medical experts in disease diagnosis. However, discrepancies and errors are often caused by subjective interpretation by radiologists of medical X-ray images, hence creating a dire need for more accurate and automated diagnostic tools. The work Multi-Class Classification of Medical X-ray Images addresses this challenge by providing a comprehensive solution for the analysis of medical X-ray images using advanced deep learning technologies. Unlike previous studies that usually focus on a single disease, this project tackles multiple diseases simultaneously, including tuberculosis, pneumonia, and osteoarthritis, offering a more versatile and scalable diagnostic tool. The system utilizes CNNs for the detection and classification of these diseases with high accuracy. This project compares three deep learning architectures: Custom CNN, VGG-16, and ResNet on a diverse set of medical X-ray datasets, which yields an overall accuracy of 94.48% with the VGG-16 model, outperforming both Custom CNN, which has an accuracy of 92%, and ResNet, which has an accuracy of 87%. It also does pretty well in precision, recall, and F1-score, particularly for normal X-rays (F1-score: 0.99 for VGG-16) and diseases like pneumonia (F1-score: 0.93) and tuberculosis (F1-score: 0.93). The difference of this work with the related works is the multi-disease approach and the comparative evaluation of several models. Whereas most of the previous works generally dealt with single diseases, the proposed system gives a holistic approach to multiple conditions, hence finding extreme applicability in realistic clinical scenarios. Advanced preprocessing techniques that were used in this study included grayscale conversion, resizing, and normalization, accompanied by fine-tuning and augmentation of the data to ensure each category of the diseases showed very high performance. The system further outperforms other approaches by being able to handle class imbalance problems and showing much better performance on the detection of complex cases like moderate osteoarthritis. The result is saving much precious time taken by health professionals in diagnosis and also helping patients with more complete and timely information about their condition. This indeed averts much-undue anxiety among patients and improves the overall healthcare outcome. This project really shows how AI can improve the experiences of patients seeking healthcare with a reliable, efficient, and correct diagnosis capable of dealing with many diseases in a single framework.

title: Research on Spatial-variant Degree Measurement Method of Cooperative Target ISAR Imaging Plane
authors: Baofeng Guo, Siyuan Chen, Wenhua Hu, Dongfang Xue
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: When the Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) adopts the range-Doppler principle for imaging, the imaging plane will change spatially, causing the projection position of the target shooting point to change, resulting in the migration of the scattering point with more resolution, making the Image quality is degraded. This paper studies the spatial variation of the ISAR imaging plane of the cooperative target, and proposes a method to measure the spatial variation of the imaging plane. First, the ISAR imaging plane determination method of the turntable model and the translation model is given. Then, three Euler angles are introduced to describe the change degree of the space imaging plane during imaging by using the transformation of the space coordinate system. Finally, a simulation experiment is carried out to verify the correctness of the proposed method for measuring the degree of spatial variation of the imaging plane is verified. The research in this paper is of great significance to the selection of imaging arcs, and also provides a basis for the implementation of subsequent data processing and compensation algorithms.

title: The Glass Door Hybrid Remote Experiment for Programmable Devices
authors: Javier Garcia-Zubia, Giovanna Lani, Nora Gallastegi, Ander Herrero, Veronica Canivell, Luis Rodriguez-Gil
abstract: This paper addresses the design, implementation and validation of hybrid remote experiments controlled with a programmable device and implemented using virtual reality. The advantages of this approach and its practical utility are addressed in this work and the two main results are the example of hybrid remote experiment of the glass door and its evaluation from the UX point of view. The hybrid remote experiments have been implemented in the University of Deusto with the collaboration of LabsLand.

title: SGSP-MRI: Segmentation-Guided Survival Prediction from Multimodal MRI in Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
authors: Yue Long, Guoheng Huang, Lianglun Cheng, Xuanxuan Ma, Zhao Li, Xuhang Chen, Siyue Xie, Junkai Zou, Zhongkun Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) is a prevalent head-and-neck malignancy in Southern China and Southeast Asia, where accurate prognostic prediction is essential for individualized treatment. Recently, multimodal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) has shown superior performance over conventional clinical tumor-node-metastasis (TNM) staging for NPC survival prediction. However, most existing models process the entire MRI volume even though lesions occupy only a small fraction of voxels, thereby allowing background to swamp prognostic signals. Therefore, we propose Segmentation-Guided Survival Prediction from Multimodal MRI (SGSP-MRI), comprising two tightly coupled modules: Lesion Localization Segmentation Module (LLSM), based on an improved 3D U-Net, that precisely localizes the tumor and generates a high-confidence probability map to focus predictions on the lesion and peritumoral tissue; TargetGuided Cascaded Survival Module (TGCSM), which fuses this map with the original multimodal MRI in a guided early-fusion manner and applies cascaded multi-scale feature extraction to capture both fine-grained lesion morphology and global context. Extensive experiments on the Pearl River Delta Multicenter MRI Dataset for Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (PRD-NPC-MRI), our self-collected multicenter dataset ($n=1,769$), demonstrate that SGSP-MRI achieves strong, reliable prognostic performance and consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods.

title: Backstepping–Sliding Mode with Anti-Windup for Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Heave and Yaw Control under Thruster Limits
authors: Mubarak Badamasi Aremu, Abdul-Wahid A. Saif
abstract: This paper investigates depth and heading control for an underactuated autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) subject to hard-thruster limits and allocation constraints. A classical sliding-mode controller with boundary layer (SMC-sat) is compared against a backstepping sliding-mode variant (BS-SMC-sat), in which the sliding surface is shaped through a first-order backstepping step and augmented with proportional damping. Both controllers employ an identical allocation-aware anti-windup mechanism, which is a leaky back-calculation driven by the allocation shortfall Δτ returned by the thruster allocator. The BlueROV2 (Heavy) heave/yaw slice is used as a realistic benchmark with smooth multi-step reference commands. Three operating scenarios are examined: nominal, matched step disturbances, and a parameter-mismatch/tight-actuation condition (reduced thruster ceilings and perturbed inertial/damping offsets). Under nominal conditions, both controllers achieve comparable tracking performance with negligible control effort and a saturation duty of < 3%. Under disturbances, BS-SMC-sat reduces depth RMSE by ≈ 66% and heading RMSE by ≈ 65% relative to SMC-sat, while cutting yaw effort by ≈ 10%. Under parameter mismatch and tighter actuation, BS-SMC-sat remains robust, lowering RMSE by ≈31% (depth) and ≈72% (heading) with effort essentially unchanged. The results highlight that (i) allocation-driven anti-windup is essential when limits are active and (ii) modest backstepping shaping of the sliding surface markedly improves disturbance rejection and robustness without increasing control activity.

title: A Pulse Sorting Method For Linear Sliding Signals
authors: Wei Min, Xiaozhong Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The conventional signal sorting method of airborne warning radar equipment can only sort conventional signals with fixed or combined pulse repetition intervals, such as fixed pulse repetition interval and staggered pulse repetition intervals. For linear sliding signals, since the pulse repetition interval is not a fixed value or combination, traditional methods are difficult to directly sort, and it is necessary to rely on signal timing analysis to draw conclusions about pulse repetition interval variation. This paper deeply studies the characteristics of linear sliding signals, combines the actual engineering requirements, and proposes a pulse sorting method for linear sliding signals. First, it carefully analyzes linear sliding signals, clarifies that their pulse repetition intervals show a linear pattern, the first-order time-of-arrival difference is not a fixed value, but the second-order time-of-arrival difference is a fixed value, meeting the requirements of histogram statistics; then it uses parameters such as direction of arrival, radio frequency, and pulse width, and adopts the density method for three-dimensional spatial clustering to sparse the high-density pulse stream; then it uses the histogram method to estimate the possible pulse repetition interval values and the second-order difference values; finally, through sequence search, according to the theoretical stability of the pulse repetition interval difference values, it determines whether the pattern of possible pulse repetition interval values conforms to the linearly varying pattern, and obtains the exact pulse repetition interval value. Simulation experiments show that this method can successfully sort out the pulse repetition interval values and types, with an error of about 0.1 us, meeting the engineering requirements, and providing an effective means for solving the problem of pulse sorting.

title: Mobility-Aware Localization in mmWave Channel: Adaptive Hybrid Filtering Approach
authors: Abidemi Orimogunje, Kyeong-Ju Cha, Hyunwoo Park, Abdulahi A. Badrudeen, Sunwoo Kim, Dejan Vukobratovic
abstract: Precise user localization and tracking enhance energy-efficient and ultra-reliable low-latency applications in the next-generation wireless networks. In addition to computational complexity and data association challenges with Kalman-filterlocalization techniques, estimation errors tend to grow as the user’s trajectory speed increases. By exploiting mmWave signals for joint sensing and communication, our approach dispenses with additional sensors adopted in most techniques while retaining high-resolution spatial cues. We present a hybrid mobilityaware adaptive framework that selects between the Extended Kalman Filter at pedestrian speed and the Unscented Kalman Filter at vehicular speeds. The scheme mitigates data-association problem and estimation errors through adaptive noise scaling, chi-square ($\chi^{2}$) gating, and Rauch-Tung-Striebel smoothing. Evaluations using Absolute Trajectory Error, Relative Pose Error, Normalized Estimated Error Squared, and Root Mean Square Error metrics demonstrate roughly 30-60 % improvement in their respective regimes, indicating a clear advantage over existing approaches tailored to either indoor or static settings.

title: Radiation Parameter Design of FDA-MIMO Radar for Angle Deception
authors: Jiale Wang, Yuxi Zhang, Fei Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Frequency diverse array multiple-input multipleoutput (FDA-MIMO) radar, characterized by its range-angle coupling, can be employed to enhance the radar’s radio frequency (RF) stealth effectiveness. To degrade the performance of enemy passive interferometer direction finding system, this paper proposes a radiation parameter design methodology based on FDA-MIMO. By optimizing the radiation parameters of the FDAMIMO, including radiated power and frequency increment, angle deception against passive interferometer direction finding systems can be achieved. Utilizing interception range, we propose an $\mathbf{R F}$ stealth performance metric that quantifies the effectiveness of angle deception, thereby measuring the contribution of angle deception techniques to RF stealth. Simulation results show that FDA-MIMO radar direction finding can achieve a 13% angular deviation, with a 63% reduction in interception range compared to MIMO radar and a $\mathbf{1 3 \%}$ reduction compared to FDA radar. In comparison to phased array (PA) radar, conventional MIMO radar, and FDA radar, the RF stealth design based on FDAMIMO offers superior RF stealth performance.

title: Parameter-Insensitive Non-Repetitive Iterative Learning Operation Control of High-Speed Train Subject to Safety Constraints
authors: Yong Chen, Deqing Huang, Yupei Jian, Hairong Dong, Yanhui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The periodic operation pattern of high-speed train (HST) grants the immense potential for iterative learning control (ILC) approach regulating the displacement and velocity, but the non-repetitive uncertainties caused by carrying loads, random disturbances, etc., may weaken the capability of controller. Further, the typical operating situations of rail transit, e.g., station entrance/exit, slowdown sections, can compress the safety margin of HST, increasing the difficulty of precise tracking. In this paper, an adaptive ILC scheme is proposed for HST subject to the safety constraints, where the unknown iteration-varying parameters and the modeling inaccuracies are handled deliberately. Our technical route could be divided into two phases. The transformation mechanism of tracking errors, that can convert the control problem of constrained systems into an unconstrained form, is first established to guarantee that HST is always located within the safety zone. On this basis, the iterative learning controller is devised through integrating the hyperbolic tangent function and iteration-related sequence, where the neural network is leveraged to approximate the unmodeled lumps. The main innovative features lie in that, the iteration-dependent terms of control system are evolved into the parametric compensation components of controller and the iterative convergence parts, while the nested structure of control law is built to accommodate the iteration-variation of loads. As a result, the proposed approach can theoretically achieve the zero-error tracking of HST in the presence of the non-repetitive uncertainties and safety constraints, which indicates the better performance and practicability than the existing ones.

title: A Radio/INS Fusion Positioning Method
authors: Xuanyu Chang, Dong An, Mengrou Lv, Qun Wan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With the advancement of wearable technology, foot motion tracking based on Inertial Measurement Unit (IMU) has been widely adopted. However, due to the inherent cumulative error of IMU sensors, long-term positioning accuracy can be significantly compromised. However, due to the inherent cumulative error of IMU sensors, long-term positioning accuracy can be significantly compromised. To address this issue, this paper analyzes the respective characteristics of IMU-based independent positioning and radio positioning, and proposes a fusion positioning method combining IMU and radio direction-finding modules. By constructing a linear observation equation and solving the least squares solution, the complementary advantages of multi-source information are achieved. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively suppresses the error accumulation effect of the Inertial Navigation System (INS) and improves positioning accuracy, providing a reliable solution for pedestrian positioning in complex environments.

title: A UAV Target Detection and Localization Method based on Long-time Coherent Integration and RAMADMM under Multipath Environment
authors: Fan Lv, Xiaokuan Zhang, Ninghui Li, Binquan Dai, Min Xu, Denghui Li, Jiahua Xu, Zhaolong Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Radar has emerged as a pivotal technology for detecting low-altitude unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) targets owing to its all-day and all-weather operational capabilities. To address the challenges posed by low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) in multi-UAV target echoes and multipath interference within elevation beams, this study proposes a novel radar system methodology incorporating the long-time coherent integration (LTI) with reweighted atomic norm (RAM). The SNR enhancement achieved through LTI delivers dual operational benefits. First, the improved SNR enables reliable extraction of targetassociated Range-Doppler cells and subsequent echo filtering, which effectively decomposes mixed coherent/incoherent source swarms into separable neighboring coherent source groups. This decomposition directly mitigates hardware-imposed resolution limitations. Second, the SNR gain provides inherent compensation for RAM’s well-documented sensitivity to noise contamination. To overcome the computational inefficiency of conventional convex optimization (CVX) toolboxes in solving semidefinite programming (SDP) problems under RAM frameworks, we implement the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) algorithm. This adaptation achieves significant computational complexity reduction while maintaining performance fidelity comparable to conventional solvers. Simulation results demonstrate the method’s efficacy in achieving simultaneous multi-UAV target detection and high-precision localization under multipath scenario.

title: Risk-Aware Routing for a Robot in a Shared Dynamic Environment
authors: Elena Stracca, Giorgio Grioli, Lucia Pallottino, Paolo Salaris
abstract: This paper explores the challenge of optimal routing for a mobile robot navigating a dynamic and shared human environment. The primary goal is to minimize the risk of performance degradation during motion, such as delays in completing tasks due to the need for safe or acceptable human robot encounters. The problem is formulated as a graph whose edge costs become progressively known only as the robot moves through the environment. We model this problem as a Markov Decision Process (MDP), enabling an offline evaluation of the expected cost of alternative routes based on statistical information about human spatial distributions and possible observations at each intersection. This compact state representation scales linearly with the number of intersections in the map. Since the memoryless property of the MDP may induce loops during online execution, we compute an offline policy and introduce an online policy adaptation mechanism to prevent cyclic behaviors. Exten sive simulations across environments of different complexity, and using data collected from real-world experiments, demonstrate that our approach outperforms reactive and advanced state-of the-art planners in terms of either performance or scalability.

title: Joint Beamforming and Radio Resource Scheduling in UAV-RIS Aided 5G Networks
authors: Palash Kundu, Manoj Kumar Rana, Bhaskar Sardar, Tommaso Pecorella, Debashis Saha
abstract: In infrastructure-deficient environments-such as tunnels, remote military zones, and mountainous emergency sites-wireless connectivity is often disrupted by blocked Line-ofSight (LoS) and sparse coverage. This paper proposes a unified downlink framework, combining UAV-mounted base station with passive reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS), and powerdomain NOMA, to restore communication in such scenarios. We formulate a mixed-integer problem to jointly optimize UAV placement, RIS phase shifts, analog beamforming, physical resource block (PRB) allocation, and power control, balancing throughput and energy efficiency. Our proposed solution algorithm comprises two phases: (1) joint configuration of beamforming, RIS tuning, PRB scheduling and UAV location using convex approximations; and (2) power tuning via geometric programming. Under realistic channel conditions, our method achieves up to 25% higher throughput and 18% lower power consumption over an orthogonal-access baseline, and around 6% higher throughput and 7% lower power over a zero-forcing benchmark with particle swarm optimization.

title: SecureMind: Detect Online Phishing Using Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Abdullah Abdul Aziz, Abdulrahman Adel Saleh, Imad Yaser Aldoj, Mohamed Elwathig Elyass, Ziyad Hesham Dahesh, Ziyad Sayed Awad, Mostafa Shawki, Islam Hegazy
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: The proliferation of online scams, phishing, and AIgenerated fraudulent content demands robust solutions to protect users in the digital space. This paper presents SecureMind, a Machine Learning (ML) model that detects scams in various types of content, including emails, reviews, job postings, and news articles. SecureMind employs Random Forest (RF) classifiers trained on curated datasets to achieve high detection accuracy. SecureMind is implemented as a browser extension for realtime protection and it provides interpretable decision making. An interactive gamified training module is added to SecureMind to improve awareness of online phishing tactics. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the model in classifying fraudulent content and it outperforms existing solutions.

title: Spiking Decision-Making System Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jisong Yu, Chengjun Zhang, Yuhao Zhang, Jie Yang, Mohamad Sawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Neuromorphic computing emerges as a promising solution to the high energy consumption challenges associated with conventional deep learning models. In this paper, we propose an end-to-end decision-making model using spiking reinforcement learning (SRL), by leveraging the binary spikes of spiking neural networks (SNNs), it can process information in a more biologically reasonable and energy-efficient manner. Experiments show that our model achieves respectable performance on the NoCrash benchmark in CARLA simulator, and better than existing CNN-based methods in some scenarios. Furthermore, we deploy this model on a self-driving car, enhancing its application capability in the real-world.

title: Non-uniform load mechanical modelling for direct wafer bonding incorporating the pressure distribution
authors: Shirong Cai, Yunyun Sun, Shijing Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: Considering the non-uniform bonding pressure due to the downward push of the indenter, this study proposes a mechanical model to analyze the interfacial contact behavior during direct wafer bonding. The model includes a pressure location coefficient and a pressure distribution coefficient to define the distribution of the bonding pressure. Expression of wafer deflection and strain energy is derived by the thin-plate theory. The wafer bonding process with different pressure distributions is analyzed and the bonding results are predicted. The results show that the extreme value of the contact radius occurs when the pressure location coefficient is about 0.9, and the contact radius is positively correlated with the pressure distribution coefficient. In comparison to uniform pressure, alterations in contact radius at non-uniform pressures exhibit considerable discrepancies. Finally, the correctness of the proposed model is verified by finite element simulation. This study can provide a reference for the design of wafer bonding pressure distribution in industrial applications.

title: A Brain-Computer Interface with Enhanced Power Spectrum for SSVEPs Classification
authors: Chenrui Zhang, Jiang Wang, Zhengze Jin, Haitao Yu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Steady-state visual evoked potentials (SSVEPs) represent a critical component of non-invasive brain-computer interfaces (BCIs), making decoding accuracy and response latency crucial. Parameterizing electroencephalography (EEG) into periodic and aperiodic spectral components effectively dissociates rhythmic neural oscillations from arrhythmic background activity, permitting more precise delineation of oscillatory features and cognitive-state dynamics. Such methods have been widely applied in many fields. This study investigated the modulation of periodic brain activity induced by SSVEP through spectral parameterization of EEG. We propose a novel framework that integrates periodic EEG power spectra with a recurrent neural network (RNN) architecture. By eliminating the influence of aperiodic cortical activity embedded in SSVEP-related EEG signals with enhanced power spectrum, SSVEP decoding accuracy and decoding rate are improved. Our findings provide a robust computational foundation for advancing the reliability of SSVEPbased non-invasive BCIs.

title: Data Augmentation for Radar Active Jamming Signals Based on Diffusion Models
authors: Jin Qi, Yujing Liu, Chenxi Lei, Tong Cao, Qun Wan, Hongyan Su, Yaodong Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With the widespread application of deep learning in radar signal processing, the scarcity of radar signals has become one of the bottlenecks restricting the large-scale application of deep learning. To address this issue, this paper proposes a radar active jamming signal data augmentation method based on a diffusion model. By introducing the diffusion model, diverse radar jamming signals can be effectively generated, significantly enriching the training data. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves notable performance improvements in signal enhancement and model training, providing strong support for the broad application of deep learning in the radar domain.

title: Design of Low Power SRAM Cell with Increased Read and Write Performance for Various Applications
authors: Shrikant Upadhyay, Mohit Kumar, Rakesh Kumar, Nacharam Venkatesh, Sandeep Unam, K Akhita
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The 16T low-power SRAM is a specific type of memory cell designed to help minimize power consumption and maximize stability for energy-efficient uses. The new design also reduces leakage currents, take care of the read-disturb problem and provide better noise immunity by using extra transistors. Important innovations are read/write decoupling and gated feedback to maintain reliable operations at low voltages. Using high-end instruments like Cadence Virtuoso, 16T SRAM exhibits drastically decreased levels of dynamic and static power without sacrificing performance and therefore are suited for low energy consuming applications in IoT, portable devices etc. In this paper a SRAM with 16T has been analysed in term of read and write and the proposed architecture provide a very efficient output in term of transient and DC response. The main objective of low power circuit is to enhanced the performance of system by providing low power and stabilize energy for various types of applications. Such circuit will really helpful for various devices utilizing low power and helps in saving compared to traditional existing SRAM.

title: Coding with Intelligence: The Impact of AI Tools on Mobile Programming Education
authors: Álvaro Santos, José Marinho, Cristina Chuva Costa, Anabela Gomes
abstract: This study analyses student feedback on the Mobile Device Programming (MDP) course, introduced for the first time in the Bachelor of Biomedical Engineering program at the Polytechnic University of Coimbra, during the 2024/2025 academic year. The study analyzes students' utilization of Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools, such as ChatGPT, as a learning aid for their learning process, along with their perceptions of the impact of AI on education and the job market. The findings indicate that students use AI for a variety of purposes, such as understanding code, detecting errors, solving exercises and carrying out practical assignments. Most students believe that AI can personalize learning and improve pass rates in higher education, but they also recognize the risks of over-reliance on AI and the loss of critical thinking.

title: Hybrid Prior-Based Expectation Propagation Detection for MIMO-OFDM-IM Systems
authors: Jinjie Tan, Kaining Yang, Wenyue Zhou, Xiaosi Tan, Chuan Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper presents a hybrid prior-based expectation propagation (HP-EP) detection framework designed for multipleinput multiple-output orthogonal frequency division multiplexing with index modulation (MIMO-OFDM-IM). To address the inherent sparsity and complex symbol distribution in MIMO-OFDMIM systems, the proposed detector employs a hybrid prior that combines sparse activation patterns with continuous constellation points. By iteratively refining the posterior distributions using EP, the proposed method significantly reduces detection complexity while preserving high detection accuracy. Numerical simulations validate that the proposed HP-EP detector delivers substantial improvements in bit error rate (BER) performance and offers a significant reduction in computational overhead compared to conventional detection techniques.

title: Federated Learning for Early Parkinson's Diagnosis: Deep Learning with Vocal Frequency Features
authors: Aayushi Agarwal, Ishank Goel, Navneet Prakash, Parth Bhaiya, Sumathi Gokulanathan, Aparna Mohanty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) is a progressive neurode-generative disorder that benefits from early detection for optimal patient management. Traditional centralized machine learning approaches to PD detection raise concerns around patient privacy and data security, especially when handling sensitive medical data such as voice recordings. This paper presents a federated learning-based model and Neural Network Architectures designed for early detection of PD using sound data, preserving data privacy by training across distributed devices rather than a central repository. By leveraging acoustic features known to correlate with early PD symptoms, such as vocal tremor, pitch variation, and articulation changes, our model captures these early indicators without compromising patient confidentiality. We evaluate the performance of the model across diverse datasets and show its potential to achieve accurate, privacy-preserving early diagnosis. The results indicate that federated learning is a viable approach for healthcare applications where data privacy is paramount, laying a foundation for non-invasive, scalable, and secure PD screening tools.

title: Improving the accuracy of BOFDA sensors by suppressing the secondary interaction artifacts
authors: R. Vallifuoco, L. Zeni, A. Minardo
abstract: In this paper, we propose and demonstrate a novel method to suppress the secondary interaction artifacts affecting Brillouin Optical Frequency Domain Analysis (BOFDA) sensors. These artifacts, produced by the sidebands of the acoustic wave involved in the stimulated Brillouin scattering process, add two extra components in the baseband transfer function (TF) of the fiber under test (FUT), giving rise to systematic errors in the temperature/strain profile reconstruction. The proposed method is based on an approximate measurement of the spurious term affecting the BOFDA measurements, and its subsequent subtraction from the acquired data. The accuracy of the method is first verified numerically, and then through a number of experiments carried out over properly prepared FUTs.

title: Diversity-Driven Model Ensemble Adaptive Trust Region Policy Optimization_supp1-3650850.pdf
authors: Jie Lu
abstract: Model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL) aims to promote sample efficiency and reduce the number of interactions with the true environment, via learning an environment dynamic model, compared with model-free reinforcement learning (MFRL). However, the success of MBRL heavily relies on two key aspects: model learning and planning. The former refers to learning an accurate model, and the latter aims to improve the behavior policy. In this article, we investigate these two aspects further with model ensemble learning. We design a deep residual attention U-Net (RauNet) with fewer neurons (or weights) than the widely used shallow neural network as our base models and further apply the Hilbert–Schmidt independence criterion (HSIC) as a regularization term to pursue model diversity explicitly for the model ensemble. Furthermore, we propose an adaptive trust region policy optimization (TRPO), in which the parametric Rényi alpha divergence substitutes for the Kullback–Leibler (KL) divergence for measuring the difference between two successive policies, and the alpha value can be adaptively adjusted during TRPO training iterations. This method is called diversity-driven model ensemble adaptive TRPO, or simply diversity-driven model ensemble adaptive trust region policy optimization. Our detailed experiments on six benchmark environments show that our proposed approach is optimal, compared with five state-of-the-art RL techniques.

title: AI-Driven Tool Supporting Algorithmic Thinking in Programming Education
authors: Grzegorz Madejski, Ryszard Madejski, Wlodek J. Kulesza
abstract: Understanding program structure, control flow, and problem decomposition is essential in programming education, but many students find algorithmic thinking challenging. Con-ventional educational approaches frequently prioritize syntax at the expense of logical reasoning and provide minimal per-sonalized feedback. This paper outlines the design and initial assessment of FlowBro, an AI-driven educational tool intended to enhance algorithmic thinking in early programming education. The tool integrates a flowchart visualization, sequential code simulation, and an intelligent assistant that offers contextual hints, debugging tips, and educational support while maintaining a focus on minimalism by not disclosing complete solutions. The system enables students to engage with Python code, follow its execution, and obtain tailored assistance aligned with their specific objectives. A qualitative evaluation with educators in the field revealed the tool's potential advantages, especially in large classes and self-directed learning contexts, while also pointing out challenges concerning the reliability of AI feedback and the necessity for more extensive testing. This study presents a streamlined framework for merging AI with visual learning in programming education, while also suggesting pathways for its future enhancement and empirical testing.
