title: Variational Autoencoder-Based High-Dimensional Expensive Evolutionary Algorithm
authors: Yehang Chen, Xinyue Li, Yu Zhang, Wang Hu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Evolutionary algorithms (EAs) are increasingly applied across various engineering domains. However, numerous challenges, such as low search precision and slow convergence, are imposed on traditional EAs due to high-dimensional expensive optimization problems (HEOPs) in the real world. To address these issues, a surrogate-assisted evolutionary algorithm based on variational autoencoder (SAEA-VAE) is proposed in this paper, whose search phase is divided into global search and local search to balance exploration and exploitation. Specifically, a VAE-based dimensionality reduction technique is employed in global search to effectively reduce the search space dimensionality and maintain solution consistency between the latent and original spaces. Experimental evaluations on seven benchmark HEOPs with dimensions ranging from 50 to 200 demonstrate that SAEA-VAE outperforms other benchmark algorithms in terms of both optimization performance and computational efficiency. Ablation studies confirm the effectiveness of the VAE-based dimensionality reduction, while parameter sensitivity analysis further validates the robustness of SAEA-VAE.

title: LLM-Powered Social Robots for an Indoor Navigation Assistant
authors: Gonçalo Carnaz, Esmeralda Faria, Paulo Menezes
abstract: Social robots are increasingly being deployed in indoor environments such as hospitals or malls, to assist with navigation and give information related to indoor spaces. Therefore, these social robots need to understand the human questions using a natural language understanding and generation, making them suitable for enhancing social robots' interaction capabilities, also, the need to understand the indoor environments that need to be mapped. Large language models can be useful for understanding the semantics associated with questions asked by users and the answers generated by the social robot. This paper explores the integration of LLMs into social robots for indoor location navigation. We describe the architecture of our LLM-powered social robot, its capabilities, and challenges related to real-time processing, user adaptation, and accuracy. A pilot study evaluates the robot's efficiency in guiding 20 users and responding to queries in a indoor environment.

title: Brain-Machine Interface Decoding Using Optimized Recurrent Spiking Neural Networks on MCU
authors: Eraraya Morenzo Muten, Nur Ahmadi, Timothy G. Constandinou, Trio Adiono
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Brain-machine interfaces (BMIs) offer a promising solution for restoring motor function in individuals with severe disabilities such as tetraplegia. Although artificial neural network (ANN) decoders have achieved high decoding accuracy, their large memory footprint and high computational demands limit their applicability in implantable or embedded BMI systems. Spiking neural networks (SNNs), inspired by biological neurons, provide a more efficient alternative while maintaining comparable performance. In this study, we proposed an optimized recurrent spiking neural network (RSNN) decoder for real-time neural signal decoding and deploy it on a resource-constrained ESP32-based microcontroller unit (MCU). The proposed RSNN decoder achieved improvement of $17.92 \%$ in coefficient of determination ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$), $\mathbf{7. 9 8 \%}$ in correlation coefficient (CC), and $\mathbf{2 5. 4 5 \%}$ in root mean squared error (RMSE) compared to a baseline ANN decoder. It also delivered a $15.96 \times$ speed-up while having $5.47 \%$ less memory footprint on the same MCU platform. These results demonstrate the potential of optimized RSNN for enabling energy-efficient, real-time BMI decoding on low-power embedded hardware.

title: Power Optimization of Urban Logistics with Autonomous Delivery Robots
authors: Irene Izco, Adrian Serrano, Javier Faulin
abstract: Adoption of autonomous vehicles is growing globally, and autonomous delivery robots are a promising choice for the last-mile delivery in place of conventional vehicles. Delivery companies are likely to invest in technology that improves delivery productivity as customer expectations of delivery times continue to rise and e-commerce sales continue to accelerate. This work relies on a simulation-optimization approach to determine the optimal number of the robot hubs to serve a given delivery order demand. The optimization aims at minimizing facility set up costs, operational costs and robot energy consumption to allocate the customer demands to facilities and dimension the robot fleet to deliver packages efficiently. The simulation model reproduces the parcel delivery and the robot battery consumption and charging cycles.

title: A Prognostic Approach to Alleviate Range Anxiety for E -Vehicles using Artificial Intelligence
authors: Kodali Sai Venkat, Karumulla Kaushik Reddy, S Prayla Shyry, Akash Antony J, Abishek D G
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The surge in global transportation demands, driven by urbanization and trade, has heightened the environmental toll of fossil fuel mobility. Electric vehicles (EVs) present a sustainable alternative by reducing emissions, noise, and costs. Yet, range anxiety, the fear of battery depletion—remains a key barrier to EV adoption. This study introduces a data-driven AI framework to alleviate range anxiety through accurate prediction of remaining EV range via precise estimation of state of charge (SOC) and state of energy (SOE). Using real-world datasets that include speed, power usage, road gradient, environmental factors, and driving behavior, the system employs a multilayered machine learning model to capture complex relationships and enhance prediction accuracy. Hierarchical modeling integrates SOC and SOE estimates into range forecasting, supported by preprocessing steps like normalization and outlier removal. Validation on real-world EV trip data shows a substantial drop in prediction error, with SOC MAE at 5.96 and validation loss falling from 25.0 to 7.0 over 175 epochs. The MLP model achieves a low MAE of 5.0 in range estimation, outperforming other models. This robust AI framework can boost EV user confidence, improve energy planning, and support the transition to sustainable transport.

title: Dual-Branch ConvNeXt with Attention-Based Fusion for Building Damage Detection
authors: Prativa Das, Nitin Kumar Singh, Pinky Bai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Building damage detection is crucial for post-disaster assessment and relief planning. Damage detection tasks have seen considerable enhancement through the application of deep learning techniques, notably convolutional neural networks (CNNs). This study presents a unique dual-branch ConvNeXt model enhanced with an Attention-Based Fusion (ABF) mechanism and a Cross-Attention Module (CAM) for damage assessment using the xBD dataset. Our method utilizes a two-stream architecture, where pre-disaster and post-disaster images are processed independently through ConvNeXt encoders, and their feature representations are refined and merged using an attention-based fusion mechanism. The Cross-Attention Module (CAM) is introduced to model the interdependencies between pre- and post-disaster images, effectively capturing structural differences while preserving unchanged regions. By learning spatial and temporal patterns jointly, this method enhances classification precision for damaged structures. We evaluate our method on the xBD dataset and achieve superior performance compared to existing CNN-based architectures. Our model achieves F1<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">b</inf> of 89.3%, IoU of 68.5%, and F1<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> of 80.5%, outperforming BDANet and SiamixFormer by approximately 2% and 1.4% respectively.

title: AI Driven Modeling of Scope 3 Carbon Emissions for Sustainable University Transportation
authors: Manju Rani, Bhavesh Vyas, Vineet Dahiya, Puja Acharya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The rapid urbanization and increasing demand for transportation in academic institutions contribute significantly to carbon emissions, necessitating sustainable mitigation strategies. This study systematically records annual bus-wise fuel consumption and kilometre-wise route mapping for students commuting to K.R. Mangalam University during the 2022–23 academic session. Using real-time data, carbon emissions were calculated, and artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) models, including Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average (ARIMA) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, were employed for predictive analysis. Comparative analysis of carbon emissions from bus vehicle models was performed, leveraging regression-based modeling to assess CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> levels. The results indicate that deep learning-based LSTM models outperform ARIMA in long-term forecasting, providing more accurate insights into emission trends. The study proposes multiple strategic recommendations to the university management for reducing carbon footprints, including policy reforms, sustainable transportation alternatives, and afforestation initiatives. The work highlights the institution’s role in promoting environmental consciousness, fostering carbon-conscious practices, and achieving net-zero emissions. The study also outcome with student-incubated project on route optimization and real-time student tracking to enhance transportation efficiency. Discussing the technical challenges and shifting towards AI-driven sustainable solutions in academia can work as a scalable model applicable to broader industrial sectors, including logistics, FMCG, and mining, for efficient environmental management.

title: Image Encryption Using Circular-Shifting, Permutation Expansions and XOR
authors: Ayman M. Abdalla, Qasem H. Makki, Ahmad A. Mazhar
abstract: With the rapid advancement of technology and the growing number of Internet users, the secure transmission of data, including images, videos, text, and audio, has become increasingly critical. In particular, image protection is essential to ensure confidentiality and integrity. Researchers have developed various encryption algorithms to address this challenge. This paper introduces a novel lossless image encryption algorithm for both RGB and grayscale images. The proposed approach integrates confusion and diffusion mechanisms through permutation expansions and circular transformation, along with XOR, BitXOR, and flipping operations. Additionally, it enhances security by generating highly sensitive keys with a large key space. Experimental implementation and analysis using various quality metrics confirm the effectiveness of the Proposed Algorithm.

title: An Ant Colony System Approach with Local Search for Multiobjective Logistics Scheduling
authors: Jiejing Wei, Zong-Gan Chen, Yuncheng Jiang, Jun Zhang, Zhi-Hui Zhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Logistics scheduling arranges the delivery routes of employees, which can improve delivery efficiency. However, workload fairness is not sufficiently considered in existing research. In this article, a multiobjective logistics scheduling model is formulated, which simultaneously optimizes the total length of delivery routes and the fairness of workload distribution among delivery employees. In addition, real-world traffic data is incorporated into the proposed model to enhance its practicality. To deal with the proposed model, an ant colony system approach with local search (ACS-LS) is proposed. The ants in ACSLS schedule the delivery routes of each employee and mainly optimize the total length of delivery routes. An archive is used to store the nondominated solutions found during the search process. To balance the working time among employees and optimize workload fairness, a local search strategy is designed in ACS-LS to adjust the assigned customers among delivery employees. 28 instances are constructed based on real-world traffic data in Guangzhou, China and the experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed ACS-LS approach.

title: Descriptor: Norwegian Electricity in Geographic Dataset (NoreGeo)
authors: SHILIANG ZHANG, SABITA MAHARJAN, KAI STRUNZ, JAN CHRISTIAN BRYNE
abstract: Geographic data is vital in understanding, analyzing, and contextualizing energy usage at the regional level within electricity systems. While geospatial visualizations of electricity infrastructure and distributions of production and consumption are available from governmental and third-party sources, these sources are often disparate, and compatible geographic datasets remain scarce. In this paper, we present a comprehensive geographic dataset representing the electricity system in Norway. We collect data from multiple authoritative sources, process it into widely accepted formats, and generate interactive maps based on this data. Our dataset includes information for each municipality in Norway for the year 2024, encompassing electricity infrastructure, consumption, renewable and conventional production, main power grid topology, relevant natural resources, and population demographics. This work results in a formatted geographic dataset that integrates diverse informational resources, along with openly released interactive maps. We anticipate that our dataset will alleviate software incompatibilities in data retrieval, and facilitate joint analyses on regional electricity system for energy researchers, stakeholders, and developers.

title: An alternating descent weighted least squares algorithm using single snapshot for off-grid DOA estimation
authors: Shuyu Li, Yongbo Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Recently, iterative adaptive approach (IAA) has received enthusiastic attention as a super-resolution direction of arrival (DOA) estimation algorithm based on the weighted least squares (WLS). However, this algorithm is computationally intensive and can only estimate the targets located on the predefined discrete angular grids. As a result, this paper proposes an alternating descent weighted least squares (ADWLS) algorithm to estimate the angles of off-grid targets. Under the assumption of spatial sparsity, this algorithm utilizes Taylor expansion to approximate the real steering vectors of the offgrid targets. Subsequently, using the weighted least squares as the cost function, the sparse offsets of the targets and the reconstructed dictionary matrix are alternately updated at each iteration. Afterwards, the real angles of the on-grid or off-grid targets are accurately estimated by several iterations until convergence. Compared with IAA, the novel proposed algorithm ADWLS has less computational complexity and can accurately estimate the DOAs that mismatch the predefined discrete angular grids. The simulation results show that the estimation performance of the proposed algorithm is better under certain circumstances, especially compelling in the cases of single snapshot and correlated sources.

title: Learning Platform with Remote Labs Guided by an Intelligent Conversational Agent
authors: Unai Hernandez-Jayo, Mikel Pintado, Javier Garcia-Zubia, Diego Lopez-de-Ipina, Diego Casado-Mansilla
abstract: This work presents the ongoing development of a learning environment for STEM disciplines, supervised by an AI-based conversational agent. In this framework, once the teacher has defined the learning scenario-consisting of different phases and activities-the student can follow a supervised learning path guided by an intelligent agent. This agent dynamically adapts the learning path based on the student's performance throughout the various proposed activities. Additionally, this platform allows students to interact with remote and virtual laboratories integrated within the system.

title: Homonoia: Reinventing underutilized cross-level cache resource using reinforcement learning
authors: Chao Fu, Li Wan, Yufan Jia, Zhiyuan Zhang, Kanheng Jiang, Jun Han
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems
abstract: On-chip cache resources play a crucial role in determining the performance of multi-core processors. However, certain cache resources of multi-core processors may be underutilized in a few scenarios. The rigid cache hierarchy poses an obstacle to leveraging these underutilized cache resources to benefit cache-sensitive applications. Additionally, modern processor designs tend to deepen cache levels, and share out last-level cache (LLC) capacity to individual upstream caches, resulting in fewer available LLC resources per core and potentially more underutilized cache resources. To tackle this challenge, we introduce Homonoia, a technique that reinvents underutilized cache resources, disregarding inherent constraints of cache hierarchies, and expands LLC capacity with these resources for cache-sensitive applications. The key idea of Homonoia is to allow LLC evictions with high reusability to be deposited in on-chip caches instead of being directly written back to off-chip memory. Moreover, Homonoia incorporates a reinforcement learning-based predictor to accurately forecast the reusability of LLC evictions under diverse workload scenarios. A novel coherence protocol feature called DEPOSIT is proposed to ensure the efficiency of depositing behavior and transparency to software. Our experimental results demonstrate that Homonoia significantly improves the performance of baseline multi-core processors by an average of 20% in several cache-sensitive applications.

title: Privacy-Preserving Energy Forecasting in 5G+ Smart Grids Using PSI-Constrained LSTM Networks
authors: Mostofa Hossain, Iqra Batool, Mostafa M. Fouda, Zubair M. Fadlullah
abstract: The rapid deployment of Internet of Things (IoT)enabled smart meters over 5 G networks has enabled advanced load forecasting and real-time energy efficiency optimization in smart grids. However, fine-grained smart meter data introduces substantial privacy risks when shared across stakeholders. This paper proposes a privacy-preserving, energy-efficient forecasting framework that combines Private Set Intersection (PSI) protocols with dual-output LSTM networks for collaborative modeling without full data disclosure. We simulate PSI-filtered intersections between smart meters for constrained data sharing across distributed IoT nodes. Using the UMass Smart dataset with energy-efficiency features, we evaluate the PSI-induced data reduction’s impact on forecasting and energy-optimization performance. Results show that the proposed method outperforms existing privacy-preserving approaches while achieving competitive energy-efficiency optimization, supporting secure collaborative energy analytics in 5G+ smart grid infrastructures.

title: Adaptive Multimodal AI with Low Resource and Fair Evaluation
authors: Sabeen Masood, Amna Ayub, Syed Saqib Raza Rizvi, Farah Haneef
abstract: This study presents an adaptive multimodal AI framework designed to handle text, image, and language data across various natural language processing (NLP) tasks. The framework tackles two important issues: demographic justice and low-resource adaptation. Using five benchmark datasets. i.e., Hateful Memes for hate speech detection, Multi30K for multilingual captioning, FairFace for demographic analysis, FLORES-200 for English-Swahili translation and WIT for image-text retrieval. The system achieves high performance by incorporating pretrained models such as BERT, CLIP, and MarianMT into a parameter-efficient architecture. Experimental results demonstrate notable improvements over baseline methods: a 7.1% higher Recall@10 for retrieval tasks, a 5.8 BLEU point improvement in low-resource translation, and a 6.1% increase in hate speech detection accuracy. Interestingly, the disparity in accuracy between Black and White demographic subgroups drops from 12.3% to 4.7%. This shows that a single and efficient model can handle many tasks with fairness and generalization, which helps to move closer to building responsible and inclusive AI systems.

title: Artificial Intelligence in Clinical Applications of Helicobacter pylori: A Review
authors: Swarag Reddy Pingili, Leo Thomas Ramos, Nidia Payahuala-Díaz, Elizabeth Diaz, Francklin Rivas-Echeverría, Edmundo Casas
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Helicobacter pylori infection remains a globally prevalent condition linked to peptic ulcers and gastric cancer, necessitating timely and accurate diagnosis. This review analyses a set of relevant studies that apply artificial intelligence methods to the detection and management of H. pylori. For each study, we examined key aspects including the AI technique employed, the type of input data used, reported performance, and stated limitations. We found that most approaches focused on early detection, particularly through medical imaging and deep learning models. While many systems achieved accuracy comparable to that of clinical experts, limitations were frequent, including small sample sizes, lack of external validation, and reduced effectiveness in post-eradication cases. Only a minority of works addressed explainability or assessed model performance across diverse populations. These findings reveal both the promise and the current barriers of AI-based tools for H. pylori, emphasizing the need for more robust, generalizable, and interpretable solutions.

title: A Greedy Initialization-Based Genetic Algorithm for Sampling Optimization
authors: Weirong Sun, Yueao Zhao, Ying Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, a greedy initialization-based genetic algorithm is proposed for unit-norm tight frame sampling design in spherical near-field measurements. Since the optimization criterion with respect to sampling positions constitutes a nonconvex problem, a two-stage optimization strategy is employed. First, a recursive formulation of the objective function is derived, enabling the iterative selection of sampling positions that minimize the incremental increase in the cost function. This leads to a greedy yet effective selection of near-optimal sampling locations. The sampling positions obtained from the greedy algorithm are then used to initialize the population of a genetic algorithm, which further refines the sampling configuration through global optimization. Numerical experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method, showing improved performance compared to the approach initialized using rank-revealing QR factorization.

title: Fine-Tuning Pre-trained Transformer-Based Models for Sentence-Level Medical Text Classification
authors: Tamanna Kaiser, Dan Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: This paper presents the development of sentence-level medical text classifiers by fine-tuning eight pre-trained transformer-based models on the PubMed 20k RCT dataset. The models span both general-purpose and biomedical-specific architectures. To enhance performance and address class imbalance, a composite loss function combining cross-entropy, focal loss, and dice loss was applied during training. The fine-tuned models were trained on PubMed 20k RCT and then applied, without further adaptation, to the MTSamples dataset using balanced and imbalanced test subsets. ClinicalBERT achieved the highest results, reaching 97.15% accuracy and 96.93% F1-score on PubMed 20k RCT, 95.20% accuracy and 95.10% F1-score on the balanced MTSamples subset, and 91.80% accuracy and 90.60% F1-score on the imbalanced subset, indicating strong transferability across structured and unstructured medical texts. These outcomes highlight the effectiveness of domain-specific fine-tuning combined with optimized training strategies in building accurate and adaptable medical sentence classifiers.

title: Distributionally Robust GMM Steering under Wasserstein Ambiguity Sets
authors: Yutang Li, Songzhou Li, Di Zhou, Zhen He
abstract: This letter addresses the problem of steering a discrete-time linear system from an initial Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) distribution, where the component weights are uncertain, to a prescribed terminal Gaussian distribution. We formulate a distributionally robust optimal control (DRO) problem by modeling the weight uncertainty via a Wasserstein-type ambiguity set. The resulting non-convex min-max problem is shown to be equivalently transformed into a tractable, deterministic Semidefinite Program (SDP) by leveraging duality theory and convex lifting techniques. The standard nominal (non-robust) controller can fail to satisfy terminal constraints under plausible worst-case weight distributions within the ambiguity set. In contrast, the proposed DRO controller successfully guarantees constraint satisfaction in these scenarios, demonstrating its improved robustness.

title: Frequency Control and Optimal Power Sharing in Combined Power and Heating Networks with Heat Pumps
authors: Xin Qin, Ioannis Lesta
abstract: Heat pumps have the capability for fast adjustments in power consumption with potential connections to large heating inertia district heating networks, and are thus a very impor tant resource for providing frequency support in low-inertia power systems. Nevertheless, the coupling of power networks with district heating systems renders the underlying dynamics much more involved. It is therefore important to ensure that system stability and appropriate power sharing are maintained. In this paper, we consider the problem of leveraging district heating systems as ancillary services for primary frequency control in power networks via heat pumps. We propose a novel power sharing scheme for heating systems based on the average temperature. This enables an optimal power allocation among diverse energy sources without requiring load disturbance information. We then discuss two approaches for heating systems to contribute to frequency regulation in power networks. We show that both approaches ensure stability in the combined heat and power network and facilitate optimal power allocation among the different energy sources. We also discuss how various generation dynamics can be incorporated into our framework with guaranteed stability and optimality. Finally, we conduct simulations that demonstrate various tradeoffs in the transient response and the practical potential of the proposed approaches.

title: Deep Recognition of Group Behavior in Crowded Scenes Using ResNet-STAN Fusion
authors: Saleha Kamal, Ahmad Jalal
abstract: Understanding collective group behavior in crowded environments is essential for surveillance, crowd management, and human-computer interaction applications. Group activity recognition focuses on modeling the interactions and coordinated actions among multiple individuals, going beyond isolated person-level analysis to capture socially aware, contextrich patterns. Accurate recognition of collective group activities in crowded scenes remains a critical challenge in computer vision due to complex inter-person interactions and occlusions. This work proposes an integrated framework that emphasizes socially aware modeling by combining advanced techniques for segmentation, feature extraction, and deep learning-based temporal attention mechanisms. A diverse set of handcrafted appearance features; including ORB, Texton, ridge patterns, and local binary patterns-is extracted from segmented silhouettes to enrich descriptive capacity. Dimensionality reduction is performed using t-distributed stochastic neighbor embedding (t-SNE), preserving local data structures for efficient representation. Classification is achieved through a hybrid model that integrates a ResNet backbone with a SpatialTemporal Attention Network, enabling effective modeling of inter-person dependencies and collective group behaviors over time. Experimental evaluation on the Collective Activity Dataset (CAD) demonstrates the efficacy of the proposed framework, achieving an overall recognition accuracy of 89.60 %, underscoring its suitability for real-world group activity analysis tasks.

title: LatentTAS: Constrained Transformer Architecture Search Via Surrogate-Driven Latent Evolution
authors: Lei Liu, Gary G. Yen, Zhenan He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: In practical applications, Transformer architectures have demonstrated remarkable performance in various computer vision tasks, yet their structural design often faces significant challenges such as complex, discrete search space and stringent resource constraints, which inadvertently limit their flexible deployment across diverse hardware platforms and usage scenarios. To address these two issues, this paper proposes a constraint-aware Transformer Architecture Search framework in latent space, named LatentTAS, that leverages a variational autoencoder (VAE) to map discrete architectures into a continuous latent space. A multi-objective surrogate is introduced to jointly predict the feasibility, performance indicator, and computational complexity of latent representations. To further ensure that the search converges efficiently within the feasible range, a dynamic feasibility threshold mechanism is designed, providing adaptive constraint control during both generation and selection stages in the evolutionary search. Comprehensive experiments conducted on the ImageNet under different parameter budgets demonstrate that the proposed method can consistently discover competitive and efficient Transformer architectures while adhering to resource constraints, outperforming various representative handcrafted and automated baselines. Overall, this work presents a new perspective for modeling discrete structures within a latent space and introduces a constraint-aware evolutionary search paradigm, laying a methodological foundation for practical and deployable neural architecture automation.

title: DATSIL: Domain Adaptation in Tensor Subspace for Wi-Fi-based Indoor Localization
authors: Kang Tan, Zhijie Sun, Yimao Sun, Ce Zhu, Yipeng Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Wi-Fi channel state information (CSI) enables lowcost, privacy-preserving indoor localization, but current solutions’ accuracy drops with temporal and environmental changes, especially in single access point (AP) setups. This is mainly because CSI is underutilized when treating the amplitude and phase separately or using simple fusion methods, such as concatenation, which causes cross-mode information loss. Existing domain adaptation techniques to address such drifts often assume multi-AP setups or require fine-tuning in the target domain, further widening the gap. This paper introduces DATSIL, a source-only, single-AP indoor localization framework that combines Wi-Fi CSI amplitude and phase into compact tensor fingerprints, learns multilinear projections, and aligns features before support vector regression. Using commodity hardware, this paper also contributes a real-world dataset: two collection campaigns in a large, cluttered office six months apart with significant layout changes. On this dataset, DATSIL achieves a mean localization error of 1.80 m and $8-14 \%$ improvement over the strongest baselines, with tighter low-error tails in the cumulative error distribution. Collectively, DATSIL offers a robust, low-maintenance solution for single-AP deployment in real environments.

title: AI-Powered Smart Dustbin for Waste Segregation Using CNN
authors: Aditya Mukati, Nehal Mantri, Dhruv Gupta, Kirankumar Manivannan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: With the rise of urbanisation and industrialisation, waste management has become a major issue, leading to environmental hazards. This paper presents a deep learning-based smart dustbin that classifies waste into two categories: biodegradable and non-biodegradable, using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The system integrates a Raspberry Pi, an ultrasonic sensor, a camera module, and a servo motor to automate the classification process. A pretrained ResNet50 model is fine-tuned using a dataset of 190k+ images of biodegradable and non-biodegradable waste, which takes the images captured by the camera and classifies the waste accordingly. Our model achieved an accuracy of 98.93% on validation samples. If the detected waste is biodegradable, the dustbin lid moves left; otherwise, it moves right for non-biodegradable waste. Our work aims to increase the efficiency of waste management.

title: An Efficient Index-Based Source Task Selection Approach for Large-Scale Evolutionary Sequential Transfer Optimization
authors: Jiawei Zhao, Xuefeng Chen, Liang Feng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: As historical task repositories expand and new optimization requests continuously arrive in practical scenarios, one-to-one similarity evaluation becomes a major bottleneck in Evolutionary Sequential Transfer Optimization (ESTO). To address this, we propose an index-based transfer optimization framework that enables fast and scalable source task selection by combining hierarchical feature-based indexing with fine-grained similarity evaluation. Experiments on the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) demonstrate that the proposed method offers over an order-of-magnitude reduction in similarity evaluation overhead while preserving optimization performance, offering a practical solution for scalable task reuse in dynamic, large-scale environments.

title: Exploring Mathematical Background in Spectrum Graph Coloring for Channel Allocation in Wireless Communication Networks
authors: Varsha Gautam, Riddhima Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Reducing co-channel interference in wireless networks necessitates efficient channel assignment. If conflicting network nodes are divided into orthogonal channels, it is easy to lessen the disruption between them. Selecting the optimum channel assignment is believed to be a non-linear problem with potential practical implementation issues, such as control signaling issues and significant computing costs. To address the issue of channel allocation in these networks, graph theory is applied to analyze the features of the wireless channel from a macro viewpoint and applies the graph coloring in wireless channel allocation from a microscopic perspective. In our study spectrum coloring induced by threshold issue fixes the number of colors available and seeks to minimize the disruption threshold for a given spectrum. On the other hand, the goal of spectrum coloring induced by chromatic number problem is to reduce the number of colours that can be used to respect a given threshold.

title: Transient-Simulation-Driven Model Order Reduction for Efficient Periodic Steady-State Analysis via Shooting Method
authors: Germin Ghaly, Emad Gad, Michel S. Nakhla
publish: IEEE Transactions on Components, Packaging and Manufacturing Technology
abstract: This paper presents an efficient method for analyzing the periodic steady-state of non-linear circuits via shooting method. Conventional Newton Shooting Method (NSM) suffers from expensive computational complexity and intensive memory usage when dealing with large-scale circuits. The proposed technique integrates Model Order Reduction (MOR) into the NSM framework, creating a smaller, surrogate model that leads to substantial reduction in both CPU time and memory consumption. The proposed method also demonstrates the advantages of using a least squares Petrov-Galerkin (LSPG) projection against the standard Galerkin projection (GP). The resulting ROM, once generated, can be reused for different input stimuli, not limited to the nominal input, enabling exploration of stimulus variations. To further alleviate computational overhead proportional to the full-order model size, the approach leverages hyper-reduction via Interpolatory Proper Orthogonal Decomposition (IPOD). The method is validated through several numerical examples, showcasing its accuracy, efficiency, and capability to handle different input stimuli with a single reduced model.

title: Enhancing Business Education Through AI-Powered Teaching Innovations in Quantitative Subjects Using Neural Architecture Search with Self-Attention
authors: Maharajan K, Anuradha Parasar, Poonam Khurana, RVS Praveen, Sathiyanathan S, Chetna Priti
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Recent entrepreneurship education advancements include case studies, guest speakers, business plan development, simulations and games, team-based discussions, seminars, problem-solving, individual and role-playing, group projects, lectures, and guest lecturers. Despite student-centered approaches that encourage active participation, lectures are generally teacher-centered. The facts show that occasionally a variety of strategies is needed. DMs K-means clustering method is used to develop an analytical model for assessing entrepreneurship education initiatives because making judgements in unexpected business environments, especially functional domains, is difficult. The study found no effective Neural Architecture Search (NAS) technique for attention-based models. NASSA, an attention-based network Neural Architecture Search technique, solves this. For better performance, NASSA eliminates undefined components like attention layers and cells from attention-based models. The NASSA framework greatly improves attention-based architectural search in trials. The model outperforms previous attention-based neural network optimization methods with 97.33% accuracy. Entrepreneurship programs should use many training methods to tackle business unknowns, according to the report. NASSA improves attention-based networks by searching neural architectures systematically. They foster education and DL research and development.

title: A Circular Multipath Cell-Based Measurement Platform for Characterizing Atmospheric Propagation Attenuation in the Terahertz Band
authors: Seok Yoon, Tae-Hong Kim, Jun-Oh An
publish: IEEE Transactions on Terahertz Science and Technology
abstract: This paper proposes a closed experimental platform based on a Circular Multipath Cell (CMC) to quantitatively measure terahertz (THz) atmospheric attenuation characteristics under various environmental conditions. The proposed system realizes a long propagation path of 16.61 m through 26 internal reflections within a compact chamber, thereby simultaneously overcoming the spatial constraints of existing long-path experiments and the sensitivity limitations of small cells. Measurement results in the 330–490 GHz band under precisely controlled relative humidity (20–90%, ±0.5%) showed high agreement with the ITU-R P.676-13 model and demonstrated that stable measurements are possible even at high attenuation levels, which are difficult to implement in open environments. With its structural flexibility and precise environmental control capabilities, the CMC platform is expected to serve as a key tool for future 6G channel modeling and atmospheric propagation research.

title: Compound Jamming Recognition based on Modified Detection Transformer
authors: Zilu Guo, Xiaodong Han, Jin He, Ting Shu, Jinyu Yang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Jamming signal recognition is a crucial aspect of radar anti-jamming technology. In practice, radar systems often encounter highly complex environments involving multiple jamming sources. This paper addresses the problem of compound jamming recognition and proposes a modified end-to-end model based on the Detection Transformer (DETR). The enhanced model incorporates multi-scale feature fusion, allowing for precise identification and localization of individual jamming sources in the time-frequency domain. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model consistently outperforms existing methods under various jamming-to-noise ratio (JNR) conditions.

title: Advancing IoT Security with Temporal-Based Swin Transformer and LSTM: A Hybrid Model for Balanced and Accurate Intrusion Detection
authors: Chandrakanth Reddy Borra, Ramya Vani Rayala, Piyush Kumar Pareek, Srinivas Cheekati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The fast proliferation of smart things heightens cybersecurity concerns, which are already high due to prevalence besides severity of assaults. Internet of Things (IoT) device security is already a major concern because to large amounts of data produced by communication between devices besides the presence of imbalanced data from network traffic. There is hope that AI technologies, chiefly machine learning and deep learning, might identify and counteract these security risks to IoT networks. For the purpose of making predictions, this research suggests creating a TSTN, or Temporal-based Swin Transformer Network. The LSTM and the Swin Transformer are the two primary components of TSTN. To learn extremely expressive representations and encode remote dependencies, the Swin Transformer uses the attention mechanism. For time-related data extraction, the LSTM is the way to go. It can learn long-range dependencies. To further ensure that the input dataset is balanced, the study employs the optimal Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) model. To improve classification accuracy, the Horse Herd Optimization Algorithm (HHOA) ideally selects the SMOTE sample rate. Lastly, the suggested prototypical is put through its paces using a publically available dataset for intrusion detection, the CIC IOT 2022 dataset. And by quickly responding to security issues in IoT networks, the representations may even improve intrusion detection in such networks.

title: Improved Variational Sparse Bayesian Learning for Off-Grid DOA Estimation of 5G Wideband Signals
authors: Yuzhuo Chen, Yinzhe Hu, Enwen Hu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To improve the efficiency of DOA estimation and address the grid mismatch problem of traditional sparse Bayesian algorithms under low SNR and limited snapshot conditions, this paper proposes an off-grid DOA estimation method for $\mathbf{5 G}$ wideband signals based on fast variational Bayesian inference. By introducing a fixed-point detection mechanism, the method accelerates hyperparameter convergence in variational inference and addresses grid mismatch through grid splitting and adaptive updates. For wideband signals, an improved signal subspace focusing technique is designed to convert multifrequency observations into an equivalent narrowband model. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method maintains high estimation accuracy and resolution performance even under harsh conditions such as low SNR and few snapshots, showing great potential for practical engineering applications.

title: Point Cloud Registration and Necking Defect Detection for Sheet Metal Quality Inspection
authors: Yunpeng Zhou, Tianyi Yang, Jinghan Ma, Changying Liu, Le Gao
abstract: This paper presents a high-precision measurement method for sheet metal necking defect detection using dual-path feature fusion and cascade detection. To address registration challenges in feature-sparse regions, a dual-path parallel feature fusion module is proposed, which combines local geometric embeddings (LGE) with Neighbor-to-Point (N2P) attention. An adaptive multi-mechanism loss function (AMLF) is developed to enhance registration robustness in low-overlap scenarios. For defect detection, a two-stage cascade approach is employed: the Curvature-Normal Plane Analysis and Detection (CNPAD) algorithm identifies defect cores, while the Multi-Radius PCA Growing Algorithm (MRPGA) ensures complete defect extraction. A Curved Trajectory Neck Constriction Defect Measurement Algorithm (CT-NCDMA) is introduced for precise quantification of arbitrarily shaped defects. Experimental results on the 3DMatch dataset demonstrate a registration success rate of 95.4%, with relative rotation error (RRE) of 5.827° and relative translation error (RTE) of 0.152m. On industrial validation samples, the method achieves RRE of 1.169°, RTE of 0.257mm, and 100% registration success rate. Defect detection accuracy reaches 98.30% with an F1-score of 0.9592. Measurement errors for length, width, and depth are reduced to 17.39%, 27.37%, and 40.29% of baseline methods, respectively. This method provides an effective solution for automated quality inspection of stamped components.

title: cWIDE — A CrossLab Compatible Web Integrated Development Environment for GOLDi Remote Labs
authors: Pierre Helbing, Johannes Nau, Karsten Henke, Detlef Streitferdt
abstract: The CrossLab architecture [1] enables a new approach to conducting experiments in online laboratories by connecting multiple laboratory devices via services, increasing their interchangeability and reusability. Integrated development environments (IDEs) are crucial in programming tasks, including online laboratory applications like microcontroller program-ming. The underlying work focuses on developing a CrossLab-compatible web-based IDE by reviewing the state of the art, defining requirements, and designing key functionalities. The developed IDE (see Fig. 1) provides file system management, compilation, debugging, and real-time collaboration capabilities, ensuring compatibility with the CrossLab framework. The demo will show an implementation based on Visual Studio Code and its extension API and discuss requirement fulfillment, alternative solutions, potential extensions, and open challenges. Future research can explore security aspects, complexity reduction, and the use of WebAssembly.

title: UniBreak: A Unified Evolutionary Token-Level Jailbreaking Framework for Large Language Models
authors: Shen You, Wei Jiang, Hefei Mei, Danei Gong, Zhongshen Li, Jixiang Yu, Junkai Ji, Qiuzhen Lin, Xiangtao Li, Ka-Chun Wong
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) demonstrate promising capabilities in natural language understanding and reasoning with enormous parameter spaces and vast amounts of training data. These attributes have facilitated their deployment into diverse application domains. However, the underlying parameters implicitly assume decision-making boundaries, resulting in a significant number of decision spaces not covered by training data. This makes them susceptible to adversarial manipulations through carefully crafted inputs. To illuminate the vulnerabilities of LLMs, we propose a unified token-level jailbreaking attack that makes victim models generate responses for potentially harmful queries. Specifically, we propose an evolutionary algorithm to evolve perturbation sets, utilizing gradient-based and crossover-based operators to enhance performance under multiple scenarios. Furthermore, we develop a repository for reusing past perturbations and conduct an analysis of token sensitivity within LLMs, facilitating zero-shot attacks with convergence. Extensive benchmark experiments validate the effectiveness of our method on three different models, achieving increases of 62.36%, 57.89%, and 64.81% in attack success rates compared to baseline methods under white-box scenarios. In addition, the evaluation experiments demonstrate our method is effective for multiple scenarios and different size of models. This research reveals vulnerabilities of LLMs, provides theoretical foundations for developing more robust defense strategies, and contributes to building more reliable AI systems.

title: VTK Origins
authors: Will Schroeder, Ken Martin, Berk Geveci
abstract: The enduring success of the Visualization Toolkit (VTK) has come as a surprise to the early developers of the system. Initially envisioned as a means to explore emerging technologies, and with a desire to collaborate widely with researchers and users in the visualization field, VTK is now over 30 years old, grown to a large-scale software system of more than five million lines of code, and supported by a large, active community. In retrospect, the reasons for this success go beyond technical capabilities, including the early adoption of a permissive open source license, accessible outreach through books and community engagement, sophisticated software practices, and the adoption of a hybrid business model to provide ongoing development. In this article, we speak to the origin story of VTK, include some behind-the-scenes stories, and identify factors contributing to its continuing success.

title: Design of Rare-Earth-Free Electrically Excited Synchronous Motor for Urban e-Logistics under Specified Driving Cycle
authors: Sarbajit Paul, Vu-Khanh Tran, Byoung-Gun Park, Pil-Wan Han, Jae-Gil Lee, Yon-Do Chun
abstract: This article presents a time-efficient design process of an electrically excited synchronous motor (EESM) for the use in urban e-logistics such as an Electric Mini Cargo Truck (EMCT). The aim is to develop a rare-earth-free traction motor alternative for urban e-logistics. Considering the driving cycle, the proposed design process utilizes extended scaling laws and Magnetostatic Finite Element Analysis (MS-FEA) to reach the final design of the EESM. The proposed design methodology is applied to a 22 kW EESM with fixed core dimensions. The process involves: 1) deriving the required torque-speed profile based on the New European Driving Cycle (NEDC); 2) conducting parametric analyses to evaluate key motor performance characteristics; and 3) satisfying terminal voltage constraints by optimizing stator winding configurations, including the number of turns and parallel paths, while targeting high-efficiency operating points. The rotor field winding parameters are determined based on voltage level constraints, which are influenced by the design of the contactless power supply (CPS) system that supplies the power the field winding. The designed EESM is manufactured and the electromagnetic performance including the CPS is validated at the design points.

title: Short-term SAR change detection for soil moisture retrieval: A case study over Danish test sites.
authors: Miquel Negre Dou, John Peter Merryman Boncori
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper investigates the use of a constrained short-term change detection (STCD) method for field-scale soil moisture retrieval from Sentinel-1 synthetic aperture radar (SAR) backscatter. This method estimates changes in surface dielectric properties by analyzing backscatter ratios between consecutive acquisitions, under the assumption that soil moisture fluctuates more rapidly than vegetation and/or roughness changes. The inversion scheme integrates ancillary data, namely a coarse-scale soil moisture product, soil texture maps, and field capacity, to constrain the solution and minimize outliers. The influence of key parameters, including the inversion window size, was examined. Additional corrections are introduced to handle limitations arising from crop type or measurement depth, including a seasonal adjustment model. The approach is validated using in situ soil moisture data from multiple test sites in Denmark. Results show that the STCD method achieves strong agreement with ground-based observations, yielding an overall correlation of R = 0.72, low bias (-0.26%), and an RMSE of 4.32%. These findings support the potential of short-term SAR change detection for scalable, high-resolution soil moisture monitoring in agricultural landscapes where backscatter variability is well characterized.

title: TransSE: A Transfer Learning-Based Predictive Model for Distinguishing Super Enhancers and Typical Enhancers_supp4-3657361.tif
authors: Junxiang Gao
abstract: Super-enhancers (SEs), comprising clusters of transcriptional regulatory elements, play essential roles in gene expression regulation and cell fate determination. Current computational methods for identifying SEs from genomic sequences face challenges in prediction accuracy and cross-species generalizability. This study introduces TransSE, a deep learning framework combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks with cross-species transfer learning for SE prediction. TransSE employs a two-phase strategy: pre-training on combined human and mouse data to learn conserved regulatory features, followed by species-specific fine-tuning to capture organism-specific patterns. Evaluation on human and mouse datasets demonstrates that TransSE achieves superior accuracy compared to existing methods including SENet, DeepSE, and transformer-based models (DNABERT, Enformer), with AUC values of 0.828 (human) and 0.832 (mouse). Ablation studies confirm that convolutional blocks are essential for feature extraction, while transfer learning and recurrent layers provide meaningful performance improvements. Feature analysis reveals that TransSE distinguishes SEs from typical enhancers based on learned sequence representations, achieving 10.4-fold improvement in clustering metrics. The model demonstrates effective cross-species prediction capability, maintaining AUC <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.79 when trained on one species and evaluated on another. Conservation pattern analysis shows that TransSE integrates both evolutionarily conserved and species-specific regulatory features, enabling robust performance across organisms with limited training data. A user-friendly web interface (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">http://transse.shenlabahmu.com</uri>) provides automated SE prediction, motif analysis, and variant impact assessment. Case studies using experimentally validated SEs demonstrate the tool's utility for investigating regulatory elements and prioritizing functional variants in disease-associated genomic regions. TransSE advances the investigation of gene regulatory mechanisms and facilitates identification of disease-associated variation in enhancer regions.

title: Infrared Image Simulation of Spatial Target in Various Atmospheric Environments Based on OpenGL
authors: Meng Lv, Haoting Liu, Haiguang Li, Xiaoshen Yang, Mengmeng Wang, Qing Li
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Infrared (IR) detection systems are increasingly used, but infrared image acquisition is challenging and datasets are still scarce. To generate high realistic infrared simulation data, this paper proposes an infrared image simulation method based on OpenGL, which comprehensively considers geometric model, target intrinsic radiation, atmospheric transmission characteristics and detector response model. This method constructs a process that conforms to the physical imaging process, enabling efficient rendering of infrared radiation images of spatial targets under various atmospheric environments. Experimental results show our method performs well in image realism, providing robust data support for tasks such as spatial target identification and tracking.
