title: Adaptive Multi-scale Lagrange Dynamics Spatial-Temporal Network for 3D Skeleton-based Human Motion Prediction_supp1-3657489.pdf
authors: Yumei Zhang
abstract: Human body dynamics, as a temporal variation pattern of pose sequences in 3D skeleton-based human motion prediction, has been extensively studied in spatial-temporal dependent modeling of deep learning. However, designing an effective modeling approach that fully harnesses physical principles to enhance algorithmic performance remains a challenge. Existing approaches prioritize displacement information, processing deterministic physical parameters via standard neural networks while modeling rotation motion through simplified angular constraints. Such physical approximation methods neglect the high-dimensional and dynamic characteristics of Dynamics variables, undermining the integrity and diversity of human motion feature representations. To alleviate these limitations, we propose an Adaptive Multi-scale Lagrange Dynamics Spatial-Temporal Network (AMLD-STNet), which directly embeds learnable neural network modules within physical equations to activate multi-scale dynamic physical feature modeling of human motion. Specifically, A Lagrange Dynamics Network (LD-Net) is constructed, which designs a set of joint force adjacency matrices to analyze the mechanical correlation between the velocity and acceleration of each joint motion through the Lagrange Dynamics equation. Subsequently, the Lagrange Dynamic Spatial-Temporal Network (LD-STNet) is established, which utilizes LD-Net to extract multi-perspective high-dimensional features of human displacement and rotational motion represented by Dynamics pose variables. To capture the mechanical correlation of joint node groups, we design a multi-scale streams LD-STNet, which can realize adaptive scale transformation according to the joint force adjacency. Additionally, Euler angle loss is employed to enforce rotational consistency constraints, thereby enhancing physical realism during network training. Finally, extensive experiments are conducted on three popular benchmarks, such as Human 3.6M, AMASS, and 3DPW, among which AMLD-STNet achieved state-of-the-art results with a smaller model size.

title: LPI Radar Waveform Design Based on CyclicSpectrum with Minimized Cyclic Frequency Sidelobes
authors: Haoran Zhang, Yongjun Liu, Daisheng Zhang, Xiaoyang Dong, Hao Tang, Guisheng Liao, Chilian Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With the advancement of electronic warfare, radar waveforms with low probability of intercept (LPI) characteristics have attracted increasing attention. In this paper, we propose a novel LPI waveform design method that can minimize the cyclic frequency sidelobes to enhance LPI performance under the constraint of autocorrelation-function peak sidelobe ratio (ACFPSLR) to maintain detection capability. In the proposed method, the weighted sum of cyclic frequency sidelobes is used as the LPI performance metric based on cyclostationary spectrum analysis (CSA). Under the power and ACF-PSLR constraints, the LPI radar waveform design is formulated as a non-convex quartic optimization problem. By introducing auxiliary variables, it is transformed into multiple quadratic subproblems with independent variables and linear inequality constraints, which can be efficiently solved via the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM). Simulation results verify that the proposed method can achieve better LPI performance while satisfy the demand of target detection.

title: Biosignal Simulator for Lifestyle Research
authors: Cristiana Azevedo, Matilde Ryon, Marta Cunha, Daniela Rodrigues, Alberto Cardoso
abstract: The Biosignal Simulator presented in this study is an innovative tool designed to offer the research community greater flexibility in generating artificial data for lifestyle-related studies. By incorporating user input on physical activities, experienced emotions, and locations visited, the simulator produces biosignals such as heart rate, electrodermal activity, and skin temperature across diverse contexts and scenarios. Upon completion, an interactive map is generated to visualise the traveled routes along with the corresponding simulated biosignals. The main objective of the simulator is to support the testing of hypotheses and the development of applications and technologies relating to health and well-being. The simulator demonstrated high accuracy in biosignal generation, with RMSE values of 2.27 bpm, 1.22 μS, and 0.38 °C, confirming the realism and reliability of the outputs. Future work will aim to enhance its features and extend its use to additional research areas.

title: Transformer-Based Transfer Learning for Cyber-Physical Attack Detection in Electric Vehicle Charging Stations
authors: Fida Muhammad Khan, Muhammad Hammad Nawaz, Abdul Wahab Khan, Inam Ullah Khan
abstract: Electric Vehicle Charging Station (EVCS) security faces significant challenges due to the growing complexity and frequency of cyber threats. Conventional IDS cannot identify new attacks, since detection depends on predefined specific rules, and has poor capabilities for detecting new attacks. Such systems usually rely on common machine learning algorithms that do not detect hidden indications of cyber-physical attacks. In this research study, a TL framework with a Transformer-based structure is proposed to build an effective attack detection model in EVCS, better than LSTM-based models due to scalability. In contrast to prior recurrent frameworks, the proposed framework employs three state-of-the-art transformer architectures, RoBERTa, T5, and DeBERTa, which operate on significant volumes of information and improve the ability to identify intrusions in EVCSs. The process includes data normalization and min-max scaling during preprocessing, followed by finetuning on the CICEVSE2024 dataset (EVSE-A and EVSEB). The evaluation framework uses a training and testing approach, measuring performance through various metrics such as accuracy, validation accuracy, loss, and ROC-AUC. The results show that the transformer models achieved accuracies of 98.90%, 98.95%, and 98.99% for RoBERTa, T5, and DeBERTa, respectively. These findings demonstrate that the TL framework provides high precision and robustness, offering an effective defense against a wide range of cyber-physical attacks on EVCS.

title: Toward Personalized Nutrition: Deep Learning for Food Recognition and Calorie Prediction
authors: Dennis Alejandro Guerra Calix, Muhammad Maaz Hamid, Raja Hashim Ali, Umme Rabab Syed
abstract: Accurate food recognition and calorie estimation are essential for dietary monitoring, healthcare, and personalized nutrition, yet existing systems often lack cultural inclusivity, portion awareness, and deployability. This study proposes a deep learning framework integrating YOLOv8 for food detection, EfficientNet-B3 for classification, and USDA-based regression for calorie estimation. Using the Food-101 dataset, reformatted for YOLO training, the model was trained with data augmentation and evaluated on multiple metrics, including mean average precision (mAP), F1-score, and mean absolute error (MAE). The YOLOv8 detector achieved 76.7% mAP@0.5, surpassing the 75% practical benchmark, while EfficientNet-B3 fine-tuned with ImageNet pretraining improved classification accuracy by 19.5% compared to training from scratch. Calorie estimation achieved an MAE of 48.2 kcal, with USDA integration reducing error by 14.3% relative to vision-only baselines. Robustness tests under occlusion and lighting variations revealed less than 8% mAP drop, confirming resilience to real-world noise. However, cross-dataset validation on UECFOOD100 revealed a 12.6% accuracy gap for Asian cuisines, highlighting the cultural bias of Western-centric datasets. By unifying detection, classification, and nutrition regression, this work contributes a scalable, biasaware, and partially portion-sensitive solution for AI-driven dietary monitoring. Future directions include depth-based volume estimation and mobile optimization for real-world deployment.

title: A Multidimensional Survey of Intelligent IoT Systems for Gunshot Detection
authors: Vijayalakshmi K Kumarasamy, Anitha Anandhan, Yu Liang, Dalei Wu
abstract: Gunshot Detection Systems (GDS) are increasingly deployed in public, institutional, and protected areas to enable rapid, real-time response to firearm incidents. Conventional acoustic-only solutions suffer from high false-alarm rates, limited adaptability to dynamic environments, and restricted spatial awareness. Recent advances in Machine Learning (ML), Deep Learning (DL), and Internet of Things (IoT) technologies have enabled intelligent GDS capable of context-aware detection, firearm classification, and shooter localization through multi-modal inputs including audio, video, and infrared data. These systems can adapt to background noise, time-of-day conditions, and deployment context, improving detection reliability while reducing latency. This survey focuses on sensor-driven, IoT-enabled gunshot detection pipelines that involve on-site sensing, edge or cloud-based inference, and operational deployment, and it does not address internet-only information collection or general crime analytics frameworks. This survey analyzes 156 peer-reviewed studies published between 1998 and 2025, organized into six analytical dimensions: detection and modeling approaches, application contexts, hardware and deployment infrastructure, communication and security frameworks, environmental and spatial adaptability, and performance evaluation. Across these, we identify persistent challenges spanning both technical and operational domains, including accurate detection in noisy or reverberant environments, reliable localization in GPS-poor or complex terrains, low-latency multimodal fusion, scalability under resource constraints, dataset scarcity, privacy and ethical considerations, vulnerability to spoofing or suppressors, and secure, real-time communication for rapid response. By consolidating technical advances and mapping them to these open problems, the review provides actionable insights for designing scalable, energy-efficient, and trustworthy GDS suitable for diverse real-world deployments.

title: A PSO-Based Meta-Heuristic Strategy for High-Performance Image Encryption
authors: Pradip Dhal, Nandita Behera, Rahul Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Securing image data is crucial in today’s fast-paced digital world, particularly for sensitive applications like medical imaging, military systems, and surveillance. By combining encryption using common cryptographic techniques, such as Data Encryption Standard (DES) or Advanced Encryption Standard (AES), with picture augmentation using Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), this research presents a revolutionary two-stage framework for safe image transmission. PSO improves image quality in the initial stage by maximizing visual qualities like sharpness, contrast, and brightness. The objective function was developed to retain important visual characteristics and ensure adequate clarity. The improved image undergoes symmetric encryption in the second stage using DES or AES to guarantee the confidentiality of the data during transmission and storage. This hybrid approach suits real-time applications and offers strong security and visual integrity. Experiments conducted on typical benchmark photos consistently improved encryption quality and visual qualities. This is demonstrated by the high entropy value, minimal pixel correlation, and high level of security against various cryptographic attacks. The advantages of using meta-heuristic optimization techniques in conjunction with conventional cryptographic algorithms for secure image transmission are presented in the well-considered framework that has been suggested.

title: Deep Learning Based Hybrid Framework for Food Classification and Recipe Generation
authors: Sanshruth Ralhan, Ronit Kumar Das, Sweta Srivastava
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: In this paper, an attempt is made to improve the classification of food items from real-world images in addition to images sourced from controlled conditions. The dataset, which was selected for its large number of food classes, consists of 101,000 real-world food images divided equally between 101 class labels. The proposed model is designed in a two-stage methodology using a general model trained on all classes to obtain a heuristic value followed by use of a specialized sub-model for fine-tuned classification. In the first stage, a general model groups and adds up the predictions by cluster, providing a confidence value for each cluster. In the second stage, the model for the cluster with the highest confidence value is used for the final classification. Each cluster model is trained on a small subset of classes, reducing time and cost along with improving the performance. The study evaluates whether using smaller label subsets in sub-models leads to better classification performance in comparison to the general model while keeping training time manageable. The sub-models reach over 95 percent accuracy after training for 30 epochs, while the general model achieves 82 percent after 50 epochs. Therefore, the sub-models outperform the general model on the specific label subsets they were trained on, and take converge faster.

title: Hybrid Deep Learning Framework for Estimating the Occurrence Rate of the Inverse Exponential Process: A Comparative Analysis of LSTM, ANN, and Traditional Methods
authors: Adel Sufyan Hussain, Zedan Z. Mashikhin, Naaman Omar Yaseen, Ma’Mon Abu Hammad, Emad A. Az-Zo’Bi, Mohammad A. Tashtoush
abstract: Parameter estimation needs to be precise in order to make successful failure predictions and improve system reliability within software engineering applications. This research develops a deep learning solution using LSTM networks linked to ANN models together with MLE methods for modelling Inverse Exponential Process-based SRGM parameters. The framework successfully analyses complicated failure patterns because it combines temporal networks from LSTM with ANN-based nonlinear approximation techniques. The proposed model performs better based on real failure data as demonstrated by lower MSE results and elevated AIC and BIC criteria values. This hybrid deep learning method enhances predictive accuracy which delivers a strong solution for proactive software system quality assurance and maintenance practice.

title: A Deep Learning Approach for Securing Medical IoT via SMA-based Feature Selection and SWA-CNN
authors: N Samanvita, Vidyadevi Biradar, Chaithanya Bogadi, Subhashree Rout, Harinder Pal Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The growing adoption of the Internet of medical things (IoMT) has significantly enhanced healthcare delivery but also introduced serious cybersecurity risks due to its resource-constrained and heterogeneous nature. Traditional machine learning-based intrusion detection systems (IDS) often fall short in effectively identifying complex and evolving cyber threats. To address this challenge, we propose a robust deep learning-based IDS framework tailored for IoMT environments, incorporating novel bio-inspired optimization techniques. The framework begins with preprocessing the dataset using Z-score normalization, followed by feature selection using the slime mould algorithm (SMA) to identify the most relevant features and reduce dimensionality. These features are then input into a customized stochastic weight averaging convolutional neural network (SWA-CNN) designed for accurate intrusion detection. To further optimize the model's performance, hyperparameters are fine-tuned using the Sperm Whale Optimization (SWO) algorithm. Experimental validation on the benchmark UNSW-NB15 dataset demonstrates the effectiveness of our approach, achieving an accuracy of 99.28%, precision of 98.21%, recall of 99.01%, and F1-score of 98.61%. The proposed SMA-SWO-SWA-CNN framework shows superior performance compared to conventional models and offers a promising solution for enhancing cybersecurity in IoMT applications.

title: Conformable Fractional Derivative of a Vector Field
authors: Waseem Ghazi Alshanti, Ma'Mon Abu Hammad, Hamza Alzaareer, Hassan Al-Zoubi, Ahmad Alshanty
abstract: This paper introduces the conformable fractional derivative of a vector field. Some related results are also presented.

title: Grating Lobe Suppression Method Based on Joint Amplitude-Phase Coherence Factor Processing
authors: Xun Wang, Chuandong Li, Hailing Xiong, Zhen Luo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Due to the sparse array structure, multi-input multi- output (MIMO) array radar is prone to produce significant grating lobes during the imaging process, which severely affects the image quality. To address this issue, this paper proposes a grating lobe suppression method based on the joint processing of amplitude-phase coherence factor (AM-PCF). This method first utilizes the amplitude characteristics of the back projection (BP) imaging grid to generate a threshold screening mechanism, which retains significant scattering areas and suppresses low amplitude interference areas. Subsequently, the phase coherence factor is calculated within the screened areas. Finally, the corresponding PCF is used to weight the screened BP imaging results to achieve suppression of grating lobes. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to traditional PCF weighting methods, the pro- posed method is more effective in suppressing grating lobes in MIMO array radar imaging.

title: Decentralized Swarm Formation of Miniature Robots Using the SCOPE Strategy
authors: Muhammad Adnan, Yaseer Arafat Durrani, Muhammad Haroon Yousaf
abstract: The noncentralized coordination is a must in multirobot systems in order to get the scalable and faulttolerant swarm behavior. The communication bottlenecks, the single points of failure, and the limited scalability are the reasons why centralized control is not appropriate in dynamic or communication-constrained environments. In order to solve these problems, the authors introduce SCOPE (Scalable, Communication-free Offset-based Path-planning and Estimation), which is a new and fully decentralized swarm formation strategy. The SCOPE framework marks the crucial contribution that allows small autonomous robots to create and keep up exact geometric formations without any robot communication or a main controller. Each TurtleBot3 robot works separately in its own ROS namespace and employs a modular control stack: Adaptive Monte Carlo Localization (AMCL) for probabilistic pose estimation, Navfn for global path planning, and the Dynamic Window Approach (DWA) for real-time obstacle avoidance. To compute relative formation positions without a central controller or leader, the authors introduce a new virtual target offset method. The simulations demonstrated that the proposed system is effective by accomplishing 92% of the obstacles avoided, 89% of the formation accuracy, 95% of the shortest path adherence, and 91% of the path-following precision. In simulations, four TurtleBot3 Burgers were used, and three were used in hardware (limited availability) dynamic formation control. These outcomes strengthen the idea of the proposed decentralized architecture being suitable for real-world scenarios such as warehouse automation, decentralized logistics, and autonomous material handling.

title: Range Migration Cancellation for Heart Rate Estimation based on mmWave Radar
authors: Zhan Yang, Hui Tang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Non-contact heart rate monitoring with radar has attracted considerable attention due to its ability to provide high-precision physiological measurements without physical contact. However, random body movement introduces unpredictable range migration that can overwhelm the weak respiration and heartbeat signals, posing a significant challenge for accurate heart rate estimation. In this work, we present a novel technique to suppress range migration using millimeter-wave radar. The proposed approach combines fast-time spectrum peak detection for motion compensation with slow-time autoregressive modeling to reconstruct the signal corrupted by range migration, and further leverages the acceleration characteristics to extract the target heart rate from motion-suppressed phase data. Both simulations and experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods, enabling reliable and precise heart rate measurement using an Frequency Modulated Continuous Wave radar system.

title: SQLLM: A Secure and Quantized Framework for Large Language Models in 5G Private Network Operations
authors: Jian Ma, Tong Liu, Yimeng Shang, Nan Hu, Lei Xia, Peizhen Liao, Yitong Shang
abstract: With the development of 5G technology, the demand for large language models (LLMs) in private network operation and maintenance is growing. These models enhance the intelligence and efficiency of network management through deep learning techniques. However, the application of LLMs for 5G private network operation and maintenance faces the dual challenges of data security and resource limitations. To address these challenges, we propose SQLLM, which is an integrated framework dedicated to detecting abnormal user query-based network attacks and performing high-quality compression on large language detection models for network attacks. Specifically, leveraging the powerful representational capacity of large language models, we utilize the LoRA fine-tuning technique to identify normal questions and three types of attack questions, thus avoiding behaviors that attempt to disrupt or obtain sensitive information. Moreover, this research innovatively adopts the static quantization technique to compress LLMs for private network operation and maintenance. Unlike traditional static quantization that uses fixed parameters and uniform granularity for activations, our optimized strategy introduces a dynamic smoothing factor α to transfer outlier variance from activations to weights and adopts a hybrid per-tensor/per-token granularity tailored to 5G O&M data, thus avoiding the challenge of the sharp decline in the inference ability of the quantized LLM caused by outliers, enabling it to adapt to resource-constrained and multi-user concurrent usage environments. Finally, we validate four types of questions and evaluate the performance of the quantized model on key performance indicators such as accuracy, VRAM consumption, and inference time. The experimental results demonstrate that the SQLLM model achieves excellent performance on all test indicators. This achievement proves the security and feasibility of the efficient deployment of LLMs for private network operation and maintenance in the 5G private network environment with network attacks and resource limitations.

title: Optimal Sparse Array Design Based on Robust Multiple Interferences Suppression Beamforming
authors: Weinian Li, Lichun Li, Chaoyue Song, Chenglong Ge, Hongyi Pan, Siyao Tian
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To solve the dilemma that the interference suppression number of traditional uniform linear based beamformer is limited by the number of elements and is sensitive to the angle error, this paper proposes a design method of optimal sparse array based on robust multiple interferences suppression beamforming, which realizes the super-degree of freedom interference suppression in the presence of angular errors. When the angle of the signal is roughly known, this method first takes the minimization of the $l_{1}$ norm of the weight vector of the array as the objective function, and the degree of suppression in each interference direction is used as a constraint condition to construct the original optimization problem. The paper solves the optimization problem based on the iterative weighted $l_{1}$ norm method, and then the static beamforming weights is converted into the adaptive beamforming weights by combining with the data covariance matrix of the actual received signals, so as to further improve the output signal-to-interference-to-noise ratio (SINR). The simulation results show that the sparse array designed by this method can save 1/4 of the array elements compared with the uniform linear array under the same design objectives, and has strong robustness to the angle estimation error of the signal.

title: A Novel MISC-based Sparse Array Design for DOA Estimation Exploiting Sum-Difference Coarray
authors: Pinjiao Zhao, Xiaohui Huang, LiWei Wang, Guobing Hu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel sparse array design based on maximum interelement spacing constraint (MISC) which leverages the concept of the sum-difference coarray (SDCA) to further enhance the achievable degrees of freedom (DOFs). Specifically, double-summation operations, including adjacent sum and prefix sum, are defined to construct the SDCA via interelement spacing (IES) set. According to this, existing MISCbased sparse arrays can be converted into their corresponding SDCA versions, which, however suffer from a relatively short maximum consecutive sum-coarray (SCA). By contrast, the proposed array, termed Ex-MISC, has a longer consecutive SCA, and has no overlapping virtual sensors between its maximum consecutive segments of difference coarray (DCA) and SCA, resulting in higher number of available DOFs. Simulation results validate the superiority of the proposed Ex-MISC array, highlighting its potential for improving the direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation performance.

title: Automated Psychological Profiling from Children's Drawings Using Deep Learning and Natural Language Processing
authors: Dhananjay Bhagat, Kartik Maski, Swamil Randive, Harsh Dhimmar, Ramadevi Vitthal Salunkhe, Devendra Joshi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Understanding the inner psychological world of children through their drawings has long been a cornerstone of developmental and clinical psychology. Traditional assessment techniques, such as the House-Tree-Person (HTP) test, rely heavily on expert interpretation, which is often subjective, time-consuming, and inconsistent across evaluators. In this research, we propose a novel AI-powered framework that fuses deep learning and natural language processing to automate the psychological interpretation of children’s HTP drawings. The system employs ResNet-34, a convolutional neural network (CNN), for advanced image analysis to detect and interpret nuanced visual patterns in the drawings. These patterns are then transformed into coherent, human-like psychological insights using a transformer-based language generation model, specifically BART. Unlike static, template-driven systems, our approach dynamically generates rich, context-aware psychological narratives that align with clinical reasoning. This interdisciplinary methodology presents a significant step forward in augmenting traditional psychological evaluation with scalable, interpretable, and data-driven intelligence.

title: Analytical Solution of a Modified KdV Equation via Atomic Decomposition
authors: Hamza Alzaareer, Waseem Ghazi Alshanti
abstract: This study presents an exact analytical solution for the partial differential equation u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</inf> + u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf> + u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">xx</inf> = u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">xt</inf> using the atomic decomposition method. The derived solution exhibits soliton-like wave characteristics modified by the u<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">xt</inf> term, with applications in engineering and physics. However, the presence of an exponential growth term e<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</sup> suggests potential instability, which is analyzed in detail.

title: STIR-MO: An Enhanced Hybrid Cancer Predictive Model
authors: Bibhuprasad Sahu, Janmejaya Mishra, Sameena Parveen, Biswajeeban Das, Amrutanshu Panigrahi, Abhilash Pati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Machine learning methods are applied to search for patterns in microarray and medical information datasets. Recently, much attention has been paid to creating tissue and cell samples, microarray data from them, and analyzing those datasets. Machine learning methodologies have been used to diagnose and classify cancer-related microarray data. However, microarray data analysis comes with several difficulties due to the lack of data and the focus on high-dimensional data with too many features, which can hinder classification. To overcome these problems, adequate measures have been proposed to develop feature selection or dimensionality reduction methods and classification algorithms to increase the effectiveness of microarray data classification. In this research, Statistical Inference Relief (STIR) enhanced Mother Optimization (MO) is developed as a hybrid method for dimensionality reduction and SVM, AdaBoost, and XGBoost for classification. Six microarray datasets were adopted to evaluate efficacy. Of all the methods experimented on, including SVM, Leukaemia arose as having the accurate classification of 96.44 %, while leukemia 2 and the Colon datasets forecasted 97.09% and 98.04% classification accuracy, respectively. Similarly, DLBCL, Prostrate, and SRBCT dataset achieves an accuracy of 98.36%, 99.34%, and 98.65% with the SVM classifier, which is better than its counterparts.

title: A Novel Approach for Solving Space Fractional Heat Equations with Variable Coefficients Using the Crank-Nicolson Method
authors: Reem Edwan
abstract: This study introduces a novel technique based on Fractional Grünwald-Letnikov Series designed to address fractional heat equations with initial and boundary conditions. The Crank-Nicolson method yields approximate solutions for space-fractional heat equations with variable coefficients, where the space-fractional derivative is defined in the Caputo sense. It demonstrates the method's effectiveness by discussing stability and proving that the Crank-Nicolson method is unconditionally stable. This approach enables easy solutions to many problems, and it also compares its performance with established methods, such as the tau method and the Chebyshev collocation method. The results showcase the efficacy of the Crank-Nicolson method in providing approximate solutions and highlight its potential as a valuable tool for solving fractional heat equations efficiently compared to other methods.

title: Integrating Adaptive Rewiring and Compulsory Regulating: Co-Evolutionary Epidemic Dynamics Driven by Multi-Source Information
authors: Xiao Hong, Guijuan Zhang, Zena Tian, Bing Wang, Dianjie Lu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Effective epidemic control depends on understanding how individuals respond to multi-source information. However, existing research often treats two key behavioral responses—compulsory regulating and adaptive rewiring— separately, overlooking the co-evolution of network topology with the individual states. To address this, we propose a novel Unaware-Aware-Unaware and Susceptible-Infected-Susceptible (UAU-SIS) model that integrates these dual behavioral mechanisms, driven by cognitive and official information. Our model's framework, where the network topology is regenerated at each discrete timestep, is a key simplification for mathematical tractability. Within each step, however, the connection process is highly adaptive, governed by state-dependent rules rather than pure randomness. This setup, analyzed via the microscopic Markov chain approach (MMCA), enables us to analytically derive the epidemic threshold under their combined effects. Experimental results reveal their complementary properties: adaptive rewiring excels at preventing outbreaks by raising the epidemic threshold, whereas compulsory regulating is vital for mitigating prevalence during an ongoing epidemic. Importantly, strong adaptive rewiring can substantially suppress epidemic spread even under weak compulsory regulation. Furthermore, we validate the effectiveness and robustness of our proposed model on diverse real-world networks. Overall, this study provides a rigorous theoretical framework for understanding information-behavior-epidemic co-dynamics, offering critical insights for designing effective hybrid intervention strategies.

title: Joint Design of OFDM Sensing Waveforms and Receive Filters for Distributed Radars
authors: Xinghe Li, Hongzhi Guo, Jinyang He, Huiyong Li, Ziyang Cheng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper focuses on the design of cooperative sensing waveforms for distributed radars orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) systems, aiming to minimize autocorrelation and cross-correlation sidelobe while ensuring high detection performance. Considering the main lobe gain constraint, peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR) control, energy constraint, and mismatched filtering compatibility for OFDM waveforms, the optimization problem is established by minimizing the integrated sidelobe level (ISL). To address the nonconvex term in the objective function, which make it difficult to obtain a closed-form solution, a method based on the alternating direction method of multipliers (ADMM) is designed. Numerical simulations validate the effectiveness of the proposed method, demonstrating significant ISL reduction in distributed radars cooperative sensing scenarios compared to matched filtering.

title: Electrical Characterization of Modular 3D Packaging Assembled With Removable Metal Parts
authors: Paul Bruyere, Alexis Derbey, Betina Zynger-Capaverde, Eric Vagnon, Jean-Luc Schanen, Jean-Michel Guichon, Omar Sanjakdar, Yvan Avenas
abstract: This paper proposes a novel modular packaging concept based on the 3D integration of 1.2 kV SiC MOSFET with metal foams for electrical contacts with pressure assembly. The latter make possible the disassembly of switching cells by keeping low electrical resistance and inductance inside the package. Thus, static and dynamic experimental characterizations are carried out to evaluate their impact compared to copper interposers. Static measurements show that the electrical resistance of the package is in the range from 3 to 4 mΩ. Dynamic characterizations demonstrate that the stray inductance of the switching cell is close to 3 nH. With results obtained with copper interposers close to the ones obtained with foams, the material used for the electrical interconnection have low impact on the electrical performances of the power module. However, the modification of the pressure distribution in the power module induces a modification of the resistance and stray inductance. This dependency is more important for copper interposers because they are non-deformable.

title: A Hybrid Numerical-Analytical Approach for Scalable Metasurface Design in Focused Long-Range Wireless Power Delivery
authors: Pierpaolo Usai, Martina Falchi, Danilo Brizi, Agostino Monorchio
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a low-frequency metasurface that generates a highly focused magnetic field when excited by an actively fed transmitting coil for long-range resonant inductive wireless power transfer. A theoretical framework based on magnetic dipole theory is derived to calculate the optimal currents required to shape the magnetic field into a confined hotspot at a target working distance. The optimization process maximizes the correlation between the desired field distribution and the combined contributions of the metasurface and transmitter. To verify the design methodology, practical considerations are deployed to effectively design the metasurface unit cell, an asymmetrically twisted double-layer spiral, able to maximize inductance while maintaining the ohmic losses low. Then, a 5×5 metasurface array, covering an overall area of 22 cm × 22 cm and operating at 4 MHz, undergoes validation through numerical simulations and experimental testing. Simulations revealed a 40 mm diameter hotspot (~λ/1800) at a distance of 10 cm from the transmitter, with experimental results from a PCB prototype confirming these findings and estimating a power transfer 18 dB higher in the focusing region with respect to no metasurface configuration. Besides, the system demonstrated robustness by maintaining focus despite variations in the metasurface-to-transmitter distance. This work provides a practical, scalable solution to address distance limitations in magnetic near field focusing, eliminating the need for guiding structures such as ferrites and simplifying design for WPT applications.

title: Research on 2-D Sparse MIMO Planar Array Topologies for High-Resolution DOA Estimation
authors: Xifeng Peng, Shiwei Ren, Guiyu Wang, Zhaoyixin Li, Xiangnan Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Direction of arrival (DOA) estimation constitutes a critical technology across diverse domains including detection and communication. The approach of using planar arrays with more sensors in DOA estimation has high resolution in detection. Notably, active array architectures such as MIMO configurations employed in DOA estimation offer distinct advantages in passive target detection, with their inherent sum co-array characteristics significantly improving estimation accuracy. Consequently, the development of planar sparse active array configurations emerges as a new research direction for achieving compact system dimensions while maintaining high-resolution performance. This study proposes a new planar sparse MIMO array geometry specifically designed to amplify the benefits of advanced signal processing techniques. Simulations and comparative analyses reveal that when integrated with optimized configurations, the proposed array demonstrates enhanced multi-signal detection capabilities and superior estimation accuracy compared to conventional array architectures, as well as existing sum or difference co-array methodologies.

title: Remote Debugger: A Digital Twin for Petri Nets-based Networked Embedded Controllers
authors: Fernando Pereira, Anikó Costa, Filipe Moutinho, João-Paulo Barros, Rogério Campos-Rebelo, Luis Gomes
abstract: This paper presents an interactive tool for remotely debugging, controlling, and monitoring IOPT-net models executed in networked embedded controllers. IOPT-nets is a Petri net class targeted for controller modeling. The tool behaves as a digital twin of the embedded controller. It enables users to analyze, test, and debug networked controllers via a Web interface, which allows step-by-step execution, breakpoints, and input/output signal manipulation. The tool offers a graphical interface presenting the status of the IOPT-net model under execution in the remote controller (as in a token-player simulator), as well as records and presents the evolution of the signals as waveforms, which can be exported for further analysis. Integrated into the IOPT- Tools framework, the tool uses a lightweight HTTP-based protocol for communication.

title: Upgrade of Elab's Electromagnetic Cavity by Adding a Spectroscopy Diagnostic
authors: Manuel Santos, Pedro Rossa, Goncalo Torres, João Nuno Silva, Horacio Fernandes
abstract: Elab is Instituto Superior Tecnicn's remotely con-trolled laboratory. Available online, it hosts several experimental apparatuses designed to allow the study of different physical phenomena. One of the apparatuses available is an electromag-netic cavity designed to facilitate the study of plasma diagnostics. This experiment has been recently upgraded with the addition of a UV NISINIR spectrometer. The addition of the spectrometer allows for the identification of the species in the plasma and, therefore, the identification of any impurities present. A key as-pect of this was the adaptation of elab's infrastructure, a Python- Django system known as Framework for Remote Experiments in Education (FREE), to allow for the acquisition of multiple data sources in a single experimental apparatus. Designed to allow for the integration of remote experimental apparatuses into Learning Management Systems (LMS) and Massive Open Online Courses (MOOCs), this framework aims to improve the apparatus' accessibility and the user's educational outcomes. To this end, the electromagnetic cavity apparatus is being integrated into a plasma physics MOOC.

title: Linear and nonlinear optical properties of a triangular quantum well-based terahertz photodetector
authors: Mahendra Kumar Das, Vimal Kumar Singh Yadav, Rajesh Kumar Lal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive analysis of the linear and nonlinear optical properties of a GaAs/AlGaAs-based Triangular Quantum Well (TQW) Terahertz (THz) photodetector, designed with a well width of 60 Å and an aluminum mole fraction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{x}=0.35$</tex>. The asymmetric potential formed under an applied electric field of 7.6 kV/cm and a bias of -3 V results in discrete energy levels, which were determined using both analytical Airy function solutions and validated by Finite Difference Method (FDM)-based numerical simulations. The close agreement between the two approaches confirms the accuracy of the model, with an energy separation of approximately 93.7 meV between the first two subbands, corresponding to an infrared detection wavelength of around 13.2 μm. In this study, we have examined optical response parameters, such as the absorption coefficient and refractive index change, using susceptibility-based modeling and the density matrix formalism. Results showed a strong dependence on incident optical intensity, ranging from 0 to 0.6 MW/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. This demonstrates the nonlinear behaviors of the photodetector, including saturable absorption and refractive index modulation. The third-order nonlinear susceptibility was observed to counteract the linear term, resulting in a net decrease in absorption and refractive index change at higher intensities. The originality of the present work is the dual-method investigation of a narrow TQW structure under precise control of intersubband transitions and intensity-dependent optical effects. The outcome demonstrates the potential of TQWs as high-speed, tunable terahertz and infrared photodetectors, making them applicable in high-speed THz communication devices.

title: Design, Equivalent Circuit Analysis, and Verification of A 400-Cell Broadband Dual-Polarized Reconfigurable Transmit-Array at Ka-Band
authors: Guangyao Peng, Enhao Wang, Kunjing Zhong, Fan Wu, Zhi Hao Jiang, Ronan Sauleau, Wei Hong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: A broadband 1-bit reconfigurable transmit-array (TA) featuring independent dual-polarized beam-scanning capability is reported at Ka-band. Bandwidth enhanced transmissive elements based on the current reversed mechanism are developed, which are optimized based on an equivalent circuit model. The elements are further miniaturized and aligned orthogonally in an end-to-middle scheme for dual-polarized operation. A 20 × 20-cell dual-polarized reconfigurable TA is fabricated and measured. The prototype exhibits a peak gain of 24.8 dBi, a 3-dB gain bandwidth of 18%, as well as an aperture efficiency of 26%. Moreover, it supports sum beams scanning up to 60° and difference beams steering up to 50°. The demonstrated dual-polarized reconfigurable TA can be a promising candidate for millimeter-wave communication and radar systems.

title: A Joint Frame-Frequency Smoothing DOA Estimation Method for Wideband Coherent Signals Assisted by Dynamic Metasurface Antenna
authors: Weihao Pan, Peng Li, Zihang Cheng, Renhong Xie, Rui Xu, Junhua Gao, Hui Chu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a joint frame-frequency smoothing algorithm for wideband direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation of coherent signals, leveraging a DMA-assisted receiving system. By simultaneously exploiting the diversity in metasurface coding patterns and frequency bins, the proposed method effectively restores the rank of the sample covariance matrix and overcomes the limitations of conventional singledomain smoothing techniques. Furthermore, an optimizationdriven pattern design approach based on simulated annealing is developed to maximize the decorrelation capability of the virtual array. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves significantly improved resolution and robustness for wideband coherent DOA estimation compared to traditional DFT-based and single-domain methods.

title: Mitigating Context-Memory Conflicts in LLMs through Dynamic Cognitive Reconciliation Decoding
authors: Yigeng Zhou, Wu Li, Yifan Lu, Yequan Wang, Xuebo Liu, Wenya Wang, Jun Yu, Min Zhang, Jing Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Large language models accumulate extensive parametric knowledge through pre-training. However, knowledge conflicts occur when outdated or incorrect parametric knowledge conflicts with external knowledge in the context. Existing methods address knowledge conflicts through contrastive decoding, but in conflict-free scenarios, static approaches disrupt output distribution. Other dynamic decoding methods attempt to measure the degree of conflict but still struggle with complex real-world situations. In this paper, we propose a two-stage decoding method called Dynamic Cognitive Reconciliation Decoding (<monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DCRD</monospace>), to predict and mitigate context-memory conflicts. <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DCRD</monospace> first analyzes the attention map to assess context fidelity and predict potential conflicts. Based on this prediction, the input is directed to one of two decoding paths: (1) greedy decoding, or (2) context fidelity-based dynamic decoding. This design enables <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DCRD</monospace> to handle conflicts efficiently while maintaining high accuracy and decoding efficiency in conflict-free cases. Additionally, to simulate scenarios with frequent knowledge updates, we constructed ConflictKG, a knowledge conflict QA benchmark. Experiments on four LLMs across six QA datasets show that <monospace xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">DCRD</monospace> outperforms all baselines, achieving state-of-the-art performance.

title: Investigating the Impact of Floating Non-Spherical Micro-Impurity on Transformer Oil Streamer Dynamics
authors: Mihir A. Bhatt, Praghnesh J. Bhatt, Chirag Parekh
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: The dielectric reliability of transformer oil is essential for the secure operation of high-voltage transformer in power systems. However, streamer discharge behavior can be significantly impacted by inservice contamination from micro-impurities, especially non-spherical particles like metal flakes, cellulose fibers, and aging by-products, which can cause premature insulation breakdown. This study uses a 2D axisymmetric model built in COMSOL Multiphysics to investigate how non-spherical micro-impurities affect streamer discharge behavior. Electrostatics, charge transport, and heat transfer have been used in the simulation to study the electric field distribution, space charge density, and steamer morphology in the presence of spherical and non-spherical particles. The results demonstrate that non-spherical particles, which act as secondary ionization centers and drive streamer branching, produce localized electric field enhancements due to their sharp edges and uneven surfaces. Spherical particles, on the other hand, exhibit slower and more consistent discharge behavior due to their finer field interactions. Sharp-edged impurities encourage greater space charge accumulation and electron concentrations, leading to hotspots that raise the risk of dielectric breakdown. This morphology-driven dynamic raises questions regarding the reliability of transformer insulation and significantly affects pre-breakdown procedures. This paper highlights the necessity of realistic impurity geometries in modelling for accurate investigations of streamer dynamics in liquid dielectrics. In order to increase grid reliability and asset longevity, the manufacturers may also utilize these findings to create robust insulating systems that are more resilient to particle-induced deterioration in power transformers.

title: Efficient Deployment of Neural Network Models and Dense Vehicle Object Detection Technology Based on FPGA Edge Platform
authors: Jingtu Zou, Chunxiao Qu, Qingfeng Zhou, Chanzi Liu, Gao Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To overcome existing challenges in vehicle detection technology, particularly regarding small target recognition, realtime algorithm efficiency, and edge deployment constraints, this paper presents an FPGA-optimized solution for dense vehicle detection. By restructuring hardware-unfriendly operators in the YOLOv7 architecture and integrating an Efficient Channel Attention (ECA) mechanism, we achieve $3 \%$ mean Average Precision (mAP) improvement while maintaining baseline detection speed. The hardware implementation employs a pipelined acceleration architecture with a Deep Learning Processing Unit (DPU) core on the Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC, enabling convolutional parallelization through Vitis-AI-driven model quantization and compilation. Experimental validation demonstrates $93.01 \%$ detection accuracy at 22.11 FPS with 5.85 W stable power consumption, yielding a power efficiency of $3.78 \mathrm{FPS} / \mathrm{W}$. This represents $14.5 \times$ and $189 \times$ improvements over RTX 4060 Ti GPU and Intel i7-12700KF CPU platforms, respectively. Compared with conventional GPU implementations, our solution offers enhanced compactness and energy efficiency for intelligent vehicles with spatial and power constraints.

title: Online Calibration of Soft Sensor for Batch Processes Using Just-in-Time Learning Based on Multi-Similarity Measurement
authors: Enguang Sui, Jianlin Wang, Zebin Zhang, Rui He, Yunfei Qi
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Batch process is a critical manufacturing approach in industries such as fine chemicals, biopharmaceuticals, and food processing. However, the hard-to-measure process variables poses challenges for online monitoring of batch processes. Soft sensor technology overcomes the limitations of traditional sensors and online instruments in measuring hard-to-measure variables in real time, and has become a key approach for the online prediction of these variables. To ensure the accuracy of online predictions by soft sensor models for batch processes, this study proposes an online calibration method of soft sensor for batch processes using just-in-time learning based on multi-similarity measurement. First, considering the temporal feature of data in batch processes, we introduce the sliding time window, and a calibration triggering strategy is constructed based on the changes in causal effects between the online and offline time windows to accurately identify calibration timing. Then, multisimilarity measurement is employed to calculate the similarity between different time windows, and historical time windows belonging to the same mode as the current time window are selected. Finally, these historical data are used to update the soft sensor model parameters online, enabling calibration of soft model for batch processes. Experimental results on the penicillin fermentation process verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Data-Driven Multiobjective Multimodal Transportation Route Optimization in Hybrid Uncertain Environments
authors: Jinlong Zhou, Yinggui Zhang, Hanzhang Qin, Juan Wang, Lining Xing, Ling Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Multimodal freight transportation is essential for enhancing logistics efficiency and reducing costs, with route optimization as its core component. However, uncertainties are prevalent in multimodal systems, posing challenges for the construction and validation of simulation models. Furthermore, the involvement of multiple stakeholders introduces conflicting optimization objectives. Effectively balancing these objectives to maximize overall benefits has become a critical issue that requires resolution. For the multimodal transport route optimization problem in hybrid uncertainty environments (e.g., there are uncertainties in transportation demand, transportation time, and transfer time), this study constructs a multiobjective optimization model based on fuzzy numbers. The complexity of the model is reduced by introducing the chance-constrained programming theory. To solve the model, a data-driven multi-objective evolutionary algorithm is designed, integrating Monte Carlo simulation with surrogate models to effectively reduce the computational cost of uncertainty estimation. Furthermore, a constraint prioritization strategy is developed to handle multiple conflict objectives, and complex constraints efficiently. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm exhibits excellent performance across networks of varying scales, providing robust decision support for multimodal transportation decision-making.

title: Riemannian Gradient Descent Method for Joint Blind Super-Resolution and Demixing
authors: Zeyu Xiang, Haifeng Wang, Jiayi Lv, Yujie Wang, Yuxue Wang, Yuxuan Ma, Jinchi Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) has emerged as a promising technology for next-generation wireless networks. In this work, we tackle an ill-posed parameter estimation problem within ISAC, formulating it as a joint blind super-resolution and demixing problem. Leveraging the low-rank structures of the vectorized Hankel matrices associated with the unknown parameters, we propose a Riemannian gradient descent (RGD) method. Our theoretical analysis demonstrates that the proposed method achieves linear convergence to the target matrices under standard assumptions. Additionally, extensive numerical experiments validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: A Neutral Point Voltage Balancing Control Method for Three-Level Three-Phase Four-Wire Inverters with Fewer Switching State Transitions
authors: Hongjun Shao, Ying Wang, Tao Liu, Hongjun Duan, Xia Wu
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: The four-leg three-level three-phase four-wire (TLTPFW) inverters combine the advantages of both the three-level topology and four-leg topology with low harmonic content, low voltage stress on the power devices, and high load carrying capacity. In this paper, a neutral-point (NP) voltage balancing control method with few switch-state transitions is proposed to completely eliminate low-frequency NP voltage oscillations while having the same number of switch-state transitions as a conventional carrier-based pulse width modulation (CBPWM). The proposed method uses discontinuous pulse width modulation (DPWM) in the region where the NP voltage balancing control capability of CBPWM is insufficient to achieve NP voltage balancing control in the whole region. In the DPWM method, the switching state of one leg remains unchanged during a single sampling period, the switching state of the other leg is switched twice, and the switching state of each of the remaining two legs is switched once, which ensures that the total number of switching transitions of the four legs is four during a single sampling period. Finally, the simulation and experimental studies of the proposed method are carried out, and the simulation and experimental results verify the correctness and effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Realizing Wavelet Transform via Neural Network
authors: Zhiguo Zhang, Junshan Zhong, Xiao Ma, Md Asrafur Rahman
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Wavelet transforms are powerful tools for signal analysis, but their integration with neural networks often relies on approximations that sacrifice accuracy in numerical computation. This paper presents a framework that achieves precise wavelet decomposition by combining neural networks with sampling theory. Our architecture is built up by using wavelet as activation functions and carefully selecting input weights derived from bandwidth of signals. We prove that our training algorithm can make output weights converge to true wavelet coefficients, avoiding limitations of numerical quadrature. Experiments validate our approaches, showing exact reconstruction of wavelet coefficients for multi-resolution analysis(MRAs). The results demonstrate how neural networks can inherently realize wavelet transforms without numerical error, supplying a new method for obtaining accurate wavelet coefficients for signal processing, via learning systems.

title: Lightweight Seizure Prediction via Cross-Modal Knowledge Distillation from Multi-Channel to Single-Channel EEG
authors: Xuanqi Zhang, Junyi Chen, Kehan Ye, Yue She, Xinru Xu, Lisha Zhong
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Epileptic seizure prediction is critical for improving patient safety and quality of life. However, most existing deep learning models rely on multi-channel electroencephalography (EEG), which limits wearability and practical deployment due to high hardware cost and computational complexity. This paper presents a novel cross-modal knowledge distillation framework that transfers discriminative representations from a multi-channel teacher network to a lightweight single-channel student network. The framework integrates output, feature, and attention distillation, enabling effective transfer of spatial-temporal patterns across modalities. Experiments on the CHB-MIT and Bonn datasets demonstrate that the student model achieves an AUC of 0.923 and PR-AUC of 0.943, while reducing parameters from $\mathbf{4. 4 M}$ to $\mathbf{8 7 K}(\mathbf{5 0} \times$ compression) and accelerating inference by $7.5 \times$. Ablation studies confirm that multi-level distillation, particularly attention guidance, plays a crucial role in maintaining prediction accuracy. The proposed method offers a promising solution for real-time, energy-efficient seizure prediction on wearable EEG devices, bridging the gap between high-performance models and practical clinical deployment.

title: Low-Power Machine Learning Models for Edge-Based Anomaly Detection in Wearable IoT Healthcare Devices
authors: Vindhya P Malagi, Shazia Shaikh, Manasi Vyankatesh Ghamande, Monica Bhutani, D. Ramva, P. Nisha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Wearable IoT devices: With the fast development of wearable technologies in the field of IoT., there is now the possibility of constant monitoring of the health of individuals and spotting any anomaly at an early stage., which can be greatly beneficial in providing personal health care. Nevertheless., it is still not hard to imagine using machine learning (ML) in resource-constrained edge devices because of the shortages in memory, energy, and processing capabilities. The current paper explores the most recent breakthroughs in the area of low-power ML models - namely, TinyML, model pruning, and quantization - that enables real-time anomaly detection in wearable healthcare systems. Besides the overview of edge computing frameworks (TensorFlow Lite for Microcontrollers and Edge Impulse), the given research provides a mathematical model and parametric investigation of a TinyML-based anomaly detection model. Through emulating a shallow CNN on the ARM Cortex-M4 architecture in respect to detecting ECG anomalies, we evaluate how well different models perform along with different latency, energy, and accuracy limits. Findings demonstrate that model size can be minimized by ~83%., energy use by ~65%., as well as latency by~61.” Compared to current compressed deep learning models, our results match them and are even better, which demonstrates the feasibility of shallow TinyML models in realistic edge-based healthcare systems that have low latencies, low power, and high accuracy. In this paper, the concluding observations are made on the scalability, interpretability, and moral concerns, which lead to a systematic roadmap on developing an effective wearable health system that is not only secure but also intelligent.

title: Generalized Integrated Probabilistic Data Association
authors: Ziqi Yang, Xiaoxue Li, Li Wang, Yue Jiang, Qiaoyu Li, Yatao Liu, Yong Luo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The IPDA (Integrated Probabilistic Data Association) algorithm is a traditional method in target tracking, demonstrating strong robustness in single-target scenarios. However, its inherent mechanisms lead to insufficient tracking accuracy in multi-target tracking. To address the limitations of IPDA in multi-target tracking, this paper proposes the GIPDA (Generalized Integrated Probabilistic Data Association) algorithm. GIPDA partitions and combines generalized joint events, calculates event probabilities using Bayesian principles, and further derives the existence probability for each target and trajectory. Simulation results demonstrate that with the exception of GIPDA1’s marginally inferior tracking accuracy under short sampling intervals, both GIPDA variants outperform IPDA and GPDA(Generalized Probabilistic Data Association) across all other operational conditions. Regarding target existence assessment, GIPDA maintains IPDA-comparable existence probability estimation capabilities.

title: A Novel Approach to Enhancing BER Metrics in PHOTON-Beetle Through Alternate MixColumnSerial Values
authors: Eman Malik, Maria Imdad
abstract: The need for lightweight yet safe cryptographic solutions is growing as resource-constrained technologies like embedded systems and Internet of Things devices evolve. This work investigates the fundamental transformation, MixColumnSerial, of the PHOTON-Beetle algorithm to find configurations that might enhance the security and performance of the approach. By means of systematic modification of the MixColumnSerial values and assessment of their impacts, this research aims to find configurations that improve the internal resilience of the algorithm while preserving its lightweight properties. Using structure analysis and implementation testing across many MixColumnSerial architectures, the method evaluates security posture and operational efficiency. The results show that certain substitute values improve structure without raising computation costs, therefore benefiting practical usage. This work presents an untested method for PHOTON-Beetle optimization, hence filling a vital need and providing fresh direction for safe and effective encryption in resource-constrained settings.

title: SDCNet: Stable Downward Continuation of Magnetic Anomalies by Depth Information Fusion
authors: Jinrong Shen, Zhenlong Hou, Jikang Wei, Xinyang Zhao, Jiahui Wang
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Downward continuation is an effective technique that enhances anomaly resolution and details. However, high-frequency noise is amplified with increasing continuation depth, which adversely affects data interpretation. A novel stable downward continuation network (SDCNet) model has been proposed to enhance the noise robustness and stability of downward continuation. By incorporating fully convolutional networks (FCN) and Transformer to introduce topographic features and depth information, the model achieves stable downward continuation of magnetic anomaly from a surface to arbitrary target plane or surface, which improves the flexibility of existing intelligent continuation methods. Tests on the synthetic model demonstrate that the proposed method maintains continuation stability while exhibiting noise robustness compared to conventional methods. For noisy data, the maximum reductions in relative error (RE) and root mean square error (RMSE) reach up to 78%. Real data application over the Decorah complex in northeastern Iowa, U. S. shows that the continuation results align well with the distribution of the rock mass, further validating the effectiveness and practicality of the SDCNet in downward continuation.

title: An Early Warning System for Remote Sensing of Wildfires
authors: Marta Oliveira, Luís Malarmey, Pedro Casau, Paulo Pedreiras, Sandra Millán Arias, Cristina Montesinos Barrios, João Barraca, Pedro Fonseca
abstract: In recent years, several parts of the world have experienced increasingly severe wildfires, causing extensive dam-age to forested areas and multiple casualties. The RAT_EOS_PC project, promoted by a consortium that includes CICYTEX and UA, aims to develop a low-cost forest fire monitoring and early warning system, based on wireless sensor network principles. The communication infrastructure is built around the LoRa Wanprotocol, which connects sensor nodes to gateways, and sub-sequently to network and application servers. Prior to sensor deployment, a study was conducted to determine the optimal placement of gateways. The system's IT infrastructure integrates a range of technologies, including Apache Kafka, Mosquitto, Logstash, Elasticsearch, ElastAlert, N8N, Kibana, and Nginx. To evaluate system performance, a prototype was implemented using a limited number of physical sensors, a set of simulated (virtual) sensors, and publicly available meteorological data via APIs. The results show that the system processes incoming data with response times that meet the standards required for emergency communication systems.

title: A New on-Board Preprocessing Algorithm for Ovarian Follicle Detection in Ultra Sonic Images
authors: Radhika Amar Desai, G Mahalakshmi, Chanthini Baskar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) have become a common health issue in women of reproductive age, leading to irregular menstrual cycles. Usually, PCOS ultrasonic images are characterized by stubborn noise in background and delicate boundaries between follicles making it difficult to effectively denoise and segment the image. A novel image segmentation technique called “salt segmentation technique” is introduced that effectively segments the follicles being robust to background noise. The method is an effective preprocessing step for further steps like classification of ovaries as infected with PCOS or not, determining follicle count, examining shape and size of follicles, categorization of cysts and determining a woman's fertility based on number of follicles. The effectiveness of our proposed techniques is proved by running machine learning models on raw and segmented images. We attained an accuracy of 99.48 % for SVM model to categorize it as infected ovaries or non-infected ovaries.

title: An Online Co-estimation Framework for Coupled Electro-Thermal-Aging Key State of Lithium-ion Batteries
authors: Wensai Ma, Yi Xie, Disheng Jiang, Haocheng Mao, Wei Li, Rui Yang, Satyam Panchal, Yangjun Zhang
abstract: Online acquisition of accurate battery electrical, thermal, and aging states is crucial for monitoring and management of batteries, especially in cloud-edge collaboration. In this paper, an online joint estimation method for state of charge (SOC), 3-dimensional state of temperature distribution (SOTD), and state of health (SOH) of batteries based on an electro-thermal-aging coupled model is proposed. Firstly, three well-chosen charging durations are leveraged as the aging features to achieve SOH estimation with the assistance of the extreme learning machine (ELM). Secondly, SOT is estimated through a lumped parameter thermal model (LPTM) and adaptive extended Kalman filter (AEKF), and SOTD is reconstructed using a well-designed fractal theory method (FTM) derived from the iterated function system (IFS) method and a Lindenmayer system (L-system), which ensures precise thermal state monitoring. Then, based on the parameter updating mechanism, the parameters of the equivalent circuit model (ECM) are adjusted in real time according to the accurate SOT and SOH, and the SOC is estimated by the AEKF. Subsequently, the proposed method is validated under different dynamic conditions and different temperatures, the validation results show that the proposed method can achieve accurate SOC-SOTD-SOH co-estimation with an error of no more than 2.14%, 1.37°C, and 1.26%, respectively. Lastly, the investigation of the SOT and SOH influence on SOC estimation reveals the important significance of the co-estimation framework.

title: GraphTrack-UAV: Robust Multi-Object Association in Aerial Videos via Message Passing Graph Neural Networks
authors: Yuchen Ling, Ying Lou, Yan Ding, Qingxin Cao, Zhizhen Rao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Multi-object tracking (MOT) in aerial videos presents unique challenges due to the complex nature of UAVcaptured scenes, including frequent occlusions, target density, scale variation, and dynamic backgrounds. Traditional tracking approaches often struggle under these conditions, and they rely heavily on shallow appearance or motion features, which leads to identity switches and fragmented trajectories. To address these issues, GraphTrack-UAV, a robust object association framework based on message-passing Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) is proposed. The proposed method constructs a spatio-temporal graph where nodes represent candidate detections across frames, and edges encode inter-object dependencies. A spatio-temporal graph pruning strategy is employed to ensure sparsity and computational efficiency. The message-passing mechanism enables the network to capture long-range dependencies, while feature fusion and node aggregation modules enhance robustness against occlusion and appearance variation. Extensive experiments and ablation studies on UAV aerial video datasets validate the superiority of our method in terms of accuracy, robustness, and generalization. Visualization results further illustrate the enhanced trajectory consistency and reduced identity switching achieved by GraphTrack-UAV.

title: Spatiotemporal Enhanced Joint Optimization for Spike Camera Based 3D Reconstruction
authors: Binqiang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Failure of traditional camera-based 3D reconstruction in high-speed scenarios due to temporal resolution limitations necessitates the use of high-temporal-resolution spike cameras. A unified optimization framework has been proposed for simultaneous image reconstruction, pose estimation, and 3D reconstruction. To achieve high-precision joint estimation, effective modeling of spike stream data is crucial to capture the intricate spatiotemporal characteristics. However, existing framework employing stacked convolutional architectures neglects multi-scale data properties inherent in the scene, leading to information loss. To address this deficiency in spatial modeling, we introduce a multi-scale feature architecture into the reconstruction network, leveraging convolutional kernels of varying sizes to explicitly enhance multi-scale modeling capabilities. Furthermore, to refine temporal modeling of the spike stream, an explicit temporal representation is integrated into the network architecture, augmenting overall temporal modeling capacity. Experimental results demonstrate that our method improves the PSNR by 0.628 compared to the baseline.

title: Joint Optimization of Multi-UAV Deployment and 3D Positioning in Traffic-Aware Aerial Networks
authors: Kamran Shafafi, Alaa Awad Abdellatif, Manuel Ricardo, Rui Campos
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) are a promising solution for next-generation wireless networks due to their mobility, rapid deployment, and ability to provide Line-of-Sight (LoS) connectivity. However, deploying multiple UAVs in realtime to meet dynamic, non-uniform traffic demands remains a significant challenge, especially when aiming to optimize network throughput and resource utilization. In this paper, we propose the Efficient Multi-UAV Traffic-Aware Deployment (EMTAD) algorithm, a scalable algorithm that jointly minimizes UAV count and optimizes 3D positioning based on real-time user distribution and traffic demand. In contrast to prior works that assume static user patterns or fixed UAV counts, EMTAD dynamically adapts UAV deployment to maximize spectral efficiency and satisfy userspecific Quality of Service (QoS) requirements. Simulation results demonstrate that EMTAD reduces the number of UAVs required and achieves superior aggregate throughput compared to baseline approaches.

title: A Multi-Head and Multi-Level Attention Fusion Approach for Industrial Sci-Tech Achievement Classification with Large Language Model Enhancement
authors: Yilin Xie, Kun Ding, Yumeng Fang, Jing Wang, Bin Wang
publish: Proceedings of the 2025 9th International Conference on Big Data and Internet of Things
abstract: None

title: First Experimental Measurement of Prompt Gamma Imaging with Real-Time Neutron Rejection via Pulse Shape Discrimination
authors: O. Halfon, C. Riboldi, K. Urban, G. Borghi, M. Carminati, M. Donetti, M. Pullia, F. Camera, C. Fiorini
publish: IEEE Transactions on Radiation and Plasma Medical Sciences
abstract: Prompt Gamma Imaging (PGI) holds strong potential for range verification in hadrontherapy, yet its performance is challenged by neutron-induced background, especially in carbon ion treatments. To mitigate this issue, a dedicated imaging system integrating Pulse Shape Discrimination (PSD) capabilities for real-time neutron discrimination was designed and experimentally validated. The detector employs a CLYC scintillator coupled to SiPM arrays and compact acquisition electronics, allowing real-time computation of digital PSD coefficients. Interaction point reconstruction within the crystal is achieved through an Artificial Neural Network (ANN), whose inputs are the SiPM signal amplitudes processed by four custom 16-channel GAMMA ASICs. In this work, the system is operated as a Prompt Gamma (PG) camera using a knife-edge collimator to retrieve PG emission profiles from the irradiated target, enabling range verification while efficiently reducing uncorrelated neutron contributions. We present the outcomes of the first experimental PGI campaign at Centro Nazionale di Adroterapia Oncologica (CNAO) in Pavia (Italy), during carbon ion irradiation, demonstrating, according to our knowledge, the first improvement in Bragg Peak (BP) localization precision enabled by PSD-based neutron background rejection.
