title: Development of a new S-shaped superconducting hexapole magnet for ECR ion source
authors: Shaoqing Wei, Zhichao Chen, Jiaxin Li, Zijie Lin, Siyu Ning, Lu Gao, Shengquan Xue, Fang Liu, Huajun Liu, Zhan Zhang
abstract: With the increasing demand for high-energy particles in accelerators, there is a need to develop compact, small-volume, and high-energy electron cyclotron resonance ion sources (ECRISs). As a key component in heavy ion accelerators and therapy facilities, ECRISs are capable of producing highly charged ions. A novel S-shaped hexapole magnet structure was proposed in 2016, which simplifies the distribution of Lorentz interaction forces in ECRIS superconducting magnets and facilitates achieving the required axial field. However, the fabrication of S-shaped hexapole poses significant challenges. Based on this design, we developed a superconducting S-shaped hexapole prototype for a 14.5 GHz microwave frequency using NbTi. A former with slotted ends was designed to enable the S-shaped winding. A small prototype of S-shaped hexapole used only one cable to realize winding, achieving a continuous uninterrupted winding both from the inside to the outside and from the outside to the inside. During 4.2 K cold testing, the coil attained a self‑field of 1.5 T at a current of 480 A. Under an 8 T background field, it carried 232 A with only a single quench, reaching 98.22% of its load line.

title: Analytical Investigation of Short-Circuit Protection and Post-Fault Operation in Dual Three-Phase PMSMs for Hybrid Electric Counter-Rotating Compressor Applications
authors: Yinghui Yang, Markus Henke, Georg Möhlenkamp
abstract: The hybrid electric counter-rotating compressor (CRC) has the potential to improve power-specific fuel consumption in aircraft engines. However, due to its cascaded structure, a reduction or loss of driving power in a single compressor stage can significantly degrade the overall compressor performance. A short-circuit fault is a typical electrical failure in an electric motor that can lead to a complete loss of driving power. One innovative post-fault operation strategy is to utilize the braking capability of the failed motor at low speed to lock its corresponding compressor stage. In this way, the failed stage can function as a stator stage, still providing degraded flow-guiding capability and preventing reverse rotation. This article investigates the short-circuit protection strategy and post-fault operation of dual three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motors (DTP-PMSMs) for hybrid electric CRC applications. Analytical models are developed to characterize the post-fault behavior of the DTP-PMSM. Key design factors are defined, and their influence on post-fault performance is analyzed. Critical post-fault operating points are identified to evaluate and compare different protection strategies. Based on these results, an optimized short-circuit protection strategy is proposed for DTP-PMSMs in CRC applications. Finally, the analytical findings and the proposed strategy are validated through simulation.

title: Deep Learning for Crop Health: Lightweight Modified DenseNet for Cotton and Corn Leaf Disease Detection
authors: Bushra Tayyaba, Asifa Munsif Ali, Muhammad Usman Ghani Khan
abstract: Leaf diseases significantly reduce crop yields, making timely and efficient detection crucial. While recent deep learning methods are effective, they are often computationally intensive, limiting their use in real-time and resource-constrained settings. To address this, modified versions of DenseNet and ResNet architectures are proposed using depth-wise separable convolutions to enhance computational efficiency without compromising feature extraction. The proposed lightweight models enable real-time leaf disease detection with minimal resources. The performance is evaluated on two agricultural datasets: Cotton Leaf Disease (seven classes) and Corn Leaf Disease (four classes). Experimental results show that the modified DenseNet outperforms the original ResNet, DenseNet, and MobileNet models regarding accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, achieving 97% accuracy on the corn dataset and 96% on the cotton dataset. Additionally, it demonstrated improved training efficiency with fewer parameters and layers. This study emphasizes the potential of combining dense connectivity with depth-wise separable convolutions for effective and efficient leaf disease detection.

title: Joint Segmentation and Classification with Feature Aggregation and Distance Perception in Breast Ultrasound Images
authors: Yang Wen, Jixiang Wang, Ruhan Liu, Zhiquan He, Wuzhen Shi, Lei Bi
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Segmentation and classification of breast tumors are critical for computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) using breast ultrasound (BUS), a non-invasive modality for early cancer detection. However, BUS images present challenges such as low contrast, speckle noise, irregular morphology, and indistinct boundaries, which hinder automated analysis. Existing multi-task learning frameworks that utilize shared encoders often suffer from inadequate task-specific features and interference between objectives, resulting in suboptimal performance. To address this issue, we present MDFANet, a novel multi-task learning network designed to optimize tumor segmentation and classification in BUS images. The segmentation network incorporates a Feature Enhancement Aggregation (FEA) module, which enriches semantic representations by fusing multi-scale features from both encoder and decoder stages. Moreover, we introduce a distance auxiliary branch to facilitate accurate tumor boundary localization by integrating hierarchical features with spatial contextual cues. To balance the optimization of segmentation and classification objectives, we further employ a sample-adaptive joint loss function that dynamically adjusts task contributions based on the consistency of cross-task predictions. Experimental results on a BUS dataset demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art approaches in both segmentation accuracy and classification reliability.

title: A Comparative Study of Measured and Simulated DSRC Performance in Urban V2X Scenario
authors: Fidel Alejandro Rodriguez-Corbo, Diego Fernández García, Mikel Celaya-Echarri, Leyre Azpilicueta, Imanol Picallo, Cesar Vargas-Rosales, Francisco Falcone
abstract: The progressive implementation of Intelligent Transportation Systems relies on the integration of multiple systems within different infrastructures, such as transportation pathways, energy grid or information and communication systems. Wireless connectivity plays a key role, owing to its adaptive and ubiquitous nature, leading to Vehicle to Everything communication links. In this work, the analysis of Dedicated Short-Range Communications within a Vehicle to Everything connectivity scenario will be analyzed, by means of wireless channel simulation as well as experimental validation within a real network deployment at Campus Monterrey in TEC Monterrey, Mexico. The results provide insight to performing optimization and planning for future autonomous vehicle connectivity within the surrounding urban area.

title: Synaptic Plasticity in Spiking Neural Networks for Episodic Memory
authors: Chenjun Xu, Wenwu Jiang, Rui Yan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Episodic memory is a core component of the human brain, and how information is stored and learned in the neural system is closely related to the representation of memory. Synaptic plasticity, an important mechanism for memory formation, allows the strength of synaptic connections between neurons to vary with the timing of spiking neurons, thus enabling neurons to learn and remember information efficiently. Inspired by the way the brain encodes and processes information, spiking neural networks (SNNs) have been widely used to model memory formation due to their biological plausibility. In this paper, we propose an episodic memory model based on synaptic plasticity and a temporal feedback connection, aiming to simulate the process of memory storage and recall in a biological neural system. In this process, the model incorporates a soft K-Winner-Take-All mechanism within the perceptual memory layer, enabling the selective activation of neurons. Simultaneously, synaptic plasticity is employed to dynamically adjust the synaptic weights connecting the perceptual memory layer and the response memory layer, thereby implementing the storage of information. Subsequently, through generated synapses, the cued information is integrated through the time-step feedback connection, gradually recovering the complete memory content. Experimental results demonstrate that our model successfully achieves the memory storage and recall processes with superior recall performance even when the recall cues are disturbed. In addition, we validate the critical role of the soft K-Winner-Take-All mechanism in enhancing recall performance.

title: Research on Chinese Named Entity Recognition Method Based on Multi Feature Fusion and BILSTM
authors: Yanan He, Tianhao Ji, Dazi Li
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: With the exponential growth of textual data driven by the Internet of Things, Chinese Named Entity Recognition (CNER) has become increasingly important in natural language processing. However, challenges such as ambiguous entity boundaries, semantic complexity, and out-of-vocabulary (OOV) issues significantly impact CNER performance. To address these challenges, we propose a novel multi-feature fusion framework. The model integrates character-level embeddings generated by pre-trained BERT, static word embeddings from Jieba segmentation, and syntactic dependency trees processed through Graph Attention Networks (GAT), with the three features fused at the character level. Experimental results show that our model outperforms the baseline model, achieving higher F1 scores across four benchmark datasets. Additionally, we contribute an industrial dataset with technical specifications and expert annotations for chemical plant desulfurization units, on which our model demonstrates optimal performance.

title: Priority-Aware Multi-UAV Search Path Planning with Evolutionary Algorithms and MARL*
authors: İslam Güven, Umut İlkbahar, Buse İnç, Evşen Yanmaz
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly used to search and monitor operations for various tasks. However, their operational efficiency depends on advanced path planning that can balance conflicting objectives, such as minimizing mission time, maintaining connectivity to a ground control station (GCS), and prioritizing high-risk zones with time limitations. This paper formulates this challenge as a multi-objective optimization problem and provides a comparison between Evolutionary Algorithms (EAs) and Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (MARL). We implement and evaluate a Genetic Algorithm (GA), NSGA-II, NSGA-III, and an agent trained with Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO). Using a case study from a real-world risk map, we assess performance on mission duration, connectivity, and the speed of visiting priority and deadline-constrained regions. The results show that while EAs are computationally faster and effective for smaller grids, the PPO agent achieves superior performance, significantly reducing mission time while adjusting their trajectories for prioritized regions. Our analysis demonstrates the trade-offs between these methods and highlights the potential of MARL to develop more adaptive and effective disaster response systems.

title: Deep Neural Networks for Optimal Donor Matching in HLA-Haploidentical Transplantation
authors: Kaliyamoorthi P, R. Bhuvaneswari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT), particularly human leukocyte antigen (HLA)-haploidentical bone marrow transplantation (haplo-BMT), has emerged as a vital therapeutic option for hematologic malignancies when fully matched donors are unavailable. Despite significant advances, optimal donor selection remains a multifactorial challenge due to complex interactions between clinical, biological, and immunogenetic variables. This study explores the application of machine learning and deep learning techniques to enhance donor selection and predict donor availability within the context of HLA-haploidentical transplantation. By leveraging structured data from national and international donor registries, key demographic, behavioral, and clinical features, including age, registry duration, health history, donor engagement, and survey responses—are extracted and modeled using algorithms such as support vector machines (SVM), gradient boosted machines (GBM), and deep neural networks (DNN). The analysis evaluates transplant outcomes, response probabilities to confirmatory typing (CT) requests, and post-transplant complications such as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), integrating additional variables like donor telomere length and cytogenetic markers. SHAP value interpretation aids in understanding feature contributions to model predictions. Comparative analyses between haploidentical and HLA-identical sibling transplants are also presented to assess clinical effectiveness. The study demonstrates that data-driven approaches can significantly improve donor selection strategies, enhance prediction accuracy, and inform real-time clinical decision-making, ultimately aiming to improve patient survival and transplantation success.

title: Enhancing Crop Prediction and Soil Fertility Management through Bayesian Model Averaging and Machine Learning*
authors: Rasmita Dash, Ujjwal Kumar Kamila, Madhusmita Sahu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Agriculture plays a vital role in global economic growth, but unsustainable practices are degrading soil health and threatening food security. Soil nutrient depletion adversely affects crop yields, underscoring the need for reliable predictions of crop types and soil fertility. This study addresses uncertainty in agricultural predictions by applying Bayesian Model Averaging (BMA), which combines the outputs of multiple Machine Learning (ML) models to improve prediction accuracy. In agricultural environments, uncertainty arises from complex data and varying soil conditions. Rather than relying on a single model, BMA integrates predictions from multiple models, weighting them by performance for more robust results. BMA accounts for model uncertainty by assigning posterior probabilities, reflecting each model’s reliability. This offers probabilistic predictions that quantify uncertainty and improve decision-making. In this work, environmental parameters like nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, temperature, humidity, pH, and rainfall were used, employing advanced models such as Extra Trees Classifier (ETC), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Nu Support Vector Classification (NuSVC) for crop prediction (ETC achieving the highest performance: mean precision, recall, and F1 score of 0.994). For soil fertility prediction, Logistic Regression(LR) outperformed other models (mean precision, recall, and F1 score of 0.99). By incorporating uncertainty, BMA enhances predictions for crop selection and soil management, contributing to Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) 2: Zero Hunger.

title: Tree-Based Machine Learning Models for Phishing Email Detection
authors: Sunshine O. Casido, Jaydee C. Ballaho, Edwin I. Arip
abstract: This study addresses the increasing threat of phishing emails, a significant cybersecurity challenge that can lead to severe financial and data breaches. The primary objective is to develop robust machine learning models to accurately classify emails as safe or phishing. A dataset of 6,331 emails was employed to train and evaluate several models, including J48 Decision Tree, Simple CART, Random Tree, ADTree, REPTree, and Random Forest. The models were assessed using metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-Score, and ROC AUC. The Random Forest model achieved the highest accuracy of 98.73%, precision of 100.0%, recall of 97.21%, F1-Score of 98.59%, and ROC AUC of 98.61%, demonstrating its effectiveness in identifying phishing attempts. In contrast, the Majority Voting Algorithm did not enhance performance metrics across the models. The findings highlight the superiority of the Random Forest algorithm in phishing email detection, particularly in classifying unseen data. Future research should focus on enhancing algorithms to better capture linguistic and contextual nuances, integrating additional indicators like metadata and sender reputation, and complementing technical solutions with user education to strengthen overall cybersecurity defenses.

title: Intelligent Spectrum Management in RIS-Assisted CRNs: A BiLSTM-Based Approach with AMRFO Fine-Tuning
authors: Mallikarjun Dheshmuk, S. B. Kumbalavati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The shift from 5G to the new 6G paradigm is defining a watershed moment in the history of wireless communication. The future of 6G networks will be shaped by improvements in system architectures and technology brought about by this transformation. A potential new approach to improving wireless communication performance in ever-changing surroundings is Cognitive Radio Networks (CRNs) aided by Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS). But, because wireless channels are complicated and dynamic, optimizing and allocating spectrum in real-time is still difficult. To offer a new framework that combines the Adaptive Manta-Ray Foraging Optimization (AMRFO) algorithm for dynamic spectrum allocation and optimization with a Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM) network to tackle this difficulty. The BiLSTM model leverages its ability to capture long-range dependencies in both forward and backward temporal sequences, enabling accurate prediction of spectrum availability and optimal allocation strategies. To further enhance the decision-making process, the AMRFO algorithm is employed for fine-tuning, ensuring an optimal balance between exploration and exploitation while adapting to varying network conditions. The proposed approach dynamically adjusts RIS phase shifts and spectrum allocation to maximize spectral efficiency, minimize interference, and improve overall network performance. Extensive simulations validate the effectiveness of our method, demonstrating superior adaptability, lower computational complexity, and enhanced spectral efficiency compared to traditional optimization techniques. The results highlight the potential of the BiLSTM-AMRFO framework for real-time spectrum management in RIS-assisted CRNs, paving the way for future advancements through hybrid deep learning models and advanced metaheuristic optimization techniques for intelligent wireless communication systems.

title: Enhancing the Deep Learning-Based Pet Imaging Super-Resolution for Facial Expression Images
authors: Rahul P. Mahajan, Nilesh Jain
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Facial expression recognition in PET imaging is crucial for understanding emotional states. PET image reconstruction and noise reduction play a crucial role in enhancing medical image analysis and diagnostic accuracy. This study presents HybridResIncepNet, a deep-learning model that integrates ResNet50V2 and InceptionV3 for PET image classification and noise reduction. The methodology involves pre-processing PET facial expression images, dataset is split into training and testing, with one-hot encoding applied to labels. When training the model, the Adam optimizer is used together with an Early Stopping method to avoid overfitting and categorical cross-entropy loss. Results on standard metrics demonstrate a 97% accuracy rate on testing data and a 100% accuracy rate on training data, which is a substantial improvement over ResNet50 and DenseNet-121. The model achieves near-perfect precision, recall, and F1score, demonstrating its robustness for PET image classification. The proposed approach enhances feature extraction, improves diagnostic reliability, and reduces noise, making it a promising tool for computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems.

title: An Analytical Approach to Fixed Point results for Sehgal Guseman Contraction in Extended b−Metric Spaces
authors: Haitham Qawaqneh, Habes Alsamir
abstract: This article investigates Sehgal Guseman contraction and develops innovative fixed-point results in the context of extended b-metric spaces. The discoveries improve and broaden previous findings in fixed-point theory, thereby contributing to the advancement of metric space research. We also provide an illustrated examples to back up our theoretical findings.

title: Modulating Effort Sensations in virtual reality: A Parameter-Based Haptic Feedback Approach
authors: Yann Glémarec, Tom Roy, Quentin Galvane, Gurvan Lécuyer, Anatole Lécuyer, Ferran Argelaguet
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Virtual reality is becoming increasingly popular, and modern haptic equipment, such as vibrotactile suits, haptic gloves, and force-feedback controllers, offers new means of interaction within virtual environments, significantly enhancing user experience. When interacting with virtual objects, combined visual and haptic feedback simulates the physical sensations of grasping, lifting, or moving real objects. This sensorimotor feedback is essential for inducing a sense of presence and agency, yet it remains challenging to reproduce in the absence of reliable haptic cues. In this study, we design and evaluate several haptic metaphors using combinations of vibrotactile design parameters to simulate the lifting effort associated with light to heavy objects. These parameters include primitive signals, intensity, spatial density, propagation, and temporal density. Our contribution is threefold. First, we propose a method for modulating perceived physical effort by extending signal intensity with spatial and temporal density, which together reflect the effort required to lift an object. Second, we present a user study in which participants compared haptic effects and ranked them according to perceived lifting effort, comfort, and confidence, allowing us to assess the influence of each parameter. Third, we report the results of a second study in which participants evaluated vibrotactile effects when lifting different virtual objects. The findings confirm the importance of intensity and spatial density, as well as the influence of graphical representation on perceived effort. This research provides practical insights for designing haptic-enabled virtual reality systems and offers guidance for developers seeking to create more expressive and believable vibrotactile interactions.

title: Intelligent estimation for the local pulse wave velocity based on the time-frequency image of pulse wave
authors: Wenxia Song, Li Deng, Zhi Chen, Yi An, Xin Wang, Youjun Lu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, an intelligent method for the carotid local pulse wave velocity (CLPWV) estimation based on the timefrequency image of pulse wave was proposed. First, a database of the local pulse wave propagation along a segment of carotid artery in 4374 virtual adults with different hemodynamic parameters was built. Second, the texture energy features calculated from the time-frequency images of the pulse waves were combined with such parameters as age and heart rate used as the multi-source dataset, and then fed into the following methods for the CLPWV estimation: multilayer perceptron (MLP), Gradient Boost Regression (GBR), Support Vector Regression (SVR), Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). To investigate the impact of the noise and frame frequency on the CLPWV estimation accuracy, various data sets were created in the different noise and frame frequency conditions. The results showed that the MLP model performed the best overall and was less affected by noise and frame frequency with an average root mean squared error of 0.201, the SVR model second. These research findings are expected to provide both a theoretical foundation and technical support for the early and precise clinical assessment of the local carotid arterial elasticity in healthy people.

title: Computational Modeling and Performance Evaluation of Enhanced Orthopedic Bone Cements with Nanoparticles
authors: Safaa Gamal, Mina Mikhail, Nancy Salem, Mohamed Tarek El-Wakad, Reda Abdelbaset
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Computational modeling has become a cornerstone in biomedical engineering, enabling the virtual evaluation of materials and implants under simulated physiological conditions. Traditional bone cements, such as pure poly methyl methacrylate (PMMA), are widely used in orthopedic applications; however, they often exhibit limitations including brittleness, low fracture toughness, and poor fatigue resistance, which may compromise long-term implant stability. This study aims to address these limitations of traditional bone cements, such as pure poly methyl methacrylate (PMMA), including brittleness, low fracture toughness, and poor fatigue resistance, which may compromise long-term implant stability. by investigating the mechanical enhancement of PMMA through nanoparticle (NPs) reinforcement using advanced finite element analysis (FEA). Five different formulations were evaluated, including a control sample of pure PMMA and four composites reinforced with magnesium oxide (MgO), titanium dioxide <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{TiO}_{2})$</tex>, calcium phosphate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{Ca}_{3}\left(\text{PO}_{4}\right)_{2}\right)$</tex>, and aluminum oxide <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\text{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)$</tex> NPs. A 3D computational model of a hip joint, incorporating a 5 mm cement layer, was developed using ANSYS simulator software to simulate walking load conditions. Key mechanical responses, including total deformation and von Mises stress, were analyzed for each material. The results demonstrated that the addition of nano-additives significantly improved mechanical performance, with total deformation reduced by up to 91% compared to unmodified PMMA. This research underscores the value of computational simulation in addressing the mechanical shortcomings of conventional bone cements, supporting the development of more reliable and durable orthopedic materials through data-driven design and optimization.

title: A Cognitive Jamming Strategy Generation for Multifunction Radar via Action-Dependent Contrastive Predictive Coding
authors: Jianxin Li, Tian Tian, Weiwei Fan, Li Chao Yang, Jingjing Cai, Feng Zhou
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In modern electronic warfare, developing adaptive jamming strategy generation methods targeting multifunction radars (MFRs) is critical. However, the high flexibility of MFRs, coupled with the complexity of countermeasure environments, results in incomplete and uncertain radar information, thereby significantly increasing the difficulty of learning effective jamming strategies. To tackle this challenge, we formulate the sequential decision-making process in radar countermeasures as a Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) and propose a jamming strategy generation method based on action-dependent contrastive predictive coding. Specifically, we incorporate a belief representation module into the conventional reinforcement learning (RL) framework. This module, independent of the strategy learning, employs self-supervised contrastive learning to construct the belief representation of radar states, thereby providing more effective information support for the jamming strategy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms existing RL-based methods in terms of jamming performance.

title: Enhancing Fraud Detection in Financial Transactions: A Bio-Inspired Fine-Tuned CatBoost Approach
authors: Naresh Jetty, Prashanth V, Sanat Pattanaik, Mrinmoy Aich
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Financial institutions and individuals alike are vulnerable to the growing number and sophistication of fraudulent operations in today’s digital financial ecosystem. The most recent research from the Organised Crime and Corruption Reporting Project (OCCRP) estimates that global financial crimes in 2023 caused damages of $31 trillion. The integrity and equity of the international monetary system are gravely endangered by these transgressions, which encompass embezzlement, tax evasion, illicit trade, and money laundering. Governments and financial institutions have tried to limit these activities, but criminals still use developing technology like cryptocurrencies and intricate financial networks to avoid discovery. Using the CatBoost algorithm that has been fine-tuned in conjunction with the Cat Swarm Updated Black Widow (CSU-BW) optimisation model, this study suggests a hybrid fraud detection approach to tackle these difficulties. For reliable and scalable fraud detection, the CatBoost algorithm is used as the main classification model because of its proficiency with categorical data. The CSU-BW fine-tuner is a bio-inspired hybrid optimisation method that optimises hyperparameters and improves feature selection to promote classification accuracy. It is introduced to enhance performance. To compare the suggested model to more conventional machine learning algorithms and test it on datasets of actual financial transactions. A number of important performance metrics, score, were outperformed by conventional methods in the experiments conducted by CSU-BW on the CatBoost model. Confusion matrix analysis adds credence to its credibility as a technique for detecting financial fraud by confirming its high true positive rate and low false positive rate. This research introduces a high-performance, scalable fraud detection model that can adjust to new fraud trends by combining bio-inspired optimisation with sophisticated ensemble learning. Increased confidence in digital financial transactions, reduced risk of financial loss, and improved security are all goals of the suggested approach. Additional ways to enhance financial institutions’ fraud protection tactics can be investigated in future studies through the use of adaptive learning mechanisms, blockchain integration, and real-time fraud detection.

title: Multi-Array Fusion Localization Based on the Improved PSO Algorithm
authors: Yue Kan, Yapeng Hu, Fusheng Zha, Xingqi Yuan, Peiying Xu, Yong Zhao
abstract: In the sound localization system with the Time Difference of Arrival, due to the complex array structure and the numerous sensors, etc., the localization accuracy of single-array targets deteriorates significantly in the presence of environmental noise and a considerable distance. Aiming at this problem, a novel multi-array fusion localization is proposed in this letter. This approach initially estimates the target locations by each single array to obtains the spatial lines separately. Subsequently, the suboptimal target locations is obtained based on the geometric relationship between the spatial lines. Finally, through solving the equation constructed by the shortest distance between suboptimal target locations based on the least square method and obtains the optimal target location is obtained. Furthermore, this paper introduces an improved particle swarm optimization algorithm to solve the data fusion equation. Simulations and experiments using a self built localization platform are conducted to validate the proposed method. The results indicate that the fusion localization method proposed in this letter possesses higher accuracy and stability.

title: Detecting Phishing Websites Using an Optimized CNN Model: Leveraging Mantis Search Algorithm and SMOTE for Improved Accuracy
authors: Naresh Jetty, Mahantesh Mathapati, Sanat Pattanaik, Prashanth V
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: With the proliferation of new technology, having access to the internet has become an absolute necessity for a wide range of services. The unauthorised acquisition of personal information, passwords, and identifiers is just one of many security risks that arise with an internet connection. If an attacker wants access to a user's personal information, they will employ a phishing website. In social engineering assaults, the perpetrator creates a website that looks and feels authentic, entices the victim to visit it, and then uses that information to send them to the genuine site. The development of a powerful detector capable of filtering out phishing websites and preventing their online activity is imperative, given the critical nature of this problem. In order to identify the phoney URLs in the publically available dataset, an optimised Convolutional neural network is employed. The Mantis Search Algorithm (MSA) is used to fine-tune the CNN's parameters, which in turn enhances the classification accuracy. The classifier receives the Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) as input in order to ensure that the input data is balanced. The suggested detector has been shown to be resilient in a series of experiments, which achieved excellent detection accuracy on the test set. Also, the suggested detector worked wonderfully when tested with random URLs. Incorporating the MSA mechanism into the CNN model enhanced its efficiency and detection accuracy for phishing website detection, according to the reported results.

title: Multi-Population Evolutionary Neural Architecture Search via Multiple Zero-Cost Proxies
authors: Jiehui Feng, Wu Lin, Qingling Zhu, Songbai Liu, Junkai Ji, Qiuzhen Lin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Zero-cost proxies have attracted growing attention in neural architecture search (NAS) for their efficiency in evaluating neural architectures at low computational cost. However, empirical studies have revealed that zero-cost proxies exhibit inherent biases, leading to performance degradation in complex scenarios. To alleviate this limitation, this paper proposes the Multi-Proxy Multi-Population Evolutionary Algorithm (MMEA) that integrates the strengths of multiple complementary proxies to improve search effectiveness. Specifically, each sub-population is associated with a distinct zero-cost proxy that serves as its optimization objective for approximating the performance of candidate architectures. Subsequently, multiple high-performance architectures are evolved within each sub-population under the guidance of their respective proxies. Furthermore, the Low-Fidelity Adaptive Proxy Selection Mechanism (LAPSM) is proposed to identify the most promising architecture by leveraging limited training resources to effectively select the most suitable proxy. Experimental results on the CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ImageNet16-120 datasets. The result demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art NAS algorithms.

title: Learning Constraints from Stochastic Partially-Observed Closed-Loop Demonstrations
authors: Chih-Yuan Chiu, Zhouyu Zhang, Glen Chou
abstract: We present a method for learning unknown parametric constraints from locally-optimal input-output trajectory data. We assume the data is generated by rollouts of stochastic nonlinear dynamics, under a single state or output feedback law and initial condition but distinct noise realizations, to robustly satisfy underlying constraints despite worst-case noise outcomes. We encode the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions of this robust optimal feedback control problem within a feasibility problem to recover constraints consistent with the local optimality of the demonstrations. We prove that our constraint learning method (i) accurately recovers the demonstrator’s policy, and (ii) conservatively estimates the set of policies that ensure constraint satisfaction despite worst-case noise realizations. Moreover, we perform sensitivity analysis, proving that when demonstrations are corrupted by transmission error, the inaccuracy in the learned feedback law scales linearly in the error magnitude. Empirically, our method accurately recovers unknown constraints from simulated noisy, closed-loop demonstrations generated using dynamics, both linear and nonlinear, (e.g., unicycle and quadrotor) and a range of feedback mechanisms.

title: Compact Loop Antenna Enabling Enhanced-Lower Hemisphere Radiation for Wireless Earphones
authors: Shiming Liu, Jianhua Xie, Yan Wang
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Achieving efficient downward radiation within the limited space of wireless earphones remains a significant challenge, which contributes to maintaining reliable links with smartphones. This letter proposes an earphone antenna that realizes enhanced lower-hemisphere radiation on the head by employing an optimized compact loop configuration. The fabricated prototype exhibits a −6 dB impedance bandwidth fully covering the ISM-2.4 GHz band. Measurements demonstrate an average efficiency of −9.1 dB and a lower-hemisphere radiation proportion (LHRP) of up to 71% under on-head conditions. These results verify the feasibility of the proposed design and indicate its strong potential for future development in wireless earphone applications.

title: A Semantic—Visual—Physical Consistency Verification Method for the Digital Standard Human Based on Multimodal Large Models
authors: Jiajun Sun, Jianwei Niu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: This paper presents a semantic-visual-physical consistency verification framework for the Digital Standard Human, powered by multimodal large models. The proposed approach integrates semantic parsing, visual recognition, and physical constraint validation to enable high-precision consistency analysis of human actions in digital twin applications. At the semantic layer, large language models (DeepSeek) parse natural language instructions and generate structured semantic vectors. The visual layer leverages Qwen2VL for frame-level action recognition and temporal feature modeling, while the physical layer incorporates standardized ergonomic databases and dynamic models to validate physical feasibility. Experiments on two representative tasks—object retrieval from the ground and overhead lifting—demonstrate that the integration of multimodal large models enhances semantic-visual and semantic-physical consistency, achieving overall consistency scores of 0.73 and 0.76, respectively. The results highlight the framework's effectiveness in reducing semantic ambiguity and improving alignment between task descriptions, motion recognition, and physical validation. Future work will focus on optimizing inference efficiency, integrating 3D reconstruction and physics simulation, and incorporating individualized ergonomic parameters to further improve accuracy and scalability.

title: EM-Net: A Deep Learning Model Using Enhanced Attention and Multi-Scale Feature Fusion for Text Image Forgery Detection
authors: Kaiqi Zhao, Yan Xiang, Shicheng Dong, Xiaochen Yuan, Pengfei Du
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an EM-Net for detecting the tiny regions of subtle features, which includes three stages. First, a Multi-scale Feature Extraction module (MSFE-module) is used to extract multi-scale and multi-layer feature information. A Feature Enhanced (FE-module) catches the key information in different scales and refines the results by assigning more weights to forgery areas. Therefore valuable features can be enhanced while irrelevant information is suppressed. As the network is constantly downsampling the image, the resolution becomes small. To restore the size, in the Feature Fusion decoder module (FFU-module), the multi-level information by integrating the global features and location details, so as to improve the performance of locating the forgery areas. To demonstrate the validity of our model, we compare the performance of the proposed EM-Net with state-of-art methods. The results show that our performance was excellent on the testing dataset.

title: S-Tiering: A Unified HW/SW Solution for Memory Tiering based on the Standard CXL Hotness Monitoring Unit
authors: Seunghak Lee, Wonjae Lee, Hojin Nam, Jehoon Park, Youngshin Park, Heesoo Kim, Junhyeok Im, Jinin So, Raghu Vamsi Krishna Talanki, Praful Ramesh O, Rajeev Verma, Taeksang Song, Wonhwa Shin, Sangjoon Hwang
abstract:
In this paper, we propose S-Tiering, a unified hardware and software solution for memory tiering based on the standard CXL Hotness Monitoring Unit (CHMU). S-Tiering consists of hardware components that comply with CHMU hardware specification defined in the CXL 3.2 Specification, and software components that control hardware components. Based on these components, S-Tiering minimizes the access to CXL memory by properly steering page migration.

We evaluate various probabilistic data structure algorithms and adopt a Count-Min Sketch-based Hot Page Tracker that achieves 99% accuracy with only 0.3% tracking buffer overhead compared to assigning a dedicated counter for every 4KB page. We implement hardware components of S-Tiering on an Field-Programmable Gate Array board and software components of S-Tiering on Ubuntu 22.04 with Linux-v6.8 kernel. We evaluate the performance impact of S-Tiering on benchmarks representative of real applications (e.g., High Performance Computing, Graph-processing, In-Memory Database). S-Tiering achieves a performance improvement of up to 193% compared to first-touch allocation and outperforms AutoNUMA memory tiering by 184%p. S-Tiering minimizes the memory access to CXL memory and increases the bandwidth utilization of DDR memory up to ×11.

title: Sketch2Avatar: Geometry-Guided 3D Full-Body Human Generation in 360° from Hand-Drawn Sketches
authors: Ziwei Chen, Qiang Li, Jie Zhang, Anthony Kong, Ping Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Generating full-body humans in 360° has broad applications in digital entertainment, online education and art design. Existing works primarily rely on coarse conditions such as body pose to guide the generation, lacking detailed control over the synthesized results. Regarding this limitation, sketches offer a promising alternative as an expressive condition that enables more explicit and precise control. However, current sketch-based generation methods focus on faces or common objects, how to transfer sketches into 360° full-body humans remains unexplored. We first propose two straightforward strategies: adapting sketch-based 3D face generation to full-body human or lifting sketch-based 2D human generation to 3D format through a two-stage approach. Unfortunately, both methods result in unsatisfactory degradation of generation quality. To bridge this gap, in this work, we propose Sketch2Avatar, the first generative model to achieve 3D full-body human generation from hand-drawn sketches. Our model is capable of synthesizing sketch-aligned and 360°-consistent full-body human images by leveraging the geometry information extracted from sketches to guide the 3D representation generation and neural rendering. Specifically, we propose sketch-guided 3D representation generation to model the 3D human and maintain the alignment between input sketches and generated humans. Our transformer-based generator incorporates spatial feature guidance and latent modulation derived from sketches to produce high-quality 3D representations. Additionally, our designed body aware neural rendering utilizes 3D human body priors from sketches, simplifying the learning of articulated body poses and complex body shapes. To train and evaluate our model, we construct a large-scale dataset comprising approximately 19K 2D full-body human images and their corresponding sketches in a hand-drawn style. Experimental results demonstrate that our Sketch2Avatar can transfer hand-drawn sketches into photo-realistic 360° full-body human images with precise sketch-human alignment. Ablation studies further validate the effectiveness of our design choices. Our project is publicly available at: https://richardchen20.github.io/Sketch2Avatar

title: Railway Track Foreign Object Intrusion Detection Based on Attention Mechanism and Lightweight Convolution
authors: Shuo Wang, Qian Wang, Yang Gao, Sheng Gao, Shuhua Gao, Jing Wang, Zhengfang Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Track foreign object intrusion severely compromises train operational safety. Timely detection of objects on or near the track is crucial for ensuring operational security and preventing accidents. However, existing models suffer from issues such as excessive parameter counts and poor performance in identifying small-sized targets. To address these challenges, this study designs a lightweight railway track foreign object detection model based on YOLOv5. Firstly, Ghost lightweight convolutions replace traditional convolutions in the backbone network to reduce model complexity. Secondly, in the neck network, a bidirectional feature pyramid replaces the original unidirectional feature pyramid to achieve efficient fusion of features at different scales. Finally, the CBAM convolutional attention mechanism is incorporated into the backbone network to improve feature extraction for foreign objects of varying sizes. We applied the designed model to a laboratory-built dataset. Experimental results demonstrate that the model achieves an mAP of 88.5%, representing a 1.5% improvement over the original YOLOv5 model. Compared to the original YOLOv5 model, our model reduces computational complexity, parameter count, and model size by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$31 \%, 25.7 {\%}$</tex>, and 24.8% respectively, validating its effectiveness.

title: A Multi-Sensor Tactile Imaging System for Breast Cancer Detection: Feasibility Assessment on MRI-Derived Patient-Specific Phantom_supp1-3655101.docx
authors: Emiliano Schena
abstract: Breast palpation is a widely accepted preliminary exam for early tumor detection. However, it carries substantial risk of incorrect assessment, due to its operator-dependent nature. Tactile imaging (TI) techniques has recently emerged as a promising alternative, capable of mapping the spatial distribution of force (F) and identifying localized variations in tissue stiffness associated with potential abnormalities. This study presents a novel multi-sensor tactile imaging system based on fiber Bragg grating sensors (FBGs) for breast cancer detection. A 3x3 sensing matrix was designed and integrated within a compact and ergonomic 3D-printed probe, enabling high spatial resolution, high F sensitivity, and simultaneous multi-point measurements. The system was tested on a patient-specific breast phantom derived from magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data, under both controlled loading and examiner-driven palpation scenarios. In both testing conditions, tumor-containing areas exhibited higher median F and reduced F variability compared to tumor-free areas. Tactile images extracted from the recorded F signals at varying indentation depths revealed distinguishable F distributions in the tumor areas across both testing scenarios. The results demonstrated the system’s ability to measure F distributions at contact areas, highlighting its potential for tumor identification. These promising findings lay the foundation for further optimizations toward applications in real-world clinical scenarios.

title: When LLM Agents Disagree, Do Humans Mirror? Behavioral Comparisons on Moral Dilemmas
authors: Haotian Deng, Sitian Wang, Ruxin Wang, Xuetao Wei, Chen Wei, Quanying Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Moral dilemmas are widely used to study ethical decision-making in humans and artificial agents. While recent studies have shown large language models (LLMs) can produce consistent human-like moral judgments, their ability to capture human inter-individual variability-especially in highdisagreement scenarios-remains unexplored. To explore this, we propose a variability-based assessment framework that evaluates human-AI moral alignment through inter-individual disagreement. We curated a diverse set of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 0 0}$</tex> moral dilemmas spanning domains such as harm, fairness, and loyalty. Using a unified experimental paradigm, we collected binary moral decisions and confidence ratings from over 100 LLM-based agents and 100 human participants. For each scenario, we quantified interagent disagreement (AI uncertainty) and inter-human response variability (Human uncertainty). Our results reveal a fundamental misalignment that AI uncertainty fails to predict human disagreement levels (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$r=0.01, p=0.73$</tex>). Paradoxically, agents exhibiting greater moral consistency diverge further from human variability patterns. This suggests current alignment strategies overlook key dimensions of moral ambiguity, risking brittle ethical AI systems.

title: Salient Difference Awareness for Remote Sensing Image Change Captioning
authors: Yunpeng Li, Xinlei Wang, Mingming Tian, XingYao Fu, Jing Xu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Remote sensing image change captioning is an innovative human-computer interaction for understanding appeared changes in bi-temporal remote sensing images (RSIs), which provides a natural language description for changes or non-changes. Current methods typically adopt a bi-temporal feature extraction, change localization and followed by a change captioning model. Most approaches aim to improve the accuracy of change recognition and description with complex network modules, lacking prior judgments on whether there are salient changes between image pairs. This deficiency can lead to inaccurate or erroneous descriptions. To alleviate this problem, a novel salient difference awareness network is designed to describe the differences between RSI pairs. Generally, the change area accounts for a relatively small proportion in a RSI, the salient changeaware module filters the redundant information in RSI scene, which benefits change localization by attaining better change perception. In addition, we propose multilayer aggregated module to sufficiently utilize the salient change features from different change awareness layers, further capturing relevant change details. Then, the Transformer decoder guarantees semantic descriptions by change-to-sentence translation. We validate the effectiveness of the proposed method on the LEVIR-CC dataset with four metrics, showcasing its superior performance compared to several state-of-the-art techniques.

title: A Coalesced Tensor Reduction Architecture for Scalable All-Bank PIM Execution
authors: Taehyung Park, Hyuk-Jae Lee, Chae Eun Rhee
publish: IEEE Journal on Emerging and Selected Topics in Circuits and Systems
abstract: The embedding layer in deep learning recommendation models (DLRM) is highly memory-bound and exhibits skewed, irregular access patterns. These characteristics lead to severe load imbalance and performance bottlenecks in processing in memory (PIM) architectures. We propose TRAM (Two-level Reduction Accelerator for Memory), a heterogeneous accelerator that integrates High Bandwidth Memory based PIM architecture (HBM-PIM) with conventional dual in-line memory modules (DIMMs) to accelerate batched embedding vector reductions. TRAM reduces redundant hot-vector accesses and employs a host-side scheduling mechanism that overlaps bank-PIM operations inside DRAM banks with logic-PIM operations, where processing units are located in the buffer die. This overlap eliminates command-bandwidth stalls and compute-bound delays. In addition, metadata-aware optimizations reduce row/column access overhead by reusing contiguous address patterns within each bank. Evaluation on six recommendation datasets and three embedding dimensions demonstrates that TRAM achieves up to 2.8× speedup and 3.0× energy reduction compared to state-of-the-art heterogeneous memory systems, while preserving full compatibility with the standard DRAM interface.

title: Classification of Stress States Using Cardiac Impedance and Ground Reaction Force in Virtual Reality
authors: Muhammad Shoaib Malik, Laiba Shafique, Shehryar Khalid, Muhammad Omar Cheema, Zia Mohy-Ud-Din, Jahan Zeb Gul
abstract: The interactions between the autonomic and the motor systems in the case of stress have been complicated to analyze, and their coordination under fear is not adequately explored. The study will combine the three-dimensional Force Plates and impedance cardiography (ICG) to categorize the response to stress in a controlled Virtual Reality (VR) setting. Fear-inducing virtual reality roller coaster was experienced by 10 healthy adults while standing on a PASCO force plate. ICG signals were used to extract cardiac parameters, such as Pre-Ejection Period (PEP), stroke volume and cardiac output. At the same time, the swaying postural and balance were monitored by the force plates. The findings revealed strong shortening of PEP during VR scare events, which means experience of a high sympathetic activity even without significant changes in sway. Measurements taken by a force plate indicated freeze reactions with an increase in stiffness and decreased sway accompanied by continued cardiac excitation. The cardiac and biomechanical features trained on impedance cardiac and force plate data yielded more than 90% accuracy in classifying the stress states, compared to the single modalities. These results emphasize the importance of multimodal physiological recording for differentiating between states of stress and show how fear is generated both in physiological dynamics and motor behaviour and how it reflects the other body systems. This combined tracking has a potential application in mental well-being tests, virtual-reality treatments and tracking the stress rate in physically challenging conditions.

title: Correntropy Based Model Predictive Consensus Control for Discrete-time Multi-agent Systems Subject to Impulsive Noise
authors: Jun Liu, Yuqi Sun, Haoran Zhu, Ming Pu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel correntropy-based Model Predictive Control (MPC) framework for discrete-time multiagent systems (DTMASs) under impulsive noise to achieve consensus. To counteract the detrimental impact of impulsive noise on conventional MPC, the maximum correntropy criterion (MCC) is adopted as a robust performance metric, which significantly improves noise resilience and optimizes the weighted consensus state. The effectiveness of the proposed method is validated through extensive comparative simulations with conventional MPC strategies. The results confirm the theoretical contributions and demonstrate the superior robustness of the proposed approach against impulsive noise.

title: RRG-YOLO: YOLOv8 with Multi-Scale Fusion Attention Mechanism for Clutter Segmentation
authors: Xuanhao Gu, Shiqian Wu, Chaobing Zheng, Zhirui Zhai
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: In the process of ore transportation and processing, the mixing of impurities will seriously affect the stability and safety of subsequent mineral processing processes. To achieve efficient detection and accurate segmentation of ore impurities, this paper proposes a segmentation method based on improved YOLOv8. Regarding the problems of the original YOLOv8, such as insufficient small target recognition accuracy and low feature utilization, this paper makes improvements from three aspects: First, introduce the RRG attention mechanism with multi-scale fusion to enhance the model's ability to express features of different scales. Second, add a high-resolution segmentation head on the basis of the original segmentation head to improve the detection and segmentation capabilities for small target impurities. Third, replace the bounding box regression loss from CIOU to GIOU to obtain a more stable bounding box fitting effect. Experimental results show that compared with the original YOLOv8 segmentation model, this method has achieved significant improvements in mAP and small target recall rate on the self-built ore impurity dataset, providing an efficient and robust solution for ore impurity recognition.

title: Machine Learning Approach to Detect Blackhole Attack over MANETs
authors: Anas Ali Alkasasbeh
abstract: This paper addresses the detection of Blackhole attacks in mobile ad hoc networks according to the traffic of the Ad-hoc On-demand Distance Vector (AODV) routing protocol. The proposed approach is based on the influence of mobility speed on network performance measures including throughput and end-to-end delay. The proposed approach uses machine learning algorithms to identify blackhole attacks in Mobile Ad-hoc Networks (MANETs). During the attack, we observe that the performance of the network becomes worse than usual. In this paper, machine learning models are used to detect blackhole attacks based on network traffic. The proposed approach uses the network traffic history for all nodes to train machine learning algorithms. According to the simulation results, network performance decreases with an increase in node speed. Machine learning algorithms used in blackhole detection show an average accuracy of 95%.

title: SAHDA: A Semantic-Aware Hybrid Approach for Arabic Spell Checking with Domain Adaptation
authors: Mossa’B Ibrahim, Pablo Gervás, Gonzalo Méndez
abstract: Arabic spell checking faces inherent linguistic challenges due to its complex word structures and ambiguous spellings, where roots generate diverse forms and identical spellings mask multiple meanings. Current systems often prioritize technical accuracy over contextual understanding, struggling to preserve regional dialects or resolve semantic ambiguities. This paper introduces SAHDA, a hybrid framework that bridges computational methods with human linguistic expertise. By combining rule-based error detection, neural semantic analysis, and collaborative human-AI refinement, SAHDA addresses both structural errors and meaning-based ambiguities in written Arabic. Key innovations include context-aware dialect preservation to maintain regional linguistic diversity and adaptive learning techniques that enable efficient customization for specialized domains. Evaluations demonstrate SAHDA’s ability to resolve ambiguous terms and dialectal variations more effectively than existing approaches while minimizing overcorrection of valid regional expressions. As an open-source tool, the framework advances inclusive language technology by harmonizing standardization with dialectal richness— a critical advancement for supporting Arabic’s diverse written traditions in the digital age.
