title: The Mean of Multi-Object Trajectories_supp1-3657434.pdf
authors: Changbeom Shim
abstract: This paper introduces the concept of a mean for trajectories and multi-object trajectories (defined as sets or multisets of trajectories) along with algorithms for computing them. Specifically, we use the Fréchet mean, and metrics based on the optimal sub-pattern assignment (OSPA) construct, to extend the notion of average from vectors to trajectories and multiobject trajectories. Further, we develop efficient algorithms to compute these means using greedy search and Gibbs sampling. Using distributed multi–object tracking as an application, we demonstrate that the Fréchet mean approach to multi–object trajectory consensus significantly outperforms state-of-the-art distributed multi-object tracking methods.

title: PCL Detection Based on DAB Symbol Processing
authors: Tomasz P. Zieliński, Gustaw Mazurek, Krzysztof Kulpa
publish: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
abstract: The classical passive coherent location (PCL) processing makes use of at least two antennas and is based on a calculation of cross-ambiguity function (CAF) between reference (REF) and surveillance (SURV) signals. In the modern approach, which is dedicated to communication signals with orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) and known as an OFDM radar, the REF signal can be reconstructed from the SURV one. Then, the channel frequency response (CFR) is estimated, and information about moving targets is extracted from it. Such an approach enables building a simple, single physical channel passive radar, which requires relatively low computational power compared to the classical, two-channel CAF approach. This paper shows what signal processing operations should be added to a standard digital audio broadcasting (DAB) receiver to obtain the PCL functionality. Several field tests confirm the correctness of the described enhancement. Two low-cost software-defined radio (SDR) devices were used in the hardware setup, i.e., RSPduo and RTL-SDR, to detect airplanes of different sizes flying at various altitudes, in outdoor and indoor receive scenarios. The investigated DAB-based PCL radar's operating range has been also estimated based on a reference from ADS-B data. The opportunity of a single-channel PCL radar design, operating with minimum hardware and just one omnidirectional antenna, opens up the possibility of deploying a network of small and inexpensive PCL sensors.

title: A Mamba-Enhanced Spatial-Channel Recombination Temporal Network using 4D Feature Flow in EEG Signals
authors: Zhuorong Li, Can Bu, Peiyu Fan, Yongming Huang
abstract: In recent years, extensive research efforts have been dedicated to the application of deep learning in EEG classification, yielding a plethora of proposed methods. Nonetheless, the majority of these methods have failed to comprehensively consider the information of EEG signals across the three essential dimensions, namely spatial, frequency band, and temporal domains, in a simultaneous manner. To this end, this paper proposes a Mamba-Enhanced Spatial-Channel Recombination Temporal Network (SCM-NET), using a four-dimensional EEG signal that has undergone DE cross-entropy as input. Firstly, the spatial-channel recombination module is exploited to recombine the spatial and frequency band features in accordance with the pre-configured activation threshold. This procedure effectively augments the spatial interactive feature information across different frequency bands. Subsequently, a lightweight convolutional neural network is harnessed to accentuate the most valuable information within the feature set. Finally, the Mamba network is applied to extract high-level temporal information features. We evaluated its performance using DEAP, MEEG, SEED, and SEED-VIG datasets and achieved recognized accuracy rates of 71.48%, 97.47%, 88.31%, and 99.89%, respectively, which outperformed the current state-of-the-art technology compared to existing methods. Codes are avaiable at https://github.com/NicoleRR2001/SCM-NET.

title: Supervised Contrastive Learning and Energy Based Network for Open-Set Radar Model Recognition
authors: Yaodong Zhao, Yujing Liu, Jin Qi, Zhixin Xu, Hongyan Su, Qun Wan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Electromagnetic target model identification technology holds significant application value in electronic countermeasures, network security, and spectrum management. However, in real-world open environments, existing technologies still face numerous challenges, such as ineffective identification capabilities for unknown categories. To address this issue, we propose a novel method that utilizes supervised contrastive learning to compress the feature space of known categories, coupled with an energy score-based open-set recognition approach to achieve high-accuracy identification of unknown categories. Specifically, we leverage supervised contrastive learning to obtain a feature space distribution with strong intra-class cohesion and inter-class separation. This compression method for known-class feature spaces expands the open space belonging to unknown classes, thereby enhancing the distinguishability between known and unknown classes. Additionally, the energy score-based open-set recognition method models the entire feature space distribution globally, amplifying confidence differences between known and unknown classes through nonlinear mapping, further enhancing the generalization capability and reliability of the openset recognition model. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance in relevant domains, effectively solving the radar model open-set recognition problem and providing new solutions for the development of electromagnetic target model identification technology.

title: Comparative Analysis of Sputter Etch Rates of Photoresists on Glass Under ICP RIE Conditions
authors: Sachin Kumar Singh, Guruswamy Rajaram, Richa Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: One of the microfabrication techniques to precisely transfer pattern onto substrate is etching. Etching process is sorted into two types: dry etching and wet etching. This study primarily aims to determine the sputter etch rates of various photoresists, including OIR 620M and MEGAPOSIT SPR 220, in the context of inductively coupled plasma reactive ion etching. The process parameters included different high frequency (HF) and ICP power levels, with a constant argon gas flow. In this work, we aim to investigate the viability of employing sputter etching in etching processes, particularly in cases where the desired etch profiles are vertical and characterized by minimal etch depths. Etch rate for MEGAPOSIT SPR220 is 1500Å/min with roughness of 1400Å and for OIR620M the etch rate is 550Å /min with roughness of 80Å at similar conditions. Various process parameters contribute to optimization of the etching process, considering compatibility with other materials and the necessary etch rates.

title: Mechanistic Biocomputing from Canopy to Clinic, Plant Centered review
authors: Malik Urfa Gul, M. Junaid Gul, Gyu Sang Choi, Chang-Hyeon Park
abstract: Computational biology blends mechanistic models with data-driven AI. In this survey, we focus on plant systems, with occasional pointers to human biology that were useful. We review four advances, organ-level growth models that allocate resources among leaves, stems, and fruit (e.g., GreenLab), whole-tree models linking physiology and form (e.g., L-PEACH), plant microbe models for nitrogen fixation (e.g., AMIGO), and AI workflows from high-throughput phenotyping to protein-structure prediction (e.g., AlphaFold). For each topic, we outline the core equations in plain terms, state key assumptions and identifiability limits, and give practical validation steps using open datasets, standard metrics, and simple ablations. We also clearly separate the survey from a forward-looking idea mimicking plant metabolism, which we present as future work, not a finished result. We end with concrete next steps: calibrating across scales, quantifying uncertainty, testing models across species and sites, and sharing reproducible pipelines that connect simulations with AI. Our aim is a tighter, clearer guide for both method builders and applied researchers. To bridge plant science and computer science, we suggest modeling plant metabolism mathematically. Such models mirror biochemical pathways, deepen biological insight, and open new avenues for algorithm design in computational biology. We argue that the convergence of computational biology and AI will advance plant science and, more broadly, benefit medicine, ecology, and environmental science. This paper summarizes the current state of the field and outlines a practical path for future work

title: Adversarial Diffusion Model: Generating High Quality and Undetectable Images from Scratch
authors: Haoyue Wang, Sheng Li, Zhenxing Qian, Xinpeng Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Diffusion models have made tremendous progress in generating visually realistic images. However, these images are statistically different from the real images, which could be accurately classified by carefully designed detectors. To evade detection, researchers have proposed various adversarial example generation schemes for AI-generated images. Despite the progress, most of these schemes have the tendency to post-process the images and the distortion is inevitable. In this paper, we propose an Adversarial Diffusion Model (ADM), which is able to directly generate high quality and undetectable images from scratch on top of a pre-trained stable diffusion model. In the ADM, an adversarial denoising U-Net is proposed for searching an adversarial latent. This latent is helpful for generating a prompt consistent adversarial example which is able to deceive the detector. Then, we propose a latent compensation module to make the adversarial examples have a similar reconstruction error to that of the real images. We further propose an adversarial decoder to minimize the difference between the high-frequency components of the real and adversarial examples. Comprehensive experiments are carried out to demonstrate the advantages of our ADM in generating adversarial AI-generated images.

title: Constrained Human Preference Alignment for Natural Language Planning with LLMs
authors: Yu Zhou, Haokai Hong, Ran Cheng, Kay Chen Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Recent advances in large language models (LLMs) have established them as promising candidates for natural language planning tasks. However, existing approaches often fail to address two critical challenges: 1) the effective alignment of LLM-generated plans with human preferences, and 2) the dynamic enforcement of diverse constraints inherent in planning scenarios. To bridge these gaps, we propose a constraint-aware human-preference alignment framework for natural language planning. Our contributions are threefold. First, we design a process reward model that aligns LLM outputs with human preferences through step-by-step feedback, facilitating efficient and interpretable preference learning. Second, we develop a constraint-aware mechanism integrated into the rewriting strategy, which dynamically penalizes violations of task-specific constraints at each reasoning step. Third, we introduce a unified adaptive metric enabling a multifaceted assessment of planning quality. We validate our framework through experiments on planning benchmarks, demonstrating improvements in success rate with constraints and human preference alignment over baselines.

title: A Maximum Likelihood-Based Robust Interval Matching Strategy for TH-DSSS Signal Parameter Estimation
authors: Binbin Dou, Yibin Rui, Guoyang Gao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Accurate positioning in wireless ad hoc networks (WANETs) critically depends on precise time synchronization among distributed nodes. However, pulse detection is prone to false alarms and missed detections under complex environments characterized by low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and multipath fading. This challenge significantly impedes parameter estimation for time-hopping direct sequence spread spectrum (TH-DSSS) signals. To address the limitations of existing algorithms in terms of robustness and convergence efficiency, we proposed a Maximum Likelihood-based Robust Interval-Matching Strategy (ML-RIMS) for precise estimation of the initial frame index (IFI) in TH-DSSS signals. Specifically, the approach constructs TH interval sequences, employs a bidirectional combinatorial matching strategy for error tolerance, and integrates a trendconsistent likelihood scoring model to improve resilience against structural mismatches. Furthermore, mechanisms for burstfailure termination and signal correlation verification are incorporated to boost both accuracy and computational efficiency in path selection. Numerical results demonstrate that ML-RIMS significantly outperforms existing algorithms in overall estimation performance across varying SNR and false alarm conditions.

title: Design of Low Power AMBA APB Protocol Using Clock Gating
authors: Vangara Kalyan Naga Sai, Muvvala Rohit, Yadlapalli Sharath Chandra, Udarapu Siva Shankar, Sridevi Sathya Priya S
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The Advanced Peripheral Bus (APB) Advanced Microcontroller Bus Architecture (AMBA) is widely used in system-on-chip (SoC) for low-bandwidth peripheral interfacing. However, power consumption has always been one of the significant challenges in present power-aware applications. Here, a low-power AMBA APB protocol design with an efficient clock gating approach has been proposed. Clock gating is a very common power-saving technique that eliminates dynamic power by not supplying the clock signal to idle modules. Clock gating at more than one level is included in the proposed design, which makes it power-frugal during inactive periods without decreasing performance or reliability. The design disables the clock signal for idle modules selectively, actually minimizing redundant switching activity while master-slave communication remains uninterrupted. Simulation results show that power dissipation is decreased from 0.682 mW to 0.567 mW.

title: LLM-Driven Synthetic Text Generation for Privacy-Preserving Federated Learning
authors: Xinge Ma, Jin Wang, Xuejie Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Audio, Speech and Language Processing
abstract: Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative fine tuning of pre-trained language models (PLMs) across user devices by aggregating locally trained model parameters rather than raw data, exhibiting great potential in privacy-sensitive natural language processing (NLP) applications. However, the inherent tendency of model parameters to memorize training data puts existing efforts at risk of disclosing raw data. Knowledge distillation (KD) offers a privacy-preserving alternative for knowledge transfer between the cloud server and user devices by exchanging lightweight model predictions associated with a public proxy dataset. Nevertheless, a desirable proxy dataset may not always be available in practice as its construction requires careful deliberation and even prior knowledge about the private domain to ensure satisfactory performance, which conflicts with the privacy-preserving principles of FL. To tackle this challenge, this paper proposes FedSTG, a privacy-preserving FL framework empowered by synthetic text generation of large language models (LLMs), which combines the exceptional generation capability of a pre-trained LLM deployed on the cloud server with the domain specific understanding capabilities of local PLMs distributed across user devices to generate high-quality synthetic text for knowledge transfer, facilitating the integration of KD and FL without the need for publicly available proxy data. Extensive experiments across a wide range of benchmark tasks demonstrate that FedSTG achieves superior performance without requiring any prior knowledge about the private domain, delivering a privacy-preserving FL solution for NLP.

title: Zero-Shot Event Causality Identification via Multisource Evidence Fuzzy Aggregation With Large Language Models
authors: Zefan Zeng, Qing Cheng, Xingchen Hu, Wentao Li, Weiping Ding, Zhong Liu
abstract: Event causality identification (ECI) aims to detect causal relationships between events in textual contexts. Existing ECI models predominantly rely on supervised methodologies, suffering from dependence on large-scale annotated data. Although large language models (LLMs) enable zero-shot ECI, they are prone to causal hallucination—erroneously establishing spurious causal links. To address these challenges, we propose MEFA, a novel zero-shot ECI model based on multisource evidence fuzzy aggregation. First, we decompose causality reasoning into three main tasks (temporality determination, necessity analysis, and sufficiency verification) complemented by three auxiliary tasks. Second, leveraging meticulously designed prompts, we guide LLMs to generate uncertain responses and deterministic outputs. Finally, we quantify LLM's responses of subtasks and employ fuzzy aggregation to integrate these evidence for causality scoring and causality determination. Extensive experiments on three benchmarks demonstrate that MEFA outperforms second-best unsupervised baselines by 6.2% in <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$F1$</tex-math></inline-formula>-score and 9.3% in precision, while significantly reducing hallucination-induced errors. In-depth analysis verify the effectiveness of task decomposition and the superiority of fuzzy aggregation.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Cybersecurity Training: Key Elements, Best Strategies, and Future Prospects
authors: Omran Salem, Marwa Fayiz Hamza, Akram M Zeki
abstract: Cybercrime methods are constantly evolving and increasing, which necessitates an urgent need to raise the level of individuals and enhance their security behavior, for fear of falling victim to these crimes. Hence, the need for training workshops to raise awareness of cybercrime has emerged. Accordingly, this research evaluates the effectiveness of these workshops by analyzing the results of the questionnaire of participants in these workshops before and after the workshops. The research discussed the most important strategies and evaluation models that can be used to improve these training programs. Based on the analysis of the questionnaire results, which showed a significant improvement in the awareness of participants, the research presented several recommendations aimed at increasing the effectiveness of these workshops in a way that ensures increased societal impact in combating cyber threats.

title: FedAgri: A Federated Learning Framework for Sustainable Agriculture in Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Rabinarayan Mohanty, Ranjan Kumar Dash, Pradyumna Kumar Tripathy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Integrating Federated Learning (FL) with Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS) is a novel approach to sustainable agriculture. CPS uses real-time data from distributed sensors, drones, and edge devices to monitor and manage important agricultural elements. FL allows farmers to train collaborative learning without exchanging raw data, securing confidentiality and privacy. In several key application areas, such as precision irrigation to minimize water waste, yield prediction for effective resource allocation, pest and disease detection to minimize the need for pesticides, smart crop rotation to preserve soil fertility, and adjusting to climates for proactive planning. CPS and FL work together to produce sustainable outcomes. We present FedAgri, a federated, sensor-aware learning algorithm designed for resource-constrained and diverse agricultural environments that can achieve these objectives. FedAgri uses client selection, adaptive learning, and model compression techniques to improve scalability and reduce communication overhead. By addressing the issues of data management and environmental sustainability, the proposed framework promotes efficient, adaptable, and intelligent agricultural practices.

title: Integrating Natural Language Processing and Exercise Monitoring for Early Diagnosis of Metabolic Syndrome: A Deep Learning Approach
authors: Yichen Zhao, Yuhua Wang, Xi Cheng, Junhao Fang, Yang Yang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Metabolic Syndrome (MetS), which affects approximately one-quarter of the global population, significantly increases the risk of numerous chronic conditions, including type II diabetes mellitus. As a result, early detection and timely intervention are essential in managing this syndrome. MetS is conventionally diagnosed through blood tests performed in clinical settings. However, the condition is often underestimated, resulting in significant unmet healthcare needs among affected individuals. In this study, we aimed to diagnose MetS using non-invasive physiological data and unstructured narrative descriptions of personal physical activities, both of which can be easily collected. We collected data from 40 volunteers in a nursing home and developed a deep learning framework that integrates natural language processing (NLP) with physiological data using a feature fusion approach for MetS classification. The optimal model achieved strong results, with an AUROC of 0.806 and a recall of 76.3%. Feature importance analysis indicated that textual descriptions and daily minimum heart rate were the most influential factors in classifying MetS. These findings demonstrate the potential of leveraging easily accessible daily life data for the early detection of MetS, which may help lower the costs associated with screening and management for at-risk populations.

title: Enhancing NICUs Cry Signals: A Comparative Study of Traditional Denoising Methods for ML Applications
authors: Preeti Kumari, Kartik Mahto
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: The paper investigates the challenge of noise reduction in neonatal cry recordings within Neonatal Intensive Care Units in hospital environments. This is done to increase the reliability of machine learning based audio signal analysis or cry classification. The background noise due to the beeping of cardiorespiratory monitors, pulse oximeters, ventilators, or alarm sounds in NICU gets added to the neonate's cry recordings and significantly affect the accuracy of cry analysis, posing challenge for machine learning techniques. The focus is to improve the quality of these cry recordings by decreasing the background electronic noise while preserving the necessary cry signal information. Further, various traditional noise reduction techniques like Spectral Subtraction, STFT, Wavelet Transform, Triangular Filter, and Band Reject Filter are compared on SNR basis for background noise removal. Results indicates that the Wavelet Transform gives the maximum SNR value of 10.6 dB among all.

title: On the Importance of Neural Membrane Potential Leakage for LIDAR-Based Robot Obstacle Avoidance Using Spiking Neural Networks
authors: Zainab Ali, Lujayn Al-Amir, Ali Safa
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Using neuromorphic computing for robotics applications has gained much attention in recent year due to the remarkable ability of Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) for highprecision yet low memory and compute complexity inference when implemented in neuromorphic hardware. This ability makes SNNs well-suited for autonomous robot applications (such as in drones and rovers) where battery resources and payload are typically limited. Within this context, this paper studies the use of SNNs for performing direct robot navigation and obstacle avoidance from LIDAR data. A custom robot platform equipped with a LIDAR is set up for collecting a labeled dataset of LIDAR sensing data together with the human-operated robot control commands used for obstacle avoidance. Crucially, this paper provides what is, to the best of our knowledge, a first focused study about the importance of neuron membrane leakage on the SNN precision when processing LIDAR data for obstacle avoidance. It is shown that by carefully tuning the membrane potential leakage constant of the spiking Leaky Integrate-andFire (LIF) neurons used within our SNN, it is possible to achieve on-par robot control precision compared to the use of a non-spiking Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Finally, the LIDAR dataset collected during this work is released as opensource with the hope of benefiting future research.

title: Inverse-Design of Scalable Wideband Aperiodic Array Topologies with Realistic Element Patterns Accelerated via a Surrogate Directivity Model
authors: Colin A. Mussman, Syed Mohammed Ashab Uddin, Wooram Lee, Gregory H. Huff, Douglas H. Werner
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Motivated by the critical challenges posed by modern wireless data trends and RFIC layouts, an aperiodic phased array topology which remains scalable to an arbitrary number of elements is proposed. Facilitated by an analytical surrogate directivity model of realistic embedded elements in an arbitrary planar array, such scalable aperiodic layouts are inversely-designed for several element counts and representative cosine element patterns. It is seen that the proposed topology can operate over a wider bandwidth and field of view (FOV) than counterpart periodic arrays, yet with similar maximum gains across more than an octave of operation. Moreover, use of the surrogate directivity model in the inverse-design of these arrays bears out, for the first time, the importance of considering an array’s embedded element pattern during the design process, not just after. It is shown that this process, which represents a significant break from the traditional optimization approaches, can yield array designs with superior performance.

title: A Framework for Measuring Innovation District Performance: Input–Output Metrics for Policy and Practice
authors: Martin Bliemel, Jarrod Ormiston, Jan Henrik Gruenhagen, Jochen Schweitzer, Mariana Gonzalez Lago, Dilek Cetindamar, Renu Agarwal
abstract: In this article, we introduce a framework for measuring innovation in innovation districts (IDs). While the intellectual roots of IDs are in urban design, this study conceptualizes them as highly localized place-based innovation systems. The innovation systems perspective brings the innovation activities and their measurement to the fore, which is taken for granted in the urban design literature. This study synthesizes prior research on innovation measurement and 67 interviews with innovation experts across six cities to derive a concise and pragmatic set of measures. The measures are pragmatic and dashboard ready because the measures recommended by the experts could be matched to organisation for economic co-operation and development (OECD) and other readily available data sources. The ID measurement framework will enable engineering managers to monitor their performance in the context of a given ID and help researchers and policymakers evaluate the performance of IDs and related policy interventions.

title: Low Sidelobe Design for Small-Scale Sparse Array Antennas Using Mechanical Rotation
authors: Mst Mostary Begum, Bidya Debnath, Brooke E. Molen, Junming Diao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Reducing the number of antenna elements within a fixed aperture while maintaining low sidelobe levels is a key challenge in sparse array design. Although various sidelobe suppression techniques exist, most are tailored for large-scale arrays and are not directly applicable to small-scale sparse arrays. This paper addresses a critical gap in array design for small sparse arrays with low sidelobes using mechanical rotation and time-averaging techniques. By continuously rotating the array and time-averaging radiation patterns, the mainlobe remains coherent and stable, while the rapidly varying sidelobes are effectively averaged out and suppressed. An analytical model is developed to determine the required integration time, optimize element placement, mitigate Doppler effects, and enhance time-selective radiation pattern strategies. Experimental validation using a four-element circularly polarized array with 0.74λ spacing demonstrates a PSLL reduction of 11.5 dB compared to a conventional non-rotated array, and can be further reduced by 4.7 dB through time-selected pattern optimization. The proposed method has many potential applications, such as passive remote sensing using rotating UAV swarm arrays, making it a flexible and low-cost solution for precision agriculture and environmental monitoring applications.

title: A Comparative Analysis of MobileNetV2, InceptionV3, and VGG19 with Different Activation Functions for Coconut Tree Disease Classification
authors: Sriharinadha Savaram, Muthulakshmi M, Vaisshale Rathinasamy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Coconut trees play a critical role in tropical areas, serving as sources of food, shelter, and economic means. Diseases in coconut trees, though, impact the yield of crops remarkably, and therefore early and precise identification is significant. This work explores the performance of deep learning models-MobileNetV2, InceptionV3, and VGG 19-in classifying coconut tree diseases. This work employs advanced deep learning techniques, including data augmentation and L2 regularization, to enhance disease management strategies in coconut plantations. This developed model has been examined for the five major diseases: Bud Root Dropping, Bud Rot, Gray Leaf Spot, Leaf Rot, and Stem Bleeding, by deploying precision, recall, and F1-score for evaluating the model. We also experimented with four different activation functions-ReLU, LeakyReLU, Swish, and ELU. Our best model has achieved an accuracy of 99.88% in classifying the coconut tree diseases, demonstrating great performance.

title: Cluster-Fair-FL for Multi-Label Consumer Health Privacy-Preserving Image Analysis
authors: Yuchen Zhang, Donghong Cai, Zahid Khan, Pengfei Chen, Adel Ammar
abstract: The integration of Internet of Things (IoT)-enabled consumer medical devices, platform and professional expertise has significantly improved clinical diagnosis accuracy. However, privacy concerns and variations in consumer device-specific or hospital-specific data analyses hinder centralized processing of massive multi-label medical image data. This paper proposes a Cluster-Fair Federated Learning (CFFL) framework to address data heterogeneity in distributed IoT-based consumer healthcare systems. Using an end-to-end Dual Decoder Network (DDN), medical consumers are grouped into clusters by data similarity, with cluster-specific models optimized locally and aggregated through intra-cluster volume-weighted and inter-cluster contribution-based strategies. Experiments on the Chest X-ray14 and CheXpert datasets show that the proposed CFFL improves diagnostic accuracy by 6.2% on average compared to baselines and achieves performance close to centralized learning while ensuring privacy. These results underscore the framework potential for secure, efficient, and scalable distributed consumer medical image analysis.

title: A Radar Active And Passive Interference Identification Method Based on Waveform Control
authors: Yun Zhou, Fulai Wang, Chen Pang, Yongzhen Li, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: As an important premise of radar anti-jamming, jamming perception is an important part of the electronic warfare antagonism. The existing research mainly focuses on active interference recognition, but there may be passive interference such as corner reflector in actual scenes, so this study focuses on the perception of active and passive interference scenarios. Based on the existing recognition methods, this paper proposes an interference recognition method based on entropy features under the combined control of linear frequency modulation and phase-coded waveform (LFM-PE). In this method, the interference signals under the two types of waveforms are obtained by simultaneously transmitting two types of waveforms with different frequency points, the interference signals under the two types of waveforms are extracted, and the support vector machine classifier under the particle swarm optimization (PSO-SVM) model is used for classification. Among them, the recognition accuracy of the five types of interference under the combined control of linear frequency modulation and phasecoded waveform is significantly improved compared with that without this method, and the recognition accuracy of the entropy features under the LFM-PE control method is higher than that of the original under the jamming-to-noise ratio from -10dB to 20dB.

title: Deep Unfolded Network-Based Robust Waveform Design for Multi-Target Jamming
authors: Xuecheng Xia, Wenjun Wu, Xinkuang Wang, Junning Zhang, Xiongpeng Wang, Bo Tang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper tackles the challenge of robust multitarget jamming with digital array systems. We develop a probabilistic model to account for array imperfections, with the goal of minimizing the matching error between transmitted and desired waveforms. Our approach employs a model-driven deep learning method to tackle the non-convex problem under the constantmodulus constraint. We integrate an iterative optimization algorithm (i.e., the projection-descent-retraction (PDR) algorithm) into the network architecture, where the gradient step sizes are learned across the layers. Numerical experiments demonstrate that the deep unfolded algorithm achieves lower matching errors and faster execution speeds than the PDR algorithm.

title: Dirac's Thought Experiment: N-Polarizers and Quantum State Superposition
authors: Francisco Laranjo, Pedro Monteiro, André Nabais, Pedro Rossa, João Nuno Silva, Horácio Fernandes
abstract: In his book (1931), Dirac introduced the principle of quantum superposition with a 3-polarizer experiment on polarized photons to explain the principle of superposition in quantum mechanics. This thought experiment can be extended to n-polarizers leading to a better understanding of the principle of quantum states superposition. Here we discuss and demonstrate this principle of superposition in quantum mechanics by using a remotely controlled laboratory equipped with up to five polarizers. For <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$n=1$</tex> to 5 cascaded polarizers we can retrieve similar results to those expected from the theoretical interpretation of single photons being transmitted through several polarizers. It is worth mentioning that single-photon theory and light polarization are the essence for quantum communications.

title: NeuroPlat: An FPGA-Based Neuromorphic Computing Platform with Optimized Toolchain for Efficient SNN Deployment
authors: Zhipeng Liao, Tianyang Li, Ziyang Shen, Chaoming Fang, Jie Yang, Mohamad Sawan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: As the applications of brain-inspired computing become increasingly complex, the efficient hardware implementation of spiking neural networks faces two critical challenges: the lack of specialized hardware architectures for simulating spiking neuron behaviors and the absence of dedicated toolchains for mapping SNN algorithms to neuromorphic hardware. To address these limitations, we propose a reconfigurable FPGA-based computing platform featuring specialized computational cores optimized for spiking neuron behavior simulation, incorporating multiple hierarchical storage units, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6}$</tex>-parallel spiking processing array, and a dedicated instruction set. Additionally, we develop a comprehensive deployment toolchain that enables the combination of the PyTorch model with our dedicated instruction set, facilitating efficient end-to-end deployment of brain-inspired algorithms on neuromorphic hardware. Spiking-YOLO network has been implemented on this platform and achieves a peak processing speed of 20 FPS, achieving an optimal balance between computational efficiency and resource utilization.

title: Research and Application of UAV Path Planning
authors: YanJun Sun, ChangMing Liu, Yan Sun, Lin Deng, Shuang Han, Wei Xiao
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Owing to the significant strides in UAV technology, path planning, as its core component, plays a vital role in improving mission efficiency, ensuring flight safety and expanding application scenarios. Path planning not only determines whether the UAV can accomplish its tasks efficiently and safely, but also directly affects its adaptability and application scope in complex environments. Especially when multiple UAVs cooperate to perform tasks, reasonable path planning is very important for the successful implementation of tasks. This paper summarizes a comprehensive review of UAV path planning techniques, focusing on the key technologies and algorithms involved, as well as their importance and practical value in various fields.

title: Deep Learning-Based Detection of Chest X-Ray Abnormalities Using CNNs for Enhanced Diagnostic Accuracy
authors: Niteesha Sharma, T. Ashalatha, Y. Sowjanya, G. Siva Santosh, M Nikhil, Vuppu Sripadh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Chest X-ray abnormality is an important diagnostic indicator of many lung and heart diseases such as tuberculosis, pneumonia, lung cancer, and cardiomegaly. Early detection of such abnormalities is time-consuming and radiologist-based identification are prone to errors. The current study uses a deep learning-based method utilizing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for the detection of chest X-ray abnormalities with high accuracy and precision. A public dataset of chest X-ray images with labels were used to train and test the model, using TensorFlow and Visual studio code to deploy it. The model developed hence was able to achieve over 90% accuracy, confirming that AI-enabled radiology, has potential to get precise medical diagnosis. It is entrenched from the study that such AI can assist radiologists in precise and rapid results in initial diagnoses.

title: Marine Sensing Technologies: Applications for Monitoring Underwater Volcanic Activity, Geothermal Springs, and Ocean Exploration
authors: T. Matos, M.S. Martins, C.L. Faria, J.L. Rocha, L.M. Goncalves
abstract: This work presents the development of low-cost, low-power, and disposable marine monitoring technologies designed to support oceanographic studies in remote and extreme environments. These platforms were initially targeted for underwater volcanic locations but offer a broader application potential for ocean research. Three main technologies were developed and tested: underwater monitoring probes for real-time water quality assessments in geothermal springs, deep-sea probes for vertical ocean profiling and autonomous drift-phase monitoring, and a surface buoy for rapid-response environmental monitoring. Field deployments in diverse locations, including the Ponta da Ferraria (S. Miguel, Azores), Banco D. Joao de Castro (Atlantic Ocean), and the Cumbre Vieja volcanic eruption site (La Palma, Canarias), demonstrated the operational feasibility of these systems. Despite challenges in deep-sea operation and deployment conditions, the results highlight the potential of these platforms for scientific studies, environmental monitoring, and emergency response. Their adaptability and modularity make them valuable tools for a wide range of oceanographic applications beyond their initial focus. Ongoing efforts to improve marine communication reliability, sensor integration, and resilience to extreme ocean conditions hold the potential to further expand the role of these technologies in marine exploration.

title: An Intelligent Diagnosis Framework for Industrial Faults Based on Dynamic MS-Dynp and AW-GGS
authors: Xiangxin Li, Rong Fei, Anqi Shangguan
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Industrial failures pose a serious threat to the safety of life and property. Therefore, it is necessary to identify the fault's initial point promptly and perform accurate fault diagnosis. However, industrial signals are often cluttered and subject to various disturbances, which makes it difficult to identify the fault' s initial point promptly. In addition, fault signals are frequently accompanied by environmental noise and exhibit disorder, which adversely affects diagnostic accuracy. To address these pressing challenges, this paper introduces an intelligent industrial fault diagnosis framework, referred to as MDAG-CNN, which integrates three key components: the dynamic MS-Dynp algorithm, the adaptive window greedy Gaussian segmentation (AW-GGS), and a multi-CNN classification architecture. Specifically, the proposed dynamic MS-Dynp algorithm, developed on the basis of Dynp and enhanced with multivariate statistical parameters, is designed to detect the fault initiation point with high accuracy and robustness. Subsequently, the AW-GGS algorithm is applied to effectively normalize and standardize the collected signals, thereby alleviating the adverse effects of noise and amplitude variations. Finally, a multi-CNN structure is employed to perform precise and high-resolution fault classification. Experiments conducted on the widely used XJTU-SY bearing dataset demonstrate that MDAG-CNN achieves a remarkable diagnostic accuracy of 96.250%, which convincingly validates both the effectiveness and the practical applicability of the proposed framework.

title: Modern Temporal Convolutional Networks for Intelligent Fault Diagnosis of machines under Multiple Working Conditions with Noisy Labels
authors: Chuanfang Zhang, Wenxiao Yin, Zhibin Huang, Qiang Min, Daye Li, Kaixiang Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Machinery fault diagnosis plays an important role in enhancing equipment reliability and ensuring production safety. Varying working conditions and the occurrence of label noise make it difficult to learn patterns from complex data distribution. In this work, loss function named sigmoid symmetric cross entropy in modern temporal convolutional network (SGSCE-MTCN) is proposed to solve the rotating machinery fault diagnosis with noisy labels under multiple working conditions. Vibration data is first preprocessed to time-frequency sequence. Then, MTCN leverages depthwise separable convolution to extract cross-variable and cross-feature information after capturing long-term time series features. An adaptive loss is designed to improve model’s robustness to label noise, the probability of the predicted output processed by sigmoid function is taken as the dynamic parameter for adjusting the loss weight. Comprehensive experiments are conducted on two datasets with multiple working conditions, the proposed MTCN model outperforms other methods and reaches an accuracy over 95%, experiments with label noise indicate that SGSCE enables the model to perform fault classification under varying levels of noise.

title: An Enhanced Markerless Triangulation-Based Approach for Quantitative Gait Stability Assessment in Older Adults
authors: Shengyun Liang, Yingnan Xiong, Xiangwen Zheng, Guoru Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Quantitative evaluation of human movement dynamics can predict fall risk. However, these measures are rarely quantified in clinical practice due to high costs, time constraints, and laboratory restrictions. This study aims to develop an enhanced markerless triangulation-based approach for pose estimation in older adults. Thirty-two participants performed the time up and go test, and their movements were measured using both markerless and marker-based motion capture. We proposed formulas for feasible stability regions and conducted age-related statistical analyses. The results showed that our image-based 3D position method is consistent with state-of-the-art marker-based techniques. Age-related differences were significant. The elderly group exhibited significantly smaller changes in knee extension, hip extension, and ankle plantarflexion moments than the younger group ($\mathbf{p}\lt0.05$) during chair rising. The normalized CoM velocity in the elderly group was significantly smaller than in the younger group ($1.492 \pm 0.166$ vs $1.415 \pm 0.117$). The normalized CoM acceleration in the elderly group was significantly larger than in the younger group ($-0.388 \pm 0.086$ vs $-0.433 \pm 0.108$) while walking 3 m. Our study provides promising evidence for the feasibility of markerless triangulation-based gait stability evaluation in natural environments.

title: RF-ADMM-Net for Sparse Aperture ISAR Imaging Under Low Signal-to-noise Ratio
authors: Yu Wu, Ruize Li, Yanbo Mai, Shuanghui Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Sparse aperture (SA) and low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) echo are common challenges in inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) systems. Compressive sensing (CS) methods are widely utilized to reconstruct ISAR images from sparse echo. Combined with deep learning, unfolding nets based on different CS methods are proposed to obtain higher reconstruction accuracy in the SA case. However, these nets are not applicable for the sparse echo under low SNR, the denoising threshold is difficult to set appropriately for the balance between noise removal and structure preservation. To achieve the issue above, we proposed a random fields-based alternating direction method of multipliers net (RF-ADMM-Net). We design a segmentation method for the intermediate ISAR image based on random fields (RF) model, which can operate efficiently with better migration, robustness and stability to noisy ISAR images. Further, the segmentation is taken to assist for the denoising layers in distinguishing the target region from the background area. The denoising layers set different thresholds for target and noise regions to retain more information of target while thoroughly denoising. Experimental results based on both simulated and measured data, indicate the applicability and robustness of the RF-Net to noisy ISAR images suffer from SA and low SNR, and show high reconstruction accuracy for ISAR images under SA and low SNR of the RF-ADMM-Net.

title: Radiofrequency Method for Rapid Detection of Woody Breast in Chicken Breast Fillets
authors: Samir Trabelsi, Brian Bowker
abstract: Increasing global demand in poultry meat and poultry meat products prompted the broiler industry to use genetic selection and improved feeding practices to achieve significant gains in broiler size and growth rate. However, fast-growing and heavier weight broilers induced myopathies such as woody breast (WB), which affect the meat quality and cause significant economic losses. A radiofrequency method based on measurement of the dielectric properties at microwave frequencies was developed for rapid and nondestructive detection of woody breast disorder found in chicken breast meat. Dielectric measurements were performed with an open-ended coaxial probe connected to PNL-N5235B vector network analyzer for normal and defective (WB) fresh chicken breast meat for frequencies ranging from 200 MHz to 20 GHz and a meat temperature of about 7 °C. Spectra obtained for the normal and severe WB chicken breast show similar trends with frequency, with values of dielectric properties slightly higher for the WB chicken breast meat. At a given frequency (500 MHz), there exists correlations between the dielectric properties and composition of chicken breast meat (water content and protein content) that can be used to discern between normal and fillets with severe WB. Results show potential for rapid and systematic detection of the woody breast condition from measurement of the dielectric properties at a single microwave frequency.

title: Research on Image Watermarking Technology Based on Multi-head Attention Mechanism
authors: Xiaowei Wang, Lingling Jian, Kaiqi Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Digital watermarking is a technology that embeds copyright information or user information into an image in a way that is imperceptible to the human eye, and it is an effective copyright protection measure. Aiming at the problem that watermarking methods based on deep learning cannot fully highlight the key features of an image, to improve the visual quality of watermarked images, this paper proposes an image watermark embedding and extraction model based on the multihead attention mechanism. The feature representation capability is enhanced by introducing the multi-head attention module, and the watermark embedding and extraction are realized by using an end-to-end network architecture. The introduction of the multihead attention mechanism significantly enhances the watermark feature representation capability and maintains the structural integrity of the image through feature space manipulation. Experimental results show that the model improves the accuracy of watermark extraction while ensuring the image quality.

title: VB-based multi-target tracking under measurement merging
authors: Zijie Shang, Lin Gao, Wanchun Li, Yue Li, Huaguo Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper considers the problem of multi-target tracking (MTT) under measurement merging, which differs to the traditional MTT in the aspects that a measurement can be produced by many targets. Therefore the standard data association criterion cannot be applied to the case considered in this paper. In this paper, MTT under measurement merging is addressed within the framework of variational Bayesian inference. The resulting algorithm, termed by VB-MTT-MM, works with a newly designed likelihood function that allows each measurement to be associated with arbitrary number of measurements. Besides, data association events are parameterized into the likelihood function so that they can be explicitly computed. Leveraging the variational Bayesian method, the multi-target posterior can be efficiently computed with satisfactory accuracy. The performance of proposed algorithm is verified via simulations.

title: An Interrupted Sampling Repeater Jamming Suppression Method Based on Reference Signal Dictionary Matching
authors: Yingbo Qin, Bingxu Chen, Weiwei Fan, Feng Zhou
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: A DRFM-based interrupted sampling repeater jammer (ISRJ) poses a serious threat to radar by achieving signal processing gain and maintaining main-lobe jamming. A class of parameter-estimation-based reconstruction and cancellation methods has been proposed to suppress ISRJ. However, such methods often suffer from model mismatch in complex electromagnetic environments, resulting in poor suppression performance or severe target signal loss. To address this issue, a suppression algorithm based on reference signal dictionary matching is proposed in this article. The method reconstructs ISRJ through cross-correlation matching and amplitude estimation with phase compensation to achieve precise suppression. Simulation results verify the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method.

title: Adaptive Clutter Cancelation in Doppler Space under Purity Deficiency of Frequency Source
authors: Dehua Zhao, Qiang Cheng, Yuhao Yang, Linghao Xia, Pin Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Due to purity deficiency of frequency source, radar may not completely remove strong clutters in traditional moving target detection (MTD) or pulse Doppler (PD) modes. To address this problem, we propose an adaptive clutter cancelation method which leverages the insensitivity of data-dependent adaptive filtering to system model errors. The proposed method essentially employs adaptive Doppler filters instead of the traditional window-weighted discrete Fourier transform (DFT) in suppressing clutters. Due to the large number of pulses in MTD/PD modes, it is difficult to collecting sufficient independent identically distributed (i.i.d.) samples for covariance matrix estimation and computational burdened to inverse the covariance matrix. To address this challenge, this paper implements dimension reduction by conducting adaptive processing in Doppler space, i.e. collecting the target channel and a limited number of strong clutter channels to perform adaptive processing. This approach significantly reduces the demand for i.i.d. samples and also lowers computational complexity. Numeric results illustrates that the proposed method can effectively suppress the strong clutter which otherwise leakages using traditional Doppler filters under spectral purity deficiency.

title: Key Neighborhood Selection Graph Convolutional Network for Fault Diagnosis of Welding Robots

title: Evaluation of Sick Building Syndrome with Fuzzy COPRAS: a multi-criteria approach for ranking alternatives to mitigate symptoms
authors: Iasmin Lourenço Niza, João Carlos Colmenero, Evandro Eduardo Broday
abstract: Sick Building Syndrome (SBS) refers to symptoms that building occupants can experience due to poor indoor environmental quality, such as respiratory problems, headaches, and fatigue. These symptoms are often associated with factors such as inadequate ventilation, insufficient humidity and temperature control, and contaminants in the air. The complexity of SBS requires advanced decision-making approaches, especially in scenarios involving multiple criteria evaluation. This article proposes applying the fuzzy COPRAS (Complex Proportional Assessment) method as a robust tool for deepening knowledge about SBS in built environments to mitigate its effects. The fuzzy methodology makes it possible to deal effectively with uncertainties and subjectivity, characterizing the weights of design resources and sub-resources in linguistic terms generated from triangular fuzzy numbers. Five alternatives and six factors related to indoor air quality, promoting occupant well-being, humidity and temperature control, advanced ventilation systems, and the implementation of indoor green spaces were evaluated. The COPRAS fuzzy model made it possible to rank these alternatives according to their relative effectiveness in mitigating SBS. The results indicate that internal green spaces and chemical and materials management policy are priorities, highlighting the importance of careful planning in choosing the most appropriate solutions to improve the health and well-being of building occupants.

title: Fast and Effective Video Inpainting via Implicit Motion-Guided Propagation and Sparse Attention
authors: Xinyu Yang, Yuanman Li, Bin Li, Yanshan Li, Jiantao Zhou, Xia Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Video inpainting aims to reconstruct missing or corrupted regions in video frames, with applications in video editing, restoration, and special effects. Current deep video inpainting methods rely on optical flow to guide the propagation of effective features and spatiotemporal attention mechanisms to model relationships between frames. However, as an explicit motion representation, the optical flow extracted offline in preceding steps often suffers from instability and errors during estimation. These errors accumulate during subsequent content hallucination, resulting in artifacts and blurring. Meanwhile, although traditional spatiotemporal attention effectively captures frame relationships, its dense computational nature introduces redundant information, disrupting inpainting tasks and reducing efficiency. To address these issues, we propose an implicit motion-guided approach for efficient video inpainting. Instead of relying on optical flow, our method uses implicit motion in the latent feature space to guide the dual-domain propagation of images and features end-to-end, avoiding error accumulation from the independent optical flow estimation process. Additionally, we introduce a self-correcting module that enables feedback between image and feature propagation, reducing errors during propagation. Furthermore, we design an adaptive sparse video attention mechanism to focus on highly relevant regions, minimizing the impact of irrelevant information. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches both qualitatively and quantitatively, while also delivering superior efficiency.

title: Dual-Band Rectifying Metasurface for Energy Harvesting with Second-Order Response
authors: Chengxiang Lei, Lianwen Deng, Shengxiang Huang, Lei-Lei Qiu
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: Conventional multi-frequency rectifying metasurface (RMS) generally suffer from drastically degraded rectification efficiency at slight frequency shifts. To this end, this letter presents a dual-band second-order RMS based on a multi-mode patch resonator. Through etching symmetrical ring slots and bended H-shaped slots into the unit, four resonating modes are effectively excited and properly allocated to cover dual ISM bands. A 6×6 array prototype was fabricated and experimentally evaluated. The measured total efficiency remains above 50% in the 2.51–2.595 GHz band and above 35% in the 5.68–5.8 GHz band, with peak values reaching 53% and 42.2%, respectively. Moreover, the proposed RMS maintains stable performance under varying polarization conditions. As the main advantages, the second-order response is firstly designed for broader bandwidth and improved frequency selectivity. As a result, the proposed RMS shows strong potential for application in energy harvesting systems, where it can significantly improve the frequency robustness of the rectification efficiency.

title: A Deep Slow Feature-Based Multi-Source Information Fusion Model for Fault Diagnosis of Rotating Machines
authors: Yuanyuan Liu, Jiayu Wang, Yang Hu, Le Yao, Xiaoyu Jiang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Traditional intelligent fault diagnosis methods for rotating machines are constructed on vibration signals. Such sole reliance on a single signal limits comprehensive extraction and analysis of process information, leading to unsatisfactory accuracy. For example, signal attenuation trends of rotating machines are easily neglected. To enhance fault diagnosis accuracy, we propose a Siamese-based multi-source information fusion method. In this framework, we employ multiple feature extractors for diverse-source feature extraction, including vibration, acoustic, temperature, and current signals. Each feature extractor integrates a Siamese network with slow feature analysis (SFA) for signal attenuation trend extraction. Specifically, the principle of SFA is embedded into training loss of supervised Siamese networks, which employs adjacent samples as pairs to guide the network in learning representations that change minimally. Multiple features are then fused for rotating machine fault diagnosis. Effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by a bearing fault case from the Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology. According to results, compared to conventional single-source approaches, the proposed method significantly enhances the fault diagnosis accuracy and demonstrates superior robustness under high-speed operating conditions.

title: Satellite Resource Scheduling Based on Multi-Agent POMDP
authors: Wangjie Chen, Wenlong Li, Weiqiang Zhu, Zhenhong Fan, Jian Yang, Han Yu, Tianyu Wang, Ping Huang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With the rapid development of large-scale satellite constellations, efficient resource scheduling in dynamic and complex electromagnetic environments has emerged as a critical challenge. Traditional centralized optimization algorithms suffer from high computational complexity, poor adaptability to nonconvex mixed-integer constraints, and limited robustness in nonstationary environments. In this paper, we propose a novel multiagent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework based on Partially Observable Markov Decision Process (POMDP) modeling and a Modified Multi-Task Multi-Agent Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (Mod-MTMATD3) algorithm. Through a hierarchical state space design, joint action space optimization, and a composite reward mechanism, this framework achieves joint optimization of power allocation, task scheduling, and topology coordination in multi-satellite collaborative communication scenarios. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves over 40% improvement in convergence speed and a 63.6% increase in final reward value compared to traditional methods. Under extreme conditions where the inter-satellite distance is extended to 400 kilometers, it maintains a broadcast success rate of 96.2%, representing an 11.2% enhancement over benchmark algorithms. Additionally, the algorithm reduces energy consumption by 30%, significantly improving system energy efficiency. This study provides a scalable intelligent decision-making framework for large-scale satellite networks, offering crucial technical support for the development of space-air-ground integrated networks.

title: Clock-Asynchronous Single-Beacon Navigation with A Range-Only EKF Fusion Method
authors: Haidong Gu, Yanjun Lin, Xudong Zhao, Yunshi Yang, Fengwei Tian, Li Chai
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Addressing GPS unavailability underwater and high deployment costs of conventional acoustic navigation systems, this paper presents a clock-asynchronous single-beacon navigation method. Using just one acoustic beacon, the approach constructs a range-only observation model through a time difference of arrival (TDoA) analysis of UUV-received signals. By integrating vehicle motion data and sound speed profiles, it achieves joint estimation of underwater positions and current velocities via extended kalman filter (EKF). Simulations verify the performance of position accuracy along comb-shaped paths. During lake trials at 10 m depth and 1 km communication range, initial bearing estimation achieved 10 meter RMS precision, effectively overcoming sound speed variations. This solution provides small UUVs with a low-complexity, high-stealth navigation approach, substantially enhancing underwater operational capabilities.

title: Energy Efficiency Optimization in the IoT using Whale Optimization Algorithm and Simulated Annealing
authors: Ameen Shaheen, Ala’a Al-Shaikh, Abdallah Sameer Damra, Mohammad Rasmi Al-Mousa, Sami Askar, Suha Afaneh
abstract: The Internet of Things (IoT) has found applications across a wide range of sectors, including smart cities, agriculture, waste management, weather monitoring, and energy grids. Despite its growing impact, there is still room for enhancement—particularly in terms of energy efficiency. This study focuses on extending the lifespan of IoT networks by minimizing the energy consumption of sensor nodes. To achieve this, it proposes an optimal selection of Cluster Heads (CHs) that can effectively balance energy usage across the network. A hybrid meta-heuristic algorithm is introduced, combining the strengths of Simulated Annealing (SA) and the Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA). Key performance indicators such as node density, energy distribution, ambient temperature, remaining battery power, and a defined cost function are employed to identify the most efficient CHs. Experimental results show that the proposed hybrid method outperforms existing algorithms, including WOA, Adaptive Gravitational Search Algorithm (AGSA), Genetic Algorithm (GA), and Artificial Bee Colony (ABC).

title: HCA-Net: Hierarchical Contextual Attention Network for Lightweight and Accurate Polyp Segmentation
authors: Chengcheng Li, Huiying Xu, Xinzhong Zhu, Huiling Chen, Xinwang Liu, Yun Liu, Chang Tang, Zhendong Chen, Miaomiao Li, Shanfu Lu, Yue Hu
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: Early detection of colorectal polyps is crucial for clinical screening and cancer prevention, where accurate and efficient automatic segmentation plays a pivotal role. However, colonoscopy images often suffer from low contrast, blurred boundaries, and scale variations, making segmentation challenging. Existing encoder-decoder networks (e.g., U-Net) suffer from asymmetric supervision and feature redundancy, which in turn lead to semantic inconsistency and loss of fine details. While deeper or hybrid designs alleviate these issues, their high complexity and computational burden limit feasibility in real-time clinical practice. To address these challenges, we propose a lightweight segmentation framework, Hierarchical Contextual Attention Network (HCA-Net), consisting of the Redundancy-Suppressed Dual-Path Downsampling (RS-DPD) module and the Boundary-Aware Semantic Alignment Upsampling (BA-SAU) module, applied to the encoder and decoder, respectively. RS-DPD suppresses redundancy while preserving fine-grained details through a dual-path design, whereas BA-SAU leverages cross-layer contextual attention to enforce semantic consistency and enhance boundary sensitivity. Both modules are built upon our proposed Hierarchical Contextual Attention (HCA) mechanism, which combines convolutional projection with pooling-based compression to achieve efficient global modeling and accurate local boundary restoration. In addition, a composite boundary-aware loss function is designed to improve pixel-level accuracy, structural consistency, and robustness in low-contrast and boundary-ambiguous regions. Extensive experiments on public colorectal polyp datasets demonstrate that HCA-Net achieves state-of-the-art (SOTA) segmentation accuracy with significantly improved efficiency, while maintaining robustness under low-contrast and blurred-boundary conditions.

title: Power Analysis Attacks on Cryptographic Devices: Insights, Solutions, and Emerging Challenges
authors: Muhammad Younas, Muhammad Usama Riaz, Daud Shah, Zakir Khan
abstract: Security is the predominant challenge from past few years and still gaining attention in cryptographic devices. Cryptographic algorithm stand alone cannot fulfill this need because of the presence of side channel attacks. Due to the emission of power, electromagnetic field, time, sound and various kind of other glitches it seeks the attacker attention. To obfuscate the side channel attack various countermeasure has been proposed in literature and evaluated on various crypto graphic algorithms i.e. AES, Present, SIMON, SM4 etc. As no countermeasure fully obfuscate the attack but to increase the time and resources of attacker makes the counter measure efficient. The primarily focus of this paper is power analysis attack and at some places touches the electromagnetic attack as electromagnetic attack is ensued because of the power emission. This survey classifies the recent counter measures as hardware and software counter measure then highlight the scheme, also insight the overhead argument of each scheme. Additionally, we consider these approaches based on efficacy, power overhead, and area constraints, offering an equalized perspective on their practical deployment. Finally, the paper defines key research challenges and future directions, aiming to guide upcoming researchers in advancing the field of cryptographic security against side-channel threats.

title: Normalized Gradient-based Convex Combination Proportionate Adaptive Feedback Cancellation Algorithm
authors: Xiru Liu, Yi Yu, Yongcun Fan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In order to effectively suppress the phenomenon of whistling in hearing aids, we propose the convex combination scheme of the proportionate adaptive feedback cancellation algorithm with different step sizes through the mixing parameter, with performance in both fast convergence and low steady-state residual error. Importantly, we design a normalized gradient learning rule for updating the mixing parameter, which narrows the range of the learning rate significantly as compared to the non-normalized gradient-based learning rule. Furthermore, to make the transition between convergence and steady-state stages smoother, a novel weight vector transfer strategy is developed. By using the realistic speech input, simulation results have demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in contrast with its counterparts.

title: Design and Implementation of a Virtual Instrument for Dream Onset Detection Using Physiological Signals in LabVIEW
authors: Sarmad Saeed, Muhammad Omar Cheema, Rija Khan, Sohaib Raheem, Anusha Ishtiaq, Noor Fatima, Ayesha Saleem, Areeb Ahmed, Zia Mohy-Ud-Din, Jahan Zeb Gul
abstract: This research introduces an application of a multimodal analysis system of physiological signals that can help in identifying dream episodes during sleep via Electrooculography (EOG), Electromyography (EMG), and Electrocardiography (ECG). The BIOPAC MP36 data acquisition system was utilized in obtaining data with sampling at the rate of 2000 Hz. Participants were followed up to natural sleep onset in sleep-deprived conditions to allow an opportunity to enter a sleep state under controlled conditions. Rapid eye movement was monitored by EOG signals, which constitute a main indicator of REM sleep that is often accompanied by dreaming. EMG was applied to measure atonia in muscles during sleep to observe the state of the autonomic nervous system, and ECGs were analyzed to calculate heart rate variability (HRV), which provided information about the state of the autonomic nervous system in dreams. Threshold-based analysis and point-by-point analysis were used to implement signal processing and REM detection logical steps in LabVIEW.

title: Traditional vs. Self-Supervised Audio Features for Speaker Verification in Urdu: A Comparative Study
authors: Saqlain Ahmed, Farhan Mazhar, Isha Imaan, Muhammad Hamza, Junaid Mir
abstract: This study examines the performance of traditional handcrafted audio features alongside self-supervised learning (SSL) audio features for automatic speaker verification (ASV) in Urdu, which is categorized as a low-resource language. Given the rising concern over audio deepfakes, particularly in biometric authentication systems, developing robust ASV methods is increasingly critical. The research evaluates Mel-frequency cepstral coefficients (MFCCs), linear predictive cepstral coefficients (LPCCs), and Gammatone cepstral coefficients (GTCCs) against wav2vec2-based SSL features, utilizing a support vector machine (SVM) classifier. Experiments were conducted on a newly developed Urdu deepfake audio dataset that includes both authentic and spoofed samples generated using Tacotron and VITS text-to-speech models. Results reveal that while LPCCs and GTCCs perform competitively among handcrafted features, wav2vec2 embeddings significantly surpass all traditional methods, achieving an equal error rate as low as 0.01 when employing the radial basis function kernel. These findings emphasize the advantages of SSL-based representations in capturing speakerspecific traits and effectively resisting spoofing attacks in Urdu.

title: TransSE: A Transfer Learning-Based Predictive Model for Distinguishing Super Enhancers and Typical Enhancers_supp3-3657361.tif
authors: Junxiang Gao
abstract: Super-enhancers (SEs), comprising clusters of transcriptional regulatory elements, play essential roles in gene expression regulation and cell fate determination. Current computational methods for identifying SEs from genomic sequences face challenges in prediction accuracy and cross-species generalizability. This study introduces TransSE, a deep learning framework combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks with cross-species transfer learning for SE prediction. TransSE employs a two-phase strategy: pre-training on combined human and mouse data to learn conserved regulatory features, followed by species-specific fine-tuning to capture organism-specific patterns. Evaluation on human and mouse datasets demonstrates that TransSE achieves superior accuracy compared to existing methods including SENet, DeepSE, and transformer-based models (DNABERT, Enformer), with AUC values of 0.828 (human) and 0.832 (mouse). Ablation studies confirm that convolutional blocks are essential for feature extraction, while transfer learning and recurrent layers provide meaningful performance improvements. Feature analysis reveals that TransSE distinguishes SEs from typical enhancers based on learned sequence representations, achieving 10.4-fold improvement in clustering metrics. The model demonstrates effective cross-species prediction capability, maintaining AUC <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.79 when trained on one species and evaluated on another. Conservation pattern analysis shows that TransSE integrates both evolutionarily conserved and species-specific regulatory features, enabling robust performance across organisms with limited training data. A user-friendly web interface (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">http://transse.shenlabahmu.com</uri>) provides automated SE prediction, motif analysis, and variant impact assessment. Case studies using experimentally validated SEs demonstrate the tool's utility for investigating regulatory elements and prioritizing functional variants in disease-associated genomic regions. TransSE advances the investigation of gene regulatory mechanisms and facilitates identification of disease-associated variation in enhancer regions.

title: Enhancing Security and Reliability in IoT Smart Homes via Advanced Engineering Testing Methodologies
authors: Tarek Kanaan, Ceselia Alyawanseh, Ghassan Kanaan, Nesreen A. Hamad
abstract: This paper analyzes how new software testing approaches affect the security and reliability of smart home systems in the Internet of Things (IoT). Given the fluid and multifaceted nature of the IoT environment, it is not possible to perform comprehensive testing of all scenarios. This prompts the need for selecting test cases that provide the needed validation for resource expenditure. It looks into major software testing purposes, functionality, and reliability, as well as robustness on all levels of testing - unit, integration, system, and acceptance testing. Particular emphasis is put on white-box methods, for instance, control flow and dataflow testing IoT software components, which are most capable of detecting faults. Further, the paper analyzes research gaps in combinatorial testing, IoT security, and software automation, underlining their shortcomings. The gaps correspond with the existing knowledge that automated and combinatorial testing while improving coverage and efficiency, are difficult to adapt in IoT ecosystems with high interconnectivity. It could be deduced that further studies should concentrate on adaptive testing frameworks for smart IoT homes to scale with the proposed intelligent techniques for security and reliability.

title: Protein Matching for Function Prediction using Siamese Neural Network
authors: Varsha Shukla, Rahul Pradhan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Protein similarity lies at the heart of many critical tasks in bio-informatics, from predicting protein function to drug discovery and evolutionary studies. The discipline has deployed traditional approaches such as sequence alignment and structural comparison to serve the field for decades, their limitations in scalability, sensitivity to remote homologs, and reliance on handcrafted features have become increasingly apparent in the era of high-throughput data. In this study, one of the concept of deep learning, specifically Siamese neural networks for similarity matching, is explored for protein matching. By leveraging pretrained protein sequence embeddings and biologically informed functional annotations, a framework is developed that can learn nuanced relationships between protein pairs.
