title: Three-dimensional Microwave Imaging of Intracerebral Hemorrhage Based on Confocal Algorithm
authors: Jiapeng Li, Qinwei Li, Xiaoguang Lu, Hang Wu, Ming Yu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the clinical demand for precise detection of hemorrhagic stroke, this study proposes an ultra-wideband (UWB) microwave localization method based on confocal imaging. A preconstructed 3D brain model incorporating electromagnetic properties of seven tissue types was employed, with a 5 mm -radius hemorrhagic lesion embedded. The finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) method was utilized to simulate electromagnetic wave propagation within the model. A 13-antenna array and a 0.73-3.27 GHz Gaussian pulse served as the excitation source to acquire multi-channel scattered signals. A dual-matrix differential processing scheme was designed to effectively suppress system noise and extract lesion-specific scattering features. Combined with a wave velocity model based on the average dielectric constant of brain tissue and signal interpolation techniques, a time-domain confocal imaging algorithm was applied to achieve 3D spatial energy back-projection reconstruction. Experimental results demonstrate that the reconstructed lesion coordinates (93, 93, 27) successfully localized the preset hemorrhagic site (90, 90, 30), with localization errors confined to the millimeter scale (maximum localization error: $\mathbf{3 ~ m m}$). This study validates the feasibility of microwave imaging for detecting intracranial microbleeds and provides a theoretical foundation for developing portable diagnostic devices for stroke.

title: Mitigating Sunlight with Differential Signaling in Underwater Optical Wireless Communication
authors: Tharuka Govinda Waduge, Boon-Chong Seet, Kay Vopel
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Underwater optical wireless communication (UOWC) is an emerging technology vital to provide highbandwidth connectivity underwater. However, inhomogeneity of the inherent optical properties of the stratified seawater column and interference from sunlight in the euphotic zone can negatively affect optical communication links. In such environment, longer-wavelength (yellow) spectra are preferable for close-range, low-power communication links, whereas short-spectrum transmissions (blue) can support high-powered, long-distance links. Here, we assess the possibility of using modified, dual-color differential signaling (DS) with complementary detection and spread spectrum to mitigate solar interference in diffused line-of-sight links. We discuss the utility of a dual-color direct-sequence spread-spectrum scheme (DSSS), and show that among purely monochromatic on-off keying (OOK) types, 465 nm performed the worst under sunlight ($\mathbf{B E R} \approx \mathbf{3. 1} \times \mathbf{1 0}^{-3}$ for a 1 W output, 10 m link at 25 m depth in clear, S1 ocean water), but the best below the subsurface chlorophyll maximum (BER $\lt2.8 \times 10^{-7}$ for 465 nm, at below 120 m). The 2-level DS-OOK (2LDS-OOK) schemes outperformed the monochromatic OOK, particularly under strong sunlight ($B E R\lt4.5 \times 10^{-7}$ at 25 m). Their performance can be further enhanced through iterative, multiplicative signal combination ($\operatorname{BER}\lt1.3 \times 10^{-7}$ at 25 m). We conclude that adopting multi-wavelength strategies may enhance UOWC in dynamic, time-varying environments.

title: Quantifying Solidarity Economy Credit Risk using CNNs and Hybrid Optimization
authors: Srimaan Yarram, Madhura G K, Naresh Jetty, Pavani Addanki, Sanat Pattanaik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Sophisticated risk management systems are essential for lowering credit risk in financial operations, particularly in the current unpredictable economic environment. Credit risk, or the possibility that a borrower won't fulfill their responsibilities, poses a serious threat to the stability of the financial system. Traditional methods for assessing and managing credit risk, such as credit scoring and historical data analysis, are insufficient given the complexity of today's financial markets. Modern risk management tools can assist identify, assess, and reduce credit risk more effectively. A significant advancement in this field is the integration of machine learning algorithms with big data. By sorting through mounds of data from multiple sources, financial institutions can gain additional insight into economic indicators, market trends, and borrower behavior. Machine learning algorithms enable more precise default probability forecasts, opening the door for risk-reduction strategies. Additionally, real-time risk monitoring solutions have become more and more common. These tools enable banks to monitor loan portfolios continuously, spot warning signs that can point to a default, and take prompt action. A novel approach to redefining the concept of a "default" in the context of the often-present severe class disparities is proposed in this paper, which deals with the assessment of credit risk in solidarity economy firms. The objective of creating and assessing credit scoring models is to enhance risk management by identifying default risk using both internal and external data. Machine learning models and statistics are evaluated using a one-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The first design use hyper-parameter learning in conjunction with an optimization method known as the hybrid bat algorithm to learn crucial features for classification. To prevent overfitting and maintain a consistent predictive capacity of the model, the second architecture uses an attention mechanism on top of the deep network and evaluates it using the Balanced Accuracy metric and the holding power of the performance. A balanced sample within a class size is essential for improving prediction performance.

title: A Heuristic-Based Approach for Classifying Functional and Non-functional Arabic Security Requirements
authors: Baraa Khamayseh, Nabil Arman, Faisal Khamayseh
abstract: Research on classification of requirements written Arabic continue to increase. However, there is a shortage of reliable classification of security requirements. This paper addresses the absence of Heuristic-Based approaches for classification of Functional and Non-functional Arabic Security Requirements. The study presents a semi-automated method for categorizing Arabic security requirements into functional and non-functional types using CAMeL Tools, a natural language processing tool. The main contribution of this study is in proposing the set of classifying-heuristics. Researchers developed these heuristics tailored to Arabic sentence patterns by employing CAMeL v1.4.1 to extract tokens, part-of-speech tags, and lemmas, which were subsequently analyzed for classification.

title: Hybrid CNN-RNN Deep Learning Framework for EEG-Based Mental Health Disorder Diagnosis with Explainable AI
authors: Shams Tabrez Siddiqui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Mental health diseases like depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia affect worldwide healthcare systems. Traditional diagnostic methods are subjective, thus data-driven methods are needed. EEG, a non-invasive brain activity measurement method, reveals neural patterns related with mental health disorders. EEG data processing is now automated thanks to deep learning, boosting mental disease classification and detection. This study introduces a hybrid deep learning framework that leverages both Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs)—specialized in detecting spatial patterns—and Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs)—suited for modeling temporal dynamics. This paper provides a Hybrid CNN-RNN Deep Learning Framework that uses CNNs for spatial feature extraction and RNNs for temporal relationships in EEG signals. The proposed approach uses Explainable AI (XAI) for clinical interpretability and an attention strategy to improve feature learning. After testing on benchmark EEG datasets, the suggested method outperformed CNN and RNN models with 88.9% accuracy. Despite promising results, dataset variability, class imbalance, and real-time processing persist. Future research should focus on multimodal data fusion, privacy-preserving federated learning, and real-time wearable EEG-based mental health monitoring. This study shows how deep learning might improve mental health diagnostics and enable clinically viable AI-powered treatments.

title: Classification of Health of Foetus using Machine Learning
authors: Ayushi Jayaraj, Shubham Kumar, B. Ankayarkanni, R. Sathyabama, Mercy Paul Selvan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Pregnancy is a critical period during which vigilant monitoring of fetal and maternal health is essential to prevent complications and ensure positive outcomes. Traditional fetal health assessment methods such as cardiotocography (CTG), ultrasound imaging, and clinical evaluation, though effective, often suffer from interpretability issues, episodic monitoring, and dependency on expert judgment. This study proposes an advanced machine learning-based framework to classify fetal health status into normal and abnormal categories using CTG data, aiming to enhance diagnostic accuracy and clinical reliability. A comparative analysis was conducted using ensemble-based models—XGBoost and LightGBM—as well as support vector machines (SVM). Among these, XGBoost achieved the highest performance with 94.2% accuracy, 0.93 precision, and 0.94 recall. LightGBM followed closely, offering comparable results with faster computation. Furthermore, the study integrates explainable AI techniques to improve model transparency and facilitate trust among healthcare practitioners. The results demonstrate the potential of interpretable machine learning models to support obstetric decision-making, especially in settings lacking specialized medical expertise. This approach not only enhances fetal health classification but also lays the foundation for intelligent, data-driven prenatal care systems.

title: Intelligent NSGA-II governed Type-2 Fuzzy-PSS approach for stability improvement of two-area Microgrid
authors: Shibanika Panda, Alivarani Mohapatra, Byamakesh Nayak
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The power source that can provide electricity to a small geographic area where electrifying it with a utility system would be too difficult is a microgrid. A "microgrid" is a distribution level grid that is linked to a range of small-scale power generating devices, such as micro-turbine generator, solar panels, wind turbines, and fuel cells, as well as new accumulation devices, such as flywheels and ultra capacitors and battery bank. The weather affects the capacity to produce electricity from renewable energy-based power plants, such as wind and solar photovoltaic systems. Variations in load dynamics, wind speed, and sun intensity all cause a considerable decline in microgrid performance, especially frequency. The frequency oscillation degrades the microgrid performances and it requires an immediate action for obtaining steady and constant frequency. To acquire a stable system frequency performance under various conditions, this work has employed a unique Type-II Fuzzy power system stabilizer (T2-FPSS) controller. This research forum also made a performance related comparison analysis of the projected PSS-FFO controller over Fuzzy-PID and standard PID controllers. This work also planned a non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm-II (NSGA-II) to tune the relative gains of the implemented controllers.

title: Exponential Weighting Based Network Ranking for Heterogeneous Wireless Networks
authors: Faizan Bashir, Syed Hassaan Ali Shah, Jawaid Iqbal
abstract: With the enormous development in communication infrastructure different wireless technologies like (2G,3G,4G,5G, WLAN, WiMAX, Wi-Fi) is being developed nowadays. These different technologies infrastructure implemented in different areas and has different coverage area makes the situation complicated. The most challenging situation in this scenario is to provide seamless communication and enable the user to connect the best available networks among the multiple available networks. To confront this situation, network ranking is intended on the basis of user's provided service quality. For that, multi attribute decision making (MCDM) algorithms namely AHP (Analytical Hierarchy Process) and TOPSIS was applied. AHP evaluates weight of each criteria in networks and TOPSIS ranks each network according to different network characteristics. But here we will use these algorithm combined to avoid the ranking abnormalities when executing TOPSIS. Because TOPSIS determine entropy as an objective weight for networks attributes which eliminate the arbitration and subjectivity problem while executing AHP algorithm. The algorithms use relative relationship of business types and network performance attributes to determine the subjective weights calculated by AHP and objective weights by TOPSIS algorithm and then combined these weights to form an integrate weights. Choosing this AHP-TOPSIS algorithm to perform optimum network ranking in HetNets can rank the networks correctly and select the best suitable network for the required business requirement.

title: EEG-triggered Awareness for a Collaborative Robot
authors: Gustavo Assunção, Bruno Ferreira, Paulo Menezes, Zohar Tal, Andrey Solovov, Aniana Cruz, Ana Pinto
abstract: Awareness is a major safety factor in human- machine interaction environments, with worker accustomation to robot operation and consequential oblivion of their surroundings potentially having disastrous consequences for either agent or equipment. This is particularly relevant in collaborative scenarios, with workers and robots engaging in close proximity. While consideration for safety is an inherent, albeit forgettable trait of human workers, robots are yet incapable of making such judgements. This translates to collaborative robots typically integrating overt shutdown procedures activated if and when danger is detected for workers, tying with production and other equipment damage issues. Moreover, human focus is both intrinsically tied with safety judgement and manifestable in variable bio-signalling, of which some can be captured via brain-computer interface technologies. This short paper advocates for the evaluation of worker bio-signalling to avert danger, by instead adapting robot operation. It presents the monitoring of human attention as a by-product of single channel electroencephalography waves, to modulate robot functioning to complete its task, track its human colleague while they do their part, or halt. Implications and limitations are pondered for usage in real-life industrial scenarios.

title: A Low-Power Decoder for 1000BASE-T Transceiver using T-Algorithm
authors: Shengyi Chen, Xin Chen, Ying Zhang, Zongyi Lan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Conventional Parallel Decision Feedback Decoder (PDFD) for $\mathbf{1 0 0 0}$ BASE-T transceivers, using Register Exchange Architecture (REA) in the Survivor Memory Unit (SMU), inherently suffers from high dynamic power consumption since the requirement to store and shift symbols for all possible paths at every decoding step, leading to massive register bit-flipping activity. To address this critical inefficiency, this paper leverages path pruning with the $\mathbf{T}$-algorithm to reduce the power consumption in SMU. The core innovation lies in integrating the T-algorithm to discard paths dynamically and deliver the enable signal to the ACSU (Add Compare Select Unit) and SMU. In SMU, these enable signals are used to gate the clock of SMU registers, effectively preventing the storage and unnecessary switching activity associated with pruned paths. These signals are also used in ACSU to eliminate redundant addition operations for discarded paths. Crucially, this power reduction is achieved without effecting BER performance. Synthesized with a 28 nm CMOS standard cell library, the results demonstrate that the proposed decoder achieves a significant 21% reduction in power consumption compared to a conventional PDFD.

title: Explainable Deep Learning for Modbus/TCP Traffic Classification in Industrial Control Systems
authors: Mohamed Tawfik, Wael Badawy
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Industrial Control Systems (ICS) are essential to critical infrastructure, from manufacturing and transportation to power generation. Among their communication protocols, Modbus/TCP remains widely deployed due to its simplicity and interoperability, but its lack of built-in security makes it vulnerable to spoofing, packet injection, and replay attacks. To address these vulnerabilities, deep learning models have emerged as powerful tools for intrusion detection. Yet, their “black-box” nature raises challenges of trust and interpretability in high-stakes industrial environments. This paper presents a comparative study of two deep learning approaches for Modbus/TCP traffic classification: a baseline Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and an Attention-enhanced CNN. Using a dataset of 6,690 labeled Modbus traffic samples, both models were trained and evaluated for accuracy, robustness, and interpretability. The baseline CNN achieved perfect classification accuracy but displayed overconfidence and reliance on a narrow set of packet bytes. In contrast, the Attention-CNN slightly reduced accuracy but provided more calibrated outputs and richer interpretability. Local Interpretable Model-Agnostic Explanations (LIME) were applied to both models, showing that the CNN focused on a few dominant features, while the Attention-CNN distributed importance more broadly across packet fields. The findings underscore the trade-off between predictive performance and explainability. While the baseline CNN demonstrates flawless accuracy on the dataset, the Attention-CNN offers insights more aligned with expert reasoning, making it better suited for real-world deployment where transparency and trust are as critical as detection accuracy.

title: MaskScene: Hierarchical Conditional Masked Models for Real-time 3D Indoor Scene Synthesis
authors: Xinyu Zhang, Yusen Liu, Qichuan Geng, Zhong Zhou, Wenfeng Song
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Indoor scene synthesis is essential for creative industries, recent advances in scene synthesis using diffusion and autoregressive models have shown promising results. However, existing models struggle to simultaneously achieve real-time performance, high visual fidelity, and flexible scene editability. To tackle these challenges, we propose MaskScene, a novel hierarchical conditional masked model for real-time 3D indoor scene synthesis and editing. Specifically, MaskScene introduces a hierarchical scene representation that explicitly encodes scene relationships, semantics, and tokenization. Based on this representation, we design a hierarchical conditional masked modeling architecture that enables parallel and iterative decoding, conditioned on both semantics and relationships. By masking local objects and leveraging the hierarchical structure of the scene, the model learns to infer and synthesize missing regions from partial observations, enabling rapid construction of 3D indoor environments that more accurately reflect real-world scenes. Compared to state-of-the-art methods, MaskScene achieves 80× faster generation speed and improves scene quality by 10%, while also supporting zero-shot editing, such as scene completion and rearrangement, without extra fine-tuning. Our project and dataset will be public.

title: Complex Vector Harmonic Current Controller Based on Multiple Synchronous Reference Frame for Harmonic Reduction Considering Saliency and Flux Saturation of IPMSMs
authors: Yun-jae Lee, Hwigon Kim, Sung-ho Kang, Young-doo Yoon
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: In this paper, a harmonic current controller based on the multiple synchronous reference frame (MSRF) is proposed to achieve stable harmonic current control in an interior permanent magnet synchronous motor (IPMSMs) at dynamic response. The structure of the controller consists of complex vector PI controllers that control the current of each frequency component connected in parallel. To ensure a stable dynamic response, controller is designed to achieve pole-zero cancellation between the plant and the resonant controller. In this process, the controller structure and gains are determined by considering the saliency and flux saturation of the plant. To consider saliency, the controller gains are applied before performing the rotational transformation into each harmonic reference frame. Additionally, considering flux saturation, the controller gains are designed with dynamic inductance and apparent inductance. The proposed controller can be applied with the same structure even to motors without saliency like SPMSMs. Experiments were conducted on a 17 kW IPMSM including 6th harmonic components, and the improvement in controller performance was verified through dynamic current response analysis.

title: Review of the Application of 3D Modeling on Trains
authors: Zhibo Sun, Chuanzhi Zang, Jiaxing Sun, Yetian Tian, Xiaoming Han, Xinxin Wang, Zhijia Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper reviews potential technical approaches applicable to train 3D reconstruction. It first presents 3D data acquisition methods, including image-based, LiDAR-based, and multi-source fusion approaches. The paper then systematically summarizes 3D reconstruction algorithms, ranging from traditional multi-view geometry to deep learning and generative models. Subsequently, the advantages and limitations of each method in terms of modeling accuracy, detail recovery, and realtime performance are discussed, along with their specific applications to trains. Finally, the paper identifies existing technical bottlenecks and highlights directions for future research.

title: A Novel Framework for Spatial-Temporal Soft Measurements with Sparse Graph Structure
authors: Rui Zhao, Haotian Zhang, Yan Chen, Dazi Li, Jinglin Zhou
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: In complex industrial processes, multivariate time series data often exhibit complex and dynamic nonlinear dependencies between variables. Traditional modeling methods are difficult to effectively capture the structural characteristics of such high-dimensional data. In order to improve the soft measurement prediction accuracy of key quality variables, this paper proposes an end-to-end modeling framework that integrates component long short-term memory network (cLSTM) and residual graph convolutional neural network (ResGCN). This method constructs the input graph structure for the graph neural network using the sparse adjacency matrix obtained from the cLSTM. The hidden states output by the cLSTM are employed as node features fed into the graph convolutional module, enabling spatiotemporal joint modeling. To enhance the deep representation capability of the graph neural network, this paper introduces residual connections to mitigate over-smoothing issues. A composite loss function combining mean squared error and structural sparsity regularization terms is designed to guide the model toward learning more distinctive graph structures. Experiments on Tennessee Eastman process data demonstrate that this method exhibits outstanding performance in prediction accuracy, structural modeling capability, and robustness, showcasing strong application potential in modeling complex industrial processes.

title: Subband-Enhanced Time-Frequency and Perceptual Modeling for Diffusion Speech Enhancement
authors: Chang Zhuang, NengHeng Zheng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Diffusion-based speech enhancement has demonstrated remarkable performance, but existing models still lack precise time-frequency modeling capabilities and fall short in aligning with perceptual metrics. To address these issues, we propose TF-NCSN++, which integrates a TF-GridNet module into the NCSN++ backbone to enable explicit cross-frequency and temporal modeling; at the same time, we introduce MD-NCSN++, which leverages normalized PESQ scores to train a lightweight metric discriminator, providing auxiliary perceptual guidance and imposing a weak constraint on the diffusion objective. Experiments on the VoiceBank+DEMAND and WSJ0-CHiME3 datasets show that TF-NCSN++ significantly improves intelligibility and distortion metrics, while MD-NCSN++ effectively enhances perceptual metrics. When combined, the two achieve optimal or near-optimal results across six evaluation measures, fully demonstrating the synergistic advantages of structural modeling and objective alignment.

title: Wireless Fire Alarm System Using ATmega8A and nRF24l01 Featuring Power Redundancy
authors: Nesma Tamer Alabyad, Ali Ehab Mohamed Ali
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and evaluation of a wireless fire alarm system that integrates an ATmega8A microcontroller with an nRF24L01 transceiver to enable reliable multi-sensor fire detection and robust wireless communication. The system supports smoke, heat, and flame sensing through distributed transmitter nodes, each incorporating a built-in self-test button for routine functional verification and maintenance. A dual power strategy combines standard main home power supply with a rechargeable lithiumion backup battery, using a dedicated charging module for safe replenishment when mains power is available and a P-channel MOSFET to ensure seamless automatic switchover to battery power during outages, thus maintaining uninterrupted operation. To avoid communication collisions in multi-node environments, the design employs unique addressing and timesliced transmission, improving reliability in dense sensor deployments. Experimental validation confirmed fast detection-to-alert response, with alarm triggering well within NFPA 72 recommendations and a high wireless packet success rate despite typical home interference. Wireless architecture also enables a substantial reduction in new copper wiring, decreasing installation effort, cost, and embodied carbon compared to fully wired fire alarm systems. This sustainability aspect aligns with multiple United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by reducing material use and supporting resilient, adaptable infrastructure. The proposed system offers a scalable, costeffective, and environmentally conscious fire safety solution suitable for residential, commercial, and light industrial buildings, while providing a foundation for future features such as wireless fire alarm control panels (FACP), remote notifications, and enhanced security.

title: SDAR-Net: A Low-Power Solution to EEG-Based Auditory Attention Detection
authors: Zheyuan Lin, Sirui Li, Yuan Liao, Siqi Cai, Haizhou Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Auditory Attention Detection (AAD) from EEG signals is an enabling technology for next-generation hearing aids and brain-computer interfaces. However, deploying state-of-the-art deep learning models on resource-constrained wearable devices is hindered by high computational and energy cost. To overcome this challenge, we propose SDAR-Net, a novel, fully spiking neural network (SNN) designed for highly efficient and accurate AAD. SDAR-Net synergistically combines a dualpathway convolutional front-end for rich feature extraction with stacked transformer-based spiking attention blocks for hierarchical feature refinement. Evaluated on a challenging audiovisual EEG AAD dataset, SDAR-Net achieves state-of-the-art accuracy of 84.9 percent, outperforming established artificial neural networks, while reducing energy consumption by over 62 percent. Our work showcases the potential of deep SNNs to enable high-performance, low-power neurotechnologies for realworld applications. The source code for SDAR-Net will be made publicly available.

title: 2025 Index IEEE Open Journal of the Solid-State Circuits Society Vol. 5

title: From Edge to Edge: A Flow-Inspired Scheduling Planner for Multi-Robot Systems_supp1-3653428.mp4
authors: Kai Huang
abstract: Trajectory planning is crucial in multi-robot systems, particularly in environments with numerous obstacles. While extensive research has been conducted in this field, the challenge of coordinating multiple robots to flow collectively from one side of the map to the other—such as in crossing missions through obstacle-rich spaces—has received limited attention. This paper focuses on this directional traversal scenario by introducing a real-time scheduling scheme that enables multi-robot systems to move from edge to edge, emulating the smooth and efficient flow of water. Inspired by network flow optimization, our scheme decomposes the environment into a flow-based network structure, enabling the efficient allocation of robots to paths based on real-time congestion levels. The proposed scheduling planner operates on top of existing collision avoidance algorithms, aiming to minimize overall traversal time by balancing detours and waiting times. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed scheme in achieving fast and coordinated traversal. Furthermore, real-world flight tests with ten drones validate its practical feasibility. This work contributes a flow-inspired, real-time scheduling planner tailored for directional multi-robot traversal in complex, obstacle-rich environments. Code: https://github.com/chengji253/FlowPlanner.

title: Context-Aware Threat Detection for Malicious URLs: An AI-Driven Approach Integrating Traditional and Transformer-Based Models
authors: Muhammad Gulzaib, Tayyab Rehman, Muhammad Abdullah Tariq, Noshina Tariq, Marwah Alsadun, Mamoona Humayun
abstract: Traditional cybersecurity systems are significantly challenged by dynamically generated and obfuscated malicious URLs. This paper suggests an architecture to detect threats using hybrid AI to augment multi-level context modeling and feature extraction in malicious URL classification. The strategy constructs a comparative pipeline spanning multiple representation levels. It tackles the problem with a blend of pretrained transformerbased language models, Deep Learning (DL) frameworks with distributed semantic embeddings, and classical Machine Learning (ML) models. The TF-IDF feature-set baseline classifiers ensemble voting, Random Forest, and XGBoost classifiers derive competitive performance. Word2Vec DL models significantly improve capturing the syntactic structure of URLs. Other transformer-based architectures prevail over other approaches to the problem due to contextual token encoding and DL self-attention mechanisms. The advanced model showcases an incredible 97.06% accuracy on the test set, indicating effective performance on obfuscated and adversarially modified URL samples. A detailed assessment of the model's scalability, overfitting, and performance optimizes the computational cost. This study proposes a broader analytical framework for AI architectures, emphasizing real-time defensive URL systems. Subsequent studies will incorporate multi-modal threat intelligence fusion and edge-oriented model compression for deployment.

title: Combining Physical and Remote Hardware for Teaching Hardware-Oriented Programming
authors: Daniel Versick, Marcus Soll, Louis Kobras
abstract: This demo presents an experiment for teaching hardware-oriented programming. The experiment contains both physical (in the form of a Joy-Pi system) and remote (3-axis portal) hardware. It focuses on the technical realisation (including the use of the CrossLab architecture for remote connection) and the course in which the experiment is embedded. First results show that the experiment was perceived as a valuable addition to the course and that the many usability aspects are well implemented.

title: The Mismatched Filter Design Method Based on Environment Sensing
authors: Bin Hu, Shijian Shen, Yu Zheng, Zhiyong Lei
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the performance degradation of conventional matched filters under narrowband interference, this paper proposes a mismatched filter design method based on environmental interference sensing. A mathematical model is established under the criterion of maximizing the signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) of the target output in the presence of interference. By incorporating sensed environmental information such as the power spectral density and system parameters of the interference, analytical expressions for two frequency-domain mismatched filters are derived. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed methods can effectively perceive the spectral characteristics of narrowband interference and adaptively adjust the filter’s frequency response to form frequency-domain nulls at interference locations. Additionally, this paper theoretically analyzes the impact of different methods on interference suppression and target signal loss, offering practical guidance for algorithm selection in real-world radar systems.

title: Comparative Study on xy -Current Control Performance Within Different Reference Frames in DTP-PMSM
authors: Fengyang Sun, Wesam Taha, Subarni Pradhan, Babak Nahid-Mobarakeh
abstract: A dual three-phase permanent magnet synchronous motor (DTP-PMSM) is a high-performance electric motor that integrates two three-phase windings into a single PMSM stator, offering enhanced power, efficiency and fault tolerance for various electrification applications. To further improve the efficiency of DTP-PMSM, undesirable circulating currents in the stator windings should be eliminated. In the automotive industry, the suppression of circulating current improves overall system efficiency, extending battery life, and reducing heat generation, thereby enhancing reliability. To address the above issue, this paper introduces and assesses four distinct control methods: proportional integral control (PI), proportional resonance control (PR), sliding-mode control (SMC) and SMC with disturbance compensation (SMCDC). Furthermore, the comparative analysis includes implementing the foregoing controllers in three different reference rotation frames: stationary, synchronous, and anti-synchronous frames. FFT analysis and root mean square error (RMSE) are presented from simulation and experimental test results. With support of the analyzed results, it is validated that these four methods can successfully reduce circulating currents to varying degrees. Among all presented methods in this paper, PR controller implemented in the anti-synchronous frame is found to be the best xy current controller.

title: A Hybrid Eeg Based Emotion Recognition with Dimensionality Reduction and Ensemble Learning
authors: Menahil Khawar, Sanay Muhammad Umar Saeed, Sohail Khalid
abstract: Electroencephalography (EEG)-based emotion recognition is challenged by the high dimensionality across time samples, epochs, and channels. We introduce Adaptive Feature Filtering and Entropy-based Epoch Selection for Recognition (AFFEET-R), a compact and interpretable framework that integrates multidomain feature extraction with hybrid ensemble learning. Using the SEED-IV dataset, EEG signals were adaptively downsampled from 800 Hz to 200 Hz, while redundancy was reduced through entropy-based epoch selection and channel importance ranking. From this optimized representation, 49 multidomain features were extracted and classified using an ensemble of the hybrid models. AFFEET-R achieved an accuracy of 88.89 %, demonstrating excellent performance, interpretability, and efficiency for real-time EEG-based affective computing.

title: The Current Situation and Development of Multitarget ISAR Imaging
authors: Siyuan Chen, Wenhua Hu, Baofeng Guo, Dongfang Xue, Miao Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Inverse Synthetic Aperture Radar (ISAR) imaging for multiple targets holds significant value in military and civilian applications. This paper systematically reviews the technical framework and challenges of multi-target ISAR imaging, conducting a comparative analysis of mainstream methods including deep learning, sparse representation, time-frequency analysis, and motion compensation. The study shows that deep learning approaches rely on massive annotated datasets and highcomputing hardware, prone to feature aliasing in dense target scenarios. Sparse representation techniques enhance resolution but are constrained by complex motion parameter decoupling and surging algorithmic complexity. Classical time-frequency analysis faces cross-term interference and computational inefficiency, while motion compensation suffers from significant characteristic scatterer extraction errors under low signal-to-noise ratios. By analyzing the advantages and disadvantages of existing technologies, this paper prospects the research direction of integrating multi-target and ISAR imaging techniques, and developing new intelligent algorithms to improve adaptability in complex environments and real-time processing capabilities, providing references for technological development.

title: Machine learning prediction of mass concrete temperature using random forest
authors: Chao Gao, Chao Min, Gaoxuan Li, Weijie Yin, Liqing Wang
abstract: Analyzing the temperature evolution during the construction of mass concrete and establishing accurate prediction models are essential for ensuring structural quality and construction safety. This paper proposes a temperature prediction model for mass concrete based on Random Forest Transfer Learning. By integrating data preprocessing and feature extraction, the model leverages a transfer learning mechanism to enhance generalization performance under small–sample conditions, enabling high–precision short–term temperature forecasting. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves significant predictive accuracy, with a coefficient of determination (R2) exceeding 95%. Compared to conventional machine learning models, the model exhibits superior robustness, with prediction residuals confined within the range of –2 to 2°C. Furthermore, the predicted values for unmonitored locations closely align with observed temperature patterns. This high–fidelity prediction enables engineers to implement proactive thermal control measures, effectively mitigating the risk of structural cracking and enhancing the long–term safety and durability of mass concrete structures.

title: Performance Evaluation of IoT-Enabled PV Panels Using Graphene-Paraffin Composite Thermal Management
authors: Ritu Jain, Amit Tiwari, Paresh Jain, Himanshu Vasnani, Pooja Varshney, Payal Bansal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This work provides a detailed assessment of the thermal performance of a PV panel operating in conjunction with an IoT -based thermal control strategy with graphene-paraffin composite phase change materials (PCMs). It aims to control the voltage, current, and surface temperature of a typical PV panel through the in-body integration of a graphene-paraffin composite (in 5 wt. % and 10 wt. %) as a passive cooling solution. Overheating of the surface of PV panels is one of the significant challenges which impact the efficiency and durability of PV panels. In view of this, the high thermal conductivity of graphene is utilized in this work to obtain better heat removal in combination with the latent heat storage performance of paraffin. An IoT system with temperature, voltage, and current sensors linked to a cloud-based dashboard provides real-time data acquisition and monitoring. It is found that the adding effect of graphene-paraffin composite can remarkably enhance the power of PV panels, especially as the (10wt. %) the highest concentration providing the best temperature control and electrical output stability. The surface temperature was decreased by (G10P) upto 4% as compared to without material, and similar increments were observed in the voltage and current. The novelty of this integration consists in the combination of novel nanomaterials and IoT -assisted smart energy management of solar panels in real time, which represents an important leap toward intelligent renewable energy solutions. The proposed work not only contributes to the enhanced efficiency of solar energy harvesting but also lays the groundwork for real-world scalable IoT -enabled PV thermal management technologies.

title: Integrated Waveform Design for LFM-MPSK Radar and Communication Systems Based on Chaotic Sequences
authors: Deng Pan, Fengming Xin, Zeyu Chu, Yiwen Sun
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes an integrated radarcommunication waveform design for LFM-MPSK systems based on chaotic sequences.The radar detection performance of the integrated signal is enhanced, and the communication bit error rate is lowered through spread spectrum operations.The causes of spectral leakage were systematically analyzed, and corresponding mitigation strategies were proposed.Through simulation analysis, the LFM-MPSK radar-communication integrated waveform based on chaotic sequences demonstrates excellent radar detection performance while simultaneously achieving higher communication data rates and reduced bit error rates.

title: Radio-Frequency Toroid Susceptometry of Magnetic Nanoparticles: What Goes Around Comes Around
authors: Ronald B. Goldfarb
abstract: The intrinsic magnetic susceptibility of noninteracting magnetic nanoparticles is calculated from the measured complex radio-frequency susceptibility of dipolar-coupled particles in colloidal suspension. The susceptibility, derived from the impedance of toroidal specimens in a shorted coaxial transmission line, requires no adjustment for demagnetizing factors. Three established models for interacting superparamagnetic particles — the Weiss molecular-field model, the Onsager model, and the modified mean-field model — are extended to magnetically viscous particles at frequencies above their Néel relaxation frequency. Magnetic figures of merit for nanoparticles are the real and imaginary parts of complex intrinsic susceptibility scaled by particle concentration. The work seeks to promote standard characterization methods for interlaboratory comparison of realistic distributions of magnetic nanoparticles at radio frequencies.

title: Integrating IT Infrastructure Metrics into Business Process Mining: A Telecommunications Industry Case Study
authors: Zhi Chen, Sally McClean, Zeeshan Tariq, Nektarios Georgalas, Adeshola Adefila
abstract: Business Process Mining has become crucial in optimizing operational efficiency by analysing event logs to discover process bottlenecks and predict future behaviours. However, traditional techniques mainly focus on internal process attributes, often overlooking external factors that significantly impact performance. This research addresses the gap by investigating the influence of IT infrastructure performance metrics, specifically within the telecommunications industry, on business process execution. Leveraging event logs combined with infrastructure anomaly data, we employ One-Class Classification methods (OneClassSVM and Isolation Forest) to identify process deviations related to infrastructure issues such as hardware failures and network congestion. Our methodology aligns time-series event logs with concurrent infrastructure anomalies, revealing how these external events affect order-processing workflows. The OneClassSVM yields a recall of 0.81 and an F1 score of 0.70 for class 1, and a recall of 0.93 and an F1 score of 0.95 for non-class 1. The Isolation Forest attains a recall of 0.80 and an F1 score of 0.73 for class 1, while it achieves a recall of 0.94 and an F1 score of 0.96 for non-class 1. Results demonstrate the efficacy of integrating exogenous IT features, improving predictive accuracy, anomaly detection, and facilitating more robust process monitoring. Both methods in our model attain elevated recall and F1 scores in predicting both classes. While acknowledging limitations such as empirical labelling of data and class imbalance issues, this study highlights the importance of external contextual data in refining process mining techniques and contributes practical insights for predictive maintenance, root-cause analysis, and customer experience optimization within telecommunications. Future research will focus on enhancing data labelling accuracy and incorporating additional order-level features for more precise analysis.

title: A Spiking Transfer Learning Method for Event Camera Based on Structural Decoupling
authors: Peiming Kan, Qiugang Zhan, Ran Tao, Zhuxi Li, Zhiguang Qin, Guisong Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Event cameras are widely used in high-speed, lowexposure scenarios due to their high dynamic range and high temporal resolution. Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs), with their event-driven and energy-efficient characteristics, are particularly suitable for training on event data. However, compared with frame-based image datasets, the labeled event data is insufficient for training SNN models with comparable performance. Existing research typically addresses this issue by optimizing the architecture and training process of SNN models, rarely considering the physical properties of event data. Specifically, compared to detailed texture information, frame-based images and event data share higher structural similarity. Therefore, we propose a Structural Decoupling-Based Spiking Transfer Learning Method (SDSTL), which leverages frame-based structural knowledge to assist in training SNNs on event data. We achieved a notable improvement in classification accuracy on two neural datasets compared to the baseline.

title: Double Aperture HTS Dipole Magnet Model for the Persistent Current Operation
authors: Vladimir Kashikhin, Daniele Turrioni
abstract: Particle accelerators use many different types of magnets. There is an interest in replacing rather low-field conventional resistive magnets with high-temperature superconducting (HTS) magnets. The main goal is to reduce operational expenses, which is critical during the continuously increasing cost of electricity. At Fermilab, several HTS accelerator magnets were built and successfully tested. The paper described a variant of the double-aperture dipole magnet that could be suitable for future Lepton Colliders. A single short-circuited HTS coil of 3.8 kA generates a homogeneous magnetic field of 57 mT in both magnet gaps of 84 mm. The short model magnet was designed, built, and successfully tested at liquid nitrogen temperature. This magnet works in a persistent current mode, which provides additional cost savings when used in particle storage rings operated at a stable magnetic field. The results of design, fabrication, and tests are presented and discussed. The magnet demonstrated a high magnetic field stability in both apertures, efficiency of correction coils, and primary powering circuit.

title: Image Tampering Detection Method Based on RCE - CBAM Net Architecture
authors: Can Cui, Kaiqi Zhao, Chunting Li, Zhengqin Zhang, Chenyi Yang, Yan Xiang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The popularization and development of image tampering technology pose a severe challenge to digital information security. This paper proposes an image tampering detection model that integrates the Residual Network (ResNet) and the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM), and enhances the feature representation ability by introducing a dual attention mechanism of channels and Spaces. Experimental data on public datasets such as Pscc show that the performance of this model in the tasks of tampered region location and category discrimination is superior to that of traditional convolutional neural networks and single attention mechanism models, verifying the effectiveness of the combination of the attention mechanism and the residual structure.
