title: A New Touchscreen Cover for Braille-Based Data Entry on Mobile Devices
authors: Ghassan Aladool, Olivier Togni
abstract: The emerging advances in mobile technology, along with the anticipated global increase in the blind and low-vision population, emphasize the importance of introducing this community to such technology as an effective and low-cost communication tool. Aiming to enable blind and deaf-blind individuals to use mobile devices, many tactile-based methods and systems have been presented in literature over the last decade. Although these methods are well-regarded, their limitations include the need for object localization on mobile devices’ embedded touchscreens and the requirement to apply multiple gesture types, often involving several fingers from both hands. Addressing these limitations, this work presents a framework offering a new tactile-based communication method for blind individuals on mobile devices, with a touchscreen cover as a core component. The invented cover splits the touchscreen into eight equally-sized cells — six for data entry and two for control input — and provides an effective solution to localization and navigation challenges faced by blind individuals on touchscreens. In particular, the proposed framework enables Braille-based character entry. An Android app has also been developed to identify entered characters and save them for further processing. The proposed framework was tested at a foundation providing care for blind and low-vision individuals. Two-phases experiments, preliminary and final, were designed and conducted with ten participants. Experimental analysis based on measuring data entry time and input error indicates that the proposed framework performs well. Furthermore, two participant surveys were conducted prior and post the experiments to justify the calculated performance measures, asses cognitive load, and verify the usability and learnability of the proposed framework.

title: Quantum-Secured Fully Distributed Drone Swarm Coordination Using DC-GHZ Keying and Continuous-Time Quantum Walk Routing
authors: Kumar Sekhar Roy, Manish Kumar, Shweta Singh, Himanshu Ranjan Das, Tanvir Habib Sardar
abstract: This paper proposes a quantum-secured, fully distributed coordination framework for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarms that integrates distributed cluster GHZ (DC-GHZ) quantum key distribution, Hamiltonian continuous-time quantum walk (CTQW) routing, distributed average consensus, and constrained 3D kinematics within a single closed loop. DC-GHZ keying partitions the swarm into entanglement clusters, generates fresh symmetric keys each epoch, and monitors quantum bit error rate (QBER) as an intrinsic spoofing and eavesdrop detection signal. CTQW is applied over a waypoint graph whose potential encodes a multi-objective cost field combining distance, threat intensity, and congestion, while altitude is selected via separation-risk minimization and UAV motion is updated under bounded velocity, acceleration, and climb-rate limits. Our simulation shows that the quantum layer achieves mean QBER values of 0.1152 and 0.1089 across two GHZ clusters and raises intrusion alarms in seven of eight epochs, whereas the routing layer maintains stable average costs in the range 0.2771-0.3740 and the consensus process drives variance to near 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">–3</sup> after initial transients. The results demonstrate that the proposed architecture can simultaneously provide quantum-layer intrusion awareness, stealthy multi-objective routing, collision-aware 3D mobility, and robust decentralized coordination, making it a viable candidate for secure and scalable UAV swarm operations in contested environments.

title: Multimodal Machine Learning and Interactive Visualization for Early Detection of Autoimmune Flare Dynamics via Multi-Omics Integration
authors: K. Lakshmi Vasanthi, Kesaven S, Shruti Mishra, Sandeep Kumar Satapathy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This research predicts flare-ups of autoimmune disease, where the flare-up prediction is performed through the use of multi-omics data. Fast k-Nearest Neighbor’s (k-NN) with SARSA (State-Action-Reward-State-Action) is the machine learning methodology that breaks the model training for the prediction of flares into seven biological features. The first task to be undertaken is concerned with rescaling practitioners' needs in order. Example: all features can be on the same lexical scale. After the Rescaling, the features undergo a ranking as a process of determining the most useful ones for prediction tasks. Then, the features of the fast-kNN training model are used to perform fast training of kNN to allow easy data classification. Lastly, the three steps of SARSA learning, that is, one that shows that data expectation changes and the ordinary expectation of the data can be used to change the prediction model. SARSA learning is used in this situation for the stimulation of SARSA prediction to make the data interactions better for the prediction model explanation. The results suggest that a better combination of Fast-kNN and SARSA can improve the predictions of the target. It may address the need for a better early warning for a flare-up, allowing for better management of the autoimmune disease and treatment.

title: Feature Enhancement Aggregation Network for Efficient Image Super-Resolution
authors: Zhisheng Zeng, Yulong Fan, Chunjiang Duanmu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: State-space models (SSMs) excel in modeling longrange dependencies, but Mamba is limited in modeling local interactions. Existing methods typically use windowed multi-head self-attention mechanisms (MHSAs) to address this problem, but this brings the challenge of increased parameters. To address this challenge, we propose a Feature Enhancement Aggregation Network (FEANet) that effectively models local dependencies using a Local Feature Enhancement Block (LFEB) and further enhances and fuses global and local features with the help of a Spatial Channel Aggregation Block (SCAB) to achieve advanced super-resolution performance. Specifically, we design a Local Feature Enhancement Block (LFEB) and a Spatial Channel Fusion Block (SCFB). We use the LFEB module to help enhance the image features extracted by Mamba, enhancing the ability to capture local features while maintaining computational efficiency. SCFB, as a substitute for a Feed-Forward Network (FFN), effectively refines deep features through partial convolutions and channel interactions, and SCFB also achieves the fusion of global and local features. Experiments show that our method achieves excellent performance while maintaining model complexity.

title: Multi-Stage Image Enhancement for Superficial Forearm Vein Visualization
authors: Yuchen Wang, Haoting Liu, Song Wang, Wenhan Bao, Zhenlin Deng, Weiwei Zhao, Qianru Ji, Yuning Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: This paper proposes a multi-stage enhancement algorithm for near-infrared images of superficial forearm veins, addressing challenges of low contrast, blurred vessel edges, and loss of structural details. The input image is decomposed via Laplacian pyramid into base and detail layers. The base layer is enhanced using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex>-CLAHE and secondary <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex> correction to optimize brightness and suppress background interference. Detail layers are sharpened using Laplacian filtering to reinforce vascular contours. Final reconstruction fuses both branches. Quantitative results show improvements of 4.82 in PSNR and 0.56 in SSIM over conventional methods. The proposed approach enhances vascular visibility and structural clarity, providing high-quality input for clinical tasks such as segmentation and thrombus detection.

title: Tracking Public Attention to Influenza in China: Lagged and Directional Trends from Baidu Search Index (January 2019–March 2025)
authors: Jiaojiao Wang, Cheewei Tan, Weijian Zhong, Zixiong Yang, Xiliang Liu, Xiangyu Zhang, Zhidong Cao, Daniel Dajun Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: This study investigates the evolving dynamics of public attention toward multiple influenza subtypes in China from 2019 to early 2025, using Baidu Search Index (BSI) as a proxy for collective health awareness. Drawing upon official surveillance data from the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), we examine the temporal and directional relationships between public search behavior and influenza epidemic indicators across multiple time scales and platforms. Using correlation analysis, lagged cross-correlation, and Granger causality modeling, we identify both synchronous co-movements and predictive lead-lag structures between BSI and surveillance-based indicators. Influenza A, Swine, and Avian Influenza consistently emerge as early signals of rising public concern, with Swine and Avian strains often showing directional influence on broader influenza-related search trends. In contrast, Influenza B remains peripheral, with weaker and less interconnected public attention. Our findings highlight a post-pandemic amplification of influenza awareness during the 2023–2024 season, marked by historically high search volumes and the re-establishment of predictive lag structures, particularly at Lag = 2–3 weeks. Regional disparities are evident: southern provinces exhibited more resilient BSI-CDC coherence during the pandemic, while northern regions showed delayed recovery. These results underscore the utility of search engine data for real-time infodemiological surveillance and early warning. From a policy perspective, integrating BSI into national influenza monitoring frameworks can enhance the timeliness and responsiveness of public health interventions. This study provides actionable insights for designing adaptive, multi-scale digital surveillance systems in the post-pandemic era.

title: TransSE: A Transfer Learning-Based Predictive Model for Distinguishing Super Enhancers and Typical Enhancers_supp5-3657361.tif
authors: Junxiang Gao
abstract: Super-enhancers (SEs), comprising clusters of transcriptional regulatory elements, play essential roles in gene expression regulation and cell fate determination. Current computational methods for identifying SEs from genomic sequences face challenges in prediction accuracy and cross-species generalizability. This study introduces TransSE, a deep learning framework combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks with cross-species transfer learning for SE prediction. TransSE employs a two-phase strategy: pre-training on combined human and mouse data to learn conserved regulatory features, followed by species-specific fine-tuning to capture organism-specific patterns. Evaluation on human and mouse datasets demonstrates that TransSE achieves superior accuracy compared to existing methods including SENet, DeepSE, and transformer-based models (DNABERT, Enformer), with AUC values of 0.828 (human) and 0.832 (mouse). Ablation studies confirm that convolutional blocks are essential for feature extraction, while transfer learning and recurrent layers provide meaningful performance improvements. Feature analysis reveals that TransSE distinguishes SEs from typical enhancers based on learned sequence representations, achieving 10.4-fold improvement in clustering metrics. The model demonstrates effective cross-species prediction capability, maintaining AUC <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.79 when trained on one species and evaluated on another. Conservation pattern analysis shows that TransSE integrates both evolutionarily conserved and species-specific regulatory features, enabling robust performance across organisms with limited training data. A user-friendly web interface (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">http://transse.shenlabahmu.com</uri>) provides automated SE prediction, motif analysis, and variant impact assessment. Case studies using experimentally validated SEs demonstrate the tool's utility for investigating regulatory elements and prioritizing functional variants in disease-associated genomic regions. TransSE advances the investigation of gene regulatory mechanisms and facilitates identification of disease-associated variation in enhancer regions.

title: Size-Change Behavior of Free-Form Microstructures During Ultrafast Laser Direct Writing Within Pure-Protein Precursors
authors: Daniela Serien, Aiko Narazaki
abstract: Ultrafast laser direct writing (LDW) is a versatile 3D microfabrication technology with a high spatial resolution, reduced heat accumulation, and a diverse range of applications usually tied to the applied precursor material. When using a protein precursor, it is possible to fabricate proteinaceous microstructures with the native protein function retained for use in cell cultures, lab-on-a-chip, and soft robotics. It is common to fabricate such proteinaceous microstructures by adhering them to glass. However, when we perform so-called free-form fabrication, without any substrate adhesion, we observe size changes during the fabrication process. This study quantified the in-precursor size changes to increase predictability. We also evaluated a potential mechanism for these changes by examining the role of protein hydration shells. These findings are expected to contribute to the fabrication of desired designs and promote the use of this technology.

title: Comparison of AODV and DSDV Routing Protocols in MANETs
authors: Ayush Sharma, Sarthak Negi, Shalini Singh, Abhay Sharma, Md. Irfanul Hasan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: With the advancements in technology and due to rapid demand for connecting everything (nodes) to the internet(network). There is a paradigm shift in network from earlier generations to 5G. The Fifth generation of mobile networks is inclined towards providing communication for-high node density, high data rate, high security (in terms of channel spoofing) and high mobility for achieving uninterrupted and seamless communication. For achieving 5G features like-network with high speed, least delays and dense nodes over MANETs, they are tested by simulating in a computer tool i.e. ns-3 under various conditions of 5G mobile environment and analysed for the performance. After several testing, by varying 5G environment conditions like node speed and node density. Performance parameters has been traced out and analysed for two different routing protocols in MANETs that are AODV and DSDV. The simulation results have shown that AODV achieves a low packet loss ratio, particularly in larger networks, due to its on-demand routing mechanism. However, it experiences higher end-to-end delays, which increase significantly as the number of nodes grows. In contrast, DSDV demonstrates more stable delays and higher throughput, owing to its proactive routing strategy. However, this comes with the downside of higher packet losses and power consumption due to periodic updates. These findings highlight the trade-offs between reactive and proactive routing protocols, with AODV being more suitable for delay-tolerant applications, while DSDV is better suited for scenarios that require consistent throughput and lower delays. This study contributes to the optimization of MANET routing architectures by providing a detailed performance evaluation based on simulation results. Hence, Conclusion has been made stating that AODV is a preferred communication protocol which is suitable for 5G environment and provides 5G features. [1]

title: Embedded System Experimentation Powered by Petri Nets-Driven Development and Rapid Prototyping
authors: Luis Gomes, João-Paulo Barros, Anikó Costa, Filipe Moutinho, Fernando Pereira
abstract: This work introduces a model-driven development methodology that facilitates the rapid prototyping of Petri net-based embedded controllers. The suggested method takes advantage of using a low-code development strategy along with design automation tools that allow the rapid prototyping of centralized and/or distributed/networked embedded controller systems. It is completely supported by a web-based tool platform that covers all stages of development, starting with the Petri net model edition, covering simulation and property verification, and finally supporting the generating of the execution code, amenable to be deployed at implementation platforms, such as FPGAs and microcontroller-based ones. allowing direct support for hardware- or software-based implementations.

title: Blind Estimation of OFDM Symbol Length Based on Spectral Leakage in Short Cyclic Prefix Systems
authors: Liuyang Zhao, Canhui Liao, Qiyue Feng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In addressing the blind estimation problem of symbol length for short cyclic prefix (CP) and no-protection interval OFDM signals, we propose a novel blind estimation method based on inter-symbol spectral leakage characteristics. By analyzing the spectral properties of OFDM signals derived from the transmitter system model and elucidating the mechanism of inter-symbol spectral leakage, we introduce an innovative approach for symbol length estimation. This method leverages existing signal detection algorithms to estimate the number of symbols by extracting spectral leakage features from the time-frequency energy distribution of the received signal, subsequently using the ratio of these features as the estimated symbol length. The proposed technique does not rely on the CP, thereby partially overcoming the challenges associated with blind estimation of symbol length in short CP and no-protection interval OFDM systems. Simulation results demonstrate that, at an in-band SNR of 15 dB and when the ratio of CP length to effective symbol length is less than or equal to $3 / 32$, the new method outperforms traditional estimation techniques in accuracy. Furthermore, with an increasing number of received symbols, the Normalized Root Mean Square Error of the symbol length estimate achieved by this approach can reach levels as low as $10^{-4}$ or below.

title: Demonstration of Concurrent Application Provision with LoRaMesher
authors: Joan Miquel Solé, Felix Freitag, Leandro Navarro, Mennan Selimi
abstract: There is an increasing interest in extending traditional LoRaWAN-based IoT applications by LoRa mesh networks. The mesh technology introduces the capacity for multi-hop and node-to-node communication and new opportunities for IoT applications. This demonstration showcases the LoRaMesher library, which enables the concurrently provisioning of multiple applications within a LoRa mesh network. The paper demon-strates the library operating with real IoT boards. This includes showing the self-configuring of the nodes to build the LoRa mesh networks. Then, we will run concurrent applications to demonstrate to the audience the different communication patterns of distributed applications within a LoRa mesh network. Finally, we will review how the LoRaMesher library can be used. The implementation of LoRaMesher is open source.

title: Mitigating Jamming in Chaos-Based Communication Systems Using Adaptive Interference Suppression
authors: Manasa Charitha, Sunil Hosur, Mallikarjunaswamy Srikantaswamy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Chaos-Based communication systems have emerged as one of the promising solutions for secure and robust wireless communications because of their inherent randomness and resistance to interception. Even those, however, are still susceptible under jamming attack mechanisms that may seriously degrade the quality of a signal and render reliable data transmission impossible. Traditional anti-jamming methods, such as Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum (DSSS) and Frequency Hopping Spread Spectrum (FHSS), although resistant to interference, face some serious problems, including high computational overhead, reduced spectral efficiency, and the threat of being vulnerable to intelligence jammers. This paper proposes an Adaptive Chaos-Based Jamming Mitigation System (ACJMS) based on Recurrent Neural Network-Assisted Chaotic Signal Processing (RNN-CSP) that allows dynamic detection and mitigation of jamming attacks. The adaptive learning mechanism in the proposed system optimizes chaos-based signal reconstruction, making the system resilient against different jamming strategies. In the comparison of results with conventional methods, ACJMS improves key performance parameters a Signal-To-Interference Ratio (SIR) improvement of 0.28%, Bit Error Rate (BER) reduction improvement of 0.35%, and spectral efficiency improvement of 0.22%. This new approach guarantees a much more secure and efficient chaotic communication framework, suitable for next-generation wireless networks.

title: Technical and Ethical Strategies to Prevent Machine Learning Models from Exploiting Personally Identifiable Information (PII)
authors: Rand N Albustanji, Ahmad Alkhatib, Ameen Shaheen
abstract: The growing ubiquity of machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) has propelled wide-ranging breakthroughs but also laid bare systemic weaknesses in the safeguarding of Personally Identifiable Information (PII) . ML models, for example, have been demonstrated to unintentionally memorize and leak sensitive data at generation time, and highly reported incidents highlight the potential for PII misuse. Traditional methods to maintain privacy, including anonymization, have been found to be inadequate against more advanced AI- powered attacks. As deep learning models become more sophisticated, the risks associated with this phenomenon become ever more complex, making the need for adequate privacy-preserving mechanisms all the more pressing. We explore the nature of the challenges posed by the PII exploitation threat in the domain of ML systems, highlighting existing frameworks, showcasing their shortcomings, describing a series of threats, and finally examining alternative approaches to mitigate those threats through the use of federated learning, encryption, differential privacy (DP), and other methods. It further stresses user-focused approaches, such as data minimization and informed consent, to enhance privacy protections. This work aims to build secure and ethical AI systems that are driven by a combination of technical, regulatory, and ethical solutions, striking a balance between innovation and privacy preservation.

title: Enhancing Digital Investigation: The Role of Generative AI (ChatGPT) in Evidence Identification and Analysis in Digital Forensics
authors: Marah Radi Hawa, Majdi Owda, Amani Yousef Owda
abstract: Generative Artificial Intelligence (GAI) has garnered considerable attention across disciplines such as science, digital forensics, and literature. Advanced large language modeling systems (LLMs), including ChatGPT and Large Language Model Meta AI (LLaMA), have become essential tools in digital forensics due to their sophisticated Natural Language Processing (NLP) capabilities. These systems enable efficient processing of extensive text datasets, sentiment analysis, and real-time threat detection. This research explores the effectiveness of AI-driven methods in digital forensics by conducting comprehensive tests on various applications, such as artifact comprehension, evidence search, and incident response. The results confirm the transformative role of ChatGPT in enhancing the speed and accuracy of investigation, as the study showed that the system can analyze data and images related to crimes and provide comprehensive reports. Not only does he process evidence, but it can also extract complete conversations related to crime, determining when it occurred and whether it was planned. The system meticulously analyzes the data sent to it to provide additional details such as possible motives and behavior of suspects. It provides investigators with an in-depth understanding that can be used at various stages of the investigation, and even in the courts as credible evidence. This approach reflects the importance of responsible adoption of the system while offering guidelines for its responsible adoption and future development.

title: Evolution Assisted Pareto Set Learning for Multi-Modal Multi-Objective Optimization
authors: Yu Wang, Ke Shang, Zexuan Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: We propose a novel framework that integrates multi-modal multi-objective optimization evolutionary algorithms (MMOEAs) with Pareto Set Learning (PSL) to more effectively address multi-modal multi-objective optimization problems (MMOPs), which are characterized by multiple Pareto sets corresponding to the same Pareto front. In the proposed framework, evolutionary search is first employed to obtain a diverse set of initial solutions. These solutions are then used to construct a dataset of preference-solution-label triplets, which guides the pre-training of a Pareto set model. Following this stage, the model is further fine-tuned using the PSL methodology. To better capture the diversity of solutions in the decision space, we adopt a backbone network with multiple output heads. The resulting model is capable of generating multiple continuous Pareto sets. Preliminary experiments on benchmark MMOPs show that our method can successfully learn all major Pareto sets, outperforming both PSL and its improved variant in terms of decision-space diversity and coverage completeness. Code is available at: https://github.com/fortherace/EAPSL.

title: High-Fidelity NIR Vascular Image Enhancement Using a Triple-Stage Optimization Strategy
authors: Fengjie Chen, Haoting Liu, Song Wang, Wenhan Bao, Zhenlin Deng, Weiwei Zhao, Qianru Ji, Yuning Wang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Near-infrared (NIR) imaging of autogenous arteriovenous fistulas is frequently compromised by insufficient contrast, pervasive noise artifacts, and non-uniform illumination, all of which impede precise vascular structure delineation and clinical interpretability. To overcome these challenges, this study presents a novel three-stage image enhancement framework integrating global histogram equalization (HE), contrast-limited adaptive histogram equalization (CLAHE), Frangi vesselness filtering, and gamma correction. A <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3$</tex> median filter is first applied to suppress impulse noise while preserving vascular boundaries. Then, a weighted combination of HE and CLAHE (7:3 ratio) is used to enhance both global contrast and localized vessel detail. The result is further refined by multi-scale Frangi filtering to accentuate tubular vascular structures. Finally, gamma correction adjusts luminance distribution, revealing lowintensity anatomical features. This framework is validated on a proprietary NIR forearm vascular dataset, demonstrating notable performance improvements. Specifically, contrast increases by a factor of 1.8, information entropy improves by 0.6, and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) rises by 5.2 dB. These results confirm the effectiveness of the proposed method in generating highfidelity, diagnostically valuable images and highlight its potential clinical applications in thrombus detection and vascular access evaluation.

title: Optimizing User-Space UDP Stack for 80 Gbps Full-Duplex Forwarding Based on DPDK
authors: Yanxiao Peng, Xiaoli Yi, Jie Tang, Zhenhua Liu, Jiusheng Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a high-performance user-space network protocol stack based on the Data Plane Development Kit (DPDK), optimized for nextgeneration high-speed network interfaces. The primary objective of this study is to achieve full-rate, full-duplex data transmission on dual-port 40 GbE network adapters. To meet this goal, we design a customized socket-like management framework that combines array and linked-list structures to enable efficient connection tracking and resource allocation. In addition, a redblack tree is employed to dynamically manage multi-connection states, ensuring fast lookups and excellent scalability under high connection loads. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the proposed approach consistently achieves full-rate, full-duplex throughput on dual-port $\mathbf{4 0 ~ G b E}$ interfaces, validating the efficiency and robustness of the proposed architecture. These results provide valuable insights into optimizing user-space protocol stacks using DPDK in ultra-high-speed networking environments.

title: SAR Target Recognition Algorithm and Lightweight Based on Deep Learning
authors: Hongge Li, Qian Yin, Qiang Ling, Miao Li, Jungang Yang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With the improvement of computer computing power, the application of deep learning in the field of synthetic aperture radar (SAR) target recognition is becoming more and more important. However, due to the limited computing power of radar terminal equipment, the current deep learning algorithm parameter model is huge, and the operation efficiency on radar terminal equipment is low. In view of the above problems, this paper uses data enhancement methods and constructs a lightweight neural network to realize the lightweight of the model while ensuring the recognition accuracy. In terms of model training, this paper selects the classic network represented by ResNet18 and the specially designed lightweight network represented by MobileNetV3 as the objects, and adds the attention mechanism to the ResNet18 structure to obtain the ResNet18-SE model to improve its performance. In terms of model lightweight, this paper first performs five channel prunings with different pruning rates on ResNet18-SE and MobileNetV3 to reduce the number of parameters and explore the maximum pruning rate. Secondly, the accuracy is restored by fine-tuning, and the knowledge distillation method is used to realize the transfer of knowledge. Finally, the Pruned-ResNet18-SE and PrunedMobileNetV3 models with parameters of $0.497 \mathrm{M}, 0.967 \mathrm{M}$ and test set accuracy of $94.57 \%, 92.26 \%$, respectively, are obtained to reduce the number of model parameters and improve the accuracy, and the inference frame rate exceeds 400 frames.

title: An Unsupervised Image Enhancement Method Based on Degradation Priority and Feature Aggregation
authors: Xinyi Li, Rui Wang, Rui Ruan, Zheng Liang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Most of the existing works on low-light image enhancement focus either on dealing with multiple unknown parameters of physical model via hand-crafted priors, or assumptions; or on designing supervised image enhancement networks that heavily rely on paired ground-truth images. These methods are less practical and generalizable in real-world settings. In this paper, we propose an unsupervised enhancement network based on degradation priority attention module (DPAM) and cross-level feature aggregation module (CFAM) to enhance low-light images, called DPFANet. Specifically, DPAM uses unbalanced attenuation of $R, G$, and B channels to roughly estimate attenuation degree of the image, and pays additional attention to regions with stronger attenuation. Then, CFAM first extracts attention-guided features, and spatial-extended features, and then fuses these features with encoding features to simultaneously capture low-level details and high-level semantic knowledges from the input image, which provides a helpful support for enhancing overall structure and maintaining natural appearance. Besides, we synthesize a remotesensing image dataset including 650 samples of different remotesensing scenes. Extensive experiments on real-world and synthetic image datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in low-light image enhancement. Moreover, our method shows a good generalization capability for enhancing underwater images.

title: Continuous Non-invasive Cardiac Output Monitoring Method Based on Phonocardiogram Signals
authors: Yiming Hu, Hong Tang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Cardiac Output (CO) is a critical hemodynamic metric for evaluating cardiac pumping function, and continuous non-invasive monitoring holds significant clinical value for cardiovascular disease management and exercise rehabilitation. To address the limitations of existing monitoring methods, this study proposes a novel CO estimation framework that integrates phonocardiogram (PCG) and electrocardiogram (ECG) signals, focusing on CO dynamics during post-exercise recovery. ECGderived cardiac cycles enabled precise heart rate measurement and the extraction of discriminative features from PCG signals, including sample entropy, total power, systolic duration, diastolic duration, root mean square (RMS) and standard deviation (STD) of the first heart sound amplitude. Using impedance cardiography (ICG)-derived CO as the reference, multiple regression models were developed for CO prediction. Gradient Boosting Regression achieved the best performance under leave-one-subject-out crossvalidation, yielding a mean absolute error of $0.622 \mathrm{~L} / \mathrm{min}$ ($R^{2}=0.883$), with sample entropy identified as the most influential predictor. Collectively, these findings validate the feasibility of PCG-ECG fusion for non-invasive CO monitoring and establish a technical foundation for cost-effective, portable health monitoring systems suitable for home-based care and clinical rehabilitation.

title: Text-Centric Sparse Interaction Fusion Network with a Modality Calibrating Module for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
authors: Hongkun Zhou, Jin Liu, Xingye Li, Yuxin Liu, Huihua He
abstract: Despite significant progress in Multimodal Sentiment Analysis (MSA), particularly with methods based on Transformers and Attentions, three major issues remain unresolved. First, existing unimodal representation learning methods overlook the noise and redundancy present within unimodal sequences. Second, current methods ignore the uneven distribution of emotional information across different modalities and fail to consider the highest contribution of text. Third, they neglect the issue of inter-modal noise redundancy in modal interactions. To address the aforementioned issues, this paper proposes a Text-Centric Sparse Interaction Fusion Network with a Modality Calibrating Module (TC-SIFN-MCM). A Modality Calibrating Module (MCM) is introduced during the unimodal representation learning phase to suppress noise within modalities. A Text-Centric Sparse Interaction Fusion Network (TC-SIFN) is designed to guide the learning of resource-poor non-text modalities with the resource-rich text modality, fully leveraging the highest contribution of the text modality. A Top-K Sparse Attention Transformer is utilized as a means of modal inter action, suppressing inter-modal noise generated during modal interactions. We conducted extensive experiments on the CMU MOSI, CMU-MOSEI, and SIMS datasets, and the results show that our TC-SIFN-MCM model outperforms current methods, with a notably impressive Acc-2 score of 86.07% on the MOSEI dataset.

title: Photonics-RAN (P-RAN) for 6G: A Transformative Architecture with Performance Evaluation
authors: Eman A. Anowr, Mohamed I. Ismail, Mona Nashaat Ali Elmowafy, Mohamed A. Mohamed, Mostafa M. Fouda, Heba M. Abdel-Atty
abstract: As Fifth-Generation (5 G) deployments begin, wireless research is rapidly turning its attention to Sixth-Generation (6G). Establishing a vision for future communications is crucial at this point in order to guide that research. This paper proposes a novel Fog-based Radio Access Network (F-RAN) architecture integrated with full photonic technology, called Photonics Radio Access Network (P-RAN), aiming to address critical limitations in conventional fog deployments, namely excessive power consumption, ultra-high speed, low latency, and constrained energy efficiency. In particular, the integration of photonic components and the use of technologies like Photonics Integrated Circuit (PIC), Radio Frequency Over Fiber (RFOF), and Electro-absorption Modulated laser (EML) significantly alleviate the Power Consumption (PC) or Energy Efficiency (EE) and latency bottlenecks associated with dense fog node deployments. The proposed architecture establishes a robust and scalable 6 G radio access network framework. It sets a new standard for next-generation mobile systems by offering a superior trade-off between PC performance and latency. A comprehensive performance evaluation uses advanced mathematical modeling to assess key metrics such as power consumption (PC) and latency. The energy-efficient deployment potential of P-RAN is demonstrated by its 18% reduction in power consumption at 25 photonic baseband units (P-BBU) and 16% reduction in latency at 100 photonic remote radio heads (P-RRH) compared to traditional F-RAN. All findings show that the P-RAN is ideal for time-sensitive 6 G applications, not only improving spectrum and energy efficiency but also dramatically reducing latency.

title: Magnetic Levitation Pocket Lab: Modeling and Experimentation
authors: Pavol Bisták, Mikuláš Huba
abstract: This paper presents possibilities for how to model and experiment with a portable pocket-sized dynamical system representing the operation of magnetic levitation. It describes different models (mathematical, 3D, simulation) of the magnetic levitation system and discusses Arduino IDE and Matlab/Simulink platforms with the use of Arduino Uno and Arduino Due microcontrollers for a magnetic levitation control.

title: CD-TA-RTM: A Dual-Pathway Deep Learning Architecture for Rainfall Estimation Using Commercial Microwave Links
authors: Minghao Liang, Biling Zhang, Yong Liu, Zixuan Qin, Congzheng Han, Guoan Zhao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Commercial microwave links (CML) create opportunities for rainfall sensing by leveraging signal attenuation patterns as indicators. However, existing CML-based rainfall estimation methods face several challenges. These include difficulties with complex spatiotemporal precipitation patterns, fixed parameter dependencies, poor regional adaptability, and systematic underestimation of heavy rainfall events. To address these challenges, we propose CD-TA-RTM, a dual-pathway deep learning architecture which exploits Convolutional Downsampling (CD) for spatial pattern extraction, Temporal ion (TA) for multi-scale temporal dynamics, and Raw Temporal Modeling (RTM) for preserving original sequence information. To balance contributions of imbalanced rainfall intensities during training, we also introduce an Adaptive Rainfall-Intensity Weighted (ARIW) loss function that dynamically addresses underestimation bias during heavy precipitation events with small proportion in the dataset. Experiments based on dual-frequency E-band CML data demonstrate that our approach achieves excellent prediction performance across the entire test dataset with PCC of 0.8915 and $\mathbf{R}^{2}$ of 0.7805 while maintaining remarkable robustness to noise.

title: Disentangling Technical and Content Attributes in Search Engine Ranking: A Comparative Study of Google and Bing
authors: Göker Cebeci, Banu Diri
abstract: This study presents a novel empirical methodology to characterize and compare the ranking environments of major information retrieval systems, specifically Google and Bing. By analyzing technical and content attributes from a dataset of 14,465 Search Engine Results Page (SERP) items collected from a homogeneous commercial discount domain comprising 500 queries, we aim to characterize observable associative patterns between resource attributes and ranking outcomes. The dataset includes Lighthouse performance metrics and advanced content features, such as Sentence-BERT-based semantic similarity. Using K-Means clustering, we identify five resource profiles representing emergent optimization archetypes. The analysis revealed that content-related factors had a higher aggregate importance for both systems (Google: 70.1%, Bing: 61.8%) than technical factors. Specifically, Random Forest feature importance analysis highlighted that for Bing, content volume was a dominant predictor, whereas for Google, semantic relevance signals outweighed pure keyword targeting. We further contextualize these findings within an "Authority–Optimization Trade-off" framework, suggesting that Google’s negative associations for certain on-page optimization signals likely reflect a ranking function that heavily weights latent domain authority over explicit on-page compliance. These findings highlight how modern learning-to-rank systems may differentially weight explicit content features and latent authority signals when balancing relevance, diversity, and quality.

title: To Mask, or Not to Mask, Alice and Bob&#x02019;s Dating Dilemma_supp2-3634842.xls
authors: Zhanshan Sam Ma
abstract: Face masking in current COVID-19 pandemic seems to be a deceivingly simple decision-making problem due to its multifaceted nature. Questions arising from masking span biomedicine, epidemiology, physics, and human behaviors. While science has shown masks work generally, human behaviors (particularly under influences of politics) complicate the problem significantly given science generally assumes rationality but our minds are not always rational and/or honest. Minding minds, a legitimate concern, can also make masking legitimately confusing. To disentangle the potential confusions, particularly, the ramifications of irrationality and dishonesty, here we resort to evolutionary game theory. Specifically, we formulate and analyze the masking problem with a fictitious pair of young lovers, Alice and Bob, as a Sir Philip Sydney (SPS) evolutionary game, inspired by the handicap principle in evolutionary biology and cryptography figures in computer science. With the proposed Alice and Bob’s dating dilemma (ABD) as an asymmetric four-by-four strategic-form game, 16 strategic interactions were identified, and six of which may reach equilibriums with different characteristics such as separating, pooling, and polymorphic hybrid, being Nash, evolutionarily stable or neutrally stable. The six equilibrium types seem to mirror the diverse behaviors of mask believers, skeptics, converted, universal masking, voluntarily masking, coexisted and/or divided world of believers and skeptics. We suggest that the apparently simple ABD game is sufficiently general not only for studying masking policies for populations (via replicator dynamics), but also for investigating other complex decision-making problems with COVID-19 pandemic including lockdown versus reopening, herd immunity versus quarantines, and aggressive tracing versus privacy protection.

title: Ultrarobust Underwater Kicking Phase Estimation for Robotic Exosuit-Assisted Diving_supp1-3650487.pdf
authors: Xinyu Wu
abstract: Assisting divers with robotic exoskeletons would increase their working efficiency and reduce the risk of accidents. Nonetheless, the synchronization of assistance with underwater movements has not been investigated and remains a complex issue. Due to the agility and individuality of these movements in aquatic environments, conventional methods utilized on land may not work properly. In this article, we proposed an ultrarobust adaptive oscillator (AO) (URAO) method for predicting the kicking phase for the flutter kick and breaststroke kick, two main underwater motion patterns in diving activity. The URAO works without the need for data collection or training and can adapt to different users, motion patterns, and rapid changes in kicking frequency, offering greater precision than methods previously utilized for land-based exoskeletons. Eight participants were tested while performing fluctuating-frequency flutter and breaststroke kicks in indoor and outdoor swimming pools. The results showed that URAO outperformed both conventional AO and state-of-the-art estimators in predicting underwater kicking phases, reducing RMS_EWS prediction error by up to 49.5% for flutter kicks and up to 44.8% for breaststroke kicks.

title: Lightweight Secure Communication Protocol for IoT Devices Using ECDH and Spritz
authors: Sarah Alkadi, Muhammed Umair Khan, Waleed Alsabhan
abstract: This study proposes a lightweight secure communication protocol for Internet of Things operating in resource-constrained environments. The protocol introduces a wired PIN-based pre-authentication phase to verify device identity, followed by a wireless handshake that uses elliptic curve Diffie-Hellman to establish a shared session key. To ensure confidentiality, a modified version of the Spritz stream cipher is used to encrypt messages between devices. The protocol was implemented using Python and tested with two simulated ESP32 devices in Wokwi, with message transmission handled via the HiveMQ MQTT broker. Results demonstrate successful authentication, key agreement, and encrypted data exchange, supporting the protocol's effectiveness in lightweight, real-time IoT systems.

title: Numerical Simulation of a Bulk Superconductor Based HTS Dynamo-Type Flux Pump
authors: Rui Du, Mark D. Ainslie
abstract: The high-temperature superconducting (HTS) dynamo is a promising technology for generating large DC currents in superconducting coils without thermally inefficient current leads or bulky power supplies, with potential applications in electric machines and MRI/NMR magnets. A key factor influencing the output voltage and charging performance of HTS dynamos is the magnetic field strength of the magnet(s) rotating past the HTS wire, which is limited in conventional permanent magnet-based designs. In this study, the permanent magnet in the HTS dynamo benchmark model is replaced with a bulk superconductor of similar size. A two-dimensional finite-element model is developed in COMSOL Multiphysics to evaluate the open-circuit voltage of the bulk-based dynamo under different trapped field assumptions corresponding to different bulk operating temperatures. The results show that the bulk-based HTS dynamo can generate significantly higher output voltage than conventional designs, increasing approximately linearly with the trapped field strength. These findings demonstrate the strong potential of bulk superconductors to enhance the performance and coil-charging capability of HTS dynamos.

title: A Causality-Guided Adaptive Dual-Population Evolutionary Algorithm for Constrained Multi-Objective Optimization
authors: Jiachun Huang, Zhaojun Wang, Wenji Li, Jiaping Hu, Biao Xu, Shushan Huang, Junjie Yao, Yun Li, Zhun Fan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Most existing constrained multi-objective evolutionary algorithms primarily rely on heuristic search and empirically designed operators, often overlooking the underlying causal relationships between decision variables and objective functions. This limitation reduces their ability to avoid deceptive regions in the search space and increases the risk of premature convergence, particularly in problems with complex feasible regions. To tackle this challenge, we propose a novel causalityguided adaptive dual-population evolution for constrained multi-objective optimization algorithm (named CAD-CMOEA). The proposed CAD-CMOEA first employs an information-geometric causal inference method to model causal effects between decision variables and objectives, identifying the positive or negative influence of each variable. Based on this insight, a causality-aware genetic operator is developed by integrating competitive cooperative optimization strategies with Gaussian perturbation, enabling guided and directional variation to produce high-quality offspring. To further balance convergence and diversity, we propose a new dual-population co-evolution mechanism: one population explores high-quality solutions within the feasible region, while another population investigates promising areas near the infeasible boundary, thereby strengthening global search capabilities. Experimental results on LIR-CMOP1-14 benchmark problems demonstrate that CAD-CMOEA outperforms eight state-of-the-art algorithms in terms of IGD and HV metrics, confirming its effectiveness in causal modeling, search efficiency and solution quality.

title: A Wavelet Convolutional Neural Network Algorithm for Multi-Source Physiological Signal Denoising
authors: Bincai Wu, Qian Jia, Xulong Zhi, Xingwen Wu, Wenjing Zhang, Haoyi Fan, Lei Li, Zongmin Wang, Hao Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The accuracy and consistency of multi-source physiological signals are critical to the performance of medical large language models (MLLM). Traditional filtering algorithms suffer from fixed parameters and poor adaptability, while deep learning-based denoising approaches often involve excessive training parameters and high model complexity, resulting in high hardware requirements. This work proposes a wavelet convolutional neural network (WCNN) for denoising multi-source physiological signals. In the preprocessing and coarse-grained processing stages, signals contaminated by motion artifacts are converted into signals with only frequency-overlapping noise. By exploiting the ability of wavelet transforms to capture highfrequency features, the convolutional layers of a conventional CNN are replaced with wavelet transform layers, enabling precise separation of physiological signals. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed full-process WCNN improves the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of multi-source physiological signals by 12.96 dB and achieves effective denoising under frequency overlap conditions. This algorithm holds significant potential for denoising tasks in multi-source physiological signals and for applications in MLLM.

title: Single-Snapshot Direction of Arrival Estimation Using a Modified Smooth L0 Norm Algorithm
authors: Yue Jiang, Xiaoxue Li, Li Wang, Ziqi Yang, Yatao Liu, Qiaoyu Li, Yong Luo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The Smoothed L0 Norm (SL0) algorithm is a widelyused compressed sensing reconstruction technique that approximates the $\mathbf{L 0}$ norm through steepest descent and projected gradient principles, utilizing a decreasing sequence to approach the optimal solution. However, its conventional implementation with fixed step sizes often leads to suboptimal performance when the decreasing sequence is improperly selected. To address this limitation, we propose an enhanced single-snapshot Direction of Arrival (DOA) estimation method based on compressed sensing. Our improvement involves replacing the fixed step size in the steepest descent process with an optimal step size derived from exact one-dimensional search. This modification enables more accurate iterative solutions through optimal step sizes and descent directions. Comprehensive simulation results confirm that our proposed algorithm not only achieves effective DOA estimation but also significantly outperforms the conventional SL0 approach in terms of estimation accuracy and convergence performance.

title: Multi-Task Learning Empowered Network for Cervical Lymph Node Diagnosis
authors: Weihua He, Peng Ding, Li Liang, Guangming Yang, Fei Ouyang, Tong Zhang, Zhiyong Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposes a deep learning framework based on multi-task learning for the automated ultrasound diagnosis of cervical lymph node metastasis (CLNM) in papillary thyroid carcinoma before surgery. To address the challenges of low contrast, significant noise in ultrasound images, and the heavy reliance of diagnosis on physicians’ experience, existing methods are mostly limited to a single classification task or fail to effectively fuse global and local features. In this study, a dual-branch encoder-decoder architecture is designed, which can simultaneously achieve accurate segmentation of lymph node regions and classification of metastatic status. The model extracts local features via convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and global dependencies via Transformers in parallel, and realizes multi-scale feature fusion by integrating a feature alignment module. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a Dice coefficient of 0.7526, an intersection over union (IoU) of 0.8589, and a classification accuracy of 80.63%. Its performance is significantly superior to that of existing single-task methods and mainstream segmentation networks, which proves its application potential in clinical auxiliary diagnosis.

title: ADRC and Fuzzy Control-Based Cascade System for Unmanned Helicopter Flight Control
authors: Qianwen Xie, Tinghui Yuan, Huajun Gong, Shouzhao Sheng
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: In this paper, a cascaded flight control approach combining ADRC and fuzzy control is proposed and presented for unmanned helicopters subject to system uncertainties and external disturbances. The inner loop is the attitude control loop, incorporating an ESO to estimate the system's total disturbances. The outer loop is the height control and horizontal speed control loop. Fuzzy PID control is adopted to improve the high-dimensional nonlinearity problem caused by the large flight envelope, wide load and wide rotational speed of the helicopter. This paper demonstrates the superiority of the controller proposed in this study through detailed simulation results. The controller enables the helicopter to track control commands effectively, while the system exhibits excellent stability and robustness.

title: Single CCCII (Second Generation Current Controlled Conveyor) Based Integrator and Differentiator
authors: Syed Zahiruddin, K. Pavan Kumar, V. Adinarayana Reddy, A. Valli Bhasha, P.V.S. Murali Krishna, M. Prabhakar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Current mode devices excel in high-speed, low-noise, high-precision, and power-efficient environments in comparison with voltage mode devices. The key advantages are improved linearity, faster response times, higher bandwidth and reduced sensitivity to power supply variations, inherent current feedback, improved noise immunity, simplified circuit design and easier integration with other current devices. Second generation Current Controlled Conveyor (CCCII) is the exceptional device in the category of current conveyors which gives all of the above detailed advantages. In this manuscript current mode Integrator and Differentiator circuits utilizing a single CCCII are proposed. The novelty of the proposed configuration is it requires only one CCCII and minimal external passive components. Integrator and differentiator circuits find the applications in the field of Bio-medical field, analog signal processing, communication systems, waveform generators, pulse width modulators, ADCs, sensor interfaces and in many more circuits. The proposed designs are tested using transient analysis, Fourier analysis and Monte Carlo analysis. Cadence orcad tool is used to test the performance of the proposed designs.

title: The Role of Artificial Intelligence Literacy in Motivation Towards Usage
authors: Caterina Sapone, Silvia Francesca Maria Pizzoli, Stefano Triberti
abstract: The use of artificial intelligence (AI) tools in educational and professional contexts is a topic of profound interest to our society, currently studied from diverse disciplinary perspectives. From a pedagogical and psychological standpoint, understanding the dynamics that guide the interaction between individuals and the technologies they develop is fundamental. This article aims to explore the link between the perception of one's competencies in AI usage (i.e., AI literacy) and motivation types according to Self-Determination Theory (intrinsic motivation or external, introjected, identified, or integrated regulation), in using AI-based technologies among the general population. Regression analyses on a sample of 207 Italian-speaking were conducted, participants revealed that the AI literacy “engagement” factor, that is, the ability/interest towards actively participating in AI projects development, predicts more autonomous forms of motivation for using these technologies. These elements are crucial to developing educational strategies and professional training programs useful to people for more conscious and purposeful use of AI technology.

title: SoEdit: Improving Instruction-Driven Object Editing by Focusing on a Single Object within a Cropped Region
authors: Wuyang Luo, Su Yang, Hao Niu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Recently, instruction-driven image editing methods have demonstrated promising capabilities, requiring only a brief text to guide image modifications. However, most of them often yield suboptimal results for object editing in complex scenes, due to two major defects: (1) Over-editing, where unintended regions of the image are inadvertently altered; (2) Inability to precisely adhere to instructions, particularly in scenes with numerous elements. To resolve these issues, we propose a Single object Editing scheme, termed SoEdit, which distills complex editing tasks into single-object editing within cropped regions through a pipeline that integrates task parsing, object localization, editing, and context blending. This approach minimizes interference from irrelevant areas, ensures proper object size and placement, and ultimately enhances model performance. Furthermore, we introduce a lightweight Spatially-Adaptive Mixture of Experts (SAMOE) to better model spatial heterogeneity, enabling tokenwise adaptive processing and further enhancing the overall editing capability with minimal additional parameters. Moreover, we introduce a large-scale object-centric dataset to further optimize the model. Extensive experiments demonstrate that SoEdit outperforms existing methods, especially in precise responses to fine-grained editing requirements, such as multi-action and quantity-sensitive object editing.

title: The Width of Aerosol Size Distribution: A Non-Negligible Factor in the Hyperspectral Infrared Radiative Transfer Simulations and Aerosol Remote Sensing
authors: Jiaqi Zhao, Shuai Hu, Lei Liu, Ruijun Dang, Yao Xiao, Yulong He
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing of aerosols by infrared hyperspectral radiation has become an emerging research frontier in recent years. In current infrared hyperspectral remote sensing of aerosol, only the aerosol type and effective radius (Reff) are considered, while the width of the aerosol size distribution (Geometric Standard Deviation, GSD) is simplified as a constant, neglecting its impact on infrared radiative transfer. Is this simplification physically justified? To clarify this issue, an infrared hyperspectral radiative transfer model considering the variation of GSD of aerosol particles was established, and the impacts of GSD on both upwelling and downwelling radiances are investigated. It can be found that radiance discrepancies attributed to variations of GSD exceed those caused by effective radius up to 70%. The downwelling radiance demonstrates far greater sensitivity to GSD compared to its upwelling counterpart. Furthermore, the sensitivity of infrared radiance to GSD will be amplified with the increase of Aerosol Optical Depth (AOD). Finally, to further validate the necessity of considering GSD in aerosol remote sensing, both triple-parameter (AOD, Reff, and GSD) and dual-parameter inversions (AOD and Reff) were performed by using machine learning methods respectively. The results indicate that incorporating GSD into the inversion process can help improve the accuracy of effective radius inversions.

title: Can TDD Be Employed in LEO SatCom Systems? Challenges and Potential Approaches
authors: Hyunwoo Lee, Ian P. Roberts, Jehyun Heo, Joohyun Son, Hanwoong Kim, Yunseo Lee, Daesik Hong
abstract: Frequency-division duplexing (FDD) remains the de facto standard in modern low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite communication (SatCom) systems, such as SpaceX's Starlink, OneWeb, and Amazon's Project Kuiper. While time-division duplexing (TDD) is often regarded as superior in today's terrestrial networks, its viability in future LEO SatCom systems remains unclear. This article details how the long propagation delays and high orbital velocities exhibited by LEO SatCom systems impedes the adoption of TDD, largely due to challenges involving the frame structure and synchronization. We then present potential approaches to overcome these challenges, which vary in terms of spectral efficiency and operational/ device complexity and thus may likely be application- specific. We conclude by assessing the performance of these proposed approaches, putting into perspective the tradeoff between complexity and performance gains over FDD. Overall, this article aims to motivate future investigation into the prospects of TDD in LEO SatCom systems and solutions to enable such, with the goal of enhancing future systems and unifying them with terrestrial networks.

title: Origami-Inspired Deformation Feedback Twisted Tower for Adaptive Sensing_supp1-3657470.docx
authors: Shaohui Zhang
abstract: To advance the perception capabilities of flexible robotic arms,this study integrates sensing capabilities into a hybrid design combining conductive fabric with a “twisted tower” origami structure. This approach enables the creation of flexible structural units that combine flexibility, reconfigurability, and sensing-deformation feedback capabilities. Through experiments and simulations, we analyzed the effects of manufacturing processes, mechanical properties, electrical responses, and layer count on sensing performance. Our results demonstrated a positive correlation between displacement and load under static conditions, accompanied by stable and synchronized sensing signals. We also found that the layer count significantly modulated structural stiffness, load-bearing capacity, and sensing sensitivity. Furthermore, stable resistance changes observed during deformation validated the sensing reliability, and stress-strain simulations effectively revealed the correlation between deformation and sensing signals.

title: A Spatially-variant Error Correction Method for Downward-forward-looking SAR
authors: Wentao Li, Zhian Yuan, Bin Deng, Ke Xu, Xiaoqiang Hua, Yang Zeng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Downward-forward-looking synthetic aperture radar (SAR) is valuable for autonomous navigation, structural monitoring, and disaster management. However, its imaging quality is often degraded by severe spatially variant phase errors resulting from range-azimuth coupling. To address this issue, this paper introduces a high-precision echo signal model and a novel correction method aimed at spatially-variant error compensation. The proposed approach first achieves range-azimuth decoupling using dechirp processing combined with the Keystone transform. A key contribution is the application of a series expansion-based phase compensation method that effectively eliminates residual spatially-variant errors. Finally, azimuth focusing yields a wellfocused SAR image. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves image quality and validates its effectiveness in spatially-variant error correction.

title: Stability Region Analysis for HVDC-Connected Off-shore Wind Farm Participating in Grid Frequency Support
authors: Zhihao Zhang, Yuanhang Zhang, Peng Kou
abstract: When the high-voltage direct current-connected offshore wind farm (HVDC-connected OWF) participates in grid frequency support, excessively high frequency controller gains may exacerbate the electromagnetic oscillations within system. Therefore, it is essential to study the stability region for frequency controller gains of HVDC-connected OWF, thus ensuring the grid secure operation during frequency events. Currently, numerical methods are used to analyze the operational stability region of HVDC-connected OWF. However, these methods involve exhaustive calculations to obtain the stability region, resulting in a significant computational burden. To address the issue, this work proposes an analytical stability region identification method for HVDC-connected OWF when it participates in the grid frequency support. Specifically, a comprehensive small signal model, tailored for analyzing frequency support-induced oscillation, is first developed by considering both the frequency regulation characteristics and the power converter dynamics. Further, using the Padé approximation technique, the reduced order equivalent model is derived while preserving its accuracy. With this equivalent model, the mechanism underlying frequency support-induced oscillation is qualitatively elucidated, and the stability region for frequency support is also analytically derived. Finally, the analysis results are validated through electromagnetic transient simulations.

title: Multitask Multilayer Model for Predicting HR, BP Inside ICU as Well as Patient Death
authors: Nora Elrashidy, Wael Sobhy, Tamer Medhat
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Predicting vital signs in real-time has critical impact on predicting life-threatening events such as mortality, morbidity, etc. To ensure the importance of the chosen study, we conduct a bibliometric study that analyzes the utilization of vital signs in mortality prediction. We analyze the authors, keywords, organizations, studies, and citations from 2020 to 2024. Our proposal in this paper is a two-layer multilayer system. To anticipate the patient's heart rate and blood pressure during the following three hours, we start by analysing past vital data. In addition to these critical signs prediction, the patient's data should be used to produce an early death prediction. The MIMIC-III database was used for this study. Along with other metrics like vital signs, lab results, imaging reports, etc., it contains patient data like age, weight, and height. To estimate a patient's heart rate and blood pressure, we suggest a technique that uses a Multitask multilayer LSTM_GRU model to extract signal and statistical information from the patient's vital signs. For the regression task, LSTM_GRU gives the best performance of 22.906, 2.91, and 0.921 for MSE, MAE, and R2 score, respectively. For the classification task, the stacking ensemble model gives the best performance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{A C C} = \text{0. 9 4 3}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}$</tex>-measure <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.955$</tex>, and AUC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=0.943$</tex>.

title: GenoCGC: A Hybrid CNN and Graph-based Transformer Model for Genomic Sequence Classification
authors: Anas Abu-Doleh
abstract: Advancements in sequencing technologies have resulted in rapid growth in genomic data. This revolutionary technology has enabled conducting large-scale studies in biology and medicine. In bioinformatics, accurately classifying genomic sequences is a necessary step for understanding genetic variations, identifying disease mutations, and advancing precision medicine. However, it remains one of the key challenges in the field. Traditional machine learning approaches often struggle with the complexity of genomic data. However, deep learning approaches, such as transformer-based models, improve analysis by capturing long-range dependencies. We introduce GenoCGC, a hybrid model combining Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and a Graph-based Transformer (Graphormer) for genomic sequence classification. GenoCGC uses CNNs for capturing local features while utilizing Graphormer to model complex dependencies. We compared GenoCGC with traditional classifiers and genomic large language models across multiple genomic benchmark tasks. Experimental results show that GenoCGC achieves promising performance, providing an accurate and practical solution for genomic sequence analysis.

title: Non-Contact Rotational Speed Measurement Along with Direction by Using Optical Technique
authors: Sampa Das, Ramendra Debnath, Ardhendu Saha
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This article presents the design and construction of a contactless real time speed and direction measurement technique by using IR LED and sensor pair. The infrared system detects a break in the stream of rays induced by a spinning object and creates pulses; the pulses are then examined with a Cathode Ray Oscilloscope (CRO). This measurement system uses infrared sensors to record phase-shifted signals, allowing it to determine the direction of rotation in addition to precisely measuring rotational speed in revolutions per minute (RPM). The RPM values acquired by the developed system have been calibrated using a commercial tachometer DT-2235 and it has been observed that values recorded by the system are accurate. The novelty of this measurement technique lies in its ability to measure both speed and direction simultaneously in real time, without any contact, for the first time. The technology is cost-effective and has several uses in the automotive and medical industries.

title: Incorporating Hebbian Learning into Biologically Plausible Dendritic Learning
authors: Zhenyu Lei, Wenzhu Gu, Xiangmei Li, Jiake Wang, Shangce Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: The simulation of biological neurons presents a promising direction for advancing artificial neural networks, particularly in architectural design, learning mechanisms, and interpretability. In this study, a novel biologically plausible dendritic learning network (pDL) is proposed that integrates dendritic computation with Hebbian learning. Unlike conventional models based on McCulloch-Pitts neurons and backpropagation (BP), the pDL leverages dendritic structures for nonlinear information processing and adopts a local, biologically inspired Hebbian learning rule that incorporates both local and global error signals. This architecture not only enhances the network's computational capacity but also mitigates common limitations associated with BP, such as gradient explosion and vanishing gradients. Experimental results show that the pDL outperforms traditional multilayer perceptron in classification tasks and effectively extracts discriminative features through dendritic processing. Furthermore, the use of plausible Hebbian learning significantly improves inter-class feature separation, thereby increasing the confidence coefficient in classification outcomes. Overall, the proposed method offers an effective and interpretable alternative to conventional deep learning approaches, bridging the gap between artificial and biological intelligence.

title: Robust Generalized Adaptive Estimation Via Least Mean P-power Error Minimization: Convergence and Steady-state Performance Analysis
authors: Chen Zhou, Yihui Yang, Shiwei Yun, Liangfu Peng, Chuanwu Zhang, Sihai Guan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel robust adaptive estimation algorithm based on the generalized least mean p-power error (GLMP) criterion, which significantly enhances the filtering performance under both Gaussian and non-Gaussian noise environments with correlated or uncorrelated input signals. The proposed GLMP algorithm innovatively combines the versoria function with the LMP principle, demonstrating superior adaptability to unknown system dynamics. Through theoretical analysis, we establish the convergence conditions and derive the steady-state mean square error expression for the proposed estimator. Comprehensive simulation studies on system identification validate the theoretical findings and demonstrate the algorithm’s advantages over existing robust techniques. The results indicate that the GLMP algorithm achieves improved steady-state performance while maintaining strong robustness against diverse measurement noises and input signal conditions.

title: Transfer Learning-Based Channel Prediction for Multi-IRS Assisted Communication Systems
authors: Chengfang Yue, Chengcheng Xie, Yang Fu, Hao Feng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper investigates transfer learning-based channel prediction in multiple intelligent reflecting surfaces (multi-IRS) assisted communication systems. Existing models are primarily designed for single-IRS systems and face limitations when applied to multi-IRS configurations. To address this challenge, we propose to formulate the channel predictions in multiIRS systems as a deep transfer learning (DTL) problem. The DTL algorithm employs a two-phase methodology, beginning with the pretraining of a neural network on source tasks, followed by fine-tuning for target tasks. In the pretraining phase, the fully connected neural network (FNN) is trained to predict downlink cascaded channels based on their uplink counterparts from prior IRS systems. In the fine-tuning phase, this pretrained model is adapted to target tasks by transferring the pre-established channel knowledge to new IRS scenarios. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed DTL model achieves satisfactory channel prediction accuracy with reduced training overhead in multi-IRS assisted communication systems.

title: Global Refugee Analysis: Insights into Asylum Applications, Demographics, and Resettlement Trends
authors: Gouri Lakshmi S, Bhagyasree G H, Gowry Nandana M, Yaswanth O S, Alwin Poulose
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: As global displacement continues to rise due to conflict, persecution, and humanitarian crises, there is an increasing demand for data-driven insights to inform policy and improve support systems for refugees. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for analyzing refugee movements, asylum applications, and resettlement trends using Tableau and UNHCR data. It explores key metrics such as origin and destination patterns, demographic breakdowns by age and gender, and the various stages of refugee status determination. Combining descriptive analytics with predictive modeling, this study integrates temporal and spatial dimensions to identify critical trends and disparities in host country responses. The framework also highlights opportunities for enhancing humanitarian efforts and guiding evidence-based decision-making. By bridging the gap between data visualization and policy implications, this work aims to provide stakeholders with actionable insights to address the complexities of the global refugee crisis.

title: Epileptic Seizure Prediction Using Deep Learning
authors: Vishnu P I, Vishnu Rajan, Gnana King
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Epilepsy is not common disease and it’s a situation, but its becoming like a common disease and it happens to more people and also animals compared to old times. This research tries to find multiple ways for epilepsy seizure solution. It is not easy to control after the seizure has been occurred, because patient will be out of control and they don’t know what they are doing at that moment. So the best solution is, it should be get predicted. Then only the patient can avoid this situation. The best ways to predict the epilepsy seizure is the main aim of this research. There were already researched and found much prediction methods for epilepsy seizures. The main challenge is that it is need to propose the best and accurate method with latest technologies. The technique can be a new algorithm or new technology or new method with existing algorithm. The study of epilepsy seizure can be done by electroencephalogram recordings of epilepsy patients. So that we can only use existing recordings to design a method by comparing the recordings of non-epileptic patients. The recordings can be represented by time domain and frequency domain. We are here trying to propose a method by using deep learning for prediction of epilepsy seizure. This work then suggests mainly the latest convolutional neural network for best result. We believes that it shall be a good framework for using deep learning to represent the issue of risk prediction in the medical field.

title: Enhancing Project Selection Process Via Machine Learning
authors: Yasmin AlHowail, Meshaal Alqahtani, Atiq W. Siddiqui
abstract: Project portfolio management has evolved as businesses attempt to optimize their project selection approaches. In this work, we first investigate the critical determinants of project success in project portfolios. These factors, which are rooted in the typical strategic goals of companies, the project managers' experiences, and the competitive climate, are then used to evaluate new potential projects in terms of their likely success on the dimensions of scope, cost, and time. We collected data on these determinants and the actual success or failures of these projects, which is then used to train various machine learning models, including Decision Trees, Random Forest, XGBoost, and Feedforward Neural Network (FNN), which will then help classify projects based on their potential for success. The dataset includes 284 projects collected from an internal company source under confidentiality constraints. The models aim to predict the likeliness of success of projects competing in a portfolio. ANN outperforms all other models, achieving the highest accuracy in predicting project success, followed by Random Forest and XGBoost, which also performed well but with slightly lower predictive power.
