title: Celebrity Hairstyle Recommendation System with Hairstyle Transfer
authors: Long Vu Pham, Vanha Tran, Truongminh Ngo
abstract: Hairstyles significantly shape an individual’s personality and fashion sense, accentuating appearance in social perception. The challenge of selecting a suitable hairstyle for one’s face is crucial as mass media expands access to celebrity fashion trends. Hairstyle recommendation systems have been introduced; however, they exhibit certain drawbacks, such as relying on facial shape classification combined with rule-based methods to match specific hairstyles to user face shapes. This paper introduces a Celebrity Hairstyle Recommendation System with Hairstyle Transfer, which will provide more flexible and personalized hairstyle options for the user’s face. Our method first uses the Swinface model to extract and analyze the facial features. Secondly, we apply a comparison algorithm based on the similarity between the attributes of the user’s face and the faces of celebrities in the database to recommend the four most suitable hairstyles. Finally, the new hairstyles will be quickly and accurately rendered on the user’s face using the HairFastGAN model. We conduct experiments by applying our recommendation algorithms on the SCUT-FPB5500 dataset, using a SEResNeXt50 backbone combined with ComboLoss to score the input and generated images to determine an effective recommendation strategy. The experimental results indicate that our recommendation method improves the average beauty score by 7.69% for the faces in the filtered SCUT-FBP5500 dataset, with the best PC metric of approximately 0.96.

title: Minimum-Variance-Based Blind CFO Estimator for OTFS Systems in V2X Communications
authors: Liangdong Wei, Aijun Liu, Kegang Pan, Xiaohu Liang, Xinhai Tong, Xin Xu
abstract: This letter proposes a new low-complexity blind carrier frequency offset (CFO) estimator for orthogonal time frequency space (OTFS) systems in vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communications. The estimator leverages the statistical properties of the element-wise modulus vector of OTFS symbols in the delay-Doppler (DD) domain. It is shown that, under ideal CFO compensation, the variance of this vector reaches its minimum while the expectation reaches its maximum. Based on this finding, the objective function for CFO estimation is formulated. Moreover, to reduce complexity and meet the real-time requirement of V2X communications, the expectation of the objective function is approximated as its mean via the law of large numbers. Simulation results demonstrate that, for sufficient signal lengths, the proposed estimator achieves lower complexity while achieving higher estimation accuracy under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions compared with existing estimators.

title: QLMS-QHM: Accelerated Quaternion LMS Algorithm with Quasi-Hyperbolic Momentum
authors: Qiankun Diao, Dongpo Xu, Shuning Sun, Danilo P. Mandic
abstract: Quaternions adaptive filtering has become a defacto standard in multidimensional signal processing, however, challenges remain regarding in the balance between convergence speed and stability. To this end, we propose a novel quaternion least mean square algorithm with quasi-hyperbolic momentum (QLMS-QHM), which incorporates a quasi-hyperbolic momentum mechanism to adaptively integrate historical gradient information, thereby accelerating convergence and improving robustness in noisy environments. Theoretical analysis establishes step size bounds for asymptotic convergence, along with comprehensive evaluations of both mean and mean-square behaviors. Simulations demonstrate that the QLMS-QHM algorithm outperforms the classical QLMS, particularly in scenarios requiring rapid adaptation and interference suppression. Practical applications in quaternion-valued adaptive beamforming validate the effectiveness of the QLMS-QHM algorithm under dynamic interference conditions. Overall, the QLMS-QHM algorithm provides a unified framework for incorporating momentum mechanisms into quaternion adaptive filtering, enhancing the design and application of filters in real-world scenarios.

title: An FDA-STAP Approach based on Clutter Subspace for Airborne Radar
authors: Di Song, Chunyu Song, Zhiyong Cheng, Jie Zhao, Ruyi Chun, Kaile Zou, Xingyao Li, Xuewan Zhang, Jialun Wu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Space-time adaptive processing (STAP) has been a promising methodology in clutter rejection for airborne radars. However, the performance of STAP is commonly restricted by range ambiguity. It is confirmed that Frequency diverse array (FDA) can address range ambiguity by providing range-related degrees of freedom. Therefore, FDA-STAP becomes popular for rejecting range ambiguous clutter. Nevertheless, the existing FDASTAP commonly performs poorly while the number of training samples is small. This paper develops a novel FDA-STAP, which realizes range ambiguous clutter cancellation by constructing orthogonal subspace of clutter subspace according to the platform and radar system parameters. The proposed method is not restricted by samples and has significant performance advantages when system parameters are known accurately.

title: Leveraging LLMs for LncRNA Classification and LncRNA-Protein Interaction Prediction: A Novel Approach for Sequence-Based Feature Extraction
authors: Yuhan Sun, Huaijin Wu, Kaipeng Zeng, Xiaoxing Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Long non-coding Ribonucleic Acids (IncRNAs) play critical roles in cellular regulation, yet their functional annotation remains challenging due to sequence complexity and limited datasets. Traditional methods for IncRNA classification and Ribonucleic Acid (RNA)-protein interaction prediction rely on handcrafted feature engineering, which is labor-intensive and suboptimal. We propose a novel approach leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) for sequence-based feature extraction to automate IncRNA analysis. We address two key bottlenecks: (1) classifying IncRNAs into categories (LincRNA, Antisense, Exonic, Sense No Exonic) using sequence data alone, and (2) predicting IncRNA-protein interactions. Our framework integrates fine-tuned RNA Foundation Model (RNA-FM) and Evolutionary Scale Modeling (ESM) models with multi-head attention pooling and Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs) for end-to-end prediction. We then built two different datasets: Lnc-4 (458,104 sequences) and LncPI-180k (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3 5 7, 4 3 8}$</tex> pairs). Results show our model outperforms baselines (CORAIN and RPITER) in both tasks, achieving significant improvements in accuracy, F1-score, recall, and Area Under the Curve (AUC), while reducing computational time by over 90%. This study establishes a robust, scalable framework for IncRNA functional annotation. We release the code at https://github.com/kelly159951/LLMs-LncRNA

title: Online Monitoring of Batteries in Modular Multilevel Energy Storage Systems without Disturbing the Electrical Network
authors: Enrique Nunes, Ezequiel Rodriguez Ramos, Ramon Leyva, Gaowen Liang, Hein Wai Yan, Glen G. Farivar, Josep Pou
abstract: Accurate monitoring of battery parameters is essential for optimizing the performance, safety and longevity of grid scale battery energy storage systems (BESSs). Conventionally, equivalent circuit model (ECM) parameter identification is per formed through offline testing, which results in costly downtime, or through online perturbation-based methods, which disturb the grid undesirably. In contrast, this paper proposes a method for online ECM parameter identification in modular multilevel cascaded converter (MMCC)-based BESSs that introduces no disturbances into the electrical grid. The proposed technique injects controlled current harmonic perturbations into the battery terminals while using a novel control strategy to cancel the net effect of these harmonics at the grid interface. This is enabled by leveraging the inherent interleaving capability of the MMCC-based BESS. This control-based solution eliminates the need for oversized buffer capacitors or extra hardware, and can be integrated seamlessly within existing control schemes. Validation is performed using a 3.84-kW/3.46-kWh lab prototype under various grid conditions, demonstrating accurate real-time ECM parameter estimation via recursive least squares without distorting the grid current.

title: A Hybrid Multi-Criteria Decision-Making Based Fuzzy System for Comprehensive Health Assessment of Power Transformers
authors: Teruvai Manoj, Chilaka Ranga, Shrikrishna V. Kulkarni
abstract: Precise evaluation of transformer health using well-structured asset management methodologies is essential, and over the last two decades, several health assessment methods have been developed based on various diagnostic tests. However, the literature on methods to ensure a comprehensive health evaluation with a focus on prioritized correlation analysis is limited. In this context, this work proposes a framework for evaluating the performance of power transformers using 15 diagnostic attributes. The model is designed with Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP), Grey Relational Analysis (GRA), and Technique for Order Performance by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS). The diagnostic attributes are initially normalized, and then prioritized based on closely related characteristics and finally grouped into three specific health degrees using the proposed systematic hybrid decision-making approach. The three health degrees are further coupled with a technical fuzzy rule base to derive the actual health status of power transformers. The hybrid model is validated using known health conditions of 200 transformers collected from Himachal Pradesh State Electricity Board, India, and compared with recent similar health prediction methods published in the literature. The comparison reveals the superiority of the model with 97% accuracy. Moreover, the following are the main advantages of the model over the existing health assessment methods: prioritization among closely related attributes, assessment of samples with respect to positive and negative ideal solutions, no dependency on training data, less complexity, and consideration of visual inspection and maintenance parameters. Furthermore, it facilitates an appropriate alert system for conditional maintenance.

title: Fault Tolerance in Fog Computing with Architectures Scheduling and Optimization for IoT
authors: Vidyashree K N, Mallikarjunaswamy S, Sharmila N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The exponential growth of Internet of Things (IoT) applications requires efficient, low-latency, and reliable data processing systems. Fog computing, which brings computation closer to data sources, addresses latency and bandwidth concerns but remains vulnerable to node failures, task interrupts, and resource heterogeneity. This survey explores fault-tolerant mechanisms in fog computing with emphasis on architectural resilience, dynamic task scheduling, and system optimization techniques. It examines various fault tolerance approaches such as Markov models, learning automata, reinforcement learning, and heuristic-based algorithms for enhancing reliability and performance in distributed fog systems. The study further explores the integration of energy efficiency, deadline awareness, and cost minimization in fault-tolerant designs. Through the examination of recent advances, this survey ascertains current challenges, evaluates performance metrics such as latency, makespan, and system reliability, and outlines potential future directions for the development of robust fault-tolerant fog infrastructures for IoT applications.

title: Agentic AI for Healthcare: Solutions to Intelligent Patient Care
authors: Shadi AlZu’Bi, Muder Almiani, Yaser Jararweh
abstract: The advancement of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare has opened new avenues for improving patient out-comes through enhanced diagnostic accuracy, optimized treatment strategies, and more efficient clinical workflows. This study presents a novel Agentic AI system designed to address key inefficiencies in modern healthcare systems. Unlike conventional AI approaches, the proposed system integrates adaptive decision-making mechanisms that dynamically respond to patient conditions, ensuring real-time anomaly detection, predictive diagnostics, and intelligent intervention strategies. To validate its effectiveness, the model was tested across three critical healthcare scenarios. The early disease detection module achieved a predictive accuracy of 92.3%, outperforming traditional risk models. The real-time patient monitoring system demonstrated an anomaly detection rate of 98.7%, with an alert response time of just 2.5 seconds, showcasing its reliability in clinical settings. Moreover, the proposed system outperformed existing AI solutions, attaining a 96.5% confidence score, reducing misdiagnosis rates by 22%, and surpassing traditional radiologists in both sensitivity and specificity. This work bridges the gap between theoretical AI advancements and real-world healthcare applications, laying the foundation for intelligent, autonomous systems in modern medical practice.

title: Physics-Constrained Self-supervised Learning Based Halo-Free Quantitative Phase Imaging
authors: Haobin Ye, Tianhe Wang, Lin Liu, Liangwei Li, Xiaohui Du, Juanxiu Liu, Ruqian Hao, Jing Zhang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Recent advancements in quantitative phase imaging (QPI) have facilitated label-free, high-resolution assessments of cellular dynamics and material properties of various biological samples. Although white-light diffraction phase microscopy enables rapid phase reconstruction through common-path interferometry with single-frame holograms, these systems are plagued by halo artifacts owing to limited spatial coherence and unmeasurable noise, such as spatial light modulator jitter. To address this issue, we propose a physics-constrained self-supervised halo-free network (PC-SHFN) using Gaussian-approximated noise modeling and physical constraints, which can effectively eliminate halo effects without sacrificing phase accuracy by utilizing digitally simulated training data for robust generalization. This approach offers a practical solution for real-time, artifact-free QPI in biomedical imaging and materials science.

title: On Ambiguity in 6-DoF Electromagnetic Pose Estimation Systems_supp5-3649744.mp4
authors: Heng Wang
abstract: Magnetic pose estimation is an accurate, noncontacting pose tracking method that is insusceptible to occlusion, making it widely used for tracking intracorporeal medical robots and devices in minimally invasive interventions. However, the ambiguity problem in magnetic pose estimation has been long overlooked that could result in inaccuracy and even divergence of pose tracking. This article is devoted to fundamentally investigating the ambiguity issue in 6-DoF electromagnetic pose estimation systems. Magnetic ambiguity is formally defined, and its existence and impacts on pose estimation are analyzed for single-magnet and dual-magnet tracking systems, then generalized to multiple-magnet systems. It is found that there are different types of ambiguity, each with distinct influence on pose estimation. Efficient algorithms are proposed to systematically identify all ambiguous poses in a workspace. The ambiguity in typical configurations of dual-magnet systems is identified and discussed. It is found that ambiguity can be completely eliminated by using at least THREE magnetic sources. An unambiguous tri-magnet system is proposed by combining the collocated and parallel dual-magnet systems and validated by tracking a continuum robot. This article lays the foundation for optimizing configurations of magnetic sources and designing compact, energy-efficient, but unambiguous magnetic tracking systems with minimum number of magnetic sources.

title: Leveraging Adverse Weather for Enhanced LiDAR Spoofing in Autonomous Driving: Challenges and Opportunities
authors: Richard Capraru, Emil Lupu, Jian-Gang Wang, Boon Hee Soong
abstract: Lidar-based 3D perception systems are critical for autonomous vehicle (AV) navigation, yet they remain vulnerable to spoofing attacks that can create false detections (ghost objects) or hide real obstacles. Despite significant advances in object detection, existing methods remain highly susceptible to adversarial attacks. Furthermore, existing research has largely overlooked the impact of weather conditions on both attacks and defenses. No existing study provides a systematic analysis on how the rain effect affects spoofing and hiding attacks. Motivated by this critical gap, we propose a novel rain-aware threat model in this article, focusing on lidar spoofing attacks involving object insertion (ghost objects) and removal (hiding attacks). We review state-of-the-art attack implementations and emphasize how rain increases attack feasibility and stealth, enabling attackers to achieve effective spoofing with significantly fewer perturbed points. We call this a reduced attack budget (AB). Formally, we define the AB as the minimal number of spoofed points (and corresponding laser returns) needed to meet attack success (ghost insertion: high-confidence false positives; object hiding: low-confidence false negatives).

title: A Novel ADP-based Neurooptimal Control Methodology for Teleoperation Systems under Interactive Shared-control Framework
authors: Huixin Jiang, Yana Yang, Changchun Hua, Junpeng Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper delves a robust neurooptimal shared control tactic for teleoperation systems affected by model uncertainties and external disturbances. A novel shared-control structure is established with an explicitly defined and dynamically adjustable weights mechanism, enabling smooth authority transitions across control modes and consistent task execution. A neural near-optimal adaptive dynamic programming (ADP) framework firstly applied to uncertain teleoperation eschews the conventional dependence on precisely known dynamics to deliver near-optimal control. Moreover, a prescribed-time exponential disturbance observer (PPTEDO) featuring a rigorously designed continuous switching function, thereby overcomes the inherent instability and chattering pitfalls associated with discontinuous PT schemes. Under the impedance control layer, a reset regularized exponentiation sliding mode (RRESM) surface is designed to ensure fast transient-state response while elevating system transparency and improve human-robot interaction fluency. Additionally, the absolute stability of the closed-loop teleoperation system is rigorously proved via establishment of Lyapunov candidate function. Finally, experiment results are presented to demonstrate the practical availability of the designed algorithm.

title: Analysis and Modelling of Compensation Topologies of Wireless Power Transfer for Electric Vehicles
authors: Komal Kore, Srinivas Nagaballi, Totappa Hasarmani, Amruta Kudalkar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Wireless Power Transfer (WPT) system's primary goal is to increase efficiency and accessibility as compared to plug-in system. In various WPT compensation methods, the Series-Series (S-S) is frequently utilized for electric vehicles due to its constant current and constant voltage charging capabilities. The main objective of this paper is to study various types WPT system for EVs, analysis of different compensation and convertor topologies, in detail mathematical modelling and comparison of Series Series(S-S) and LCC-LCC compensation of the WPT system. This study helps to understand different compensation topologies which offer several benefits and are crucial to the dynamic behaviour of WPT systems as they will increase efficiency, facilitate the passage of reactive current, and help with coil impedance matching. The Commercial acceptance of magnetic resonance wireless power transfer (MRWPT) systems for EV battery chargers is expected as it provides greater efficiency at power levels up to 100 KW and a greater power transmission range for charging of EV's which gaining popularity in both academia and industry because of its dependability and efficiency.

title: HMSP: Hierarchical Multimodal Semantic Fusion of Pathology-Text-Genomic Representations for Robust Survival Prediction
authors: Jiaqi Yang, Jingxi Hu, Xiangjian He
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Computational pathology has become an indispensable component of cancer survival analysis, yet state-of-the-art multimodal pipelines still depend heavily on paired whole-slide images (WSIs) and in situ genomic or immunohistochemistry (IHC) profiles. In practice, however, IHC and high-throughput sequencing are costly, tissue-consuming, and frequently unavailable, creating a critical performance gap for cases lacking molecular data. To bridge this gap, we introduce HMSP (Hierarchical Multimodal Survival Prediction), a framework that leverages richly structured pathology reports as a flexible linguistic surrogate for missing genomic information. Concretely, HMSP formulates WSIs, free-text pathology narratives, and (when present) genomic features as a three-level hierarchy of visual, lexical, and molecular semantics. We enforce hierarchical consistency with a Tri-Modal Ranking Contrastive Loss and a Cone-Based Hyperbolic (H-Cone) regulariser, enabling (i) fine-grained alignment between image regions and report phrases and (ii) high-level alignment between report embeddings and genomic biomarkers. Once trained, the report encoder alone can act as a plug-in genomic proxy, allowing robust survival prediction even when molecular assays are absent. Extensive experiments on five public cohorts demonstrate that HMSP not only surpasses previous multimodal baselines under full-data settings, but also maintains state-of-the-art performance when genomic channels are wholly ablated—highlighting the practicality of text-driven surrogates in real-world resource-constrained scenarios. Code and pretrained weights will be released upon publication.

title: MS-STO-Net: A Multi-Scale State Transition Optimization-Based Ensemble Network for Accurate White Blood Cell Classification
authors: Omair Bilal, Arash Hekmat, Saif Ur Rehman Khan, Asif Raza, Ghazanfar Ali
abstract: The precise classification of white blood cells (WBC) plays a crucial role in the prompt diagnosis of a range of health conditions. However, current methods face significant challenges including overfitting, reliance on trial-and-error strategies for model selection, and suboptimal performance, particularly in scenarios involving diverse and complex datasets. To address these challenges, we propose the Multi-Scale State Transition Optimization-based Ensemble network (MS-STO-Net). Initially, we selected three deep learning (DL) models named MobileNetV1, DenseNet169, and DenseNet201 due to their exceptional performance on a specified blood cancer cells dataset. These models are used to extract robust features from blood cell images. To further enhance feature extraction at various scales, we integrate a Naive Inception Block (NIB) with each of these selected DL models and considered them as base models for the building the proposed method. The significant advantage of using NIB lies in its ability to efficiently capture multi-scale features without a significant increase in computational complexity. In prior studies, manually assigned weightage in weighted ensemble approaches restricted the full contribution of base models. To overcome this, we use the State Transition Algorithm (STA) to optimize the contribution of each base model by dynamically adjusting their weightage for improved performance. The inclusion of STA allows the method to dynamically find the optimal set of weightage vector for each base model, thus maximizing the ensemble performance. To evaluate the proposed method, we utilized the publicly available Kaggle BCCD WBC dataset consisting of five distinct classes. The proposed MS-STO-Net model achieved an impressive accuracy performance of 98.86% by outperforming prior studies and individual base models. Additionally, Grad-CAM visualizations were used to demonstrate the decision-making capability of the models, and the ROC curve was also incorporated to further validate the performance of models.

title: Thermal-Hydraulic Modeling and Code Benchmark of the EU-DEMO TOKAMAK Building Under Accident Conditions
authors: Gianluca Nesti, Matteo D’Onorio, Tommaso Glingler
abstract: This work presents a code-to-code comparison of a loss of coolant accident (LOCA) scenario in the European DEMOnstration (EU-DEMO) fusion reactor. The analysis involves GOTHIC and MELCOR, two well-established system codes commonly used for thermal-hydraulic simulations of nuclear reactors under accident conditions. Containment models were developed in both codes to predict the thermal-hydraulic response of the system with a particular focus on the pressure evolution in different compartments of the building. Key physical phenomena influencing pressure behavior, namely flashing, condensation, heat exchange, and choked flow have been examined. For each phenomenon, its relevance to the accident scenario was discussed, followed by a comparative analysis of the modeling approaches adopted by each code. Finally, the resulting differences in the main thermal-hydraulic variables were analyzed and interpreted on the basis of the underlying physical models.

title: Public Datasets for Multimodal Machine Learning-Driven Depression Detection: A Comprehensive Survey
authors: Yutao Dou, Siyu Li, Haihua Zhu, Shaoliang Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Depression is a common mental health disorder that significantly affects the physical and psychological well-being of hundreds of millions of people worldwide. Recent advances in deep learning have driven notable progress in automatic depression detection (ADD) systems. These systems are capable of efficiently analyzing multimodal data, including electroencephalography (EEG), audio, video, and text, to identify signs of depression with high accuracy. Existing reviews have introduced various methods. However, they often lack comprehensive coverage of data sources across all these modalities. This academic review aims to address that gap by examining publicly available datasets used in multimodal machine learning for depression detection. It systematically analyzes the characteristics, strengths, and limitations of datasets involving different modalities, including textual, auditory, visual, and EEG signals. Integrating multiple data modalities holds promise for improving the accuracy and reliability of depression diagnosis. Despite significant progress, several key challenges remain unresolved. These include the heterogeneity of data across modalities, variations in individual symptom expression, and the scarcity of datasets that incorporate more than three modalities.

title: Robust Softplus Pipeline Spline Adaptive Filtering
authors: Tianci Xu, Jiashu Zhang, Xingyu He, Wei Ge
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The pipeline-structured spline adaptive filter has demonstrated excellent performance in nonlinear system identification tasks and has garnered significant attention in recent years. However, the traditional pipelined nonlinear spline filter, which employs the mean squared error (MSE) criterion, suffers from limited robustness in non-Gaussian noise environments, restricting its practical application. To address this issue, we propose an enhanced softplus pipelined nonlinear spline filter (SPNSF) based on the softplus cost function, aimed at improving its adaptability in non-Gaussian noise conditions. Additionally, a theoretical analysis of the algorithm’s stability is provided, confirming its convergence and reliability. Simulation results indicate that the proposed SPNSF algorithm achieves superior identification performance across various nonlinear systems and significantly enhances the applicability of the pipeline spline filtering framework in complex noise environments.

title: Event-driven Control Approach of Cooperative Localization-Formation Hybrid for Internet of Multi-USV
authors: Hong Zhu, Xiuwei Xia, Ya Zhang, Haomiao Yu, Shiwei Fan, Wei Gao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: This article considers the cooperative localization and formation control problem for unmanned surface vessels (USV) with actuator magnitude as well as rate saturation and model uncertainty. To facilitate the accuracy of the USV positioning and the robustness of formation control, a cooperative localization formation hybrid (CLFH) framework is conceived. The finite-time back-stepping formation controller is constructed to accelerate the convergence speed of the formation for the CLFH strategy. Considering communication redundancy between controller and actuator, fixed and time-varying thresholds are designed to reduce communication frequency, resulting in communication cost savings. The unknown model and unknown time-varying disturbances are taken into consideration, adaptive fuzzy logic estimator is estab lished to evaluate model uncertainty and external disturbances. Time-varying Lyapunov function is designed to avoid collisions between USVs. The Lyapunov theory for CLFH framework proves that the line of sight range error and bear angle error can converge to a tiny neighborhood near zero. The simulation experiment verify the proposed control method is valid and efficient.

title: FastICA-Comb: A Novel Algorithm for Extracting Voluntary Electromyography and M-Wave in Functional Electrical Stimulation Scenarios
authors: Xingjian Li, Xiang Chen, Penghui Lin, De Wu, Xu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Functional electrical stimulation (FES) is commonly used in clinical practice to induce muscle contractions for rehabilitation therapy. However, the collected electromyography (EMG) under FES is a mixed signal containing voluntary electromyography (VEMG), which is generated by neural system recruited motor units, and FES response, which is composed of initial spikes generated by current passage and M-waves generated by stimulation recruited motor units. To realize close-loop control of FES system or to reveal the mechanism of FES through EMG signal, it is necessary to separate the three components from mixed signal. Based on the assumption that signal sources of initial spikes and action potentials related signals (VEMG and M-waves) are independent of each other, this study presents a novel mixed FES signal decomposition algorithm termed FastICA-Comb. Specifically, in order to achieve high-quality separation of VEMG, M-waves and initial spikes, the algorithm is designed as a unique scheme combining one-stage comb filtering and two-stage fast independent component analysis (FastICA) decomposition and classification. To evaluate the proposed algorithm’s effectiveness, FES data collection experiment was conducted on 6 healthy subjects. The experimental results confirm that the FastICA-Comb algorithm has better VEMG and M-wave extraction capabilities than the classical methods including comb filter, GS-PEF, EMD-notch and blanking window in both simulated and real mixed FES signal. Therefore, the research findings provide an effective signal analysis tool for exploring the therapeutic mechanism of FES.

title: Volumetric ultrasound imaging with a sparse matrix array and integrated fiber-optic sensing for robust needle tracking in interventional procedures_supp1-3653277.pdf
authors: Wenfeng Xia
abstract: Objective: Accurate visualization of interventional devices, such as medical needles, in relation to the procedural target is critical for the safe and effective guidance of interventional procedures. Ultrasound (US) imaging is widely used for guiding percutaneous needle interventions, but the 2D nature of most clinical US probes limits accurate 3D localization, particularly of the needle tip. In this work, we introduce a novel system that combines both volumetric US imaging and 3D needle tracking. Method: The proposed novel system integrates a fiber-optic hydrophone (FOH) into the needle and employs a 2D sparse spiral US array with 256 active elements. Real-time volumetric US imaging was achieved by plane-wave imaging with the sparse array, while 3D needle tip tracking was enabled through communications between the US probe and the FOH. Results: The system achieved spatial resolutions (mean ± standard deviation) of 2.06 ± 0.29mm (lateral), 2.26 ± 0.23mm (elevational), and 0.69 ± 0.12mm (axial) at depths ranging from 10 to 40mm. The tracking accuracy was better than 0.30 ± 0.21mm. The clinical potential of the system was demonstrated using a nerve block training phantom. Conclusions: This study presents a proof-of-concept for an integrated solution that enables simultaneous volumetric anatomical imaging and precise 3D needle tip tracking. Significance: The proposed system holds strong potential to enhance the efficacy and safety of image-guided interventional procedures by providing real-time 3D anatomical visualization and accurate needle tracking.

title: Scilab-Based Online Simulation Engine for Online Virtual Laboratory
authors: Jakub Matišák, Adrián Vrbovský, Katarína Žáková
abstract: This paper presents a Scilab-based simulation engine, originally designed for virtual laboratories. The platform integrates Scilab Xcos with a web-based interface, providing users with a flexible tool for simulations. Using the developed API, the system allows interaction with simulation models and parameter adjustments directly in Scilab Xcos. The application also allows both graphical and data visualization of experiment results. The proposed solution contributes to the field of online education by offering a cost-effective and scalable approach to practical training in automation and control. Experimental validation with various mechatronic systems, including a reaction wheel pendulum, demonstrates the system's applicability for academic and research purposes.

title: Adaptive Continual Learning for Online Visual Object Tracking via Dynamic Grassmannian Appearance Modelling
authors: Jinglin Zhou, Tianyang Xu, Xuefeng Zhu, Xiao-Jun Wu, Josef Kittler
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Online visual object tracking fundamentally constitutes a continual learning challenge, demanding persistent adaptation to target variations within dynamic video streams, while preserving critical features to prevent forgetting. Existing template-based trackers are particularly vulnerable to severe target deformation and drastic background changes in real-world scenarios. Recent explorations enhance adaptability through local update strategies—such as dynamic templates, appearance tokens, and parameter fine-tuning—to address rapid appearance variations. However, these methods inherently propagate target appearance changes without explicit modelling and prioritise short-term adaptation over long-term global representation. Consequently, they fail to balance initial target features with current observations, leading to tracking failure in long-term scenarios. To overcome these limitations, we propose DG-Track, an adaptive continual learning framework leveraging Grassmannian manifold geometry. Specifically, we represent target appearance within a Grassmannian affine subspace and perform continual adaptation via incremental learning. Compared to Euclidean geometry, the Grassmannian manifold captures nonlinear appearance representations, yielding more compact and geometrically consistent temporal dynamics modelling. Furthermore, an adaptive forgetting module dynamically regulates the interplay between the current observed subspace and the initial template, ensuring stable long-term tracking. DG-Track is a plug-and-play solution for online tracking, adding no learnable parameters. Comprehensive experiments with diverse baseline trackers on LaSOT, GOT-10k, TrackingNet, and UAV123 validate the efficacy of our continual learning framework and Grassmannian manifold geometry in enhancing visual object tracking performance. Code is available at https://github.com/xiaoqing0825/DGTrack.

title: An Algorithm for Shallow Water Low-Frequency Acoustic Channel Estimation Based on TimeFrequency Analysis
authors: Shuang Xiao, Yaqi Zhang, Bin Liu, Tiantian Liu, Hanbo Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The shallow water low-frequency acoustic channel is characterized by evident inter-modal and intra-modal frequency dispersion, which seriously affect the accuracy of conventional channel estimation methods. To address this challenge, a channel estimation algorithm based on timefrequency (TF) analysis is proposed. The algorithm utilizes time warping technique to transform the complex global channel into a linear combination of multiple single-modal channels, and effectively reduce the impact of channel extension length and multipath effects on estimation accuracy through mode decomposition. On this basis, the separated single-modal channels are estimated independently. After the estimation is completed, the reconstruction is performed to obtain accurate estimation of the global channel. The validity of the proposed algorithm is substantiated by simulation results. Compared with the conventional method, the normalized mean square error (NMSE) of channel estimation is greatly reduced. Furthermore, the equalizer based on the proposed algorithm attains a lower bit error rate (BER) in the context of shallow water low-frequency communication system.

title: Indoor-Outdoor Scene Classification: A Novel Depth Framework Using Markov Segmentation and ResNet
authors: Muhammad Waqas Ahmed, Ahmad Jalal
abstract: Accurate scene classification in cluttered and low-light environments remains a persistent challenge in computer vision. This paper introduces a novel depth-based framework that leverages structural and geometric cues for robust scene understanding, without depending on RGB data. The key innovation lies in the integration of multi-source depth features surface normals, gradient magnitude, and geometric curvature optimized using Kernel Discriminant Analysis, and classified through a modified ResNet-18 architecture. Unlike existing models that rely on raw image input or direct RGB-D fusion, our approach emphasizes refined region-level features derived from enhanced depth segmentation. Experimental evaluations on the Scene 15 and SUN RGB-D datasets yield mean classification accuracies of 91.97% and 91.5%, respectively. These results validate the model's generalization capability and effectiveness, outperforming several existing methods in challenging indoor and outdoor scenarios.

title: UAV-RIS Backscatter IoT Networks: System Models and Performance Analysis
authors: Sonia Zappia, Ivan Iudice, Domenico Pascarella, Angela Vozella
abstract: Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RIS) integrated with Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) have emerged as a promising technology in the evolution of next-generation wireless communication systems. Herein, the potential of RIS-assisted UAV architectures are discussed, focusing particularly on their role in supporting Backscatter Communication (BackCom)— a low-power paradigm suitable for passive IoT devices — which remains little explored. To fill this gap, two representative paradigms are introduced: (i) UAV-empowered RIS-enabled BackCom and (ii) UAV-assisted RIS-enabled BackCom. These use cases are analyzed through a structured framework based on Concepts of Operation (ConOps), mission-level attributes, and Key Performance Indicators (KPIs), offering a comprehensive assessment of their performance, scalability, and deployment feasibility. In addition, a theoretical throughput-oriented performance analysis is developed, deriving closed-form rate (R) and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) scaling laws as a function of the number of RIS elements and UAV transmit power. The analytical results highlight the quadratic SNR scaling behavior under ideal conditions and clarify the fundamental trade-offs between RIS aperture size and power beacon requirements. The findings demonstrate that UAV–RIS–BackCom architectures can achieve scalable, low-power, and rapidly deployable connectivity in infrastructure-limited environments, while also revealing practical limitations related to hardware impairments, control overhead, and channel dynamics. This work provides a unified conceptual and analytical framework to guide the design of sustainable, adaptive, and high-efficiency wireless systems toward practical 6G implementations.

title: Adaptive Rank Allocation for Federated Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning of Language Models
authors: Fei Wu, Jia Hu, Geyong Min, Shiqiang Wang
abstract: Pre-trained Language Models (PLMs) have demonstrated their superiority and versatility in modern Natural Language Processing (NLP), effectively adapting to various downstream tasks through further fine-tuning. Federated Parameter-Efficient Fine-Tuning (FedPEFT) has emerged as a promising solution to address privacy and efficiency challenges in distributed training for PLMs on resource-constrained local devices. However, our measurements reveal two key limitations of FedPEFT: heterogeneous data across devices exacerbates performance degradation of low-rank adaptation, and a fixed parameter configuration results in communication inefficiency. To overcome these limitations, we propose FedARA, a novel Adaptive Rank Allocation framework for federated parameter-efficient fine-tuning of language models. Specifically, FedARA employs truncated Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) adaptation to enhance similar feature representation across clients, significantly mitigating the adverse effects of data heterogeneity. Subsequently, it utilizes dynamic rank allocation to progressively identify critical ranks, effectively improving communication efficiency. Lastly, it leverages rank-based module pruning to automatically remove inactive modules, steadily reducing local computational cost and memory usage in each federated learning round. Extensive experiments show that FedARA consistently outperforms baselines by an average of 6.95% to 8.49% across various datasets and models under heterogeneous data while significantly improving communication efficiency by 2.40×. Moreover, experiments on various edge devices demonstrate substantial decreases in total training time and energy consumption by up to 48.90% and 46.95%, respectively.

title: LEUT-Net: Underwater Image Low-light Enhancement Method Based on U-shape Transformer
authors: Xiyuan Zhang, Kaiqi Zhao, Zhengqin Zhang, Chunting Li, Qingshi Han, Yan Xiang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Underwater image enhancement faces significant challenges due to light attenuation, scattering, and low-light conditions. To address these issues, we propose a novel method named LEUT-Net, integrating a U-shape Transformer architecture with an advanced low-light enhancement module and a hybrid attention mechanism. To preserve details across both shallow and deep-water regions, we introduce the depth-aware enhancement, which guide the enhancement process through water depth estimation. Furthermore, with the goal of capturing long-range dependencies and address non-uniform degradation, the framework incorporates an improved channel-spatial hybrid attention mechanism, including a Multi-scale Feature Fusion Transformer (CMSFFT) for dynamic feature weighting and a Global Feature Modeling Transformer (SGFMT) for spatial attention. The results of experiments demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art techniques on multiple metrics, including Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity (SSIM), and Underwater Image Quality Measure (UIQM). Notably, it achieves a 1.21 dB higher PSNR than FUnIE-GAN and a $10 \times$ faster inference speed than WaterNet. Code implementation validates the efficacy of the core modules, particularly in depth-guided enhancement and color reproduction. This work bridges the gap between model-driven and learning-driven approaches, offering an efficient and reliable solution for practical underwater vision applications.

title: The Degree of Awareness of Engineering, Science and Mathematics Teachers of The Importance of Using Internet of Things Technology In The Educational Process
authors: Hamzeh Abdelfattah Awad Alassaf, Fadi B Ahmad, Haitham Qawaqneh
abstract: The study aimed to identify the degree of awareness of engineering, science and mathematics teachers of the importance of using the Internet of Things technology in the educational process. The study was conducted during the second semester of the year.2024-2025, and to achieve the objectives of the study, the descriptive survey approach was adopted, and a questionnaire tool was prepared to measure the level of students’ awareness, consisting of (27) paragraphs, distributed over four axes, which are (awareness of Internet of Things security applications. Awareness of the nature of Internet of Things security, ways to enhance awareness of Internet of Things security), and after verifying its validity and reliability, it was applied to the study sample consisting of (113) A male and female teacher from public and private schools in the capital, Amman, who were selected randomly. Among the most prominent results reached by the study: The degree of awareness of engineering, science and mathematics teachers of the importance of using the Internet of Things technology in the educational process was high, and the results showed that there were no statistically significant differences in the degree of teachers’ awareness attributed to the school classification variable.

title: Inference-Time Rule Eraser: Fair Recognition via Distilling and Removing Biased Rules
authors: Yi Zhang, Dongyuan Lu, Jitao Sang
abstract: Machine learning models often make predictions based on biased features such as gender, race, and other social attributes, posing significant fairness risks, especially in societal applications, such as hiring, banking, and criminal justice. Traditional approaches to addressing this issue involve retraining or fine-tuning neural networks with fairness-aware optimization objectives. However, these methods can be impractical due to significant computational resources, complex industrial tests, and the associated CO2 footprint. Additionally, regular users often fail to fine-tune models because they lack access to model parameters. In this paper, we introduce the Inference-Time Rule Eraser (Eraser), a novel method designed to address fairness concerns by removing biased decision-making rules from deployed models during inference without altering model weights. We begin by establishing a theoretical foundation for modifying model outputs to eliminate biased rules through Bayesian analysis. Next, we present a specific implementation of Eraser that involves two stages: (1) distilling the biased rules from the deployed model into an additional patch model, and (2) removing these biased rules from the output of the deployed model during inference. Extensive experiments validate the effectiveness of our approach, showcasing its superior performance in addressing fairness concerns in AI systems.

title: Evaluating Machine Learning Models for Wildfire Prediction Across Different Geographic Regions
authors: José Silva, Jacinto Estima, Alberto Cardoso
abstract: Wildfires pose significant environmental, social, and economic challenges, making their accurate prediction crucial for risk management. While several studies have explored wildfire forecasting using machine learning, most of them focus on individual models without systematically comparing different training strategies. This study evaluates the performance of four machine learning models: Random Forest, XGBoost, LSTM, and BiLSTM, to determine which model is best suited for wildfire pre-diction. Unlike previous works, this research analyzes how model performance varies across different geographic regions, using four distinct districts in Portugal as test locations. The models are trained and tested under multiple dataset configurations to assess their generalization capability and adaptability to unseen wildfire occurrences. Results indicate that deep learning models (LSTM and BiLSTM) achieve a more consistent performance across regions, particularly in southern Portugal, where wildfires are harder to predict. Additionally, results also show that using region-specific data improves performance for certain areas, highlighting the importance of more localized training strategies.

title: Bangalore, Czechoslovakia, and Madras Chapters Receive the 2025 Chapter of the Year Award! [Society News]
