title: Investigation of Machine Learning Models for Multi-Class Detection and Classification of DDoS Attack
authors: Nasir Musa Imam, Muquaddar Ali, Abhinav Bhatnagar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Online services face a danger from DDoS attacks. The usual methods now detect only whether an attack is happening, not what kind of attack it is. Due to this barrier, special protection strategies cannot be implemented. To deal with this, this research applies a complete approach by contrasting ML models for detecting and classifying multi-class DDoS attacks. By utilizing the CICDDoS2019 dataset, we cleaned, down-sampled, normalized and reduced dimensionality using Principal Component Analysis (PCA). The PCA reduced the number of features from 86 to 30 which helps reduce the training complexity. Seven different ML models are investigated and analyzed with accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. The widely used dataset CICDDoS2019 was applied for training and testing of these models. The investigation suggests XGBoost and Random Forest based classifiers outperform the other models, providing a better overview of DDoS threats since they each have an accuracy rate of 98.92 % and 98.83%.

title: Pointwise Reliability Assessment
authors: Cláudio Correia, Simão Paredes, Jorge Henriques, Teresa Rocha, Lino Gonçalves
abstract: In critical areas with significant user impact, the effective application of machine learning models to support decision making faces the important challenge of lack of trust. Despite their impressive performance, machine learning models are often perceived as “black boxes,“ making their adoption difficult. This is the case of health care area, where the lack of trust is undoubtedly a barrier to the application of those models in daily clinical practice. While metrics like accuracy, sensitivity, specificity are valuable to assess the global performance of a model, they provide little insight at the individual instance level (single patient). This highlights the importance of pointwise reliability assessment, evaluating whether a model can be reliable to classify a specific instance. This work aims to develop a systematic method for comparing a machine learning model pointwise reliability provided by different methods. Besides error rate quantification, this framework comprises t-Distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding visualizations. Thus, different data driven methods for assessing pointwise reliability are compared. These methods address the problem based on two different perspectives: i) density principle; ii) local fit principle. The validation was performed in the context of cardiovascular secondary prevention supported by a real patient dataset (N=1544). The findings show that approaches integrating both density and local fit principles tend to surpass single principle methods, associating lower error rates to more reliable predictions.

title: Design and Research of Online Self-Calibration System for Piezoelectric Vibration Sensors
authors: Yang Li, Yujie Wang, Yongping Zheng, Leipeng Song, Xiaozhou Xu, Xinjian Xiang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: For vibration sensors in wind tunnels, long-term online operation is required. Regular removal for calibration is impractical. This paper presents an online piezoelectric selfcalibration system. The system integrates actuation through the inverse piezoelectric effect and sensing via the direct piezoelectric effect, thereby enabling in-situ excitation with simultaneous signal acquisition. Based on the massspring dynamic model, the analytical expressions of the stiffness and charge sensitivity of the system are derived. Sensitivity is enhanced through structural dimension design, material selection, and interior-point method optimization. COMSOL static and dynamic simulations demonstrate that the optimized charge sensitivity increases by an order of magnitude, remaining stable between 10 Hz and 1 kHz with errors below 5 %. The system provides an in-situ calibration method for all application scenarios that require online operation and stable medium-frequency performance, such as wind tunnel monitoring and industrial fault warning.

title: High-Accuracy Plant Disease Detection: A ResNet18 Transfer Learning Approach for Multi-Class Classification
authors: Serik Sailau, Muhammad Zaid Mohsin, Raja Hashim Ali, Umme Rabab Syed
abstract: Plant diseases threaten global food security and agricultural productivity, particularly in regions heavily dependent on farming. Early and accurate disease detection is essential for minimizing crop loss, improving yields, and supporting sustainable agriculture. This study presents a deep learning-based framework for automated plant disease detection using transfer learning with the ResNet18 architecture. A subset of the publicly available PlantVillage dataset comprising <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{2, 0 0 0}$</tex> leaf images across 16 classes (healthy and diseased) was used for experimentation. Images were preprocessed, resized to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$128 \times 128$</tex> pixels, normalized, and split into training, validation, and test sets. The pretrained ResNet18 model, fine-tuned for this task, was trained using the Adam optimizer and cross-entropy loss. Experimental results demonstrated a test accuracy of 98.67 % and a weighted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$F 1$</tex>-score of 0.9867, outperforming several prior benchmarks. Confusion matrix analysis showed strong generalization across diverse disease categories, with only minor misclassifications among visually similar leaf conditions such as early blight and bacterial spot. Visualizations of correct and incorrect predictions further confirmed the model's robustness. These findings highlight the effectiveness of transfer learning in agriculture and suggest that lightweight CNN-based solutions like ResNet18 can enable scalable, accurate, and practical plant disease detection tools for real-world deployment.

title: SAR-PMAE: Phase Modulation-Guided Adversarial Example Generation for SAR Images
authors: Jiahao Cui, Wang Guo, Qi Wang, Keyi Zhang, Lingquan Meng, Haifeng Li
abstract: The presence of adversarial examples can cause SAR image classification systems to produce incorrect predictions, severely compromising their accuracy and robustness. However, existing adversarial example generation methods for SAR images often suffer from limited physical interpretability, low perturbation energy utilization, and insufficient perturbation stealthiness. To address the above issues, this paper proposes SAR-PMAE, a phase modulation-guided adversarial example generation method for SAR images. Specifically, to tackle the lack of physical interpretability, a phase modulation strategy based on the point target scattering model is employed, coupling adversarial perturbations with the EM scattering mechanism to enhance their physical interpretability; to improve perturbation energy utilization, a local focusing strategy is adopted, in which foreground targets are precisely segmented and centered via a watershed algorithm combined with morphological operations, concentrating perturbations in strong response regions and avoiding redundant energy dispersion into background clutter; and to enhance perturbation stealthiness, constraints are applied separately to the phase in the complex coherent domain, thereby maximally preserving SAR speckle statistics and improving perturbation concealment. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves an average untargeted attack success rate of 55.53% and a targeted attack success rate of 20.92% across ten classifiers based on CNN and Transformer architectures, while exhibiting strong attack transferability. The complete implementation is publicly available at https://github.com/muzhengcui/SAR-PMAE.

title: False Alarm Reduction in Broadband Active Sonar Based on Multidimensional Features
authors: JiaZuo Qing, GaoFeng Cheng, Ji Xu, YongHong Yan
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Broadband active sonar detection, while effective for marine exploration, faces critical false alarms from seabed echoes and clutter. This study proposes a multidimensional feature fusion framework to suppress false alarms. Key innovations include:(i) target scattering analysis exploiting differences between target and seabed echoes;(ii) target strength inversion using acoustic propagation loss and echo energy;(iii) time-frequency total variation characterizing frequency modulation.These features are integrated with Doppler features fed into a cost-sensitive support vector machine classifier. Lake trials demonstrated an $89 \%$ false alarm reduction versus conventional constant false alarm rate detection.

title: An OAMP Based Signal Detection Algorithm for MIMO-AFDM Communications
authors: Yuchen Zhang, Shan Luo, Lifan Wu, Zongyi Wu, Rongping Lin, Hui Li, Haiyan Jin
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM) shows excellent performance in environments with significant delay spreads and high Doppler shifts, while keeping pilot overhead low. While AFDM has been widely studied in the single-input single-output (SISO) form, extending it to multipleinput multiple-output (MIMO) systems presents new challenges for signal detection. In this paper, we apply the orthogonal approximate message passing (OAMP) algorithm to MIMOAFDM systems and further reduce its computational complexity by taking advantage of the sparsity in the AFDM channel matrix. Specifically, a preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) method is used to accelerate matrix inversion in the linear estimation stage. Simulation results show that the PCG-OAMP detector provides better bit error rate (BER) performance compared to traditional detection methods in doubly selective channels.

title: End-to-End DNN-based Joint Combining Matrix Optimisation and Channel Estimation in Near-Field Large-Scale THz Communications
authors: Yanyan Ge, Li Zhang, Kevin Morris, You You
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) communication has emerged as a critical technology for next-generation wireless communication systems due to its exceptionally wide bandwidths and ultrahigh data rates. However, channel estimation in THz bands faces severe challenges, especially in near-field regions where planarwave assumptions break down. Conventional compressive sensing (CS) and machine learning (ML) based channel estimation methods often struggle with near-field intricacies and large-scale antenna arrays, necessitating novel estimation techniques. Motivated by the success of autoencoder-based channel estimation approaches in end-to-end system design, this work proposes a novel deep neural network (DNN)-based THz channel estimation technique tailored for near-field THz communication systems with a large-scale Widely-Spaced Multi-Subarray (WSMS) architecture. By exploiting near-field properties and leveraging the spatial diversity provided by WSMS and large-scale arrays, the proposed framework achieved a $\mathbf{6 ~ d B}$ improvement in normalised mean square error (NMSE). Simulation results confirm that this technique outperforms state-of-the-art channel estimation schemes, thus paving the way for more efficient and accurate near-field THz channel estimation in future wireless communication systems.

title: A vehicle lateral stability criterion fusing phase plane and RBF neural network
authors: Dequan Zeng, Lixiong Rao, Yiming Hu, Peizhi Zhang, Lu Xiong, Jun Lu, Giuseppe Carbone, Yinquan Yu
abstract: Precise stability criteria are essential for vehicle handling control, but conventional methods based on tire adhesion limits or linear models often lack robustness across diverse scenarios. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel lateral stability criterion fusing phase plane analysis and RBF neural networks. The approach begins with an analysis of the vehicle’s stable state using the phase plane, followed by the division of the vehicle stability region employing the diamond method to generate a phase plane stability region database. Subsequently, the proposed phase plane-RBF stability criterion is constructed by leveraging the RBF neural network for nonlinear fitting of the stability region data, which is further refined through multiple rounds of optimization. Compared to traditional tire force and linear single-track model criteria, the proposed criterion demonstrates superior accuracy in identifying extreme conditions and enhanced adaptability across operational scenarios.

title: Thermal Fault Model Validated in Mineral Oil for Dissolved Gas Analysis
authors: Matias Meira, Raúla Álvarez, Carlos Verucchi, Leonardo Catalano
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: This paper presents a thermal fault model that reliably reproduces the gases generated by hot spots in transformer insulation systems. The model, designed without paper insulation, is based on a configuration of four stacked transformer core plates that enable the controlled simulation of fault scenarios over a temperature range from 200 to 800 °C through direct thermocouple measurements. Thus, core faults such as inter-lamination short circuits caused by circulating currents, as well as mechanical issues like a loose bushing bolt, can be emulated. Experimental validation was carried out using mineral oil, a liquid with well-established behavior and extensive field experience, ensuring that the model generates fault conditions consistent with real operational environments. A case study with a soybean-based natural ester further demonstrates the model’s adaptability to alternative insulating liquids. The proposed model offers a robust, scalable platform for advancing transformer fault diagnosis and supports the development of improved diagnostic techniques in the field of Dissolved Gas Analysis (DGA).

title: Intelligent Crop Recommendation Using IoT Sensors and Machine Learning Techniques
authors: Suruchi Naik, Shatarupa Dash, Ishan Ayus
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: India is an agricultural dominated country where agriculture contribute major source of income and livelihood for people. Agriculture contributes major factor to the India’s Gross Domestic Product (GDP). However, the crop yields per hectares is very less if we compare it to international standard. It can be due to various reason as India is also a country which suffer natural calamities and flood every year which affect the crop production which indirectly or directly leads a huge loss for farmers which leads to increase suicide case of most of the farmers in India. So, deciding the correct crop in correct time with a correct amount of fertilizer can help the farmers to come out of difficulties. If farmer can predict the crop in advance, then it will be easy and beneficial to farmer. Government can also take proper planning and action if they can know the crop yield in advance. Government has various types of data available in terms of soil type, rainfall, natural calamities predictions which can be used to decide a proper recommendation system which can help the farmer to decide which crop will be beneficial for him based on the various deciding criteria like soil colour, pH, Nitrogen, Phosphorous, Potassium etc. For collecting the real-time data related to soil like composition of soil, humidity content of soil, temperature of the soil and nutrient available in the soil, system can utilize various sensors like FC-28 sensor, DHT11 sensor and JXBS-3001 sensor [6]. Along with the real time data from the field, system can also use data available on government like rainfall, calamities prediction to predict the best suitable crop for that soil condition This research paper summarizes the results obtained by various machine learning algorithm which are most commonly used method to predict the crop with their accuracy and suggested the best recommendation system.

title: Deep Learning Architectures for Multimodal Sentiment Analysis
authors: Rishav Jha, Mohit Ranjan Panda, Shubham K C, Aaditya Dahal
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: In recent years, multimodal sentiment analysis has become a popular domain of research due to the rise of deep learning architectures designed to handle multiple feeding modalities such as text and images. This work delves into sentiment analysis utilizing images and text, extracted with Optical Character Recognition (OCR) from the Memotion dataset. We evaluate the performance of four different model architectures: DEIT+SBERT, DistillBERT+ResNet, RoBERTa+ResNet, and BiLSTM+ResNet. In our study, we assess these models using accuracy, F1-score, precision, and recall. According to the results of experiments, DistillBERT+ResNet achieves the best performance of 78.83% accuracy relative to others. We draw on this paper to outline how we approached our methodologies, data preprocessing steps, and comparison of model performances

title: Real-Time Detection and Mitigation of GPS Spoofing in UAV Systems
authors: Rajanbir Singh Tucker, Muhammad Nadeem, Shahbaz Pervez
abstract: With the increasing use of drones for commercial, industrial, and military applications, global positioning system (GPS)-based navigation is the most critical tool for positioning accuracy and autonomous decision-making. GPS spoofing attacks, however, are a realistic threat with the potential to mislead drones in estimating incorrect positions, thus inducing navigation failures, illegal landings, and security intrusions. This study experimented with the vulnerability of drones to GPS spoofing attacks and examined various mitigation and detection strategies. A laboratory-controlled setup with hardware equipment, such as GPS receivers, software radio (SDRs), and machine learning techniques, was used for anomaly detection. The Drone Flight Path Controller interface was used for the real-time observation and evasion of GPS spoofing attacks. The resultant system accurately identified spoofed signals with 97% detection performance and initiated a return-to-home (RTH) mode with an average of 2.3 seconds of detection latency. The outcomes emphasize the need to integrate high-level security solutions to protect drones against GPS-based cyberattacks, along with enabling safe and reliable autonomous operation.

title: Edge-Enabled UAV Swarm Deployment for Rapid Post-Disaster Search and Rescue
authors: Alaa Awad Abdellatif, Helder Fontes, Andre Coelho, Luis M. Pessoa, Rui Campos
abstract: This paper presents an optimized framework for Post-Disaster Search and Rescue (PDSR) that leverages multiple Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) equipped with integrated radar and communication capabilities to simultaneously address sensing and connectivity requirements. The proposed solution includes a scalable system architecture and an optimization strategy that enable the rapid deployment of UAV swarms with diverse sensing, communication, and edgeenabled coordination features, ensuring enhanced performance in real-world disaster environments. The proposed approach formulates and solves a 3D UAV positioning and power allocation problem to maximize sensing performance and communication efficiency over multiple targets in designated zones. Due to the NP-hard and combinatorial nature of the problem, we propose a Distributed Joint Radar-Communication (DJRC) solution. This solution employs an efficient reward for potential actions and consistently selects the best action that maximizes the reward while ensuring both communications and sensing performance. Simulation results demonstrate significant performance improvements of the proposed solution over state-of-the-art radar-or communication-centric methods, with polynomial complexity dependent on the number of UAVs and linear dependence on the iteration count.

title: Resonant Pressure Sensor with On-Chip Integrated Diode for Rapid Temperature Change in Aerospace
authors: Qingtao Mu, Jianbing Xie, Xiaofeng Chen, Yulu Han
abstract: Resonant Pressure Sensors (RPS) are key for high-precision MEMS pressure measurement, but traditional Off-Chip Temperature Sensors (OFTS) suffer heat conduction lag under rapid temperature change, limiting accuracy in aircraft rapid maneuvering. To address this bottleneck, this study proposes a novel RPS scheme integrating resonant and diode temperature-sensitive structures. By combining an On-Chip Integrated Temperature Sensor (OCITS) and a frequency-temperature dual-parameter 4th-order polynomial compensation algorithm, high-precision pressure measurement under rapid temperature change is achieved. A COMSOL multi-physics model compares OCITS and OFTS responses at 0.1 to 10 °C/min: at 1 °C/min, OCITS exhibits ≤50 ms delay (vs. 946 s for OFTS) with ≤0.3 °C tracking error; at 10 °C/min, OCITS maintains synchronization while OFTS loses validity (error >62.4 °C). Prototypes were fabricated via the DRIE bulk silicon process and tested under dynamic temperature-pressure conditions. Experiments show: OCITS achieves synchronous response at 10 °C/min， within −55 °C to 100 °C and 3.5 kPa to 285 kPa, comprehensive accuracy reaches 0.0038% full scale (FS) which is 3.68 times higher than that of OFTS (0.014% FS). This work addresses the pressure measurement bottleneck of aircraft during rapid maneuvering, providing a reliable solution for high-precision MEMS sensors in aerospace.

title: Masthead
authors: N/A

title: Demand Characterization and Forecasting for Cost-Effective Mobile Network Planning
authors: Caner Kilinc, Mahesh K. Marina, Gokhan Kalem, Fatih Cogen
abstract: We consider mobile network demand characterization and forecasting from the perspective of enabling costeffective mobile network planning. This is however, challenging because of market and service usage dynamics and unanticipated events like COVID-19. To this end, in collaboration with a prominent national-scale mobile network operator, we conduct, for the first time, a demand characterization and forecasting study that is based on multi-year and nationwide region-level mobile network traffic data. Specifically, we analyze the demand characterization of mobile and fixed wireless access (FWA) services at national and regional scales. Crucially, we introduce a clustering-driven methodology for national and regional mobile network demand forecasting at a yearly timescale. Our results highlight the significant diversity in region-level traffic characterization as well as differences between mobile and FWA services. Differently from prior work studying the effect of COVID-19 on mobile network traffic, we do not find any observable effect due to COVID-19 on region-scale traffic characterization. Our proposed clustering-driven methodology, besides being scalable, is shown to yield significant gains in accuracy around an order of magnitude relative to the baseline approach for both mobile and FWA service demand forecasting.

title: Using LSTM Machine Learning Models to Foretell Stock Market Prices
authors: Abdulaziz Alghamdi, Abdulaziz Alshaibani, Ahmad Alfaqehi, Hossam Meshref
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Accurate stock market predictions are essential for informed financial decisions, especially amid rising market fluctuations. This research explores the capabilities of deep learning models to enhance prediction accuracy and reliability. Traditional statistical and machine learning techniques often struggle with the nonlinear, complex dynamics of financial markets. In contrast, deep learning models, particularly Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks, demonstrate superior performance in identifying intricate patterns. This study employs LSTM, a type of Recurrent Neural Network (RNN), to analyze Apple Inc. (AAPL) 5 years' stock data at Kaggle. The model, trained on historical prices, achieved an accuracy of 97.72%, outperforming many existing approaches. These findings underscore the potential of LSTM networks for financial forecasting and support the development of more robust predictive systems for strategic investment and risk management.

title: Neuro-Physics Hybrid State Estimation of Distribution System with Smart Meter Voltage Measurements
authors: Wentao Zhang, Yuzhang Lin, Md. Zahidul Islam, Heqing Huang
abstract: The lack of measurements poses a significant challenge for the medium-voltage distribution system state estimation (MV-DSSE). The proliferation of smart meters can alleviate this issue by providing abundant measurements at customer-end points in low-voltage (LV) networks; however, their voltage measurements cannot be directly incorporated into the MV-DSSE. This paper proposes a novel neuro-physics hybrid SE model for MV networks, incorporating smart meter voltage measurements from LV networks into MV-DSSE. In our approach, the physical SE model is adopted for the MV network, while a neural network (NN)-based model is trained to represent the relationship between the MV state variables and the LV network voltage measurements. The hybrid SE model does not require the LV network model, which is often unavailable to utility operators. The test results demonstrate that the proposed model enhances the accuracy and robustness of MV-DSSE by incorporating smart meter voltage measurements in LV networks.

title: Compressive Sensing with Dynamic Grid for Spectrum Map Reconstruction
authors: Xiangrui Huang, Yechao Bai
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In low-altitude scene with limited spectrum resources, reconstructing spectrum map contributes to enhancing spectrum utilization efficiency and ensuring aviation safety. The UAV equipped with RF devices is able to explore more spatial spectrum opportunities, benefiting from its high mobility. In this paper, Bayesian compressive sensing is attempted to spectrum map reconstruction leveraging the spatial sparsity of signal sources, and parameters of signal sources is recovered combined with the path loss model of signal propagation. Then we propose a dynamic grid optimization algorithm to address the grid mismatch problem between actual parameters and predefined discrete grid, which significantly improves reconstruction accuracy compared with compressive sensing with fixed grid. The simulation results show that the proposed method can effectively realize the parameters recovery of unknown signal sources, and it can be applied to spectrum map reconstruction.

title: Preliminary Study for Autonomous Evolutionary Multitasking Method Design
authors: Yuxiao Huang, Xuebin Lv, Liang Feng, Kay Chen Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Evolutionary Multi-task Optimization (EMTO) enhances optimization performance by sharing knowledge across optimization tasks. While existing knowledge transfer methods can improve optimization performance, they often require significant domain expertise that consume huge expert resources. To handle this problem, we introduce a preliminary LLM-assisted framework that autonomously designs knowledge transfer methods for EMTO without human intervention. Empirical studies on WCCI competition benchmarks demonstrate that the knowledge transfer methods designed by our proposed framework can achieve superior performance against existing hand-crafted knowledge transfer approaches.

title: Study on Bearing Estimation Performance of HLA under Mixed Layer Effect
authors: Xinming Guan, Qiulong Yang, Yukun Zhang, Yucheng Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Under the influence of factors such as seasons, a mixed layer with a positive sound speed gradient will be formed near the sea surface of the deep ocean. In presence of this mixed layer, a surface duct is capable of achieving long-distance propagation of acoustic signal. In the surface duct, sound rays with small elevation angles can transmit over a longer distance with lower transmission loss than the bottom reflected rays. Bearing estimation error of the horizontal linear array will be generated when the incident acoustic signal has a steep elevation angle. Signal with small elevation angle can effectively reduce such error. When there is no mixed layer, as soon as the target enters the bottom reflected zone, the bearing estimation error increases rapidly. Moreover, the error will significantly increase as the target bearing becomes larger, seriously affecting the bearing estimation. However, when both the target and the array are located within the mixed layer, bearing estimation results will not significantly deviate from the true bearing when propagation range gets larger. Thus, the existence of the mixed layer can provide accurate and stable bearing estimation results within the bottom reflected zone.

title: Learning-Enhanced Predefined-Time Adaptive Optimal Control for Quadrotors with Disturbance
authors: Wei Yang, Yumei Ma, Qing-Guo Wang, Jinpeng Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper presents a learning-enhanced predefined-time adaptive optimal control strategy for a quadrotor unmanned aerial vehicle subject to disturbances. First, a predefined-time disturbance observer with a tunable convergence time bound is developed to ensure rapid and accurate estimation. Within a command filtered backstepping architecture, actor-critic neural networks are incorporated to achieve adaptive optimal control with learning capability for both position and attitude subsystems. Specifically, novel learning laws facilitate the rapid online updating of network weights, where the critic network approximates the value function while the actor network optimizes the control policy to minimize control cost. The proposed framework effectively compensates for disturbances and filtered error effects, ensuring that all tracking errors converge within a predefined time. Rigorous analysis establishes the predefined-time stability of the closed-loop system. Finally, comparative simulation results are provided to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed strategy.

title: A Smart Packaging Solution Based on the BLE-PAWR Protocol
authors: Rúben R. P. Susano, Telmo R C. C. Fernandes, Paulo J. C. Ventura, Sérgio M. M. Faria, Filipe S. Perdigoto, Nelson Figueiredo, Nuno M. M. Rodrigues
abstract: This paper describes a demonstration of an electronic-based Smart Packaging solution to monitor package shipping in a supply chain. The system effectively traces temperature, humidity, atmospheric pressure, impacts, and location of packages in transit. The architecture comprises two main components: Package Tags and Gateways. Package Tags are compact, energy-efficient units inserted into each package to collect environmental data during transportation. Gateways are strategically deployed in logistics centers and transportation vehicles, including trucks and vans for inland delivery, and containers for overseas distribution, to aggregate package information. The communication between Package Tags and Gateways is carried out using a modified version of the Periodic Advertising with Response (PAwR) feature of the Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) protocol, which is an innovative use of this technology, that was originally designed for static applications, like price tags in supermarkets. The demo includes information on the design and development, including hardware and firmware, as well as a practical demonstration of the system and its performance in operational real-word tests.

title: Design Development and Analysis of Frequency Reconfigurable Antenna for C-band Applications
authors: Teena Raikwar, Jitendra Ahir, Laxmi Singh
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper presents a reconfigurable microstrip antenna designed for C-band applications, covering a broad operational frequency range from (4 to 8) GHz. The proposed design incorporates three symmetrically placed p-i-n diodes along the non-radiating edges, enabling frequency reconfiguration across five distinct states. The antenna exhibits strong resonance characteristics, with measured operational frequencies spanning 5.4 GHz to 6.4 GHz. Notably, it achieves a peak gain of 3 dBi and a radiation efficiency of 94%, ensuring reliable performance for dynamic frequency sensing in C-band communication systems. The compact structure features a single-layer substrate, a simple DC bias circuit, and stable unidirectional radiation patterns, making it well-suited for wireless applications requiring miniaturization without compromising performance. Both simulated and measured results demonstrate excellent agreement, validating the design's effectiveness.

title: Topology-Cognizant Machine Learning for Multi-Parameter Estimation and Digital Twin of LLC Resonant Converters
authors: Yangxiao Xiang, Weiting Yuan, Xiong Du, Zhuojun Xie, Yunzhi Chen, Hongjian Lin, Chaoran Liu, Yechi Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: System parameters, particularly those within the resonant tank, fundamentally govern the converter’s dynamic behavior and operational performance of LLC resonant converters. Accurate estimation of these system parameters is essential for enabling real-time condition monitoring, high-efficiency operation, and advanced model-based control of LLC resonant converters. However, due to strong parameter coupling, high system nonlinearity, and unobservable topology transitions, performing accurate multi-parameter estimation for LLC converters remains considerably challenging, and has rarely been effectively solved in existing works. To address this issue, this study proposes a topology-cognizant machine learning (TCML), which explicitly embeds the converter’s discrete-time topology-dependent dynamics into a neural network architecture. In contrast to conventional PINN, TCML introduces a semi-supervised data reconstruction mechanism to infer system states at unobservable topological transitions, enabling consistent supervision across discontinuous dynamic regimes. This physics-guided structure compels the network to jointly satisfy observed data consistency and converter-specific physical laws, thereby achieving high-accuracy multi-parameter identification under a data sampling configuration compatible with commonly used microcontroller units (MCUs). Furthermore, the proposed method offers additional advantages, including reduced reliance on accurate parameter pre-estimation, nanosecond-scale digital twin capability, and online implementation, The effectiveness is verified through both simulations and experiments.

title: A Design of Helicopter Horizontal Profile Adaptive Flight Guidance Law
authors: Ziwei Zheng, Zhiyuan Gu, Shi Qiu, Shouzhao Sheng
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Regarding problems with a fixed preview failing to enable the flight guidance of the helicopter rapidly and accurately tracking the complex track, proposing a helicopter horizontal profile adaptive flight guidance law. Transferring the design of the guidance law from the traditional Cartesian coordinate system to the Frenet coordinate system, considering the track, lateral deviation, preview point information and other factors, the helicopter horizontal profile flight guidance law is designed. Aiming at the problem that the fixed preview distance can not adapt to the complex track, based on the tracking effect, the roll command and its change rate, using the improved particle swarm optimization-beetle antennae search optimization algorithm (IPSO-BAS) to obtain the adaptive preview distance, which improves the safety and reliability of the guidance law in the complex environment. The simulation results show that, compared with the fixed preview distance guidance law, this adaptive guidance law can obtain better prediction effect on the track steering while ensuring the tracking accuracy, having the best overall route tracking effect.

title: Sequence Impedance Model Based Harmonic Current Suppression Method for VSG Connected to the Grid
authors: Muzhuo Lv, Siran Lu, Lei Guo, Bo Zhou, Weitao Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Power Electronics
abstract: When the virtual synchronous generator (VSG) control is connected to a weak grid with background harmonics, the voltage distortion of the grid will cause a large amount of harmonics in the output current of the VSG, and may lead to system oscillation. To enhance the stability of the grid-connected system, an optimization control strategy based on the sequential impedance model of virtual synchronous generator for grid connection was proposed. By improving the control strategy, the system is able to adapt to the changes in the grid state in real time. Compared with the traditional control method, the grid-forming system’s stability margin is greatly increased by the enhanced control technique, which also raises the phase in the low frequency range. The experimental findings demonstrate that the enhanced control approach can guarantee the system’s stable functioning and prevent unstable oscillations from occurring.

title: From Disruptions to Discussions: How GenAI Impacts Human Interactions in Software Development
authors: Marie Salomon, Ekaterina Koshchenko, Agnia Sergeyuk, Reid Holmes, Gail C. Murphy, Thomas Fritz
abstract: New technologies often change how an individual performs work, such as how generative AI (GenAI) can help a developer write code. New technologies can also impact how people interact with one another, such as how GenAI’s ability to summarize API documentation can reduce the need for developers to ask each other technical questions. In this paper, we report on a two-phase mixed-method study exploring how GenAI influences how humans interact in software development. During phase one, 30 industrial software developers provided data over a period of 5 to 12 days as they worked, contributing 627 experience sampling responses and 207 end-of-workday survey responses. To gain further insight into their work, we interviewed 22 of these developers. During phase two, 131 additional professional developers responded to a survey to explore whether and how the results from phase one are seen across a larger population. Our analysis of the data found that (1) the ability of GenAI to help answer low-level technical questions in a timely way enables developers to see GenAI as a technical mentor, providing opportunities for developers to turn to tools rather than teammates; (2) developers perceive that GenAI can help them experience more focus and experience fewer flow disruptions; (3) GenAI can help developers pursue more meaningful conversations with their colleagues by shifting human interaction towards clarification, joint reasoning, and exploring alternative perspectives; and (4) in the presence of GenAI, developers report still seeking human-to-human interaction for contextual expertise, mentorship, and social connection. Together, these findings show what changes, when it changes, and what teams can do next in response to this shift in team interaction dynamics, where GenAI increasingly handles routine technical queries and human conversations center on context, reasoning, and connection. Teams can adopt norms for delegating questions, sustain human judgment in complex decisions, and create space for expertise, mentorship, and connection, alongside increasing technical self-sufficiency.

title: Energy-Efficient Transmission in STAR-RIS Assisted Secure ISAC Networks With RSMA: An MoE-RBPPO Approach
authors: Shuangyuan Ma, Ruichen Zhang, Zhangfeng Ma, Guangyuan Liu, Dusit Niyato, Bo Ai, Renmin Zhang
abstract: Simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS) represents an innovative technology with the potential to enhance global coverage in future wireless networks. This paper investigates secure down link transmission and rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) in a STAR-RIS-assisted integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system, focusing on the communication and sensing needs of future networks. We propose an optimization problem to maximize system secrecy energy efficiency (SEE) by jointly op timizing beamforming vectors, the common-stream secrecy rate for users, and the amplitude and phase of the STAR-RIS under various operational constraints. To address the challenges inherent in solving this non-convex optimization problem, primarily stemming from complex channel dynamics and the coupling of mixed variables, we introduce a novel mixture of experts rollback proximal policy optimization (MoE-RBPPO) approach. Additionally, we utilize maximum ratio transmission and zero forcing techniques for beamforming design. Simulation results indicate that the proposed MoE-RBPPO method significantly outperforms several baseline approaches in terms of SEE. For example, it achieves a SEE gain of up to 4.5% over MoE-PPO and up to 9.2% over PPO, with these gains observed under varying radar cross section values of the target. Meanwhile, the overall simulation findings further highlight the inherent advantages of STAR-RIS-enhanced ISAC systems and the benefits of RSMA over space division multiple access.

title: Facial Expression-Based Parkinson's Disease Severity Diagnosis Via Feature Fusion and Adaptive Class Balancing
authors: Yintao Zhou, Wei Huang, Zhengyu Li, Jing Huang, Meng Pang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Parkinson's disease (PD) severity diagnosis is crucial for early detecting potential patients and adopting tailored interventions. Diagnosing PD based on facial expression is grounded in PD patients' “masked face” symptom and gains growing interest recently for its convenience and affordability. However, current facial expression-based approaches often rely on single type of expression which can lead to misdiagnosis, and ignore the class imbalance across different PD stages which degrades the prediction performance. Moreover, most existing methods focus on binary classification (i.e., PD / non-PD) rather than diagnosing the severity of PD. To address these issues, we propose a new facial expression-based method for PD severity diagnosis which integrates multiple facial expression features through attention-based feature fusion. Moreover, we mitigate the class imbalance problem via an adaptive class balancing strategy which dynamically adjusts the contribution of training samples based on their class distribution and classification difficulty. Experimental results demonstrate the promising performance of the proposed method for PD severity diagnosis, as well as the efficacy of attention-based feature fusion and adaptive class balancing.

title: Spiking U-Net++: A Quantization-Adaptive Rate Encoding Based Spike Image Segmentation Framework
authors: Chenxi Zhao, Shi Gu, De Ma, Qian Zheng, Gang Pan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: This paper presents Spiking U-Net++, a novel framework for converting artificial neural networks (ANNs) to spiking neural networks (SNNs) with complex skip connections. We address three key challenges in ANN-to-SNN conversion: 1) developing computationally efficient normalization coefficient calculation through quantized statistics; 2) proposing domain-adaptive rate encoding for improved performance under distribution shifts; and 3) deriving proper normalization alignment forms for complex skip connections in U-Net++ architectures. Experimental results on medical image segmentation tasks demonstrate that our method achieves comparable performance to source ANNs while maintaining the energy efficiency advantages of SNNs. The proposed quantized statistical method reduces memory usage by several orders of magnitude compared to direct statistical approaches.

title: reconCTI: A Proactive Approach to Cyber-Threat Intelligence
authors: Mohammed Mahir Rahman, Shahzad Memon, Tauseef Ahmed, Ameer Al-Nemrat
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: The rapid advancement of information technology has introduced a noticeable shift from traditional offline practices to more efficient and interconnected online environments. This transition, while offering convenience, has also increased exposure to various cyber threats such as identity theft, impersonation, and phishing scams. Reconnaissance, or briefly known as information gathering, is a key stage for threat actors, often relying on open-source intelligence (OSINT) to collect sensitive and extensive data on targets. In response to this challenge, this study introduces reconCTI, a command-line tool built using Python for Linux systems. The tool is designed to search for sensitive data leaks across both surface web and dark web platforms. It allows users to input specific keywords, scan multiple sites at once, and then assess the findings by referencing the MITRE ATT&CK framework. The results are compiled into a threat report that also includes possible mitigation strategies. reconCTI is intended to support both cybersecurity professionals and individuals in identifying risks early and taking appropriate action.

title: Exploring Negative Differential Resistance in an Extended Source T-Shaped Channel NCTFET
authors: Jatin Jagathkar, Mukesh Kumar, Purohit Rohit Laxmankumar, Shivam Kumar, Puja Ghosh, Aminul Islam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: In this article, we have done a comprehensive study in analyzing various electric parameters of an extended source with T-shaped channel negative capacitance TFET (ES-TC-NCTFET) and have compared it to those of a standard TFET using Sentaurus TCAD tools. The proposed structure features a T-shaped channel, inspired by the design of an extended source, along with a silicon-germanium (SiGe) pocket. Furthermore, it has been observed that incorporating a Ferro layer with increasing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{t}_{\text{FE}}$</tex> enhances the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{I}_{\text{oN}}/\mathrm{I}_{\text{oFF}}$</tex> current ratio reaching 1.92 ×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup>, and improves the subthreshold swing (SS) to 10.69 mV/dec. However, this also leads to Negative Differential Resistance (NDR), which is not desirable in TFET applications. Finally, we sought to neutralize this NDR effect by virtue of drain underlap engineering. This development positions the drain-engineered ES-TC-NCTFET as a promising candidate for low-power analog circuit applications.

title: Compact Size Higher Order Wideband Low Pass Filter Based on a Suspended Substrate Stripline
authors: Ghiayas Tahir, Hidayat Ullah, Waqar Ahmad Malik, Athar Naveed, Abdul Basit, Hamza Abbas Kiani
abstract: This letter presents a post-synthesis optimization method for a DC-18 GHz low-pass filter (LPF) implemented in suspended substrate stripline (SSS) technology. The proposed approach enhances passband performance by selectively tuning only the first series stubs on both sides of the filter, thereby preserving the desired inductive characteristics. Furthermore, without increasing the footprint, the filter order is raised from 11 to 16 by embedding additional shunt resonators beneath existing ones, resulting in a significantly sharper roll-off. The fabricated prototype achieves >45 dBc suppression across 22.5 – 38 GHz, with 20 dBc attenuation at the 10% band edge, while maintaining a compact size of 20.96 mm × 7.535 mm × 1.778 mm. These results demonstrate a compact and high-performance filter, well suited for integration into RF front ends of electronic support measure (ESM) systems.

title: Analyzing the Effectiveness of Evolutionary Transfer Optimization Through Bayesian Estimation
authors: Yi Lu, Xiaoming Xue, Kai Zhang, Wu Lin, Kay Chen Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Evolutionary transfer optimization (ETO) seeks to improve the optimization performance of evolutionary algorithms through knowledge transfer (KT) across tasks. Although various KT mechanisms have been developed in the literature, a unified analysis of their effectiveness is still lacking, leaving researchers without a systematic framework to guide the design of ETO algorithms. To fill this gap, we propose modeling KT mechanisms as distinct functions with unknown parameters, offering a coherent view to accommodate our limited understanding of ideal KT processes. This transforms the design of any KT mechanism into a mathematical task of parameter estimation, enabling its effectiveness to be evaluated through Bayesian estimation. Consequently, the success of KT, like accurate parameter estimation, depends on either strong prior understanding or a wealth of empirical data. Finally, we utilize the Fisher information to emphasize the importance of combining prior knowledge with empirical evidence to enhance the estimation efficiency, highlighting the potential of hybridizing both a priori and a posteriori insights to design effective KT mechanisms in ETO.

title: Robust Group Activity Recognition with Graph Attention Networks and Bi-LSTM Modelling
authors: Ishrat Zahra, Ahmad Jalal
abstract: Group activity recognition (GAR) plays a vital role in understanding human interactions in various real-world scenarios. The proposed method uses DeepLabv3 for semantic segmentation, YOLOv11 for human detection, and MediaPipe for skeleton extraction, followed by feature extraction using RootSIFT and contour-based features. We also introduce the Fourier Temporal Pyramid (FTP) and relational features for capturing the spatiotemporal dependencies between individuals in the group. The model leverages Graph Attention Networks (GAT) and Bi-LSTM for spatial and temporal modeling, respectively, followed by a Sparsemax classifier for group activity classification. Evaluated on the CAD dataset, our method achieves 92.6% accuracy, 91.5% MPCA, and 91.8% mAP, outperforming existing state-of-the-art models. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of combining full-body visual features with skeleton-based pose representations for robust group activity recognition.

title: Swarm Decision-Making via Evolutionary Optimization in Pursue-Containment Scenarios
authors: Xiaoyue Jin, Yinglan Feng, Ran Cheng, Dengxiu Yu, Kay Chen Tan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Swarm systems require effective decision-making for timely action coordination. The pursuit-containment task, in particular, highlights the necessity of both intra-swarm co-operation and external competition. However, existing learning-based methods often suffer from poor coordination and are typically limited to small-scale swarms. To address these issues, this paper proposes an evolutionary optimization framework that efficiently facilitates real-time decision making for large-scale swarms, enabling the formation of a uniformly distributed containment circle around targets.

title: A Spatial-Temporal Dual Interpolation Network for Change Detection in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Wenjie Ma, Jia Liu, Wenhua Zhang, Fang Liu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Remote sensing change detection (CD) is a critical task in Earth observation, and like other computer vision domains, is being revolutionized by deep learning. However, existing deep learning-based change detection methods often struggle to simultaneously model fine-grained spatial and temporal information, leading to suboptimal detection accuracy. To tackle this challenge, we model and refine the spatial and temporal features of bitemporal images separately with two different branches, and propose a spatial-temporal dual interpolation network (STDINet). In the spatial branch, we use interpolation to enhance spatial details, while an efficient network leveraging conditionally parameterized convolution extracts refined spatial features. In the temporal branch, we generate a pseudo video sequence for each image pair to construct a progressive representation of change and better characterize the temporal relationships between bitemporal images. Then the temporal branch is designed based on a bidirectional long short-term memory network to capture the refined temporal features. Finally, to obtain the final change map enriched with refined spatial and temporal semantics, we propose a feature adaptive weighting module to fuse the outputs of the two branches. Comprehensive quantitative and qualitative experiments conducted on three representative datasets, compared against seven advanced change detection methods, validate the effectiveness of refined spatialtemporal modeling and highlight the state-of-the-art performance of the proposed STDINet.

title: Adaptive Ring-constrained Loss for Radar HRRP Open Set Target Recognition
authors: Mengdie Wu, Ziheng Xia, Chaoyu Fu, Feng Xiao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With growing demands for precise battlefield reconnaissance, radar automatic target recognition (RATR) systems must address open-set scenarios where unknown targets may appear. While high-resolution range profile (HRRP) provide geometrically discriminative features, conventional closed-set classifiers exhibit limited adaptability. This paper proposes an adaptive ring-constrained loss (ARCL) function based on prototype learning to enhance open-set recognition (OSR) performance. Validation experiments based on the measured HRRP dataset verify the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: MediaAdaptNet: Deep Representation Alignment with Cross-Platform Attention for Legacy Media Acceptance Discovery
authors: Peng Wang, Leila Mirzoyev, Aigerim Alzhanova
abstract: In an increasingly fragmented digital media landscape, understanding the sustained acceptance of legacy media demands models that can effectively align heterogeneous platform representations and audience behaviors. Traditional techniques often struggle with poor generalizability and lack contextual awareness, particularly in cross-platform environments. To address these limitations, we propose MediaAdaptNet, a deep representation alignment framework that leverages a cross-platform attention mechanism to capture acceptance signals of legacy media across diverse online ecosystems. Our architecture includes two pivotal components: LEGEND (Latent Engagement Generative Encoder for Narrative Dynamics) and TRAILS (Temporal Reasoning for Acceptance Inference in Legacy Systems). LEGEND integrates multimodal content encoding, user trait embeddings, and graphical propagation to dynamically model audience acceptance behaviors. It employs topic-guided attention and structured representation projection for user behavior grouping to enable semantically grounded predictions over time. TRAILS complements LEGEND by introducing a graph-based temporal reasoning strategy that tracks cross-episode user-media interactions. It utilizes episodic memory, hierarchical segmentation, and structural alignment to infer stable, causal acceptance patterns while enhancing interpretability. Evaluated on multiple real-world datasets, MediaAdaptNet achieves substantial improvements, with a 12% increase in F1-score and an 18% boost in cross-domain retrieval R-precision over standard baselines. Ablation studies further validate the complementary strengths of LEGEND and TRAILS, demonstrating robust performance even under content noise and platform shifts. Our work contributes a scalable, interpretable, and empirically validated solution for legacy media acceptance discovery, advancing research at the intersection of digital media analytics, audience modeling, and deep learning.

title: Goal-oriented Dynamic Weight Optimization for Multi-Object Navigation
authors: Haitao Zeng, Xinhang Song, Shuqiang Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Multi-object navigation (MON) tasks involve sequentially locating multiple targets in an unknown environment, requiring global long-term planning under incomplete information. This necessitates that the agent dynamically balance immediate actions and long-term rewards while considering both local adaptability and global foresight. However, current methods overly focus on local path optimization, which leads to slower convergence in sparse reward settings and increases the risk of deadlocks or trap states. The core challenge of MON lies in the deformation of the shared decision space, where independent optimization leads to redundant and overlapping paths. Thus, path planning requires dynamic, cross-task optimization rather than simple subtask aggregation. To minimize overall effort, the optimization process should adaptively balance task contributions through weight adjustment. Thus, we propose the Goal-oriented Dynamic Weight Optimization (GDWO) algorithm. GDWO integrates target-specific value loss functions into a unified optimization framework and dynamically adjusts weights through gradient-based updates. To prevent over-optimization, weights are normalized during training according to navigation success rates, prioritizing more challenging targets. This adaptive mechanism effectively addresses the challenge of sparse rewards and improves convergence efficiency. By leveraging this mechanism, GDWO unifies multiple objectives within a unified decision space, achieving efficient optimization and balancing short-term gains with long-term goals. Additionally, we introduce two auxiliary modules: prior knowledge-based navigation and frontier-aware exploration to further enhance GDWO's performance. Experimental results on the Gibson and Matterport3D datasets demonstrate that GDWO achieves improvements in key metrics for MON tasks. It optimizes path planning, reduces exploration costs, and enhances navigation efficiency, enabling the agent to perform tasks more effectively in complex environments.

title: Phase Shift Information Compression in IRS-aided Wireless Systems: Challenges and Opportunities
authors: Xianhua Yu, Dong Li
abstract: Intelligent reflecting surfaces (IRS) have emerged as a promising technology for future 6G wireless networks, offering programmable control of the wireless environment by adjusting the phase shifts of reflecting elements. However, IRS performance depends on accurately configuring the phase shifts of reflecting elements, which introduces substantial phase shift information (PSI) delivery overhead, especially in large-scale or rapidly changing environments. This article first introduces the architecture of IRS-aided systems and highlights real-world use cases where PSI delivery becomes a critical bottleneck. It then reviews current PSI compression approaches, outlining their limitations in terms of adaptability and scalability. To address these gaps, we propose a prompt-driven plug-in module that leverages task-aware prompts to achieve efficient, real-time PSI delivery under diverse conditions. Simulation results demonstrate improved reconstruction accuracy and robustness compared with the baseline method. Finally, we discuss open challenges and outline promising directions for future research.

title: A Polynomial-Fitted Nonlinear Frequency Modulated Signal Intra-Pulse Modulation Recognition Method Using Dual-Threshold Decision
authors: Qiu Shuofeng, Min Baicheng, Fang Guolong
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Advanced radar systems often employ sinusoidal frequency modulation (SFM) as an intra-pulse modulation method to suppress side lobes after pulse compression. Due to the relatively low degree of nonlinearity in polynomial-fitted nonlinear frequency modulated (NLFM) signals, methods based on Short-Time Fourier Transform (STFT) for calculating the instantaneous frequency (IF) curve and then extracting fitting error features struggle to distinguish them. This paper adopts a phase difference method to calculate the IF curve, improving its calculation accuracy. Subsequently, a segmented fitting dualthreshold decision classifier is constructed to distinguish sinusoidal frequency modulation types. Tests using data collected in the field show that this method significantly improves the accuracy of intra-pulse modulation recognition for sinusoidal frequency modulated signals.

title: Diffusion Meets Evolution: Constraint-Guided Learning for Large-Scale Dynamic Multi-Objective Evolutionary Optimization
authors: Chenyang Li, Gary G. Yen, Zhenan He
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Large-scale dynamic multi-objective optimization problems (LSDMOPs) are becoming increasingly prevalent in practical scenarios such as logistics planning, smart grids, and intelligent manufacturing, to name a few. These problems place higher demands on existing dynamic multi-objective evolutionary algorithms (DMOEAs), requiring them to address the dual challenges of large-scale search spaces and dynamic environmental changes. To this end, this paper proposes a large-scale DMOEA based on constraint-guided diffusion model (DM-LSDMOEA). This proposed method, for the first time to our best knowledge, integrates historical population search experience with the hierarchical sampling mechanism of diffusion learning, enabling the learning of change patterns between neighboring Pareto-optimal solutions in historical environments. Through an explicit dual-constraint guided diffusion learning process, DM-LSDMOEA injects decision boundary and historical convergence guidance information into each reverse denoising step, so that the generated solutions progressively converge to the Pareto-optimal solutions of a new environment. In addition, a diversity maintenance-based inference generation mechanism is designed, which uses dynamic noise strength adjustment and multiple independent Gaussian samplings to rapidly generate diverse solutions, providing a highquality initial population for the new environment. Comparative experiments on the DF test suite demonstrate that DM-LSDMOEA achieves superior performance on LSDMOPs ranging from 30 to 600 dimensions.

title: Heterogeneous Clutter Estimation CFAR based on Weighted Group Sparse Regularization
authors: Ruixin Yang, Renhong Xie, Lingyi Hu, Liwen He, Zihang Cheng, Peng Li, Zhonghai Yang, Junhua Gao
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposed a heterogeneous clutter estimation constant false alarm rate algorithm based on weighted group sparse regularization, which solved the problem of poor detection performance of heterogeneous clutter estimation constant false alarm rate algorithm in multi-target environment. The weighted non-convex regularization term was used to regularize the outliers, and the index function was introduced to optimize the background clutter power estimation and parameter calculation to improve the stability of the detection threshold. The proposed algorithm overcomes the problem of large rise of detection threshold in multi-target environment, improves the detection performance in multi-target environment, and improves the robustness of false alarm in clutter edge.

title: Analyzing the Impact of COVID-19 on Gas Demand Markets: A Process Analytics Perspective
authors: Syed Arshad Raza, Atiq W. Siddiqui, Zeeshan Tariq
abstract: COVID-19 profoundly disrupted the global economy, underscoring the need for sustainable and resilient energy systems. In addition to traditional time-series approaches, incorporating process analytics provides a deeper understanding of energy consumption patterns during a disruptive event. This paper analyzes the behavioral interrelationships of various natural gas demand markets— residential, commercial, industrial, electric power, and transportation—across short-, medium-, and long-term planning horizons. Using monthly gas consumption data from January 2001 to May 2024, we apply Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition (CEEMD) to extract intrinsic demand cycles and explore their co-movements. To enhance interpretability, we introduce a process mining perspective that treats demand data as event logs, uncovering structural shifts in market behavior due to COVID-19. Our findings reveal significant post-pandemic changes in inter-market dynamics, particularly in the strategic horizon, and highlight the value of integrating event-driven process insights with empirical forecasting. The results provide actionable guidance for sustainable production and integrated energy planning in the face of such future disruptions.

title: The Role of Large Language Models in Personalized Obesity Management: Opportunities and Challenges
authors: Qasem M. Abdallah, Farah Al-Daghistani, Hussam Mizher, Mohammad Abdallah, Asad A. Abukhalil
abstract: Background: Obesity is a worldwide public health issue that needs to be treated individually, with the use of multidisciplinary therapy. Large Language Models (LLMs), like ChatGPT, provide large-scale AI-supported solutions for nutritional planning, physical activity prescription, and behavioral treatment. Their safety, accuracy, and effectiveness, nonetheless, have to be tested. Objective: This systematic review introduces the potential of LLMs in the treatment of obesity and their advantages, disadvantages, and ethics. Methods: The PubMed, Scopus, and IEEE Xplore databases were searched from 2023 to 2025 for peer-reviewed journal articles on the use of LLMs for weight management following PRISMA standards. Results: The promise of LLMs was discovered to discover individualized diet and exercise regimens, promote user engagement, and provide pharmacotherapeutic management of obesity. But there are issues of AI-generated advice reliability, user input quality dependence, absence of human control, and ethical issues like data privacy and accountability. Conclusion: Though LLMs enhance availability for obesity control, their potential risks need stringent control. Hybrid human-AI offers a solution that can maximize benefits while securing safety and efficacy. Future studies need to enhance transparency in AI, formulate regulatory systems, and promote cultural flexibility for equitable health utilization.

title: Stock Market Prediction: Leveraging Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Pournamasi Parhi, Prajna Paramita Debata, Satyajit Rath, P N Pratikshya
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The stock market's complexity makes it a challenging yet compelling area for predictive modeling. Accurate predictions can greatly benefit investment and economic decision-making. In this study, "Stock Market Prediction Leveraging Deep Learning Techniques", we explore and compare the effectiveness of different neural network architectures— Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs), and Long Short-Term Memory networks (LSTMs)—in forecasting stock prices. By leveraging the unique strengths of each architecture, the aim is to identify the best model for stock market prediction. CNNs excel at recognizing spatial patterns, RNNs handle sequential data well, and LSTMs manage long-term dependencies effectively. This comparative approach provides a comprehensive analysis of their performance differences and similarities. Grid Search Optimization is implemented with three optimizers—Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD), Adam, and RMSprop—to find the optimal configuration for each model. Performance is evaluated using R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> (R-Squared), Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE), and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), offering insights into model accuracy and predictive error. In summary, this study thoroughly examines deep learning techniques for stock market prediction, aiming to uncover the most effective strategies and contribute valuable knowledge to financial forecasting and machine learning.

title: Customer Segmentation for Targeted Campaigns Using RFM Analysis and K-Means Clustering
authors: Roa Omar Baddad, Amani Yousef Owda, Majdi Owda
abstract: Customer segmentation is critical for tailoring marketing campaigns to specific consumer needs, enhancing engagement, and maximizing business profitability. This study integrates Recency-Frequency (RF) analysis with the K-Means clustering algorithm to classify customers of "Ramallah Outfit" into distinct behavioral segments. The Monetary (M) component was excluded because spending levels can sometimes be misleading high or low expenditures do not always reflect true loyalty or engagement. While monetary data may indicate how much a customer spends, it does not necessarily correlate with the frequency or recency of purchases, which are more reliable indicators of customer behavior and engagement. Excluding the Monetary component allows for a clearer focus on customer retention and loyalty. A high spender might make only occasional large purchases, whereas a customer with frequent smaller purchases could be more engaged and loyal. By focusing on Recency and Frequency, the analysis more accurately captures ongoing engagement, providing actionable insights for marketing. Using a unique first-hand dataset, the model achieved a clustering accuracy of 99.47%, effectively segmenting customers into actionable clusters: Gold (34.4%), Bronze (35.2%), and Silver (30.4%). The results demonstrate the effectiveness of this refined approach in optimizing marketing efforts and fostering customer loyalty.

title: EEG-based Validation of Neural Response Similarity Between Vibration and Electrical Stimulation for Virtual Tactile Feedback
authors: Tianshi Gao, Jiahui Jiang, Xiaoyun Sun, Guosheng Yi, Zhenxi Song, Jixuan Wang
abstract: Electrical stimulation virtual vibration is widely used in fields like virtual reality and medical rehabilitation. However, its parameter optimization still relies on subjective psychological evaluation. This approach lacks objective quantitative criteria. The purpose of this paper is to investigate the neural response relationship between low-frequency vibration stimulation and electrical stimulation using EEG technology, providing quantitative theoretical support for optimizing electrical stimulation parameters. This paper employs a custom-built electrical stimulation system (incorporating a flexible electrode array) to conduct tactile EEG experiments with 42 participants under both electrical stimulation and vibration stimulation conditions. We extract beta-band power spectral density (PSD) and regional permutation entropy (PE) features for the two types of stimulation. Results demonstrate that under vibration stimulation, PSD at C6 and T8 channels exhibit positive correlation with frequency, while PE in the right central region and right temporal-frontal-parietal region shows positive correlation with amplitude. During electrical stimulation, corresponding neural features follow analogous patterns. For both modalities, PSD-frequency correlations (Pearson's r > 0.84) and PE-amplitude correlations (r > 0.68) achieve statistically significant levels. Finally, we conducted classification experiments using a k-nearest neighbor (kNN) classifier, with EEG features from vibratory stimulation as the training set and EEG features from electrical stimulation as the test set. The results show that the accuracy reached 66.7% for the frequency discrimination task, while the average accuracy for the amplitude discrimination task was 67.9%. These findings demonstrate significant similarity in neural signatures elicited by low-frequency vibration stimulation (1-15 Hz) and electrical stimulation. Our study provides new insights for quantifying the refinement of electrical stimulation parameters.

title: A Comprehensive Analysis Framework for Performance Evaluation of Private Cloud Environments
authors: Yasser Kamal
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Traditional methods for evaluating cloud computing performance typically depend on metrics provided by vendors, such as CPU utilization, memory usage, disk I/O, network latency, throughput, and availability. However, factors like configuration drift, long-tail latency, security overhead, and user behavior can significantly influence system performance. This study introduces a comprehensive framework for analyzing cloud environments, emphasizing holistic monitoring and behavioral modeling within an open-source private cloud infrastructure. Our key findings reveal operational inefficiencies and recommend enhancements, including the adoption of the Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS) and contemporary monitoring tools such as Prometheus and Grafana.
