title: Fully Discrete and Phase-Coupled STAR-RIS-Aided MIMO Multiuser Communications Using SZFDPC
authors: Hsiao-feng Lu
abstract: This paper proposes a practical, high-performance transceiver for STAR-RIS-aided MU-MIMO downlink systems with discrete, phase-coupled, quantized energy-splitting elements. The base station employs successive zero-forcing dirty paper coding to mitigate interference and approach capacity limits. To optimize the phases and energy splits of STAR-RIS, we first decompose its coefficient matrices and develop a powerful method to optimize discrete phases on one side. We then introduce an ingenious transformation that jointly optimizes phase coupling and energy splitting using the same phase optimization framework. Simulations show significant sum-rate gains over existing MU-MISO works and MU-MIMO scenarios, justifying the robustness and practicality of the proposed design.

title: A Large Language Model-Assisted Reinforcement Learning Framework with Evolutionary Algorithm for Hybrid Flow-Shop Scheduling
authors: Fuqing Zhao, Bin Wu, Ling Wang, Hongyan Sang
abstract: With the growing emphasis on sustainable manufacturing, green scheduling has gained prominence from practitioners and researchers in the industry manufacturing enterprises. This article addresses the hybrid flow shop scheduling problem with peak power consumption constraints (HFSPP) to minimize makespan and total energy consumption (TEC), while ensuring real-time power usage does not exceed a predefined threshold. A hybrid framework, LLM-MODPPO-Evo, is proposed to solve HFSPP by simultaneously minimizing makespan and TEC. The framework consists of three parts: 1) large language models (LLMs) are introduced to automatically design algorithms and generate initial solutions; 2) evolutionary algorithm based on adaptive evolutionary strategy of covariance matrix (CMA-ES) is adopted to diversify solutions; 3) multi-objective distributed proximal policy optimization (MODPPO) is utilized to refine solutions. Firstly, initial scheduling algorithms generated by LLMs via tailored prompt frameworks produce diverse heuristic operators and decoding methods. Secondly, after screening feasible algorithms and producing the initial schemes, these solutions are extended through an EA to create a population of the improved schemes. Finally, the populations are adaptively optimized by MODPPO to yield the best Pareto-optimal solution set to balance makespan and TEC under peak power consumption constraints. The comparative results demonstrate that the framework outperforms that of the existing algorithms in solving the HFSPP.

title: Improving the Classification of Arabic Tweet Sentiment Using Word Embedding Models
authors: Ghassan Kanaan, Mariam Dabaeen, Raed K. Kanaan, Ghazi Kanaan, Salahiddin Altrahat, Ibrahim Atoum
abstract: Enhancing the Classification of Sentiments in Arabic Tweets through Word Embedding Models Sentiment analysis in Arabic tweets is applied in this research using word embedding techniques. The primary objective is to determine how to classify Arabic tweets as positive or negative. The analysis was based on a dataset of 4,546 Arabic tweets obtained from Kaggle. The word embedding model (e.g. Word2Vec and GloVe) was used to facilitate the analysis because its semantic meaning and relations of words were better than what was provided through traditional methods like TF-IDF. To analyze the data, some of the classification techniques that were used include logistic regression, decision trees, and support vector machines. The results of the study showed that SVM has the best accuracy at 87%, followed by decision trees at 80%, and then logistic regression at 85%. This demonstrates that word embedding simulation models are effective for Arabic sentiment analysis on social networking sites. With 80% decision trees, word embedding greatly aided pyramid computing’s divergence modulation, which allows for sentiment and mining analyses of Middle Eastern users’ social activities. SVM performed well at the more sensitive and sophisticated tasks of opinion and market research analysis involving the Arabic language. Even so, a more precise classification can be performed with the application of deep learning algorithms or a hybrid model in future work.

title: An Intelligent Systems for Heart Sound Signal Analysis
authors: Manu Saraswat, Chhote Lal Prasad Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Globally, heart failure is the leading cause of death. One of the first diagnostic techniques for examining the state of the heart is cardiac auscultation. The heart's mechanical activity, which is triggered by biopotentials produced by the Sino-Atrium (SA) node, results in non-stationary and non-deterministic signals known as Heart Sound Signals (HSS). When captured by an electronic stethoscope, the graphical representation of HSS is known as phonocardiogram (PCG). PCG can provide very helpful diagnostic information when evaluating a range of cardiac abnormalities, like valvular heart disease, irregular heartbeat, cardiac decompensation, and anatomical defects in the heart. PCG is composed of the first and second (S1, S2) heart sounds, which are frequently the two loudest heart sounds. In both diseased and non-pathological situations, the PCG signal may comprise murmurs, the third and fourth cardiac sounds (S3), and other odd sounds like clicks, snaps, and rubs.PCG analysis is effective for non-invasive cardiovascular disease diagnosis. The thesis is on creating an Automatic Computerised Auscultation (ACA) for effective cardiac state monitoring. ACA provides diagnostic and prognostic data in a non-invasive, affordable, fast, and precise manner, helping clinicians detect cardiac sickness early and prevent cardiovascular disease deaths.Following the same steps for classifying heart sounds, the suggested RNN+LSTM approach deals with classifying heart murmurs as harmless (normal) and pathological (abnormal). The classification AUC for the optimal murmur classification combination was $\color {Orange}{\text{93}}{\text{.69}}\% $.

title: Structured Instruction Tuning for Syntax-Semantic Fused Software Defect Detection
authors: Weihao Zhang, Haoyu Huang, Rui Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Software defect detection is crucial for ensuring software quality and reliability. Traditional static analysis approaches often struggle with high false positive rates and limited semantic understanding. This paper presents an approach that combines syntactic analysis with semantic understanding through Large Language Models (LLMs). We introduce the Predicate Event Relation Graph (PERG), a structured protocol for describing code defect patterns, and construct a dataset based on mutual distillation between LLMs and rule-based detection tools. Through structured instruction fine-tuning on this dataset, we develop a specialized 7B parameter LLM that effectively fuses traditional rule knowledge with deep semantic understanding. Experimental results demonstrate that our approach significantly reduces false positives to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0. 7 5 \%}$</tex> and improves overall detection precision from 63.75% to 83.3%. The proposed method provides a promising direction for more accurate and reliable software defect detection.

title: Case Study: Apply AI Mosquito Identification Models in Dengue Fever Prevention for Public Participation
authors: Robert Kuo-Chung Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Dengue fever prevention and control is a critical task in subtropical and tropical countries. Public participation is widespread, with measures such as clearing water from vases and wearing long sleeves and long pants when outdoors to avoid bites. Public health agencies are implementing measures such as widespread insecticide spraying, releasing sterilized male mosquitoes, and distributing testing kits. However, the annual dengue fever infection rate remains unchecked. Dengue fever peaks between May and October and causes flu-like symptoms such as high fever, severe headache, and body aches. In extreme cases, it can lead to bleeding, difficulty breathing, and even death. This case study focuses on leveraging artificial intelligence technology to develop a public-engaged dengue fever prevention and control system, enabling citizens to actively participate in dengue fever prevention and control, both during outdoor activities and at home. The approach involves deploying multiple models trained using the ResNeXt-101 residual network framework on a public dengue fever prevention and AI control platform. The system is designed to instantly upload mosquito photos, identify the mosquito species, and provide alerts indicating the risk of infection and the number of cases in the area, thereby increasing public engagement and improving prevention and control effectiveness. The government, through the platform’s integration with the city’s extensive dengue monitoring infrastructure, can conduct targeted area disinfection and distribute dengue testing kits after a case occurs, enabling early detection and treatment. Implementing this system minimizes environmental impact, enabling targeted dengue prevention and control.

title: Text-vision guided Latent Prediction for High-Fidelity Blind Face Restoration
authors: Juan Cai, Lianxin Xie, Wen Xue, Si Wu
abstract: Blind face restoration (BFR) aims to recover high-quality (HQ) facial images from degraded inputs with unknown distortions, while preserving identity consistency. Existing methods either rely solely on visual priors or incorporate generic textual cues, struggle with noise sensitivity or insufficient semantic guidance. In this paper, we present a vision-language guided BFR framework that consists of three key components: (1) a Facial Key Attribute Estimation module that leverages structured text to compactly describe facial attributes; (2) a Dual-modal Based Latent Prediction module built on a shared-attention Transformer, which fuses visual and textual embeddings to predict dictionary elements representing the target face; (3) a Text-based Adaptive Feature Filter that dynamically suppresses noise in skip-connected features by aligning them with textual semantics, enhancing the generator’s ability to leverage multi-scale spatial information. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our method outperforms state-of-the-art approaches on multiple benchmarks, particularly under severe degradation.

title: Spatiotemporal Maps for Dynamic MRI Reconstruction
authors: Rodrigo A. Lobos, Xiaokai Wang, Rex T. L. Fung, Yongli He, David Frey, Dinank Gupta, Zhongming Liu, Jeffrey A. Fessler, Douglas C. Noll
abstract: The partially separable functions (PSF) model is commonly adopted in dynamic MRI reconstruction, as is the underlying signal model in many reconstruction methods including the ones relying on low-rank assumptions. Even though the PSF model offers a parsimonious representation of the dynamic MRI signal in several applications, its representation capabilities tend to decrease in scenarios where voxels present different temporal/spectral characteristics at different spatial locations. In this work we account for this limitation by proposing a new model, called spatiotemporal maps (STMs), that leverages autoregressive properties of (k, t)-space. The STM model decomposes the spatiotemporal MRI signal into a sum of components, each one consisting of a product between a spatial function and a temporal function that depends on the spatial location. The proposed model can be interpreted as an extension of the PSF model whose temporal functions are independent of the spatial location. We show that spatiotemporal maps can be efficiently computed from autocalibration data by using advanced signal processing and randomized linear algebra techniques, enabling STMs to be used as part of many reconstruction frameworks for accelerated dynamic MRI. As proof-of-concept illustrations, we show that STMs can be used to reconstruct both 2D single-channel animal gastrointestinal MRI data and 3D multichannel human functional MRI data.

title: Leveraging BERT and LDA for Semi-Supervised Augmentation of Chinese Sexism Hate Speech Datasets

title: Boosting Adversarial Transferability with Low-Cost Optimization via Maximin Expected Flatness
authors: Chunlin Qiu, Ang Li, Yiheng Duan, Shenyi Zhang, Yuanjie Zhang, Lingchen Zhao, Qian Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security
abstract: Transfer-based attacks craft adversarial examples on white-box surrogate models and directly deploy them against black-box target models, offering practical query-free threat scenarios. While flatness-enhanced methods have recently emerged to improve transferability by enhancing the loss surface flatness of adversarial examples, their divergent flatness definitions and heuristic attack designs suffer from unexamined optimization limitations and missing theoretical foundation, thus constraining their effectiveness and efficiency. This work exposes the severely imbalanced exploitation-exploration dynamics in flatness optimization, establishing the first theoretical foundation for flatness-based transferability and proposing a principled framework to overcome these optimization pitfalls. Specifically, we systematically unify fragmented flatness definitions across existing methods, revealing their imbalanced optimization limitations in over-exploration of sensitivity peaks or over-exploitation of local plateaus. To resolve these issues, we rigorously formalize average-case flatness and transferability gaps, proving that enhancing zeroth-order average-case flatness minimizes cross-model discrepancies. Building on this theory, we design a Maximin Expected Flatness (MEF) attack that enhances zeroth-order average-case flatness while balancing flatness exploration and exploitation. Extensive evaluations across 33 models and 43 current transfer-based attacks demonstrate MEF’s superiority: it surpasses the state-of-the-art PGN attack by 4% in attack success rate at half the computational cost and achieves 8% higher success rate under the same budget. When combined with input augmentation, MEF attains 15% additional gains against defense-equipped models, establishing new robustness benchmarks. Our code is available at https://github.com/SignedQiu/MEFAttack.

title: Evaluating Civil Engineering Master Programs: The Case for an International Joint Master's in Pavement Engineering
authors: Eshta Ranyal, Antonio Roberto, Davide Lo Presti, Elisabete Freitas, Girish Murgod, Wim Van den bergh
abstract: In the last decade the effects of climate change, increasing levels of traffic and the need to move to a circular and sustainable economic strategy have led to a more complex and interdisciplinary design and management strategy of transportation infrastructure. Because of that, many international, national, and regional agencies are funding and promoting interdisciplinary based projects. This development underlines the need to integrate workplace dynamics into learning, ensuring that education remains aligned with the realities and demands of the professional environment. In recent years, European Union has been shedding light on advancing asphalt pavement engineering through a series of research projects under the umbrella of Horizon 2020 and the European Regional Development Fund. In light of these developments, there is a growing need for advanced master's programs that introduce students - the future workforce, to industry-applied processes while maintaining strong connections to the world of work through close cooperation between the education sector and industry. This paper aims to investigate whether asphalt pavement-based master's programs exist and the need for such programs. Particularly, this study aims to review the existing joint and cross-country master's programs offering specific, transversal, and multidisciplinary courses for pavement engineering. The review is based on a global search of university programs and a detailed examination of their curricula, by performing an online search assisted by the generative AI tool ChatGPT. Finally it proposes the need for a joint master's program relevant to pavement engineering with a focus on technological advancements and sustainability.

title: A Robust Drone Based Parking Space Detection System Based on Deep Learning Algorithms
authors: Li-Sha Zhou, Richard Tai-Chiu Hsung, Harris Sik-Ho Tsang, Tony Yu-Lin Zhu, Wai-Lun Lo
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: With the acceleration of urbanization and the continuous growth of the number of motor vehicles, traditional parking management methods are increasingly unable to meet the needs of modern cities, especially China's cities. Existing parking space detection technologies, which rely on sensors such as geomagnetic, infrared, and ultrasonic, face challenges including high costs, limited adaptability, and complex maintenance, hindering their widespread implementation. However, many urban parking is equipped with surveillance cameras, which provide an essential infrastructure for advanced computer vision and deep learning-based parking lot detection systems. In response to these challenges, this paper introduces an innovative system that leverages high-resolution video data captured by drones, along with publicly available datasets, to efficiently detect the availability and occupancy status of parking spaces in real time. The proposed system aims to tackle the challenges presented by complex environments-such as varying lighting conditions, angle tilts, and occlusions. It adopts the state-of-the-art YOLOv8 model. It is trained with various data augmentation and optimized with some model optimization strategies to maximize the system's robustness. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed YOLOv8-based model achieves remarkable accuracy and stability across diverse environmental conditions. It achieves precision, recall, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP} {@} 0.5$</tex> and mAP@0.5:0.95 values of 0.97, 0.90, 0.94, and 0.85 respectively, reflecting robust detection accuracy across various Intersection over Union (IoU) thresholds and scales.

title: Improving the Curriculum of IT Foundations Course for Estonian and International Non-IT Students at Tallinn University of Technology
authors: Aleksandr Kormiltsyn, Olga Mironova
abstract: Computer technologies are now widely accessible. Individuals encounter information technologies (IT) from a young age. Consequently, the importance of computer science and its impactful teaching is increasing. At Tallinn University of Technology (Tal Tech<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup><sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>https://taltech.ee/), the Study Center for IT Foundations emphasizes imparting IT fundamentals to first-year non-IT students, both local and from abroad. A key aspect of the course is the initial assessment, which tests students' prior knowledge in the IT field. The preliminary quizzes provided to students include both practical and theoretical questions based on the course curriculum. The course instructors use these results to assess each student's knowledge level and to define for them an individual learning path. However, the information technologies (IT) industry is rapidly changing nowadays. New technologies such as artificial intelligence, blockchain, internet of things (loT), extended reality, digital twins, etc. provide new services for our daily life every year. In such a continuously changing context, the IT Foundations course does not cover all cutting-edge technologies, focusing on the previously defined course curriculum. Also, educators of the course have limited resources to continuously monitor cutting-edge technologies and add them to the course program. In this paper, we provide the integration of AI and blockchain technologies into the educational process for the IT Foundations course. AI enables continuous alignment of the course program with the evolving IT landscape with technologies arriving in the IT industry, while blockchain, in combination with gamification, aims to increase the motivation of the non-IT students during the course. The approach is aligned with Education 5.0 principles and enables agile course adjustments while enhancing student engagement.

title: Harmonic Current Suppression in Modular Multi‑Sector PM Machines via Virtual Current Reconstruction
authors: Zekai Lyu, Litao Dai, Shuangxia Niu, K. T. Chau
abstract: This letter proposes a low-frequency harmonic current suppression method for modular multi-sector permanent-magnet machines based on virtual current reconstruction. Unlike conventional approaches that require additional controllers or complex parameter tuning, the proposed scheme utilizes the inherent harmonic decomposition capabilities of modular multi-sector architectures to facilitate harmonic current suppression. The currents of three sectors are phase-shifted by 15°, 30°, and 45° electrical degrees with respect to a reference sector, forming a virtual quadruple three-phase machine with angle displacements. The reconstructed currents are further processed using vector space decomposition, which separates the fundamental and harmonic components, and enables independent regulation of each subspace using only proportional-integral controllers. Experimental validation on a modular four-sector machine confirms the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: An Efficient-Energy Charge-Domain Convolution Operator for CNN
authors: Jose-Angel Diaz-Madrid, Gines Domenech-Asensi, Ramon Ruiz-Merino, Francisco-Javier Andreo-Oliver
abstract: This paper proposes a compact and low-power mixed-signal approach for implementing a convolutional operator in the charge domain. The circuit integrates a voltage divider with selector circuits to perform multiplications using multibit weights ranging from -1 to +1 and analog signals. Additionally, charge-domain average circuits accumulate, sum, and average these multiplications sequentially. For this study, a new convolution operator was designed to compute the convolution product over a pixel using a multibit 3x3 mask. Subsequently, a computing circuit was developed to perform 30 convolution operations in parallel per clock cycle. The charge-domain average circuit was synthesized in 180 nm CMOS technology, and post layout simulation results indicate its capability to convolve a 32×32 grayscale pixel image in 5.12μs while consuming only 117 μW, achieving an efficiency of 22154 1b-TOPS/W (1-bit tera-operations per second per watt) with a similarity to ideal processing of up to 99%.

title: Descriptor: A Dataset on Educational, Lifestyle, and Socioeconomic Factors of Bangladeshi Students (DELSFBS)
authors: Anika Rahman, Mst. Taskia Khatun, Alfat Tasnim Hasan
abstract: We present DELSFBS, a curated dataset of 1,504 Bangladeshi students collected between March and September 2025. The dataset includes 20 variables covering study habits, academic performance, socioeconomic background, and lifestyle factors such as sleep, extracurricular engagement, and physical activity. Data were collected via a structured Google Forms survey across urban and rural regions. All responses were anonymized, and preprocessing involved cleaning, outlier handling, and normalization using Python (Pandas). DELSFBS supports analysis of the relationships between lifestyle, socioeconomic status, and academic outcomes, enabling modeling of student performance and evidence-based policy analysis. The dataset, along with preprocessing scripts and metadata, is publicly available on Mendeley Data. Detailed metadata and technical validation are provided to ensure reproducibility and reuse, filling a critical gap in publicly available educational data from Bangladesh.

title: MC-MLA: Accelerating Multi-Head Latent Attention on RISC-V Many-Core Chips
authors: Xifu Qian, Qibin Chen, Xinxin Zhao, Min Liu, Qisheng Tong, Kai Jiang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: As the core mechanism of the DeepSeek-V3 model, Multi-Head Latent Attention (MLA) significantly reduces the computational complexity by low-rank matrix factorization. However, the memory access overhead and computing bottlenecks are becoming increasingly prominent as the sequence length continues to grow. The performance of this mechanism is severely limited by the efficiency of memory access. Meanwhile, existing research on MLA acceleration mostly relies on NVIDIA GPUs and the CUDA ecosystem, which significantly constrains the expansion of its application scenario. Given this, this paper proposes Many-Core Optimized Multi-Head Latent Attention (MC-MLA), which is committed to achieving efficient parallel acceleration of MLA on a many-core RISC-V architecture. The scheme includes two core optimizations: (1) KV Reuse-Oriented Parallel Dataflow Optimization: For the matrix absorption characteristics in MLA, we design an online transposition dataflow that absorbs value matrices into key matrices. This approach ensures efficient reuse of KV-Cache while achieving pipeline overlap between data movement and computation, thereby reducing memory access pressure and hiding latency for KV-Cache load operations. (2) Balanced Tree-like Inter-Core Reduction Algorithm based on Semaphore: This algorithm resolves workload imbalance in high-parallel scenarios, significantly promoting many-core collaboration efficiency. The experimental results demonstrate that MC-MLA can enhance the computational efficiency of MLA under various configurations of batch size, number of heads, and sequence length. Final comparison results reveal that MC-MLA effectively alleviates key bottlenecks: load imbalance in reduction operations and NoC congestion in memory accesses, achieving up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.69 \times$</tex> performance improvement and 76 % of bandwidth utilization. This competitive implementation provides a reference for MLA adaptation and performance optimization on similar many-core architectures.

title: Early Earthquake Warning System for Commercial Business
authors: Arturo Montalvo, Antonio Noe Perez
abstract: This paper presents a prototype's development of an Early Earthquake Warning System (EEWS) dedicated to complement warning's equipment for the Internal Civil Protection Program (PIPC by its Spanish acronym) in retail or manufacturing commercial business whit important public attend. Main development goal is the early detection of seismic waves with sufficient ground motion acceleration capable of producing damage, reducing clients and staff risks due fire or merchandise, machinery or structural elements falling through the generation of acoustic, visual and Telegram warnings.

title: A Semi-Physical and Semi-Statistical Simulation Method to Sea Clutter for High-Speed Maritime Radars
authors: Jian-Ming Wang, Peng-Lang Shui, Jia-Bo Lin, Shu-Wen Xu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Sea clutter simulation is of critical importance for the design of maritime radar systems and the performance evaluation of corresponding target detection algorithms. However, the acquisition of sea clutter data under high-speed moving radars remains challenging, making it essential to analyze the underlying clutter characteristics and develop effective simulation methods. In this paper, the characteristics of sea clutter under high-speed moving radar platforms are first analyzed. Building upon existing sea clutter simulation methods, a novel simulation method tailored for moving platforms is proposed. The proposed method comprehensively takes into account oceanographic factors, sea surface scattering mechanisms, high-resolution sea clutter statistical characteristics, and the illumination geometry associated with moving platforms. The simulation results produced by the proposed method exhibit amplitude distributions, spectral characteristics, and structural trends that are consistent with the theoretical analysis.

title: Hybrid Where-What Neural Decoder: Approximating Bayesian Inference for Real-Time Spike-Train Reconstruction
authors: Siyao Zhang, En Lin, Huajin Tang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: We introduce a modular, hybrid decoding architecture that separates motion tracking (“where”) and image reconstruction (“what”) to recover high-resolution visual stimuli from noisy retinal ganglion cell (RGC) spike trains under naturalistic fixational drift. Our “where” network learns to infer instantaneous eye displacement directly from recent spike-image inputs via a compact CNN+GRU pipeline, amortizing the diffusion-pluslikelihood update of Bayesian filters into a single feed-forward pass. Conditioned on these shift estimates, a “what” network uses 3D convolutions over aligned spike volumes to reconstruct the static image with per-pixel probability outputs. On synthetic letter stimuli, the hybrid decoder achieves over 90% pixel accuracy, close to an ideal Bayesian baseline-while running over an order of magnitude faster. By embedding principled motion priors into a deep-learning framework, our approach combines interpretability, robustness, and real-time performance. This work suggests a general template for biologically inspired neural decoding: explicitly factor latent state and content inference, train specialized modules in sequence, and tightly integrate them in an online loop. Future directions include natural scenes, spiketiming dynamics, and cortical population recordings.

title: Radar HRRP Target Recognition in the Open World Based on a Hierarchical Autoencoder
authors: Xianwen Zhang, Wenying Wang, Yao Wei
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Radar automatic target recognition is of vital importance in modern radar systems and realistic recognition is commonly applied in the open world, which requires not only classifying the known targets accurately but also detecting the unknown targets. In this paper, we propose a novel HRRP target recognition method in the open world based on a hierarchical autoencoder. The hierarchical autoencoder is composed of an encoder to extract latent features and a decoder to reconstruct the inputs. The Encoder extracted hierarchical features from every layer to detecting the unknown targets in the feature space based on distance, and the feature from the last layer was exploited to classify the known samples. Our method was validated on measured HRRP data and the results showed its superior performance over other methods, indicating its potentials in the realistic application of HRRP target recognition in the open world.

title: Surveillance Video-Based Face Recognition Pipeline and Comparative Performance Evaluation of SOTA Deep Learning Models
authors: Nadim Zia, Mohsin Ullah, Memona Zulfiqar, Aqsa Hussain Raja, Imtiaz Ahmad Taj
abstract: The global facial recognition market is projected to reach $16.74 billion by 2030, driven by the growing need for secure and intelligent biometric authentication systems. However, accurate recognition in surveillance videos remains challenging due to motion blur, low resolution, and uncontrolled lighting. We present a surveillance video-based face recognition pipeline and evaluate 16 model-detector combinations by pairing state-of-the-art face recognition models (ArcFace with ResNet, ArcFace with MobileNet, AdaFace, and Sub-center Contrastive Distillation model) with four detectors (MTCNN and three RetinaFace variants). Testing was conducted on benchmark datasets and a custom multi-view video dataset of 48 students recorded using four cameras at varied positions and distances. AdaFace with RetinaFace (ResNet) achieved the highest accuracy and robustness under real-world conditions. We also introduce FaceTrack, a lightweight tracking algorithm combining the IoU-based motion model from SORT with the embedding-based matching of Deep SORT, improving stability and ID consistency without the overhead of deep appearance models. Pipeline optimizations such as detection resizing and coordinate mapping further reduced inference time by about 50%. This work provides a comprehensive evaluation of model-detector combinations and an efficient tracking solution for realtime surveillance.

title: Large-Scale Many-Objective Evolutionary Algorithm Based on Overlapping Grouping of Objective Guided Variables
authors: Liang Chen, Hongyan Jiang, Xiaole Guo, Linjie Wu, Zhixia Zhang, Zhihua Cui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Large-scale many-objective optimization problems (LSMaOPs) are prevalent in various fields such as engineering design, urban planning, and production scheduling, aiming to optimize multiple conflicting objectives simultaneously. However, traditional methods often struggle with LSMaOPs due to subjective weight allocation and insufficient diversity capture, making it difficult to fully reflect the complexity and diversity of these problems. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a multi-objective evolutionary algorithm based on overlapping grouping of objective guided variables (MaOEA-SOG). The algorithm categorizes decision variables into diversity and convergence variables through interaction analysis and dynamically adjusts groupings to match different stages of population evolution. It also optimizes interaction analysis by weighting interaction indicators to enhance grouping rationality. Experiments on LSMaOPs and Walking Fish Group (WFG) test suites demonstrate that MaOEA-SOG effectively balances solution diversity and convergence, outperforming state-of-the-art algorithms and showing strong adaptability and optimization efficiency.

title: Classification for UAV and Meteorological Clutter based on One-dimensional Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Meiyan Pan, Lan Pang, Xingyu Cai, Jian Xue, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In this paper, we study the classification problem of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and meteorological clutter embedded in radar land clutter environments. To suppress the land clutter and enhance the target features, the radar multipulse echo data is processed using the Fourier transform and frequency-domain pruning operation to obtain micro-Doppler spectral input samples. Then, a tailored one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1DCNN) architecture is designed to extract multi-dimensional features and to classify UAVs and meteorological clutter. Experimental results based on measured radar data demonstrate that the proposed method achieves a classification accuracy of $86 \%$ with an accumulation time of approximate 25 milliseconds. Furthermore, we give the minimum accumulation time required for effective classification using micro-Doppler spectrum features.

title: Measuring X-Ray Emission Line Shapes in Neutral Species for XRISM Calibration
authors: Frederick S. Porter, Gregory V. Brown, Renata S. Cumbee, Megan E. Eckart, Natalie Hell, Richard L. Kelley, Caroline A. Kilbourne, Maurice A. Leutenegger, Thomas Lockard, Makoto Sawada, Chintan D. Shah, Stephen J. Smith, Michael C. Witthoeft
abstract: Space X-ray spectrometers such as the Resolve instrument on XRISM require precise calibration in order to interpret the spectra of astrophysical objects. Key components of the calibration are the energy scale and the core line spread function, both of which vary with photon energy. A major issue in the calibration of high-resolution spectrometers is locating good calibrators with well-known, stable intrinsic line shapes. Neutral fluorescence is widely used, but inner-shell transitions in neutral atoms often exhibit complex, poorly documented line shapes that vary with excitation conditions. Here we present empirical measurements of K-shell transitions in neutral O and F below 1 keV using an engineering model XRISM calorimeter array, an electron bombardment modulated X-ray source, and an Electron Beam Ion Trap (EBIT) to provide a precise energy reference. In addition, we report measurements of the Mo Lα complex with the Transition-Edge Microcalorimeter Spectrometer (TEMS), which reveal strong satellite structure and sensitivity of the line shape to the incident exciting spectrum. Together, these results demonstrate the need for empirical line-shape models, highlight the non-stationary nature of neutral fluorescence features, and define a path toward developing transfer standards for XRISM and future precision instruments such as Athena/X-IFU.

title: Largest Connected Component-Centered Dual-Layer Gravity Optimization of Network Robustness
authors: Yuan Zhong, He Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Improving network robustness to prevent catastrophic disruptions is inherently important and challenging due to its NP-hard nature. Many existing optimization algorithms require repeated computation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R$</tex>, which leads to their inefficiency. Based on the definition of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R$</tex>, the Largest Connected Component (LCC) serves as the backbone of a robust network. Thus, enhancing the topology both within and outside the LCC can significantly improve network robustness. Inspired by this insight, with the intrinsic properties of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R$</tex> in mind, we design a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R$</tex> computation free algorithm, Largest Connected Component-centered Gravity for Robustness Optimization (LCCG-RO), which can improve network robustness with extremely low computational cost. In LCCGRO, two gravity operators at both micro scale within LCCs and macro scale among LCCs and other CCs are designed to efficiently achieve the re-linking. The experiments on scale-free networks with various sizes and densities validate the performance of LCCG-RO, which can achieve significant improvements in terms of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R$</tex> over the original networks with extremely low computational cost.

title: Competency-Based Modular Higher Education: Key Features and Technological Integration
authors: Catherine Hills, Justine Baillie, Alexander A Kist
abstract: Competency-based education is a feature of vocational training, medical education and other fields. Changes in technology, the abundance of information, and consequent shifts in education make competency-based learning a promising alternative to traditional content-centric, timed, and graded curriculum. Modularised content allows for manageable, achievable, and scaffolded competencies. However, implementing a competency-based modular curriculum will likely require functionality that is not readily available in existing learning management and curriculum management systems. This paper outlines key requirements for delivering such a curriculum based on educational specifications. Requirements are identified and articulated, justifying the need for a system to augment existing functionality. Examples of features are included, along with key considerations in the development process. A case study is presented to support the understanding of the underlying use case.

title: Joint Sine-Type Sparse Arrays with Multi-Coset Sampling: Comparison of Two Structures
authors: Lei Yang, Yubing Han
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: The primary objective of electronic support measures is to perform real-time parameter estimation of intensive signals. For wideband scenarios, spatio-temporal sparse sampling is a potential strategy. In this paper, a novel sine-type sparse array is proposed, which is combined with multi-coset sampling (MCS) to constitute two types of spatio-temporal sparse sampling structure. Compared with uniform arrays, the nonuniformity of sine-type arrays includes both larger and smaller inter-element spacing, which is more reasonable for wideband requirements, and the expanded virtual elements allow for increased degrees of freedom. In two patterns, Structure 1 connects multiple different delay channels only to the first antenna, while Structure 2 connects the same delay channels to each antenna. Simulation experiments validate their effectiveness, showing that better accuracy and robustness are mutually exclusive with low computational complexity. In summary, Structure 1 is more accurate and robust, while Structure 2 performs better in real-time tasks.

title: Frequency Entropy: a New Entropy for Underwater Acoustic Signal Processing
authors: Sihao Chen, Yuxing Li
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Underwater acoustic signal is sound wave that propagate in water and are important carriers for underwater communication, detection, and positioning. However, there are significant non-stationary characteristics in underwater acoustic signals in the marine environment, which limits traditional signal processing methods. In order to effectively handle these non-stationary underwater acoustic signals, it is necessary to adopt analysis methods that can capture the complex time-frequency domain characteristics of the signals. In response to the above issues, this paper proposes frequency entropy (FrEn), a novel complexity measure aimed at revealing the nonlinear dynamic characteristics of signals. This paper further uses the chaotic evolution optimization (CEO) to optimize threshold parameters to improve performance of FrEn, and proposes chaotic evolution optimization-FrEn (CEO-FrEn). The method was ultimately applied to classification recognition of vessel sounds and ambient noises, demonstrating the excellent feature extraction ability of CEO-FrEn.

title: Robust Radar HRRP Recognition under Non-uniform Jamming Based on Complex-valued Frequency Attention Network
authors: Yanhao Wang, Lei Wang, Jie Wang, Yimin Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Complex electromagnetic environments, often containing multiple jammers with different jamming patterns, produce non-uniform jamming power across the frequency spectrum. This spectral non-uniformity directly induces severe distortion in the target’s high resolution range profile (HRRP), consequently compromising the performance and reliability of conventional HRRP-based target recognition methods. This paper proposes a novel, end-to-end trained network for robust radar target recognition. The core of our model is a Complex-valued Frequency Attention (CFA) module that operates directly on the complex spectrum of the received echo. The CFA module learns to generate an adaptive frequency-domain filter, assigning lower weights to bands corrupted by strong jamming while preserving critical target information in cleaner bands. The filtered spectrum is then fed into a classifier backbone for recognition. Experimental results on simulated HRRP data with various jamming combinations demonstrate our method’s superiority. Notably, under severe jamming conditions, our model achieves a recognition accuracy nearly 9% higher than traditional modelbased approaches, all while introducing negligible computational overhead. This highlights its exceptional performance and robustness in challenging jamming environments.

title: Locally Hosted DeepSeek and Llama3.2 Code Generation and Computer Science Pedagogy
authors: James Wolfer
abstract: The emergence of Generative AI as expressed in Large Language Models is having a significant impact on society by encapsulating and correlating knowledge. One aspect of this emergence concerns student adoption of these models for automatic code generation. Most previous work assessed code generation using internet-hosted, very large, language models. In contrast, this work presents the results of deploying smaller, locally hosted, openly available, models on modest hardware consistent with that owned by students. Specifically, this work compares DeepSeek and Llama models on typical student assignments and describes some implications for pedagogy.

title: Active Replay for Continual Learning in Plant Species Classification
authors: Dinis Costa, Joana Costa, Bernardete Ribeiro, José Paulo Sousa, Rui Pedro Paiva, José Rafael Silva, Rui Lourenço, Catarina Silva
abstract: Continual Learning (CL) is essential in dynamic environments, such as biodiversity monitoring, due to the continuous emergence of new species or changes in their distribution over time. A major challenge in CL is catastrophic forgetting, where a model loses performance on previously learned classes as it learns new ones. One common approach to mitigate this issue is replay, in which samples from previous tasks are reintroduced during training. We investigate how Active Learning (AL) can improve replay strategies for the classification of plant species in a class-incremental learning setting. Specifically, we compare two AL-based sampling methods: selecting samples with the lowest confidence and those with the highest confidence, with a baseline random sampling strategy. The results show that while all methods achieve similar final accuracy, AL-based strategies significantly reduce catastrophic forgetting. High-confidence sampling reduces forgetting by 11.9 percentage points, while low-confidence sampling achieves a reduction of 9.2 percentage points compared to random sampling. We apply CL in a real-world scenario rather than a benchmark dataset, demonstrating its practical relevance for dynamic and evolving environments. Hence, our approach contributes to biodiversity monitoring, with the potential to support the development of a biodiversity index for tracking species diversity over time.

title: Attribute-Based Credentials with Verifiable Human Binding: towards Compactness and Revocability
authors: Yulin Liu, Debiao He, Jianting Ning, Zijian Bao, Cong Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Digital and physical identity authentications are often implemented concurrently to meet strict access control for online services. Although privacy-preserving digital credentials provide strong guarantees such as anonymity and minimal disclosure, these benefits are compromised if holders must simultaneously present physical identification (e.g., government issued IDs) to establish ownership. To securely bind digital credentials to their physical holders while preserving privacy, a new protocol called card-based anonymous credentials (cbAC) was proposed by Hesse et al. (USENIX Security'23). However, this approach faces two significant drawbacks: the size of the communication during credential presentation scales linearly with the number of disclosed attributes, and it lacks revocability, which is essential for internal governance, including identity management and accountability. In this paper, we bridge the above gap by first introducing a constant-size two-party proof of knowledge protocol in asymmetry settings, where there exists a disparity in storage and computational resources between the two parties. Furthermore, building upon this two-party proof of knowledge protocol and utilizing signatures with randomizable keys, we meticulously design a cbAC scheme that is both efficient and capable of supporting revocation. We formalize all notions and conduct a rigorous security proof of the proposed construction. Finally, we present benchmarks from our implementation to illustrate the better than-state-of-the-art performance and features of our solutions.

title: A Two-Layer Metadata Framework for Cross-Platform Sharing of Ergonomics Digital Human Models
authors: Yating Zhang, Jianwei Niu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: To address the long-standing challenges of sharing and reusing ergonomics-oriented digital human models across heterogeneous modeling platforms (e.g., Jack, RAMSIS, Unity, and OpenSim), this paper proposes a two-layer metadata framework that unifies representation while preserving platform-specific requirements. At its core, the Universal Metadata Layer specifies platform-agnostic descriptors for common DHM content—including anthropometry, skeletal topology, basic kinematic parameters, functional tags, and identification/version information—thereby providing a consistent “lingua franca” for model exchange. On top of it, the Platform Adaptation Layer supplies bidirectional adapters that map the universal schema to proprietary data structures and APIs of individual tools, enabling loss-aware conversions and extensibility when direct one-to-one mappings are not available. The framework further incorporates versioning and update mechanisms to ensure lifecycle traceability and consistency management of standardized digital humans. Collectively, these design choices lower migration costs, mitigate semantic fragmentation, and allow digital standard humans to function as reusable “standard resources” that can flow coherently through product design, verification, and evaluation stages—ultimately improving the efficiency and fidelity of ergonomics simulation workflows.

title: Automated Analysis of Naturalistic Recordings in Early Childhood: Applications, challenges, and opportunities
authors: Jialu Li, Marvin Lavechin, Xulin Fan, Nancy L. McElwain, Alejandrina Cristia, Paola Garcia-Perera, Mark A. Hasegawa-Johnson
abstract: Naturalistic recordings capture audio in real-world environments where participants behave naturally without interference from researchers or experimental protocols. Naturalistic long-form recordings extend this concept by capturing spontaneous and continuous interactions over extended periods, often spanning hours or even days, in participants’ daily lives. Naturalistic recordings have been extensively used to study children’s behaviors, including how they interact with others in their environment, in the fields of psychology, education, cognitive science, and clinical research. These recordings provide an unobtrusive way to observe children in real-world settings beyond controlled and constrained experimental environments. Advancements in speech technology and machine learning (ML) have provided an initial step for researchers to automatically and systematically analyze large-scale naturalistic recordings of children. Despite the imperfect accuracy of ML models, these tools still offer valuable opportunities to uncover important insights into children’s cognitive and social development. Several critical speech technologies involved include speaker diarization, vocalization classification, word count estimate from adults, speaker verification, and language diarization for code switching. Most of these technologies have been primarily developed for adults, and speech technologies applied to children specifically are still vastly underexplored. To fill this gap, we discuss current progress, challenges, and opportunities in advancing these technologies to analyze naturalistic recordings of children during early development (<3 years of age). We strive to inspire the signal processing community and foster interdisciplinary collaborations to further develop this emerging technology and address its unique challenges and opportunities.

title: Assessing and Mitigating Multi-Turn Jailbreak Vulnerabilities in Large Language Models: A Crescendo Attack Study
authors: Muhammad Saad, Shafaq Fatima Mughal, Muhammad Mustafa, Ikhlas Ahmed, Adnan Masood
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are vulnerable to multi-turn jailbreak attacks like Crescendo, which exploit context retention to bypass safety mechanisms and generate harmful outputs. This study is among the first to address the gap in understanding vulnerabilities of LLMs released after 2024 by reproducing the Crescendo attack on six recent models. We introduce two novel mitigation strategies—prompt hardening and LLM-as-guardrail—evaluated via Attack Success Rates (ASRs) across 15 tasks. Our contributions include these mitigation strategies, a comprehensive vulnerability assessment, and an open-source framework shared under the MIT License to foster collaborative AI safety research. Findings reveal that Llama-3.1-8b-Instruct (Llama 3.1) was the most resistant, achieving the lowest ASRs in 9 of 15 categories due to robust safety alignment, while DeepSeek-R1-Distill-Qwen-32B (DeepSeek R1) was highly vulnerable with 1.0 ASRs in 13 categories. Prompt hardening significantly outperformed LLM-as-guardrail, reducing ASRs effectively across models, though DeepSeek R1 maintained 1.0 ASRs despite mitigations. These results underscore prompt hardening as a superior defense, enhancing LLM security for safer deployment in critical domains like healthcare, education, and public policy.

title: A Range-Doppler Domain Registration Method Based on Searching for The Minimum Error in The Intersection Distance Space
authors: Hua Zhang, Yiheng Liu, Qinghai Dong, Xuemei Wang, Xiaode Lyu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This study investigates the registration issue in a mobile passive multistatic radar system that consists of multiple illuminators of opportunity and a single receiver. Based on the geometric relationships among high peaks in multiple RangeDoppler Maps (RDMs), a registration method searching for the minimum error in the intersection distance space is proposed. Furthermore, by employing a unit-based range-Doppler domain registration method, incoherent fusion from multiple sources is achieved, enhancing the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for target detection. Additionally, compared to traditional methods such as spatial direct search registration detection methods or phase compensation registration detection methods, this method further reduces false alarm rates. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of this method.

title: IoT Medical Network Security System Based Explainable AI Model
authors: Abdallah Altrad
abstract: Internet of Things (IoTs) technology built new useful data transmission networks alongside the existing networking systems. Technology has revolutionized various aspects of life such as healthcare systems, smart home, smart vehicles, etc. However, it also showed security weaknesses due to a lack of regulation and standards. This causes security threats and risks to malicious exploitation and therefore hacking opportunities. The digital vulnerabilities are a big concern in medical systems; to highlight this issue, this paper designed a simple ease of use AI-based intrusion detection framework that can detect and classify traffic of IoT networks to normal or malicious in real-time manner. To accomplish the goal of this research, CICIoMT2024 dataset is applied, which includes diverse IoT traffic data and features commonly targeted by attackers. The machine learning models trained on this dataset showed impressive results, achieving up to 97% accuracy in classifying network traffic for cybersecurity applications.

title: Optimized Tree-Structured LoRa Networks for Energy-Efficient Data Aggregation
authors: Anil Kumar, Rahul Kumar, Ruchika Rana, Ajay Ravidas
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Employing Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to predict traffic accidents presents a variety of significant benefits that could transform the industry. Their remarkable ability to effectively extract spatial features and automatically learn them greatly boosts hybrid models’ performance, achieving an impressive accuracy rate of 95% when integrated with XGBoost. This allows CNNs to proficiently process and gain insights from complex data, leading to marked improvements in predictive accuracy for traffic accident forecasting and safety management. By consolidating information from multiple sources, CNNs support the development of innovative approaches to accident prevention within a broader traffic management context. Looking ahead, there is considerable potential for further research, which could focus on developing sophisticated CNN architectures and utilizing more pertinent input data from conventional traffic accident prediction sources—ultimately enhancing road safety and traffic management efficiency. In this research, we provide a novel tree-structure-based information forwarding routing technique. To develop energy-efficient adaptive information forwarding in a decentralized manner, we modify wireless sensors in this study to choose better neighbour LoRa nodes.According to the suggested procedure, a wireless sensor first gathers the state and action data of its nearby LoRa node, including the distance and direction of information transmission, the amount of energy left, and the energy used for the information transmission action. For the future generation of IoT, where mesh topology is primarily used in current networks, LoRa technology is a possible alternative. This paper describes a LoRabased tree network and communication protocol that accounts for energy constraints. When employing LoRa technology, the nodes self-configure according to the physical link’s behaviour and forwarding, where mesh nodes are used to gather information when scalable. Analytical, computational, and experimental results show that the suggested approaches achieve energy efficiency and produce notable gains in energy performance. These findings provide helpful starting points for optimizing large-scale IoT networks. According to the experimental results, this approach also enhanced the lifetime of the entire LoRa network and reduced energy consumption in LoRa nodes.
