title: Improved DDoS Attack Detection Through PCA-Enhanced Ensemble Machine Learning Approach
authors: Soumya Snigdha Mohapatra, Sourav Parija, Debendra Muduli, Santosh Kumar Sharma, Rakesh Ranjan Kumar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Distributed Denial-of-Service (DDoS) attacks pose a serious threat to network infrastructure by overwhelming systems with traffic from multiple sources, leading to service disruptions. Detecting such attacks in real time remains a complex challenge in cybersecurity, especially as reliance on digital platforms and financial transactions continues to grow. This study explores the effectiveness of combining Principal Component Analysis (PCA) with machine learning algorithms to detect and classify DDoS attacks using network log data. PCA, a dimensionality reduction technique, is employed to streamline data processing, enhance model efficiency, and mitigate overfitting. By reducing data complexity, PCA helps improve both the speed and accuracy of machine learning models. Several classifiers are evaluated in this research, including Logistic Regression, K-Nearest Neighbours (KNN), Support Vector Machines (SVM), Naïve Bayes, Decision Trees, Random Forest, AdaBoost, and XGBoost. Among these, ensemble methods, particularly when integrated with PCA, demonstrated superior performance. Experimental results revealed a detection accuracy of 97.86%, highlighting the potential of this hybrid approach. This high accuracy is particularly valuable in handling high-dimensional datasets commonly found in network traffic analysis. The findings underscore the critical role of dimensionality reduction in improving the effectiveness of cybersecurity solutions driven by machine learning, making this integration a promising direction for real-time DDoS detection and network protection.

title: Student Feedback on Technology Enhanced Learning during COVID-19 Pandemic in the First Internal Medicine Clinical Postings of MBBS Program
authors: Benjamin Samraj Prakash Earnest, Su Yin Lim, Anitha Ponnupillai, Prabal Bhargava, Gnandev Phutane, Win Min Thien, Ajitha Ponnupillai
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The aim of this study is to explore if the internal medicine posting in the first clinical year was dynamic enough to respond by adopting technology enhanced learning (TEL) to situational challenges by comparing student evaluation of the postings before and during the pandemic-instigated movement control order (MCO). The study retrospectively analysed responses from an anonymous, online self-administered student satisfaction survey which all third-year medical students were required to complete at the end of the seven-week internal medicine module. Thirty relevant items were selected for analysis, covering module workload and organization, student progress, delivery of teaching and learning, learning resources, learning environment, and assessments. Responses comprised of a 5-point Likert scale ranging from Strongly disagree = 1 to Strongly agree = 5. Respondents were grouped into either Before MCO or During MCO according to the timing of their module. Differences in the responses between the two unpaired groups were inferred using the Mann-Whitney U test (significant p value < 0.05). There were 145 respondents in total, of which 61 were classed as Before MCO and 84 as During MCO. Respondents in the During MCO group generally felt that the learning sessions were better organized and adhered better to the timetables (median 4, IQR 4-5 vs median 4, IQR 3-4, p 0.0001), that the instructors were more responsive to their needs (median 5, IQR 4-5 vs median 4, IQR 4-5, p 0.04), that module facilitators dealt effectively with their problems (median 5, IQR 4-5 vs median 4, IQR 4-5, p 0.005), and that (online) case-based learning was useful (median 5, IQR 4-5 vs median 4, IQR 4-5, 0.008) compared to the Before MCO group. All other items showed comparable responses between the two groups. Students‟ evaluation showed comparable or better outcomes in the during MCO group compared to before MCO group. Online TEL can offer a satisfactory experience comparable to that of face-to-face learning in the first clinical year (3rd year) of MBBS program.

title: Sarcasm Detection in Social Media Texts Using Natural Language Processing Techniques
authors: Ansh Tandale, Vaidat Patel, Aditi Yawale, Aukshani Londhe, Dhananjay Bhagat
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: In the digital age, sarcasm is very hard to detect, it presents a significant challenge to sentiment analysis and natural language understanding systems. This research investigates application of machine learning algorithms to classify the data as sarcastic or non-sarcastic, emphasizing the tweets and its class. The data set was originally having four classes, which were optimized to combine irony and sarcasm as a sarcastic comment and normal and figurative as a non-sarcastic comment. Pre-processing techniques like text cleaning, stop-word removal, Tokenization, Vectorization etc. were used to remove noisy data and enhance feature selection.

title: Computational Simulations and Structural Analysis of Bispecific Aptamers Targeting Dual Biomarkers for Enhanced Ovarian Cancer Diagnosis
authors: Vyom Sharma, Gaurav Sharma
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: Ovarian cancer ranks as the third most common gynecological malignancy. It presents significant global health challenges due to its high mortality rates, mainly resulting from late-stage diagnoses and inadequate early detection methods. Existing diagnostic techniques primarily focus on identifying morphological changes in the ovaries, which often overlook early cellular-level alterations, resulting in delayed diagnoses. Consequently, early detection is crucial for preventing cancer progression and improving patient survival rates. Aptamers, small nucleotide sequences that specifically bind to target proteins, represent a novel approach for identifying tumor cells. Recent advances include the design of a bispecific aptamer capable of detecting exosomes released by ovarian cancer cells. We hypothesize that these aptamers can specifically bind to the receptor surface and can be used to detect ovarian cancer. The current research utilized computational methods to investigate the binding capabilities of aptamers to surface receptors (EpCAM and CD24) present on exosomes. By predicting the aptamers secondary and tertiary structures, we performed molecular docking simulations to assess their interactions with the target receptors. Our findings indicate that the aptamers Apt1 and Apt2 exhibit strong binding affinities, warranting their selection for further evaluation. The docked structures were further validated by using the GrASP web server, which is a machine learning based method to enhance the accuracy of our predictions. This research contributes to identifying the most effective aptamers for binding to exosome surfaces, which may potentially advance ovarian cancer screening methods.

title: SARD: Segmentation-Aware Anomaly Synthesis via Region-Constrained Diffusion with Discriminative Mask Guidance
authors: Yanshu Wang, Xichen Xu, Xiaoning Lei, Guoyang Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Synthesizing anomalies that are both realistic and spatially precise is most valuable when it directly benefits pixelwise segmentation. Recent diffusion-based methods show strong generative capacity but often lack spatial controllability and can unintentionally alter background content. We propose SARD (Segmentation-Aware Anomaly Synthesis via Region-Constrained Diffusion with Discriminative Mask Guidance), a diffusion-based framework tailored for segmentation-oriented anomaly generation. Specifically, Region-Constrained Diffusion (RCD) performs a masked reverse update: the posterior sample is written only inside the anomaly mask while the background is passed through from the current noisy input, preventing background drift outside the target region. In addition, a Discriminative Mask Guidance (DMG) module augments the discriminator with a mask-aware branch that supplies localized adversarial feedback for sharper textures and boundary alignment. Extensive experiments on MVTec-AD and BTAD, across SegFormer and BiSeNet V2 backbones, show consistent gains in mIoU and pixel accuracy over strong baselines. By explicitly coupling background preservation with mask-guided discrimination, SARD advances segmentationaware anomaly synthesis.

title: An Improved FBLMS Direct Path Interference Suppression Algorithm for Passive Bistatic Radar Systems
authors: Li Zhang, Qinglong Bao, Xuesong Wang, Long Chen
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Passive bistatic radar systems face interference from direct path signals during the processing of received pulsed echo signals. This interference can obscure target signals, making target detection difficult. Traditional Frequency-domain Block Least Mean Square (FBLMS) algorithms are typically designed for continuous wave signals and struggle to balance convergence speed and steady-state error, resulting in poor direct path interference suppression. To address this, we propose a Kalman filtering-based FBLMS algorithm. By using the Kalman gain to update the weight coefficients, instead of a fixed step size, we mitigate the impact of inter-pulse intervals on convergence, improve iteration speed and steady-state error, and thus maximize the preservation of the target signal. Experimental results demonstrate that, compared to fixed-step-size and other improved algorithms, our proposed algorithm achieves faster convergence, effectively suppresses direct path interference, and has a minimal impact on the target echo.

title: Artificial Intelligence Innovations and Strategic Insights for a Smart Retail Transformation
authors: Firas Omar, Mohammad R. Hassan, Shadi Nashwan, Ahmad Al-Qerem, Ali Mohd Ali
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming consumer engagement and store operations across the retail sector. This paper looks at basic technology, present uses, implementation difficulties, ethical concerns, future directions, and artificial intelligence’s effects on retail. We go over customer segmentation, demand forecasting, price optimisation, and mechanics, advantages, and pragmatic examples of recommendation systems. The paper addresses corporate governance in artificial intelligence research and development, algorithmic bias, and data privacy. The environmental impact of large-scale data processing, potential job displacement, and challenges surrounding intellectual property in an AI-driven retail sector also warrant close examination, as AI promises unprecedented personalization and efficiency. The paper uses an integrated approach to show retail AI’s transforming possibilities and responsibilities. The paper underlines future research, offers safe AI application directions, and concludes that artificial intelligence is necessary for surviving in the changing retail sector.

title: On Ambiguity in 6-DoF Electromagnetic Pose Estimation Systems_supp3-3649744.mp4
authors: Heng Wang
abstract: Magnetic pose estimation is an accurate, noncontacting pose tracking method that is insusceptible to occlusion, making it widely used for tracking intracorporeal medical robots and devices in minimally invasive interventions. However, the ambiguity problem in magnetic pose estimation has been long overlooked that could result in inaccuracy and even divergence of pose tracking. This article is devoted to fundamentally investigating the ambiguity issue in 6-DoF electromagnetic pose estimation systems. Magnetic ambiguity is formally defined, and its existence and impacts on pose estimation are analyzed for single-magnet and dual-magnet tracking systems, then generalized to multiple-magnet systems. It is found that there are different types of ambiguity, each with distinct influence on pose estimation. Efficient algorithms are proposed to systematically identify all ambiguous poses in a workspace. The ambiguity in typical configurations of dual-magnet systems is identified and discussed. It is found that ambiguity can be completely eliminated by using at least THREE magnetic sources. An unambiguous tri-magnet system is proposed by combining the collocated and parallel dual-magnet systems and validated by tracking a continuum robot. This article lays the foundation for optimizing configurations of magnetic sources and designing compact, energy-efficient, but unambiguous magnetic tracking systems with minimum number of magnetic sources.

title: Dil-RWKV: A Hybrid Framework for Automated AIF Selection and Enhanced Hemodynamic Quantification in Dynamic Contrast - Enhanced Medical Imaging
authors: Jiaxuan Zhang, Yu Shen, Feng Xi, Jinhong Tao, Lei Lei
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Accurate identification of the arterial input function (AIF) is critical for reliable quantification of hemodynamic parameters in dynamic contrast-enhanced (DCE) medical imaging. However, conventional manual or semi-automatic approaches are inherently subjective and inefficient. In this study, we propose Dil-RWKV, a novel hybrid architecture that integrates dilated convolutional layers with the Recurrent Weighted Key-Value (RWKV) framework to achieve fully automated and robust AIF selection. The model hierarchically extracts multi-scale temporal dynamics via dilated convolutions and enforces spectral coherence through a dual-domain optimization strategy that leverages time-frequency representations in the Fourier domain. Temporal consistency is further enhanced using RWKV’s linear attention mechanism, while a multimodal scoring module facilitates accurate AIF voxel discrimination. Compared to traditional and Transformer-based methods, Dil-RWKV achieves a 54.1% reduction in parameter complexity without compromising fidelity in hemodynamic estimation. Extensive validation on multi-institutional DCE-MRI datasets demonstrates high correlation with expert-annotated cerebral blood volume (CBV) maps, confirming its clinical reliability. The proposed framework offers a reproducible and scalable solution for automated perfusion analysis, promoting translational applications in neurovascular imaging.

title: Modeling the Impact of U.S.-China Flight Connectivity on Pandemic Dynamics and China’s Economy
authors: Yuhong Mu, Mengyu Jiang, Shanshan Zhang, Lichao Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International conference on Medical Artificial Intelligence (MedAI)
abstract: The international aviation network has facilitated global population movement. This has not only significantly contributed to the cross-border spread of infectious diseases, but has also had substantial economic consequences worldwide during the pandemic. Thus, understanding the dynamic relationship between mobility, epidemic spread, and economic trends is crucial for informing more balanced and adaptive public health and economic policies. Existing models have a tendency to prioritize infection trends, neglecting to account for the nonlinear interplay between population mobility, epidemic spread, and economic fluctuations. We propose a hybrid model architecture that combines the graph sample and aggregate (GraphSAGE) algorithm for modeling spatial dependencies driven by population flow and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) for capturing temporal patterns of infections and economic indicators. The simulation results demonstrate the model’s capacity to predict infection dynamics and economic trends accurately. These findings underscore the value of data-driven strategies in enabling timely public health responses and in supporting the formulation of coordinated cross-border mobility policies during global health emergencies.

title: From Chaos to Stability: Entropy and Volatility Dynamics in the Indian Stock Market Over Three Decades
authors: Avik Das, Jyoti Dutta, Suddhasanta De, Susovon Jana, Keya Das Ghosh, Manisha Dey
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Financial crises adversely affect investors wealth through increasing volatility and decreasing asset prices that ultimately reduce portfolio valuation. To safeguard investors’ wealth, one must clearly understand how stock market volatility and efficiency change throughout periods. This study investigates stock market entropy and volatility dynamics to reveal uncertainty and complexity in the Indian market. This study analyses 7,248 trading days from 1995 to 2024, applying the Shannon entropy formula. Daily trading data are collected from the NSE website, and R Studio is used for empirical analysis. The findings show that market post-crisis recovery phases exhibit elevated market entropy levels with decreased price volatility reflecting market efficiency. But during crises, it reveals high volatility and low entropy that signify inefficiency and market predictability. The study delivers practical knowledge that helps policymakers and investors to devise approaches for managing and stabilizing their portfolio risk levels. Analysis results can serve as early signs of financial instability and highlight the importance of strategic actions.

title: Optimized Deep Learning Model for Power Consumption Prediction Using Hyperparameter Tuning Techniques
authors: Charchit Gharai, Sunil Kumar Mohapatra, Somanath Parida, Chinmayee Dora, Raj Kumar Mohanta, Sujata Chakravarty
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Accurate prediction of power consumption is crucial for effective energy management, operational planning, and sustainability. Due to urbanization and industrialization, analyzing and predicting household energy consumption has become essential. According to earlier research, machine learning models play a key role in this area. However, these models are limited in their ability to handle complex data patterns. To address this issue, this research applied deep learning models, including Recurrent Neural Networks (RNN), Long Short-Term Memory Networks (LSTM), and Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), along with advanced hyperparameter optimization techniques for power consumption predictions. These optimization techniques include Optuna, Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO), Cuckoo Search, and Ant Colony Optimization (ACO). The model was trained and tested on the household_power_consumption dataset obtained from the Kaggle open-source data repository. The results show that without using the optimization techniques, LSTM demonstrated better baseline performance with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.9601. After hyperparameter optimization, the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> scores achieved by the LSTM, GRU, and RNN using Optuna were 0.9982, 0.9982, 0.9888, and 0.9779, respectively. It was found that LSTM is the most effective model for power consumption prediction, particularly when optimized with the Optuna technique. Thus, this research signifies a new direction for applying optimized deep learning models in the development of robust energy management systems.

title: Detection of Adversarial Evasion Attack on AI Model Running on IoT Devices
authors: Fatimah Alaliwat, Lena Alqahtani, Manar Alzahrani, Nouf Alamoudi, Shaima Hakami, Abdulrahman Alharby
abstract: The attack surface of adversarial is expanding with the wider application of AI-driven IoT devices. It is thus very crucial to research and come up with defense mechanisms. This paper will cover an evasion attack in which the attacker tampers with input and sends the input to bypass detection instead of manipulating the model itself. It provides the unauthorized capacity to carry out data transmission without being detected. We cover the types of adversarial attacks, bring to light the security risks in AI models, and provide a critical examination of existing detection solutions for evasion attacks. Gap analysis is also provided for the revelation of deficiencies in current methods.

title: AzureIQ-RAG: Hybrid RAG System for Automated Information Retrieval and Semantic Query Answering Using Azure AI
authors: Ishtiaque Mahmood, Mahammad Mastan, Zunysha Naveed, Hamza Iftikhar, Wakeel Ahmad, Syed M. Adnan
abstract: Extracting relevant information from documents and websites is a time-consuming task that becomes increasingly complex as document length grows and websites expand. Manually retrieving precise information to meet user requirements from large documents and extensive websites is challenging and inefficient. In this context, Artificial Intelligence (AI) has emerged as a transformative technology, offering unparalleled capabilities for automating systems. AI has been widely utilized to streamline various processes, demonstrating its potential to simplify complex tasks, enhance accuracy, and reduce human effort. This research paper introduces "AzureIQ-RAG" Azure powered Intelligent Query and Hybrid Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) system with two primary features: (1) extracting and retrieving information from diverse document formats, including PDF, TXT, DOCX, etc. and enabling question-answering based on the provided document(s), (2) extracting content from website and enabling question-answering regarding the content of the website. The system automates the extraction process from both documents and websites. The extracted content is segmented, embedded using Azure OpenAI Embeddings, and indexed in Azure Cognitive Search for efficient retrieval and then a reranking mechanism is applied to improve precision and accuracy further. Then the final response is generated by passing the relevant content and user query to the Large Language Model (LLM) GPT -4 omni. Additionally, the system maintains separate session memory for both document and website searches, ensuring context retention for improved query handling and user experience. The document processing feature of the system has been tested on a dataset of over 950+ documents of various formats and achieved an accuracy of 94.77 %, and the website feature of the system is tested on 50+ different websites, achieving an accuracy of 75.22%.

title: A Novel Approach Combining Physics-Informed Neural Networks and Parabolic Equations for Maritime Propagation Modeling
authors: Zoubair Alimouch, Mohamed Et-Tolba, Najib Naja
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Advanced Communication Technologies and Networking (CommNet)
abstract: Modeling electromagnetic (EM) wave propagation is critical for achieving efficient and reliable transmissions in maritime communication systems. Indeed, the signal propagation in this environment is strongly affected by several factors including surface roughness, diffraction, and atmospheric ducting. Even though traditional methods like ray tracing and mode theory analysis are computationally efficient, they often fail to capture the irregularities caused by these factors. The parabolic equation (PE) model has proved successful in addressing this issue but remains computationally intensive. This paper proposes a physics-informed neural network (PINN) approach that integrates the PE model with real-world data. The idea is to decompose the complex wave field into real and imaginary components, considering impedance boundary conditions, rough sea reflections, and wide-angle Padé approximation. Simulation results show that the proposed method significantly improves both accuracy and generalizability compared to the conventional models.

title: Trusted AI for Medical Image Classification using AE-DBN and Secure Blockchain Transmission
authors: Kush Patel, Chaithanya Bogadi, Pradyumna Amasebail Kodgi, N Samanvita, Shailaja Nilesh Uke
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Data security has been a hot topic in e-health since data sharing began. Digitization has sped up operations and increased cyberattack risk. Hackers seem to target medical documents. Past data breaches have driven new security practices to prevent future breaches. Recently developed blockchain technology is a wonderful tool for preserving private data. To protect medical data, the zero trust security model requires all steps, including transmission, to be secured. This paper reviews existing works on similar themes to provide a decentralized and trustless system for safe medical pictures and data sharing and storage. A timely and accurate diagnosis is needed to treat gastrointestinal illnesses like ulcerative colitis, polyps, and esophagitis. To show a Kvasir dataset Autoencoder-deep belief network (AE-DBN) model that automatically classifies gastrointestinal abnormal symptoms. The proposed AE-DBN model combines Autoencoders' unsupervised feature extraction with Deep Belief Networks' hierarchical classification. Experimental results show that the AE-DBN framework efficiently extracts discriminative features, resulting in more accurate and resilient classifications than classic deep learning methods. The results suggest that AE-DBN could be an artificial intelligence-driven gastrointestinal disease diagnostic tool due to its increased feature learning, classification accuracy, and processing efficiency.

title: CACBH-Net: A CNN-Attention BiLSTM Hybrid Deep Learning Model for Enhanced Detection of Epileptic Seizure
authors: Smitaranjan Tripathy, Brajesh Kumar, Adyasha Rath, Ganapati Panda
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Reliable and early identification of epileptic seizures plays a vital role in improving clinical outcomes and supporting real-time therapeutic responses. Electroencephalogram (EEG) signals, despite being rich in brain activity information, are nonlinear and complex, which makes manual analysis both labor-intensive and prone to subjectivity. To address this challenge, we propose CACBH, a combined deep learning based architecture that aims at integrating CNN and BiLSTM. CNN is useful for capturing spatial representations, and BiLSTM units are effective for temporal sequence modeling, and an Attention mechanism for emphasizing clinically significant patterns in the EEG signal. The input signals are processed using bandpass filtering (0.5–40 Hz), z-score normalization, and segmented into 10-second intervals. The model’s training and testing is based on the CHB-MIT Scalp EEG dataset using a stratified data split that preserves the ratio of seizure to non-seizure events. Results show that CACBH achieves an impressive accuracy of 95.03%, surpassing traditional CNN and LSTM approaches. The attention layer improves interpretability by focusing on seizure-relevant features, while the overall architecture provides consistent detection performance. Evaluation through confusion matrices and classification metrics further validates the system’s reliability. Overall, CACBH shows promise as a deployable and scalable solution for automated seizure monitoring in both hospital-based EEG systems and portable health devices.

title: Flying Co-Stereo: Enabling Long-Range Aerial Dense Mapping via Collaborative Stereo Vision of Dynamic-Baseline
authors: Zhaoying Wang, Xingxing Zuo, Wei Dong
abstract: For Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms operating in large-scale unknown environments, lightweight long-range mapping is crucial for enhancing safe navigation. Traditional stereo cameras constrained by a short fixed baseline suffer from limited perception ranges. To overcome this limitation, we present Flying Co-Stereo, a cross-agent collaborative stereo vision system that leverages the wide-baseline spatial configuration of two UAVs for long-range dense mapping. However, realizing this capability presents several challenges. First, the independent motion of each UAV leads to a dynamic and continuously changing stereo baseline, making accurate and robust estimation difficult. Second, efficiently establishing feature correspondences across independently moving viewpoints is constrained by the limited computational capacity of onboard edge devices. To tackle these challenges, we introduce the Flying Co-Stereo system within a novel Collaborative Dynamic-Baseline Stereo Mapping (CDBSM) framework. We first develop a dual-spectrum visual-inertial ranging estimator to achieve robust and precise online estimation of the baseline between the two UAVs. In addition, we propose a hybrid feature association strategy that integrates cross-agent feature matching—based on a computationally intensive yet accurate deep neural network—with intra-agent, optical-flow based lightweight feature tracking. Furthermore, benefiting from the wide baselines between the two UAVs, our system accurately recovers long-range co-visible 3D sparse points. We then employ a monocular depth network to predict up-to-scale dense depth maps, which are refined using accurate metric scales derived from the triangulated sparse points via exponential fitting. Extensive real-world experiments demonstrate that the proposed Flying Co-Stereo system achieves robust and accurate dynamic baseline estimation in complex environments while maintaining efficient feature matching with resource-constrained computers under varying viewpoints. Ultimately, our system achieves dense 3D mapping at distances of up to 70 meters with a relative error between 2.3% and 9.7%. This corresponds to up to a 350% improvement in maximum perception range and up to a 450% increase in coverage area compared to conventional stereo vision systems with fixed compact baselines.

title: Time-Varying Low-Rank Recurrent Networks for Predicting and Interpreting Seizure Dynamics
authors: Jingzhe Lin, Ziwei Ou, Guangyu Yang, Weiting Sun, Zhichao Liang, Quanying Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Accurate seizure prediction and a mechanistic understanding of seizure dynamics are critical for improving the diagnosis and treatment of epilepsy. However, modeling and interpreting these complex neural dynamics remain a major challenge. In this study, we present a hypernetwork-based low-rank recurrent neural network (LR-RNN) that dynamically adapts its connectivity to predict and characterize time-varying seizure dynamics. We validate our model on both simulated Jansen-Rit models and real intracranial sEEG recordings from epilepsy patients. Our model exhibits high predictive accuracy, effectively capturing the onset and propagation of seizures. Furthermore, we conduct a compact, interpretable phase portrait analysis in a low-dimensional state space, enabling visualization and exploration of seizure trajectories over time. This geometric representation highlights distinct transitions between pre-ictal and ictal states, providing new insights into the underlying mechanisms of seizure evolution. Our work offers a unified computational framework for seizure forecasting and the interpretability of neural dynamics in epilepsy.

title: Co-Ideating with Caregivers and Healthcare Professionals: Socio-Technical Strategies to Support Early Childhood Nutrition
authors: Deysi Ortega, Rosario M. Bartolini, Rossina Pareja, Katarzyna Stawarz, Hilary M. Creed-Kanashiro, Michelle Holdsworth, Paula Griffiths, Emily Rousham, Nervo Verdezoto
publish: ACM Transactions on Computing for Healthcare

title: Lightweight U2-Net ECG signal reconstruction model with attention fusion
authors: Junchen Lu, Ping Hu, Lei Zhao, Min Xiang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This study focuses on improving the ECG readability of wearable ECG monitoring devices with finite leads, and explores a model capable of reconstructing standard 12-lead ECG signals from finite-lead signals. First, the performance and computational efficiency of U2-Net are optimized by streamlining its parametric number and computation; second, the 2D standard convolution of the RSU module in U2-Net is replaced by a 1D multi-scale convolution in order to enhance the model’s ability of capturing multi-scale features; furthermore, a differential convolution is introduced in the RSU module in order to highlight the characteristics of the R-wave in the ECG signals; lastly, this paper, with respect to the spatio-temporal and lead characteristics, a quadruple attention mechanism is proposed to enhance the model’s ability to perceive key ECG features. The experimental results show that the model proposed in this paper performs better in terms of reconstruction effect than the existing traditional models such as U2-Net, U-Net, LSTM and TCN. Among them, compared with the traditional model U2-Net, the amount of parameters of this paper’s model is reduced by $95.62 \%$, and the amount of computation is reduced by $85.64 \%$; compared with the traditional model U-Net, the root-mean-square error (RMSE) of this paper’s model is reduced by $13.87 \%$ year-on-year, and the mean absolute error (MAE) is reduced by $49.01 \%$ year-on-year; compared with the traditional model TCN, the correlation coefficient (CC) improved by $11.82 \%$ year-on-year. The reconstruction model proposed in this paper not only significantly streamlines the number of parameters and computation of traditional U2-Net, but also improves the reconstruction effect on ECG signals.

title: A Probabilistic Approach for Drift Compensation of Gas Sensor Data
authors: Gabriel F.A. Bastos, Jugurta Montalvão, Luiz Miranda
abstract: Long-term drift is widely recognized as a key challenge in gas sensing systems, undermining the reliability and accuracy of these systems over time, as the pattern recognition systems lose their capability of performing gas discrimination. In this work, we employ a probabilistic modeling framework to address the drift problem. This perspective yields a novel scheme for drift compensation, which is grounded on probabilistic modelling. The potential usefulness of the proposed approach is demonstrated through an experimental evaluation on the classification task, which reveals consistently higher accuracy and stability when compared to baseline methods. In addition to its robustness, the proposed method also presents several desired attributes such as, computational simplicity, continuous adaptability and suitability for online applications. The experiments were conducted using a dataset acquired in an interval of 7 months, comprising nearly 4000 measurements from three different gases at different concentration levels in an array containing 17 polymeric sensors.

title: Developing a Knowledge Management Model for a Small IT Business
authors: Fletscher Luis, Bedoya Dago
abstract: Knowledge management (KM) is a critical process for organizations aiming to maintain competitiveness and drive innovation. Small businesses, however, often struggle to retain and circulate knowledge, particularly in the face of high staff turnover and dynamic market conditions. This study presents the design and implementation of a customized KM model for a small IT company specializing in cybersecurity. The proposed model is aligned with the company's value chain and strategic planning, integrating G Suite tools to streamline knowledge processes and incorporating an automated idea tank to foster innovation. Developed through an iterative methodology, the model was validated and refined using feedback from organizational stakeholders. The results demonstrate that small IT firms can effectively mitigate knowledge loss and enhance innovation by adopting practical, technology-supported KM practices. Although tailored to a specific organization, the model offers transferable components and actionable insights for similar enterprises. This research highlights the strategic role of KM in enabling agility, competitiveness, and sustainable growth in rapidly changing environments.

title: Multipath-Resistant Urban Acoustic Source Localization Using an Eight-Rotary-Arm Helical Array and Enhanced Spatial Differencing
authors: Shumeng Zhang, Chongyi Fan, Yong Liu, Linhong Jiang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the degradation of localization accuracy caused by multipath effects in urban environments, this letter proposes an improved spatial differencing method combined with a subarray selection strategy for an eight-rotary-arm helical array. Conventional methods (e.g., MUSIC, Bartlett) suffer from significant performance degradation under highly correlated multipath signals, while existing spatial differencing approaches are primarily limited to one-dimensional linear arrays. In this study, the proposed subarray selection strategy based on element numbering is proposed to establish a mapping relationship between the selection matrix and array elements, thereby extending the spatial differencing method to two-dimensional arrays. Experiments using a $\mathbf{6 4}$-microphone array in a urban multipath environment demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method over traditional algorithms (spatial differencing without subarray selection, MUSIC, Bartlett). The results show that the proposed method achieves a mean square error (MSE) of 0.1011, significantly outperforming the compared algorithms (0.3311-0.4954). Additionally, the error ellipse analysis reveals a smaller deviation range, confirming its effectiveness in suppressing multipath interference and enhancing localization stability. Future work will explore the application of transfer learning models to complex array structures.

title: Comparative Analysis of NLP and Graph-Based Embedding Techniques for Malware Classification
authors: Yadhunandan Karumbayiram, Harish Loghashankar, Quang Duy Tran, Younghee Park
abstract: Malware classification is a key component in cybersecurity, where automated systems detect and then categorize malware by transforming behavioral patterns into machineunderstandable representations. Recently, embedding techniques have gained popularity, with researchers using both Natural Language Processing (NLP) and graph embeddings for malware classification. However, it remains unclear which embedding technique leads to superior results. In this study, we perform a comparative analysis between two NLP embedding techniquesWord2Vec and FastText-and a graph embedding technique, Node2Vec, applied to both directed and undirected graphs. We evaluate these embeddings using three machine learning classifiers: Support Vector Machines, Random Forest, and multilayer perceptrons. Results show that optimal embeddings vary by classifier: undirected graph-based embeddings achieved the highest F1 score ($\mathbf{0. 9 4 8 1}$) with Random Forest, while NLP embeddings performed more consistently across classifiers. Undirected graphs also outperformed directed ones, suggesting bidirectionality captures richer opcode context. These findings demonstrate novel insights into how embedding choices impact malware classification, highlighting the reliability of NLP embeddings and the superiority of undirected graph-based embeddings.

title: LLM-MTPSO: Large Language Model-Assisted Multi-Task Particle Swarm Optimization for Imbalanced Classification
authors: Guanghua Lv, Jiahui Wang, Jiping Lin, Yu Zhou
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Imbalanced data widely exists in security-prioritized domains, where minority classes often bring a disproportionately high risk. Especially in multi-class scenarios, challenges arise not only from the imbalance between majority and minority classes, but also from the difficulty in separating minority classes and their underrepresentation in the training data. To address these issues, this paper adopts a One-Versus-One decomposition strategy to transform the multi-class problem into multiple binary subtasks. This formulation naturally increases the visibility of minority classes. Furthermore, we propose a large language modelassisted multi-task particle swarm optimization (LLM-MTPSO) algorithm. Each subtask is independently optimized via PSO, while a LLM is leveraged to semantically fuse optimal solutions among similar subtasks. This mechanism facilitates knowledge transfer and refinement at the solution level, enhancing the model's capacity to recognize minority patterns. Experiments on nine imbalanced datasets show that the test results of our method in terms of imbalanced classification accuracy outperform four classical methods. The ablation experiments indicate that the introduction of LLM promotes information sharing among subtasks, thus improving the algorithm performance.

title: Two-Stage Bidirectional Inverter Equivalent Circuit Model for Distribution Grid Steady-State Analysis and Optimization
authors: Emmanuel O. Badmus, Amritanshu Pandey
abstract: This paper presents a physics-based steady-state equivalent circuit model of a two-stage bidirectional inverter. These inverters connect distributed energy resources (DERs), such as photovoltaic (PV) and battery systems, to distribution grids. Existing inverter models have technical gaps on three fronts: i) inadequate modeling of inverter losses ii) use of mathematical abstractions for bidirectional flow of power, iii) inability to integrate different control modes into nonlinear solvers without loss of generality. We propose an inverter model that explicitly captures losses in passive circuit components, grounded in circuitlevel principles. We enable bidirectional power flow without binary or complementarity constraints by formulating loss terms as smooth, sign-aware expressions of current. We introduce and parameterize controlled current sources with twice-differentiable continuous functions to enable inverter control modes without loss of generality. We integrate DERs with the proposed inverter model at the load buses of distribution networks to perform power flow and optimization studies on real-world distribution networks with over 20,000 nodes. We demonstrate that the proposed model is more accurate, integrates seamlessly with various control modes without loss of generality, and scales robustly to large optimization problems.

title: Arabic Email Spam Detection Using Machine Learning and Deep Learning: A Comparative Study
authors: Ghassan Kanaan, Motaz Zghoul, Ghazi Kanaan, Ala’ M. Al-Zoubi, Tarek Kanaan
abstract: Due to the relatively small figure of research conducted on Arabic email spam about the number of Arabic-speaking individuals using the internet, comes challenges related to Natural Language Processing in morphologically rich languages such as Arabic. The target goal of this research is to create a classification framework for spam email detection in Arabic. The recent dataset obtained from Kaggle contains phishing and legitimate emails written in Arabic. Term frequency - Inverse document frequency (TF-IDF) and word embeddings are some of the text preprocessing methods used in this research. Support Vector Machine (SVM), Naïve Bayes, and Random Forest machine learning models are used, along with Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) deep learning methods. The SVM performed best in the comparative analysis, peaking at an ROC-AUC of 98% and F1 score of 99%. These results will aid in shifting Arabic spam detection and email security in the Arabic digital world forward, showcasing the positive role machine learning can play in this process.

title: The Rise of Artificial Intelligence in the Film Industry - A Study on Story-Writing AI Applications
authors: Valarmathi Subramaniam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The advent of artificial intelligence (AI) has begun to reshape the creative landscape of filmmaking, particularly in the domain of screenwriting. Once relegated to speculative fiction, AI now emerges as a practical co-creator, offering tools capable of generating compelling narratives from minimal input. This study explores the evolving role of AI in screenwriting by evaluating story outputs generated by Bard AI against those written by human screenwriters. Using a structured, two-phase research design, the investigation compares the narratives based on five qualitative variables: plot, narration, character development, dialogue, and cultural relevance. A three-tiered input strategy—ranging from basic to extended prompts—was adopted to assess the AI's creative flexibility and responsiveness. Results show that while AI-generated stories demonstrate coherence, stylistic fluency, and efficient scene setting, they fall short in emotional depth, cultural nuance, and imaginative progression. Human-written scripts, though less structured, excel in dialogue and subtextual character portrayal. The findings highlight the potential of AI as a valuable tool in early-stage ideation and structural support, especially for Gen Z creators, while reaffirming the irreplaceable role of human imagination in storytelling. This research advocates for a hybrid screenwriting model, where AI serves as a creative assistant rather than a substitute for human authorship.

title: BiLSTM and SCA: A Multimodal Emotion Recognition Algorithm Based on Speech, Text, and Expressions
authors: Kexin Lu, Guoping Zhang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: With the development of artificial intelligence technology, emotion recognition has also developed from single modality to multimodal trend. Aiming at the problems of feature extraction and how to efficiently perform modal information fusion in multimodal emotion recognition, this paper proposes a multimodal emotion recognition algorithm based on speech, text and expression based on existing research. Firstly, openSMILE, Open L3 and RoBERTa, which are publicly available feature extractors, are used for feature extraction of speech and text modalities respectively, while Dense Convolutional Network method is used for expression feature extraction. Secondly, bidirectional long- and short-term memory is combined with self-attention and cross-attention units to form a feature fusion module, which performs feature fusion for speech, text and expression in a step-by-step manner. We assessed the proposed approach using the widely recognized multimodal emotion dataset MELD. Experimental outcomes indicate that our method attains competitive performance on this benchmark.

title: Advance Driver Assistance System: Trip planning of Electric Vehicle
authors: Sutapa Mondal, Debasree Sarkar, Arup Kumar Nandi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Present work proposes an advanced driver assistance system (ADAS) for trip planning of electric vehicle (EV) and analyses its effectiveness towards energy consumption (EC) reduction. The proposed system is an AI-based software and sensor-integrated system that assists driver by repeatedly providing optimal driving strategy (ODS) to be followed and predicting trip completion possibility after a certain interval. Prediction of EV anticipated range helps to take any useful decision in well advance including recharging. ADAS evaluates energy consumption for the remaining trip following the concerned EV drive model and find ODS using an optimization algorithm. Minimizing energy consumption, trip time and jerk are considered for optimization objectives. Effectiveness of ADAS is verified by analysing the effect of adopting ODS in a micro-trip planning with an E-bus based on experimental drive data. ADAS is found to reduce both EC and travel time than that obtained by following a random DS.

title: DOA Estimation Method of Frequency Agile Phased Array Radar Based on Optimal Fusion
authors: Yichen Shan, Baoqing Xu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: For frequency-agile phase array radar, the pulseechoes are not correlated with each other, and the signal-to-noise ratio fluctuates drastically, so it is difficult to effectively accumulate multiple unrelated snapshot data when estimating DOA, and the angle measurement accuracy is very poor. Therefore, in this paper, we study the accumulation method of multiple uncorrelated snapshot data of frequency agile phased array radar, and propose a DOA estimation method for frequency agile phased array radar based on optimal fusion, which effectively accumulates multiple snapshot data through optimal weighting, and significantly improves the accuracy of DOA estimation of frequency agile radar, Finally, the correctness and effectiveness of the method are verified by computer simulation.

title: Design of a New Reversible Logic Gate and it's Implementation in Digital Logic Family
authors: Snigdha Chowdhury Kolay, Mandakinee Bandyopadhyay, Subrata Chattopadhyay
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: In modern research, the reversible logic gate has become very popular because of its attractive features like low power consumption, decreasing the quantum cost, no. of garbage output. For those features, it has been involved in different circuit design, such as, nanotechnology, quantum computing, signal processing, optical information processing, bio-informatics, cryptography etc. Previously, different types of reversible logic gates have already been developed in different times and are also being used in different digital circuits. This paper represents the development of a new reversible gate, its input output characteristics and also some applications in the digital family. By those applications, it would be clear that the newly implemented reversible gate is more superior than the other reversible gates in terms of its minimum usage number and lower garbage value.

title: A Taxonomy of Segmentation in Network Security
authors: Rohit Dube
abstract: Segmentation has been a foundational concept in network security for decades, evolving from coarse techniques such as virtual local area networks to more granular approaches like micro-segmentation. Yet the absence of clear definitions and a standardized taxonomy has hindered consistent understanding, effective implementation, and rigorous research. This paper introduces practical definitions for key segmentation concepts and a comprehensive taxonomy for classifying methods across technologies, infrastructures, and enforcement strategies. We apply this language to describe major product categories, demonstrate its utility through a real-world enterprise case study, and use it to analyze prior research to identify under-explored areas for future work. Overall, this paper systematizes fragmented segmentation practices by providing clear definitions and a unified taxonomy that support consistent analysis of segmentation design across diverse networked environments.

title: A Cost-Effective Security Framework for Multi-Application Environments Across Multi-Domain Networks
authors: Yasser Kamal
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: This paper introduces a scalable and cost-effective security framework designed to safeguard complex enterprise IT environments that feature a mix of legacy and modern applications across multiple domains. As organizations confront rising threats and more distributed infrastructure, traditional one-size-fits-all security models are no longer adequate. The proposed architecture utilizes open-source technologies-pfSense, NGINX with ModSecurity, Active Directory, Graylog, and Wazuh-to implement layered defenses, network segmentation through a DMZ, and centralized monitoring. Empirical analysis of ten real-world scenarios shows that the framework achieves higher throughput, lower latency, and greater detection accuracy compared to existing models. The results highlight the effectiveness of a modular, opensource approach for protecting hybrid environments without depending on proprietary solutions.

title: FHSS-aided FDA Covert Communication with Instantaneous and Robust Optimization
authors: Zihao Cheng, Jiangbo Si, Zan Li, Rui Huang, Naofal Al-Dhahir
abstract: In this paper, we utilize frequency hopping spread spectrum (FHSS) to help enhance covert performance in frequency diverse array (FDA) covert system. Compared to conventional FDA covert communication, FHSS signals can hide in different channels by rapidly switching the transmission frequency to avoid being detected. Therefore, FHSS-aided FDA covert system can effectively counter the warden with strong detection ability and enhance covert performance. We focus on maximizing the covert capacity during the entire transmission by jointly optimizing the beamfoming vector and antenna frequency vector at the transmitter. Based on the system equipment constraints, two different optimization schemes, i.e., instantaneous optimization scheme (IOS) and robust optimization scheme (ROS), are proposed to solve the problem. Moreover, to evaluate the covert performance provided by FHSS-aided FDA covert communication, we introduce three benchmark schemes, i.e., phased array (PA) and logarithmic distribution FDA (Log-FDA) and non-FHSS. Simulation results demonstrate that FHSS combined with IOS can significantly improve covert performance compared to other benchmark schemes. In contrast, FHSS combined with ROS can effectively enhance covert performance when transmitting signals over a wide bandwidth.

title: Integration of the Test Mode into the Electronic Control Unit for End-of-Line Testing
authors: M. Horák
abstract: In this article, we experimentally evaluate three flash and test strategies of automotive ECUs during serial production. These strategies are: (i) a test-oriented firmware in Virgin Mode, (ii) a dual-bank parallel flash strategy, and (iii) a test that is implemented in the production firmware. The latter could not be evaluated experimentally due to cybersecurity concerns. In this section, we employ 506 flashing cycles (actual production cycles and synthetic cycles from an independent reproduction), and report process time, process jitter, and p-value. In particular, we find that the dual-bank scheme provides the best performance with a mean flashing time of 23.3 s which is a 45% improvement over Virgin Mode. The variance was reduced by a factor of 25, showing that the reduced cycle times were appropriate for a takt time sensitive environment. All differences were statistically important (p < 10−5). The data can be used as a basis to aid the decision making on flashing strategies in the automotive industry, and to define the next generation of ECU manufacturing processes considering process efficiency, cyber security limitations, and EoL procedures robustness.

title: Privacy-Preserving Federated Evolutionary Optimization with Personalized Data Transformation
authors: Qianhui Ding, Wu Lin, Xiaoming Xue, Qingling Zhu, Genghui Li, Lijia Ma, Qiuzhen Lin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Data privacy and security have attracted increasing attention in evolutionary computation. In this context, Privacy-Preserving federated evolutionary optimization (PPFEO) has emerged as a promising search paradigm by integrating federated learning into surrogate-assisted evolutionary algorithms (SAEAs). However, privacy-preserving techniques that add random noise during local training introduce additional heterogeneity across clients, thereby degrading the performance of SAEAs. To address this issue, this paper proposes a novel Privacy-Preserving Federated Evolutionary Algorithm with Personalized Data Transformation (PPFEA-PDT). Specifically, a personalized data transformation layer is incorporated into each client and trained to shift the distribution of local data, compensating for heterogeneity during local training. Additionally, a personalized surrogate management strategy is developed by combining multiple historical local models to construct the acquisition function on each client, preserving data privacy while enhancing optimization performance. Experimental results on six widely used benchmark problems demonstrate the effectiveness of PPFEA-PDT.

title: Data Estimation in Wireless Sensor Network with Interference and Hardware Distortion
authors: Afaque Azam
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: In this work the performance of a typical wireless sensor network (WSN) is analyzed assuming the presence of the in-band interference arising due to nearby operating wireless devices. It is assumed that the fusion center(FC) has apriori knowledge of interference distribution and its first-order moment. The interference is assumed inverse gamma distributed, and an approximate closed-form expression of the mean square error (MSE) of the estimated transmit signal at the FC is derived. The impact of imperfect hardware at the FC on the information estimation quality is also studied. The performance of this network is then analyzed and verified numerically.

title: Unveiling the Potential of Machine Learning Models for an Improved Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring
authors: Yasir Ali, Muskan Chaudhary, Eman Shabbir, Intisar Ali Sajjad, Muhammad Abbas, Faisal Hammad Khan
abstract: Challenges in energy conservation are at the forefront, and non-intrusive load monitoring (NILM) has proven itself an effective approach for disaggregation of load and extracting separate appliance power consumptions from aggregated data. Among the different AI techniques, machine learning has proven to be the better option to solve the disaggregation problem. This paper compares four supervised machine learning approaches—Decision Tree (DT), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Extreme Gradient Boosting—for NILM on the UK-domestic appliance level electricity dataset. The evaluation criteria are accuracy, precision, recall and F1-score. The classification performance of DT and XGBoost is better than that of KNN and SVM. On the event detection side, XGBoost provided the highest classification accuracy and robustness. The results of this paper show that enhanced machine learning techniques like DT and XGBoost can have significant beneficial implications for energy efficiency and demand side management.

title: AI and Blockchain: Transforming Data Security in Higher Education Institutions
authors: Virendra Gawande
abstract: In contemporary knowledge domains, cybersecurity became an important factor to consider across all the institutions of higher education. Blockchain technology together with Artificial Intelligence (AI) must be aligned to ensure that seamless and safe learning ecosystems. Blockchain ensures data integrity and transparency by preventing unauthorized access, while AI strengthens the procedure by identifying apprehensive activities and adapting appropriate accurate defenses. This research explores the integration of blockchain technology and AI, offering a robust framework for the enhancement of educational data security. Thematic analysis-based research involved ten respondents in eight in-depth semi-structured interviews. The analysis results emphasized two major themes: the significance of data security within higher educational institutions; the role of blockchain technology and artificial intelligence (AI) in ensuring data integrity, in technological innovation in education technology. Case studies showcase the successful application of AI blockchain systems for the management of digital identities, safeguarding of sensitive research data, and the preservation of academic records. The study also discusses potential issues such as the complexity of implementation, resource allocation, and the requirement for regulatory frameworks. The study concludes by stating that blockchain technology and artificial intelligence (AI) offer advanced solutions for data security in institutions of higher learning and establish benchmarks for institutional security policies in the digital age.

title: Leveraging SVM for Accurate Multiple Disease Prediction in Healthcare
authors: P. Srinivasa Rao, Triveka Nidubrolu, G. Nithya, J. Kartigeyan, K. Sreenivasulu, Amit Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The method of determining who is most likely to contract a specific sickness is known as disease prediction. It is necessary for contemporary medical treatment. The combination of artificial intelligence and machine learning is revolutionizing healthcare, particularly in the areas of disease detection and prediction. Machine learning algorithms have demonstrated exceptional effectiveness in treating disease because of their capacity to manage enormous datasets and identify intricate patterns. New approaches to the diagnosis and treatment of chronic diseases have been made possible by the advancement of machine learning (ML) in the medical field. This study introduces a multiple illness prediction system that uses cutting-edge machine learning algorithms to accurately forecast conditions including diabetes, Parkinson's disease, and heart disease. Proposed algorithm finds trends and risk factors linked to a variety of diseases by analyzing intricate medical databases. The system employs techniques like Random Forest Classifier, Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to evaluate complicated medical data and identify patterns and risk indications. The system's user-friendly interface, developed using Streamlit Cloud, allows users to choose a specific ailment, input relevant medical data, and obtain predictions. This innovative technique increases the precision of early disease detection and is crucial for proactive health management that benefits patients and healthcare professionals alike.

title: Enhancing Sea Clutter Suppression with Attention Weight Transfer LSTM Architecture
authors: Lu-Xi Zhang, Peng-Lang Shui, Zi-Jian Zhao, Shu-Wen Xu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Sea clutter suppression remains a critical challenge in maritime radar systems. While the short-term predictability of sea clutter enables suppression via time-series prediction, traditional linear model fails to address its nonlinear dynamics, and existing neural network-based methods often neglect timevarying characteristics and rely solely on amplitude information. This paper proposed a framework to suppress sea clutter with the following three innovations. Firstly, a complex-to-real transformation is achieved by decomposing complex radar returns into amplitude-phase components, allowing for holistic suppression while preserving phase correlation, which is critical for non-stationary signals. Secondly, a pre-train strategy leveraging heterogeneous clutter data with matched power of sea clutter to enhance global characterization of sea clutter. Third, the novel positional-attention enhanced Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) network links amplitude and phase training via locationattention weights, while concentrating on the clutter information instead of random noise. Experiment results on the IPIX database attain better suppression performance than other algorithms.

title: Hierarchical Subspace Adaptation for Efficient Fine-Tuning of Large Language Models
authors: Junwei Dong, Yifan Wang, Sijia Wang, Xuefeng Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) has emerged as a key approach for adapting large language models (LLMs) to specific tasks while minimizing computational resources. However, existing PEFT methods often struggle to balance parameter efficiency and model performance, particularly as model scales increase. To overcome these limitations, a Hierarchical Subspace Self-Adaptive (HSSA) framework is proposed, facilitating parameter sharing across model components while enabling task-specific rank adjustments. Experiments on benchmark datasets demonstrate that HSSA achieves competitive or superior performance with substantially fewer parameters (0.055% for LLaMA 2) and exhibits strong generalization and robustness across diverse tasks. The proposed method represents a significant advancement in efficient large-model adaptation and provides a practical solution for resource-constrained deployment.

title: Utilizing Augmented Reality to Create and Control a Digital Twin of a Collaborative Robot
authors: Mohamed-Kamel Koumenji, Marcus Soll, Louis Kobras, Jan Haase
abstract: Robotic automation is an integral part of modern industry. It is thus imperative to prepare students of engineering and computer science to handle industrial robots. However, as stopping a single machine can impact the productivity of an entire facility, training on live machinery might not always be feasible. Likewise, setting up enough laboratory space and equipment for students to use during their studies requires much available space and funding and thus also might not always be feasible. This paper presents a prototype of a digital twin for a collaborative robot arm. The digital twin makes use of augmented reality for visualisation and connects to either a physical robot or a simulated robot controller inside a virtual machine. Several aspects of the implementation as well as limitations and lessons learned are described.

title: Molecular Communication Model for Drug Delivery in Multi-Layered Spherical Channels
authors: Mitra Rezaei, Michael Chappell, Adam Noel
publish: IEEE Transactions on Molecular, Biological, and Multi-Scale Communications
abstract: Spherical multi-layered structures are prevalent in numerous biological systems and engineered applications, including tumor spheroids, layered tissues, and multi-shell nanoparticles for targeted drug delivery. Despite their widespread occurrence, there remains a gap in modeling particle propagation through these complex structures from a molecular communication (MC) perspective. This paper introduces a generalized analytical framework for modeling diffusion-based MC in multi-layered spherical environments. The framework is capable of supporting an arbitrary number of layers and flexible transmitter-receiver positioning. As an example, the detailed formulation is presented for the three-layer sphere, which is particularly relevant for different biological models such as tumor spheroids. Through this analytical model, two drug delivery scenarios for a three-layered tumor spheroid are investigated: (1) conventional drug delivery from a point source transmitter, and (2) targeted delivery utilizing pH-sensitive carriers that release their payload within the spheroid’s acidic necrotic core (i.e., innermost layer). The analytical results are validated using particle-based simulation (PBS) for configurations with short inter-layer distances. These findings advance the understanding of molecular transport mechanisms in multi-layered spheroids and provide a theoretical foundation for designing more efficient targeted drug delivery strategies.

title: Comparison of Buildings Extracted from the Colaborative Project OpenStreetMap with the Microsoft Building Footprints dataset
authors: Cidália C. Fonte, Joaquim Patriarca
abstract: An update dataset of buildings is important for many applications. These may be available in large scale topographic maps, but such maps are not available in many parts of the world, or may be outdated. However, there are open datasets that map buildings for the whole world, namely the OpenStreetMap collaborative project and the Microsoft Buildings Footprints dataset. In this paper the buildings mapped in these two datasets are analyzed and compared for a study area located in continental Portugal, in terms of geometric accuracy of the building's polygons, as well as the omission and commission errors. Finally, some conclusions are presented on the strong points and limitation of each dataset and some future work.

title: Findings of Mega: Math explanation with LLMs using the socratic method for active learning
authors: Tosin Adewumi, Foteini Simistira Liwicki, Marcus Liwicki, Viktor Gardelli, Lama Alkhaled, Hamam Mokayed
abstract: This article presents an intervention study on the effects of the combined methods of 1) the Socratic method, 2) chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning, 3) simplified gamification, and 4) formative feedback on university students’ math learning driven by large language models (LLMs). We call our approach Mathematics Explanations through Games by AI LLMs (MEGA). Some students struggle with math, and as a result, avoid math-related disciplines or subjects despite the importance of math across many fields, including signal processing. Oftentimes, students’ math difficulties stem from suboptimal pedagogy. We compared the MEGA method to the traditional step-by-step (CoT) method to ascertain which is better by using a within-group design after randomly assigning questions for the participants, who are university students. Samples <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">${(}{n}{=}{60}{)}$</tex-math></inline-formula> were randomly drawn from each of the two test sets of the Grade School Math 8 K (GSM8K) and Mathematics Aptitude Test of Heuristics (MATH) datasets, based on an error margin of 11%, a confidence level of 90%, and a manageable number of samples for the student evaluators. These samples were used to evaluate two capable LLMs at length [Generative Pretrained Transformer 4o (GPT4o) and Claude 3.5 Sonnet] out of the initial six that were tested for capability. The results showed that students agree in more instances that the MEGA method is experienced as better for learning for both datasets. It is even much better than the CoT (47.5% compared to 26.67%) in the more difficult MATH dataset, indicating that MEGA is better at explaining difficult math problems. We also calculated the accuracies of the two LLMs and showed that model accuracies differ for the methods. MEGA appears to expose the hallucination challenge that still exists with these LLMs better than CoT. We provide public access to the MEGA app, the preset instructions that we created, and the annotations by the students for transparency.
