title: Unlearning Comparator: a Visual Analytics System for Comparative Evaluation of Machine Unlearning Methods
authors: Jaeung Lee, Suhyeon Yu, Yurim Jang, Simon S. Woo, Jaemin Jo
publish: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics
abstract: Machine Unlearning (MU) aims to remove target training data from a trained model so that the removed data no longer influences the model's behavior, fulfilling “right to be forgotten” obligations under data privacy laws. Yet, we observe that researchers in this rapidly emerging field face challenges in analyzing and understanding the behavior of different MU methods, especially in terms of three fundamental principles in MU: accuracy, efficiency, and privacy. Consequently, they often rely on aggregate metrics and ad-hoc evaluations, making it difficult to accurately assess the trade-offs between methods. To f ill this gap, we introduce a visual analytics system, Unlearning Comparator, designed to facilitate the systematic evaluation of MU methods. Our system supports two important tasks in the evaluation process: model comparison and attack simulation. First, it allows the user to compare the behaviors of two models, such as a model generated by a certain method and a retrained baseline, at class-, instance-, and layer-levels to better understand the changes made after unlearning. Second, our system simulates membership inference attacks (MIAs) to evaluate the privacy of a method, where an attacker attempts to determine whether specific data samples were part of the original training set. We evaluate our system through a case study visually analyzing prominent MU methods and demonstrate that it helps the user not only understand model behaviors but also gain insights that can inform the improvement of MU methods.

title: Space Generation for Robust Interactive Video Streaming over LEO Satellite Network
authors: Qianyun Gong, Jianxin Shi, Jiapei Xu, Haoyuan Zhao, Hao Fang, Jiangchuan Liu, Lingjun Pu
abstract: Interactive applications have experienced significant growth in recent years. The rapid development of low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite networks (LSNs) providing global coverage has ushered in a new era of remote interactive applications. Yet, the dynamic nature of LSNs often mismatch the requirements of interactive video streaming for high bandwidth and low latency. Motivated by the recent advancements in generative artificial intelligence (GenAI) and satellite computing, we suggest a space generation-aware interactive video streaming framework over LSNs. We closely examine the potential and challenges of integrating GenAI with satellite computing, highlight key design issues toward its implementation, and demonstrate its effectiveness through a prototype study and large-scale simulations.

title: A Beam-space ESPRIT Algorithm for DOA Estimation in FMCW Radar
authors: Lijiao Zeng, Yaoru Yang, Bo Xiang, Zhonghua Deng, Yang Hong Li
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper addresses the critical trade-off between estimation accuracy and computational complexity in Direction-of-Arrival (DOA) estimation for Frequency-Modulated Continuous-Wave (FMCW) radar systems equipped with Uniform Rectangular Arrays (URAs). The received radar echoes are first processed through de-chirping to convert wideband signals into narrowband intermediates. A 2D Fast Fourier Transform (2D-FFT) with windowing is then applied to construct the range-Doppler spectrum, from which target signals are extracted via peak detection within range-velocity gates effectively suppressing irrelevant interference. To reduce computational burden, a Discrete Fourier Transform (DFT)-based beam-space transformation is introduced, projecting the high-dimensional element-space signals into a lower-dimensional beam-space. This transformation preserves essential signal energy while suppressing out-of-beam noise, thereby enhancing the effective signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). In terms of simulation results, at 15 dB SNR, the Root-Mean-Squared Error (RMSE) of used algorithm for azimuth angle estimation is $\leq 0.3^{\circ}$, and for elevation angle estimation is $\leq 0.2^{\circ}$. Even at 3 dB SNR, BESPRIT maintains excellent estimation stability, avoiding the phase estimation error issue of PM-ESPRIT, which exhibits azimuth RMSE $\gt 1.4^{\circ}$ and elevation RMSE $\gt 0.8^{\circ}$. The used approach enables high-accuracy DOA estimation with significantly reduced computational overhead, making it suitable for real-time applications in large-scale URAs-based FMCW radar systems.

title: MetaKAN: A Multimodal KAN-based Network for Omni-Domain Infrared Small Target Detection
authors: Peng Ding, Weihua He, Luping Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Infrared Small Target Detection (IRSTD) is a critical technology, yet most deep learning models suffer from poor generalization when deployed in diverse, real-world scenarios, a challenge known as Omni-Domain IRSTD. Furthermore, the “black-box” nature of these models undermines their trustworthiness in high-stakes applications. To address these limitations, this paper introduces MetaKAN, a novel multi-modal architecture that pioneers the fusion of imaging metadata with visual features. MetaKAN employs a context-aware dynamic modulation module to adaptively adjust feature extraction based on metadata, such as sensor type and spectral band. Concurrently, it is the first to integrate a Kolmogorov-Arnold Network (KAN) into an IRSTD framework, enhancing both parameter efficiency and providing a clear path toward model interpretability. Extensive experiments on the challenging WideIRSTD-Full benchmark demonstrate that MetaKAN achieves state-of-the-art performance, significantly outperforming existing methods in both detection accuracy and suppression of false alarms in complex backgrounds. Our work presents a robust solution to the omni-domain problem and offers a new paradigm for developing generalizable and trustworthy IRSTD systems for practical applications.

title: IoT Enabled Automatic Planting Robot for Smart Environment
authors: Karisma Mohapatra, Sangam Malla, Anil Kumar Biswal, Rojalin Mallick, Monalisa Behera, Prabhat Kumar Sahu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The goal of our article is to develop an Internet of Things (IoT)-based automated tree-planting robot that is adaptable to various tree plantation tasks, while also being dependable and efficient—key requirements for our initiative. The primary aim is to reduce the human labor needed for tree planting. With people’s busy schedules today, there is little time left to dedicate to planting trees, leading to a potential decline in the number of trees in the future. To address this, we conceived the idea of creating a tree-planting robot through IoT that can help prevent this decline. The robot is designed to plant a wide variety of saplings and has been engineered with cost-effectiveness in mind, making it accessible to everyone. Additionally, its controls have been simplified to ensure ease of use for all users.

title: IoT Cybersecurity Policies: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Gana Sawalhi, Bisan Nasser, Mais Khatib
abstract: The increasing adoption and rapid development of the Internet of Things in different industries has led to great cybersecurity challenges on a global scale and different countries have developed different policies and frameworks to mitigate the risks associated with IoT security. This paper examines a comparative analysis of IoT cybersecurity policies for several different countries, including the United Kingdom, United States, Canada, United Arab Emirates, Saudi Arabia and Singapore. This analysis highlighted the security requirements, mechanisms and key guidelines applied in each country and also highlighted the commonalities, strengths and weaknesses while some countries emphasize strict regulatory compliance and others focus on voluntary safety standards. The analysis reveals a global shift towards design safety principles, risk management, security vulnerabilities, as well as consumer protection measures, and makes recommendations for improving the Internet of Things.

title: A Dataset of Media Articles on ChatGPT
authors: Ahmad Abdel-Hafez, Areej Yousef
abstract: The emergence of ChatGPT has shocked the world with its remarkable capabilities, particularly in the education sector. This paper presents an analysis of 2589 media articles on ChatGPT, a large language model developed by OpenAI. The articles were collected by crawling Google News RSS feeds from 10,235 websites. Our analysis finds that news coverage of ChatGPT is predominantly positive in tone, frequently highlighting its potential to revolutionize education through personalized learning experiences, improved accessibility, and reduced costs. At the same time, substantial concerns are raised regarding employment (job displacement due to AI automation) and privacy, underscoring the need for further research into ChatGPT’s ethical and societal implications. We also perform an exploratory data analysis to profile the geographical distribution of coverage and to quantify article sentiment. The findings confirm a largely optimistic media narrative tempered by cautionary perspectives on risks. Overall, this study demonstrates ChatGPT’s significant impact on public discourse – especially in education – and provides a novel dataset for understanding global media perceptions of generative AI. The curated dataset is being made publicly available on GitHub to support future research in AI and media studies <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>.

title: Comparison of ML Methods for Analyzing Scaffolding Behavior: A Case Study on Safety and Multimodal Results
authors: Mohamad Al Omari, Mojtaba Eslahi, Amine Ammar, Rani El Meouche, Laure Ducoulombier, Laurent Guillaumat
abstract: Ensuring scaffolding safety on construction sites is a critical challenge due to accidents caused by structural instability under varying loads. This research builds on previous work using neural networks (NN) to study scaffold behavior by comparing several machine learning (ML) methods. Using an 8-story scaffolding structure in Paris as a case study, we assess the performance of NNs, Random Forests, Support Vector Machines (SVM), and Linear Regression in predicting displacement, stress, strain, and axial loads. A dataset of 30,000 scenarios generated through finite element modeling provides training and testing data. Methods are compared for prediction accuracy, computational efficiency, and real-time applicability. Findings identify the best ML method for real-time scaffold behavior prediction, offering insights for integrating advanced ML techniques into construction safety practices. This research aims to enhance scaffolding safety and contribute to the future development of a digital twin for scaffold safety.

title: A Stereo-Wise Masking Strategy for Weakly Supervised Point Cloud Semantic Segmentation
authors: Ziyu Huang, Guoqing Jiang, Xiaorong Zhang, Yundong Wu, Jinhe Su
publish: 2025 International Joint Conference on Neural Networks (IJCNN)
abstract: Weakly supervised point cloud semantic segmentation (WSPCSS) has gained attention for reducing reliance on densely annotated data. However, inefficiencies in utilizing sparse annotations hinder comprehensive understanding of complex scenes. Inspired by masked autoencoder (MAE) techniques in image processing, researchers have adapted these methods to WSPCSS. Yet, current 3D masking strategies often fail to capture intricate geometric properties, resulting in generated to-be-filled content that inaccurately represents the underlying 3D scene structure. To address these limitations, this study proposes a novel stereo-wise masking strategy, which extends 2D plane masking into 3D space to generate coherent and semantically rich masked regions with contextual relevance. These regions serve as high-quality learning targets, enabling the model to better comprehend complex point cloud structures. Experimental results demonstrate that, at a 0.01 % annotation density, the proposed method achieves improvements in mIoU by 1.9 % and 4.72 % on the indoor datasets S3DIS and ScanNet V2, respectively, compared to previous methods. Furthermore, at a 0.1% annotation density on the forest dataset For-Instance, the method exhibits a 0.29 % improvement. These results substantiate the effectiveness and stability of the stereo-wise masking strategy.

title: Comparing Face-to-Face and Remote Interactions: How Communication Modality Influences Teamwork
authors: Giulia Magni, Luana Amadini Genovese, Silvia Francesca Maria Pizzoli, Daniele di Lernia, Claudia Repetto, Giuseppe Riva
abstract: Technological advancements have transformed interactions, affecting socio-cognitive processes and overall communication experiences. This study investigates the impact of communication modalities - face-to-face (FTF) versus remote work (RW) - on collaborative performance and interpersonal closeness. 48 participants were paired into dyads and engaged in collaborative tasks under both FTF and RW conditions. Participants performed two cooperative tasks, namely, the Lost at Sea/Desert Survival task, to measure cooperation and shared decision-making abilities, and an ecological work problem simulation in which they had to allocate a budget for employee training, to assess practical collaboration and problem-solving skills. Participants also completed standardized questionnaires assessing media richness, interpersonal closeness, and perceived performance. Results indicate that FTF communication is perceived as richer and more socially engaging compared to RW, facilitating greater social connection between participants. However, no significant differences emerged in perceived performance or collaboration scores. These results suggest that FTF interaction is perceived as richer as RW, facilitating stronger interpersonal connections and greater social engagement. Future research could further investigate the role of individual and contextual variables to better understand the conditions that optimize collaboration in FTF and RW, through the use of more complex measures and by involving larger groups.

title: Exploiting Spatial Multiplexing Based on Pixel Antennas: An Antenna Coding Approach
authors: Zixiang Han, Shanpu Shen, Ross Murch
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing
abstract: An antenna coding approach for exploitingthe spatial multiplexing capability of pixel antennas is proposed. This approach can leverage additional degrees of freedom in the beamspace domain to transmit more information streams. Pixel antennas are a general reconfigurable antenna design where a radiating structure with arbitrary shape and size can be discretized into sub-wavelength elements called pixels. The adjacent pixels are connected by radio frequency switches. By controlling the switch states, the pixel antenna topology can be flexibly adjusted so that the resulting radiation pattern can be reconfigured for beamspace spatial multiplexing. In this work, we introduce the antenna coder and pattern coder for pixel antennas, provide a multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) communication system model with antenna coding in the beamspace domain, and derive the spectral efficiency. Utilizing the antenna coder, the radiation pattern of the pixel antenna is analyzed and efficient optimization algorithms are provided for antenna coding design. Numerical simulation results show that the proposed technique using pixel antennas can enhance spectral efficiency of 4-by-4 MIMO by up to 12 bits/s/Hz, or equivalently reduce the required transmit power by up to 90%, when compared to conventional MIMO, demonstrating the effectiveness of the antenna coding technique in spectral efficiency enhancement and its promise for future sixth generation (6 G) wireless communication.

title: A Robust HECC-based Authentication and Key Agreement for UAV-enabled SAR Networks
authors: Ruiyang Huang, Ning Gao, Qiang Ni, Shi Jin
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have become an indispensable tool in search-and-rescue (SAR) missions, playing a crucial role in locating victims and delivering essential supplies in disaster-stricken areas. However, due to communications in open channels, these unignorable security issues including unauthorized data access, data tampering and leakage, potentially disturb, or even damage the SAR missions. The authentication and key agreement (AKA) technologies are designed to try to allow only verified legal entities can access the data securely with a negotiated session key. Despite the advantages of AKA, existing UAV-specific AKA solutions are unable to resist specific attacks which threaten the security of authentication and session key, and are plagued from the unsatisfactory performance given limited resources of UAVs. To address these issues, based on hyperelliptic curve cryptography (HECC), we propose a robust AKA for UAV enabled SAR network and preserve the desiring performance as well. With detailed security analysis, we demonstrate the robustness of our scheme under the eCK Adversary Model. Furthermore, the performance analysis shows the efficiency and utility of our design in terms of computational overhead and communication cost, in which it indicates that our scheme can be applied to the UAV-enabled SAR network.

title: FBG Sensors Assisted Programmable Device for Plantar Pressure Measurement
authors: Ibrar Jahan Mohammed Aslam, Sunit Goel, Parimal Sah, Yogendra Kumar Awasthi, Gaurav Kumar Bharti
abstract: This article presents a programmable device for plantar pressure measurement using fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors, integrated with a Python-based interface for data visualization, foot classification, and report generation. The device measures pressure at five key foot locations, classifying feet into categories such as normal, flat, pronated, supinated, and abnormal. The system demonstrates high sensitivity (355.98pm/kPa for left foot, 384.60 pm/kPa for right foot) and operates efficiently with a calibration factor of 6.4474. The interface features data storage, email functionality, and pdf report generation, making it suitable for clinical and healthcare applications. The study includes calibration and experimental validation with 70 subjects, and discusses potential future integrations, such as screen mounting for enhanced usability.

title: Physiological Stress Response Assessment During Immersive Virtual Reality Using ECG and PPG Signals
authors: Tooba Naeem, Malaika Ali, Muhammad Omar Cheema, Zia Mohy-Ud-Din, Jahan Zeb Gul
abstract: Immersive virtual reality (VR) environments have shown the potential to evoke measurable psychophysiological responses. This study investigates how the human body reacts to an intense VR stimulus-epic roller coasters (secret cave)-by monitoring electrocardiography (ECG) and photoplethysmography (PPG) signals. Using the Oculus Quest 2 and the BIOPAC MP36 acquisition system, physiological signals were recorded from 4-5 healthy participants in three stages: before the ride (baseline), during the ride (stimulus), and after the ride (recovery). Signal processing and timedomain feature extraction were carried out in Google Colab to evaluate heart rate (HR), heart rate variability (HRV), and pulse wave amplitude. Initial findings suggest that immersive VR elicits increased HR and reduced PPG amplitude, indicating sympathetic nervous system activation. The results validate the use of consumer-grade VR and portable biosignal equipment for short-term stress and arousal research.

title: Modulation Recognition and Parameter Estimation for Nonstationary Signals using Segmentation Processing and Wavelet Transform
authors: Xiao Cao, Jian Liu, Wangjie Chen, Chen Ghao Bao, Binbin Shang, Han Yu, Yi He, Siyu Du
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To address the challenges of high computational complexity, poor robustness in low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions, and the reliance of deep learning on large-scale data in modulation recognition of non-stationary signals, a novel method combining segmented frequency estimation with multi-wavelet basis-based joint analysis is proposed. This approach reduces data dimensionality through signal segmentation and down-sampling, and extracts segmental frequency sequence features using the Kay instantaneous frequency estimation algorithm. Additionally, a multi-wavelet basis phase-jump detection mechanism based on the Gaussian derivative function family is designed. By utilizing modulus comparisons from wavelet transforms, the method achieves phase-jump angle decision-making and constructs a joint classification criterion combining frequency fitting slope, variance, and phase-jump angle. Simulation results demonstrate that, within the SNR range of -5 dB to 15 dB, the proposed algorithm achieves over 90% recognition accuracy for chirp signals and bi-phase/quad-phase shift-keyed (BPSK/QPSK) signals at low SNR levels, outperforming traditional methods like STFT, WignerVille Distribution (WVD), and CNN-based time-frequency imagery approaches. In terms of parameter estimation, the carrier frequency error remains below 1 MHz when SNR exceeds 0 dB. In contrast, the root mean square error (RMSE) of symbol width estimation stays under 1 ns when SNR is above 3 dB. The algorithm has been validated on an FPGA platform, providing an efficient solution for signal sensing and feature analysis in complex electromagnetic environments.

title: From Entanglement to Explanation: Bridging Quantum ML and XAI for Network Traffic Classification
authors: Alfredo Nascita, Idio Guarino, Vincenzo Spadari, Domenico Ciuonzo, Antonio Pescapè
abstract: Quantum Machine Learning (QML) promises computational advantages over Deep Learning (DL), but its effectiveness in practical network Traffic Classification (TC) remains underexplored. In this paper, we provide the first systematic use of eXplainable Artificial Intelligence (XAI) to interpret QMLbased classifiers for (mobile) network TC. We combine (a) SHAPbased attribution and (b) calibration analysis to compare QML and DL models across both small- and large-scale TC tasks. This dual perspective enables a deeper understanding of QML interpretability and reliability relative to DL in network TC, exposing key limitations and avenues for improvement.

title: Front-front Vehicle Detection Via MMW Automotive Radar
authors: Wenli Zhang, Kefan Chen, Kaicheng Wang, Yirui Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper proposed a Front-Front-vehicle (FFvehicle) detection via millimeter-wave (MMW) automotive radar. First of all, the FF-vehicle signal propagation model based on the multipath propagation of electromagnetic wave is established. Then, a FF-vehicle echo signal processing algorithm is proposed. Finally, the feasibility of the FF-vehicle detection model is validated by the experimental.

title: A Lightweight Deep and Wide Network for Image-Based Detection of Industrial Waste Gas
authors: Ke Gu, Hongyan Liu, Jingchao Cao, Lai-Kuan Wong, Junfei Qiao, Guangtao Zhai, Wenjun Zhang, Weisi Lin, Sam Kwong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Due to inadequate monitoring, key pollutants (e.g., PM<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2.5</sub>, VOCs, etc) very possibly leak into atmosphere, thus to endanger the long-term and short-term life safety of people that work and live in the environment. Therefore, it is imperative to effectively and efficiently detect the leakage of industrial waste gas, for the purpose of timely lowering the risk of pollution and explosions. To solve such a problem, we in this paper propose a new lightweight deep and wide network (LdwNet) for detecting the leakage of industrial waste gas from an image, which brings about the two main merits: 1) Compensating for the deficiencies of sensor-based detection methods, which can accurately detect the leakage of waste gas and even measure its concentrations but require to seek leakage sources beforehand; 2) Overcoming the shortcomings of image-based detection methods, which leverage DNN-based recognition technologies and usually suffer from low efficacy, low efficiency and high energy consumption during the model training and inference. To specify, the proposed LdwNet is developed by simulating human perception, motivated by the method which detects the leakage of industrial waste gas from surveillance images with the human observation and judgement. First, based on the inspiration that the human eyes are highly sensitive to horizontal and vertical stimuli, we construct a novel lightweight parallel-series-stripe (PS2) module to validly extract features with very few parameters. Second, to fully exploit deep and shallow features for fusing the global and local information, we extend the PS2 module as a backbone along both the deep and wide directions to build the multi-channel network. Third, to achieve effective, efficient and low-carbon detection in model running, we constraint the extended PS2 modules with parameter sharing to prodigiously reduce the model parameters and thus to make the proposed model ultra-lightweight. Experiments on the datasets of carbon particulate matters and ethylene leakage prove that our LdwNet with ten thousand parameters outperforms the state-of-the-art models with millions of parameters in detection accuracy and implementation cost, and this renders our proposed LdwNet more suitable for real industrial applications.

title: Comparative Study Between CNN, VGG16 and DenseNet121 on Classifying COVID, Pneumonia and Healthy X-Ray Images
authors: Marco Sebastian Viznay Cabrera, Syed Ghazi Abbas, Raja Hashim Ali, Talha Ali Khan, Shan Faiz
abstract: Chest X-ray imaging is a widely used, non-invasive diagnostic tool for detecting respiratory conditions such as pneumonia and COVID-19. Rapid and accurate automated classification of these diseases has become critical to support overwhelmed healthcare systems and improve patient outcomes. Despite advances in deep learning, existing methods often suffer from limited datasets, overfitting, and lack of interpretability in clinical settings. Moreover, most studies focus on binary classification rather than multi-class detection of COVID-19, bacterial pneumonia, and normal cases in a single framework. In this study, we developed a custom convolutional neural network alongside VGG16 and DenseNet121 using a balanced chest X-ray dataset of over 12,000 images. We employed data augmentation, early stopping, and transfer learning techniques to enhance generalization and prevent overfitting during training and validation. The models were evaluated using metrics such as accuracy, F1-score, AUC, and confusion matrices. Our custom CNN achieved a high accuracy, macro F1-score and AUC, outperforming the transfer learning baselines. These results compellingly demonstrate the effectiveness of lightweight, wellregularized CNNs for reliable automated diagnosis and clinical decision support.

title: Early Detection of Bladder Cancer Using Advanced Feature Engineering and Swarm Intelligence Optimization on EHRs
authors: Xu Wang, Andrea Preston, Jonathan Aning, Michael Loizou, Shang-Ming Zhou
abstract: Background: Bladder cancer (BC) symptoms often overlap with benign conditions, while no routine screening exists for general population. We aim to develop a machine learning (ML)-based screening pipeline for early BC detection using electronic-health-records (EHRs) in primary care. Methods: A multi-centred case-control cohort (1995–2018; n = 64,884) was created for model training and testing. We further validated the model prospectively on an independent cohort (2019–2020; n = 4,569). We proposed the Parsimony driven REweighting for Calibrated Input-based Screening for Early detection—Adjustable Grey Zone (PRECISE-AGZ), which identified influential features from 48,261 candidates and developed a calibrated logistic regression screening model with optimised grey-zone thresholds. Results: We finally identified 38 features, achieving an AUC (area under the curve) of 0.789 (95% CI: 0.780–0.798) on testing set. Neurological disorders (e.g., Parkinson's disease, OR: 0.86, 95% CI: 0.79–0.92) and medications (e.g., Tamoxifen, OR: 1.13, 95% CI: 1.07–1.20) emerged as novel predictors for BC screening. The screening model stratified the population into three risk categories based on predicted probability: low-risk (0.55), achieving a sensitivity of 0.852, F1-score of 0.799, and screening population coverage (SPC) of 34.5%. Applied to the prospective validation cohort, model performance varied by months before BC diagnosis, with sensitivities ranging from 0.872 (F1-score: 0.714, SPC: 29.9%) at the first month to 0.667 (F1-score: 0.690, SPC: 12.7%) at the twelfth month. Conclusion: The PRECISE-AGZ pipeline efficiently identified clinical signals from EHRs for early BC detection, offering promising potential for implementing population-based BC screening.

title: A Data-Driven Approach to Short-Term MUF Forecasting in HF Communications: Leveraging Measured Data and Statistical Distributions
authors: Ke Du, Kun Xu, Yangyang Li, Peiwen Feng
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Accurate prediction of the Maximum Usable Frequency (MUF) is critical for reliable high frequency (HF) communications. On the one hand, long-term prediction methods based on models such as VOACAP exhibit strong generalization capability but suffer from limited accuracy. On the other hand, deep learning-based approaches achieve higher prediction accuracy but require extensive historical data and demonstrate poor model generalization. Therefore, this paper proposes a novel short-term MUF prediction framework that balances high precision, low data dependency, and engineering feasibility. The method leverages real-time MUF measured data and its statistical distribution. First, by analyzing the temporal validity characteristics of communication links under specific accuracy requirements, a quantitative model is established to describe the evolution of MUF prediction error over time. This model precisely characterizes how prediction error increases when measured data are directly extrapolated into future time intervals. Within the validated time window, measured values can reflect the state of the ionosphere effectively. Beyond this window (i.e., when the required accuracy cannot be guaranteed), the method fits an hourly statistical distribution to short-term MUF observations, reconstructs missing data through distribution-based imputation, and performs prediction using the Kalman Filter (KF). Experimental results demonstrate that, the proposed approach significantly reduces reliance on large-scale continuous historical data. Furthermore, it achieves higher prediction accuracy than short-term distribution-based prediction method and lightweight LSTM.

title: Pedagogical Approach for Virtual Reality Tools at Universities of Applied Sciences
authors: Margareth Gfrerer, Ephrem Tekle, Tomas Benz
abstract: Virtual Reality (VR) is considered as the tool to introduce lecturers in Ethiopian Universities of Applied Sciences (UASs) to real world processes in companies. This approach has been selected due to the fact that in general UAS lecturers have to have a certain number of years of experience in industry. So that they are familiar with processes in industry and able to educate their students in the knowledge, skills and competences as requested by the industry. Due to the lack of lecturers' experience in working in companies on one side and on the other side the lack of companies available to accommodate lecturers for ‘externships' a consortium composed of Ethiopian UASs and European universities was formed in order to elaborate the proposal ‘Methodology and Didactic Education for UASs' (MaDE for UASs) to use VR / Augmented Reality (AR) / simulations to mirror the W orld-of-Work (W 0 W) and to capture real world processes in companies. This proposal has been awarded as Erasmus+ Project for implementation. Before the development of the VRI ARisimulation based teaching and learning intervention will commence, it is important to define the pedagogical/educational approach. This paper tries to find an answer to the research question on ‘the most suitable learning theories/frameworks/approaches for the development of the VRI ARisimulation based teaching and learning interventions for the Ethiopian UASs'. A literature review clarify the terms learning and educational theories/frameworks/approaches and sets the baseline for the discussion on the most suitable educational/pedagogical approach for the development of the VRI ARisimulation based teaching and learning intervention.

title: Wide-Beam Pattern Synthesis for Linear Phased Arrays via Power Gain Maximization
authors: Longyao Ran, Shengyao Chen, Feng Xi
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: To further characterize the antenna array’s capability to focus energy, we introduce the power gain as the performance metric. Hence, with the aim of maximizing the minimum power gain in the mainlobe region, this paper discusses the wide-beam power gain pattern synthesis (PGPS) of linear phased arrays. It is greatly intractable due to the coupling of a max-min fractional objective function and lots of nonconvex unimodular constraints. To tackle these, we first translate the fractional objective function into an integral form by using generalized fractional programming. Then, we provide a penalty-based algorithm by using the equivalent rank-one expression and successive convex approximation to solve the problem. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed algorithm significantly outperforms the conventional shaped beam pattern synthesis algorithms in the mainlobe power gain, while the performance degration introduced by phased arrays remains acceptable relative to a comparable digital array.

title: Feedforward-Based Variable Frequency Second Harmonic Current Suppression Strategy for Cascaded H-Bridge Energy Storage Converter
authors: Jinhao Zhang, Fanqiang Gao, Zixin Li, Cong Zhao, Ye Zhang, Yaohua Li
abstract: The second harmonic current (SHC) is significant in the cascaded H-bridge converter with dc–dc stage and supercapacitor under high current and variable output frequency, increasing the risk of overcurrent in the dc–dc. Conventional suppression strategies designed for fixed-frequency SHC constrain the dc–dc controller bandwidth to the SHC frequency, inevitably degrading dynamic performance. To address this issue, this article proposes a feedforward-based SHC suppression strategy. By analyzing the transmission path of SHC, an accurate feed-forward compensation is introduced at the dc voltage reference point, blocking the second harmonic signal from entering the dc–dc control loop. This decouples the SHC suppression strategy from the controller, eliminating the bandwidth constraint imposed by the SHC frequency. Therefore, the proposed strategy ensures both effective SHC suppression and enhanced dynamic performance under variable frequency conditions. Furthermore, the dc–dc controller design process is significantly simplified. Finally, the experimental results validate the effectiveness of the proposed SHC suppression strategy.

title: Ultrarobust Underwater Kicking Phase Estimation for Robotic Exosuit-Assisted Diving_supp3-3650487.mp4
authors: Xinyu Wu
abstract: Assisting divers with robotic exoskeletons would increase their working efficiency and reduce the risk of accidents. Nonetheless, the synchronization of assistance with underwater movements has not been investigated and remains a complex issue. Due to the agility and individuality of these movements in aquatic environments, conventional methods utilized on land may not work properly. In this article, we proposed an ultrarobust adaptive oscillator (AO) (URAO) method for predicting the kicking phase for the flutter kick and breaststroke kick, two main underwater motion patterns in diving activity. The URAO works without the need for data collection or training and can adapt to different users, motion patterns, and rapid changes in kicking frequency, offering greater precision than methods previously utilized for land-based exoskeletons. Eight participants were tested while performing fluctuating-frequency flutter and breaststroke kicks in indoor and outdoor swimming pools. The results showed that URAO outperformed both conventional AO and state-of-the-art estimators in predicting underwater kicking phases, reducing RMS_EWS prediction error by up to 49.5% for flutter kicks and up to 44.8% for breaststroke kicks.

title: Evaluating Deep Learning and Machine Learning Approaches for Prostate Cancer Detection
authors: Mamata Beura, Partha Sarathi Pattnayak, Pradeep Kumar Mallick, Debahuti Mishra, Gyo Soo Chae
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive review and performance analysis of deep learning and traditional machine learning techniques for prostate cancer diagnosis using multi-parametric MRI (mpMRI) and histopathological data. A robust hybrid framework is proposed that integrates principal component analysis (PCA) with convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transfer learning, significantly enhancing diagnostic accuracy while reducing computational complexity. Extensive benchmarking was conducted across various models including support vector machine (SVM), random forest (RF), XGBoost, CNN, ResNet-50, EfficientNet, vision transformer (ViT), and the proposed ProsGradNet. These models were validated on benchmark datasets such as ProstateX, PROSTATE12, and ProsGradNet, covering diverse imaging modalities and clinical settings. The hybrid PCA-deep learning approach demonstrated superior performance, with ProsGradNet achieving 94.5% accuracy, 92.1% sensitivity, 94.5% specificity, and an AUC of 0.97—outperforming conventional architectures. The study also emphasizes the trade-off between interpretability and accuracy, catering to both high-performance and resource-limited clinical environments. Key challenges such as dataset standardization, computational cost, and explainability are addressed, offering insights for future deployment of AI-powered diagnostic systems in real-world clinical workflows.

title: Enhancing Cloud Resource Utilization: African Bison Optimization Algorithm for Scalable and Sustainable Computing
authors: Jitender Jain, Piyush Kumar Pareek, Pradeep Kumar Mallick, Diganta Sengupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: This research focuses on the African Bison Optimization Algorithm (ABOA) for enhanced cloud-based resource allocation and management. By integrating virtualization, dynamic workload balancing, and predictive analytics, cloud service providers can optimize resource utilization, minimize energy consumption, and reduce operational costs. The ABOA mimics the natural behaviors of African bison, including foraging, bathing, jousting, mating, and elimination, to enhance resource allocation. The foraging behavior ensures efficient exploration of computing resources, bathing signifies stability in resource allocation, jousting helps in competitive resource distribution, mating ensures optimal solution propagation, and elimination removes inefficient resource allocations. To address challenges like over-provisioning, underutilization, and latency, this study explores advanced techniques such as AI-driven resource scheduling, container orchestration, and auto-scaling. By emphasizing efficient resource utilization, this research aims to enhance the performance and sustainability of cloud computing systems.

title: Research on ECG Signal Denoising Based on FCNDAE Deep Learning Model
authors: Lei Zhao, Min Xiang, Jiaqi Yang, Ping Hu, Hu An Luo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Electrocardiogram(ECG) signals are susceptible to noise such as baseline wander and electromyographic interference, which compromises diagnostic reliability. This study aims to integrate deep learning techniques to propose an efficient ECG denoising model for enhanced signal quality. First, a hybrid model combining fully convolutional networks with denoising autoencoder (FCN-DAE) is constructed, featuring a symmetric encoder-decoder architecture where the encoder compresses signals and extracts features through multiple convolutional layers while the decoder reconstructs signals via transposed convolutions, forming a complete autoencoder framework. Second, exponential linear unit (ELU) activation functions are introduced in the encoder to strengthen multi-scale feature extraction, while linear output layers are employed in the decoder to optimize signal detail restoration. Finally, the model is trained using clean signals from the MIT-BIH database mixed with multi-source noise and compared with traditional filtering methods (bandpass filtering, wavelet transform, etc.). Experimental results demonstrate that the FCN-DAE model outperforms conventional approaches in mean square error ($\mathrm{MSE}=\mathbf{0. 0 2 9 3}$) and sum of squared differences (SSD $=14.98$), with denoised signals closely approximating original waveforms while effectively preserving key features such as QRS complexes.

title: Improved Faster R-CNN for Aircraft Detection in SAR Images
authors: Jinhua Wei, Ziheng Xia, Muyuan Fan, Yingxia Wang, Wenjun Huo
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images play a crucial role in various fields due to their high resolution and capability to operate under diverse lighting and climatic conditions. However, due to the coherence of SAR systems, SAR images inherently contain speckle noise, posing challenges for detection algorithms to distinguish targets, especially aircraft. Aircraft features in SAR images often appear unclear, leading to significant intra-class variations among the same aircraft type and inter-class similarities between different types, making precise discrimination difficult. This paper proposes an enhanced detection framework based on Faster R-CNN, leveraging Dynamic Prototypical Contrastive Learning to strengthen intraclass compactness and inter-class discriminability. The proposed algorithm is validated on a self-constructed dataset extended from SAR-AIRcraft-1.0. Experiments demonstrate that the method exhibits stronger robustness in detecting dense aircraft clusters under complex backgrounds, particularly improving the discrimination ability for aircraft types with high inter-class similarity. These results verify the effectiveness of Dynamic Prototypical Contrastive Learning in SAR aircraft detection.

title: Island Model Human-Based Evolutionary Computation System
authors: Yuto Yamada, Takato Utsumi, Kei Ohnishi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: One form of evolutionary computation is human-based evolutionary computation. In human-based evolutionary computation, a human group evaluates solutions and performs evolutionary operators such as selection, crossover, and mutation. Therefore, if a human-based evolutionary computation system is implemented on the Web, it is possible to efficiently create effective solutions to problems in human organizations without time and place constraints. However, as the number of people participating in problem solving increases, the burden on participants to recognize other participants increases. In addition, the possibility that solutions proposed by participants with minority views is buried increases. To solve these issues, we propose island model human-based evolutionary computation and implement it as a system. In the implemented system, the similarity of participants' views is measured, people with similar views form islands, and good solutions created on each island are sent to other islands, which is migration of solutions. The implemented system is evaluated in a small-scale experiment with 10 participants. The results show the basic effectiveness of creating islands with people with similar views.

title: A Computational Biomechanical Analysis of Composite Ankle Foot Orthosis for Pediatric Cerebral Palsy Patient
authors: Mohamed T.El Wakad, Noorhan Abdelgawad, Reda Abdelbaset, Marwa M. A. Hadhoud
publish: 2025 1st Future International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Cybersecurity (FICAC)
abstract: Children with cerebral palsy often suffer from gait abnormalities that limit mobility and increase the risk of chronic joint deformities. Ankle-foot orthoses (AFOs) are commonly prescribed to enhance ankle stability and improve gait patterns. However, conventional orthotic materials may exhibit limitations, such as excessive stiffness or insufficient deformation behavior, which can potentially cause discomfort or restrict natural gait motion. This study investigates the mechanical performance of Orthocryl composites reinforced with carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and polylactic acid (PLA) for pediatric AFO applications. Finite element analysis (FEA) was performed in ANSYS software to evaluate structural behavior and assess the materials' orthopedic suitability. A 3D model of the orthosis was generated using 3D scanning to match the patient's anatomy, then imported into ANSYS for simulation. Four material configurations were analyzed: pure Orthocryl, Orthocryl with CNTs, and two CNT-reinforced composites with varying PLA content. Simulations were conducted under dynamic gait loading, using ground reaction force data to represent heel strike, midstance, and toe-off phases. Results showed that maximum stress occurred during toe-off across all materials, corresponding to peak gait loading. CNT and PLA additions preserved the uniform stress distribution of pure Orthocryl without creating localized concentrations. Deformation analysis revealed minimal deflection in pure Orthocryl, indicating rigidity, while PLA enhanced flexibility, allowing greater deformation in midstance and toe-off. CNTs enhanced structural stability, and the hybrid composites balanced flexibility and support. Safety factors remained within acceptable limits throughout the gait cycle. Overall, CNT/PLA-reinforced composites demonstrated enhanced mechanical adaptability under dynamic gait conditions compared to pure Orthocryl.

title: Harvesting Human Kinetic Energy: Design and Implementation of a Piezoelectric-Based System for Powering Biopotential Acquisition Circuit
authors: Syeda Iqra Naveen, Aroosha Irfan, Shanzay Nadeem, Anusha Ishtiaq, Muhammad Omar Cheema, Zia Mohy-Ud-Din
abstract: This paper presents the idea of designing and implementation of an innovative energy harvesting system, which captures and converts ambient energy into electrical energy to power devices, using piezoelectric material, an Arduino micro controller along with a 16x2 LCD display. The system is designed to harness power from human body movements and therefore converts the kinetic energy into electrical energy. The resulting energy is used to power biopotential acquisition circuits like ECG and EMG systems. The following report contains a thorough detail of the methodology used and the experimental setup with their respective results. A successful development of this energy efficient system highlights the importance of piezoelectric technology in biomedical devices and contributes to a greener, more sustainable healthcare solution.

authors: Xinyu Wu
abstract: Assisting divers with robotic exoskeletons would increase their working efficiency and reduce the risk of accidents. Nonetheless, the synchronization of assistance with underwater movements has not been investigated and remains a complex issue. Due to the agility and individuality of these movements in aquatic environments, conventional methods utilized on land may not work properly. In this article, we proposed an ultrarobust adaptive oscillator (AO) (URAO) method for predicting the kicking phase for the flutter kick and breaststroke kick, two main underwater motion patterns in diving activity. title: Optimizing Resource Scheduling for Enhanced Efficiency in Cloud Computing
authors: Prayansh Mishra, Prakash Kumar Jha, Ipsita Sahoo, Bhaskar Chakraborty, Omkar Pratik Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Cloud computing is a significant advancement in computing technologies as it operates on a pay-as-you-use model. It provides resources like storage, servers, etc., through a virtual platform which makes the remote access of distributed resources easy and efficient. This enhances flexibility, scalability, and cost-effectiveness. Clients provide tasks to the cloud service providers through some software which follow the resource scheduling. Resource scheduling is a critical process that shows the overall performance of a system. It is the process to generate the schedule appropriately that decides which task will be mapped to which resource. Efficient resource scheduling ensures optimal utilization of a resource. Sometimes many tasks are provided to the same set resources repeatedly and the rest of the resources remain idle. This creates an uneven distribution of workload which may have impact on the efficiency of the system. For this reason, load balancing is required. It is an important component of cloud computing which is designed to distribute workloads and computing resources efficiently across multiple servers or VMs. Several resource scheduling algorithms have been proposed over the years addressing multiple factors and challenges. However, many of these could not adequately integrate several factors of resource scheduling and load balancing for an overall optimal performance. This project aims to address those problems and enhance efficiency in resource scheduling through a simulation-based evaluation. The project proposes an algorithm which considers task length and task priorities simultaneously and then finds their credit. Since load balancing is equally important as resource scheduling, the proposed method integrates credit-based task allocation with a load balancing strategy to improve Makespan and system performance. This maintains an even distribution of workload.

title: Optimizing Security in Satellite-Integrated IoT Networks: A Hybrid Deep Learning Approach for Intrusion Detection with JBOA and NOA
authors: Chandrakanth Reddy Borra, Ramya Vani Rayala, Piyush Kumar Pareek, Srinivas Cheekati
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: The assistances of satellite-based Internet of Things (IoT) systems include low energy consumption, low latency, and high throughput. However, when these systems are integrated, they are vulnerable to specific security threats that can develop as a result of security threats migrating from one system to another. Modern network environments, including those with satellite integration, can also benefit from the high level of protection offered by Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS). The study developed a feature selection model based on a mixture of deep learning and other methods to improve the detection presentation of harmful activity in network traffic. Using the Jarratt-Butterfly optimisation algorithm (JBOA), the most important features are picked from the SWaT dataset. Lastly, the suggested hybrid model is fine-tuned using the nutcracker optimiser algorithm (NOA), which combines a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) with a Long Short-term Memory (LSTM) for attack categorisation. Using a publicly available dataset, to mimic the experimental assessment and find that the CNN+LSTM technique significantly improves the accuracy, reaching a maximum of 92% to 93%. Using deep learning and an optimisation methodology to improve SIoT intrusion detection capabilities, the fallouts prove that the suggested method has active security solution potential

title: TransSE: A Transfer Learning-Based Predictive Model for Distinguishing Super Enhancers and Typical Enhancers_supp1-3657361.tif
authors: Junxiang Gao
abstract: Super-enhancers (SEs), comprising clusters of transcriptional regulatory elements, play essential roles in gene expression regulation and cell fate determination. Current computational methods for identifying SEs from genomic sequences face challenges in prediction accuracy and cross-species generalizability. This study introduces TransSE, a deep learning framework combining convolutional and recurrent neural networks with cross-species transfer learning for SE prediction. TransSE employs a two-phase strategy: pre-training on combined human and mouse data to learn conserved regulatory features, followed by species-specific fine-tuning to capture organism-specific patterns. Evaluation on human and mouse datasets demonstrates that TransSE achieves superior accuracy compared to existing methods including SENet, DeepSE, and transformer-based models (DNABERT, Enformer), with AUC values of 0.828 (human) and 0.832 (mouse). Ablation studies confirm that convolutional blocks are essential for feature extraction, while transfer learning and recurrent layers provide meaningful performance improvements. Feature analysis reveals that TransSE distinguishes SEs from typical enhancers based on learned sequence representations, achieving 10.4-fold improvement in clustering metrics. The model demonstrates effective cross-species prediction capability, maintaining AUC <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\gt $</tex-math></inline-formula> 0.79 when trained on one species and evaluated on another. Conservation pattern analysis shows that TransSE integrates both evolutionarily conserved and species-specific regulatory features, enabling robust performance across organisms with limited training data. A user-friendly web interface (<uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">http://transse.shenlabahmu.com</uri>) provides automated SE prediction, motif analysis, and variant impact assessment. Case studies using experimentally validated SEs demonstrate the tool's utility for investigating regulatory elements and prioritizing functional variants in disease-associated genomic regions. TransSE advances the investigation of gene regulatory mechanisms and facilitates identification of disease-associated variation in enhancer regions.

title: Design of Low-Power DFFs with Unipolar Thin-Film Transistor
authors: Shubham Ranjan, Czang-Ho Lee, Pranav Gavirneni, William S. Wong, Manoj Sachdev
abstract: Thin-film transistors (TFTs) have become the foundation of modern flexible and large-area electronics, enabling applications such as displays, wearable sensors, and IoT systems. However, realizing energy-efficient sequential circuits with unipolar TFTs remains challenging due to limited voltage swing and substantial direct-path current. This work presents the design and analysis of three low-power D flip-flops (DFFs), a Dynamic TFT Flip-Flop (DTFF), and two generations of Static TFT Flip-Flop (STFF-I and STFF-II), implemented using unipolar amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) TFTs. The first-generation STFF-I DFF, fabricated and measured on glass and flexible substrates, achieves a 79.8% reduction in total power relative to a conventional design. The STFF-II DFF incorporates optimized feedback control to achieve full-swing static operation with reduced switching delay. The DTFF design uses dynamic bootstrap-assisted feedback to suppress direct-path current while maintaining a compact area. All circuits were benchmarked in simulation against prior TFT-based DFFs and evaluated in subsystem-level implementations, including a 3-bit counter, frequency divider, and TFT-based scan-chain structures. The proposed DTFF achieves up to 77% lower power and 69% lower Power-Delay-Product (PDP) than state-of-the-art designs. These results establish the DTFF, STFF-I, and STFF-II designs as compact, energy-efficient sequential building blocks for next-generation flexible and large-area electronics.

title: DRL-Based NFV Orchestration for Ultra-Low Latency Edge Applications
authors: Iqra Batool, Mostafa M. Fouda, Mohamed I. Ibrahem, Zubair Md Fadlullah
abstract: Ultra-low latency applications such as autonomous vehicles, industrial IoT, and augmented reality require end-to-end latency below 10 ms, necessitating intelligent placement of Network Function Virtualization (NFV) across the edge-cloud continuum. Current NFV orchestration approaches use static placement strategies that fail to adapt to dynamic network conditions and application mobility patterns, resulting in suboptimal latency performance. This paper presents a novel Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL)-based orchestration framework that dynamically places and migrates Virtual Network Functions (VNFs) to minimize end-to-end latency while maintaining service continuity. Our approach combines a Deep Q-Network (DQN) agent for placement decisions with a predictive migration mechanism that anticipates application demands. Experimental results on a real testbed demonstrate that our solution significantly outperforms existing static placement approaches in both latency reduction and resource utilization, enabling new classes of latency-critical applications in $5 \mathrm{G} / 6 \mathrm{G}$ networks.

title: Password Guessing Based on Hidden Weak Password Analysis
authors: Chenyang Wang, Min Zhang, Zhijie Xie, Shasha Guo, Yuliang Lu, Fan Shi, Yi Shen, Pengfei Xue
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: Password has become the mainstream method of authentication today. To improve password security, researchers evaluate the strength of target password datasets through early brute-force attacks to current password guessing methods, aiming to help users reduce the use of weak passwords. With users becoming more aware of security, they make local variations on weak passwords to improve the password strength while being easy to remember. These transformations render passwords more complex and enhance the score in password strength meter. However, such variations do not genuinely enhance password security, as human habits tend to converge. This allows attackers to deduce the modification patterns and consequently crack these passwords. Motivated by this, this paper defines the hidden weak passwords, a local variant of explicit weak passwords, which appear to enhance password security yet remain vulnerable. We systematically analyze transformation behavior between explicit and hidden weak passwords. Then we design an automated rule generation algorithm to identify hidden weak passwords and generate transformation rules. Based on automatically mined rules, we generate a large number of password guesses and fuses them with existing methods to improve password guessing performance. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method through password guessing experiments on eight real-world datasets, where the cracking rate improves on all five state-of-the-art methods.

title: Compact Dielectric Resonator Antenna for 5G Communication
authors: Turio Sinha, Navita Kumari, Vibha Rani Gupta
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper proposes a compact dielectric resonator antenna (DRA) with high gain for n79 band of 5G FR1 wireless communication. The square-shaped DRA is fed with conformal feed. A square metallic plate is placed at the top of the dielectric resonator, which helps in increasing the gain and reducing the size of the antenna. The final configuration of the proposed DRAs is analyzed using the commercially available full wave electromagnetic simulation tool CST Microwave Studio. The impedance bandwidth of the proposed antenna ranges from the frequency band 4.39 to 5.1 GHz, the n79 band of the 5G communication system. The peak gain of the antenna is 7.82 dBi, whereas the efficiency of the antenna is 97.82%.

title: Landslide Prediction Using AI Techniques and Satellite Imagery
authors: Boine Abhinaya, K. Shruthi, Pasam Ashok Kumar, Dudekula Roshni, Goli Naresh Reddy, M. Prasanna
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Landslides pose a significant risk to infrastructure, human lives, and environmental balance and hence robust pre-dictive models are essential for effective risk mitigation. This study gives a robust artificial intelligence (AI)-driven model for predicting landslides utilizing satellite images. Deep learning-based approach is employed to analyze important factors like topographical variation, soil characteristics, vegetation values, and weather conditions. Satellite images with high resolution are aggressively preprocessed to extract useful geospatial data, which is then integrated into a machine learning model to predict landslide. The proposed framework convolutional neural networks (CNNs) in combination with geospatial analytics to enhance prediction accuracy. Model performance is evaluated using previous landslide events and validated through quantitative metrics. Experimental results shows the efficiency of the proposed method in accurately identifying risk prone zones, thereby validates proactive disaster management policies. The research points out the application potential of geospatial analysis and disaster risk evaluation, facilitating the development of early warning systems and decision-making in landslide hazard-prone regions.

title: Unsupervised Segmentation Method for 3D Point Clouds in Underground Complex Environments
authors: Wenjie Zhang, Liya Dou, Mengting Liu, Haijiang Zhu
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: Underground environments present challenges for 3D point cloud segmentation, including complex structural characteristics and limited semantic annotations. To address these issues, this study introduces a novel unsupervised semantic segmentation framework for 3D point clouds. The proposed approach facilitates autonomous learning of semantic features through a progressive superpoint growth mechanism. During feature extraction, it incorporates an attention mechanism combined with a spatial pyramid architecture to improve the modeling and capture of global contextual information within intricate scenes. Additionally, a scene-aware superpoint construction strategy, specifically designed for underground point cloud data, is developed. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the method attains high-precision unsupervised semantic segmentation on both the publicly available Seg2Tunnel dataset and proprietary underground mine datasets. Importantly, it achieves a substantial enhancement in mean Intersection over Union (mIoU) on the public S3DIS dataset. These findings substantiate the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed approach for 3D point cloud segmentation in complex underground scenarios characterized by sparse annotations.

title: Towards Automated Materials Analysis: Multi-Scale Spatio-Spectral Approach for Registering Secondary Electron Hyperspectral Images
authors: Ali Alsari, Jingqiong Zhang, Nicholas T.H Farr, Cornelia Rodenburg, Lyudmila Mihaylova
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Secondary electron hyperspectral imaging (SEHI) is an emerging technique that allows experimental investigation of the chemical properties of material surfaces at the nanoscale. Despite advancements in automated image registration, registering SEHI images across different spatial scales remains a challenging task, and it is still typically performed manually in practice. Many image registration approaches often lead to inadequate registration in SEHI due to primarily focusing on spatial features, and do not capture the rich spectral information in SEHI. To fill in this gap, we propose a multi-scale spatio-spectral approach based on the scale-invariant feature transform (SIFT) to automate SEHI image registration. The main novelty of this work lies in the proposed multi-scale SIFT spatio-spectral descriptors that effectively integrate both the SIFT spatial descriptor and differentiate the spectral signal profile as a function of electron energy. A new spatio-spectral descriptor matching algorithm is designed, achieving accurate image registration, with an accuracy error of less than 0.44 pixels. Results over real SEHI datasets show that the proposed approach performs better than other state-of-the-art registration methods. Two performance metrics are used for evaluation, including normalized cross correlation (NCC) for examining spatial alignment and cosine similarity regarding spectral alignment. The results show that our proposed approach achieves good accuracy, with an NCC of above 82%, and a cosine similarity of over 93%. This work offers a promising solution for automated multi-scale image registration, which is an essential step for SEHI analysis tasks for material surface chemical composition and accelerating materials discovery.

title: Digital Design Techniques for IGZO-Based Circuits
authors: Sven Baerten, Yari Nowicki, Jelle Biesmans, Kris Myny
abstract: This paper explores two optimization strategies for digital circuits based on Indium-Gallium-Zinc-Oxide (IGZO) thin-film transistors (TFTs). The first method focuses on clock tree synthesis (CTS) and its impact on performance. To evaluate the effectiveness of CTS, a 32-bit counter incorporating a Brent–Kung adder was designed and fabricated. Implementing the clock tree improved the maximum operating frequency up to 50%. The second optimization strategy is a mixed standard-cell library that integrates both high-performance and low-power cells, using a two-stage resistor-load logic topology. The high-performance cells will be placed along the critical paths of the integrated circuits, while low-power cells will be used in non-critical areas. To validate this approach, two MOS 6502 microprocessor versions were developed: one with only highperformance cells, and another with the mixed library. Our findings indicate a threefold reduction in power consumption when employing the mixed library during the digital flow at comparable clock speeds. Additionally, we developed what is, to our knowledge, the fastest IGZO-TFT microprocessor reported to date, achieving a clock frequency of 295 kHz, and the lowest power-consuming microprocessor in this technology, marking the first IGZO-CPU to operate in the sub-mW range at 580 μW.

title: Distributed Nodes Detection and Event-Triggered Links Isolation of Stealthy Attacks in Multiagent Systems by Topology-Oriented Watermarking
authors: Changda Zhang, Jingbo Wang, Zhijie Li, Dajun Du, Changchun Hua
abstract: The communication links of multiagent systems (MASs) could be compromised by stealthy cyber attacks. To solve the problem, this paper proposes distributed nodes detection and event-triggered links isolation of stealthy attacks in MASs by topology-oriented watermarking (TOW). Firstly, the limitation of traditional MASs against distributed pole-dynamics attacks (dPDAs) is revealed. Secondly, different from existing water-marking methods for single-agent systems, a novel TOW method with four optional parameters selection schemes is proposed for distributed nodes detection in MASs, where it is proved that only one of optional parameters selection schemes can simultaneously possesses complexity and resistance to collusive dPDAs. Moreover, TOW combines the advantages of multiplicative and additive watermarking to achieve dPDAs detection. Furthermore, the positive relationship between dPDAs detection performance and the coupling factor of attack topology, attack signal and TOW parameters is quantified. Thirdly, a new TOW-based event-triggered links isolation algorithm incorporating multiple link-deletion observers is proposed, where TOW is leveraged to trigger running of link-deletion observers. It is proved that the compromised links can be correctly isolated. Finally, the simulation results verify our proposed scheme.
