title: Blockchain-Enabled Healthcare Optimization: Enhancing Security and Decision-Making Using the Mother Optimization Algorithm
authors: Santosh Reddy Addula, Yogesh Ramaswamy, Deepa Dawadi, Zabiha Khan, Praveen Veeramachaneni, Ashok Kumar Pamidi Venkata
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Blockchain technology is revolutionising healthcare data management with its decentralised ledger, which allows for safe transactions and transparent record-keeping. Better privacy protections are necessary, nevertheless, because patient information is very sensitive. By improving decision-making and facilitating safe, transparent, and efficient handling of medical data, the Mother Optimisation Algorithm (MOA) and blockchain technology are reshaping the healthcare industry. Data security, interoperability, and privacy protection are becoming more important issues due to the exponential growth in volume of sensitive patient data generated by the proliferation of digital healthcare systems and medical equipment based on the Internet of Things (IoT). Secure and transparent data sharing across healthcare providers is made possible using blockchain technology, which offers a decentralised, immutable, and tamper-proof ledger. This helps to avoid data breaches. The MOA also improves healthcare system efficiency by maximising the use of available resources for illness diagnosis and therapy suggestion optimisation. Better patient outcomes, lower operational costs, and more efficient use of medical resources are all results of healthcare predictive analytics that are enhanced by MOA's intelligent, adaptive problem-solving skills. Making decisions in real-time, streamlining medical workflows, and creating personalised treatment plans are all possible with the integration of MOA with blockchain-based healthcare systems. This creates an environment that is trustworthy, intelligent, and patient-centric. Further study is address obstacles such as computational complexity, scalability, and interaction with existing healthcare infrastructures, despite its advantages. To build a stronger, safer, and more efficient healthcare system, future developments should concentrate on optimising MOA's methods, making blockchains more scalable, and integrating AI-driven approaches. This strategy has the ability to revolutionise healthcare by making it safer, more data-driven, and patient-centered. As a result, medical services will be better and more accessible for people all over the world.

title: Machine Learning-Driven Intrusion Detection System for Enhanced Accuracy and Scalability
authors: Nara Vedavyass, Nali Sri Hari, T. Sasikala, G Nagarajan
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Intrusion detection systems (IDS) are critical for safeguarding networks against evolving cyber threats, but traditional solutions often face challenges such as high costs, integration difficulties, and inaccurate detection. This manuscript proposes a novel IDS framework that integrates machine learning techniques, including random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and long short-term memory (LSTM)-based anomaly detection, to address these limitations. The proposed system was evaluated using the NSL-KDD dataset in a simulated enterprise network environment, and its performance was measured using key metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, false positive rate (FPR), false negative rate (FNR), and response time. The results showed that LSTM outperformed RF and SVM with an accuracy of 97.2%, precision of 97.0%, recall of 98.1%, and F1-score of 97.5%. It also demonstrated the lowest FPR (1.9%) and FNR (2.1%) and the fastest response time (124 ms). RF followed closely with 96.2% accuracy and an F1-score of 95.9%, while SVM achieved 94.6% accuracy and 94.0% F1-score. The system's integration with tools like Snort and Suricata, coupled with real-time alert generation and a centralized dashboard, significantly improved the efficiency of incident response. The proposed IDS framework demonstrated a 13–17% increase in detection accuracy and a 40% reduction in false alerts compared to baseline systems, highlighting its effectiveness for real-time network security monitoring.

title: Agentic Recommender Systems: A Systematic Literature Review
authors: Ivens da Silva Portugal, Paulo Alencar, Donald Cowan
abstract: Recommender systems (RSs) are software systems that use machine learning techniques to suggest items, such as movies, products or routes to users based on input provided over time. These systems have been widely used by companies, such as Amazon, Google, and Netflix, who rely heavily on recommendations as a core element of their interaction with users. In the case of software engineering, RSs are used to recommend, for example, software tasks, developers, APIs, libraries, and bug fixes. More recently, advancements in natural language processing and large language models (LLMs) have led to the creation of LLM agents capable of generating plans, interacting with users and the environment, receiving feedback, and using tools. These developments have resulted in the use of LLM agents in RSs, giving rise to multi-agent RSs referred to as agentic recommender systems (ARSs). However, agentic RSs are not yet well characterized in terms of the basic elements of system modeling and design. This systematic literature review characterizes agentic recommender systems with respect to agents, roles, relationships, prompts, integration, use cases, strategies and evaluation methods. An analysis of published studies yields insights, such as (i) the identification of 13 distinct types of agents, (ii) the popularity of GPT models, (iii) a framework for ARSs, (iv) a generalized prompt, (v) the use of persona, cues, output format, and zero-shot prompting, (vi) the frequent use of Amazon, Yelp, and MovieLens datasets, (vii) the use of nDCG@k and Recall@k as common evaluation metrics, and (viii) the identification of many research gaps. This systematic literature review aims to support the continued research and development of agentic recommender systems.

title: Low-Elevation Estimation Method for Meter-Wave Array Radar in an Interference Environment
authors: Derui Tang, Yongbo Zhao, Dewu Wang, Zhuolin Li, Shuaijie Zhang, Chen Zhou
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Target low-elevation estimation is of great significance in the field of radar detection. However, as the current electromagnetic environment grows increasingly complex, interference significantly degrade the performance of radar angle estimation. To address this issue, this paper proposes a low-elevation estimation method for meter-wave array radar in interference environments: firstly, the multipath signals of both target and interference are fully considered and a refined model is constructed; secondly, based on the minimum variance distortionless response, interference samples are combined with the target’s composite steering vector to derive a weight vector that integrates both interference suppression and elevation estimation functions; finally, the target elevation is estimated using the idea of maximum likelihood estimation. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Aadptive Fault Control based on Non-singular Terminal Sliding Mode for Quadrotor UAV subject to Input Saturation Constraint
authors: Junhui Peng, Xiaoyu Shi, Zhang Sun, Shifu Gu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper presents an adaptive fault-tolerant control framework for quadrotor UAVs operating under coupled actuator faults, input saturation, and disturbances. By combining non-singular integral terminal sliding mode control with prescribed-time super-twisting algorithms, the framework ensures system convergence within a prescribed time independent of initial conditions while alleviating chattering effects. To mitigate the adverse impacts of partial loss-of-effectiveness faults and saturation-induced dead zones, Nussbaum-type adaptive gains compensate for unknown control effectiveness without requiring fault detection mechanisms. Prescribed-time stability is rigorously established via Lyapunov theory. Comparative simulations show that the proposed approach reduces tracking error by 60% relative to state-of-the-art adaptive sliding mode controllers, delivers superior transient performance with faster convergence, and exhibits stronger robustness against fault-saturation coupling, confirming its viability for safety-critical UAV applications.

title: Control-Communication Co-Design for Cloud&#x2013;Fog Automation over 5G-TSN: A Coupling Loop Method under Network Uncertainty_supp1-3653896.pdf
authors: Cailian Chen
abstract: The cloud–fog automation (CFA) paradigm accelerates Industry 4.0 by enabling fully automated industrial systems through interconnected wired and wireless devices. However, dynamic uncertainties such as environment-induced network delays and disturbances challenge the stability and efficiency of these systems. To address these issues, this paper proposes a control–communication co-design framework named C<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>L (Control– Communication Coupling Loop), which integrates 5G and Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) to coordinate transmission and control across cloud and fog layers. A hierarchical control strategy is introduced based on a delay threshold derived from Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) analysis, enabling dynamic selection between cloud and fog control units for both stability and responsiveness. To ensure timely and reliable control input delivery under uncertain networks, we develop a deterministic transmission mechanism centered on a novel metric, Packet Loss Tolerance (PLT), which quantifies how many consecutive losses the system can endure while maintaining stability. Additionally, a new optimization criterion, Pareto Deviation Value (PDV), is proposed to avoid combining control and communication costs with incompatible physical units. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method enhances control robustness and communication efficiency in complex industrial networks.

title: Optimizing Cancer Diagnosis with Image Classification
authors: Thandu Asha Latha, Niteesha Sharma, Y Sowjanya, J Nikhil Reddy, Erri Gopal Reddy, Tammu Manohar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Cancer diagnosis from scans has become as a main use of deep learning for medicine, which helps along with locating concerns earlier as well as improve treatments. We employed a MobileNetV3-based architecture for our cancer screening system, integrated within a Flask-React web application designed for efficient and rapid clinical use. We back several special cancer types including: brain, breast,lung & colon, lymphoma, cervical, kidney, and oral cancer. We give one special model to every single type. An enhanced confidence-based validation mechanism was implemented to ensure more accurate and reliable predictions. This scheme definitively excludes certain bad sorts by intensely denying poor forecasts and unfit tumor types, lessening the issue of false alarms. The system is well-designed in order to find, and to get rid of benign images, stopping any false positives. React aids in the user interface”s creation, giving a simple, useful platform for experts as well as for doctors. MobileNetV3 models, when thoroughly assessed, show adequate classifier accuracy for many cancer types. This work contributes to medical AI by improving cancer detection accuracy and ensuring robustness against irrelevant data.

title: Dynamic Ensemble Learning With Received Signal Strength Transformation for Robust Multi-Floor Wi-Fi Indoor Localization_supp1-3657332.txt
authors: PANARAT CHERNTANOMWONG
abstract: Received Signal Strength (RSS)-based Wi-Fi localization offers a cost-effective solution for multi-floor indoor location estimation. However, its accuracy is often degraded by signal fading, multipath propagation, and device heterogeneity, posing major challenges to reliable localization. Recent studies have increasingly employed deep neural networks due to their ability to extract meaningful patterns from RSS data; however, these models require substantial computational resources and extensive parameter tuning, which limits their adaptability across diverse dynamic environments. To address these limitations, we propose DELLoc-RT, a localization framework integrating Dynamic Ensemble Learning (DELLoc) with RSS Transformation (RT) for accurate, efficient, and adaptable multi-floor indoor localization. The RT module applies Sigmoid-scaled normalization and confidence weighting to convert RSS values into compact, learnable features. DELLoc employs multiple base learners optimized via the Tree-structured Parzen Estimator with a pruning strategy (TPE-PS) that accelerates convergence by focusing on promising configurations. Additionally, Iterative Ensemble Optimization with Stepwise Selection (IEO-SS) selects complementary learners to enhance overall performance. Experimental results demonstrate that DELLoc-RT achieves floor classification accuracies of 93.32%, 94.38%, and 94.02% on the UJIIndoorLoc, UTSIndoorLoc, and Tampere datasets, respectively, with mean Euclidean errors (MEE) of 10.63 m, 7.87 m, and 8.19 m. These results highlight the model’s strong adaptability across diverse datasets. Evaluation on a self-constructed dataset further confirms that DELLoc-RT delivers high accuracy and efficiency while substantially reducing the need for manual tuning, enabling rapid deployment in practical scenarios.

title: A Novel DS-GIN-DANN Approach: Limited-Sample Cross-Domain Recognition of Partial Discharge from Generator Stator Bars to PP Cables_supp1-3657739.docx
authors: Xiaosheng Peng
abstract: With the increasing deployment of polypropylene (PP) cables in power systems, early identification of partial discharge (PD) defects is critical for ensuring equipment reliability. However, as PP cables remain in the trial stage, defect samples from industrial sites are limited, making traditional recognition methods ineffective under limited-sample conditions. A limited-sample cross-domain recognition method for PD defects in PP cables is proposed in this paper, with the transfer recognition task from generator stator bar PD to PP cable PD being addressed. In the proposed framework, PD signals from generator stator bars and PP cables are collected as source- and target-domain data under typical defect scenarios. Phase-resolved PD (PRPD) patterns are constructed, and a deep synthetic minority oversampling technique (DeepSMOTE, DS) enhancement technique is applied to balance feature distribution among defect types in the target domain. A transfer framework combining graph isomorphism networks (GIN) and domain-adversarial neural networks (DANN) is then employed to improve graph feature representation and cross-domain adaptability. Experimental results show that the DS-GIN-DANN method achieves 90.25% accuracy at 64×64 resolution under limited-sample conditions, outperforming CNN-based transfer methods by 8.75%, effectively mitigating the problem of limited samples. Therefore, a new technical pathway for limited-sample recognition of PD defects in cable equipment is provided, with significant practical application value.

title: Trust in the Deep: a Survey on Authenticating Acoustic Underwater Communication
authors: Luisa Lux, Elmar Padilla, Jan Bauer
abstract: The increasing capabilities of underwater sensing and wireless networking have led to a growing range of applications in both civilian and military domains. As these underwater systems become more pervasive, the integrity of the collected sensor data - and consequently the authenticity of the communicating entities and the messages exchanged - becomes critical for ensuring trust in the data, its interpretation, and eventually in the envisioned concept of a transparent ocean. Over the past decade, various approaches have been proposed to ensure authentication in underwater acoustic communication, ranging from adaptations of traditional cryptographic mechanisms to novel physical-layer techniques tailored to the underwater environment. This paper provides an overview of these developments, systematically analyzing their advantages and limitations in light of the unique challenges posed by underwater acoustic communication.

title: A Subdomain-Consistent Robustness Evaluation Method for Time Series Forecasting Models
authors: Zixuan Gao, Yimeng He, Changqing Ye, Bingbing Shen, Xiaoyu Jiang
publish: 2025 9th International Symposium on Computer Science and Intelligent Control (ISCSIC)
abstract: This study proposes a novel framework for evaluating the robustness of time series forecasting models, centered on subdomain consistency assessment through the Subdomain Consistency Metric (SCM). We employ K-means clustering with objective quality metrics (Silhouette Coefficient and Davies-Bouldin Index) to partition time series datasets into balanced subdomains, then quantify model performance consistency across these subdomains using SCM. Furthermore, we systematically test model robustness under six realistic perturbation types including Gaussian noise, shift, trend, outlier, missing value, and time delay, analyzing their impact on SCM values. Our approach introduces a logarithmic scoring mechanism that provides standardized robustness assessment across different perturbation intensities and ratios. This framework not only evaluates global model performance but also emphasizes stability across subdomains, thereby offering a new perspective for understanding model generalization in complex, perturbed environments. Experimental results on the M4 dataset demonstrate that this evaluation framework effectively reveals model robustness characteristics, with LightTS, TSMixer, and MICN showing superior performance, providing valuable insights for practical model selection and deployment.

title: Joint Range-Angle Estimation Method for Sparse Terahertz Frequency Diverse Arrays Based on the MUSIC Algorithm
authors: Chongyang Xin, Qi Yang, Lepeng Zhang, Hongqiang Wang, Kaiyan Xu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Phase arrays (PA) are widely used in radar target detection due to their flexible spatial scanning capabilities. However, in the terahertz (THz) band, the higher frequency makes the fabrication of phase shifters difficult. To address this issue, the use of the frequency diverse array (FDA) radar was proposed in this paper. It is able to achieve spatial automatic scanning in the THz band without the phase shifter. This work also examines the range-angle coupling problem in target localization and the errors arising from the array configuration, including amplitude and phase errors, element position errors, and other factors. These analyses aim to improve the estimation accuracy of the position parameter. The proposed method is applied to experimental data obtained from a sparse THz-FDA and effectively restores the unique identifiability of the target. This work fills the gap in the application of THz-FDA and is of great significance to achieve the target positioning task using automatic scanning radar in THz band.

title: A Comparative Study of CRNN Architectures for CAPTCHA Recognition Using EfficientNet and CNN-LSTM Models
authors: Zain Javed, Muhammad Maaz Hamid, Raja Hashim Ali, Umme Rabab Syed
abstract: CAPTCHA systems are widely used to protect websites and online platforms from bots by presenting distorted text that is easy for humans but hard for machines to read. As automated attacks grow more advanced, there is a strong need for accurate and efficient CAPTCHA solvers that can help evaluate and improve these systems. However, many existing studies focus on a single model design without comparing the performance and complexity trade-offs between different deep learning architectures. This work fulfil that gap by evaluating two CRNN-based models for solving image-based CAPTCHA challenges. The first model uses EfficientNetB0 as a feature extractor followed by LSTM layers, while the second model uses a simpler architecture with two convolutional layers and LSTM blocks. Both models use the Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) loss function to find the variable-length text from CAPTCHA images. The results show that although the EfficientNet-based model achieves a bit higher accuracy but the simpler CNN-LSTM model trains faster and uses fewer resources. The comparison highlights the balance between accuracy, training efficiency, and model complexity. Both models performed well on real-world CAPTCHA data, showing their practical value. Overall, this study provides a useful comparison of two CRNN architectures and offers insights for designing effective and efficient CAPTCHA recognition systems.

title: Intelligent Traffic Management Using Anonymized Trajectory Data for Personal Multimodal Commuting Recommendations
authors: Gielians Jona, Seidel Tim, Westerkamp Clemens, Schaarschmidt Marco
abstract: Motorized private transport in cities with around 200,000 inhabitants, such as Osnabrück and Münster in northwest Germany, has increased over the years, leading to congested roads. To improve this situation, mobility data in the urban area is recorded and anonymized in an Urban Data Platform (UDP) of the municipality. In an Open Data approach, it combines existing official and publicly available data and allows to add new data sources from crowdsourcing projects. A digital traffic twin uses aggregated data to predict traffic congestion up to three days in advance. This way, commuters can adapt their commuting times, home office days, and change to public transport. In all sections of the UDP a collection of anonymization modules for depersonalization of commuting trajectories is used to protect commuters and other road users' privacy. The system was integrated on a traffic simulation basis and is currently being assessed. Early results from experiments with student groups and project partners are presented. In summer 2025, a large experiment with the public is planned to remove potential bias from the project results.

title: Synaptic Delay Plasticity and Temporal Attention Enhance Temporal Classification Capability of Spiking Neural Networks
authors: Hangming Zhang, Qiang Yu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Spiking Neural Networks (SNNs) are a novel event-driven computational model with great potential for handling temporal classification tasks, such as speech recognition. Research has shown that synaptic delay plasticity in SNNs can significantly enhance their expressive capabilities. However, traditional SNNs face numerous challenges when dealing with sparse, inhomogeneous, and noisy temporal classification data, which limits their performance. To address these challenges, we introduce a temporal attention mechanism into the synaptic delay plasticity of SNNs to enhance the ability of the model to capture critical temporal information. Specifically, we use extended convolution to learn delays and weights, and then apply the temporal attention mechanism along the temporal dimension to dynamically quantify the importance of different time steps. Our approach achieves accuracies of 96.21% and 80.87% on two benchmark temporal classification datasets, Spiking Heidelberg Digits and Spiking Speech Command, respectively, representing a significant improvement over traditional SNNs. These results validate that the integration of synaptic delay plasticity with the temporal attention mechanism enhances the temporal classification capability of SNNs and offers new perspectives for applying SNNs to temporal classification tasks.

title: A Multi-Scan Possibility GLMB Smoothing for Multi-Target State Estimation in the Context of Possibility Theory
authors: Chenghu Cao, Peiyuan Hui, Jiayao Han, Jing Jiang, Jiawei Huang, Haisheng Huang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: This paper considers the multi-target tracking problem under epistemic uncertainty. A multi-scan possibility generalized labeled multi-Bernoulli (GLMB) smoothing is proposed to eliminate track fragmentation and switching in scenario with unknown and time-varying detection profiles. The labeled uncertainty finite set (UFS) based on outer probability measure is introduced into multi-scan GLMB model for improved multitarget state estimation, resulting in a possibility-based analog of the conventional multi-scan GLMB smoothing process. The multi-scan possibility functions are capable to capture epistemic uncertainties arising from incomplete knowledge about detection profile. These prediction-update possibility functions are represented by the Gaussian max-mixture (GMM), facilitating the implementation of the multi-scan possibility GLMB recursion. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed multi-scan possibility GLMB smoothing yields better multi-target trajectories and cardinality estimation under epistemic uncertainty, especially in real-world applications.

title: Can we help them better? Planning an Intervention with the Support of a Learning Analytics Dashboard
authors: Jordi Cuadros, Vanessa Serrano, Unai Hernandez-Jayo, Javier Garcia-Zubia, Laura Fernández-Ruano, Judith Báguena
abstract: VISIR-DB is a teacher-facing learning analytics dashboard designed for VISIR, a remote laboratory for electrical and electronic circuits. With the recent transition from VISIR to HIVE-an updated platform that retains VISIR's trace collection capabilities-VISIR-DB has been enhanced to support HIVE-generated data. These advancements enable the use of VISIR-DB insights to inform and guide instructional interventions throughout a course. This study focuses on trace data from a module on DC circuit measurements. By applying multiple grading strategies, four distinct student groups were identified from their work in HIVE, and targeted teaching interventions are proposed based on these findings.

title: FLISBI: A Fast Linear Iterative Sparse Bayesian Inference for UAV Partial Discharge Localization
authors: Xiaobo Zhang, Chun Li, Jinchan Zhu, Xiaoxing Wei, Xiqing Yang, Maoheng Jing, Haijun Wang, Ping Wang
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: In aerial inspection of high-voltage power equipment, acoustic signals emitted by partial discharge (PD) are often severely interfered by environmental noise and unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) self-noise, which significantly degrades the accuracy and stability of sound source localization. Traditional methods, such as beamforming and subspace decomposition algorithms, suffer from poor resolution and low robustness under low signal-to-noise ratio conditions. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a Fast Linear Iterative Sparse Bayesian Inference (FLISBI) algorithm. Based on the conventional Sparse Bayesian Inference (SBI) framework, the proposed method introduces a linearized covariance update strategy that eliminates the need for matrix inversion, thereby improving computational efficiency while maintaining noise robustness. Utilizing a UAVmounted acoustic sensor array, experiments were conducted in complex noisy environments to evaluate the proposed approach. Results demonstrate that the FLISBI algorithm achieves superior localization accuracy and robustness within a fixed number of iterations, outperforming existing methods and showing strong potential for practical deployment in power equipment inspection tasks.

title: A Transformer-Based Deep Learning Model for Arabic Image Captioning
authors: Israa Al Badarneh, Bassam H. Hammo, Omar Al-Kadi
abstract: Image captioning is a crucial process that connects text to images. Transformer-based deep learning models have successfully created captions, especially for Arabic. This paper introduces the Attention-Based Transformer Model for Arabic Image Captioning (ARTIC), which uses a deep learning convolutional neural network for feature extraction and a transformer encoder-decoder architecture for textual captions. The model uses an ensemble learning approach with a voting mechanism to select the caption with the highest bilingual evaluation understudy (BLEU) score. The model achieved the best BLEU-1, CIDEr, and ROUGE scores, while other metrics like BLEU-2 and METEOR achieved competitive rates.

title: Anomaly detection in Internet of Things-based healthcare: An approach based on improved proximal support vector machine
authors: Omar Farshad Jeelani
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent and Cloud Computing (ICoICC)
abstract: Incorporating IoT in the medical field immensely promotes patient care efficiency and effectiveness and reduces the cost-effectiveness of healthcare processes. IoT devices play a critical role in early disease detection and monitoring of significant symptoms, harvesting medical information, and processing it with algorithms in offsite servers. Despite its numerous advantages, IoT devices have no exceptions when it comes to cybersecurity vulnerabilities that can leak patient information and jeopardize the security of the entire system. In this article, a complex model is proposed for improving efficiency in anomalous network activity detection, particularly in handling imbalanced distribution of classes and hyperparameter sensitivities. We introduce a novel approach, the imbalanced maximizing area under the curve (AUC) proximal support vector machine (ImAUC-PSVM), improving the traditional PSVM by directly including AUC optimization in its main goal. This change simplifies the structure of the model and reduces the need for numerous hyperparameter adjustments, making it highly effective for training on datasets with skewed class distributions. The theoretical basis for the ImAUC-PSVM is that it retains all meaningful aspects of traditional PSVM and extends its adaptability to update its performance promptly, a key consideration for efficient anomaly detection. In addition, we use the Bayesian optimization hyperband (BOHB) algorithm for meticulous hyperparameter fine-tuning of our model. On testing with the NSL-KDD and MAWI datasets, our model reaches an average F-measure of 87.050% and 89.089%, respectively, and validates its high performance in various IoT anomaly detection scenarios.

title: Should Benevolent Deception Be Allowed in EHMI? A Mechanism Explanation Based on Game Theory
authors: Linkun Liu, Jian Sun, Ye Tian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: The application of external human–machine interface (EHMI) on autonomous vehicles (AVs) facilitates information exchange. Existing research fails to consider the impact of the sequence of actions, as well as the effects of EHMI applications and deception, raising the question of whether benevolent, well-intentioned deception should be permitted (i.e., misleading statements that are intended to benefit both parties). We established a game theory based EHMI information disclosure framework for AVs in this study. In considering benevolent deception, this framework divided the decision-making process into three stages, respectively encompassing three key questions: whether to disclose, when to disclose, and what type of intention information to disclose. The results show that theoretical advantages of deception exist in certain cases when AV expects to maximize the safety of the interaction. In 40 out of 484 cases (8.3%), safety can be enhanced through successful deception. Those successful deceptions fall into two categories: 1) In 28 of these cases, the straight-going AV expected the left-turning human-driven vehicle (HV) to yield, while HV exhibited lower speed and higher acceleration; 2) In 12 of these cases, AV expected HV to proceed first, while HV exhibited higher speed and lower acceleration. We also conducted a VR-based driving simulation experiment, and the results confirmed our conclusion. Additionally, we found that when participants had low trust in the EHMI, its use negatively impacted interaction efficiency instead. This study serves as an exploratory behavioral mechanism study based on specific hypotheses for future EHMI design and ethical decision-making of autonomous driving system.

title: Attention is All You Need for Boosting Graph Convolutional Neural Network
authors: Yinwei Wu, Xingyi Yang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Machine Intelligence and Nature-Inspired Computing (MIND)
abstract: Graph Convolutional Networks (GCNs) effectively integrate topological structure and node features for learning on non-Euclidean data. They have been widely applied in domains such as recommendation systems, social networks, and molecular biology. As GCNs grow in complexity, enhancing their performance while reducing model size has become a key research focus. This paper proposes a plug-in module, Graph Knowledge Enhancement and Distillation Module (GKEDM), which improves node representations through multi-head attention aggregation and enables efficient knowledge transfer via attention-based distillation. GKEDM boosts GCN performance with minimal computational overhead and facilitates the compression of large teacher GCN models into compact student models. Experiments on multiple benchmarks validate the module's effectiveness in both performance enhancement and distillation tasks.

title: Early Detection of Breast Tumour Using Bi-Static Microwave Imaging with Tapered Slot Vivaldi Antenna
authors: Sharmeen Sultana, Neela Chattoraj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: This paper introduces a Bi-Static Microwave Imaging System for medical applications, specifically for breast tumour detection. We present a novel Ultrawideband (UWB) Vivaldi antenna enabling early-stage breast tumour detection with un-precedented resolution, detecting tumours as small as 5 mm. This compact antenna (48mm x 40mm x 0.8mm) operates from 2–15 GHz, achieving a maximum gain of 14.98 dBi at 2.5 GHz. The bistatic radar concept enhances detection accuracy, while the low-cost FR4 substrate ensures affordability. The imaging system consists of a fixed source and receiving antenna, with a phantom model placed in between. The end-fire radiation pattern makes the antenna suitable for radar and microwave imaging. Simulation results using HFSS analyze the S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</inf> parameter to detect tumour presence. A breast phantom model mimics actual human breast properties.

title: SAR Ship Target Multi-Scale Detection Based on DiffusionDet
authors: Mingyao Chen, Tianpeng Liu
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) enables all-weather and all-day imaging, playing a critical role in military and civilian applications. Ship detection, as a fundamental task in SAR image interpretation, supports downstream applications including attitude estimation and target tracking. Although existing methods address multi-scale ship detection through traditional strategies like Constant False Alarm Rate (CFAR) or deep learningbased feature fusion architectures, they often suffer from limited robustness in complex scenarios (e.g., ports and nearshore areas) and high computational complexity. Recently, diffusion models have shown remarkable potential in generative tasks by learning data distributions through iterative noise addition and denoising. Inspired by DiffusionDet, which formulates object detection as a reverse diffusion process, this paper proposes a novel multiscale SAR ship detection method based on a diffusion model. During training, our model learns to recover ground-truth boxes from noised versions via a Markov chain. At inference, it detects ships of various scales directly from random boxes without anchor-based priors. To mitigate false alarms on land, we further introduce a segmentation-derived land-sea mask as structural prior knowledge. Extensive experiments on SAR ship datasets demonstrate that our method achieves competitive accuracy and robustness across diverse marine environments, offering a new perspective for scalable and efficient SAR target detection.

title: MACSDE:Multi-Head Autocorrelated Convolutional Squeeze Densely-Connected Encoder for Alzheimer’s Volumetric Biomarker Prediction
authors: Sonali Deshpande, Nilima Kulkarni
abstract: Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that manifests with subtle structural changes in key brain regions, often occurring years before clinical symptoms appear. Early and accurate identification of volumetric biomarkers, such as the hippocampus, entorhinal cortex, and ventricles, from MRI scans is essential for timely diagnosis and monitoring disease progression. However, existing deep learning models primarily focus on classification tasks and often fail to capture the region-specific anatomical nuances necessary for precise volumetric estimation. To address this limitation, we propose a novel hybrid architecture,MACSDE (Multi-head Autocorrelated Convolutional Squeeze Densely-connected Encoder), which combines spatially-aware multi-head correlated convolution with dense connectivity and attention-based recalibration. This architecture is designed to capture region-specific features, enhance inter-regional interactions, and prioritize Alzheimer-relevant channels for accurate volumetric predictions. The model incorporates a brain-wide feature extraction layer, a cognitive integration module, and a regression block tailored for volumetric output. Extensive experiments conducted on benchmark MRI datasets demonstrate the superior performance of MACSDE. Our results show that MACSDE achieves a 15% reduction in MAE, a 20% improvement in RMSE, and significantly higher correlation scores compared to existing methods. Specifically, the model outperforms state-of-the-art approaches like MRNN, PLSTM-Z, and Deep RNN, which show MAE values of 0.143, 0.305, and 0.059, respectively, while MACSDE reduces this to 0.0508. Similarly, RMSE improves from 3.951 (MRNN) and 2.929 (PLSTM-Z) to 1.125 for MACSDE, showing enhanced consistency in biomarker volume prediction. MACSDE offers competitive, state-of-the-art volumetric AD biomarker prediction performance in the 2024-2025 literature, as demonstrated by comparisons with recent advanced architectures.

title: Quality Factor and BER Estimation Using Artificial Neural Networks
authors: Dhirendra Kumar Jha, Jitendra K. Mishra
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: An ultra-fast approach based on deep learning (DL) is introduced for the accurate prediction of dispersion compensation in optical transmission systems. This method provides an alternative to conventional time-consuming and high-complexity communication system techniques by implementing artificial neural networks (ANNs). Existing knowledge is efficiently utilized, and new insights are gained through the development of a specific algorithm designed to perform the required tasks. The study combines transmission setup with ANN techniques to predict the Q-factor and minimum bit error rate (BER) in an dispersion compensation systems. The ANN-based algorithms demonstrate the capability to accurately predict critical properties of a system. This research contributes to the advancement of DL-based optimization techniques in optical fiber communication systems.

title: Brain Tumor Detection and Identification with Advanced Deep Learning Techniques
authors: Patturi Ankitha, S. Charan, N. Manikanta, A Anitha, B. Varshith, G. Sekhar Reddy
publish: 2025 International Conference on Communication and Smart Devices (ICCoSD)
abstract: Prompt identification and diagnosis of a brain tumor improves the patient's prognosis and medicinal options. Brain cancers can be seen and diagnosed using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Nevertheless, the clinical practice of manually identifying brain tumors from a huge number of MRI images is entirely dependent on the time and expertise of medical professionals. Computer-aided expert systems are currently in high demand for helping with medical diagnostic and therapy suggestions. Many frameworks based on deep learning and machine learning are used to detect brain tumors. The purpose of this paper is to develop an effective deep learning framework for brain tumor segmentation and classification. The MRI scans are volumetrically segmented using the 3D-UNet model, and CNNs are then used to classify the tumor. The models' validity is demonstrated by the presentation of the loss and precision diagrams. The effectiveness of the suggested models is evaluated, and the outcomes are contrasted with those of alternative strategies documented in the literature. The suggested work is determined to be more effective than the most advanced methods.

title: TextMonkey: an OCR-Free Large Multimodal Model for Understanding Document
authors: Yuliang Liu, Biao Yang, Qiang Liu, Zhang Li, Zhiyin Ma, Shuo Zhang, Xiang Bai
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: We present TextMonkey, a large multimodal model (LMM) tailored for text-centric tasks. Our approach introduces enhancement across several dimensions: By adopting Shifted Window Attention layer, we achieve cross-window connectivity at higher input resolutions and stabilize early training; We hypothesize that images may contain redundant tokens, and by using similarity to filter out significant tokens, we can not only streamline the token length but also enhance the model's performance. Moreover, by expanding our model's capabilities to encompass text spotting and grounding, and incorporating positional information into responses, we enhance interpretability. Evaluation on 12 benchmarks shows notable improvements: 5.2% in Scene Text-Centric tasks (including STVQA, TextVQA, and OCRVQA), 6.9% in Document-Oriented tasks (such as DocVQA, InfoVQA, ChartVQA, DeepForm, Kleister Charity, and WikiTableQuestions), and 2.8% in Key Information Extraction tasks (comprising FUNSD, SROIE, and POIE). It outperforms in scene text spotting with a 10.9% increase and sets a new standard on OCRBench, a comprehensive benchmark consisting of 29 OCR-related assessments, with a score of 561, surpassing previous open-sourced large multimodal models for document understanding. Code is released at https://github.com/Yuliang-Liu/Monkey.

title: An improved Wavelength Modulation Spectroscopy based on Natural Logarithm and Hilbert Transform for Oxygen Detection within Pharmaceutical Vials
authors: Yibo Wang, Chunhua Yang, Qiwu Luo, Mingrui Li, Weihua Gui
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Tunable diode laser absorption spectroscopy (TDLAS) based on wavelength modulation spectroscopy (WMS) is widely used for gas concentration measurement due to its rapid detection, high accuracy, and non-destructive nature. However, traditional WMS produces unreliable results for residual oxygen detection in pharmaceutical vials due to laser attenuation caused by glass walls. Although advanced methods such as ln-WMS and WMS-2f/f attempt to overcome this limitation, they suffer from algorithmic inflexibility or high computational cost. This paper introduces ln-Hilbert-WMS, an improved technique that integrates natural logarithm processing with the Hilbert transform. This method effectively isolates gas absorption components from laser intensity variations while simultaneously enabling harmonic extraction, laser intensity elimination, and offset noise suppression. A detection system for oxygen within pharmaceutical vials is established for validation. Experimental results demonstrate that the method can accurately measure the oxygen concentration without being affected by variations in vial transmittance. Furthermore, comparative analysis under different offset-noise conditions, together with FPGA implementation results, shows that the proposed method provides greater algorithmic generality than ln-WMS while requiring lower computational cost than WMS-2f/f. In pharmaceutical vial testing, ln-Hilbert-WMS achieves the best detection performance, with a standard deviation of 0.45% and an RMSE of 0.51%, outperforming traditional WMS, ln-WMS, and WMS-2f/f techniques.

title: Resource Allocation Strategy for Satellite Communication Anti-Jamming Enabled by Collaborative Multiagent Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xinghai Li, Yifan Tan, Yubing Han
publish: 2025 17th International Conference on Signal Processing Systems (ICSPS)
abstract: With the intensification of electronic countermeasures and the complex electromagnetic environment, antijamming is the bottleneck problem to guarantee the performance of satellite communications. In the face of dynamic and diverse jamming environment, a multi-domain resource allocation method for satellite communication anti-jamming is proposed based on reinforcement learning. The satellite communication efficiency is maximized by jointly considering several anti-jamming strategies such as channel, time slot and transmitting power. The multi-domain anti-jamming decision model is established, and a collaborative multi-agent layered Deep Q-Learning (MALDQN) algorithm for this model is proposed, which can reduce the dimensions of action space and state space. Compared with existing methods, the simulation results show the effectiveness and better performance of this algorithm subjected to different jamming strategies.

title: Quantum Infused Multi-Modal Sentiment Analysis of Low Resourced Language
authors: Muzammal Hussain, Waheed Yousuf Ramay, Ali Raza
abstract: We introduce a quantum-enhanced multimodal framework for Urdu sentiment analysis that integrates classical feature extractors with a variational quantum circuit (VQC) classifier. Raw text, audio, and visual signals are first processed by a cross-modal transformer to produce a unified embedding. These fused embeddings are then angle-encoded into a parameterized quantum state on a noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) processor. The VQC's trainable rotation gates are optimized via simultaneous perturbation stochastic approximation (SPSA) under realistic hardware-inspired noise models. Evaluated on UMSA-U, a curated dataset of 6,000 Urdu video clips with aligned transcripts, audio, and facial-expression annotations, our quantum-enhanced model achieves 84.2% overall accuracy and a macro-F1 score of 81.7% improving over both the classical cross-modal baseline (82.4%/79.6%) and a purely classical MLP head (83.1%/80.8%). Ablation studies demonstrate that quantum feature encoding yields more separable decision boundaries, and noise-robust SPSA tuning sustains performance on simulated hardware error rates up to 5%. These results showcase the promise of variational quantum classifiers for low-resource, multimodal language tasks and set a new benchmark for Urdu sentiment understanding on NISQ devices.
